title: Weicker Refuses to Support More WagePrice Cohtrols
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he could never again vote for any wage or price controls.

title: Boyle Improves, Is Moved From Intensive Care Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) W. A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers, was in satisfactory condition at George Washington Hospital today and was moved to a private room from the intensive care unit.

title: In Saigon, a House for Gracious Living Combines the Best of East and West
description: SAIGON, South VietnamA stone's throw from the United States Embassy, hidden by high walls, is a house built as a haven from the ubiquitous guardposts, sandbag protectives and rusting barbed wire of Saigon. In present  day Vietnam, it's rather uniqueit's a building designed for gracious living.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Faded denim lined in sable. Quilted gabardine lined in nutria. Knitted borders on mink or sable. Seal with stitched antelope collar and cuffs. A marmotlined safari jacket. Diamondquilted Russian broadtail edged in fox.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Drivers for the New York, Keansburg and Long Branch bus company struck the line, forcing 3,000 Monmouth County commuters to find other ways to get to work. The strike began after the union was told that negotiations, aided by a Federal mediator, could not begin until Oct. 8

title: Falling Slab Kills Driver
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (UPI)A 1,400pound slab of granite fell 32 stories yesterday and crushed a Minnesota truck driver at the site of the new Northern Trust Bank building in downtown Chicago. The dead man was identified as Harry A. Cash, 28 years old, of Minn.

title: Bridge: For Outdated Psychic Bid There Are Realistic Uses
description: Outright psychic bids, such as an opening with 10 points less than the normal minimum, had some popularity in the thirties and again, in a systemic version, in the fifties. They have been virtually abandoned by modern experts, who find that the partnership uncertainty engendered by the psychics is too high a price to pay for an occasional triumph.

title: A Silent Voice
description: With an eloquence that bespeaks sincerity, expressions of concern for the rights of free men are issuing daily at the United Nations from statesmen of the West.

title: Of Witches and Pagans, Female
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.I had a somewhat epochal Sunday recently. In the morning I attended a Holy Communion service at a Lutheran church celebrated by a woman priest. I was jarred and moved. Words I had heard a thousand times beforeblood, bread, bodyall seemed to take on a more vibrant meaning. I came away with whole new attitude toward the ordination of women: they should become priests not because they are no different from men, but because they are different.

title: Personal Finance
description: In all the columns of financial figures published each day in newspapers, no other category seems to leave so many readers perplexed as the quotations of bonds of the United States Government and its agencies. Whenever rates reach high ground, as they did in September, the perplexity spreads.

title: 102 Banks and Loan Units Said to Mislead on Rates
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 30The New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit student corporation affiliated with Ralph Nader, charges that 102 New Jersey banks and loan companies have violated the Federal Truth in Lending Act by quoting misleading interest rates in response to consumer inquiries. Out of 254 banks and loan companies surveyed, 76 banks and 26 loan companies, or 40 per cent, seem to be deliberately confusing the consumer by illegally quoting a hodgepodge of numbers, said Christopher Burke, the group's research coordinator.

title: ANALYSTS DEBATE TREND FOR RATES
description: When the Federal Reserve made a subtle move 10 days ago to indicate an end to its policy of increasingly tight credit, the money and capital markets picked up the scent like bloodhounds and chased interest rates into vigorous retreat.

title: COLLEGE SYSTEM CALLED LIMITED
description: The country's present system of posthigh school education favors a relative minority of young middleclass students and neglects the growing needs for education and training among older and working people, according to the latest report from the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education.

title: Work Will Begin Today On West Side Highway
description: Mayor Lindsay reminded motorists yesterday that the southbound lanes of the West Side Highway below 48th Street would be closed for a threemonth period beginning at 10 A.M. today.

title: Ohioans Wed in Klan Robes
description: LEWISBURG, Ohio, Sept. 30 (UPI)The bride and bridegroom each wore Ku Klux Klan robes and hoods as they exchanged marriage vows last night in a field south of this community. The ceremony featured a burning cross. Marvin Miller, 43 years old, took Clarice Hill 37 for his bride. Both are from the Columbus area.

title: Miss Kalmus Bride Of Donald Partier
description: Miss Susan Jane Kalmus, daughter of Allan H. Kalmus and Mrs. Richard Deneau, both of New York, was married here yesterday to Donald W. Partier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Partier of San Francisco. Dr. Algernon Black, leader emeritus of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the bride's apartment.

title: 8 Killed in CarVan Crash
description: HICKORY, N.C., Sept. 30 (AP) A bridetobe, four members of her wedding party and three other persons were killed in an autovan collision late last night, the State Highway Patrol said. The victims were listed as Ruby Penley Delvechio, 37 years old, of Newton, N.C., the bridetobe; Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Edwards of Hickory and Mr. and. Mrs. C. W. Williams of Hendersonville, N.C. Killed in the van were Leroy King of Louisville, Ky.; Clarence Smith of Bunnell, Fla., and Ben Brown of East St. Louis, Ill., all migrant workers.

title: NARCOTIC ARRESTS DROP 75% IN CITY
description: Only onequarter as many felony drug arrests were made in the city in Septemberthe first month under the state's new stringent drug laws  as in the average month of 1972, according to police statistics.

title: U.A.W.DEERE PACT AVERTS A WALKOUT
description: MOLINE, Ill., Sept. 30 (UPI) The United Auto Workers and Deere & Company, one of the nation's three major implement makers, agreed today on a new contract, averting a walkout that had been set for midnight.

title: Pro Hockey Exhibition
description: NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE

title: WILLIAM J. M'COVERN
description: William J. McGovern, a vice president of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., investment bankers and brokers, died Saturday of a heart attack in Hempstead, L. I. He was 51 years old and lived in Old Bethpage, L.I.

title: Browns T op Giants, 1210 On 4 Cockroft Field Goals
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 30  The New York Giants playoff express, running in high gear only three weeks ago, was slowed, if not completely stopped for the season today in a 1210 loss to the Cleveland Browns.

title: Bills Upset Jets, 9 to 7, On 3 Kicks
description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., Sept. 30With O. J. Simpson ripping through the Jets' defensive line and Earl Edwards bursting through the Jets' offensive line, the Buffalo Bills scored a stunning 97 victory today on three field goals by John Lepoldt.

title: 100,000 Soviet Lecturer's Are Instructed to Battle Western Ideas
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30  Moscow's small army of party propagandists, 100,000 strong, fanned out through the Soviet capital today to wage aggressive, uncompromising battle against Western ideas at a time of international dtente.

title: Boston Shop Owner Killed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The owner of a Dorchester dress shop became Boston's 91st homicide victim of the year. Samuel Alsen, 55 years old, of Milton, was shot and killed in the apparent robbery of his, shop, Eileen's Fashions.

title: Vikings Top Packers in Power Test
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 30The winning team had the quarterback aid the losing team did not today as the Minnesota Vikings beat the Green Bay Packers, 113, in a contest of suspense that embraced all the entertainment values of football except a touchdown.

title: China Celebrates 24th Anniversary With Firecrackers
description: PEKING, Sept. 30 (Reuters) China's National Day celebrations marking the 24th anniversary of the establishment of the Communist government in Peking got under way officially tonight with a reception for 1,500 people in the glittering banquet hall of the capital's Great Hall of the People.

title: Bodies of 8 of 11 Are Recovered In Plane on Arkansas Mountain
description: MENA, Ark., Sept. 30 (AP)Eight bodies were recovered tonight from the wreckage of a Texas International plane, missing since Thursday, that slammed into a mountainside near here, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board said.

title: Mass for Auden Wednesday
description: A solemn requiem mass for W. H. Auden will be offered at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Wednesday at 8 P. M. Poets who were friends of the Britishborn poet, who died Friday in Vienna, are expected to participate in the service.

title: LOVE SEES RISE IN GASOLINE PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) The Presidential energy adviser, former Gov. John A. Love of Colorado, said today he believed all gasoline price controls would be lifted soon and that costs to the consumer could rise 10 to 15 per cent within the coming year.

title: Hartford Ballet Season Opens With 2 Premieres
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30The Hartford Ballet Company opened its fall season yesterday at the handsome Millard Auditorium.

title: Jews Protest in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (UPI) Some 1,500 British Jews marched to the residence of the Austrian Ambassador toclay to present a petition asking Austria not to close transit facilities for Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel.

title: Film Festival: Frawley's 'Kid Blue,' a Western:Dennis Hopper Stars as Unlucky Robber Polish 'Illumination' ComedyTries Too Hard, Lacks Spontaneity
description: "Kid Blue," which was shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center Saturday night and again yesterday evening, is an American Western set at the turn of the century in the tiny but go-getting Texas town of Dime Box, about a train robber named Kid Blue (Dennis Hopper), who tries unsuccessfully to go straight.Rampant capitalism, in the form of the town's Great American Ceramic Novelty Company, and Puritan morality, as defined by Sheriff ("Mean Bob") Simpson (Ben Johnson), eventually force Kid Blue again to take up the life of crime at which he never was any great shakes in the first place."Kid Blue" is the sort of movie that is likely to sound a lot better than it really is. It's nice to hear about a Western that begins, as "Kid Blue" does, with a carefully planned train hold-up that doesn't even succeed in stopping the train. Inept bandits are usually funny. So are bogus preachers and the innocence of solid citizens who don't recognize a high-class whore when they meet her.Yet "Kid Blue" is never very funny or provocative. It tries too hard. It's too insistent. Like the performance of Mr. Hopper (who is getting a bit long in the tooth to play naifs with much conviction), "Kid Blue" is a heavily mannered work, with little or no sense of the spontaneous gaiety that one got from time to time in Eliot Silverstein's "Cat Ballou."One has the feeling that James Frawley, the director, and Edwin Shrake, who wrote the screenplay, are good-hearted but essentially humorless men, incapable of constructing any kind of comfortable bridges between the film's would-be comic and melodramatic sequences. When Warren Oates, as Kid Blue's best friend, starts to talk admiringly of "the old-time Greeks" who went bare-of clothes, one cringes in the anticipation of the about-to-be-delivered folksy wisdom, with which the movie is unspontaneously stuffed."Kid Blue" is a well-meaning, liberal, anti-fascist Western, dressed up with some good performances by Peter Boyle, Lee Purcell and Janice Rule. But it's not a very good movie.

title: Baltimore Responds To Officer's Death With Shotgun Squad
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 30The Baltimore police department has adopted a militant approach to the growing number of attacks on policemen by forming a special shotgun squad to respond to crimes in which guns are used.

title: Jersey Delays in Setting Policy For Abortions Under Medicaid
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30Eight months after the United States Supreme Court limited state regulation of abortions, New Jersey has still not drawn up guidelines that would make financially poor women who elect to end a pregnancy on a doctor's advice eligible for Medicaid payments.

title: OUTPUT OF VITAMINS UNDER RESTRICTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Further production of superstrength Vitamin A and D products labeled for nonprescription use is barred by new Federal regulations taking effect at midnight.

title: PROFITS ON COCOA ELUDE GHANAIANS
description: KITASE, Ghana  The farmers of Ghana, who produce almost a third of the world's cocoa, have watched the world price rise from $1,392 a ton in June to $2,304 in August, then fall back to $1,752. They have watched, but they have not profited.

title: Burma, to Help Economy, Is Ending Isolation Policy
description: RANGOON, BurmaThe Burmese Government, seeking to bolster a crumbling economy, is ending a 10year policy of isolation.

title: Tap on Halperin Continued After He Joined Muskie
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 30A national security wiretap authorized by President Nixon and placed on an assistant to Henry A. Kissinger remained in effect after the assistant, Morton H. Halperin, left the Nixon Administration and joined the campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, at the time Mr. Nixon's chief Democratic rival.

title: Houk Resigns
description: Ralph Houk, who had two years left on his contract, resigned yesterday as manager of the Yankees after the final game at Yankee Stadium, which will be rebuilt over the next two years. Houk gave a tearful farewell to his players.

title: Circus Elephant Executed By Police in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Tyler, a 14yearold performing elephant with Ringling Brothers, Barnum & Bailey Circus was executed here tonight because, her trainer said, she had lost her fear of people.

title: Black Caucus to Join Foes To Achieve Political Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Congressional Black Caucus leaders emerged early today from daylong strategy meetings with a commitment to form coalitions, even with those traditionally regarded as enemies of black people, to promole the interests of black Americans.

title: Minor Quake Strikes Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30 (UPI)A minor earthquake, centered 60 miles east of here, struck Japan's Pacific coast today, causing minor damage and no injuries. The Government's meteorological agency said that in Choshi, a port city, the tremor registered 4 on a scale of 7.

title: U.S. Issues Report
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Soviet Union appears headed for a record grain harvest this year, although excessive rain in some areas may have reduced the crop, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Whippet Is Named Best At Westbury Dog Show
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 30A 6yearold brindle and white whippet, Ch. Winterfold's Bold Bid, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Butt of Honeybrook, Pa., found the going to her liking and came up a winner at the 51st Westbury Kennel Association show on the grounds of C. W. Pot College today.

title: Hoffa Thinks He Can Win Reinstatement of Union Role
description: WESTPORT, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)James R. Hoffa, the former teamsters, president, said here today that he thought he could get the court ban on his union activities overturned.

title: Japan's External Reserves Declined During September
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Japan's external reserves declined by $331million during September to. $14.8billion at the end of the month, the Finance Ministry announced.

description: Assemblyman Calvin Williams of Brooklyn was arrested yesterday for allegedly bribing the driver of a gypsy cab to drop charges of assault, robbery and auto theft against Mr. Williams's21year old son.

description: MAILLARDVILLE, British Columbia, Sept. 21Mrs. Alma Langlois, who grew up here in a house where the use of French was the rule, even among playmates, tries hard to offer her five children the same encouragement.

description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, Sept 30 (AP)Sam Adams, a lefthander, shot a 68 today and captured the $100,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament by three strokes with a 72hole total of 268.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile Sept. 30  Chile's Roman Catholic bishops have offered to cooperate with the ruling junta in tile reconstruction of the country, but there is deep malaise in church circles over the continuing violence and the authoritarian actions of the military since it seized power nearly three weeks ago.

description: FICTION

title: TV: Fred Wiseman's Juvenile Court, a Portrait
description: Juvenile Court is Fred Wiseman's latest portrait of an American institution. Produced for WNETTV, it will be shown on the Public Broadcasting Service tonight at 8 o'clock. Shot in black and white, the film runs for just under 2 hours.

title: Austrian in the Middle
description: VIENNA, Sept. 30As has often happened in his extensive political career, the urbane Federal Chancellor of Austria once again finds himself a man in the middle.

title: Dave Anderson
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30In the sunshine of the first inning, Henry Aaron stepped up out of the Atlanta Braves' dugout onto his stage. At last, needing one home run to equal Babe Ruth's record of 714, he had attracted 40,517 spectators to Atlanta Stadium today for his final game of the season. The atmosphere had changed. In the imminence of history, a big crowd finally had surrounded him, but Henry Aaron hadn't changed. He never deviated from his ritual. When he appeared, he was holding his blue batting helmet in his left hand. In his right hand was his white bat. When he knelt on his right knee in the ondeck circle, he looked out at Dave Roberts, a lefthanded pitcher for the Houston Astros, while he dropped his helmet on the grass and picked up the brown weighted bat. Quickly, he swung the two bats together. Then, his cheeks slightly puffed, he let out a deep breath. It was his only apparent surrender to tension in the afternoon that ended in a downpour, that ended with his lifting his batting average to 301 with three singles, but that ended without the home run, Babe Ruth's record has endured for 38 years, and now it will endure for six more months.

title: Plan to Base U.S. Carrier Prompts Marches in Japan
description: YOKOSUKA, Japan, Sept. 30 (AP) Thousands of union members and students demonstrated today against American plans to make the. United States Navy base at Yokosuka the home port of the aircraft carrier Midway.

title: U. S. LISTS PLANS TO IMPROVE POLICE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A Federal commission sponsored the Law Enforcement Assisiance Administration recommended today that small police departments of fewer than 10 officers consolidate for improved efficicency and effectiveness.

title: Anticinematic 'History Lessons':The Cast
description: After seeing Jean-Marie Straub's short feature on Nazism, "Not Reconciled," Susan Sontag said that she wanted to kiss the screen. I doubt that this latest work, "History Lessons," will arouse quite the same response, but Straub, a political exile from France who lives in Germany and Italy, is a director who clearly stirs passionate feelings among cinastes.His reputation here comes directly from the film festival and Dan Talbot of the New Yorker Theater, who has acquired his films despite their scant commercial appeal. Intensely political and self-consciously intellectual, Jean-Marie Straub is becoming a cult director who gets those kissesand also boos."History Lessons" may well be the festival's most teasingly irritating film. It is impossible to likeeven for many dedicated Straubists. Half the press audience walked out of "Othon," his adaptation of a Corneille drama, a few years ago at the festival, and it was more comprehensible than "History Lessons," Straub's austere version of a Brecht novel about Julius Caesar.The camera seldom moves. Mostly it stays slightly behind the head of a young man as he drives his sports car aimlessly through the streets of Rome, a modern city suspended in an ancient world.The young man's function is almost that of a detective in a philosophical thriller. He searches out elderly Romans  a banker, a lawyer, a peasant  who remember Caesar. As their garlanded past blends into his transistorized present, he pieces together a Brechtian-Marxian-Straubian viewpoint on history.The interviews are long tedious monologues, in which the static figures speak almost expressionlessly in German, a language that sounds very curious amid sunburnt Italian settings. But German also has a harsh, didactic quality that provides another Straubian juxtaposition.Jean-Marie Straub deliberately alienates his audience. He defies traditional concepts of the medium just as minimal art in the nineteen-sixties went against prevailing sculptural ideas and as the music of Philip Glass ignores accepted theories of composition today.With "History Lessons," he further tests his audiencewith a film that is coldly anticinema.

title: BRONX MAN SEIZED AFTER AUTO CHASE
description: YONKERS, Sept. 30 (UPI)A 24yearold Bronx man was arrested early today after a sixmile, highspeed auto chase along the Bronx River Parkway from Yonkers to the Bronx, the Westchester County police reported.

title: A Tear in the Ocean' From France:The Cast
description: Jewish resistance to the Nazis in Poland needs no stressing now as a heart-breaking, indelible testament to courage and faith. But if the likes of the 1943 Warsaw ghetto uprising has become familiar in films, "A Tear in the Ocean," the French feature that had its local premiere at the Plaza yesterday, is disturbingly different as an exposure of men's minds (both Jew and Pole) under extreme stress.Henri Glaeser, who produced, directed, helped adapt and appears in this dramatization of a novel by Manes Sperber, is more concerned with the terrible decisions his principals must make than with guerrilla action. Even though there is enough gunfire and bloodshed here to make this more than just a tract, the heart of the matter is whether the Jews of Wolyna will cling passively to their beliefs in the face of callous, godless invaders or resist as men fighting oppressors.However, this is multifaceted, philosophical drama dominated by the convictions of its beleaguered characters. There is the flinty performance of Alexandre Stere, as a tough, singleminded Austrian Jewish doctor, determined to save Wolyna's ghetto dwellers. And there is Armand Abplanalp, as a Polish count and the leader of his own resistance group, who is his friend and quite ready to help him.But some of the villagers choose not to fight and are mowed down, among them a revered rabbi, played with dignity and reserve by Mr. Glaeser. Others, including Dominique Rollin, as the rabbi's dedicated, frail but fearless teen-age son, follow the doctor and join the compassionate count's underground guerrillas. However, peasant Poles resent these newcomers, unlikely warriors all, because they feel their fight is for Poland and not for Jews. It's a smoldering situation that, after a successful ambush of a Nazi platoon, erupts with tragic results.Mr. Glaeser, who shot his color film in 1971 on strikingly autumnal locations in Alsace, purposely leaves unanswered the gnawing question: whether resistance in fictitious Wolyna, like the actual bloody Warsaw uprising that followed it in time, was no more effective than the titular "tear in the ocean."Like the performances and the philosophies that are translated in lucid English subtitles, "A Tear in the Ocean" is both effective and provocative.

title: Nearing The Limits
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30In dealing with the acute public concern about food prices, official Washington has taken a generally reassuring line. There have been some unexpected trends, it is said, and perhaps some fault in negotiation, but careful planning can put things right for the future.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NATIONAL FOOTBALL LOTTERY. By Larry Merchant. 325 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.50.

title: Shanghai: Mutual Admiration Society
description: SHANGHAIIt was surprising enough that the newspapers in Peking devoted a great deal of space to the first concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra including a photograph of the entire ensemble grouped around Chiang Ching, Chairman Mao Tsetung's wife. Even more surprising were articles by critics about the orchestra. Almost never are there critical articles in the Chinese press. The Philadelphia Orchestra was lauded. for its tone, impeccable ensemble and international importance. Eugene Ormandy was hailed as a great conductor, and the music on the programs  ranging from Mozart to Respighiwas seriously discussed. All of which leads experienced observers here to believe that a thaw is coming. Bits of Western music are beginning to reappear on programs. The party leadership went out of its way to indicate satisfaction with the Philadelphia Orchestra's visit, imparting a wonderful aura of good feeling.

title: Testimony Indicates Hughes Sought Political Influence With Huge Campaign Gifts
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 Sworn testimony and other evidence on file in a pending Federal court case here paint Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive industrialist, as a man who gave hundreds of thousands of dollars to politicians, including President Nixon, in a relentless drive for political influence.

title: 75 Missing in Thai Slide
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 30 (AP)A landslide sent part of a north Thailand village into a floodswollen river yesterday, burying 12 houses and about. 75 persons, reports reaching Bankok said.

title: PERSIAN MUSICIANS MAKE A RARE VISIT
description: Persian music isn't heard so often in New York as some other kinds of nonWestern musicIndian, especiallyand thus it was pleasant to welcome a santur andzarb concert Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall/

title: If Mets Gain Playoffs, Jets Stay on the Road
description: MIAMI,. Sept. 30 (AP)Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, said today that next week's game between the New York Jets and the Miami Dolphins will be moved from Shea Stadium to Miami if baseball's New York Mets are in the playoffs.

title: GOEBBELS DIARIES STIR A DISPUTE
description: A major West German publishing concern charged last night that a New York publisher, the David McKay Company, had been misled by unauthorized individuals into falsely saying that it had an option on the United States and Canadian rights to secret diaries kept by Josef Goebbels, Hitler's propagandist.

title: Grassroots G. O. P. Women Warmly Support Agnew, but Express Sadness for His Plight
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30Vice President Agnew had left the hall and returned to the Palm Springs estate of his friend, Frank Sinatra. Members of the National Federation of Republican Women were having cocktails and talking about the speech he had just givenan impassioned denunciation of the Justice Department and a stern refusal to resign, even if indicted.

title: TRAVIATA REOPENS CITY OPERA SEASON
description: The New York City Opera got back into business at the New York State Theater on Saturday night, four weeks after the orchestra strike began on the fourth day of the company's fall season.

title: CAMBODIA TROOPS BITTER AT ORDEAL
description: SALA LEK PRAM, Cambodia, Sept. 30Maybe the Government has forgotten us, maybe we are too far away for Phnom Penh to think of us, the soldiers say.

title: Christian Commune in Israel Celebrates 2 Sabbaths
description: DOR NA ASHRAT, Israel,  The sun had set over western Galilee, and it was time to kabatat Shabbat, or receive the Sabbath. A young girl lit the candles, a man with a beard read the story of Abraham and the sacrifice of Isaac. There were blessings and the singing of Hebrew songs.

title: Richardson Reorganizes His Antitrust Division
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson announced today he had reorganized the Justice Department's antitrust division in order to emphasize planning, economic policy and consumer protection.

title: IRA FRANK, 79, AIDED THE BRAININJURED
description: Ira Frank, a founder of the Asociation for Brain Injured Children, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: Research May Prevent Most Malaria
description: LAKE APASTEPEQUE, El Salvador, Sept. 25American scientists have entered the final stages of research that they feel may lead to the virtual elimination of malaria as a major world health problem.

description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30The New York Mets, who stood last in the National League East one month ago, finally got one foot over the finish line today when they split a doubleheader with the Chicago Cubs and were assured. of at least a tie for baseball's most complicated championship.

description: Arson Suspected in Fatal Fire

title: Appropriate Sentence?
description: The quality of mercy was overstrained and mocked in the United States District Court the other day in case that called to mind the ancient aphorism, If you steal a loaf of bread you get a year in jail, but if you steal a railroad you get into the Social Register.

title: Film Festival: 'Ritorno':The Cast
description: Gianni Amico's "Ritorno" is set thematically near the soulless wasteland of Michelangelo Antonioni, whose beautiful but emotionally dried-up couples embark on a search into their past that reveals the arid desert of their lives. Their experiences, which expose desensitized nerves, are painfully cathartic.In "Ritorno" a handsome married couple, on the verge of being bored with each other, suddenly leave Rome one night and drive through an ominous thunderstorm to the husband's family several hours away. A telegram had arrived announcing that his father was dying. Now, wordlessly  and fearfully  they race the shadow of death.But their homecoming is a surprise; the withered father is very much alive. No one knows who sent the wire. As they attempt to find the answer from discarded lovers, disillusioned friends and relatives who only want to eat, they realize the trip is a preview of death. They will have to make it again, soon.A provocative situation quickly becomes dulled by the mushy influence of another director, Claude Lelouch. "Ritorno" focuses on billowing storm clouds, radiant meadows and simmering afternoon sunlightexternal textures.The puzzled, windswept couple have about as much depth as a cup of espresso. Their accidental remembrance of youth past is never more meaningful than the excessively used pleasantry, "Ciao."The film stops being a prosaic postcard for only a brief moment, when the unforgettable Laura Betti, as the husband's demented old flame, sends a wickedly sensuous venom stinging across the landscape. Her gothic villa frightens the husband away. If his "return" has any truth worth pursuing, it probably remains hidden there.

title: Nixon's Return Home
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 30 (UPI)  President and Mrs. Nixon returned here tonight after spending the weekend at their Camp David, Md. retreat.

title: NASA, on 15th Birthday Today, Finds Itself in an Identity Crisis
description: After a fast and glorious youth, full of promise and widely heralded achievement, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reaches its 15th anniversary today and finds itself in an identity crisis.

description: The Health Department has released the names of 25 more restaurants and food stores in the city that after failing an initial inspection did not correct the infractions when inspected a second time.

title: DEMOCRATS PUT OFF CONVENTION REFORM
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., Sept. 30 (AP)An almost evenly divided Democratic party committee has delayed a final decision on convention delegate selection quotas after voting tentatively to eliminate any preferential treatment for women, minorities and young people.

title: A.P. and U.P.I. Will Close National Service in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 (AP)The Associated Press and United Press International will close their national news services here tomorrow under a Government decree that prohibits foreign agencies from transmitting Argentine news in the country.

title: Partial List of Priorities Submitted by Planning Boards
A.D.A. Board Urges Congress to Stiffen Economic Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 80 (UPI) The governing board of the liberal Americans for Democratic Action urged passage of stiff economic controls today, blaming the Nixon Administration for the nation's economic problems.

title: Bills Upset Jets, 9 to 7, On 3 Kicks
description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., Sept. 30With O. J. Simpson ripping through the Jets' defensive line and Earl Edwards bursting through the Jets' offensive line, the Buffalo Bills scored a stunning 97 victory today on three field goals by John Lepoldt.

title: 395 Enter, and Most End, Marathon Here
description: A field of 395 runners, including 12 women, had their problems with bicyclists and Sunday strollers as well as with one another as they ran 26 miles thought Central Park yesterday in the fourth. annual New York Marathon.

title: Preseason Basketball
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Goldin Reports $37,678 In Campaign Contributions
description: Since the primary election, State Senator Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday, he has taken in $37,678.34 in contributions to his campaign as Democratic nominee for City Controller.

title: The Petersen Case
description: WASHINGTONWe've got the evidence. We've got it cold.

title: PUBLIC COLLEGES URGED TO DOUBLE TUITION CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30An influential businessoriented research group urged today that public colleges and universities more than double their undergraduate tuition charges.

title: Miss Palmer Wins Golf by 2 Shots
description: CAMERON PARK, Calif., Sept. 30 (UPI)Sandra Palmer shot a courserecord, sixunderpar 67 today and won the Cameron Park Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by two strokes with a total of 212.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WESTFIELD, Sept. 30It didn't require a Bobby RiggsBillie Jean King match to stimulate interest in tennis in this community, headquarters of the Youth Tennis Foundation.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Nearly two years ago, C. William Verity Jr., the outspoken chairman of the Armco Steel Company, proclaimed in a moment of exuberance that if he had another son he would name him John Connally Verity.

title: Italian Liner in for Repair
description: GENOA, Italy, Sept. 30 (AP) The Italian liner Raffaello, on a voyage from Spain to New York with 1,100 passengers, put into Genoa for several days for repairs last night after damaging its rear propeller.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30The Montreal Expos' pennant dream ended today, but that of the Pittsburgh Pirates went on. Salvaging the final game of the threegame series, the Pirates beat the Expos, 102, and eliminated them from the Eastern Division race on what was to have been the last day of the regular season.

title: 630 Deer Killed in Day
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 30 An estimated 630 deer were killed by Pennsylvania archers yesterday, the first day of the 1973 deer season, the state Game Commission reported to day.

title: Brandt, Home Again, Facing Dispute Over East Europe
description: BONN, Sept. 30 (AP)Chancellor Willy Brandt returned home from the United States today to face a developing controversy over demands from a political associate that he soften his attitude toward Moscow.

title: LAWRENCE MILLER
description: Lawrence Miller, assistant to the Commissioner of Relocation in the City Housing Department, died Saturday in Downstate Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived at 8860 20th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Bemis Rites at Yale Oct. 15
description: A memorial service for Samuel Flagg Bemis, the Yale historian who died Wednesday, will be held in the university's Dwight Memorial Chapel in New Haven on Monday, Oct. 15 at 3 P.M. The Rev. Sidney A. Lovett will officiate.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The Boston Red Sox, frustrated by another bridesmaid finish in the American League East, dismissed Eddie Kasko as manager today and promoted Darrell Johnson to field boss for the 1974 season.

title: 2 Carriers' Cost Overruns Are Put at $273Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)Delivery of the nuclearpowered aircraft carrier Nimitz will be delayed five to 11 months, and cost overruns on both the Nimitz and her sister ship, the Eisenhower, will amount to $273.6million, the Navy said today.

title: Surrender to Terror
description: The decision of the Austrian Government to capitulate. to Arab terrorists and to promise to end the existing system of organized transit facilities for Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel was a grevious error. This policy obviously based on the fatal misconception that if only the Soviet Jews would stop entering Austria, Chancellor Kreisky implies, then the murderous Arab terrorists would disappear and Austria could go on enjoying its postWorld War II prosperity and peace.

title: A U. N. Incursion
description: Late on the evening of Sept. 3, a small contingent of North Koreans landed on American soil. Twenty years ago such a statement would have been an appropriate beginning for a chilling novel.

title: Growing Debt Seen
description: LONDON, Sept. 30An ?? ford University economist projects that the Soviet Union will have approximately $29billion of foreign debt by 1980 and that the interest payments then could absorb half of the country's export earnings.

title: PUBLIC COLLEGES URGED TO DOUBLE TUITION CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30An influential businessoriented research group urged today that public colleges and universities more than double their undergraduate tuition charges.

title: AUSTRIA'S LEADER ASKS U.S. TO SHARE REFUGEE BURDEN
description: VIENNA, Sept. 30  Chancellor Bruno Kreisky suggested today that the United States and other countries share the burden of assisting Jewish refugees.

title: Senator Baker Writing a Novel; Doubleday Negotiating Contract
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, vice chairman of the Watergate Committee, said in Washington last night that he was negotiating with Doubleday to publish a novel with a Washington setting that he started writing in the nineteenfifties.

title: Jobs Are Sought Abroad for Chilean Intellectuals
description: Jobs are being sought outside Chile for intellectuals who prefer not to live there now that the country is under military rule, experts in LatnAmerican Affairs reported here over the weekend.

title: Baldwin Gets Approval To Acquire Five Banks
description: The D. H. Baldwin Company, a musicalinstrument manufacturer that diversified into banking in 1968, has disclosed that it received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to acquire five banks in Colorado with total assets of $130million.

title: Roosevelt and His Lawyers Work on Senate Testimony
description: MIAMI, Sept. 30 (UPI)Elliott Roosevelt met privately with his lawyers today in preparation for a Senate subcommittee appearance Wednesday to rebut charges that he had tried to arrange the assassination of Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling of the Bahamas.

title: Spirit and Economy of St. Louis Damaged by Newspaper Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30I feel so isolated, said Mrs. Ronald Greenberg, wife of the owner of an art gallery. It's not that I pore over the newspapers. It's, just good to know they're there.

title: Black Caucus to Join Foes To Achieve Political Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Congressional Black Caucus leaders emerged early today from daylong strategy meetings with a commitment to form coalitions, even with those traditionally regarded as enemies of black people, to promote the interests of black Americans.

title: Watergate Session Off Till Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  An alleged campaign spy known as Fat Jack and Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, have refused to testify before the Senate Watergate committee, delaying resumption of the hearings until Wednesday.

title: MRS. HERBST
description: Mrs. Bertha Friedman Herbst, who with her late husband, Alex, founded in 1933 the pastry and strudel bakery known as Mrs. Herbst, 1437 Third Avenue, died yesterday in Gracie Square Hospital. She was 92 years old and lived at 222 East 82d Street.

title: NARCOTIC ARRESTS DROP 76% IN CITY
description: Only onequarter as many felony drug arrests were made in the city in Septemberthe first month under the state's new stringent drug laws  as in the average month of 1972, according to police statistics.

title: Rock Concert Canceled
description: A rock concert scheduled for last evening at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center was canceled when two groups scheduled to perform, Dr. John and Blues & Roots, refused to cross picket lines set up by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which is on strike against the New York Philharmonic. Negotiations between the union and the Philharmonic management are to resume at 11 A.M. today under the guidance of Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, at the board's offices at No. 2 World Trade Center.

title: GOING OUT
description: THAT'S ENTERTAINMENT One of the fascinations of the Rizzoli International Bookstore is its quite civilized practice of staying open until midnight six days each week for posttheater and postdining browsing.

title: Houk Out As Yanks' Manager
description: Ralph Houk said goodby yesterday, not only to Yankee Stadium, but to his ballclub.

title: ARREST OF BLACKS STIRS BIAS CHARGE
description: WILLINGBORO, Sept. 30 The arrest of 22 black children for allegedly cutting through the back yards of white families on their way home from school here last week has stirred bit ter feelings in this integrated onetime Levittown.

title: Agnew Loosed Attack After Weeks of Anger
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Sept. 30Associates of Vice President Agnew said today that his denunciation of the Department of Justice for its conduct of the criminal investigation against him was the product of weeks of having dwelt on the dark side of an inferno.

title: Peter Chimicles Weds Miss Diana Chagaris
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Sept. 30Miss Diana Chagaris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Chagaris of Tenafly, was married here this afternoon to Peter Chimicles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Euthimios Chimicles of Fort Lee. The Rev. Socrates Tsamutalis performed the ceremony in the Greek. Orthodox Church of St. John the Theologian.

title: Arson Suspected in Fatal Blaze; 9 Bodies Found in 4 Tenements
description: HOBOKEN, Sept. 30 (UPI)Firemen said today that the blaze that swept four aging tenements and killed at least nine persons here had apparently been set by an arsonist.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Badillo Maintains Silence on His Choice, if Any, in Mayor Race
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal endorsed Representative Herman Badillo in the Democratic runoff primary for Mayor but Mr. Badillo has not returned the favor. Mr. Badillo, a Bronx Democrat, has not endorsed Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate, or said whether he would sit out the election. But he has said that he will not endorse Mr. Blumenthal, the Liberal candidate. Mr. Badillo is still smarting from his defeat in the Democratic mayoral primary, and he believes that his fellow liberal and Reform Democrat, Mr. Blumenthal, is largely to blame for his loss by winning the New Democratic Coalition's endorsement and siphoning liberal Democratic votes from himself.

title: Joseph Barnett, Former Chief At U.S. Bureau of Public Roads
description: Joseph Barnett, former chief of the urban road division of the United States Bureau of Public Roads, died Sunday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived on Greenwood Lane in Sands Point, L. I., and in Miami Beach.

title: Fiscal Impact of Senate Bills Analyzed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Libertarian Task Force, a group of college students that hopes to focus public, attention on Government spending and size, has released an analysis of the fiscal impact of legislation supported and sponsored by each member of the Senate since 1970.

title: Okker Beats Newcombe in Net Final
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP)Tom Okker rallied to capture the final two sets, including a tiebreaker, to beat John Newcombe of Australia today and win the $50,000 Tam tennis tournament.

title: U.S. Begins Publicity Campaign To Spur Preschool Vaccination
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)The Government announced a major publicity, campaign today to increase vaccinations for preschool children, fearing that the alarming decline of immunization in recent years might provoke epidemics of polio, measles and diphtheria.

title: GRIZZLY'S FUTURE TARGET OF DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Department of the Interior and the Fund for Animals, Inc., a national conservation group, are involved in a clash over the treatment of the grizzly bear in Yellowstone National Park, the last major refuge for the grizzly in the United States outside Alaska.

title: Blighted Niagara Falls Works to Rebuild Itself
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y.For decades, old smokestacks have scarred the skyline of this city, once known as the honeymoon capital of the world. And the city's center, always a wasteland, architecturally speaking, now looks worselike Berlin after World War II.

title: Cardinals Win, Still In Race
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP)  Bernie Carbo robbed Tommy Hutton of an extrabase hit in the fourth today, then doubled home the deciding run in the bottom of the inring as the St. Louis Cardirials defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 31.

title: 29 Killed in Mexican Crash
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Twentynine people were killed and 15 injured in a collision between a bus and a truck near Guadalajara about 280 miles northwest of Mexico City yesterday, the police reported today.

title: YUGOSLAVS STOP AMERICAN FILM
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30International political sensitivities have apparently thwarted an American movie company's plans to produce a film in Yugoslavia about a romance in Moscow between an American journalist and a Russian girl.

title: POLLUTION REVIEW SET BY SCIENTISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Scores of scientists will provide ammunition for the battle over whether to change the Federal regulations on air pollution when a threeday conference of the National Academy of Science opens here Wednesday.

title: DR. JOHN W. DODD EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: Dr. John W. Dodd, Superintendent of the Freeport (L.I.) Schools from 1925 to 1961 and professor of education at Long Island University from 1961 to 1968, died Saturday of a heart attack at West Point, N.Y., before the ArmyCalifornia football game. He was 80 years old and lived in Freeport.

title: HONGKONG COPING WITH SOCIAL ILLS
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 30 Faced with many of the ailments that are common to modern urban societies, the colonial government of Hong Kong is making a diffident entry into the field of social welfare.

title: Major Bills In Congress
New London's Heritage
description: Although the local redevelopment authority claims that 90 per cent of the people of New London neither know nor care about the city's H. H. Richardson railroad station, this is hardly conclusive proof that the registered landmark should be torn down. The test does not lie in New London's understanding of its place in art and history, nor its awareness of how skillful urban design can tie new and old to a richer environment. And local resentment of meddling outsiders is hardly a proper incentive to destruction. That the plight of the New London station has received national attention proves that public concern is rising about the loss of landmarks and about the sterilization programs that have gone under the name of urban renewal.

title: Fires in Harlem and Bronx Leave 17 Firemen Injured
description: A total of 17 firemen and two civilians were overcome by smoke yesterday morning in apartmenthouse fires in Harlem and the Bronx.

title: Yankee Stadium Finale Stirs Memories of Days of Glory
description: They rang down the curtain on historic Yankee Stadium yesterday, and it came down with quite a thud. However, considering what such an occasion might have produced, it was quite an orderly procedure.

title: Three Business Executives Promoted by The Times
description: The promotions of three executives at The New York Times were announced yesterday by John J. McCabe, a senior vice president.

title: Agnew Loosed Attack After Weeks of Anger
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Sept. 30Associates of Vice President Agnew said today that his denunciation of the Department of Justice for its conduct of the criminal investigation against him was the product of weeks of having dwelt on the dark side of an inferno.

title: South Vietnamese, Formally at Peace, Find CeaseFire Accord a Mockery
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 27They buried Pvt. Chau Tan Tai in the national military cemetery at Bien Hoa one recent morning, When the ceasefire agreement was signed in Paris last January, he was a high school student, but then he failed an exam and was drafted.

title: GeoStar Is Investigated
description: VANCOUVER, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press)The British Columbia Securities Commission has begun an investigation into, the sale of 61,450 shares of GeoStar Resources, Ltd., listed on the Vancouver Stock Exchange. GeoStar, a small mining company, was legally, declared bankrupt in August.

title: MRS. S. Y. AGNON
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 30 (AP)Ester Agnon, widow of Israel's first Nobel Prize winner in literature, died Friday at the age of 84.

title: Lindsay Will Participate In Urban Housing Parley
description: Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday that the Mayor would participate in a dayandahalf meeting on urban housing needs to be held by the Legislative Action Committee of the United States Conference of Mayors.

title: Moscow's Fall Quest: Mushrooms
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30The. propagandists' may be focusing on the ideological struggle, the diplomats on EastWest trade and the scientists on the latest Soviet maninspace shot. But the ordinary Muscovite is more likely to have his mind on prowling through the woods around the city for mushrooms.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1973

title: Southern California's No. 1 Ranking Tarnished by 77 Tie With Oklahoma
description: Southern California's 77 tie with Oklahoma Saturday night marked the first time since 1966 that the team ranked No. 1 in the nation battled to a deadlock. Notre Dame, rated No. 1 seven years ago, settled for a 1010 standoff with Michigan State, rated No. 2 then, in the highly publicized game of the century of 1966.

title: Jack Elliott Dips Anew Into Woody Guthrie Era
description: Ramblin' Jack Elliott remains the most faithful upholder of the Woody Guthrie spirit before the public today. He long has sung mostly Western songs, influencing other singers and poets in turn.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Research May Prevent Most Malaria
description: LAKE APASTEPEQUE, El Salvador, Sept. 25American scientists have entered the final stages of research that they feel may lead to the virtual elimination of malaria as a major world health problem.

title: Train Derails in Wisconsin
description: ALLENTOWN, Wis., Sept. 30 A train derailment hurled freight cars into a liquid petroleum gas storage area here early today, setting several tanks afire. Residents evacuated homes within three blocks of the storage facility, but the authorities said there was little danger to most of the community of about 600 persons. There were no reports of injuries. The cause of the derailment, of 21 cars was not immediately determined.

title: FIREMES PACT TO BE MEDIATED
description: Mediation will begin today in an effort to avert a strike by the city's 11,000 uniformed firemen, who have empowered their leaders to call a walkout if necessary to win their contract demands.

title: Mrs. Meir, in Strasbourg, Expects Austrian Reversal
description: STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 30  Premier Golda Meir of Israel told an audience of French Jews here tonight that Israel still hopes and believes that Austria will rescind her decision to suspend largescale transit of Soviet Jews through Vienna.

title: Advertising: B.&B. Goes West
description: Landing the Continental Airlines account means that Benton & Bowles can at long last establish what one executive calls a West Coast presence.

title: Canadian Paper Company May Recycle in California
description: Canada's largest forestproducts company announced here yesterday, according to Reuters, that it was studying the feasibility of building a $30million newsprint recycling plant in the San Francisco Bay area.

title: Shultz Arrives in Moscow; Will Discuss Trade Issue
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP)Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz arrived in Moscow tonight and said that he would try to solve the question of Congressional opposition to granting the Soviet Union most  favored  nation trade status.

title: Despite Drawbacks, the Skunk Has Its Friends
description: A skunk can be repellent, as everyone knows.

title: Innovative Aid Reform
description: The Senate will have opportunity this week to give a decisive push to the most promising innovation in foreign aid since President Truman enunciated Point Four for the world's needy in his 1948 inaugural. A new departure, already adopted by the House, would redirect American aid from largescale industrial projects to direct assistance to the poorest majority in the underdeveloped countries via rural development, food production, population control, health and education.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES A SUIT BY VESCO
description: NEWARK, Sept. 30 (UPI)A Federal judge has dismissed a $20million defamation suit brought by the New Jersey financier, Robert L. Vesco, who has chosen to remain in Costa Rica and not face separate criminal charges in connection with a $200,000 contribution to President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign.

title: LEYITT CRITICIZES THE STATE BUDGET
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt contended yesterday that the state budget accounted for only twothirds of actual expenditures and was so subject to manipulated and distorted entries as to lessen the public's understanding of and confidence in government.

title: Dolphins and Morris Romp
description: Mercury Morris crashed out of Don Shula's doghouse yesterday. The fleet running back for the Miami Dolphins made up for a handful of mistakes he committed two weeks ago by scoring three touchdowns and setting Dolphin game record of 197 yards gained as Miami rolled over the New England Patriots, 4423, in Miami.

title: Sandman Pledges to Bar Public Funds for Abortion
description: NEWARK, Sept. 30  Five hundred people at a rally sponsored by opponents of legalized abortion heard Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, declare today that if he were elected, no public money will be appropriated for mass murder  for that is what abortion is.

title: AUSTRIA'S LEADER ASKS U.S. TO SHARE REFUGEE BURDEN
description: VIENNA, Sept. 30  Chancellor Bruno Kreisky suggested today that the United States and other countries share the burden of assisting Jewish refugees.

title: Four Mayoral Candidates Attend Annual Red Mass
description: New York City's four mayoral candidates met at the annual red mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, then scattered around the city for a day of handshaking in bright crisp weather that was perfect for campaigning.

title: Industrialized World Turning to Third Parties to Settle Labor Strife
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Increasingly, industrialized nations are turning to third parties to settle or prevent strikes, according to a ninecountry study by the Conference Board.

title: Local Planning Boards Submit First Lists of Budget Priorities
description: A new era in budgetmaking began yesterday as the city's 62 community planning boards for the first time submitted their priority items to the City Planning Commission to help shape the capital budget.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: SPECIAL ELECTION SET FOR WEST SIDE
description: West Side voters will choose two Democratic nominees for Civil Court judgeships tomorrow in a special primary election only a month before the general election.

title: Theater: Period Piece
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 29The Hartford Stage Company began its 11th season boldly last night with the world premiere of My Sister, My. Sister, a new black play by a new playwright, Ray Aranha. It is work guaranteed not to soothebut it should stimulatea subscription audience.

title: COLLEGE BASEBALL
KnicksNets Exhibition Excites Only the Fans
description: A man waiting to purchase tickets yesterday for Thursday night's second game between the Knicks and the Nets at the Nassau Coliseum, said, this is a biggie. Our Nets are going to get a chance to show up the big boys.

title: A Soviet Youth Show To Begin in U.S. Oct. 12
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1The Soviet Union announced today that an exhibition on Soviet youth, including a mockup of an American Apollo and Soviet Soyuz spacecraft docking, would begin a 10month tour of the United States in Washington on Oct. 12.

title: Health Warning Is Issued Again On the Metal in Stamford Water
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 1The public water supply serving most of this city's homes, offices and hospitals is contamminted with high levels of manganese and Health o a threat to health, the Health Department's director warned today.

title: Gulf Oil Is Seeking Acquisition of CNA
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, world's third largest producer of crude oil, said late yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the CNA Financial Corporation, a large holding company with interests in insurance, real estate and other financial services.

title: ASSEMBLYMAN SAYS HE OFFERED NO BRIBE
description: Assemblyman Calvin WilHams charged yesterday that his arrest on bribery charges was an attempt to put the gypsy cab industry, of which he is a leader, out of business.

title: PRICES ARE DOE FOR COMMODITIES
description: Rain and the Soviet Union influenced commodity futures trading early yesterday, but by the end of the session on the Chicago Board of Trade the news from the Soviet Union had the stronger impact.

title: MORE GRAIN SALES TO CHINESE SEEN
description: Peking officials are negotiating to buy large additional quantities of North American grain despite prospects of a record harvest in China this year, according to knowledgeable Midwest grain trade sources.

title: Peanut Acreage Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) The House passed a peanut, allotment transfer bill by voice vote today and sent it to the Senate. Under the bill, a peanut grower who could not plant all of his farm acreage allotment this year because of flood or other natural disaster could transfer the allotment to other farms in which he has an interest.

title: LEGG, MASON JOINS WOOD IN NEW FIRM
description: Despite more profitable operating conditions on Wall Street, the consolidation trend continued yesterday with the announcement that two brokerage houses had merged to form First Regional Securities, Inc.

title: HAROLD M. LEWIS, CITY PLANNER, 84
description: BRUNSWICK, N. Y., Oct. 1 Harold M. Lewis, for many years executive engineer and secretary of the Regional Plan Association of the New York metropolitan area, died Saturday in Samaritan Hospital, Troy. He was 84 years old.

title: FAREWELL PARTY FOR BLUE POLES
description: A small, private bonvoyage party was held on Central Park West last night for a celebrated and fabulously valuable member of the art world about to depart for Australiathe painting Blue Poles by Jackson Pollock.

title: People and Business
description: Mary Gardiner Jones is ending her nineyear term on the Federal Trade Commission and will join the faculty of the University of Illinois in January.

title: TV: James Stewart in a Stylish Series
description: Hawkins, which will be rotated. Tuesdays with two other series on the Columbia Broadcasting System, stars James Stewart as Billy Jim Hawkins, a criminal lawyer with a pronounced downhome country manner. Wrapped securely in the familiar Stewart stammeranddrawl method of acting, Billy Jim uses an ingratiating veneer of hick to disguise his innate and sophisticated shrewdness. Under that facade there is indeed another facade.

title: BADILLO WILL BACK BERME FOR MAYOR AT MEETING TODAY
description: Representative Herman Badillo, whose anger at losing the Democratic mayoral primary persisted long past election night, has agreed to endorse the man who beat him, Controller Abraham D. Beame.

title: OFFDUTY POLICEMAN KILLS BRONX GUNMAN
description: An offduty police officer shot and killed a gunman in the South Bronx last night, after the gunman had allegedly wounded another man and was preparing to finish him off with a bullet to the head.

title: Bonn Aide's Remarks in Soviet Stir Up a Storm Around Brandt
description: BONN, Oct. 1The Parliamentary leader of the governing Social Democratic party, Herbert Wehner, has stirred a political storm with his reported remarks during a trip to the Soviet Union that Bonn had pushed too hard for concessions from the East on West Berlin.

title: TEXASGULF RAISES ITS PRICE FOR ZING
description: Texasgulf, Inc., said yesterday that it had raised its price for zinc sold in the United States and Canada by 3 cents a pound, effective immediately.

title: John Cogley, Long A Catholic Writer, Joins Episcopalians
description: John Cogley, a leading Roman Catholic writer, was received into the Episcopal Church at a ceremony in Santa Barbare, Calif., last Thursday.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Israeli Premier to Council of Europe
description: STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Following are excerpts from a transcript of an address given today by Premier Goida Meir to the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe:

title: The Forest Report
description: The Nixon Administration throughout its tenure office has shown a marked partiality in favor of the economic interests of the timber industry. But because of Congressional and judicial restraints, it has not been able to do much beyond issuing sympathetic reports.

title: City Is Star of Multimedia Show
description: Fog rolls in from the East River, lightning crackles high above the Empire State Building, the old Third Avenue El rumbles downtown. Moments later firecrackers explode, Fourth of July music whips to a frenzy and the Statue of Liberty is dedicated.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Eight Brain Twisters
description: Riddles for our time:

title: SERVICE PROGRAMS OF NATION MERGED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. (AP) President Nixon has signed legislation formally consolidating the Government's major volunteer service programs under one agency. He called it an example of bipartisan harmony between the White House and Congress.

title: E. H. Werner, Former Head Of Jersey Power and Light
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Oct. 1E. H. Werner, who retired in 1954 as president of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, died yesterday at the Bethesda Memorial Hosiptal. His age was 83.

title: REBELS IN CAMBODIA CAPTURE RIVER BANK
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Cambodian insurgents today forced Government troops off the south bank of the Prek Thnot River, leaving rebel ferces in control of the river bank 11 miles south of Phnom Penh, reports from the field said.

title: School Destroyed In Suspicious Fire At Children's Home
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1A $250,000 learning center at Abbott House, a children's home in Irvington, N. Y., was destroyed yesterday in a blaze apparently set by an arsonist.

title: Sandman and Byrne Limit Their Campaign Spending
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1  Despite a new state law permitting them to spend up to $1.5million each, the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor reported today that they would actually spend far less.

title: HUMPHREY TO FORGO '76 PRESIDENTIAL BID
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP)Senator Hubert Humphrey said tonight that he would not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976 but would not abandon his party.

title: Mets Win East Title, Start Playoff Saturday
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1  The New York Mets completed their rousing dash from last place and finally won the most complicated race in baseball history today when they defeated the Chicago Cubs, 64, to capture the Eastern Division title in the National League.

title: Those Gourmet Meals for Motorists Turn Out to Be Pike Dreams in Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 1Promises of gourmet dining on the. New Jersey Turnpike  complete with chafing dishes and Viennese pastriesproved to be pie in the sky today.

title: Refuge in Spain for Europe's Migrating Birds Becomes Death Stop for Many
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Sept. 22One of Europe's most important nature reserves, the Coto de Doana, has been struck by disaster  the massacre of thousands of birds, mainly by pesticides.

title: ARTHUR C. LINK
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 1 Arthur C. Link, who retired as defense projects manager of Western Electric Company in 1959, died here Saturday. He was 79 years old and lived at 12 Knollwood Drive.

title: Musicians' Mediation Fails; New Session Set Today
description: James J. McFadden, a mediator in the dispute between the New York Philharmonic and striking orchestra members, said that a mediation session yesterday had failed to resolve differences and that another was planned for 10 A.M. today at the offices of the State Mediation Board in the World Trade Center.

title: Price of Gold Falls Below $100 an Ounce
description: PARIS Oct. 1The price of gold fell below $100 an ounce today for the first time in six weeks, reflecting a combination of factors, including the strengthening dollar, a lively foreign interest in Wall Street and gold's declining monetary role.

title: Those Gourmet Meals Are Just Pike Dreams
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct 1Promises of gourmet dining on the New Jersey Turnpike complete with chafing dishes and Viennese pastries  turped out to be pie in the sky today.

title: Detective Here Gets 2 Years On Probation for Taking Bribe
description: A Federal judge adopted the recommendation of a prosecutor yesterday and imposed a suspended, sentence on a New York City detective who last May 21 pleaded guilty to splitting a $4,000 payoff.

title: South African Miners to Get Raise as Result of Riot
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 28  As a result of the recent goldmine rioting in which 11 black workers were killed by the police, large wage increases are being planned for black miners.

title: No Sugar Beet Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)The Agriculture Department announced today that there would he no acreage restrictions next ??ar on sugar beet production.

title: Advertising: On Going Public
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which almost went public last year but stepped away from it because other agency stocks were doing poorly, is about to give it another try.

title: Youth on Minibike Killed by Cable Blocking Road
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., Oct. 1A 16yearold boy on a minibike was killed. Yesterday when he ran into an inchthick steel cable stretched across a dirt road here.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost its savor, wherewith shell it be salted?

At that time the Yankees were riding along in first place behind the fantastic relief pitching of Sparky Lyle, while the Mets were dragging dreadfully because Tug McGraw, their relief artist, had lost his touch.

title: Jane Fonda Is Solid Nora in Doll's House
description: A psychologist once remarked: After your namesake slammed the doll's house door, I bet her first words were Oh God, I've forgotten my keys! This suggestion inspired some embattled evenings. If that cynic had a clue to Nora's key ring, there were two possible interpretations. Some of us agreed that she might evenutally need her keys to collect a few papers crucial to divorce. But of course the opposition claimed that she would hate her new freedom  hence the keys would be, necessary for rushing back and locking herself in.

title: Exit Through Austria
description: The most immediately urgent point now, in the negotiations between Israel and the Austrian Government over the emigration process for Soviet Jews, is to insure that the line of exodus through Austria remains open. This is the prime issue to be resolved when Chancellor Kreisky and Premier Golda Meir confer in Vienna today.

title: Theodorakis Crosses the Picket Line But Asserts His Unity With Musicians

title: Film Festival: A Story of Corruption:' Rejeanne Padovani' Is the Canadian Entry The Cast
description: As a sobering drama, "Rjeanne Padovani," shown last night as the Canadian feature entry at the New York Film Festival, is, like its venal principals, fascinating but imperfect.Corruption among its effete, influential Canadian wheeler-dealers, politicos and their ruthless hirelings is made shockingly obvious but it remains as an indictment of characters who are sometimes undefined and shadowy. In essence, "Rjeanne Padovani" evolves as an intermittently vivid illustration of truths that more often strike at the mind rather than the heart.Denys Arcand, its 32-year-old director and a newcomer to the United States movie scene, maintains a good deal of suspense as his group of bigwigs dine at the plush Montreal home of Jean Lajeunesse on his completion of a superhighway. He, like the governmental minister, the mayor, their assistants, wives and secretaries as well as their police and bodyguards dining in the servants' quarters, are obliquely exposed as urbane, suave or rough, direct men and women callously on the take or on the make.Unfortunately, Luce Guilbeault, as the ill-fated, estranged wife of the builder, who turns up pleading to be reunited with her children after a long liaison with another man, is not entirely convincing in her motivations. If she provides a strong portrayal as the only decently emotional individual in an otherwise nefarious crew, Mr. Arcand also indicates the power, lust and money drives that propel the others in that cynical crowd.As the cool, polished tycoon, Mr. Lajeunesse is there with payoff gifts to his guests who helped him steal millions, as well as their muscle men. He loves his kids and he is ready to daily with one of his willing guests while looking the other way as his wife faces her doom. And the fatuous mayor, the minister and the builder's tough strongarm man, Pierre Theriault, among others in a large cast, make the going rough for inquiring reporters, potential demonstrators and the gangster opposition.Although its French dialogue is made plain by English subtitles, "Rjeanne Padovani" presents a grim picture of corruptors whose acts are more explicit than their feelings. The film will be shown again tomorrow night.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1  The New York Mets completed their rousing dash from last place and finally won the most complicated race in baseball history today when they defeated the Chicago Cubs, 64, to capture the Eastern Division title in the National League.

title: Clean Money Welcome

Having concluded that money was corrupting American elections, T. R. suggested that the Federal Government itself should finance election campaigns for Presidential and Congressional office, with strict limits on supplementary private contributions. Prospects are bright now for passage of some legislation in spite of its drastic nature and the novelty of an idea only 66 years old.

The commission pointed out that the activities of the police are limited or shaped by the rules and procedures of the court and that the work of the correctional system is determined by the sentences given by the court.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)France M. Boone, of Roan Mountain, Tenn., a 70yearold former miner who entered the West Virginia coal pits when he was 15, has received the first black lung claim signed by a Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan. Mr. Boone, disabled by a disease caused by coal dust, will receive $254.70 a month.

title: Austria Hints Concession
description: VIENNA, Oct. 1Austria appeared tonight to be softening her announced decision to close special transit facilities for Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel.

title: Notes on People
description: On arrival in Geneva yesterday, the reception for the Dalai Lama of Tibet was about as cold as the bitter north wind that swept across the airport runways.

title: Bomb Suspect Held in Bond
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 (UPI) A Federal magistrate today ordered Byron De La Beckwith, twice tried but never convicted in the slaying of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, held on a $100,000 bond on Federal bomb charges. He allegedly brought a ticking bomb into Louisiana from Mississippi on Sept. 27.

title: High School ports
description: New Dorp has one of the strongest football teams in the city, but the Public Schools Athletic League calls it Class B.

title: Greek Politician Named to Form Cabinet
description: ATHENS, Oct. 1President George Papadopoulos, who as an artillery colonel six years ago seized power boasting he had saved Greece from the politicians, today turned to a veteran politician and asked him to form a new government.

title: ACCORD IS REPORTED IN NEWSPRINT STRIKE
description: The United Paperworkers International Union reported yesterday that tentative agreements had been reached with the Eastern Newsprint Group and the ConsolidatedBathurst Group at their Canadian mills.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Giant Players Lose Sleep; Ask: What Happened?
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 1Norm Snead said he stayed up all night trying to figure out what went wrong with the New York Giants offense in their 1210 loss to the Cleveland Browns last Sunday:

title: I Never Gave Up, and Neither Did the Players, Says Berra About How the Mets Won the Eastern Title
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1The tortoise had done it again, to a whole bunch of hares this time, and the fact that they had come from last place to first in the final month of the season was the central satisfaction expressed by the New York Mets as they celebrated winning the National League's Eastern Division race.

title: Government Raise Begins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 1 (UPI) About 3.3 million white collar government workers and military personnel begin working under a 4.7 per cent higher coostofliving pay scale today over the objections of President Nixon. The increase became automatic when the Senate voted 72 to 16 Friday to reject Mr. Nixon's attempt to postpone the pay rise from Oct. 1 to, Dec. 1.

title: Chamberlain Is In, Not On, the Court
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (UPI)A suit on behalf of Wilt Chamberlain and the San Diego Conquistadors was filed in superior court today seeking a quick decision on whether Chamberlain may play for the American Basketball Association team this season.

title: Terrorist Seizure Of Emigrant Train Recounted by Jews
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 1 (AP)The men appeared to be train robbers, but Moshe Litvak soon found out otherwise.

title: Odds Favor A's, Reds
description: Reno, Nev., Oct. 1. (AP)The Oakland A's and the Cincinnati Reds have been installed as favorites in the American and National League playoffs that will begin Saturday. The Reds were 85 favorites over the New York Mets. The A's were 65 over Baltimore.

title: Queries and Replies on Mandatory Allocation of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Nixon Administration is on the verge of adopting a mandatory allocation program for heating oil. The following questions and answers examine the asserted need for such a program, how it would work and political aspects of the debate.

title: Big Battle Reported By Saigon in Area 35 Miles From City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1The Saigon command today reported a major battle in Tay Ninh Province, 35 miles northwest of the capital.

title: William King, ExU.S. Aide And an A.P. Correspondent
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Oct. 1 (AP)William B. King, a former Associated Press foreign correspondent who retired here last year after more than two decades with the United States Information Agency, died today. He was 62 years old.

title: House Votes to Elevate Indian Commission Rank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 1 (UPI)  The House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that would elevate the office of Commissioner of Indian Affairs to the status of an assistant secretary of the Interior Department.

title: Jorgensen Back at Helm, So Redskins Revive Pass
description: For quarterbacks, the Redskins have shifted from Bill Kilmer to Sonny Jurgensen and their style of play will change too, leading perhaps to A shift in the kind of football the pros are playing. Because Larry Brown appears to be worn out after only threegames and because the enigmatic Duane. Thomas is not ready to help him, Washington will turn from a running team to a passing one. This will become apparent in the Redskins' next game, the big one on the league schedule for the fourth week when Dallas comes to Washington next Monday night.

title: Gasoline Prices Up Slightly in Area, but Many L.I. Dealers Who Sought More Will Close Temporarily
description: Some motorists in the metropolitan area had to pay slightly more for gasoline yesterday after the Cost of Living Council permitted filling stations to raise prices, but many service stations on Long Island are expected to be closed in midweek because their owners did not feel the increase was large enough.

title: New ParityGoRound?
description: Every few years the city's uniformed services begin chafing under the parity shackles that keep the pay scales of police officers, firemen and sanitationmen chained to one another. Every time that happens it is bad news for the taxpayers, in the form of strikes, slowdowns or expensive me too pay settlements.

title: Chinese Delegation In Washington Has First Big Reception
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1For the first time since the establishment of the Chinese Communist Government 24 years ago, the anniversity was offically celebrated in Washington tonight.
