title: Stefan Osusky, Diplomat, Dead; Led Czech Resistance to Nazis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Dr. Stefan Osusky, a former Czechoslovak diplomat, who led efforts to free his country from Nazi and Communist domination, died Thursday here, where he lived in exile. He was 84 years old.

title: Shultz, in Moscow, Is Stressing Trade
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz was reported to have stressed tonight to Soviet leaders that the momentum of expanding SovietAmerican commerce could be maintained by American industry and by the White House despite a recent Congressional setbacks for trade concessions to Moscow.

title: Israelis Are Hopeful
description: STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 1 Premier Golda Meir of Israel will fly to Vienna tomorrow to confer with Chancellor Bruno Kreisky on a possible compromise arrangement for the continued transit of Soviet Jews through Austria.

title: Jets Tackle an Offensive Line Problem
description: While officials in the Jets' offices on Madison Avenue completed plans yesterday for switching next Sunday's game to Miami (courtesy of the Mets), coaches in the Jets' workrooms at Shea Stadium puzzled over a more significant problem (courtesy of Earl Edwards).

title: Richardson Denies Aide Leaked Report on Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson assured President Nixon this morning that Henry E. Petersen was not the source of a disputed news broadcast about Vice President Agnew.

title: A Legend of the Game
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1  When Lawrence Peter Berra was a small boy in the Hill section of St. Louis, devoting almost all his waking hours to playing some sort of sport with the other sons of Italian immigrants who were so numerous in that neighborhood, he once began a series of exercises he thought would increase his already considerable athletic prowess. Without knowing the exact nature of the exercises, his friends, who included a quickwitted kid named Joe Garagiola, started calling him Yogi.

title: CITY STUDIES RISE IN PRISON BREAKS
description: A special unit in the Department of Correction, consisting of private investigators who were brought in last February, has been investigating the record number of escape attemptsat least 50 in the last 12 monthsfrom the city's detention facilities.

title: Deliverers Ratify New Contract With City Dailies
description: Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union last night approved a contract with the city's three major daily newspapers by more than a 4to1 margin.

title: Senate Vote F.H.A. Extension
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UN) The Senate passed a oneyear extension of the Federal Housing Administration home loan guarantee program today and sent the measure to the White House. The resolution, previously adopted by the House, was approved by voice, vote with only a few Senators present. Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, cast the only audible vote against the resolution.

title: Grant of a Leave to Convict Is Studied
description: The Senate Investigations Committee is examining the circumstances through which Federal District Judge Mark A. Costantino granted a convict a fiveday furlough from, prison in June, to enable him to attend a relative's wedding.

title: Baseball Transactions NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: CHICAGOLarry Jansen, Pitching coach, retired; Purchased Bob Sperring, Infielder, from Midland of the Texas League; released Francisco Estrada and Jim Hibbs.

title: KnicksNets Exhibition Excites Only the Fans
description: A man waiting to purchase tickets yesterday for Thursday night's second game between the Knicks and the Nets at the Nassau Coliseum, said, this is a biggie. Our Nets are going to get a chance to show up the big boys.

title: Proxmire Assaulted in Capital; Two Youths, 14 and 15, Seized
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, was attacked by two youths as he walked home from work tonight, the District of Columbia police reported.

title: Health Food Groups to Sue Over Vitamins A and D Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Two health food organizations announced today that they would go to court to try to stop the Food and Drug Administration from banning the sales of large doses of Vitamins A and D without a prescription.

title: Nine in Chile Are Executed For Attacks on the Military
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 1The military Government today announced that nine more people had been executed over the weekend.

title: Hordes of Monarch Butterflies Migrating South
description: Never, since systematic observations of the remarkable behavior of monarch butterflies began, has there been such a profusion of those insects as those in the hordes now migrating south, according to a leading specialist in their population trends.

title: Orioles or A's Host First Series Game
description: The World Series will open in an American League city, either Baltimore or. Oakland, on October 13, the baseball commissioner's office said yesterday. If the A's take the American League pennant. the game is scheduled for 4 P.M. Should the Orioles be champion, the game begins in Baltimore at 2 P.M.

title: Indianapolis Busing Plan for Desegregation Arouses Enmity, With Move to Impeach Judge Who Ordered
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 1  A courtordered desegregation plan for this city's public elementary schools that requires busing to achieve racial balance has provoked strong opposition here, including a move by a local judge to impeach the Federal judge who imposed the plan.

title: Sears, Roebuck Strike Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (UPI) Some 800 warehouse em, ployes of Sears, Roebuck & Co. returned to work today, ending a strike of almost two months.

title: Man Who Touched Off Payola Inquiry Is on Trial
description: NEWARK, Oct. 1  The heroin  smuggling  conspiracy trial of the talent manager who accidentally touched off the nationwide poprecord payola scandal opened here today in United States District Court.

title: Bridge: To Dispel Magic of Italian Pair Even a Misunderstanding Fails
description: The European Championships, which ended in Ostend, Belgium, last week, resulted in a notexpected double victory for Italy. The astonishing partnership of Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo demonstrated once again that they are virtually unbeatable.

title: TCHI CHANG YUN
description: Tchi Chang Yun, Minister to Britain from South Korea from 1949 to 1951 and its Ambassador to Turkey in 1961, died yesterday in New York, where he lived. His age was 74. He studied at Ohio State University and the University of Chicago.

title: Guard Ordered for Boyle
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 1 (AP)A Federal magistrate today temporarily suspended bond and ordered a protective hospital guard for the former United Mine Workers president, W. A. Boyle, until the indicted union official recovers from an apparent suicide attempt.

title: Stennis Jury Is Selected
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) A jury of nine women and three men was chosen today to try a teenager charged under the Congressional Assassination Act with attempting to kill Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi during a robbery.

title: Dallas Hearing Scheduled
description: DALLAS, Oct. 1 (UPI)Two former Attorneys General, John Mitchell and Richard Kleindienst and the former Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, L. Patrick Gray 3d, are scheduled to appear in United States District Court tomorrow to answer allegations that the Texas stock fraud scandal was a Republicanmanipulated scheme to embarrass the state's Democratic officeholders.

title: 4 Years Later, Mets Are Again Darlings of Gotham
description: Confetti was thrown from the windows of Wall Street buildings, cab drivers, shouted joyfully at each other in Times Square, and a Seventh Avenue shoeshine man won $50 in what he called a sociable bet yesterday after the New York Mets won the Eastern Division championship of the National League.

title: DR. MARTIN WEISZ
description: Dr. Martin Weisz, a physician who survived the Dachau concentration camp in Nazi Germany and came here in 1947, died yesterday on vacation in Miami. He was 73 years old and lived at 115 Ascan Avenue in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: SENATE APPROVES $20.9BILLION BILL TO PROCURE ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate approved today a $20.9billion military procurement bill after rejecting a lastminute proposal for an acrosstheboard $500million cut in the defense budget.

title: BADILLO WILL BACK BEAM FOR MAYOR AT MEETING TODAY
description: Representative Herman Badillo, whose anger at losing the Democratic mayoral primary persisted long past election night, has agreed to endorse the man who beat him, Controller Abraham D. Beame.

title: Chess: Caissa as True Catharsis, Or the Inner Self Revealed
description: Paul Xeres once remarked that one of the fascinations of chess for him was the way it lent itself to the expression of the style and temperament of its practitioner. The veteran Soviet grandmaster further admitted that, facing an opponent whose style was similar to his, he would deliberately alter his play to bring about the kind of clash he delighted in.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1973

title: Whose Ox Is Being Gored?
description: Beware of poetic justice, which often means one wrong on top of another.

title: Iowa Democrats Pick Chief
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. (UPI)The Democratic State Central Committee early Saturday elected Polk County Supervisor Tom Whitney, 291 years old, as state chairman.

title: U.S. Is Airlifting Soldiers To Germany in Exercise
description: RAMSTEIN, West Germany, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway and Defense Minister Georg Leber of West Germany officially welcomed American troops arriving at the air base here in southern West Germany to take part in a vast reinforcement exercise codenamed Reforger V.

title: Guidelines Set for Bids at Sale Of Parochial School Equipment
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1 (AP)The State Division of Purchase and Property today set ground rules for bidding on some $2.9million worth of equipment purchased under a state parochial school aid program later declared unconstitutional.

title: Business Briefs
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it would discontinue operation of its block automation systern Dec. 31 in an economy move.

title: I.C.C. Asks Court to Ward Off Trustees' Plan to Close Pennsy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Interstate Commerce Commission today asked a Federal District Court in Philadelphia not to permit the Penn Central Railroads's trustees to proceed with their plans for shutting down the 20,000mile system at the end of the month. The commission said it believed that the railroad is financially capable of continuing all of its train operations through the first quarter of 1974, and probably through the remainder of 1974,

title: QUANG TRI LEADER IS PLACED ON TRIAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1The Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu, which has been talking of a Communist offensive next year, today put on trial the brigadier general charged with fleeing before last year's North Vietnamese drive in Quang Tri Province.

title: SOCIALISTS GAIN IN FRENCH VOTING
description: PARIS, Oct. 1Final results of yesterday's cantonal, or county, elections in France showed today that the revived Socialist party has continued its surge forward, apparently overtaking the Communists as the strongest opposition group.

title: SENATE APPROVES $20.9 BILLION BILL TO PROCURE ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate approved today a $20.9billion military procurement bill after rejecting a lastminute proposal for an acrosstheboard $500million cut in the defense budget.

title: She Picks the Men Who Pose in Magazine's Centerfold
description: John W. Dean 3d said no, Fabian said yes, and Engelbert Humperdinck said may be. That was their response when a glamorous, strawberry blond, sometime Hollywood gossip columnist named Toni Holt called and asked them: Will you pose in the nude for Playgirl magazine?

title: Hockey Transactions WORLD ASSOCIATION.
description: LOS ANGELESAcquired Bill Horton, defenseman, from Cleveland for future consideration; Sent. Howie Heggedal and Guy Hildebrand to Greensboro of the Southern league.

title: Penn State Leads Poll
description: Undefeated Penn State, which beat Iowa, 27.8, Saturday for its third straight victory, continued as the unanimous choice in the weekly voting for the Lambert Trophy. The Nitany Lions received a maximum 80 points. West Virginia was second, with 72 points.

title: SOVIET GAS LINE OPENS IN BAVARIA
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1The Soviet Union today opened a naturalgas transmission line to West Germany that is part of a continuing effort to expand markets in Western Europe and ultimately in the United States for vast Soviet naturalgas resources.

title: Ehrlichman Linked Nixon to Sanction For Covert Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1President Nixon specifically authorized the use of covert tactics by White House assistants to gather information about Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, according to grand jury testimony by John D, Ehrlichman, formerly the President's chief domestic adviser.

title: Opera: Gay and Fag
description: Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana and Leoncavallo's Pagliacci returned to the New York City Opera repertory Sunday night in Frank Corsaro's double bill production, which continues to succeed in pinching these two weary warhorses into a semblance of youth.

title: Note to Readers
description: Starting in today's issues of The New York Times, overthecounter listings provided by the National Association of Securities Dealers have been selected on the basis of both volume and price, rather then solely on the basis of volume.

title: CURB ON FOREIGN AID FAILS SENATE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The Senate today rejected an attempt by liberals to cut off all United States financial support for the police, prisons and intelligence operations of foreign nations.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: WORLD ASSOCIATION

title: ERVIN SEES REFORM AS WATERGATE GAIN
description: Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. predicted here last night that the Watergate scandal would lead to electoral reform, including Congressional enactment of laws to prohibit cash contributions to candidates in Federal elections and to create a nonpartisan commission to supervise the contests.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PRATED The films shown Tuesdays at the Donnell Library Center, on West 53d Street, and on Wednesdays across the street at the Museum of Modern Art are political, polemical, often socially perverse. Which is what they're intended to be.

title: Prices on Amex Close Higher As the OTC List Moves Lower
description: Prices closed higher on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as steppedup trading at the closing bell pushed them up after being lackadaisical during most of the session. Prices closed lower in the overthecounter market, however.

title: Palestinians Warn Austria to Stay Firm
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1Palestinian guerrillas warned Austria today against going back on a commitment to discontinue transit facilities for Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union to Israel.

title: Rights of Press Defended On Watergate and Agnew
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Davis Taylor, board chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that newspapers in the United States had the right to report and comment as they saw fit on the Watergate affair and kickback charges against Vice President Agnew.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. 1 (AP)Thomas Keller, president of the International Rowing Federation, shocked the opening session of the Olympic Congress today with a charge the games have become an open exhibition of lying, free propaganda for politicians and a fashion show. Keller said the International Olympic Committee must either open the games to professionals or restrict them to genuine amateurs.

title: BUILDER FINED $1,000 FOR 3 EXTRA FLOORS
description: The ownerbuilder of a 36story apartment house at 300 East 34th Street was fined $1,000 yesterday for putting three additional stories on the building. The fine is the maximum that could have been imposed as prescribed by law.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Missing Lobster Boat Found After Large AirSea Search
description: SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me., Oct. 1 (AP)The largest airsea search in the New England area this year for a missing boat has ended in the location of a lobster boat off a Maine island, the Coast Guard said.

title: Silenced Former Cadet Hissed at Fort Benning
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 1 (AP)Lieut. James Pelosi, who drew national attention when it was disclosed that he endured more than a year of silencing as a cadet at West Point, was hissed by classmates today as he received his infantry officer's basic course diploma. Many members of the class of 380 were West Point graduates.

title: Displaced Amtrak Workers To Get Benefits for 6 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan announced today an agreement between Ambrack and rail unions to provide benefits for employes who are dismissed or demoted because of cutbacks in passenger service by the Governmentrun rail corporation.

title: 12 ACCUSED IN IRAN IN PLOT TO KILL SHAH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 2 (Reuters)The Iranian Government said today that it had uncovered a plot to assassinate the Shah of Iran during presentation ceremonies later this month to the makers of the best movies for children.

title: BATTLE IN VIETNAM IS BATTALIONSIZED
description: THANH DUC, South Vietnam, Oct. 2The Government military spokesman announced yesterday in Saigon that a regiment of Communist troops, supported by a Vietcong battalion, had attacked two Government battalions just northeast of here.

title: Mean Streets at Film Festival
description: No matter how bleak the milieu, no matter how heartbreaking the narrative, some films are so thoroughly, beautifully realized they have a kind of tonic effect that has no relation to the subject matter. Such a film is Mean Streets, the third feature film by Martin Scorsese, the oncepromising young director (Who's That Knocking at My Door? and Boxcar Bertha) who has now made an unequivocally firstclass film.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's 4,569 local election boards will be open today and tomorrow from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. and on Saturday, Oct. 13, from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. to register voters. To register, a person must be 18 years old on or before the Nov. 6 general election, have lived in this city or in his county outside the city for 30 days by Election Day and be a citizen.

title: Telephone Company to End 8 Cent Ripoff on Its Bills
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 (UPI) The Pacific Telephone Company said yesterday that it would no longer play along with the 8 cent ripoff.

title: AliFrazier Set Feb. 4
description: Nearly three years after their $20million extravaganza for the world heavyweight title, Joe Frazier and Muhammad All will meet in a 12round rematch at Madison Square Garden on Monday, Feb. 4.

title: GrieseWarfield Is Key Test for Jets' Pass Defenders on Sunday
description: The Jet pass defense, the worst in the National Football League last season and questionable at best at the start of this year, has distinguished itself in the first three games.

title: SIX DRUG JUSTICES NOT OF TOP RATING
description: Six of the 16 new Court of Claims appointees who will be sitting in the new narcotics courts as acting Supreme Court Justices did not receive the highest rating of qualified from Governor Rockefeller's new State Judicial Screening Committee, but instead were listed as qualified with reservations.

title: Books of The Times
description: ROSE, WHERE DID YOU GET THAT RED? Teaching Great Poetry to Children. By Kenneth Koch. 360 pages. Random House, $7.95.

title: Democrats Deny Rooney Backing for a 17th Term
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Brooklyn Democratic organization has informed Representative John J. Rooney, an ailing 69yearold legislator who is one of the most powerful men in Congress, that it will not support him if he seeks a 17th term.

title: REPUBLICANS VOTE IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 2Connecticut Republicans voted in primary elections in 18 of the state's 169 towns yesterday.

title: Agnew Counsel Reported To Seek Inquiry on Leaks
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2Vice President Agnew's lawyers will meet with Federal District Judge Walter E. Hoffman in secret tomorrow in a reported effort to set up an inquiry into leaks of information about the Agnew investigation, according to persons familiar with the case.

title: PRICES RAISED 14% ON VOLKSWAGENS
description: Volkswagen of America yesterday instituted a round of price increases for foreign cars sold in the United States, announcing a 14 per cent rise in list prices of 1974 models.

title: Conferees Set Increase For School Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2, (UPI)House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a 25 per cent increase in Federal aid to the school lunch program, with a promise of more money if Mood costs continue to rise.

title: Permanent Revolution
description: PEKING  A journalist is fated to follow the advice given by a Shanghai friend to Teilhard de Chardin: Write about China before you have been there too long; later you would break your pen.

title: A Malpractice Suit For Leg Amputation Brings $350,000
description: A Staten Island widow yesterday received the highest cash settlement ever awarded by the medical malpractice mediation panel of the State Supreme Court $350,000 for the amputation of her left leg by a orthopedic surgeon.

title: Stennis Stirs Dispute In Testimony to Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)Senator John C. Stennis told a Federal District Court jury today how he was shot and robbed last Jan. 30.

title: Telescope Grinding to Begin
description: VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 2 (AP)  Grinding of a 14ton telescope mirror blank will begin soon at the Dominion Astrophysical Observatory here, and it will be some three years before it is completed. The mirror blank will become the primary mirror for the 144inch telescope being built by the University of Hawaii, France and Canada atop the extinct volcano Mauna Kea, 14,000 feet above the Pacific on the island of Hawaii.

title: 80 City Teachers Take First Steps in Learning How to Teach Dancing
description: Peter Gennaro's method of teaching dancing is to catch his students unawares. He has them take a few light steps, bouncing up and down in place in time to the music and glide around in a circle. Before they know it, they find themselves in the middle of jazz dance routines far more complicated than any they would have thought they could manage.

title: Senators Decry Nixon Plan on Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 President Nxon's proposal to replace most housing programs for the poor with an experimental program of cash subsidies met strong opposition today from Senate Democrats in its first Congressional hearing.

title: Nurmi, Star Runner of the '20's, Dies
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 2Paavo Nurmi, the celebrated long distance runner of the nineteentwenties, died here today. He was 76 years old and had been in declining health for several years.

title: People and Business
description: Charles F. Knight, who joined the Emerson Electric Company last December, has been named chief executive officer of the St. Louisbased electric and electronics manufacturer.

title: A Popular Route in London: Down and Across, Rapidly
Study Group for Maine
description: AUGUSTA. Me., Oct. 2 (AP) Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis created today a 21member study group to review correctional programs in Maine.

title: ExCity Official Says He's Homosexual
description: Dr. Howard J. Brown, the Lindsay administration's first Health Services Administrator, openly acknowledged his homosexuality in an interview yesterdayin an effort, he said, to end the prejudice homosexuals face in obtaining employment.

title: Finally Some Plain Talk
description: Maybe the most hopeful sign in Washington these days is that officials are beginning to say in public what in the first Nixon term they hesitated to say even in private.

title: Detroit Utility Is Ordered to Pay $4Million to Black Workers
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2A Federal fudge ordered the Detroit Edison Company today to pay $4million in punitive damages to blacks who, according to the judge's finding, have been victims of deliberate and invidious racial discrimination by the utility.

title: WHITEONLY RULE DROPPED BY ELKS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, its liquor permits imperiled by its racially exclusive membership laws, has voted to accept persons of all races.

title: Paavo Nurmi Dies
description: Paavo Nurmi, the Finnish distance runner who won nine gold medals in the Olympics in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday in Helsinki at the age of 76, Details on Page 1.

title: Civilian P.O.W. Aid Pushed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to increase benefits payable to civilians held prisoner during the war in Southeast Asia to $150 a month. The benefits now total $60 a month.

title: Army Added to Suit to Save 600 Beagles in Experiment
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UPI)The National AntiVivisection Society announced yesterday that it would amend an earlier complaint to include the Army in a suit to save 600 beagles from military tests.

title: Marchi, Blumenthal Make a Joint Tour
description: The Republican and Liberal candidates for Mayoraided by joint swarms of elbowingnewsmenturned a supposed joint crime factfinding tour into a joint handshaking tour through a squalid section of the South Bronx yesterday.

title: Rep. Findley Seeking to Force House Vote on Agnew Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, said today that he would seek a vote of the full House of Representatives if necessary to force an inquiry into whether the Vice President has committed impeachable offenses.

title: Youth Awarded $1.6Million
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UPI)A Cook County Judge awarded $1.6million today to Jerome Lisiecki, 18 years old; who suffered brain damage and paralysis in the crash of an Illinois Central Gulf. Railroad train in 1972. Circuit Court Judge Nicholas J. Bua said the award, which was agreed to by the Illinois Central, was the largest in Illinois history.

title: SIX DRUG JUSTICES NOT OF TOP RATING
description: Six of the 16 new Court of Claims appointees who will be sitting in the new narcotics courts as acting Supreme Court Justices did not receive the highest rating of qualified from Governor Rockefeller's new State Judicial Screening Committee, but instead were listed as qualified with reservations.

title: Gold Views of South Africans Changing
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 2South Africa does not mind being called a nation of gold bugs as long as it can call its opponents chrysophobes  haters of gold.

title: Segretti to Face Senators Today In an Inquiry Into Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate Watergate committee resumes its hearings tomorrow with testimony from Donald H. Segretti, who was hired by White House aides to disrupt the campaigns of candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Meadow Stable Riddle: Will They or Won't They?
description: Will they or won't they? That was the question at Belmont Park yesterday as the focus continued on Meadow Stable's two crack colts, Secretariat and Riva Ridge. Both are eligible for next Monday's $100,000 added Man o' War. Will both compete? Two days ago, Lucien Laurin, the capable Meadow trainer said he felt that both of the Meadow stars probably would take part in the 15th running of the 1mile turf feature. Mrs. Helen (Penny) Tweedy was standing by and listening.

title: Entertainment Events Today
Dairy Chain to Cut Prices As ShortMeasure Penalty
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Cumberland Farms dairy store chain will return at least $17,500 to customers to compensate for the alleged sale of short measure for half gallon milk containers in Massachusetts, State Attorney General Robert H. Quinn said yesterday.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: CLEVELANDAssigned Doug Brindley, center; Ted Hodgson, right wing; Ralph Hopiavouri, Jim McMasters, defensemen; Brad Buetow, left wing, and Yves Belanger, goalie, to Jacksonville of the American League.

title: APPRAISAL IS ASKED ON A NIXON ESTATE
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 2 (UPI)  The Orange County board of supervisors voted today to ask the State Board of Equalization to appraise the value of President Nixon's property at the Western White House in San Clemente.

title: Soviet Honors Spacemen
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP)The Soviet Union conferred high honors today on the two astronauts who successfully completer a twoday space flight aboard the Soyuz 12. Commander Vasily Lazarev and the flight engineer, Oleg Makarov, became Heroes of the Soviet Union and received the Order of Lenin and gold star medals, Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced.

title: JERSEY CHECKING MERCURY LEVELS
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2  State Environmental officials disclosed tonight that they were attempting to learn if New Jersey inland waters near Atlantic City were dangerously contaminated by mercury.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: TriCounty Women Top Jersey Golfers
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 2The Women's TriCounty Golf Association defeated the Garden State Women's Golf Association, 21 to 8, today in their annual betterball team Match played on the 5,451yard, par 37, 3673 course at Ridgeway Country Club.

title: Ancient Bellevue Is New Building
description: A 25story, $160million concrete and glass building, stheduled to open next month, will bring the ancient rambling Complex known as Bellevue into the age of modern hospitals.

title: Biaggi Visits Willowbrook
description: The Conservative mayoral candidate, Representative Mario Biaggi, shook hands at the ferry terminal on Staten Island and then visited the Willowbrook State School.

title: The Theater: Crown Matrimonial
description: Royce Ryton's Crown Matrimonial is a strongly conceived historical drama of variable impact. This London import, which opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theater, is the first major offering of the somewhat sluggardly Broadway season.

title: $6.5Million Grant Will Help Columbia Build Biology Center
description: Columbia University announced yesterday the receipt of a $6.5million grant from the Fairchild Foundation that will permit beginning construction next spring of a $12million, sevenstory life sciences building.

title: Butz Crisscrossing Country as Most Visible and Audible Nixon Domestic Aide
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  There are a lot of people these days wondering why the Secretary of Agriculture has not been canned, said Dr. Earl L. Butz, speaking of himself.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The versatile, moderatepriced plastic shelving system that Ernesto Gismondi brought to town the other day is child's play to assemble. Or so claims everyone at Artemidi/USA, a division of Burlington Industries, Inc.

title: Astronauts Feeling Weak But Are Adapting Quickly
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Skylab 2 astronauts said today that they were still experienclug feelings of weakness from their 59 days in space but the recordholding space tray. elers said they were rapidly readapting to earth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What the Vice President has done, as lawyers would call it, is to attempt to change the venue; when someone whom you oppose does it, it is called forum shopping. Sometimes this is a legitimate attempt to escape a hostile and prejudiced tribunal; sometimes it is a flight to a friendly, benign one.

title: PRICE RISES SHARP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: In sharply steppedup trading, prices rose markedly along a broad front on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as well as in the overthecounter market.

title: Drinking Age Lowered
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UPI) As of 12:01 A.M. yesterday bartenders and saloon keepers in Illinois had a new clientele 19 and 20yearolds; A new law allows them to drink beer and wine but maintains the previous legal drinking age of 21 for those wishing to drink hard liquor.

title: Samuel Baron, a Labor Leader In Textile Industry, Dies at 70
description: Samuel Baron, a former vice president of the Textile Workers Union of America and high official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters until an incident with the then president, James R. Hoffa, in 1962, died yesterday in Miami, where he had been living. He was 70 years old.

title: ATTACK IS RENEWED ON FAIR TRADE ACT
description: The state's Fair Trade Act came under renewed attack yesterday at a hearing sponsored jointly by the Assembly Commerce. Committee and the Senate Select Committee on Consumer Protection.

title: Ruckelshaus Brings Maid Into U.S. on Apparently Illegal Visa
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2William D. Ruckelshaus, the Deputy Attorney General, and his wife, Jill, a White House consultant, brought a young Finnish woman into the United States last June to work in their household and help are for their five children, *Suiting in an apparent violation of the immigration laws.

title: Dave Anderson
description: About two weeks ago, when the New York Mets were beginning to perform their miracle of changing water in the basement into champagne in the clubhouse, somebody asked Yogi Berra if he had heard any encouraging words from the front office.

title: MUSIC MEDIATOR SEES LONG STRIKE
description: They are worlds apart, and it looks like a long strike.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Paintings, manuscripts, imperial artifacts and calligraphy from 17thcentury Persia, including a letter from Shah 'Abbas to King Charles I of England, will be shown in an exhibition at Asia House Gallery from Oct. 11 through Dec. 2. The exhibition, called Shah 'Abbas and the Arts of Isfahan, was prepared by Asia House in collaboration with Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum. Gathered by Prof. Anthony Welch of the University of Victoria in British Columbia, the show is supported by a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: BREZHNEV TO VISIT INDIA NEXT MONTH
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 2.India announced today that Leonid I. Brezhnev would make an official visit here in the latter part of November at the invitation of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. No specific date was announced.

title: Level of Mercury Pollution In State Waters Is Studied
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2  State Environmental officials disclosed tonight that they were attempting to learn if New Jersey inland waters near Atlantic City were dangerously contaminated by mercury.

title: The Lambs, in Debt, Petitions for Reorganization
description: The Lambs, the actors' club at 130 West 44th Street, filed a petition for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act yesterday morning in Federal Court seeking temporary relief from its current indebtedness. Thee club listed liabilities of $567,011 and assets of $463,399 as of last July 31.

title: Nets Down Knicks, 9787
description: In an atmosphere more reminicent of a playoff game than an exhibition, the Nets defeated the Knacks, 9787, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Cahill Asks Improvements In Worker Compensation
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2Governor Cahill said today he intended to push for reform of New Jersey's Workmen's Compensation Law when the Legislature returned on Nov. 12.

title: CAIRO APPROVES AUSTRIA ATTACK
description: CAIRO, Oct. 2The Arab commando raid that impelled the Austrian Government to announce a suspension of special transit arrangements for groups of Soviet Jews going to Israel has won the official approval of the Egyptian Government.

title: Strike Authorized At the Modern Art; Mediation Goes On
description: Strike action against the Musuem of Modern Art has been authorized by members of its union of professional and administrative workers, which has been working without a contract since June 30.

title: A New Issue Snags Talks to End Strike At Catholic Schools
description: Negotiations aimed at ending the 12day strike by lay teachers against eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens hit a new snag yesterday, this time over the issue of job security.

title: Ammunition Figures Show Active Saigon Air Force
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2In the first six months after the signing of the Paris peace agreement, the United States provided the South Vietnamese Air Force with 142,000 bombs, rockets and flares and 13.8 million rounds of smallarms ammunition, according to American military officials.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: A Regular and a Reformer Win Special Court Primary
description: A regular Democrat and a Reform Democrat won nominations for Civil Court seats in a special primary el ction yesteray. The primary, in Manhattan's Third Judicial District on the West Side, ha been ordered by State Supreme Court JusTice Abraham J. Gelinoff, who rfuled invalid 642 votes in the original primary last June.

title: Traffic Just Rolls Along On West Side Highway
description: Traffic was light and the Crack was fast yesterday morning on the West Side Highway, where major repairs are under way.

title: 2 Held in Florida In Capital Slaying Of Seven Moslem
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 2 (AP) Two men sought in conned tion with the mass slaying her last January of seven Hanaf Moslems were arrested today in Jacksonville, Fla., the Fed. eral. Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Wehner's Berlin Gaffe
description: Why Herbert Wehnerof all peoplefelt moved during a visit to the Soviet Unionof all placesto blast his own West German Government's stand on Berlin is a kingsized enigma. Mr. Wehner's charge that Bonn had pushed the Soviet bloc too hard for concessions on West Berlin is bound to embarrass Chancellor Brandt and Foreign Minister Scheel, and to handicap their effort to get their stalled Ostpolitik moving again.

title: SENATE, 54 TO 42, VOTES $12BILLION FOR FOREIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate approved a $1.2billion foreign assistance bill today by a vote of 54 to 42 after resisting two attempts to trim the authorization sharply.

title: Bridge: ??ans' Foes for World Title Are Likely to Be Aces Again
description: The Italian world champions will defend their title on their home ground next May, and their chief rivals, for the third straight year, are likely to be the Aces.

title: Old Haunt of Literati, Costello's, Is Closing
description: It must have been about 25 years ago, to hear John Gallagher tell it, that Ernest Hemingway broke a sturdy cane over his own head in Costello's restaurant on Third Avenue.

title: SOVIET DOCTORS ASSAIL CRITICISM
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2Twentyone Soviet psychiatrists and neuropathologists today denounced charges that Soviet mental hospitals were being used to punish political dissenters.

title: James Roosevelt Backs Fuchsberg
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic candidate for chief judge, was endorsed yesterday by James Roosevelt, the former Congressman from California who hailed him as one of the most respected trial lawyers in the country.

title: Seoul's Students Hold First Protest Since Martial Law
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 2 The first open resistance to the Government of President Park Chung Hee since he declared martial law a year ago erupted today in a small but vigorous student demonstration here.

title: Egeberg to Head New Unit On Alcohol and Drug Abuse
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (UPI)The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Caspar W. Weinberger, has named Dr. Roger O. Egeberg, former dean of the University of Southern California Medical School, as interim head of the newly created Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration.

title: BEATRICE KONHEIM, DEAN AT HUNTER, 64
description: Dr. Beatrice G. Konheim dean of the Institute of Health Sciences at Hunter College and a faculty member for 43 years, died Monday at New York; Hospital. Her age was 64 and she lived at 500 East 77th Street.

title: 20 Food Concerns Are Cited For Violating City Health Code
description: The City Health Department has released the names of 20 more resturants and other foodhandling outlets in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that had persisted after two inspections.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WAYNE, Oct. 2Paul Cavalier, who has toiled before thousands of sports spectators during a long career, will face the crowd again.

title: Test Rocket for Planetary Exploration Rolled Out
description: The test version of a new rocket for planetary exploration, including the first American robot landings on Mars in 1976, was rolled out last week to its launching pad at Cape Kennedy, Fla.

title: Defense Unlimited?
description: America's war in Southeast Asia is at an end, and limitations on strategic armaments are in effect between the United States and the Soviet Union. But the old habits of the Cold War, of blank checks for a military establishment which thrives on a momentum of its own, seem still to overpower all efforts to reorder national priorities when the Congress comes to the moment of voting on defense spending.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1973

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Regulatory Power on Cigarettes By New Safety Agency in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The chairman of the Consumer Product Safety. Commission acknowledged today that the new Federal agency may lack regulatory authority over cigarettes.

title: BIDS ON TEXAS OIL SWELL SCHOOL FUND
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 2Bids on Texas oil and gas leases today resulted in $21,471,657.61 going to the state's Permanent School Fund, pushing the endowment fund to more than $1billion.

title: General at Quang Tri Sentenced to 5 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2Brig. Gen. Vu Van Giai today was found guilty of abandoning his post as commander of the Third Division at Quang Tri during the Communists' 1972 offensive and was sentenced to five years' hard labor.

title: Rockefeller Urges RentIncrease Study For Vacated Units
description: Governor Rockefeller, whose administration succeeded two years ago in winning passage for a controversial law that removes vacated apartments from rent control, called yesterday for a state commission to examine, the rentincrease situation in these inflationary times and to recommend possible state action in this area.

title: CHILE TO IMPORT. U.S. FILMS BAD
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 2Chile's military junta announced today that it would import 15 American films this week, putting an end to the black night of Marxist cinema here.

title: Advertising: NewModel Time
description: From the look of your favorite television tube these days you'd think that Detroit had really beefed up its advertising spending. Don't be misled, its just the usual new molel introduction time splash.

title: Stewart Choice Sunday
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 2 (UPI)Jackie Stewart, the threetime world driving champion, was named the favorite today in balloting by auto racing experts to win Sunday's United States Grand Prix at the Watkins Glen Road Course. Stewart of Scotland is seeking his sixth Grand Prix victoty of the year.

title: They're All Deaf but, as a Family, They Don't Feel Handicapped
description: When someone climbs the rather steep flight of steps bordered by flowers and shrubs and rings the doorbell at a certain house in Flushing, a light embedded in a wall here, a ceiling there, or perhaps in an archway, flashes on, no matter how bright the day. For this is the home of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hlibok (pronounced LIEbock) and they and their four children are deaf.

title: OilConsuming Countries Press for Pooling Accord
description: PARIS, Oct. 2  Major oil consuming nations are pressing negotiations for an agreement under which they would pool their petroleum supplies in order to deal with any emergencies in case of production disturbances.

title: Marriage in the Fifties
description: This is an excerpt from a novelinprogress, My Life as a Man. It is derived from the chapter called Marriage  la Mode that appears in the current issue of American Review. In the novel, the protagonist is reflecting upon the social conditions that existed at the time of his own marriage.

title: LOTTERY CHANGES PLANNED BY STATE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The New Jersey Lottery Commission, which has proposed changing the prize structure of the weekly lottery, is also studying a possible change in the daily lottery's prize setup.

title: AUSTRIAN REJECTS MRS. MEIR'S PLEAS ON TRANSIT ROUTES
description: VIENNA, Oct. 2  Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria conferred for nearly two hours today, but were unable to reach any agreement on facilities for the continued transit of Soviet Jews through Austria.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Costello's, the Third Avenue bar that catered to James Thurber, Ernest Hemingway, John O'Hara, A. J. Liebling and others seeking shelter from life's cares, is about to be closed.

title: 2 SIDES IN LAOS NAME OVERSEERS OF PEACE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 2 (UPI)The two sides in the long Laotian civil war today named powerful men as cochairmen of a committee to oversee the ceasefire and political settlement signed last month.

title: Beame to Miss Liberals' Dinner Tonight
description: Hundreds of Liberals and Democrats will come to the aid of the Liberal party tonight at its annual fundraising event just a month before a mayoral election that will mark a crucial point in the party's 29year history and its long and often stormy relationship with the Democratic party.

title: TV: Witty Miss Hepburn in Debut
description: In two solo sessions with Dick Cavett, presented last night and tonight on the American Boardcasting Company network, Katharine Hepburn discusses herself and her career with enough wit, intelligence, humor and typical Hepburn vitality to leave the average talkshow personality speechless. In fact, that is just about what she does to Mr. Cavett, and the result is all to the good.

title: People in Sports: Lakers Lure West Into the Fold
description: The Los Angeles Lakers are breathing easier today. Though he said he still wasn't happy about some rookies getting more pay this year than he received, Jerry West has ended his holdout with the National Basketball Association team. The 35yearold West, in the second year of a contract reportedly calling for $300,000 a year, had been seeking a renegotiation, but he apparently has agreed to return. at the current rate of pay.

title: MRS. S. G. CHURCHILL
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 2Mrs. Mary Ellen Peck Churchill, a geneticist, and the wife of S. Garton Churchill, a retired New York lawyer and championship bridge player, died yesterday at her home here. She was 69 years old.

title: U.S., Soviet Arms Talks Held
description: GENEVA, Oct. 2 (UPI)United States and Soviet negotiators today held their 37th meeting in the second round of the talks on the limitation of strategic arms. The second round began Nov. 21 last year, recessed for the summer and resumed Sept. 25. Today's meeting was the third since the resumption.

title: Local Chrysler Strikes Set
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2 (UPI) Strike deadlines of 10 A.M. Wednesday were in effect at six Chrysler plants today over local issues that were not resolved with the new national contract between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation. But agreements at four other key Chrysler plants were reached shortly before scheduled walk outs.

title: Foreman Speeds Up Vikings
description: Coach Bud Grant and several of his players went duck shooting yesterday morning. Grant, an outdoorsman all his life in his native Minnesota, arranges the Viking practice schedule so mornings can be spent in duck blinds. That is one unique feature of this interesting and very good football team now going through a change of character. It is different because of the addition of one new player, Chuck Foreman. The rookie running back from the University of Miami has been compared somewhat extravagantly to Gale Sayers but, says Grant, he gives us a whole new dimension.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Equity Financing
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company: Announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 2,000,000 shares of common stock. The First Boston Corporation and Drexel Burnham and Company, Inc., were named managers of the underwriting group.

title: Nixon Delays Trip Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  President Nixon will not make a decision about a visit to Europe until after Secretary of State Kissinger completes his trip there later this month, the White House said today. He indicated to Italian tourists last night that the trip could come in about two or three months.

title: STATION MAY SUE ON TV ANTENNAS
description: WXTV (Channel 41), a Spanishlanguage television station here, said yesterday it was considering a suit to force the Port Authority to live up to is 1967 contract to place the antennas of the city's 10 TV stations atop the World Trade enter.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CINCINNATIAcquired Steve Keeley, righthanded pitcher, from Chicago White Sox to complete deal that sent Jim McGlothlin, righthanded pitcher, to White Sox last August.

title: Seaver Is Doubtful on Starting Playoffs
description: The New York Mets, again amazing after three years of third place, took the day off yesterday to savor their farfetched victory in baseball's most intricate race.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: ExCity Official Says He's Homosexual
description: Dr. Howard J. Brown, the Lindsay administration's first Health Services Administrator, openly acknowledged his homosexuality in an interview yesterdayin an effort, he said, to end the prejudice homosexuals face in obtaining employment.

title: Soviet Supersonic Bombers Appear in Iraq for the First Time
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Soviet Union in recent weeks has sent about a dozen TU22 supersonic bombers to Iraq in what American, officials interpret primarily as a psychological move to enhance Soviet credibility in the Arab world.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HAYDN SEEK There's a new cocktailhour series of onehour chamber music recitals, The First Wednesday (it will take place the first Wednesday of each month through May) starting today at 5:40 in Cami Hall, 165 West 57th Street (JU 24090).

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS PERSICO CLEARED
description: Federal Judge John R. Bartels yesterday dismissed an indictment charging Carmine Persico and three other alleged Mafia figures with conspiring to help Joseph Russo, one of the defendants, to escape prosecution for murder.

title: Amex Moves Ahead on Options Project
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday said that it was moving forward on a top priority basis with its plan to initiate trading in stock options and hoped to begin its pilot project by Dec. 10.

title: Bolshoi Opera Set To Perform Here For 4 Weeks in '75
description: The Bolshoi Opera of Moscow is scheduled to present a fourandahalfweek season of Russian operas at the Metropolitan Opera House in the summer of 1975.

title: A.&P. REGISTERS 2DQUARTER LOSS
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company set a sales record in its second quarter, reporting] $1,659,000 in revenues, but the troubled supermarket chain lapsed into red ink following a profitable first quarter, the company reported yesterday.

title: CHINA, IN U.N., SEES GLOBAL DISORDER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2Chinain a speech sharply critical of the United States, the Soviet Union and, for the first time, the United Nationstoday characterized the world situation as one of great disorder.

title: Columbia Gets $6.5Million for Biology Building
description: Columbia University announced yesterday the receipt of a $6.5million grant from the Fairchild Foundation that will permit beginning construction next spring of a $12million, sevenstory life sciences building.

title: 2 Escapees Held in Killing Of 6 Persons in Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (UPI)Six persons, including a, minister and his two teenaged children, were shot to death and two other persons were wounded early today, and the police said that two escapees from a Federal court jail had been arrested in connection with the slayings.

title: Social Security for Severe Illness Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  A bill that would have the Social Security system cover the Leavy costs of catastrophic illless and replace Medicaid with a far more comprehensive program of medical benefits for 34 million low income people was Introduced today by. 14 Senators on a bipartisan basis.

title: Democrats Deny Rooney Backing for a 17th Term
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Brooklyn Democratic organization has informed Representative John J. Rooney, an ailing 69yearold legislator who is one of the most powerful men in Congress that it will not support him if he seeks a 17th term.

title: Vandalism Is Linked to Design of Schools
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 2A sociologist said here today that much of what is called school vandalism is the product less of malice among children than of failure among adults to design schools properly and understand how young people use them.

title: Dealers Stage a Protest Against Gas Price Curb
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 2 (UPIAbout 200 blueshirted gasoline station dealers in Monroe County staged a demonstration outside the. Federal Building yesterday to protest against Federal pricecontrol guidelines.

title: Professional Football
3 Mexicans Die in Gun Fight With U.S. Border, Patrolmen
description: TACUMBA, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP)Three Mexicans believed to be delivering marijuana were killed today in a gun battle with United States border patrolmen. One of the offeat was wounded.

title: Oil Pipeline Concept Predated 1967 War
description: The projected oil pipeline through Egypt from the Gulf of Suez to the Mediterranean will bypass the blocked Suez Canal geographically, but will not take its place. It will transport only a portion of the tonnage that used to pass through the canal and now goes around the Cape of Good Hope.

title: Recently Published Books
description: A Prayer for Katerina Horovitzova, by Arnost Lustig, translated from the Czech by Jeanne Nemcova (Harper & Row, $5.95). What happened to a group of wealthy American Jewsin the hands of the Nazis.

title: House Votes $50Million for Propaganda Radios
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House agreed today to continue operations of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, despite protests that Americanfinanced propaganda stations have outlived their usefulness.

title: Heart Transplant Fails
description: PARIS, Oct. 2 (AP)A 40yearold gardener who received a new heart last Friday died today when the transplanted organ failed. Andre Lefrancos'transplant was the third to fail of five performed since last January by Dr. Daniel Guilmet.

title: Canada Cuts Payments Gap
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 2 (Reuters, Canada's Balance of Pay ments deficit narrowed to $3million in the second quartet from $253million in the first quarter, revised Government figures showed today. Statistics Canada said unadjusted capita movements led to a net inflow of $30million in the second quarter, a decline of $334million from the $364million in the first quarter.

title: Tokyo's 7 Orchestras Fight to Survive
description: TOKYO, Oct. 2It was about a year and a half ago that the Japan Philharmonic Orchestra disbanded as the result of a strike. That left Tokyo with five fullsized symphony orchestras.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that if elected Mayor, he would name Representative Herman Badillo to head a cabinetlevel committee that would seek to ease tensions among ethnic, economic and social groups within the city.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ABITIBI INCREASES NEWSPRINT PRICES
description: Prices of newsprint, homeheating oil, milk, sheets and pillowcases and copper were raised yesterday in a series of actions announced here and in Canada.

title: Burglary CoverUp Is Laid To Deputy Chief in Albany
description: ALBANY, Oct. 2A deputy chief of the Albany Police Department, investigating a report that policemen had broken into and looted a tire store, assured his men that we would try to cover this up, according to the chief's internal police report released today by the State Commission of Investigation.

title: OncePrivate CourtNominee Hearing Becomes a Contentious Open Meeting
description: The discreet, private hearing process on court appointees that has been the state's tradition ended with some raised voices yesterday as the State Senate Judiciary Committee, meeting in, public session here, heard charges that Court of Claims Judge Rose. L. Rubin of Queens was unqualified for the bench.

title: L.I. Town Is Suing Over Lost Wetlands
description: MANHASSET, L, I., Oct. 2Citing Dutch royal patents dated 1644 and 1685, the Town of North Hempstead started a suit today in State Supreme Court in Mineola, seeking $10million from persons and corporations that allegedly filled wetlands that the town asserted it owned.

title: RevenueSharing Funds Delayed by Paper Work
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)  The Government is holding $119million in revenuesharing checks, including payments for Chicago, Cleveland and Miami Beach, because local officials failed to complete required paper work, the Office of Revenue Sharing said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A total of 10,000 youngsters will receive free tickets to 20 Madison Square Garden games of the New York Golden Blades of the World Hockey Association under a program announced yesterday. The announcement was made by Louis Roddis Jr., vice chairman of Consolidated Edison Company, and Ralph Brent, president of the Golden Blades, formerly the New York Raiders.

title: CAIRO APPROVES AUSTRIA ATTACK
description: CAIRO, Oct. 2The Arab commando raid that impelled the Austrian Government to announce a suspension of special transit arrangements for groups of Soviet Jews going to Israel has won the official approval of the Egyptian Government.

title: C. Arnholt Smith Wins Rulings In Government Financial Battle
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 2 (UPI)C. Arnholt Smith, the financier, won two rounds against the Government yesterday. A Federal judge ordered suspension of grand jury proceedings against him and quashed attempts to collect immediately on a $22.8million tax lien.

title: Some Stamford Policemen Involved in Audit by I.R.S.
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 2 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service is investigating the tax returns of several members of the city police department.

title: AUSTRIAN REJECTS MRS, MEIR'S PLEAS ON TRANSIT ROUTES
description: VIENNA, Oct. 2  Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria conferred for nearly two hours today, but were unable to reach any agreement on facilities for the continued transit of Soviet Jews through Austria.

title: Britain Agrees to Pull Frigates From Icelandic Area
description: LONDON, Oct. 2The British Government yielded today to an ultimatum from Iceland and agreed to withdraw its naval frigates from disputed fishing waters.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Decline; U.S. Treasury Issues Irregular
description: Corporate bond prices were lower yesterday and Government issues were mixed.

title: Exchanges in Canada Back New Rate Proposal
description: Canada's major stock exchanges have agreed on a new schedule of commission rates designed to produce increased revenue for securities firms. The increase will be somewhat less than the 5.24 per cent that the Ontario Securities Commission said earlier it was prepared to approve.

title: Congress Fails to Dampen U.S.Soviet Trade Talks
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2Top Soviet and American officials and corporate executives made a deliberate show today of ignoring Congressional obstacles to press ahead with new programs for promoting expansion of SovietAmerican trade.

title: Granatelli Out of STP Driver's Seat
description: Andy Granatelli, one of the sports world's dominant and successful personalities, has had his contract with STP terminated because of differences with his board of directors, StudebakerWorthington, Inc. controls 55 per cent of STP. The move is comparable to having Henry Ford 2d kicked out of Ford Motor Company.

title: I Will Not Resign
description: Vice President Agnew has repeatedly charged that his constitutional rights have been violated by leaks of allegations made against him in the course of the Federal investigation into possible bribery, extortion and tax fraud. To the extent that such rumors and allegations have been allowed to breach the secrecy of the judicial process, there can be little doubtas we have noted beforethat Mr. Agnw's complaints are justified. Such violations whether they had their source in the grand jury room, the Justice Department or, as has repeatedly been hinted, in the White Housecannot be condoned.

title: Falcon Owner Not Ready To Dismiss Van Brocklin
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (AP)Rankin Smith, owner of the Atlanta Falcons, expressed bitter disappointment at his team's showing against the Detroit Lions last night, but said today he wasn't ready to fire Coach Norm Van Brocklin just yet.

title: JOHN W. CORE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2John W. Core, lawyer and speial agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who retired from Government service in 1962, died Saturday of a heart attack on his farm near Sadieville, Scott County. His age was 61.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Cahill signed an executive order yesterday setting up a board of trustees for a pilot project aimed at improving healthcare services in Newark. The federally financed projectthe Newark Comprehensive Health Services Planwas approved in September, 1972, by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The State Department of Institutions and Agencies will oversee the administration of the program.

title: Ivy Shocks Send Calculators to the Ouija Board
description: The 1973 football season is still in its infancy but the form players already have discarded their careful calculations in favor of the ouija board.

title: Bandwagon Rush
description: Most of the leaders of political reform in this city appear to have decided that the mayoral election can be dispensed with this year. The multiplicity of hitherto undetected virtues they are discovering in. Controller Abraham D. Beame reflects their conviction that he nas the mayoralty won a full month before anyone goes to the polls and that the course of wisdom for them is to scramble aboard his bandwagon now.

title: SENATE, 54 TO 42, VOTES $12BILLION FOR FOREIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate approved a $1.2billion foreign assistance bill today by a vote of 54 to 42 after resisting two attempts to trim the authorization sharply.

title: Yields Show Sharp Decline At Fannie Mae's Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (Renters)Yields on both Governmentbacked and conventional mortgages fell sharply at this week's Federal National Mortgage Asociation auction.

title: Stern Will Set Up Force to Investigate MailOrder Frauds
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney here, says he plans to establish a special task force to scrutinize the practices of more than 100 mailorder businesses accused of defrauding consumers throughout the state.

title: Genevieve Berns, Headed ThorntonDonovan School
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 2  Mrs. Genevieve Francisco Berns, an English teacher at the ThorntonDonovan School here, which she headed from 1958 to 1968, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. She was 85 years old.

title: Nurmi, Star Runner of the '20's, Dies
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 2Paavo Nurmi, the celebrated longdistance runner of the nineteentwenties, died here today. He was 76 years old and had been in declining health for several years.

title: 57 Defendants Removed From Suit on Daley Ouster
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UPI)A Judge has dismissed 57 delegates to the 1972 Democratic National Convention as defendants in a suit that charges they illegally ousted Mayor Richard J. Daley and regular Illinois Democrats from the convention.

title: Aaron's Feats in Season Pass Beyond Home Runs
description: Just how fantastic a performance Hank Aaron turned in during 1973 is only now beginning to sink in as statisticians dig through his accomplishments.

title: MARGARET CRESSON, SCULPTOR, 84, DEAD
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2  Mrs. Margaret French Cresson, daughter of the sculptor Daniel Chester French and herself a sculptor, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack. She was 84 years old and lived at Chesterwood, the family estate here.

title: Citizens Budget Unit Backs Bond Issue
description: The Citizens Budget Commission recommended strongly yesterday that voters approve the $3.5billion transportation bond issue on the Nov, 6 ballot.A report made public by Roderic L. O'Connor, the commission president, said approval would safeguard the present 35cent fare through 1975, would maintain commuter fares at their present levels, provide funds for the construction and rehabilitation of transportation facilities and commit the state to assist the city and other localities in operating their masstransit systems.

title: Islanders Battle Rangers to a 66 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 2  By sheer pluck the New York Islanders fought the New York Rangers to a 66 tie in a National Hockey League exhibition game tonight.

title: Margaret Mead Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, proposed today creation of intimate wildernesses in the midst of urban areas to bring modern man closer to the natural world and, thus, closer to himself. The 71yearold scholar's remarks came in an address at a meeting of the National Recreation and Park Association.

title: Otepka Says Nixon Nominee for Treasury Post Leaked Information to the Press
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2A former security evaluator for the State Department charged today that Helmut Sonnenfeldt the White House nominee for Under Secretary of the Treasury, had leaked classified in formation to the late Robert F. Kennedy and to numerous members of the Washington press corps.

title: Farmer Jobless Aid Vetoed
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct: 2 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan vetoed legislation today to extend unemployment benefits to 225,000 farm workers. Mr. Reagan said enactment of the bill would have the effect of increasing fod prices for California consumers.

title: Newcombe Triumphs By 62, 62
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 2 (UPI)John Newcombe, the United States Open champion, won his firstround match in the $50,000 Colonial tennis tournament today by defeating Charlie Owens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., 62, 62.

title: COPPER FUTURES RISE ON RUMORS
description: Rumorsmainly false, as it turned outdominated trading in copper futures yesterday, causing prices to push ahead.

title: Move Pressed to Undevelop Switzerland and Cut Alien Labor
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 27 Valentin Oehen is leader of the parliamentary group of the movement he founded and heads, the Nationale Aktion gegen die. Uberfremdung von Volk and Heimat.

title: Ralston Joins Norton Simon Empire
description: Roy Halston Frowick, widely acclaimed as this country's most influential designer, has been acquired by Norton Simon Inc., one of the country's largest diversified companies.

title: Agnew Counsel Reported To Seek Inquiry on Leaks
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2Vice President Agnew's lawyers will meet with Federal District Judge Walter E. Hoffman in secret tomorrow in a reported effort to set up an inquiry into leaks of information about the Agnew investigation, according to persons familiar with the case.

title: Mail by Stagecoach Slower But Not Mach
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2How slow is the mail? Slower, maybe, than a horsedrawn stagecoach?

title: Market Closes Stronger; DowJones Climbs 7.97
description: The stock market closed strong yesterday and reached its highest closing since April 19. Electronic, oils and specialty issues featured the day's trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Nottingham of Colts Traded to Dolphins
description: BALTIMORE, Oct, 2 (AP)  The Baltimore Colts announced today they had obtained Hubert Ginn, a running back, from the Miami Dolphins in exchange for Don Nottingham, a running back, and a sixthround draft choice.

title: PRICES RAISED 14% ON VOLKSWAGENS
description: Volkswagen of America yesterday instituted a round of price increases for foreign cars sold in the United States, anflouncing a 14 per cent rise in list prices of 1974 models.

title: Kleindienst Says U.S. Aide Misled Him in Texas Case
description: DALLAS, Oct. 2  Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst testified in a hearing here today that the United States Attorney for South Texas, Anthony J. P. Farris, did not follow instructions in granting immunity to the central figure in a Texas stock scandal that rocked the state government in 1971.

title: Township Reports More Girls Than Boys on Drugs
description: MONTVILLE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct. 2More local teenaged girls than boys experiment with drugs, according to a survey in this suburban Morris County community.

title: LIBERALS DISCLOSE TAX REFORM PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 2A group of liberal Democrats in the House of Representatives, plus Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, announced plans today to try to enact just one tax reform this yeara strengthening of what is called the minimum tax.

title: TEACHERS FINED $1,100 FOR STRIKE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 2The teachers who struck the Greenburgh schools in Westchester last month and returned Sept. 25 have learned that they will lose an average of $1,200 in fines.

title: White House Adopts Plan For Heating Oil Allocation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2After months of indecision, the White House committed itself today to Federal supplymanagement of heating oil for the coming winter, the first such peacetime regulation in the country's history.

title: THREE MORE SLAIN IN VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V.I., Oct. 2 (UPI)Officials disclosed today the murders of three more whites on this racially tense Caribbean island, bringing to 18 the number of whites slain here in little more than a year.

title: Merger Is Weighed By Host and Cook
description: Cook United, Inc., and the General Host Corporation announced yesterday that they were conducting preliminary discussions on a possible merger of the two companies.

title: COUNCIL IS SCORED ON REDISTRICTING
description: Members of the City Council clashed yesterday with Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams as Mr. Abrams attacked the third and latest version of council district reapportionment during a public hearing.

title: Idle Dice Scores With Jenkins Up
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2Idle Dice made his task look easy tonight when he won the first open jumper class in a jumpoff at the start of the sixday Philadelphia Horse Show at the Spectrum.

title: Cloud of Poisonous Gas Perils 500 in Alberta
description: NEW NORWAY, Alberta, Wednesday, Oct. 3 (Canadian Press)About 500 people may be forced to evacuate an area about 50 miles southeast of Edmonton to escape a cloud of poisonous hydrogen sulphide gas from a ruptured natural gas pipeline near Red Deer Lake, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said today.

title: Notes on People
description: Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., former Marine Corps Commandant, will be nominated Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, President Nixon announced yesterday.

title: Burglary CoverUp Is Laid To Deputy Chief in Albany
description: ALBANY, Oct. 2A deputy chief of the Albany Police Department, investigating a report that policemen had broken into and looted a tire store, assured his men that we would try to cover this up, according to the chief's internal police report released today by the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Inquiry Continues Into Fire Fatal to 10
description: HOBOKEN, Oct. 2 (UPI) Authorities said today they were working on the assumption that a fire that killed at least 10 persons in a fivestory tenement was started in a mattress discarded on the second floor landing.

title: POLICEMAN IS SHOT FOILING BAR HOLDUP
description: An offduty Sanitation Department policeman was shot and seriously wounded last night in a gun battle with three men who attempted to rob a bar in Brooklyn.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (Reuters)The House completed today Congressional action on legislation instructing the Federal bankregulatory agencies to put an unspecified ceiling on the amount of interest banks can pay on time deposits of less than $100,000.

title: Questions and Answers on Soviet Trade Status and Emigration
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Should the Soviet Union's trading status with the United States be upgraded? Congress wants to link any such action to a change in Soviet emigration policy while the Nixon Administration would prefer to keep the issues separate. Following are a series of questions and answers examining the nature of the dispute.

title: Records: Savoyards
description: Despite all the industrious amateur troupes that still purvey their works, Gilbert and Sullivan are no longer as well honored as they once were. The trouble is that the Savoyard shrine, the D'Oyly Carte Company in London, is in decline.

title: Extortionist Gets 15 Years For an Explosion Threat
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (UPI)Glen R. Schubert, a former Nationwide Insurance Company claims adjuster, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of trying to extort $280,000 from the company by threatening to blow up its facilities.

title: $25,000 PRIZE GOES TO THREE BIOLOGISTS
description: Three research biologistsRenato Dulbecco, Harry Eagle and Theodore Puckhave been named recipients of Columbia University's 1973 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for outstanding contributions to tissue culture research.

title: Jackson, a Black, and Massell Gain Oct. 16 Runoff for Atlanta Mayor
description: ATLANTA, Wednesday, Oct. 3The Vice Mayor of Atlanta, Maynard Jackson, rolled to victory yesterday over a field of 10 opponents in the first step in his effort to become the first black Mayor in this Southern capital.

title: MAN HELD IN MURDER OF HIS GIRLFRIEND, 20
description: The body of a 20yearold woman, wrapped in aluminum foil and painted with varnish, was found last night in a Brooklyn Heights apartment. A man who shared the oneroom apartment was arrested and charged with stabbing and strangling her to death 10 days ago.

title: Taking the 25th
description: When the 25th Amendment was ratified on Feb. 10, 1967, few would have guessed that within a decade the nation would be wondering how to apply it. But history is blessedly full of surprises; and in the autumn of 1973 Congress may well have to ponder the meaning of those bland words in the Amendment's Section 2: Whenever there is a vacancy in the office of the Vice President, the President shall nominate a Vice President who shall take office upon confirmation by a majority vote of both Houses of Congress.

title: NATO Security Is Linked to U.S. Troop Presence
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) An AmericanEuropean study panel headed by Senator Jacob K. Javits declared today that it was necessary to keep United State's ground troops in Europe to guarantee the security of the Western allies.

title: 5 ARE NOMINATED BY EPISCOPALIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Oct. 2In a break with precedent, the House Of Bishops of the Episcopal Church announced today that It had named the Bishops of Ohio, California, Arkansas, Rochester and Mississippi as nominees for Presiding Bishop. The announcement was said to mark the first time that the Bishops had revealed their decision in advance of the election.

title: White House Adopts Plan For Heating Oil Allocation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2After months of indecision, the White House committed itself today to Federal supplymanagement of heating oil for the coming winter, the first such peacetime regulation in the country's history.

title: Malaysia to Spread Fruits of Economy Dominated by Energetic Urban Chinese
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 18In the entire region, a Western diplomat says, this is the country that has the fewest problems. It's got good administration, natural resources, skilled technicians and money. The only fly in the ointment is race.

title: STEPHEN D. RAIMO
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 2 Stephen D. Raimo, president of the Ray Contracting Company of Syosset and past president of the Masonry Contractor's Association of America, died today at the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He was 73 years old and lived here.

title: Company, 75, Still Is FamilyOwned
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2The Bechtel Corporation, which Egypt Has picked to build a $400million oil pipeline across its desert, is hardly a household name. Yet it is known to virtually all the industrialists and governments around the world, and its operations have touched the lives of Americans and other peoples as much as, say, the Ford Motor Company.

title: Pressmen's Union Merges With Stereotypers' Group
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Two of the oldest unions in the printing industry merged today to form the International Printing and Graphic Communications Union with a combined membership of 132,000.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: RIGGING OF PRICES HELD GRAIN PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)  Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today that the prices of corn, wheat and other commodities can be manipulated almost without fear of discovery or penalty to the detriment of farmers and consumers.

title: NELSON W. M'COMBS
description: GWYNEDD, Pa., Oct. 2Nelson W, McCombs, who retired in 1955 after 31 years as head librarian at the Washington Square branch of New York University and two years at the University's Gould Memorial Library, died today of pneumonia at Foulkeways, a Quaker retirement home here. He was 83 years old.

title: House Group Approves Aid To World Financial Units
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (Reuters)The House Appropriations Committee approved a $2.203billion measure to maintain United States contributions to several international institutions as a result of February's 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar.
