title: State Enlists Veterans to Guide Veterans Into College
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3 (AP)The New Jersey Department of Higher Education is conducting an experimental program that uses veterans of the war in Vietnam to help other exservicemen to get into college.

title: Salomon Lost 6.6Million in Year
description: Salomon Brothers, customarily one of Wall Street's most profitable firms, yesterday said it had a pretax loss of $6.6million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. It was the firm's first loss, since 1956.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE TRADE The World Trade Center has some of the tallest buildings in town, and now it has an art exhibition to match. The mezzanine of the north, Tower No. 1 at Church and Dey Streets is currently furnished with 17 large sculptures, free standing and free for the looking, part of a traveling New York Artists on Tour series.

title: HOUSE APPROVES SUBSIDY TO CITIES FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The House voted today to pay part of the operating costs for mass transit systems in New York and other urban areas.

title: Doctors Called Ignorant of Sex Mores
description: BELLE MEAD, N.J., Oct. 3 The average physician remains in the dark ages when it comes to knowledge of his patients' sexual problems, several leading medical experts agreed today.

title: Damage to Health Is Found In Triborough's Employes
description: Results of the first two years of tests on employes of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority appear to confirm their fears of health damage from automotive air pollution.

title: Soap Box Derby Defendant Agrees to Change, in Case
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct 3 (AP) The uncle of the youth disqualified as this year's Soap Box Derby champion met yesterday with the judge handling his case and agreed to an adjustment in the charge against him. The uncle, Robert Lange Sr., is charged with encouraging his nephew, James Gronen, 14 years old, to cheat by using an illegal device to give the boy's soap box racer a faster start.

title: U.S. ASKS STATE FOR MONEY BACK
description: The Federal Government announced yesterday that it had served demands for $11,735,000 in refunds from New York State for money the Government paid out for Medicaid and welfare programs in New York City.

title: Puerto Rican Girl Now House Page
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The first page in the House of Representatives from Puerto Rico  Miss Siglinda Sanchez, now of Hobokenstarted work here this week.

title: STATE INCREASING MORTGAGE CEILING
description: The interestgate ceiling on home mortgages in New York State will be raised to 8 per cent, effective next Thursday, Harry W. Albright Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks and chairman of the Banking Board, announced last night.

title: Segretti Describes Chapin As Boss of Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Donald H. Segretti testified today that he had reported regularly last, year to President Nixon's appointments secretary about the dirty tricks he was playing on candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: MARKET DISCIPLINES FIRMS AND EMPLOYES
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had disciplined 13 individtials or firms fcir violations of exchange regulations.

title: Film: X-Rated Polanski: What?' Shows a Lo of Sydne Rome The Cast
description: Roman Polanski's "What? is an X-rated nonsense comedy about a Goldilocks marqu, a wide-eyed America girl on the loose in Asia an Europe, and her specific adventures among some mad characters she meets when she takes refuge in an Italian seaside villa to escape three would-be rapists.The girl, played by a new actress whose name is improbably spelled Sydne (conventionally pronounced "Sidney") Rome, has hair that looks like an elaborate taffy dessert. She also has a terrible time keeping her clothe on, try as she will. When they aren't torn off in usually friendly struggles, they are stolen while she sleeps. Sometimes she's reduced to wearing a dinner napkin. Sometimes she just gives up and wears nothing, but she is never daunted. Nobody in the villa notices.In addition to a body that invites constant assaults like Everest, the girl possesses the kind of optimistic American purpose that pioneered the West, invented the light bulb and developed frozen food. She is as curious unflappable and self-assured as a favored child and, as she is ravaged by the world so does she ravage it. When she finally departs the villa at least one of its inhabitants has expired in the sheer joy of contemplating her."What?", which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater is a male chauvinist pig sort of comedy. It is not consistently inspired in its lunacy, but it is so totally without redeeming social value that it should be protected and, from time to time, cherished, as when a grumpy maid attempts to clear the air of flies and mistakes and aerosol can of shaving cream for Fly-Tox.Anarchic comedy is a form that continues to challenge Polanski even though neither he nor his script collaborator, Gerard Brach succeeded in their earlier 'Cul-de-Sac" or "The Fearless Vampire Killers." Perhaps, like verse drama, it's become one of those things that need only to be attempted to succeed in partial measure. It can be fun to watch the try.Occasionally Polanski and Brach seem to want to introduce a system of surreal disorder to the girl's adventures in the villa, but I doubt that they really much care beyond presenting us with an Alice trying to comprehend an X-rated Wonderand. Among the inhabitants are Marcello Mastroianni, playing a former pimp with a sense of honor and a passion for sado-masochistic games; Hugh Griffith, the Villa's ancient owner, once a great collector of art, now a man who prefers the object to its artistic image, and other assorted odd balls, including Polanski himself.The girl, the villa and the performances are beautiful enough to bridge those sequences when the film, like its heroine, seems searching for explanations that will never be found.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Generally sunny skies and warm temperatures are forecast today for southern sections of the Northeast; cloudy and mild weather, with some rain or showers, will prevail across northern and western New England. Thundershowers may develop in Michigan. Showers and thunderstorms are likely from the middle Mississippi Valley to Oklahoma, while scattered showers and thunderstorms will occur in western sections of the Ohio Valley, central Gulf Coast and in the western portions of the Central and Southern Plains States. It will be cooler from the upper and Middle Mississippi Valley across the Central and Southern Plains States to the southern Rockies. Warmer weather will spread from the Northern Plains States across the northern Rockies to Oreand California.

description: Basketball Transactions

title: New Custom House: Modern, Functional, No Match for the Old
description: A funny thing happened on the way to the new Custom House at the World Trade Center. Public architecture declined and fell: On Oct. 19 at 2 P.M. the United States Custom Service will dedicate its new building, a sevenstory glass and aluminum structure flanking the Trade Center's North Tower, part of the complex designed by Minoru Yamasaki and Associates and Emory Roth and Sons. The new offices, a vast functional improvement over the old ones at Bowling Green, will consist of efficient, standardized accommodations with eightfoot ceilings and all the latest me

title: $300Million Sait Filed By Calcomp on I.B.M.
description: California Computer Products, Inc. filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in California charging the International Business Machines Corporation with monopolistic practices.

title: HouseSenate Panel Reaches an Accord On WarPower Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Senate and House conferees reached tentative agreement tonight on a bill limiting the powers of the President to commit United States armed forces to foreign hostilities without Congressional approval.

title: Britain's Warships Leave Disputed Waters Off Iceland
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (UPI)British warships steamed out of the disputed waters of Iceland today in a move aimed at opening negotiations that would end a dispute over fishing rights. However, British fishing boats remained in the area.

title: LEFTISTS OCCUPY ARGENTINE SCHOOL
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 (AP)  The University of Buenos Aires, the largest in Argentina, was occupied today by students protesting the removal of their leftist Peronist dean.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS AGNEW'S REFUSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 President Nixon said today that it was altogether proper for Vice President Agnew to declare that he would not resign if he should be indicted by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore.

title: Brown Is Recaptured
description: Henry Brown, an alleged member of the Black Liberation Army who escaped last week from Kings County Hospital, was captured last night in Brooklyn. Page 39.

title: Text of Letter From the Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Following is the text of a letter to The Washington Post yesterday from Vice President Agnew:

title: DAY LINE DROPS COMMUTER TRIPS
description: The Hudson River Dayliner, which can carry 3,250 passengers, had only 14 paying fares aboard yesterday on the third day of her maiden venture into mass transit, and the management decided to chuck the whole idea overboard.

title: Baboon Chased 3 Hours At a Maryland Airport
description: GLEN BURNIE, Md., Oct. 3 (UPI)An escaped 65pound baboon led pursuers on a threehour, slapstick chase through Friendship International Airport today but was caught when he ducked into a ladies room.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN COMMODITIES
description: After two days of declining prices, grains and soybeans on the Chicago Board of Trade attracted some eager buyers yesterday and prices rose sharply.

title: Decision on Emigrants Has Divided Austrians
description: VIENNA, Oct. 3In the five days since Chancellor Bruno Kreisky decided to close transit facilities for groups of Jewish emigrants, this neutral country has been deeply divided and perplexed over the move and shaken by the flood of protests from the West and Israel.

title: U. S. NEUTRALITY ON MIDEAST URGED
description: CAIRO, Oct. 3Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran says that during his recent visit to Washington he urged the United States to adopt an evenhanded policy in the Middle East and that he thought he got receptive ears, according to a frontpage interview printed in three Egyptian newspapers today.

title: Customs Service Does More Than Just Collect
description: When John Lamb, the port's first collector of customs, set up shop in the old Presidential Mansion on Bowling Green, he and his small band of assistants collected $145,329 in duties that year.

description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1973

title: Arthur Daley
description: Back in the old days when the Yankee invincibles were constantly winning pennants for Casey Stengel, the Ol' Perfessor often gestured in the direction of Yogi Berra and offered one of his seriocomic observations. This is Mister Berra which helps me manage the Yankees. He's my lucky fella. I allus win when I have him in the lineup. Besides, he's very close to the ownership.

title: Kreisky Becomes Hero in Arab World
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria, who is of Jewish descent, has emerged as a hero to the Arab world because of his refusal under Israeli pressure to reverse his decision suspending transit rights for Jewish emigrant groups moving from the Soviet Union.

title: Nearing the Limits: II
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3The sharp rise in food prices over the last year, the world around, has profoundly disturbing implications. For it may reflect strains not only on present supplies but on the earth's agricultural capacity.

title: Lesbian Pleads for Children
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 (UPI)A woman who said two children were taken away because she is a lesbian has asked the California Supreme Court to return them Carol Parrott said yesterday that there had never been any suggestion in a child court trial that the children had been inadequately cared for though an appeal court upheld the removal.

description: Following is a transcript of the news conference held by President Nixon in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News.

description: Capital (NBA) vs. Atlanta (NBA).

title: Six Youths Burn Woman to Death In Boston Attack
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3Six youths forced a 24yearold woman to douse herself with two gallons of gasoline last night and then set her afire. She died early toaay of second and thirddegree burns that covered her entire body.

title: Olympic Group Hears Plea for China
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. 3 (AP)Politics burst on the Olympic Congress today as sports officials disagreed over admitting China to the Olympic Games.

description: TOKYO  Glen Fukushima, who came here as an exchange student from Stanford University, found that many Japanese were upset on learning that he spoke English better than Japanese, the language of his grandparents.

description: A state fund to finance the rehabilitation of old apartment buildings and their conversion to lowincome and moderateincome cooperatives was urged yesterday in a report in Manhattan.

description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. (AP)Politics burst on the Olympic Congress today as sports officials disagreed over admitting China to the Olympic Games.

title: DrugCase Witness Asserts He Was Put On U.S. Retainer Fee
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3The Government's chief witness in the trial of two men and two women on charges of conspiracy to smuggle drugs testified in Federal Court today that he was put on a Justice Department retainer of $1,080 a month in August last year in return for assistance to the prosecution.

title: Hong Kong Is Weighing Curbs on Stocks
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 3 The Hong Kong stock market, which has been described as the colony's answer to the gambling casinos in neighboring Macao, has soared and plunged this yearbut plunged more than soared.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES WAITING BY JURORS
description: The average New Yorker selected for jury duty in the state and city courts spends almost twothirds of his normal twoweek jury time waiting to be called for trial and the collective cost of this waiting time is more than $5million a year, a courtsponsored study has found.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Mayor Lindsay and 12 other Mayors, speaking with a single voice, decried President Nixon's housing proposals today and warned that the cities were being caught in a crossfire between Congress and the White House.

title: 16 OFFICERS DRAW JAIL AS GRAFTERS
description: Three police sergeants and 13 police officers received prison sentences of up to three years yesterday for systematically extorting $20,000 a month from gamblers in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Dirty Tricks Man
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 About to be discharged from the Army and eager to begin his delayed career as a civilian, Donald Henry Segretti arrived in Washington two years ago for a reunion with two college buddies who had offered him a job.

title: MET LAUNCHES All 8IN1 ROCKET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3The Soviet Union today launched another set of eight satellites with a single rocket in further development of a worldwide defense communications system.
