description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie, the principal author of the Clear Air Act of 1970, said today that strict controls on automobile tailpipe emissions were designed to protect not only normally healthy people but also those susceptible to illnesses aggravated by air pollution.

title: Rx for Ron Johnson: More of Same
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 3I'm not too optimistic, Dr. Anthony Pisani said today on whether Ron Johnson would be able to rejoin the New York Giants for Sunday's game against the Green Bay Packers at Yale Bowl.

title: A Super Series of Racing Planned for Top Horses
description: Talking with the zeal of a prophet, a onetime profootball marketing expert disclosed plans here yesterday for a $13million horse race.

title: Iowa Senate Race Ruled Out
description: DES. MOINES, Iowa, Oct, 3 Gov. Robert D. Ray anpounced today that he would not be a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in 1974.

title: 4 Indian Elephants Go on Show at Bronx Zoo's Tropical Asia Complex
description: Four Indian elephants went on exhibition at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: PRESIDENT BACKS ACNEW'S REFUSAL TO RESIGN OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 President Nixon said today that it was altogether proper for Vice President Agnew to declare that he would not resign if he should be indicted by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore.

title: Terrorist Success
description: From one point of view the fundamental issue raised by Austria's surrender to Arab terrorists has nothing to do with the specifics of this particular incident. President Nixon stated the issue at his news conference yesterday when he said, We simply cannot have governmentssmall or largegive in to international blackmail by terrorist groups. The reason, of course, is that a surrender invites others to attempt similar blackmail.

title: Local Pacts Avert Strikes At Seven Chrysler Plants
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3 (UPI) Strikes were averted at seven Chrysler Corporation plants today when negotiators for the company and the United Automobile Workers reached agreement on local disputes.

title: San. Antonio Bank Reduces Prime Rate to 9 Per Cent
description: A Texas bank with $18million in assets announced yesterday it was cutting its prime lending rate to 9 per cent.

title: Manlila and Democracy
description: ITHACA, N.Y.The American conscience is not difficult to prick when democracy is in distress. It sent America into two world wars to save democracy. It sent her into a less decisive and less popular war in Vietnam to save democracy. It keeps hundreds of thousands of American soldiers posted around the world to stand guard for democracy. And it speaks up, eloquently and quite officially, whenever and wherever democracy is raped.

title: Reorganizing the Pennsy
description: In all the multilayered Federal bureaucracy, no agency has a more depressing capacity for infinite delay than the Interstate Commerce Commission. For ten years has been struggling to develop a viable plan for restructuring railroad service in the Westwith no final decision yet made.

title: COASTAL DRILLING IS ARGUED ON L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 3 Speakers and public :officials outnumbered the audience today at a hearing on offshore drilling for oil and gas along the Atlantic Coast.

title: STOPH REPLACED IN EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Oct. 3Willi Stoph, Premier of East Germany for the last nine years, was named today to the largely ceremonial role of Chairman of the Council of State, or President.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A Museum Shows Portables. From the Ingenious to the Ridiculous
description: Ever since man first ventured out of the cave, he has devised portable equipment to ease his journeys. Judging by the Portable World show that opens tomorrow at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, the range of such ingenious aides has grown into a billiondollar industry.

title: 35 Senators Submit a Bill To Widen Social Services
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Legislation to liberalize the Nixon Administration's strict regulations on the stateFederal social services program was introduced today by 35 Senators.

title: Decision on Emigrants Has Divided Austrians
description: VIENNA, Oct. 3In the five days since Chancellor Bruno Kreisky decided to close transit facilities for groups of Jewish emigrants, this neutral country has been deeply divided and perplexed over the move and shaken by the flood of protests from the West and Israel.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Office of Revenue Sharing in Washington reported yesterday that $3.5million in Federal revenuesharing funds were being withheld from 99 New Jersey municipal and county governments this week because they had failed to submit required data on time. The quarterly checks will not be mailed, according to a spokesman, until the Federal agency receives the proper forms.

title: City Seeks Oil at Same Level As 1972 for Dealers in Area
description: The Mayor's Public Utilities Committee urged, the White House yesterday to force major oil suppliers to make oil available to metropolitan area dealers in at least the same quanti ties made available last year.

title: Man Is Accused of Posing As Policeman for Extortion
description: Robert Powell, a Department of Social Services law enforcement official, was arrested yesterday and accused of posing as a city policeman to extort money from a man named Columbus Spenser.

title: Judge Grants Agnew Right to Investigate News Leaks
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 3Vice President Agnew's attorneys won from a Federal district judge today authority to conduct their own investigation, with full power of subpoena, into the alleged Justice Department leaks of information that Mr. Agnew has charged constitute a malicious, immoral and illegal attack on him by Government prosecutors.

title: SONN ENFELDT CASE DISCUSSED BY LONG
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth Rush conferred today with Senator Russell B. Long on the security charges made at a Senate Finance Committee hearing against Helmut Sonnenfeldt, the White House nominee for Under Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Columbia Appoints Architect
description: Romaldo Giurgola of Mitchell/Giurgola Associates, 170 West 97th Street, has been appointed architect for Columbia University's $12million Sherman Fairchild Center for the Life Sciences, the university's trustees have announced. Mr. pointed architect for Columbia University's $12million Sherman Fairchild Center for the Life Sciences, the university's trustees have announced. Mr. durgola, who holds degrees from Columbia and the University of Rome, is Ware Professor of Architecture at Columbia's School of Architecture.

title: MRS. GLADYS DULON
description: Mrs. Gladys Devereux Dulon, former director of the Nurses Professional Placement Agency, 141 East 44th Street, and founder of the Holland Nurses Registry in 1935, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. Her age was 79, and she lived at 152 West 58th Street.

title: Candidate Accuses Nassau Prosecutor Of Jury Tampering
description: MINEOLA, LI, Oct. 3  The Independent candidate for Nassau County Executive accused the County District Attorney's office today of grandjury tampering in a case involving a Republican official.

title: White House Is Silent on a Report Nixon Paid $1,670 Tax in '70'71
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The White House refused to confirm or deny today a report, that President and Mrs. Nixon paid only $792.81 in Federal income taxes for 1970 and $878.03 for 1971 despite an income in excess of $200,000 for each year.

title: Dillon of West Virginia StraightA as Student and as Quarterback
description: You only have to tell Ade Dillon something one time, said Bobby l owden, coach of the undefeated West Virginia Mountaineers. This makes the coach's work easier, since Dillon is the quarterback of the veer offense. He has a real fine mind and sees the total picture right away, Bowden said.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Recital
description: Robert Smith, who gave a recital of harpsichord music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, is one of those interesting fanatics whose bents are toward the encyclopedic. If he were not a musician, and an immensely skillful one, he might be happily plowing through all the novels of Conrad and Baizac, or memorizing the phone book.

title: Magruder Going to Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) A Federal judge today gave, Jeb Stuart Magruder permission to make a 17day business, and pleasure trip to Europe; with his wife. Magruder, foriner deputy director of President Nixon's reelection committee, has pleaded guilty to a single charge of trying to cover up the Watergate breakin,

title: Nance Is Frustrated Jet As Goals Go Glimmering
description: When Jim Nance started working last spring to lose about 30 pounds and revive his pro football career, he had two goals.

title: L.I. GAS STATIONS ACT ON PRICE LAW
description: WOODBURY, L. I., Oct. 3Many retail stations stopped pumping gasoline today to protest the recent rules of the Cost of Living Council, but motorists did not appear to be affected materially.

title: CURBS ARE SOUGHT ON TEEN MARRIAGE
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP)  Saying that teenage marriages end in failure more often than not, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston wants to make it harder for young people to get married.

title: Boy, 14, Held in Slaying
description: A 14yearold boy was arrested yesterday and accused of fatally shooting a 14yearold friend, Paul Clark, last March 28 and throwing his body into an incinerator in the apartment house where the victim lived at 629 Casanova Street in the East Bronx. Until a furnace repairman found the skeleton on Sept. 17, the police had listed him as a runaway.

title: Alberta Residents Are Safe As Poison Gas Dissipates
description: NEW NORWAY, Alberta, Oct. 3 (UPI)  A deadly, 35mile long hydrogen sulphide gas cloud from a well began breaking up in strong winds today, allowing hundreds of people to return to their homes.

title: Study Finds Jurors Spend 2/3 of Time In Costly Waiting
description: The average New Yorker selected for jury duty in the state and city courts spends almost twothirds of his normal twoweek jury time waiting to be called for trial and the collective cost of this waiting time is more than $5million a year, a courtsponsored study has found.

title: People and Business
description: Thaddeus N. Taube, an outside director of the troubled Koracorp Industries, Inc. for the last three years, yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of the San Franciscobased apparel and textile company.

title: Judge Grants Agnew Right to Investigate News Leaks
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 3Vice President Agnew's attorneys won from a Federal district judge today authority to conduct their own investigation, with full power of subpoena, into the alleged Justice Department leaks of information that Mr. Agnew has charged constitute a malicious, immoral and illegal attack on him by Government prosecutors.

title: Notes on People
description: The Air Force has complied with a Federal Civil Service Commission ruling yesterday and announced it would not contest the reinstatement of A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the controversial civilian cost analyst it fired after he exposed cost overruns on the C5A cargo plane in 1970.

title: Second Group of Pakistanis Is Returned Home by India
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan,. Oct. 3 (AP)A second group of Pakistani civilian and military prisoners of war being returned home from Indian camps arrived today in Pakistan. The 841 men, women and children, who had been held captive since the IndianPakistani war of December, 1971, included 222 military personnel. They were greeted at Wagah on the IndianPakistani border 15 miles from Lahore by Lieut. Gen. Tikka Khan, Chief of Staff of the Pakistani Army.

title: Personal Finance
description: The professor said cheerfully, You know what I have done? I have borrowed on my life insurance policies and set up small trusts for my children.

title: INSURANCE DATA CALLED FAULTY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  An F.B.I. agent turned consumer advocate said at a Senate hear ing today that at least 40 per cent of the information compiled by insurance companies on the health risks of applicants for policies was defective and erroneous.

title: VISIT TO BRITAIN ENDED BY TRIM
description: LONDON, Oct. 3  Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan left Britain today after a fourday visit that focused on increasing cooperation between his country, the European Economic Community and the United States.

title: The Petersen Case: II
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Deputy Attorney General of the United States, William Ruckeishaus, called the other day to tell me how wrong I was to accuse his associate, Henry Petersen, of personally leaking a prejudgment of the Agnew case: We've got the evidence, Petersen was quoted as saying, We've got it cold.

title: Plasticized, Tasteless Breads Give Rise to a Kitchen Revolt
description: When in a single month two leading publishers issue books on breadmaking and Gourmet magazine prints two articles on the subject, we are confronted with a Trend.

title: U.S. Cautions Europeans About Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3A State Department official said today that the ambassadors of all nine member nations of the European Common Market had been called in during the last two days to be cautioned to maintain secrecy concerning current AmericanWest European negotiations.

title: Israeli Cabinet Calls for Shift by Austria
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 3The Israeli Cabinet said tonight that Austria must reverse the decision made last week to curtail the transit of Soviet Jews bound for Israel.

title: Theater: Tesich Comedy
description: A husband is dying. At least he thinks he is dying. What more logical thing could he do than place a want ad in the newspaper? Asking, of course, for a new husband for his wife? That is the kind of crisp and crazy logic to be found in Steve Tesich's play Nourish the Beast, which opened at the Cherry Lane Theater last night.

title: Physicians Termed Behind Times on Sex Problems
description: BELLE MEAD, N.J., Oct. 3 The average physician remains in the dark ages when it comes to knowledge of his patients' sexual problems, several leading medical experts agreed today.

title: Lippmann Satisfactory
description: Walter Lippmann, for 60 years one of the leading figures in American journalism, was listed as being in satisfactory condition last night at New York Hospital after suffering a stroke Tuesday. His condition had been described as critical earlier in the day.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: WORLD ASSOCIATION

title: Oil Allocation: Program Pleases Few
description: The nation's first peacetime allocation program for petroleum products announced Tuesday by John A. Love, director of the Government's Energy Policy Office, appears to please almost no one. A number of oil companies contended that the program was not needed, and in addition provided no remedy in case shortages do occur. On the other side of the question, longtime advocates of an allocation system contended that this one is too little and too late.

title: INDICTMENT OF BURR IS FOUND IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3 (AP)The State Archives Office announced today that it had found the 1804 New Jersey murder indictment of Vice President Aaron Burr.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Kodes Inducted Into Czech Army

title: Albany Police Chief Not Yet Convinced of Corruption
description: ALBANY, Oct. 3  Police Chief Edward C. McArdle testified today that three weeks of sworn allegations of Albany policemen burglarizing stores, looting parking meters, protecting prostitutes and dope dealers and intimidating witnesses had not yet provided him with any information requiring disciplinary action.

title: 16 OFFICERS DRAW JAIL AS GRAFTER
description: Three police sergeants and 13 police officers received prison sentences of up to three years yesterday for systematically extorting $20,000 month from gamblers in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Nine Poisoned by Coffee
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Oct. 3 (UPI) Nine Texas Tech University graduate students and faculty members were poisoned Tuesday by coffee accidentally made with duplicating fluid and A spokesman said that the solution was apprently mistaken for distilled water and was poured into the coffee maker.

title: Nurse Aids in Capture Of a Robbery Suspect
description: With the help of a 28yearold Bellevue nurse, a police streetcrime unit captured a Man accused of robbing an elderly man on the Lower East Side yesterday afternoon.

title: California Elected Officials Must Disclose Investments
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan has signed a conflict of interest bill requiring California's elected public officials to disclose their investments.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: TV: WeekLong Irish Holiday via Today Show
description: For someone named O'Connor, it it difficult to ignore a weeklong television trip to Ireland, and when the tour includes an extended stop at the location of a lengthy childhood visit, it is impossible. My blatant prejudice conceded, it can still be said that the National Broadcasting Company's Today show is very much worth watching this week.

title: VOTING UNIT AVERTS PAPERBALLOT USE
description: By cutting threequarters of an inch of machine ballot space here and threequarters there, the Board of Elections has saved many New Yorkers from being forced to use paper ballots in the Nov. 6 election.

title: INQUIRY IN TEXAS HEARS MITCHELL
description: DALLAS, Oct. 3  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, looking refreshed and somewhat thinner than he had been, testified at a hearing today that he knew major Texas Democrats were involved in the Sharpstown stock scandal in 1971, but said he had learned this from reading newspapers long after the investigation was under way.

title: Nixon's Tax May Double On Home at San Clemente
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3It appeared today that the controversies about President Nixon's home at San Clemente, Calif., will result in an approximate doubling of his property tax bill for the current year.

title: Notes on People
description: The Air Force has complied with a Federal Civil Service Commission ruling yesterday and announced it would not contest the reinstatement of A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the controversial civilian cost analyst it fired after he exposed cost overruns on the C5A cargo plane in 1970.

title: DUNLOP DEFENDS CONTROLS ON GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, said. today that if filling stations were allowed to raise their prices every time their costs rose, the system of price controls over gasoline would be unenforceable.

title: Elliott Roosevelt Tells Hearing Assassination Charge Is Lie
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Elliott Roosevelt angrily denied under oath today the allegation of a convicted stock swindler that he was involved in a 1968 plot to assassinate Lynden O. Pindling, Prime Minister of the Bahamas.

title: Lampoon Crowns Tango New King of the Worst
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP)Bernardo Bertolucci's Last Tango in Paris was named the Worst Movie of the Year today by The Harvard Lampoon a humor magazine.

title: At Belmont: The Jerkens Way Clicks
description: Allen Jerkens, the giantkiller trainer whose horses have upset Secretariat twice in the last couple of months, succeeded in a different role yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Books of The Times; Dr. Livingstone, I Presume?
description: LIVINGSTONE. By Tim Jeal. 427 pages. Illustrated. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $10.

title: A BestinShow Produces Tears of Joy
description: Reality was overwhelming for the surrealist painter, Armando Miro, when he recently received the Puerto Rico Kennel Club bestinshow trophy. Tears of joy streamed down his cheeks as friends congratulated him and shouted Bravos,

title: New Pro Football League Plans to Start in 1974 With 12 Teams
description: Plans were announced yesterday for a new 12team professional football league that would attempt to play at a major league level beginning next year. Its name would be the World Football League and eventually it would have teams abroad. It would have a team in New York to succeed the Giants at Yankee Stadium.

title: Association of the Bar Here Is Scored As Dominated by Manhattan Brahmins
description: Members of the State Senate's Judiciary Committee complained yesterday that the Association of the Bar of the City of New York was a Brahmindominated, Manhattanoriented group that unfairly screened judicial candidates in other boroughs.

title: This Ominous Sense
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio When I graduated from college in 1956 it was fashionable for speakers on campuses across the country to talk about The Great American Dream. We were possessed then with the idea of a bountiful American destiny. The future was there for the taking, and optimism was second nature to us. We had been schooled to believe that America from the beginning was the new chosen people with a mission to lead freedom's children through the wilderness of selfgovernment to a new land of order, liberty and plenty.

title: 22 Food Places Listed as Health Code Violators
description: Twentytwo restaurants and food stores in the city were cited yesterday for violating the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions detected during two inspections.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: It may be little relief to future opponents, but Clifton High School doesn't have quite the defense it had last year, when it held its nine victims to a total of 20 points.

title: Moderate California Quake
description: SAN JOSE, Calif, Oct. 3 (AP)A moderate earthquake awakened residents from Santa Cruz to the San Francisco Bay area early today. The tremor measured 4.25 on the Richter scale at the University of California seismographic station in Berkeley.

title: Nixon Appeals to Kreisky To Review Action on Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3President Nixon appealed to Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria today to reconsider his decision to close transit facilities for Soviet Jews going to Israel because we simply cannot have governments  small or large  give in to international blackmail by terrorist groups.

title: Bruno Gets 68 to Lead Met P.G.A.
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 3Bob Bruno of the Pelham Country Club scored a 33, 3568, today at the Elmwood Country Club in the first round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: White House Is Silent on a Report Nixon Paid $1,670 Tax in '70'71
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The White House refused to confirm or deny today a report that President and Mrs. Nixon paid only $792.81 in Federal income taxes for 1970 and $878.03 for 1971 despite an income in excess of $200,000 for each year.

title: HOUSE UNIT OPENS NERVE GAS INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Because of the insistence of freshman Congressman from Utah, the House Armed Services Committee was forced today into holding its first pubIic hearing on nerve gases, a subject that the committee has tended to treat with the same secretiveness as the military.

title: Consumer Notes
description: James Thurber often conveyed the feeling that inanimate objects had a malevolent life of their own, and the consumer product hazard index issued last week certainly has its share of things that at first glance just seem to lie there, but in fact actively contribute to injuries.

title: SUSSMAN ASSAILS INSPECTION SETUP
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state health official who closed unsanitary kitchens in hospitals, restaurants and state institutions until he was reined in by the Attorney General, said today that the substitute system designed to deal with such facilities was not working.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Laotian Assembly Extends Session Over New Coalition
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 3 (UPI)The Assembly agreed today to extend its current session by nearly one month so that a new coalition government can he formed in Laos.

title: Jenny Moore, Author, 50, Dies; Wrote of Ministry Among Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Jenny Moore, an author, social activist and wife of the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., Episcopal Bishop of New York, died today of cancer at Washington Hospital Center. She was 50 years old.

title: Brown Is Recaptured With Four in Raid on a Brooklyn Tenement
description: A 24yearold black militant who escaped from a Kings County Hospital clinic a week ago while in custody awaiting trial for the murder of two policemen was recaptured in a Brooklyn tenement last night.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Newburgh Teachers End Strike

title: Chess: Brilliant Play Has Its Place, But It Is Well Behind First
description: At the Interzonal in Petropolis, Paul Keres complained that, These days no one thinks about anything but winning. There is no interest in coming up with a beautiful conception or taking a brilliancy prize.

title: SEPTEMBER SALES OF AUTOS AT PEAK
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3  United States car sales set another record in September as the auto industry wound up the 1973 model run and began 1974 model sales on a high note.

title: Home Loan Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3President Nixon signed today a bill extending the Federal Housing Administration home loan guarantee program for one more year. The bill, giving authority to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to insure loans and mortgages, extends the program to Oct. 1, 1974.

title: Five Stanek Babies Gaining
description: DENVER, Oct. 3 (AP)Four of the five surviving Stanek sextuplets are drinking milk from a bottle and all five are gaining weight daily, doctors said today. John, Jeffrey, Catherine and Steven are being given milk in bottles. Nathan, the last born of the six babies, is still being fed through a tube through his throat into his stomach. All five are listed in good condition. They were born Sept. 16.

title: Crime and the Police
description: New York City's criminal justice systempolice, courts and correctional institutionsfails adequately respond to today's incidence of crime. The situation New York City is not substantially different from that other urban centers where crime and the fear of crime have become part of a depressing way of life. Recent studies of national crime trends show that in any given year only about half the serious crimes are reported police, and that only a minuscule proportion ends arrest, conviction and punishment. The sad fact is that the criminal justice system does not deter; it does not detect; it does not convict; it does not correct.

title: Chilean and Saudi Delegates Shout and Shove Each Other at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct 3  A request by the Soviet Union in the General Assembly that Secretary General Waldhelm intercede to save the life of a Chilean Communist resulted, in a shoving and shouting match at the podium today.

title: Body of Woman, 18, Stabbed 21 Times, Found in Lakewood
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Oct. 3 The body of an 18yearold woman, who had been stabbed 21 times in the back and chest, was found by a passerby last night in a wooded area of this Dover County community.

title: Primary Puts Atlanta's. Blacks In Good Position to Control City
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 3Atlanta politicsand quite possibly the city itselfmay never be the ??me again after a nonpartisan election yesterday that put blacks in a good position to win complete control of this Southern capital's government.

title: BRANDT DEFENDS DISSENTING AIDE
description: BONN, West Germany, Oct. 3 (AP)  Chancellor Willy Brandt firmly defended today an aide who touched off a controversy by criticizing West Germany's Eastern policy.

title: Shultz Predicts U.S.Soviet Trade Gains
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3George Shultz, United States Secretary of the Treasury, winding up three days of meetings with Soviet leaders said today that SovietAmerican trade could reach about $1.5billion this year, probably enough to make the United States Moscow's largest trading partner for the first time.

title: U.N. Bars TakeOver of Austrian Camp
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3The United Nations has rejected Austria's proposal that lit take over the Schnau transit camp for Soviet Jews, insisting it has no power to do so without approval by the General Assembly.

title: New Custom House: Modern, Functional, No Match for the Old
description: A funny thing happened on the way to the new Custom House at the World Trade Center. Public architecture declined and fell. On Oct. 19 at 2 P.M. the United States Custom Service will dedicate its new building, a sevenstory glass and aluminum structure flanking the Trade Center's North Tower, part of the complex designed by Minoru Yamasaki and Associates and Emory Roth and Sons. The new offices, a vast functional improvement over the old ones at Bowling Green, will consist of efficient, standardized accommodations with eightfoot ceilings and all the latest mechanical comforts and conveniences. It will also be a paradigm of modern commercial and institutional blandness.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: LESTER A. CRANCER
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3Lester A. Crancer, founder, president and chairman of the board of Valley Industries, Inc., a leading supplier of waterwell piping, died today at the Normandy Osteopathic Hospital. His age was 69.

title: STATE INCREASING MORTGAGE CEILING
description: The interestrate ceiling on home mortgages in New York State will be raised to 8 per cent, effective next Thursday, Harry W. Albright Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks and chairman of the. Ranking Board, announced last night.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: British Press Is Gibing at Princess Anne
description: LONDON, Oct. 3  The coolness of the British press toward Princess Anne was made apparent today in articles about two postage stamps to be issued to mark her marriage next month.

title: BIDS NOTICE TO CONTRACTORS DORMITORY AUTHORITY OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK (OWNER)
description: Sealed Bids, in DUPLICATE, for Construction of KINGSBOROUGH COMMUNITY COLLEGE ART/SCIENCE BUILDING will be received by the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York at the office the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York,41 East 42nd Streit, New York, New York 10017, bearing on the outside the name of the Bidder, his address, and designated as Bid forSeparate Bids will be received for General Construction, Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning, Plumbing, and Electrical Work. Only. those bids in the hands of the Owner available to be read at 2:30 o'clock P.M. (EST) on November 5, 1973, will be considered and then at such office publicly opened and read aloud.

title: Canadian Indicted in Draft Case Released on Bond in Vermont
description: A 25yearold naturalized Canadian citizen, who reportedly left the United States with his family as a teenager, was released on bond in Vermont on Tuesday, nine days after he was arrested at Kennedy Airport on draft evasion charges.

title: Strength in Cyclical Issues Highlights Day's Trading
description: Strength in cyclical issues and weakness in favorite glamour issues were highlighted in a stock market rally that kept rolling forward along a broad front yesterday. Volume continued very heavy.

title: Pitcher Throws for 12 Minutes, Gets Nod From Berra
description: Tom Seaver tested his tender right shoulder in Shea Stadium yesterday, found that pain had subsided, reported that everything was perfect during a 12minute workout and then was named as the New York Mets' starting pitcher Saturday in the National League playoff.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
294Day Bills Auctioned At a Yield of 7.702%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Treasury Department today sold $1.8billion in 294day Government bills at an average yield of 7.702 per cent.

title: Lane Bryant, Inc. Elects
description: Tilford C. Gaines, senior vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust, has been elected to the board of Lane Bryant, Inc. Or. Gaines is Manufacturers Hanover's leading economic spokesman.

title: Nixon's Backing Drops to 32%, In Gallup Poll, a SixPoint Loss
description: Less than onethird of the Americans surveyed in the most recent Gallup poll approve of the way President Nixon is handling his job.

title: Advertising: Cond Nast Moves
description: Elsie's old homestead has certainly become terribly chichi. Elmer would never recognize the place.

title: I.T.T. Sale to Puerto Rico Of Phone System Explored
description: Merger News

title: Rangers Beat Blues, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (AP) Mike Murphy's goal with less than a minute to play tonight gave the New York Rangers a 32 National Hockey League exhibition victory over the St. Louis Blues. Murphy's goal came on a deflection of a shot by Brad Park.

title: L.I.R.R. Sets Holiday Runs
description: The Long Island Rail Road train schedule for Monday, Columbus Day, will be posted in stations and available from information clerks today, a spokesman said last night.

title: Judge's Charge to the Grand Jury in Agnew Case
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 3Following is the text of a special charge that United States District Judge Walter E. Hoffman gave today to the Federal grand jury investigating allegations against Vice President Agnew:

title: TENTATIVE PACT SET IN NEWSPRINT STRIKE
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 3 (AP)A ??entative agreement at one company today and planned resumption of negotiations at another bolstered hopes of settlement in Eastern Canada's strikeridden newsprint industry:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Patrick Buchanan's appearance before the Watergate committee showed us, with startling clarity, an interesting phenomenon that appears to be at the root of the White House malaise. For weeks, in the appearances of the young men from the White House culminating in the testimony of Mr. Buchanan, we have seen these princes of the realm come before the cameras to whine about our treatment of toads.

title: Question of Slippage
description: It's a question of slippage, said Jeb Stuart Magruder in a discussion of Watergate in Harper's Magazine. I sort of slipped into it.

title: Wood, Field, Stream: Restoring Salmon
description: BOSTONAn effort to restor the Atlantic salmon to its former abundance in New England's Merrimack River is now under way.

title: People in Sports: No Yankee Job in Martin's Future
description: Billy Martin said yesterday from Arlington, Tex., I'm happy right here, and I have no intention of becoming manager of the New York Yankees. Martin, the new manager of the Rangers, rebutted rumors that he would succeed Ralph Houk by saying, Not a damned thing. to it. Bob Short, the Texas owner, aided, No one, Billy Martin, or any club, has talked to me, and they'd have to talk to me first.

title: Opera: Maag's First Traviata at Met
description: With anew conductor and a new Violetta, the performance of La Traviata at, the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night had a freshness and interest that went beyond the fact that it was the Verdi work's first hearing of the season.

title: Perseverance Pays, But Don't Bank on It
description: Last Friday a holdupman walked into the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Bank branch at 801 Westchester Avenue in the Bronx, pointed a gun at a woman teller and demanded money. Although warned not to trigger the alarm, the woman ducked and set off the signal. The robber fled.

title: Hundreds Wait All NightSale Will Continue Today
description: About 15,000 fans lined up at 52 windows outside Shea Stadium yesterday to buy tickets to New York's first postseason baseball playoff since the miracle of the Mets in 1969.

title: Dr. Sussman Says New Inspection Plan Is Not Satisfactory
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state health official who closed unsanitary kitchens in hospitals, restaurants and state institutions until he was reined in by the Attorney General, said today that the substitute system designed to deal with such facilities was not working.

title: Senate Cuts Aid to Schools In More Prosperous Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The Senate voted today a cut of 10 per cent in Federal aid to schools in states where the number of pupils from poor families has decreased.

title: Women for Academies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Representative Pierre S. Du Pont, Republican of Delaware, flanked today by four young women who want to go to the Air Force Academy, proposed legislation to permit females to enter all military academies.

title: Brown Is Recaptured
description: Henry Brown, an alleged member of the Black Liberation Army who escaped last week from Kings County Hospital, was captured last night in Brooklyn. Page 39.

title: Islanders Win, 43
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 3 (AP) Denis and Jean Potvin helped the New York Islanders of the National Hockey League beat the New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League tonight, 43.

title: Excerpts From Segretti's Testimony Before Senator Ervin's Select Committee
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the testimony in Washington yesterday of Donald H. Segretti before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Rescue 3 From Sinking Boat
description: Three Bronx men were rescued from a 25foot boat sinking in Long Island Sound near Hempstead Harbor after three police officers patrolling in a motor launch heard their cries for help. The craft had started taking water after hitting a rock near her berth at a marina on City Island. Those saved were identified as Richard Silver, 18 years old, of 1412 East 177th Street; Rubin Rubenstein, 24, of 2402 Raymond Avenue, and Robert Negron, 21, of 790 Astor Avenue.

title: 3 TELL OF ADMISSION IN STENNIS SHOOTING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Three witnesses testified today that Tyrone Marshall told them he was involved in the Jan. 30 shooting and robbery of Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississsippi.

title: Eban, at U.N., Assails Austrian Decision
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel said at the General Assembly today that Austria's decision to close transit facilities for Soviet Jews bound for Israel raised an issue far broader than the plight of the emigrating Jews.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchangemade no report available this week.

title: Safeway Rollback on Bread
description: DALLAS, Oct. 3 (UPI)Safeway Food Stores, Inc., has agreed to refund $9,582.66 to customers of 214 of its stores in Texas because of over charges on bread products, according to the Internal Revenue Service. The refunds will he made in the form of price reductions.

title: Poets Pay Tribute at Re.quiem for Auden
description: Words and poetic imagery by W. H. Auden sounded last night in the stone vaults of the Cathedral Church of. St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, at a solemn requiem eucharist in the poet's memory. Auden died Friday in Vienna at the age of 66.

title: WOMAY, 52, KNIFED IN CENTRAL PARR
description: A 52yearold woman was stabbed in the neck at noon yesterday by a man who snatched her purse while she was sitting and reading on a bench just inside Central Park off West 72d Street.

title: S.E.C. CHIEF FIRM ON FIXEDFEE END
description: Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, emphasized last night that the S.E.C. was committed to its stand that fixed brokwerage rates must end by April 30, 1975.

title: City Opera Catches Up Prestissimo
description: It was Anna Bolena on stage last night at the New York City Opera, but until midafternoon it was the first dress rehearsal with orchestra for Ariadne auf Naxos, which will have its premiere tonight. And close on its heels today will come A Village Romeo and Juliet, in dress rehearsal for its first performance Saturday night.

title: Bridge: The Italian Women's Team May Dominate World Scene
description: The Italian women's team had no trouble in winning the European Women's Team Championship in Ostend, Belgium, last week, and seems likely to dominate the world scene as effectively as the Italian open team has done for many years.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Assemblyman Albert Blumenthal declared last night that the police alone can never restore public safety to the streets of New York.

title: Israeli High Court Puts Off Expulsion of 28 U.S. Blacks
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 (UPI)The Israel High Court today postponed the expulsion of 28 American black Hebrews but rejected their right to remain in Israel on the ground that they were Jewish.

title: JUDGESHIP FORUM HAYES ISSUES OUT
description: A discussion among the three candidates for chief judge of the state that was supposed to be on issues turned into a somewhat acrimonious debate on personalities and politics yesterday morning in the auditorium of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, at 43 West 57th Street.

title: High School Sports
description: Ken Hernson was present at the creation. As a matter of fact, Ken Hernson is the creator and first coach of the Springfield Gardens football team. Springfield Gardens is in its first season of varsity football in the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: Baboons Will Get New Front Teeth In Implant Testing
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 3 (AP)Two dozen African baboons will have their front teeth removed and false ones implanted in an experiment aimed at cutting dental costs for humans.

title: Business Briefs
description: The AllisChalmers Corporation said yesterday that Federal Judge James B. Parsons had ruled in Illinois that Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., was liable to Allis for alleged shortswing profits it realized from the sale of 3.3 Million shares of AllisChalmers stock in 1968. Judge Parsons did not make a finding on the amount of the tecovery, Allis added.

title: Rosewall, Drysdale Win, Amritraj Upset in Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 3 (AP)Topseeded Ken Rosewall and No. 3seeded Cliff Drysdale led the way into the quarterfinal round of the $25,000 Osaka open tennis tournament today.

title: City to Try to Save a Tree Cut by Vandal in Brooklyn
description: The city will use a new grafting technique tomorrow to try to save a fourstoryhigh London plane tree in Brooklyn Heights that was heavily damaged by a vandal Sunday.

title: For Mrs. Sandman, Rewards in Politics
description: ERMA, Oct. 3For Marian Sandman, wife of the Republican nominee for Governor, campaigning is a new experience despite her husband's lengthy political career.

title: Senate Democrats Planning 2Week Recess in October
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Democratic Senators agreed today to a twoweek Senate recess later this month to await House action on money bills that must be passed before Congress can adjourn for the year.

title: Albany Police Chief Not Yet Convinced of Corruption!
description: ALBANY, Oct. 3  Police Chief Edward C. McArdle testified today that three weeks of sworn allegations of Albany policemen burglarizing stores, looting parking meters, protecting prostitutes and dope dealers and intimidating witnesses had not yet provided him with any information requiring disciplinary action.

title: Six Youths Burn Woman to Death In Boston Attack
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3Six youths forced a 24yearold woman to douse herself with two gallons of gasoline last night and then set her afire. She died early today of second and thirddegree burns that covered her entire body.

title: Alabama Newspaper Editor Found Shot to Death in Car
description: MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 3 (UPI)Arch B. McKay, Sunday editor of The Mobile PressRegister, was found shot to death in his car in a parking lot near the newspaper office today.

title: A Confident Richard M. Nixon Reemerges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The man who stood before the White House press corps this morning seemed like the Richard M. Nixon of early 1972the Nixon whose voice didn't quaver, the Nixon who dealt confidently with a wide range of questions, the Nixon who clearly felt on top of his job, the Nixon who could even manage a bit of humor.

title: Paul Hartman Is Dead at 69; Starred in Angel in the Wings
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (UPI) Paul Hartman, the actor, dancer and comedian, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: Earnings of J. P. Morgan & Co. Climbed by 22.7% in 3d Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Co., parent company of the nation's fifth biggest bank and the first to report thirdquarter results, disclosed yesterday that its earnings for the period jumped 22.7 er cent.

title: Foreign Films, Popular in U.S. in '60's, Being Treated Like Foreigners in '70's
description: Emergence in the late nineteensixties of American movies that stopped looking at life through softfocus lenses, coupled with the disappearance of the art circuit, today puts foreignlanguage films in the expendable position of a Continental chef whose saucy recipes are now in the best Hollywood cookbooks. An era of profitable delicacies from overseas has come to an end.

title: NIXON IS BACKED ON TRADE POWERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)President Nixon won key Congressional committee ap proval today of a bill giving him sweeping new powers in trade negotiations, but failed in an, attempt to win mostfav orednation status for the So riet Union.

title: The Associated Press Is Accused Of Racial and Sex Bias in Hiring
description: The Associated Press was charged yesterday with discriminating against members of minority groups and women in complaint that the Wire Service Guild said it had filed with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: TWO FREIGHT CARS WITH GAS DERAILED
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 3  A Boston and Maine freight train derailed tonight as it pulled into the town of Johnsonville five miles northeast of here, sending two of its cars down a 10foot embankment, where they blocked a state highway.

title: Government Issues Ease Following Action by Fed
description: Prices stiffened yesterday in the corporate bond market after edging down again in early trading. Government issues eased following continued action in the market by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: CORONADO DANCERS OFFER 2 NEW WORKS
description: Attending a Jose Coronado concert is like assisting at a religious service whose rubric is only dimly grasped. One feels it would be much more meaningful with greater familiarity, although the surface incidents in themselves have a muted fascination. Mr. Coronado and his dancers presented a program of his works, including two new dances, at the Cubiculo Tuesday evening.

title: HOUSE APPROVES SUBSIDY TO CITIES FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The House voted today to pay part of the operating costs for mass transit systems in New York and other urban areas.

title: CAMBODIA CASUAL IN DEFENSE MOVES
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 3The Prek Thnot River is a meandering waterway that snakes its way through the sweeping plains of rice and palm trees south of Phnom Penh, sometimes less than 10 Miles from the capital.

title: Head of Cattlemen's Group, in City, Urges Return to Buying of Beef
description: The president of the American National Cattlemen's Association came to the city yesterday to invite consumers to come back to buying beef.

title: By Dawns Early Light, Its Tennis Before Business
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  Long before high school students have picked out their jeans for the day and even before the street lights turn off, residents of this Westchester village are outdoors at Scarsdale High School finding a solution to their own energy crisis.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Says Congress Gave Nixon Excess Power
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The A.F.L.C.I.O. asserted today that Congress had given President Nixon too much leeway in authorizing economic controls, and that some lowpaid workers had suffered as a result.

title: STATE AID URGED FOR COOP HOUSING
description: A state fund to finance the rehabilitation of old apartment buildings and their conversion to lowincome and moderateincome cooperatives was urged yesterday in a report sponsored by Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan and the Manhattan members of the City Council.

title: Wood, Field, Stream: Restoring Salmon
description: BOSTONAn effort to restore the Atlantic salmon to its former abundance in New England's Merrimack River is now under way.

title: Federal Raise in Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) President Nixon ordered into effect today a 4,77 per cent pay increase for civilian and military employes of the Federal Government. His action by proclamation had been promised last week after the Senate rejected his request that it be delayed as an antiinflation move.

title: Prices Continue to Rise on Amex and OTC in Active Trading
description: Continued active trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market sent prices up again yesterday.

title: High School Sports
description: Ken Hernson was present at the creation. As a matter of fact, Ken Hernson is the creator and first coach of the Springfield Gardens football team. Springfield Gardens is in its first season of varsity football in the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: Segretti Describes Chapin As Boss of Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Donald H. Segretti testified today that he had reported regularly last year to President Nixon's appointments secretary about the dirty tricks he was playing on candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Customs Service Does More Than Just Collect.
description: When John Lamb, the port's first collector of customs, set up shop in the old Presidential Mansion on Bowling Green, he and his small band of assistants collected $145,329 in duties that year.

title: Parcel Bomb Kills A Soldier in Ulster; Mailman Shot Dead
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 3A British soldier was killed by a parcel bomb in Londonderry today and a mailman was murdered while collecting mail in Lurgan, County Armagh, 25 miles west of Belfast.

title: Orange County Gets Jump Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3Judy Korn's Orange County, one of the leaders in the race for the national highpoint championship in the division, won the amateurowner jumper title by a point tonight at the Philadelphia Horse Show in the Spectrum.

title: Nixon Appeals to Kreisky To Review Action on Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3President Nixon appealed to Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria today to reconsider his decision to close transit facilities for Soviet Jews going to Israel because we simply cannot have governments small or large  give in to international blackmail by terrorist groups.

title: Bus Strike Ends 5th Day
description: LONG BRANCH, Oct. 3 (AP) Drivers on the New YorkKeansburg  Long Branch Bus Company were off the job again today, the fifth day of a shutdown of the shore commuter bus line. An official at Teamster Local 701 said there had been no change in status in the strike by the Monmouth Courty lime's 38 drivers.

title: Five Die in Collapse Of TV Tower in Iowa
description: BOWLEY. Iowa, Oct. 3 AP)Five men were killed when the 2,000foot television tower of the Cedar Rapids station, KCRG, buckled and fell today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Sinyaysky Book on His Years In Labor Camp Is Due Here
description: Andrei D. Sinyaysky, the expatriate Soviet author, has written a memoir of his years in a Soviet labor camp that is to be published here late next year, Roger W. Straus Jr. said yesterday.

title: A Full House at Coliseum for NetsKnicks Tonight
description: A rematch between the Knicks and the Nets is scheduled tonight before a packed house at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., but their first game is still a hot topic of discussion.

title: Belgian Bank Rate Raised
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 3 (Reuters) The Belgian bank rate will be increased to 7 per cent from 6.5 per cent effective tomorrow. The National Bank announced today. The rate had been 6.5 per cent since August 2.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 0.8 From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 193.2 from 194 last week.

title: Pact Accepted at Deere
description: MOLINE, Ill., Oct. 4 (UPI)The International Association of Machinists at Des Moines, Iowa, voted yesterday to accept a new contract offer from Deere & Co., ending a threeday strike. Deere is a maker of farm implements.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Snapping a threeday winning streak, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday in lighter but still moderatelyactive trading. Prices also closed lower in the overthecounter market.

title: People in Sports: Wrigley Disgusted With His Cubs
description: Phil Wrigley, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, said he was disgusted with his team's performance this season, then rehired Whitey Lockman as manager for 1974 yesterday.

title: Vietnam Autumn
description: WASHINGTONIn the fall of 1939, in my native city in Vietnam, the now sadly famous former imperial capital of Hue, a young poet, Luu Trong Lu, published his Tieng Thu (The Sounds of Autumn). Overnight he became our idol.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Miller Leads French Golf
description: ST  NOM  LA  BRETECHE, France, Oct. 4 (Reuters)Johnny Miller, the United States Open champion, took a onestroke lead on the opening day of the Lancome Trophy invitation Golf Match today with a fourunderpar 68 over the 6,825yard course. Spain's Valentin Barrios was next.

title: GUILD AT THE NEWS VOTES STRIKE POWER
description: Members of the New York newspaper Guild on the staff of The Daily News voted 696 to 5 yesterday to empower their union officials to call a strike If negotiations for a new contract were unsuccessful.

title: Books of The Times
description: PORTRAIT OF A MARRIAGE. By Nigel Nicolson. 249 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $10.

title: Mississippian Confirmed As Episcopalians' Leader
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. Oct. 4The Right Rev. John M. Allin, Bishop of Mississippi, was confirmed today as the presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church after an unusual debate in which opponents in the House of Deputies, one house of the bicameral convention, contended that Bishop Allin would symbolize church retrenchment on programs to help minorities.

title: ON HOLIDAY EVE, JEWS ASSAIL DEAL
description: On the eve of Yom Kippur, which begins at sundown to day, Jewish spiritual and secular leaders assailed the Austrian Government for deciding to close its transit facilities for Soviet Jews leaving for Israel.

title: Red Smith
description: With the possible exception of the commissionernot Bowie Kuhn, any commissionerthe most absurdly overrated figure in sports is the manager of a baseball team. The best can't win games and the worst lose precious few. If a man has enough executive ability to head the housewares department in Macy's and knows when to change pitchers, he can manage as well as his troops can play. Nobody can manage better.

title: AliFrazier Rematch: The Verbal Blows Fly
description: More for the cameras than for any other reason, Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali resumed yelling at each other yesterday at a Madison Square Garden news conference confirming their planned 12round rematch there Feb. 4.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: Pace in August Fell 10% From Level in July
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The growth of consumer credit during August slowed somewhat from the frantic pace set earlier this year, an additional indication of a slowing of economic activity, Federal Reserve Board statistics showed today.

title: EXCITY OFFICIAL INDICTED IN BRONX
description: A former deputy purchase commissioner for the city was indicted yesterday for perjury by a special Bronx grand jury investigating a scheme to bribe an unhamed public official, acdording to Maurice H. Nadjari, special state prosecutor.

title: City Opera at Its Best in Anna Bolena
description: ANNA BOLENA, opera with music by Gaetano Donizetti and libretto by Felice Romani. New York City Opera production devised and directed by Tito CamMauro with sets by Ming Cho Lee, costumes by Jose Verona, lighting by Hans Sondheimer Elena Denda, assistant director. Conductor, Julius Rudel. At the Hew York State Theater.

title: Byrne and Sandman Trade Bitter Insults In Debate in Newark
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4  Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican, and Brendan T. Byrne, the Democrat, exchanged ridicule and abuse tonight in a freeswinging campaign debate that was their most bitter confrontation so far in their fight for the governorship of New Jersey.

title: When Fashion Stumbles Off the Runway Into the Street
description: She is the mess of the moment but no one will notice.

title: Harness Drivers Bitter at Cloud Hanging Over Sport
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 4 Morris McDonald, like most of the harness racing drivers at Roosevelt Raceway, bitterly resents what he considers the filching of his good name by the Federal investigation into alleged fixing of races.

title: Producer of Movie With Burning Scene Disturbed by Death
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The producer of the, police comedy film Fuzz said, today he was disturbed by allegations that the film might have contributed to the gasoline burning of Mrs. Evelyn M. Wagler by six youths in Boston, Tuesday and said, I just hope lit wasn't so.

title: Nixon and 4 Advisers In Florida for Weekend
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 4 (AP)President Nixon and four aides arrived here this afternoon for a long weekend.

title: LoanShark Victim's Ordeal Described
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 4The Nassau County District Attorney said today that a taxi driver who could not pay 100 per cent interest on a $10,000. loan had been beaten with brass knuckles, taken for a wild ride, forced at gunpoint to watch while a grave was dug for his, body and then was driven home with the threat that his, house would be bombed if he failed to pay his debt.

title: Hornsby Wants Big Role With Giants
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 4 Remember Ron Hornsby middle linebacker for the New York Giants, leader, player with a future, the guy who in one coach's words, hustles more than anybody on the team?

title: U.S Attorney Designated For Potential Agnew Case
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI) United States Attorney James R. Thompson has been selected to represent the Government if hearings are held to investigate news leaks in the Justice Department's case against Vice President Agnew.

title: Stocks Volume Drop
description: Profit taking in the bluechip and glamour stocks helped to push the stock market lower yesterday in slower trading.

title: Dining Out: Superb Beginning and EndBut a Poor Middle
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: City Notes Auctioned
description: Interest rates traced a mixed pattern yesterday as the credit markets calmed down from the violent swings that have characterized many recent sessions.

title: U.S. to Widen Protection of Newsmen
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4 (UPI)Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson has decided to require all Justice Department employes to obtain his approval before any reporter can be questioned, arrested or indicted for an offense arising from coverage of a news story, a spokesman said today.

title: Parisians Pleased but Critics Pained By Bejart Choreographed Traviata
description: PARIS, Oct. 4Some people think that La Traviata is an opera by Giuseppe Verdi, but others are not so sure.

title: Tramunti Is Charged
description: Federal and city law enforcement officials yesterday announced the indictments of 43 persons in a move that United States Attorney Paul J. Curran said would have a substantial impact on heroin distribution in the city.

title: Delay Is Seen in NATO Security Accord
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 4  Diplomats here say that the drafting of a declaration of military security principles for the year of Europe will probably take weeks longer than the Americans had thought it would take.

title: REALESTATE AGENT SLAIN NEAR BOWERY
description: A 25  yearold real  estate agent was fatally stabbed near the Bowery yesterday morning minutes after delivering a set of apartment keys to the superintendent of a building owned by the company he worked for.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bus riders will be able to buy a 75 cent ticket to be used for unlimited rides in midtown Manhattan during nonrush hours beginning. Oct, 8, according to Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

title: Agnew Successor Accused Of Evading Federal Taxes
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 4  The special grand jury investigating allegations of contract kickbacks against Vice President Agnew and others returned today a new indictment against N. Dale Anderson, the Democrat who succeeded Mr. Agnew as the County Executive of suburban Baltimore County.

title: Westchester Judge Jails 22 Teachers in Walkout
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4Twentytwo striking teachers from Yorktown Heights, seven of them women and one a grandmother, spent most of the day in the Westchester County jail today for defying a court order to return to work.

title: Board of Trade Is Sued Over Dealings in Soybeans
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI)A $200million classaction suit has been filed in United States district court here against the Chicago Board of Trade accusing the exchange of unfair regulation of soy bean trading.

title: ACQUISITION SET BY HOLDING UNIT
description: The Republic of Texas Corporation, a bankholding company recently organized by the Republic National Bank of Dallas, has reached agreement in principle to acquire the Houston National Company, which owns the Houston National Bank.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MS. MESSAGE The second annual Women's Video Festival is in full swing, and even those women chained to household chores with no other company than soap operas or Watergate hearings on the small screen will find this television different. It's taking place every night at 8:30 (also at 3 P.M., Thursdays through Sundays) at LoGiudice Gallery, 59 Wooster Street, near Spring Street. This is the new home, at least temporarily, of the Kitchen, the room that used to hatch electronic arts at the Mercer Arts Center.

title: Billboard Sales Pitch Called LawBreaker
description: The Times Square electronic billboard of the Bulova Watch Company at 46th Street and Broadway, which tells the time to the tenth of a second, violates the Consumer Protection Law three times every four minutes, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Betty Furness charged yesterday.

title: A Violent PreDawn Quake Shakes the Chilean Capitol
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Friday, Oct. 5 (UPI)A violent Predawn earthquake rocked the Chilean Capital early today, shaking buildings and throwing thousands of persons from their beds.

title: Austrian Tells of Bargain With Gunmen
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4The Foreign Minister of Austria, in an interview today, gave some details of the bargaining process last weekend between the Austrian Government and, Palestinian guerrillas who were holding four hostages at the Vienna airport.

title: SOYUZ 12 HAILED BY U.S. SPACE AIDE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4An American space official today called the recent successful Soviet Soyuz 12 manned space mission a flight of confidence for prospects for the SovietAmerican space linkup in 1975.

title: MERRILL IS ACCUSED OF DISCRIMINATION
description: A 45yearold portfolio analyst testified to the New York State Human Rights Division yesterday that Merrill Lynch discriminated against her last year because she was pregnant and then cut her from the payroll last spring. Merrill Lynch denied the charges.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES SNOWED 1.5% DROP FOR SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The index of wholesale prices led by a large decline in food prices, went down in September, registering the largest decline for a single month since February, 1948. However, prices of industrial products shot up sharply again.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHATHAM, Mass.  At sunset, the easterly wind that had been gusting across Schoolhouse Pond subsided, an occasional trout rose, and swallows swooped low over the water picking up emerging aquatic insects.

title: LENIENCY IS CHARGED ON DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt has accused the state courts of allowing many motorists arrested for drunken driving to plead guilty to lesser offenses and of then delaying for weeks or months the report on every conviction that is supposed to be filed with the Department of Motor Vehicles within 48 hours.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES SHOWED 1.5% DROP FOR SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The index of wholesale prices led by a large decline in food prices, went down in September, registering the largest decline for a single month since February, 1948. However, prices of industrial products shot up sharply again.

title: Mets to Take Orders For Tickets to Series
description: The New York Mets announced yesterday that mail orders would be accepted for World Series tickets.

title: Jurors at Jersey Drug Trial Listen to Phone Tapes
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4A Federal Court jury today heard several hours of tapped telephone conversations that, according to the Government, prove that a conspiracy to smuggle 22 pounds of heroin into the country from Canada took place last year.

title: EXILES IN CHILE GIVEN PROTECTION
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 4 Chile's military rulers issued a decree today guaranteeing the protection of foreign political refugees here, but with certain conditions.

title: TESTIMONY OPENS IN DOUGLAS CASE
description: A witness in a class action suit against the Douglas Aircraft Company testified yesterday in Federal Court here that the airplane manufacturer had production problems when it issued a prospectus in 1966 for an offering of $75million of convertible subordinated debentures.

title: CITY PETITIONS U.S. TO RESTORE GRANT
description: The city's Corporation Counsel has formally asked the Federal Government to restore nearly $1million in Federal grants to a Brooklyn school district that refused to take part in what it charged was a discriminatory, dualstandard Government testing project.

title: Conservative Economists See Budget Surplus in '76
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  A group of conservative economists took a long look ahead at the Federal budget today and concluded that a growing economy would produce enough tax receipts to start new programs or permit tax reductions, or both, beginning two or three years hence.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Justice James Leff declared a mistrial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, blaming the Correction Department for failing to deliver one of three defendants in a robbery trial. The justice noted that the trial was three days old, that the jury had been waiting in another room since 9:30 A.M. and that it is now 1:05 P.M. and defendant James Dollston is not here.

title: Harness Drivers Bitter at Cloud Hanging Over Sport
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 4 Morris MacDonald, like most of the harness racing drivers at Roosevelt Raceway, bitterly resents what he considers the filching of his good name by the Federal investigation into alleged fixing of races.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 4 (AP)  Mario Andretti, driving an Offypowered Viceroy Special, set a world closedcourse speed record today of 214.158 miles an hour in a qualifying run. He had a previous lap of 213.460.

title: PHELPS DODGE SETS INCREASE IN PRICES
description: Phelps Dodge Industries, Inc., yesterday confirmed rumors by announcing price increases for copper magnet wire, copper water tubing and related items and brass fittings and valves. The copper product rises were between 9 and 10 per cent and the brass producers rose by an average of 5 per cent. The new prices were based on increased costs for merchant copper and scrap copper.

title: MAN SEIZED IN SALE OF 3,000 WEAPONS

title: Texaco Tells 7 Airlines It Will Cut Jet Fuel Sales

Minish of Orange, the floor manager for the bill.

title: Metsomania
description: It takes most baseball teams a few decades to build a tradition. Not so the Mets. Their swift climb from the cellar to the championship in the National League's Eastern division confirms their right to recognition inandouters capable of confounding the most knowledgeable handicappers. Never mind that all the clubs in that division barely qualify as being of majorleague caliber. The kind of drive the Mets showed in the last month (to say nothing of their pitching) makes every loyal Shea Stadium Metsomaniac certain that the World Series victory pennant will be back on the flagstaff where it hung so proudly after the miracle of 1969. Tomorrow, with Tom Seaver's throwing arm reportedly back in good shape, the Mets will be taking the first step in Cincinnati toward solidifying their dream.

title: DETROIT'S TEACHERS FOUND IN CONTEMPT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4 (UPI)Circuit Court Judge Thomas J. Foley today found striking Detroit teachers guilty of contempt for ignoring an order to return to their classrooms.

title: The New Normalcy
description: Nobody speaks much about Vietnam now, but it happened, and we are heading into a postwar era  the third in the lifetime of millions of Americans. The style for modern postwar eras was set by the first one, following World War I, and it has, so far, proved to be a rather persistent style. Our postwar periods are eras of disillusion and rebirth, marked by economic laissezfaire, political corruption, social liberation, and cultural flowering. After World War I we had Harding's normalcy, Teapot Dome, the age of jazz and flappers, and the great lost generation of writers. After World War II and its Korean aftermath, we had a great era of uncontrolled business expansion, the Truman Administration scandals (pale ones, it now appears, but scandals nonetheless), the civilrights movement.

title: Screen: 'La Rupture':Chabrol's Melodrama Shown at Festival The Cast
description: Claude Chabrol has reportedly described his 1970 melodrama, "La Rupture" (The Breakup), as belonging to his Fritz Lang period, which may be one of its virtues as well as one of its difficulties. The film, which was shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center last night, will be shown there again tonight.At least I find it difficult to sit comfortably through a movie in which innocence and virtue are so hopelessly imperiled that it takes nothing less than a fairly arbitrary plot device to straighten things out."La Rupture," with a screenplay adapted by Chabrol from a novel by Charlotte Armstrong, has so many beautiful things in it that I'm tempted to suspect some terrible weakness in myself, rather than the film, for the feeling of depressed impatience it left. Perhaps not.Perhaps one should be impatient with a film that opens with a brutal sequence in which a father beats up his wife and attempts to smash the brains of his 4-year-old son. Later on, the film treats us to the spectacle of a retarded teen-age girl, who has been kidnapped and drugged by the villain, being shown pornographic films and seduced by the man's mistress.It's not that newspapers don't contain stories of worse horrors, but that Chabrol, who is not a frivolous film maker, allows these things to be put in the service of a rather frivolous end. That is, our entertainment.I realize that in saying this I'm also testifying to the film's effect, which is torturous. But then I found Lang's "Human Desire," which is a much tougher film, much easier to endure."La Rupture" is the story of a woman trapped in such circumstances that even her decency and trust can be used as weapons against her.When Hlne, played by the extraordinarily gifted Stphane Audran, attempts to leave her husband, a part-time writer and full-time junkie, her wealthy father-in-law attempts to discredit her morals in order to obtain custody of his grandson. The father-in-law, played by Michel Bouquet (who, like Miss Audran, has become an important contributor to Chabrol's films), employs Jean-Pierre Cassel to frame Hlne, but the attempts are so clumsy that the film, though emotionally harrowing, is plausible only as an arid statement about the possibility of evil.Within this frame, which I found difficult to accept, "La Rupture" contains some true Chabrol achievements, especially the sense of locale (Belgium, which is seen as the suburb to the rest of the world), and the performance by Miss Audran. About halfway through the film, she delivers a monologue about Hlne's marriage that is one of the most moving things I've seen this year. It may be difficult on any realistic level to accept Miss Audran as the barmaid she is supposed to be, but the stunning quality of her beauty and personality become a kind of personification of Chabrol's cool concerns, which, otherwise, have no recognizable human shape.There is also another problem with the frame of the film: the disadvantages and indignities are piled so thickly on the poor heroine that one knows early that the film is obliged to offer her vindication. Otherwise it has no shape. That her vindication is achieved at a high price isn't surprising or touching enough to transform the melodrama of "La Rupture" into tragedy.
