title: Charter Pilot Killed
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI)A Midwest Air Charter pilot shuttling canceled checks from Cleveland to Chicago was killed yesterday when his twinengine plane crashed in heavy fog on an apparent approach to Meigs Field. The pilot was identified as John Fair, 36 years old.

title: Look Under the Rock
description: If Governor Rockefeller wants a straightforward answer to his request for a report on why rents are going up so fast in this city and state, he should not have to wait long.

title: Icelandic Frost
description: The withdrawal of British warships from disputed fishing grounds off Iceland is a constructive gesture. It ought to facilitate the solution of two unrelated issues which Iceland has managed to link for bargaining advantagefishing rights and NATO bases.

title: Kissinger Assures Cambodians of Continued Support
description: Secretary of State Kissinger assured Foreign Minister Long Boret of Cambodia yesterday of continued American support for the Government of President Lon Nol and said that while in Peking later this month he had no plans to meet with the rival Cambodian leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who lives in the Chinese capital.

title: 3DQUARTER LOSS SEEN BY CHRYSLER
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4The Chrysler Corporation said today that preliminary figures indicated that it had a net Ioss of up to $26million, or 50 cents a share, in the third quarter.

title: FUTURES IN COCOA IN SHARP DECLINE
description: Cocoa futures dropped sharply yesterday on word of some possible competition. Traders learned that Monsanto Company, the large United States chemical producer, has developed a true chocolate flavoring that can be sold cheaper than the real product for use in many food items.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Energy Crisis Study Commission said yesterday that it opposed lowering air quality standards this winter to help ease the predicted energy shortages.

title: Chicken With a Peanut Butter Sauce
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Candidates' Day
description: The Conservative party, badly split over the candidacy of Representative Mario Biaggi, its nominee for Mayor, has invited him to its annual dinner but has not asked, him to speak.

title: BAR CHIEF SCORES NAMING OF JUDGES
description: Orville H. Schell Jr., president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, yesterday attacked the Governor's method of appointing new Court of Claims judges and said there was a strong likelihood that, the association would join in a law suit challenging the constitutionality of the appointments.

title: The Pop Life
description: On her own after about decade of hits with the Vandellas, and about to have her first solo album released by her new record company, MCA, is Martha Reeves. The fantastic woman who really immortalized the classic pop song Dancing in the Streets sat in an outdoor cafe on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles not too long ago and talked about the past, the present and the new direction of her career and life.

title: Right to Leap Off Golden Gate at Issue on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4. The thought of that dizzying, breathstopping, last look downward before stepping off into space from the Golden Gate Bridge has long held a powerful fascination for San Franciscans.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your Sept. 27 editorial on the Vice President, Impeach or Indict Unacceptable Risk, you recognize the difference of opinion that exists regarding the difficult and complex con stitutional question of whether the Vice President would have, to be removed from office through an impeachment procedure prior to being subject to trial. You conclude that if the Vice President is determined to pursue his interpretation of that constitutional issue  an interpretation which would bar a trial in any court prior to his impeachment and conviction by Congress  such a course of action, you conclude, creates an unacceptable risk. You state that the Vice President must not only be presumed innocent, he should be perceived to be above suspicion. Your rationale appears to be that if this suspicion should continue during the time the constitutional question was being resolved, we would have an awkward and intolerable void in the event of transfer of Presidential power.

title: 3 in Bank Siege With Hostages Give Up
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 4Three exconvicts seized a bank vice president and a woman teller as hostages during an attempted holdup south of here today and repeatedly threatened to kill them before surrendering to Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and 100 policemen who surrounded the bank.

title: BURTON S. FLAGG
description: ANDOVER Mass., Oct. 4Burton S. Flagg, former president of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies and the Mutual Fire Insurance Association of New England, died yesterday at a nursing home in North Andover. He was 99 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that 95 per cent of the economists responding to its annual economic survey were bullish on the stock market for 1974.

title: Hearings Will Recess At End of Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that the Senate Watergate committee would recess its hearings at the end of next week when the Senate begins a twoweek break.

title: Syracuse Drops 3 Sports
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 4 (AP)Syracuse University today suspended three sports from its athletic program, with a fourth to be dropped later this fall. The sports are fencing, rifle and tennis, with golf also to be dropped at the end of its fall schedule.

title: ACCORD ENDS STRIKE AT ST. LOUIS PAPERS
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Striking newspaper drivers and truck loaders approved a new contract tonight, ending the longest shutdown of both major newspapers in the city's history.

title: A.C.L.U. Asks Impeachment of Nixon
description: The American Civil Liberties Union called Yesterday far the impeachment of President Nixon and said such a move was backed overwhelmingly by the group's board of directors.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ISRAEL COUNTERING BLACKS' BID TO STAY
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 4Interior Minister Yosef Burg called upon the United States Government today to reject applications for renunciation of citizenship by American blacks living illegally in Israel.

title: Gas Dealer Pleads for Understanding of Shutdowns
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. Oct. 4 Ralph Colyer has always tried to be fair. If he promised to fix a customer's car by 6 P.M., he usually managed. He gave credit. He lent old clunkers or gave lifts to customers who dropped off their cars.

title: Lawyer for Striking Musicians Reports Reduction of Demands
description: Victor Rabinowitz, lawyer for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, whose members are now in the 10th day of a strike against the New York Philharmonic, said yesterday that the musicians have substantially reduced demands to an allinclusive package of wage and fringe benefit improvements that fall well within Federal guidelines.

title: Letellier, With 138, Leads by 2
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4Ron Letellier, unattached, from Flushing, Queens, scored 69 for the second day in row at Elmwood Country Club today and, with 138. took a twostroke lead in the Izod $10,000 championship of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association.

title: HENRY LICHTIG
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 4Henry Lichtig, a real estate lawyer who was counsel to the Bronx Chamber of Commerce in New York for 25 years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old and formerly lived at 737 Park Avenue in New York.

title: TV: For Chronic Dial Flipper, MixedBag Season
description: The new season, cont'd: The Police Story. Tuesdays, 10 to 11 P.M., National Broadcasting Company. Of all the police capers on TV, this has the most potential. The series was created by Joseph Wambaugh, a bestselling author and a member of the Los Angeles Police Department. The details of police life are likely to be more authentic than usual, and Mr. Wambaugh is at his best when exploring the gray, ambiguous areas where distinctions between a policeman's job and criminal activity tend to get blurred.

title: IRT TRAIN DERAILED, 3 HURT IN BROOKLYN
description: Three persons were injured last night when an IRT Lexington Avenue express train was derailed in the subway tunnel under Flatbush Avenue near the Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn.

title: Home for Aged Passes Crucial Sanitary Check
description: BLOOMFIELD, Oct. 4 (UPI) The State Department of Health said today that the kitchen at the Bloomfield Home for Aged Men and Women was clear enough to remain in operation.

title: Mike Quarry Loses Decision to Kendall
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 4 (AP)Andy Kendall of Portland, Ore., won a 10round split decision over Mike Quarry last night in a lightheavyweight bout.

title: Against the Cold
description: The Administration has finally settled upon one step to help protect the nationor at least the northern parts of itfrom a chilly anarchy in fuel supplies this winter. A form of heatingoil rationing is to be imposed, the first such curb since World War II. Predictably, the plan has pleased no one. But the strongest criticism is not over the fact of rationing; rather, it is that the belatedly adopted policy is so close to the bare minimum required that it may fail to prevent widespread shortages and power failures in any prolonged cold spell.

title: Brutality in Boston
description: Even in an era hardened to criminal violence, the mind's capacity for horror and revulsion is overtaxed by the hideous sadism of six youths in Boston who forced a young woman to douse herself with gasoline and then set her afire, Race hatred of the kind that virulent in many sections of this historic city was apparently a motivating element in this demented tragedy, but the television screen may well have provided the murderers with instruction in the inhuman technique they used.

title: Brown Is Confined in Undisclosed Jail
description: Henry Brown, the 24yearold black militant who was recaptured Wednesday night following his escape a week ago while in custody awaiting trial for the murder of two policemen, was back in jail yesterday, but authorities would not say where.

title: 7 HELD IN MURDER OF STATE WITNESS
description: TRENTON, Oct 4  Seven underworld figures today were ordered held in lieu of $750,000 bail each in connection with the 1971 murder of a prosecution witness in an armedrobbery case.

title: Guerrillas Are Said to Warn Moscow
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 4A Palestinian guerrilla group reportedly warned the Soviet Union today that its embassies and interests the Middle East would be attacked unless it halted the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel.

title: Vietcong Walkout Brings Suspension Of Talks in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct 4 (AP)  The political talks between the Saigon Government and the Vietcong were indefinitely suspended today after the Vietcong State Minister, Nguyen Van Hieu, walked out of the 28th session without waiting for the other side to speak.

title: Eastern Proposes A Financing Plan To Major Lenders
description: Eastern Air Lines, shaken by heavy economic losses, put before its major lenders yesterday a revised financing plan tied mainly to proposed delays in deliveries of Lockheed widebody jets and to temporary waivers of some mortgage conditions.

title: Bridge: 3 Redoubles in One Evening May Be Some Sort of Mark
description: In good company, redoubled contracts are very rare. Leaving aside the wild gamblers and those who stubbornly pass when their partners make S/O/S redoubles, one might expect to be involved in a redoubled contracttwo or three times a year at the most.

title: Penn's Ivy League Hopes Clouded by Opening Loss
MRS. MOLLIE TOWNSEND
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Oct. 4Mrs. Mollie Lane Townsend, an organizer and secretary of Local 40, American Communications Association, from 1936 to 1958, died Tuesday in Southside Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived here.

title: A Gambler Says He Made a Deal With Pindling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4, (UPI) A gambler testified today that he had made a deal with Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling of the Bahamas to help finance his 1968 campaign in exchange for control of all gambling casinos on the islands

title: Narcotics judge Warns Of Pitfall in New Laws
description: Court of Claims Judge Howard A. Jones, former director of the state addiction control program, warned yesterday that provisions of the new narcotics laws mandating strict prison terms for past felony offenders allow no distinctions, even for Jim Crow conviction records in the South dating back many years.

title: Mississippian Confirmed As Episcopalians' Leader
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. Oct. 4The Right Rev. John M. Allin, Bishop of Mississippi, was confirmed today as the Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church after an unusual debate in which opponents in the House of Deputies, one house of the bicameral convention, contended that Bishop Allin would symbolize church retrenchment on programs to help minorities.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS 7% PENSION RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Social Security benefits by 7 per cent, effective as soon as enacted.

title: Mrs. Penati Is Wed to Charles F. Adams
description: DOVER, Mass., Oct. 4Mrs. Beatrice Dabney Penati was married here this evening to Charles Francis Adams, board chairman of the Raytheon Company, electronics manufacturers. The Unitarian ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. B. Howell Dabney.

title: Dash Urges Sirica Order For Surrender of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Samuel Dash, the chief counsel for the Senate Watergate Committee, argued in Federal court today that President Nixon has no right to withhold secret tape recordings that might implicate the President in criminality.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Orlando, Fla. Andy Kendall, Portland, Ore., outpointed Mike Quarry, Anaheim, Calif., 10 rounds, light heavyweights.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS CHALLENGED IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4  Black African nations today challenged the credentials of the South African delegation to the United Nations.

title: ARTHUR WEISS
description: Arthur Weiss, president of the Photographic Manufacturers and Distributors Association died, apparently of a heart attack, in Lake Success, L.I., on Wednesday. He was 58 years old,

title: State Panel Calls Albany Victim of Police Tyranny
description: ALBANY, Oct. 4  The State Commission of Investigation, reviewing what it called the appalling acts of police corruption that have been revealed here, today characterized, the citizens of the state's capital city as victims of police corruptiontyranny.

title: Urgent Course
description: By its adoption of a bill to provide operating subsidies for urban transit systems, the House of Representatives passed another milestone this week in its growing recognition that mass transit is the key to livable cities and breathable air. Unlike the Senate, which has had no great difficulty in passing masstransit bills, the House has until now yielded to the objections of its many rural members, some of whom appear to derive active pleasure from the plight of the citiesespecially New York.

title: Rosewall Beats Kuki By 62, 64
description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 4 (UPI) Ken Rosewall of Australia today entered the semifinals of the men's singles of the $25,000 Osaka open tennis tournament by beating Jun Kuki, Japanese Davis Cup player, 62, 64.

title: Rain at Nicklaus's Course Erases Round and Jack's 75
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Oct. 4  Jack Nicklaus, disappointed and embarrassed, scored a 75 today on the course that bears his name and of which he is part owner and codesigner. But three hours after he had posted his score in the $125,000 OhioKings Island open, that left him eight strokes back of the apparent leader, Don Bies, play was suspended and the round canceled because of two thunder and lightning storms.

title: Agnew Praises Nixon and His Policies
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4  Vice President Agnew returned tonight to his old role of lauding President Nixon and championing his Administration's policies.

title: ThirdTry Success
description: After two disgraceful attempts to gerrymander New York City's minority groups out of any real opportunity to increase their representation in an enlarged City Council, the Council's incumbent members have finally adopted new district lines that seem to conform to the legal criteria of compactness, convenience and contiguity. The shame, of course, is that this responsible effort came only after two mayoral vetoes and a firm court directive requiring such action.

title: Anker Finds Nepotism Rule Violated in Canarsie
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker ruled yesterday that the East FlatbushCanarsie school board had acted improperly in the way it gave teaching jobs to the son, daughter and daughterinlaw of the board's president.

title: Adviser Warns U.S. Lags in Science Growth Rate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5The man chiefly responsible for the support of American science and technology said here today there are signs that the country was falling behind other nations in the rate of growth and application of new scientific findings.

title: Some Gain Reported in Ulster. In a Parley on Coalition Rule
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 5Northern Ireland's three main political parties reached some measure of agreement here today on the desirability of setting up a coalition administration to govern the province.

title: CHANGE POSSIBLE IN THE RENT LAW
description: The head of a commission that had been ordered by Governor Rockefeller to examine rent increases throughout the state said yesterday that it might recommend some modification of the state's controversial vacancydecontrol law.

title: South Africa Is Rebuffed By U.N., but Not Expelled
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5The General Assembly voted today to reject the credentials of the South African delegation, but the President of the Assembly ruled that this did not prevent the delegation's members from speaking or otherwise participating in the organization's work.

title: Miss Haynie Gets 2 Eagles, Golf Lead
description: ALAMO, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) Sandra Haynie, the defending champion, scored two eagles on wedge shots of 56 and 50 yards today for a sixunderpar 67 and a twostroke lead in the first round of a $32,000 Ladies Profesisonal Golfers Association tournament.

title: $56MILLION IS PAID FOR NEVADA HOTEL
description: AITS, Inc., a Bostonbased travel company, reported yesterday > the acquisition of the Riviera Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., for $56million.

title: Tony Pino, 67, Participated In '50 Boston Brinks Holdup
description: BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP)Anthony (Tony) Pino, one of the eight men convicted in the $1,219,218 holdup of a Brinks armored car in 1950, died today at his home. He was 67 years old.

title: Italy Takes Security Measures After Reports of Arab Warning
description: ROME, Oct. 5  Security measures at airports, around some foreign embassies and in other sensitive points were tightened today after reports of a warning to Italy from Arab guerrilla organizations.

title: Eight Subpoenas Served In inquiry on Press Leaks
REPLY TO HIS SUIT
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5  The Justice Department argued today that a sitting Vice President can be indicted and tried on criminal charges but said it was willing to give the House of Representatives a chance to impeach Vice President Agnew before trial, should he be indicted by the Federal grand jury investigating him.

title: Japanese Building Swiss Satellite Station
description: GENEVAA giant metal saucer standing on an Alpine slope overlooking the Rhone Valley in Southwestern Switzerland marks a new step in the march into Europe by Japanese industry.

title: Oriole Fans Don't Flock To See Playoff Games
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5The yellow banner fluttering in Hopkins Plaza today read: Baltimore Promotion Council Says Watch the O's Zap the A's.

title: The Shack Closes as Police Reporters' Home
description: In the halycon days of the shack, the late Robert B. Peck, the crack rewrite man for The Herald Tribune, one day took a story from one of the newspaper's reporters, Joey George. The story was about a man who fell off a roof to his death.

title: CEMENT INDUSTRY BENEFITING SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 5 Two years ago, the South Korean cement industry was on the verge of collapse. Today, it is thriving and expanding. The reason for the change: an oldfashioned pricefixing cartel.Chung Young Hi, chairman of the Korea Cement Industrial Association, explained it this way:

title: Greetings
description: STARRYMr. and Mrs. Jacob, 1095 Park Ave., wish all their relatives and friends a very healthy and happy new near and thank there for their kind new year wishes.

title: New Governor General Is Appointed in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 5 (Reuters) A Quebecborn ambassador was appointed Canada's Governor General today.

title: CANADA. AND JAPAN INCREASING TRADE
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum biaCanada and Japan, which are the two major trading part tiers of the United States, have lately become each other's second best customers, and sign?? of the boom in trade are evi?? dent all over this graceful Pacific port.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 5  In baseball, it's always his arm, as if a pitcher has only one. In a sense, he does. His pitching arm is his career. Tom Seaver realizes it. To preserve his right arm, baseball's best pitcher doesn't play tennis. He doesn't lean it out the open window of an automobile where a breeze might stiffen the muscles. He doesn't sleep on it any more because when he did, his arm ached from the weight of his body and from the strain of his profession. Nobody's arm was created to throw a baseball for a living. As strong as it must be, the pitcher's arm is also delicate. Inside his arm recently, Seaver had an inflamed tendon above the biceps. His arm wasn't really sore. But his motion was restricted enough to decrease the velocity of his fastball. Tomorrow, his arm pitches for the New York Mets against the Cincinnati Reds in the opener of their playoff for the National League pennant.

title: FINNS SIGN LINKUP TO COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 5 (UPI)Finland signed a freetrade agreement with the European Economic Community today, providing for the removal of tariffs on all industrial goods by the middle of 1977.

title: U.S., BONN DISCUSS COSTS OF TROOPS
description: BONN, Oct. 5Under Secretary of State William J Casey met today with Wes German officials to discuss reported American request for $3.3billion over the next two years to offset the foreignex change drain from the presence of United States troops here.

title: APlant Site Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI)  The Atomic Energy Commission went on record today against the construction of a nuclear power plant at Newbold Island in the Delaware River in the midst of the heavily populated Philadelphia metropolitan area. The commission favored an alternate site along the Alloways Creek in rural Salem County.

title: MEAT PRICE DROP IS SHARP FOR CITY
description: Dramatic decreases in all prices of meats bought by the city for delivery in the last half of October were reported yesterday by Purchase Commissioner Michael L. Vallon, including a 13 per cent decline in the price of beef since the last buys.

title: Pago Pago Debates Oil Refinery Plan
description: PAGO PAGO, Americar SamoaThis tiny South Pacific island is debating whether to allow construction of a sprawling, $300million oil refinery that would transfom the territory into the largest extraterritorial oil  processing center of the United States.

title: Kissinger Calls on Latins To Join in New Dialogue
description: Secretary of State Kissinger called on Latin  American governments yesterday to join with the United States in new dialogue that would reexamine the structure and assumptions of the hemispheric alliance.

title: Veterans Day Proclaimed
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 5 (UPI)  President Nixon held out renewed hope for a lasting peace in a proclamation today setting Oct. 22 as Veterans Day, Never before, the President said in the proclamation from the Florida White House, has peace been more welcome norprospects for its permanence more substantial.

title: Soap Box Derby Mystery Of '72 May Stay Unsolved
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 5The man who has admitted encouraging his 14yearold nephew to cheat in the 1973 AllAmerican Soap Box Derby may not have to explain the mysterious disappearance of the 1972 winning car that was driven by his son.

title: Guidelines Issued For Report to U.S. Of Propane Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)The Interior Department issued guidelines today for reportilng propane supplies, under the new program of mandatory propane allocation.

title: Burchfield's Art Presents Sense of Place, Season
description: The sense of place and season that haunts the work of the American painter Charles Burchfield is a very special one. Burchfield, who died in 1967 at the age of 73, was not a realist in the usual meaning of the term, although his paintings of summer fields and old houses in brooding winter light are drawn from nature and from the countryside around Gardenville, in upstate New York, where he lived for much of his life.

title: Notes on People
description: Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary and now a figure in the Watergate investigation, needn't worry about keeping his job as a marketing official with United Air Lines, at least for the time being. Mr. Chapin has been accused by one Senate Select Watergate Committee witness, Donald H. Segretti, of hiring him to set up a network to spy on Democratic candidates. But Edward E. Carlson, president of United, said yesterday that the constitutional rights that protect all Americans apply to Mr. Chapin. If criminal charges are placed against him and he is found guilty, said Mr. Carlson, we would then look at Chapin in the same way as another employe.

title: 6 IN TEXAS CASE ASK CHARGES BE DROPPED
description: DALLAS, Oct. 5 (UPI)Attorneys for six men accused of stock fraud asked today that criminal charges be dropped because of alleged political medling by the Nixon Administration. A Federal judge told the defendants to file briefs in support of their plea by Wednesday and gave the Government until Oct. 16 to reply.

title: Off Verdict for 30 Days League Puts On Padres
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 5, (AP) The National League clubowners voted unanimously today to give the San Diego management 30 days to come up with fresh capital to keep the Padres on the West Coast.

title: Miss Haynie Gets 2 Eagles, Golf Lead
description: ALAMO, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) Sandra Haynie, the defending champion, scored two eagles on wedge shots of 56 and 50 yards today for a sixunderpar 67 and a twostroke lead in the first round of a $32,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Top Award Taken by A Lakeland
description: HORSHAM, Pa., Oct. 5A West Coast Lakeland terrier was chosen today for bestinshow honors at the third annual Hatboro Kennel Club fixture at the Deep Meadow Township Park. There were 1,533 dogs entered.

title: Greene, Nicklaus Leaders
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Oct. 5 Biggest improvement read the official scorekeeper's bulletin  Jack Nicklaus  7 strokes.

title: Agnew Case: A Classic Battle on Fair Trials and Freedom of Press
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5One of the classic battles in the history of American jurisprudence is about to be fought on territory that no one could have envisioned a month ago. The territory is the ground Vice President Agnew and his lawyers have chosen for their first stand against the charges of corruption made against him in Maryland.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Meskill Economizing With Smaller Car

title: Debate Over Tuition
description: The Committee for Economic Development has joined the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education and the College Entrance Examination Board in recommending a dramatic increase in the tuition charged by the public colleges and universities. The rationalization offered for such a course is that governmental subsidies ought to go primarily to the poor instead of being spread among all students.

title: CANADA AND CHINA IN BIG WHEAT DEAL
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 5Canada announced today the sale of up to 224 million bushels of wheat to China in a deal that could be worth more than $1billion at current international prices.

title: Austrian Says 2 Proposals On Transit Are Under Study
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 5The Austrian Foreign Minister said today that his Government was seriously studying two proposals for continuing the transit of Soviet Jews through Austria on their way to Israel.

title: Thumbs Down on Kissinger
description: PEKINGIt is a fair guess that when Henry. Kissinger returns to Peking three weeks hence, one thing he will attempt is another try at ending the Cambodian war, Indochina's most festering cancer. If so, he is unlikely to get any help from Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former king, erstwhile political chief of state, and now head of an migr government situated here.

title: One Man's Weirdo
description: It is rush hour on an August afternoon in the IRT Times Square Station. I careen through the closing doors of a graffitiladen car to join the fluorescent pallor of forty fellow robots. Faces hidden behind newspapers, squalling infants, stupors or studied disinterest, the surrounding countenances plead only for anonymity. Please don't bother me, they proclaim, I'm not rally here.

title: CANADA AND CHINA IN BIG WHEAT DEAL
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 5Canada announced today the sale of up to 224 million bushels of wheat to China in a deal that could be worth more than $1billion at current international prices.

title: Speaking for Africa
description: When Yakubu Gowon was abruptly thrust up out of obscurity into power in 1966, his prospects for mere survival seemed even worse than the chances for survival of Nigeria as a nation. Yet, General Gowon somehow held his country together during thirty terrible months of civil war and, against heavy odds, brought off an astonishing measure of reconciliation and reintegration of the Biafran secessionists after the shooting had stopped in 1970.

title: Seven Subpoenas Served In Inquiry on Press Leaks
PROSECUTOR ACTS IN ALBANY INQUIRY
description: ALBANY, Oct. 5The Albany County district attorney, Arnold Proskin, today took over the investigation of alleged corruption in the Albany. Police Department, saying, I assure the people of Albany that all prosecutable crimes will be handled by my office with due diligence.

title: Broker Assays His Style In the Year of the Bear
description: Frederick W. Lowey, a 53yearold stock broker with Andresen & Co., smiled wryly as he contemplated his personal performance during the first nine months of 1973.

title: 2 G.O.P. Leaders Deny Threat to United Way
description: WHIPPANY, Oct. 5  Two county Republican leaders said today that they had opposed having Bill Bradley, the New York Knicks basketball star, appear as featured speaker at today's kickoff luncheon for the ?? drive of the United Way of Morris County.

title: Rangers Defeated By Bruins 8 to 6
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 5 (AP)  Chris Oddliefson, a rookie, and Don Marcotte scored two goals each and No. 1 draft choice, Andre Sayard, had four assists tonight in helping the Boston Bruins to an 86 National Hockey League exhibition victory over the New York Rangers.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Seniors Buy Teachers an Air Conditioner
description: OAKHURST, N.J., Oct. 5The seniors at the Ocean Township high school here voted today to cool off their teachers.

title: E.P.A. Official Deplores Lack of Research to Support U.S CleanAir Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  A leading official of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the United States Government is not meeting its commitment to support cleanair laws with more precise scientific information.

title: Gertrude Arnold, Singer Of Lieder in the Twenties
description: Gertrude Gugler Tietjen, who, as Gertrude Arnold, was a popular lieder singer in the nineteentwenties and thirties, died yesterday at a nursing home in Brooklyn. She was 82 years old and had lived for many years at 850 Seventh Avenue. She was the widow of Charles L. Tietjen.

title: Episcopal Women Chafe at Vote Denying Higher Church Roles
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 5 When a move to let women become priests and bishops in the Episcopal Church was defeated at the last convention in Houston three years ago, proponents were disappointed but not surprised. When the move lost yesterday, many seemed shattered.

title: Sussman Charges Kugler 'Vilified Him
description: TRENTON, Oct. 5His voice choked with emotion, Dr. Oscar Sussman said today that Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. had called him a publicity seeker and had vilified and cursed him because of his criticism of the Law Department's efforts to obtain court orders against unsanitary food establishments.

title: Government's Advocate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The Solicitor General is the Government's top courtroom advocate, the man who goes in somber dress to the United States Supreme Court to argue the Government's biggestcases. Robert Heron Bork was sworn in as Solicitor General last June, but today, his first major public act, he found, himself sitting in his Washington officeand sending a 23page brief, to a Federal district court in Baltimore.

title: Top Award Taken by A Lakeland
description: HORSHAM, Pa., Oct. 5A West Coast Lakeland terrier was chosen today for bestinshow honors at the third annual Hatboro Kennel Club fixture at the Deep Meadow Township Park. There were 1,533 dogs entered.

title: Business Briefs
description: $3Billion Set for Mortgage Market

title: EXXON IS INCREASING PRICES OF FUEL OIL
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would increase prices of all heavy fuel oils imported from Venezuela to reflect higher tax payments to the Venezuelan.Government by the company's supplier.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Are Mixed at Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  Interest rates on Treasury bills rose on shortterm bills, but fell on longterm bills, the Treasury Department said today.

title: About the Giants:
description: Injuries continue to hinder the progress of Brad Van Pelt, the top draft choice who is being tried at weakside linebacker. A toe injury and slow healing from a pulled groin muscle may keep the former Michigan State safetyman out of action for another three to four weeks... Statistics confirm the team's collapse on kickoff returns. Only the Chicago Bears, with a 15.9yard average have a poorer return average. The Giants have averaged 16.6 yards on nine returns, almost 10 yards less than last season. ... There will be another public workout and clinic today at 10 A.M. at Roosevelt Stadium, with special demonstrations by Pete Gogolak, Vin Clements and Rich Glover.... The Oct. 14 game with the Redskins has been sold out, which assures local television for a second consecutive week; the Packers game will be seen on Channel 2 and also in the Hartford area.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Beyond the Higher States of Consciousness
description: Even with its nuclear arsenals and contamination of air, water and earth, it is not science that has become destructive; it is the distortion and vitiation of the human intellect that is responsible for the present unsafe situation of the world.

title: Art: Met Opens Ancient China Show
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, ever in flux, is being shaken these days by explosions having to do with the construction of a new wing to house the Michael C. Rockefeller Collection of Primitive Art. And on the second floor of the main building, to the delight of orientalists, the museum has been getting down to business in the organization, enlargement and exhibition of its Far Eastern collections.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In Pounds sterlinp per metric ton)

title: As Catholic School Strike Drags On, Breach Widens
description: Both sides thought the strike was nearly over. I went to bed just before midnight one day last week believing we had a settlement, said Robert Gordon, vice president of the Lay Faculty Association. I thought we were into the handshaking stage, said Brother Medard Shea, assistant superintendent for teacher personnel employed by the Brooklyn Diocese.

title: NIXON AIDE FEARS 10% FOOD COST RISE IN NEXT 6 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Herbert Stein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today a further sharp upsurge in food prices in the next six months that might average somewhere near 10 per cent.

title: Officer Delivers Own Baby
description: WORCESTER, Muss., Oct 5 (AP)A state trooper delivered his own baby today when a police car taking them to a Worcester hospital failed to get there in time. The car continued on to the Worcester Memorial Hospital where Mrs. Thomas K. Farrell was admitted with their new 6pound, 4ounce daughter.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Morris County. Judge John D. Collins declared a mistrial yesterday in the trial of two men charged with a 1969 slaying in Morris Township.

title: Some Gas Dealers Assert They'll Ignore Price Limit
description: Some gasoline dealers say they are ready to ignore the Government's limits on price increases.

title: Prejudging Judges
description: When Governor Rockefeller announced last spring that he would name scores of new judges to the Court Claims to handle narcotics cases, it was noted in these columns that his method of doing so lacked the proper safeguards. He did name a screening panel of distinguished citizens, including lawyers and laymen, review potential judges. Unfortunately, he reversed the procedure of various model state plans for selection. Instead of permitting a bipartisan screening panel open the lists and scrutinize the candidates in advance, the Governor gave the panel a list of names after he had made the selections.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: U.S.S.R. Hockey Visit in Doubt

title: JOSEPH PECK
description: Joseph Peck, who retired in 1959 after 40 years as a social studies teacher, the last 28 at Evander Childs High School, died Friday in the New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Ariadne Is 2d Triumph in a Row for City Opera
description: If an opera company wanted to know how it felt to go over Niagara Falls in a leaky barrel, what might it do? Well, it could risk staging three premieres in one week, making sure that one of them was Ariadne auf Naxos, Richard Strauss's delectable but elusive operawithinanopera. And yet, its gambler's luck holding, the New York City Opera not only avoided disaster in its Ariadne premiere on Thursday night; for the second evening in a row it had itself a pleasurecrazed audience at curtain's fall, and another undiluted triumph.

title: In Chilean City, the Colonel's Word Is Law
description: TEMUCO, Chile, Oct. 4The cool, crystalclear waters of the Cautin River flow past grazing cows and freshly plowed wheat and hop fields.

title: Books of The Times
description: HARVEST HOME. By Thomas Tryon. 401 pages. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Nigeria Is Steadily Assuming A Role of Leadership in Africa
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 5This West African nation, whose chief of state, Gen. Yakubu Gowon, addressed the United Nations General Assembly today, is moving steadily toward a leadership role on the African continent.

title: High School Notes
description: One device being used in some places to try to capture the interest of young people who have grown bored with formal education is the minischool. A small, informal unit of no more than a few hundred youngsters, it seeks to let students and teachers get to know each other better and to tie studies closely to student interests.

title: Gas Leak Makes 50 III
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 5 (UPI) A lethal arsine gas leak yesterday forced the evacuation of the Burr Brown Research Corporation plant. The police said 50 persons had been treated at a hospital and released.

title: Candidates' Day Marchi Vows to Seek ParochialSchool Aid
description: State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican candidate for Mayor, promised yesterday to seek additional financial aid for parochial and other nonpublic schools if he is elected.

title: Greene, Nicklaus Leaders
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Oct. 5 Biggest improvement read the official scorekeeper's bulletin  Jack Nicklaus strokes.

title: State Officers Discount Report Of Absecon Bay Pollution Peril
description: TRENTON, Oct. 5  State environmental officials today discounted reports that the waters of Absecon Bay and Channel near Atlantic City contain dangerously high levels of mercury.

title: Modern Museum Clarifies an Ad Misunderstanding
description: The Museum of Modern Art has declared it wished to clarify erroneous impressions created by an advertisement for an arts advisory program that has caused misunderstanding in the art world and expressions of concern from the curatorial staff.

title: House Panel to Investigate Work on Presidents' Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) A House panel says it will investigate the use of Federal funds to improve the private property of President Nixon and four former Presidents.

title: Bridge: A Personality Embroiders His Playing for the Press
description: Some experts have been known to embroider on their performances at the table for the benefit of gullible journalists. A case in point occurred at the European Championships in Ostend, Belgium, two weeks ago, when a wellknown personality, Mr. D, reported one of his efforts to three journalists, A, B and C.

title: Nostalgia and Confusion Mark Police Headquarters Move
description: Very early Thursday morning, a squad of police officers quietly entered the spanking new office of Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley and removed a rectilinear rosewood slab that had served as the Commissioner's desk for the, days since he had taken occupancy of his office in the new Police Headquarters building.

title: Substantial Wage Rise in 1974 Will Be Sought by Steel Union
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The United Steelworkers of America served notice today that it would demand substantial wage increases in collective bargaining next year to make up for what it said was the erosion of its members' purchasing power because of skyrocketing prices.

title: Seals Tie Islanders
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press) Marshall Johnson scored midway in the third period to give the California Golden Seals a 33 tie with New York Islanders tonight in a National Hockey League exhibition game. A crowd of 606 saw the Islanders extend their exhibition record to five victories and four ties.

title: Gulf States Co. Purchases Nuclear Reactor From G.E.
description: The Gulf States Utilities Company said yesterday that it exercised an option to purchase a second boilingwater nuclear reactor from the General Electric Company at a cost of about $31million.

title: Sidney Blackmer Dies at 78; Won Tony in 1950 for Sheba
description: Sidney Blackmer, the actor, lied last evening at the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research, 410 East 68th Street. He was 78 years old and lived it 100 Central Park South with lis wife, the former Suzanne Kaaren.

title: Nightclub Guilty of Bias
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 (UPI) Harlow's, a Society Hill nightclub, has been found guilty of racial discrimination by the city's Human Relations Commission. The threemember panel recommended yesterday a $1,200 fine be levied against the center city nightclub.

title: Judge Bars a Delay In Building Schools Because of Tax Base
description: TOMS RIVER, Oct. 5  A Superior Court judge ruled today that the State Supreme Court's decision against the use of local property taxes to finance education did not prevent the construction of new schools.

title: A Federal Jury Finds 19 Guilty In Extortion by Chicago Police
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (UPI)A Federal jury today found 19 present and former Chicago policemen, including one of the department's topranking officers, guilty of extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from the city's opulent Northslde nightclubs and bars.

title: Pesticide Ban Is Appealed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The House Agriculture Committee unanimously asked the Nixon Administration today to reconsider a 1972 ban on using major poisons to combat predatory animals.

title: Good News At Last
description: The newspapers say Senator Howard Baker, a Tennessee lawyer, is going to write a novel. It will be about a Tennessee lawyer who gets elected to the Senate. This is good news, at least for the time being, for if it succeedsand why shouldn't it?we may find ourselves at the most exciting turning point in American politics since the first time a Congressman put on eyeshadow for television.

title: Day of Prayer Proclaimed
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 5 (AP)  President Nixon set aside Oct. 17 as National Day of Prayer.

title: Blue Chips and Glamours Pace Sharp Climb in Stock Prices
description: The stock market registered a sharp gain yesterday with the DowJones industrial average closing at its highest level in almost six months.

description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5An edge. Thats what nearly everyone was looking for today on the eve of the American League championship series between the Oakland As and Baltimore Orioles.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of coinparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Antiques: New Museum
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y.The 7,000 years of ceramics production documented here in one of the nation's newest and most impressive decorative arts museums, place the emphasis where it should be  on pots.

title: Film Festival: 'The Mother and Whore':The Cast
description: Time-traveling can be demoralizing  when you're going in reverse. Watching "The Mother and the Whore," you find that you're back in the movie-sludge of the nineteen-fifties, when a number of mediocre French films focused on sub-Sagan characters: numb, semi-paralyzed creatures who hardly had the calories to drag themselves through the day. Then, boredom was a hip diseaseand it all comes rushing down the spout of memory when Jean-Pierre Laud explains that he lives "in a world where people are old at 17." Jean Eustache's picture, which was shown last night at the New York Film Festival, is so reminiscent of those mossy productions that you start wondering if nothing has been learned about movies, about acting, about men and women. The discoveries of the last decade have been erased. Or else the sixties never happened: you were just hallucinating.It's been claimed that the movie explores all the possible relationships between men and women  which seems like an invitation for a sackrace to the nearest crematorium. Laud has two girlfriends: Bernadette Lafont and Franoise Lebrun. He talks. They listen. The usher says you can't smoke. It takes three and a half hours to state that women are unpredictable and that men are easily depressed. There's a bale of boastful talk about sex but not much of it. Finally, Miss Lebrun has hysterics, Laud asks her to marry him, she says yes and throws up, Now you can smoke.But this movie won the Grand Prix and also the International Critics Prize at Cannes. Before we all take sanity tests, let's examine the fantasies afoot. The director has said that we won't be able to distinguish between the mother and the whore. He's wrong about that. While both women are made to be incredibly passive, Bernadette Lafont is permitted a bit of gumption when she's jealousan emotion that turns Laud on. (He gets very jealous himself.) When a woman is jealous, it must mean that she's possessive, therefore a mother: by definition a figure to be needled and punctually defied and, finally, left. A mother is someone to escapewhen she's not changing spiritual diapers. "The whore" is simply a woman who has had a lot of sex. At first, she says she likes it, later she calls it sordid; ultimately, she has to repent.Perhaps there's meant to be a whiff of grim maternity in her character: because she's a nurse who gives anesthetics. By implication, a nurse is supposed to cure everything, to heal all wounds. Franoise Lebrun is acutely severe, precisethus evoking Laud's childhood attraction to hospital nurses. He thought them alluring because they seemed cold and hard, impervious to pain. She asks if he's ever seen a pair of lungs, adding that they're pretty because they're pink.Toward the end, Miss Lebrun has one long drizzling aria of remorseabout the futility of sex without love. It's her only opportunity to act; otherwise, both women are allowed to alternate rapt but blank stares with faint, indulgent smiles, while Laud lectures about nothing. (Miss Lafont gets a chance to throw up too, but very quickly. Laud's monologues are spiced with maxims intended to knock us sideways. Such as: "In the long run, the phonier you are, the further you go." (Holden, you should be with us at this movie.) Or: "My only dignity is cowardice." And: "Women always belong to their rescuers"  such as their abortionists.It's worth worrying about Laud these days  as to whether he can do his best for directors other than Truffaut. Godard and Bertolucci have already brought out the aridity that also withers his persona in "The Mother and the Whore," and it's rather sad to see this dour, fatigued appearance so soon after hugely enjoying his skill in Truffaut's "Day for Night." But all we learn from his performance in this movie is that his right nipple twitches violently when he's dialing a phone.All in all, it's tempting to mail the director a list of complaints as long as his movie. What possessed him to use slow dissolves when we yearn for quick cuts? Or to give us a tour of the inside of a refrigerator or lessons in putting records on turntables or how to make a call? And occasionally, when Eustache builds toward a scene that might be almost interestingin which these weary people might have to cope with one another  he leaves it out. The program notes report that he "now hates most films." So this picture may be his vengeance on the apes who like them. But perhaps he was paying homage to Gore Vidal's Myra Breckinridge, who had "a radical theory" that "boredom in the arts can be, under the right circumstances, dull."

title: The Screen
description: In his Pittsburgh Trilogy, which opened yesterday at the Film Forum (not to be confused with the current Film Festival), Stan Brakhage sends the lens of his camera rooting across the landscape of his subject matter like a pig's snout in search of truffles of truth and meaning.

title: REPLY TO HIS SUIT
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5  The Justice Department argued today that a sitting Vice President can be indicted and tried on criminal charges but said it was willing to give the House of Representatives a chance to impeach Vice President Agnew before trial, should he be indicted by the Federal grand jury investigating him.

title: 3 Narcotics Judges Failed City Ratings
description: Three of Governor Rockefeller's appointees to the new narcotics courts had been turned down earlier as city judges by the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary because of negative ratings by committees in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, according to legal and governmental sources.

title: Colombo Sues to Stay Showing Of a Movie About Gallo Feud
description: A lawsuit seeking to prevent the Showing of Crazy Joe, a forthcoming film that tells the thinly disguised story of the life of the late Mafia figure Joseph Gallo, has been filed in State Supreme Court by Gallo's reputed archenemy, Joseph A. Colombo Sr.

title: Sanitation Policeman Honored in Death
description: The rows of somber policemen standing at attention, the uniformed honor guard, the formal ceremony of an inspector's funeralthe elements of the scene were sadly familiar, but it was not a city policeman who was being, honored in death yesterday.

title: JOHN OLYPHANT JR., HANOVER BANK AIDE
description: John K. Olyphant Jr., former vice chairman of the Hanover, Bank, died yesterday at his home in Dongan Hills, S. I. He was 78 years old.

title: All Securities Markets To Be Open on Monday
description: All securities marketsincluding the New York, American, PBW, Midwest and National Stock Exchangeswill be open on Monday, Columbus Day.

title: Prices of Stocks Surge
description: With advances outpacing declines by a twoforone ratio, the stock market climbed sharply yesterday. The DowJones industrial average soared 15:35 points to 971.25, the highest level since March 14, when it was 978.85. Prices of 1,010 issues rose, compared with 510, showing losses. Page 33.

title: 3 Narcotics Judges Failed City Ratings
description: Three of Governor Rockefeller's appointees to the new narcotics courts had been turned down earlier as city judges by the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary because of negative ratings by committees in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, according to legal and governmental sources.

title: White Houie Hints Veto of Bill Limiting Power to Wage War
description: MIAMI, Oct. 5The White House indicated today that President Nixon would veto a compromise bill limiting the power of the President to wage undeclared war without Congressional approval.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MOBILES Tourist perambulations are something of a Sunday tradition locally and there are two that seem promising tomorrow because they are downtown, where the traffic is not  or at least not, too muchon Sunday.

title: Kreisky Defends Move as an Austrian
description: VIENNA, Oct. 5  Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, reacting strongly to Israeli criticism of Austria's decision to close the transit camp for emigrating Soviet Jews, said today that although some people think I am a traitor he could, as an Austrian and a Socialist, see no other policy for Austria but equidistance between the Arab states and Israel.

title: Spanish Ballots Sought For Statewide Election
description: NEWARK, Oct. 5 (AP)The United States District Court here was asked today to order New Jersey election officials to provide Spanish translations on ballots in the upcoming statewide election.

title: People and Business
description: Cyrus S. Eaton, the controversial financier, announced yesterday that he was retiring as chairman of the Chessie System, Inc. Healthy and vigorous at 89, Mr. Eaton surprised railroad industry observers by stepping down as titular head of one of the nation's richest rail operations, a post he obviously relished.

title: Superdome Costs Go Higher
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 5 (UPI)The estimated cost of completing the controversial $150 million New Orleans domed stadium continues to increase.

title: Tanaka Says He Is Seeking Closer Ties With Europe
description: BONN, West Germany, Oct. 5 (AP)Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan said today that he seeks closer ties with Western Europe to complete the triangular linking of major nonCommunist nations proposed by the United States.

title: Secretariat's Turf Drill Startles the Clockers
description: There was Lucien Laurin, trainer of Meadow's Secretariat, waving an arm at this year's Triple Crown winner, hoping to get Ron Turcotte to slow down the colt during yesterday morning's workout at Belmont Park. And there was this great 3yearold colt charging over the grass course as if responding to a third alarm.

title: Metropolitan Life Using Projector for Sky Image
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The Metropolitan Life Insurance. Company is using the night clouds to gain public attention. From a building it owns in Tampa, Fla., it sends up what it calls Patents a Fountain of of the Light. For its Week sky projector the company received Patent 3,762,083 this week. The inventors are Charles Neenan of New York and Thomas. M. Lemons of Marblehead; Mass., lighting engineers.

title: Drug Abuse in Suburbs Called Eased, Despite Seizure of 91 in Latest Raids
description: VERONA, Oct. 5Thomas J. Rock, this suburban borough's police chief, dug into a rumpled paper bag that had just been brought into his office and drew out two blackened corncob pipes, plastic containers of what appeared to be marijuana, a spoon, a hypodermic needle, a jar of an unidentified, syrupy brown liquid, and some weedlike plants.

title: MEAT PRICE DROP IS SHARP FOR CITY
description: Dramatic decreases in all prices of meats bought by the city for delivery in the last half of October were reported yesterday by Purchase Commissioner Michael L. Vallon, including a 13 per cent decline in the price of beef since the last buys.

title: Arnie Almahurst Wins Trot Classic
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP)Arnie Almahurst, the firstheat winner, broke stride badly in the second heat but came back strong in the third heat today to capture the $64,174 Kentucky Futurity, third jewel in trotting's triple crown.

title: CHINA SAFE NEWS SPURS WHEAT RISE
description: Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade in wheat for December delivery lifted prices to $4.78 a bushel yesterdayup 6 cents.

title: WINE TALK
description: There may have been a time when what the country needed was a good 5cent cigar. Today there are a great many people who feel the same way about an inexpensive bottle of wine. Now comes a book that insists that all we need do is look around us. There are, it maintains, more good, inexpensive wines than most of us could drink in a month of Sundays.

title: U.S. DENIES HALTING PULLOUT OF TROOPS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) The Administration is reviewing its plans for withdrawing United States troops from overseas in light of continuing North Vietnamese military buildups and other factors, Defense Department officials said today. But they denied that some reductions had been canceled.

title: YOUTH SHOT CHASING GUNMEN GETS TICKET
description: A youth who tried to halt four gunmen fleeing a holdup at Staten Island Community College today ended up shot in the arm, with his car damaged and with a summons on it for illegal parking from a zealous Sanitation Department patrolman.

title: Freezer Demand Exceeds Supply
description: Americans have gone on the greatest homefreezer buying splurge in history. The boom is apparently caused by a credibility gap: Buyers say they want the freezers in order to stock up on food, which suggests that many people are not convinced by Government assurances that price increases will slow and shortages will end.

title: NATE COTT, 60, LED FLY WITHOUT FEAR
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 5Nate Cott, founder of Fly Without Fear, an organization born out of his own fears and frustrations, died here Thursday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived here at 360 Central Ave.

title: Kissinger Calls on Latins To Join in New Dialogue
description: Secretary of State Kissinger called on Latin  American governments yesterday to join with the United States in a new dialogue that would reexamine the structure and assumptions of the hemispheric alliance.

title: 2 Youths Seized in Killing of Boston Man
description: BOSTON, Oct. 5Two teenagers were charged today with murder, and the Boston police were attempting to round up 50 other black youths believed to have stoned and stabbed to death a 65yearold white man yesterday.

title: 3 TeenAgers Held in Slaying Of Toy Merchant on 125th St.
description: Three teenage boys were arrested last night in a Harlem housing project and charged with the robbery and murder Thursday of a 52yearold toy merchant in his store on 125th Street.

title: Florida Official Fails to Find Proof of Tap
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The authorities in Miami are investigating the bizarre possibility that less than a month after the illfated Watergate wiretapping plot was uncovered, a second team of Republican agents was sent to tap telephones and bug hotel rooms there during the Democratic National Convention in July of last year.

description: With advances outpacing declines by a twoforone ratio, the stock market climbed sharply yesterday. The DowJones industrial average soared 15.35 points to 971.25, the highest level since March 14, when it was 978.85. Prices of 1,010 issues rose, compared with 510, showing losses. Page 33.

description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 5 (AP) The Japanese Davis Cup player, Toshiro Sakai, advanced today to the semifinali of the $25,000 Osaka tennis tournament by beating Sherwood Stewart of Houston, 61, 64.

title: PARENTS TO SUE HARRISON BOARD
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 5  A group of parents in Harrison, where a teachers' strike is in its 21st day, prepared a citizens class action lawsuit today against the Board of Education to ensure proper utilization of more than $500,000 in unspent salaries.

title: Borek Gets 284, Wins Met. Golf By Three Shots
Mrs. Meir Urges Drive To Save Austrian Camp
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 5 (AP) Premier Golda Meir called today for an international effort to save the Schbnau transit] camp for Jews emi grating from the Soviet Union. She praised President Nixon for opposing Austria's decision to shut the camp.

title: PHNOM PENH BLAST KILLS 9, INJURES 21
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 5 (UPI)A hand grenade rigged as a booby trap exploded in the midst of a crowd buying lottery tickets at a market place near Phnom Penh's airport today, killing at least 9 people and wounding 21, most of them women.

Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second end third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Conditional A.E.C. Approval Is Given Connecticut Plant

description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 5 Douglas Mairitt Whitaker, zoologist who was a former vice president of Rockefeller University and former chairman of the National Research Council, died today at his home here. His age was 69.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) A Democratic party committee: recessed tonight in anger after failing to reach a comptomise modification of the rule that resulted in virtual qngtas for women, minority and youth delegates at the 1972 Dbitocratic convention.

description: Sames J. McFadden, state mediator, has scheduled a joint meeting of striking musicians and the New York Philharmonic fore next Tuesday at 10 A.M. Both parties have agreed to the session, the first since last Tuesday, and will resume negotiations, according to Mr. McFadden, possibly at an uptown hotel.

title: Chile's Churches Planning Help for Detained Leftists
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 5Roman Catholic and Protestant churches here have set up a human rights commission in an attempt to curb the executions and arrests that have seen reported in increasing numbers since the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens three weeks ago.

title: PRICES ON AMEX RESUME ADVANCE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday resumed the rise that was broken on Thursday.
