title: Field Goal Wins Game For Hofstra
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 5 Tim Hogan's 29yard field goal with 62 seconds left was the difference tonight as Hofstra University defeated Northeastern, 1714, for its fourth straight victory. Northeastern has yet to win in four games. Hofstra's wonlost record is 41.

title: Automation Wins Horse Show Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5Rod Jenkins took a firm hold on the Philadelphia horse show today by riding the Winners of two championships. And they weren't even jumpers, his longtime specialty.

title: Unzippered Pocketbook
description: The Administration, always at its most redoubtable in fighting inflation with reassuring press statements, finds in last month's drop in wholesale prices a signal that the worst of the inflationary surge is over. But the fine print of that forecastas supplied yesterday by President Nixon's chief economic adviser, Herbert Stein makes it plain that even the optimists in the White House expect the buying power of the consumer's dollar to keep right on shrinking.

title: South Africa Is Rebuffed By U.N., but Not Expelled
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5The General Assembly voted today to reject the credentials of the South African delegation, but the President of the Assembly ruled that this did not prevent the delegation's members from speaking or otherwise participating in the organization's work.

title: 4 ACCUSED P.O.W.'S CLEARED A 2D TIME
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Army and Navy have tossed out the last of the remaining misconduct charge against former prisoners of war in Vietnam, the Pentagon said today.

title: MILITARY CLOTHING IS BEING REVIEWED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (Reuters)The Department of Defense is reviewing its clothing specifications because of the difficulties manufacturers are having in filling its orders.

title: $6Billion Transit Project Linked to Bond Approval
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it would undertake a $6billion program of mass transit construction if voters approved the proposed state transportation bond issue.

title: Duke of SabranPonteves, Descendant of Louis IX, 64
description: AVIGNON, France, Oct. 5 (UPI)The Duke of SabranPonteves, who traced his ancestry to King Louis IX, ruler of France from 1226 to 1270, died today of a pulmonary ailment at his chateau at Ansouis. He was 64 years old.

title: Olympic Events Reduced; Swimming Loses 3 Races
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. 5 (AP)  The International Olympic Committee ignored the pleas of sports federations today and took the first firm step toward cutting the size of the Olympic Games.

title: Olympic Events Reduced; Swimming Loses 3 Races
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. (AP)  The International Olympic Committee ignored the pleas of sports federations today and took the first firm step toward cutting the size of the Olympic Games.

title: Soviet Police Assault 2 U.S. Newsmen
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 5  Two American newsmen were assaulted today by plainclothes officers as they photographed a brief protest demonstration by five Soviet Jews outside the interior Ministry.

title: High Argentine Police Official Is Latest Assassination Victim
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 (AP) A highranking police officer was shot to death last night in the fourth political murder since Juan D. Peron was elected President less than two weeks ago.

title: U. S.E. E. C. Discord Narrows On Limited Commodity Supply
description: PARIS, Oct. 5A fundamental disagreement between Europe and the United States over the international regulation of food and rawmaterials supplies appears to be narrowing. Officials of the European Economic Community welcome the development.

title: NIXON AIDE FEARS 10% FOOD COST RISE IN NEXT 6 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Herbert Stein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today a further sharp upsurge in food prices in the next six months that might average somewhere near 10 per cent.

title: Nixon Tapes Rationale Offered by Eisenhower
description: GREENSBURG, Pa., Oct. 5 (UPI)David Eisenhower said tonight that if national survival depended on President Nixon releasing the disputed White House tapes he would release them to the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Scores Obtainable By Dialing 9991313
description: Sportsphone will provide scores of the baseball playoffs on telephone number 9991313. They will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: London Being Scouted for Ways to Help New York
description: LONDON, Oct. 5All this week, London's local officials have been undergoing lively questioning by a group of New Yorkers intent on learning some lessons for improving the way New York City works and responds to citizen needs.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CLIFTON, Oct. 5Two years ago on Christmas Eve, Woody Hayes, football coach at Ohio State, toured the athletic complex at Clifton High and said it was one of the finest he had ever seen. Looks more like a college setup, he said.

title: OLIVER M. MARCY
description: FRANKLIN, N.H., Oct. 5. Oliver M. Marcy, who retired as a Foreign Service officer in 1965, died today of bronchial pneumonia, complicating cancer, in Franklin Regional Hospital. He was 54 years old and had lived here since his retirement.

title: Canada Shows Trade Deficit
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 5 (Reuters)Canada's seasonally adjusted trade balance shrank to a deficit of $13million in August from a surplus of $171million in July, Statistics Canada said today.

title: Peterson Nears Record In Watkins Glen Trial
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 5 (AP)Ronnie Peterson of Sweden came back after an earlymorning accident today and posted the fastest firstday time as qualifying began for the United States Grand Prix.

title: White House to Let Judge See Internal Taxes Memorandums
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 5The White House has agreed to let a Federal judge examine some internal Administration documents that may have bearing on a lawsuit in which it is charged that improper political influence was brought by the Nixon Administration on the Internal Revenue Service.

title: $6Billion Transit Project Linked to Bond Approval
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it would, undertake a $6billion program of mass transit construction if voters approved the proposed state transportation bond issue.

title: Palestine Group Denies It Threatened Russians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 5 A Palestinian guerrilla group repudiated today as a fabrication a statement attributed to it threatening reprisals against Soviet Union for allowing Russian Jews to emigrate to Israet.

title: Excerpts
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 5Following are excerpts from a Justice Department  memorandum filed by Solicitor General Robert H. Bork in response to Vice. President Agnew's move to block a grand jury investigation of the Vice President:

title: It's the Numbers Game Today
description: College football teams fighting for the unofficial No. 1 ranking tend to roll up huge scores wherever possible as a means of getting more votes in the weekly polls. This presents a frightening picture for four of the lowly teams that will be led out to face four of the five topranked squads.

title: After Its Stage Career, Furniture Is Put Out to Pasture
description: WARREN, Conn.  Where does stageset furniture go when the final curtain comes down on a play? Some of it may wind up in the producer's home. Especially if the producer is Morton Gottlieb, who recently shifted his weekend living scene from a rented, oneroom cottage to four interlocking barns  the oldest said to have been built in 1769, the newest in 1940  that were part of a working dairy farm until 10 years ago.

title: A DRUGCASE FIGURE FOUND GUILTY HERE
description: A manager of the nowdefunct Electric Circus discotheque in the East Village was convicted of conspiring to smuggle five pounds of cocaine past customs officers at Kennedy International Airport last June 13.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: Two Exhibitions Marking Janis Gallery's 25 Years
description: The Sidney Janis Gallery, 6 West 57th Street, is observing its 25th anniversary. To mark that happy event, the gallery is mounting two sizable exhibitions that, taken together, will constitute a retrospective survey of its activities during the quartercentury of its existence.

title: City Says It Must Continue To Pay Medicaid Factors
description: After a oneday halt in send; ing. Medicaid payments to commercial factoring companies tbat paid cash to healthcare professionals at discounts in advance of city payments, the city's Department of Social Services said late yesterday it would have to resume the practice as a result of a new state order.

title: Cairo Communiques
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6  The Egyptian Government announced today that Israeli ground, sea and air forces attacked Egypt and Syria early this afternoon along the entire length of their front lines with Israel.

title: In spite of women's sexual fantasies, men are still indispensable
description: Not another book about Sex and Women? wails the anguished reader.

title: Blacks Criticize Nixon for Not Meeting Nigerian
description: A number of prominent black officials have criticized President Nixon for not meeting with Gem Yakubu Gowon, head of the military Government of Nigeria, during his fiveday visit to this country.

title: Consumer Coalition Formed for Island
description: Long Island has a lot of consumers, but unlike its big city neighbor, Nassau and Suffolk Counties do not have a focal point for action. However, the organizers of a new bicounty coalition hope to change this situation.

title: Sex on Gunsmoke? Right, Pardner
description: THIS will not be a column about the Saturday night comedy bloc on CBS. You have already read too many such columns, and they all say the same thing, and they are all correct: With All in the Family, M*A*S*H, Mary Tyler Moore, Bob Newhart and Carol Burnett on every Saturday night for three hours, there is no excuse for leaving the house, especially since the movie at your local neighborhood cave is likely to drool over a couple of catatonics trying to think up new uses for old sex organs. (I seem to be alone in the world in finding All in the Family resistible. M*A*S*H, however, is even better this year than last. And Carol Burnett's parody of Kung Fu was not only hilarious; it was also a public service. No one who saw it will ever again be able to take seriously a TV series starring ambulatory fortune cookies. But this is not a column about any of that.)

title: Criminals At Large
description: We have all read about the mouse that turned into a tiger, and it's surefire stuff: in most of our mouselike souls, a tiger is waiting to be released. At least, we like to think so. If you go in for this kind of escapism, don't miss FAIR GAME by George Bertram (Macmillan, $6.95). It's wild, it's unbelievable, some of it is actually incoherentbut as you read it you will be rooted like an old eucalyptus.

title: Poor Bruch And the Rich Sisters
description: IN 1894, two sisters from Baltimore, Rose and Ottilie Sutro, made a spectacular debut in London as a twopiano team, and they were to be heard in European and American concert halls for another two decades after that. Baltimore always remained their home; Rose died there in 1957 at the age of 86, Ottilie in 1970 at the age of 97. The announcement that Ottilie's effects would be sold at an auction intrigued a pianist named Nathan Twining. He attended the sale and came away with a carton of miscellaneous items for which he had paid $11. On going through the box, he found an old bluebound score bearing the title Concerto for Two Pianos. On the last page was the signature of Max Bruch.

title: City Council Unit Sets Park Talks Wednesday
description: The following meeting of a City committee at City Hall is open to the public this week.

title: Dayan's Talk
description: To Nation

title: Maggie Blackmon Is Married Here
description: In St. Luke's Chapel, Trinity Episcopal Parish here yesterday afternoon, Miss Rosemary (Maggie) Blackmon, assistant curator of the theater collection at the Museum of the City of New York, became the bride of Herbert Frank Grove 2d, a member of the drama department faculty at the University of Rhode Island.

title: The World
description: As Cairo basked in the afternoon sun and Israel observed the holy day of Yom Kippur, the heaviest fighting since the 1967 war broke out yesterday along the Suez Canal and the IsraelSyria front. Israel charged she had come under concerted Egyptian and Syrian air and artillery attack and had gone into action to repel the aggressors. Cairo Radio said the fighting had been triggered by overt aggression on the part of Israeli forces that tried to cross the Suez Canal. Whether it was another serious incident another war was still unclear.

title: The whole of Africa could hardly contain him
description: Christian missionaries today are out of style as heroes, David Livingstone, once glorified by English biographers as one of the moral giants of our race, is remembered now mostly for his illfated search for the sources of the Nile. Of the several men obsessed by the coy fountainsJames Bruce, Richard Burton, John Spoke and Henry Stanleyonly Livingstone died while looking for them. Once the most famous of all these, he has now been eclipsed by the urbane explorersexologist, Burton, whom Livingstone detested as a moral idiot ... systematically wicked, impure and untruthful. If any biography can revive enthusiasm for the missionary forever associated with Henry Stanley's slightly ludicrous salutation, Dr. Livingstone, I presume, it will be Tim Jeal's Livingstone.

title: A world where most women live
description: By Erma Bombeck. Illustrated by Loretta Krupinski. 161 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $4.95.

title: Mrs. Wacht Bride Of Harry Traulsen
description: Mrs. Regine Barchi Wacht, one of the first dress designers to popularize here the caftan worn in her native Morocco, was married last evening to Harry Traulsen of New York and Deering, N.H. board chairman and chief executive officer of Traulsen & Co. of College Point, Queens, manufacturers of refrigerators and freezers for large commercial users.

title: Grants Announced By History Group
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Historical Commission has announced its 1974 GrantInAid Program for Research in New Jersey history. The program was begun in 1970 to support research projects dealing with the state's history and to stimulate original research and writing in the field among academic and amateur historians.

title: All Faiths Welcome At House of Prayer
description: MILLBROOK VILLAGE Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews will jointly dedicate here today at 2:30 P.M. a new house of prayer where the faithful of all religious persuasions may worship.

title: A Bus Plan for State Employes
description: TRENTONThe pressure on New Jersey to come up with a plan for reducing air pollution from motor vehicles has prompted officials to dust off a 10Yearold proposal to bring state employes to work on shuttle buses from outlying parking lots.

title: Housing Is Saved In Plan For School
description: The community school board of District 14 in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, in cooperation with a local councilman and the Office of School Planning and Research of the Central Board of Education, has adopted a plan that would obviate the need to evict people from their homes to make way for new school buildings in the area.

title: Lisa Nitto Betrothed
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Oct. 6Presiding Judge Harold M. Nitto of the Passaic County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court and Mrs. Nitto have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lisa Michele Nitto, to Robert T. Graham, son of Mrs. John Horgan and the late James Francis Graham.

title: Health Care Coverage Cost Seen Continually Climbing
description: Spiraling government and private expenditures for health care coverage, treatment and materials was at the $80billion level in 1972, reports Arth D. Little, Inc., a research firm, which says that the figure is likely to double by the end of the decade.

title: British Laborites Talking a Leftist Line
description: LONDON Judged by its yearly conferences at Blackpool's Winter Garden, a combination opera house, ballroom and Persian bazaarthe British Labor party would rather be Left than in office.

title: Woman Cyclist Is Gathering History on Slides
description: NUTLEY  Mrs. Henry Baldwin Scarborough careens about New Jersey every weekend on her motorcycle, the Wheeling Dervish, ferreting out historical nuggets and preserving them on film.

title: Theater in Washington, D.C. A Revolution That Fizzles
description: PAULINE KAEL was remarking recently on the Vietnamization of American movies. Today, says Miss Kael, movies have been saying that the system is corrupt, that the whole thing stinks, and they've been saying this steadily since the midsixties. But the American theater has been saying this for a much longer time: for the last 50 years, in fact. You can hear it almost as clearly in The Hairy Ape and The Adding Machine as in Sticks and Bones and That Championship Season.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONCongress, like a lot of people, is beginning to feel a financial pinch. Having set out in January to limit Federal spending in the current fiscal year to $268billion, a budget level acceptable to the Nixon Administration, the Democratically controlled Congress faces the prospect that it may not be able to squeeze every government program it wants under that ceiling.

title: Missouri Throttles S.M.U., 177
description: DALLAS, Oct. 6 (AP) Missouri's John Moseley broke six tackles on a 74yard punt return for a touchdown in the fourth quarter today as the 15thranked Tigers scored a 177 victory over 19thranked Southern Methodist.

title: Britons Now Eat Less Meat Than When It Was Rationed
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)With soaring prices, Britons are now eating less meat than they used to when it was rationed 20 years ago, according to figures published by the Ministry of Agriculture.

title: SCHOOL HEARINGS ARE ON THIS WEEK
description: The decentralization of New York City schools, which was instituted in 1970 to give the public a greater voice in de termining local school policies, will come under scrutiny at two separate hearings to be held here this week. Both are aimed at seeking ways to improve the current decentralization law.

title: John V. Bowmer Marries Janet Ostrom
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Oct. 6Miss Janet Ostrom, daughter of Mrs. Kelso Mitchell Ostrom of New York and Vincent F. Ostrom of Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to John Vance Bowmer, son of Mrs. Cecil L. Bowmer of New York, and the late Mr. Bowmer who was a sales representative with Westinghouse Electric Company. The bride's father is chairman of the board of the Putnam Trust Company of Greenwich.

title: Kennedy Against Chile Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct., 6 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has protested a $24million credit sale of wheat to Chile on the ground that human rights arc not being protected in that country.

title: T.W.U. CHIEF SETS NEW UNION GOAL
description: Matthew Guinan, president of the Transport Workers Union, said yesterday that the union would attempt to set new precedents and break new ground in upcoming negotiations in the transportation industry.

title: Annapolis Is Natural Setting for Boat Show
description: Don't miss the forest for the trees. Afte'r you've examined the boats docked at the outdoor United States Sailboat Show this weekend and at the United States Powerboat Show next weekend, take some time to wander through the historic port city of Annapolis where the shows are located. Anqapolis was a natural choice for the site of the original inthewater boat show four years ago, and its Colonial architecture has served as a picturesque background for the shows since then. Annapolis has been a center of shipping activity from the time it was settled by Puritan exiles from Virginia in 1649. The city is also the home of the United States Naval Academy whose grounds occupy 309 acres on the south bank of the Severn River. The campus of St. John's College, chartered in 1784, is adjacent to the Naval Academy. Annapolis is the headquarters of the Severn River naval command and is a port of entry of the. Maryland customs district.

title: Was Op Art Just a Flop Art?
description: THE art of Julio Le Parc, the 45yearold Argentineborn artist, now a resident of Paris, is one of those fervid attempts to achieve a programmatic and scientific form of art, a system of art that is removed from the accidents of an artist's personal tastes and expressive inclinations. Le Parc arrived in the French capital in 1958 when the reigning style was art informel, a kind of European parallel to American Abstract Expressionism. But following in the footsteps of Victor Vasarely, who had developed a counterstyle of taut geometric structuring and chromatic brilliance, Le Parc opted for the less fashionable mode of art.

title: Crown HeightsFlatbush to Elect School Board Nov. 27
description: Voters in Community School District 17 in the Crown HeightsFlatbush section of Brooklyn are scheduled to go to the polls Nov. 27 to elect  for the second time this yeara new ninemember local board to oversee the district's 13 elementary schools and 4 middle schools.

title: Catholics Give $3.4Million To Antipoverty Projects
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6  The Campaign for Human Development of the United States Catholic Conference has awarded $3.4million to 117 community organizations of poor people in 37 states, the District of Columbia and three United States possessions.

title: Shultz and Dent in Yugoslavia to Discuss Trade and Aid
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6Hard on the heels of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, who ended a tradeandaid visit Monday, the United States Secretary of the Treasury, George P. Shultz, and the Secretary of Commerce, Frederick B. Dent, conducted intensive talks here this weekend toward an expansion of economic relations.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market turned in a strong performance last week in very active trading.

title: Five Independent Candidates Are in Race for Mayoralty
description: If you go by petitions filed with the Board of Elections 103,108 registered voters intend to support one of five independent candidates for Mayor rather than one of the four officialparty nominees.

title: Gas Pipeline Contest Develops in Alaska
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, Sept. 29  Another Alaskan pipeline dispute is brewing.

title: BOCES Growing With L.I.
description: Twentyfive years ago, when a Board of Cooperative Educational Services was formed for the Towns of Brookhaven and Islip, there were 8,600 children in the towns' school districts. In its first year, working on a budget of $40,000 provided by the state and local boards of education, BOCES sent out a dozen itinerant teachers to bring music, gymnastics and art to rural students, ran five special education classes for 50 physically or emotionally handicapped children, and provided a psychologist for schools that needed one.

title: So. California Subdues Oregon State Team, 217
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 6 (AP)Anthony Davis scored twice on short runs following Oregon State mistakes as Southern California handed the Beavers a 21to7 Pacific8 Conference football loss today.

title: Love and Logic in China
description: PEKING  The developing relationship between the People's Republic of China and the United States is compounded of logic and love with considerably more of the former on the Chinese side and more of the latter on the American side. With this, in mind, one might conveniently recall the sonnet of Edna St. Vincent Millay which begins: No further from me than my hand is China that I love so well. Love does not help to understand the logic of the bursting shell.

title: Egyptians Crossed the Suez Easily
description: The apparent ease with which Egyptian forces crossed the Suez Canal was explained yesterday by American military sources in terms of Israeli tactics.

title: The Edens came to lunch. Jerk confessed . . .
description: LONDON. At the time of writing, it seems likely that a whole tradition of British politics will finally come to an end in the aftermath of the LambtonJellicoe scandals. Lord Lambton, a handsome, debonair aristocrat with two stately homes, about 40,000 acres in the north of England and an inherited fortune of some $25million, occupied the Government post of Under Secretary of State for the Royal Air Force almost by inherited right. He was one of a small number of token aristocrats included in the present Conservative administration as a symbol of continuity and social respectability. He carried the duties and privileges of Government office as lightly and as casually as the various other duties which may fall upon great landowners in Englandthe president of his local football club, perhaps, or the chancellorship of his local university. Certainly, he would never allow these things6e interfere with his serious pleasures, and Lord Lambton belonged to a tradition of pleasureloving aristocrats which is as old as human history. It is not, however, a tradition which survives easily in the present decade, with its constant exposure of men in public life. When Lord Lambton allowed himself to be photographed in bed smoking pot with two prostitutes, one of them colored, and Lord Jellicoe, a senior Cabinet officer, confessed in the same week to having relations with prostitites, the storm broke.

title: RHODE ISLANDERS TO VOTE ON 7 PLANS
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6 Rhode Islanders will vote in a special election Nov. 6 on whether they want to legalize state lotteries, raise the pay of state legislators and increase the terms of the state's general officers from two to four years.

title: Oklahoma Rallies to Beat Miami of Florida, 2420
description: NORMAN, Okla., Oct 6 (AP)Steve Davis, a sophomore quarterback raced for two touchdowns and passed for another today as sixthranked Oklahoma spoiled Miami of Florida's bid to become the nation's No. 1 giant killer with a 2420 victory.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Beats Boston U. On Pass, 3 Kicks, 160
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6 (AP)Harvard struck for a quick touchdown in capitalizing on a fakepunt gamble by Boston University, then added three field, goals by Bruce Tetirick for a 160 football victory over the Terriers today.

title: Columbia Rallies to Top Princeton, 1413
description: With the help of three guys named Mike and one named Rudy, Columbia defeated Princeton, 1413, before a crowd of 12,166 in Baker Field yesterday, the Ivy League opener for both teams.

title: Nebraska Conquers Gophers
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 6 (AP)David Humm burned Minnesota with three touchdown passes to Frosty Anderson today as the secondranked Nebraska Cornhuskers smothered the Gophers, 487, in college football.

title: Legislative Candidates Fighting Apathy
description: TRENTONCandidates in 120 legislative races are finding themselves faced with voter apathy and the more glamorous governorship campaign as they vie in contests that will decide the makeup of the Senate and Assembly for the next two years.

title: The Mills Of God
description: By William H. Armstrong. Illustrated by David Armstrong. 115 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $3.95. (Ages 11 to 15)

title: Looked into the present, wearing out shoe leather
description: This is a book so good one postpones reviewing it in order not to lay it down. A hundred photographs from the collection of the Museum of Modern Art have been anthologized by John Szarkowski, their curator. He hadn't space for more because of the commentary that he appended to each, and it's a good thing, too, because his commentary is as succinct and various as eny criticism being written anywhere. He isn't just extraordinarily intelligent; he is that fine phenomenon, a loving critic. So much of the energy of criticism seems to be drawn from bile and feuds with other critics or envy of the artist's reputation and the pursuit of celebrity. (Movie critics at the moment, being in the public eye, are guiltiest.) Here, though, the insights arise from enthusiasm for the medium and its luminaries and, since photography has been a poor relation among the arts from the beginning, Szarkowski hasn't been elbowed in his ruminations by a dozen hasty rivals. His many discoveries have a measured grace, free of the atmosphere of intellectual scoop and deadline.

title: Medical Records: They May Be Bad for You
description: WASHINGTONIf you're one of the millions of Americans who has tried to take out life insurance, sought health and accident coverage or applied for consumer credit, selected facts about your background may be lurking in a computer accessible to hundreds of companies. Such data, which has been stored on perhaps 40 million Americans, may even include information about sexual aberrations, drinking habits and drug abuse. Moreover, the information may be totally inaccurate or out of date.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems, should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: The Region
description: Orders for storm windows are running 40 per cent ahead of last year, according to Mrs. Sally Lerner, a supervisor at Abraham & Straus in Hempstead, L.I., and Macy's and Korvette's also reported brisk sales. People tell me they are afraid, Mrs. Lerner said. They're afraid of getting caught short of heating oil.

title: Jerusalem's Report
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, Oct. 7 Heavy fighting erupted yesterday between Israeli and Arab forces along the Suez Canal and Golan heights ceasefire lines, a military spokesman announced.

title: Democrats Are Hopeful Of Backlash in Suffolk
Princeton Clinches East Tennis Crown
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 6 Princeton clinched the team tennis title in the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference championships today.

title: Opera in The Bronx? Yes, Thonx
description: No one can argue: there are masses of music lovers who believe that the curtain on professional opera in New York rises and falls at Lincoln Center. But how wrong they are! According to the Central Opera Service, New York is home for 37 opera companies, ranging from the Metropolitan Opera with its dollardeirouring spectaculars to obscure groups Surviving on a shoestringor less. In between, however, several troupes offer modest but often stunningly resourceful performances that serve many purposes: they entertain those adventurous enough to seek them out, they don't make one very much poorer for having done so, they often explore unusual repertory, and they provide deeded experience for young perform talent.

title: OIL WEW, ARGUED IN SANTA BARBARA
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 6Thirteen Interior Department specialists got advice here this week from 91 witnessess on whether and how to proceed with oil production in the Santa Barbara Channel.

title: A Star Studded Dog Show in Westbury
description: Superstars with Louis Vuitton flight bags . . . Wouldbe stars with curlers in their hair . . . Dressing tables stacked with hair spray, sticks of eye makeup, powder puffs . . . With all the primping and posing, one would have thought they were holding auditions for a remake of Gone With the Wind.

title: Judge Takes His Cue From Stand by Agnew
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  Judge Charles Galbreath has indicated that if officials want to prosecute him for a $5 parking ticket, he'll have to be impeached first.

title: Wendy Weiss Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Weiss of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Joy Weiss, to Mark Steven Colte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Colte of Bellmore, L. I.

title: Palmer Fans 12, Gives 5 HitsBlue Routed
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 6There's something about a playoff that infuses the Baltimore Orioles with aggression and turns them into birds of prey. Taking wing with the first pitch today, the American League's Eastern Division champions swooped upon the Oakland A's, the Western champions, and trounced, them, 6.0, be fore 41,279 fans at Memorial Stadium.

title: Rehabilitation on Erie Line
description: HOBOKENA fivemonthold impediment has been overcome in plans for complete reelectrification and reequipping of 75 miles of electric lines used by 25,000 daily ErieLackawanna commuters who ride 1925vintage trains in and out of Hoboken.

title: N.B.A Opens on Tuesday With Chamberlain in A.B.A.
description: The National Basketball Association begins its 28th season Tuesday night with Bill Russell back and Wilt Chamberlain gone.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6There's no bump, no scar. Jon Matlack's forehead is as smooth now as his pitching motion.

title: A Public Relations View Of Academic Collecting
description: SOME years ago I met a French writer of small reputation and large curiosity who, though he occupied a teaching post in one of our distinguished Eastern colleges, seemed to spend most of his time (and salary) traveling to distant corners of the country in search of obscure museums, Nothing pleased him more than to be able to, speak of a littleknown masterpiece most of us had never seen or, indeed, even heard of. He had an insatiable appetite for pictures and objects, and a keen eye for artistic quality, and he seemed not to mind driving the immense length of our boring turnpikes and freeways on the chance that he would make still another happy discovery.

title: Sisters of the Poor Seek Aid for Abed
description: NEWARK The Little Sisters of the Poor, sworn to personal poverty and accustomed to begging in order to furnish the daily needs of the elderly poor in their care, have been confronted with an urgent need for $6.7million to continue their work in New Jersey.

title: Peter Parnall: From Ads to Bird Art in Milford
description: MILFORD  Less than 10 years ago, Peter Parnall was an advertising man in New York who hid no more thought of being an illustrator or living in New Jersey than the man in the moon.

title: P. C. Dixon to Wed Elizabeth Hobson
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 6Miss Elizabeth Anne Hobson and Philip Charles Dixon, seniors at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N. Y., have made plans to be married next summer.

title: Home Improvement
description: BECAUSE modern homes tend to be built with a more open plan than those of our grandfathers, and because improved construction methods have made them much more airtight (to conserve heat and eliminate cold drafts), adequate ventilation and removal of stale air has also become more of a problem in many households. Odors generated by cooking, smoking or cleaning in one part of the house spread rapidly to other rooms so that the air inside often becomes stuffy and uncomfortable.

title: Brick Tops Raritan in 1413 Battle
description: Dan Duddy connected wi?? Bob Walters on two thir?? quarter scoring passes ye?? terday as Brick Township e?? tended its unbeaten string 24 games with a 1413 vi?? tory over previously u?? beaten Raritan in Hazlet.

title: Local Unit In Corona Approves School
description: A new Queens high school, which has been the center of a heated controversy in the city for the last seven years, took another small step toward construction this week when it received the approval of the local community board in Corona. However, despite the board's approval, it will be several years before the plans for the school can be implemented.

title: Pennsy's Problems
description: Nearly six years after the consummation of what was toasted as railroading's perfect marriage and 39 months after the dream collapsed in bankruptcy court, it apeared last week that the saga of the Penn Central was headed for some sort of final resolution.

title: Caroline Grace To Be a Bride
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. Mr. and Mrs. David Ralph Grace have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Erskine Grace, to William Patrick Michael Casler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Casler of Fort Lee, N. J. The wedding is planned for Dec. 1.

title: Letters: Down With Niagara Falls Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings Outflow
description: Savers at thrift institutions continue to draw down their accounts to invest directly in moneymarket securities, such as Treasury bills, providing a higher return.

title: Back Scores Twice, Lifts Rush Total to 1,049 Yards
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6Penn and Brown began their Ivy League football season on a jarring note this sunny afternoon in Franklin Field, with Penn taking its first step toward a league title with a 2820 victory.

title: Lillian Stokes Tyne's Wedding Bridal Is Set To Peter Corbin Held on L.I. By Miss Falk
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 6Miss Lillian Stokes Pyne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eben Wright Pyne of Old Westbury, L. I., was married here this evening to Peter Stockton Corbin of Hartwood, N. Y., son of Mrs. Campbell Groel of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and Robert Corbin of Westfield, N. J.

title: 51 Bundler Wins Frizette; Talking Picture Runs 5th
description: On the eve of the 26th running of the $121,100 Frizette, John P. Campo, the successful trainer of Elmendorf Farm's distinctly favored Talking Picture, said, My filly is leaving from the No. 2 slotand that ain't good. She's in with a big field and the traffic may cause trouble.

title: HEREWARD COOKE, ARTIST, CURATOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Dr. Hereward Lester Cooke, curator of painting at the National Gallery of Art since 1962, died yesterday at Fairfax Hospital after having suffered a heart attack at his home in McLean, Va. He was 57 years old.

title: Two East End Lobstermen Accuse a Spanish Trawler of Deliberately Wrecking Gear
description: MONTAUK, L. I.The dispute over fishing rights in international waters spread this week when American lobstermen out of East End ports contended that they were being harassed 85 miles southeast of the Shinnecock Inlet by a Spanish vessel.

title: Nixon's Impounding of Billions in Federal Money Is Complicated Issue, Abounding in Misconceptions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6In 1970 the Missouri Highway Commission sought Federal funds due the state from gasoline taxes to help complete Interstate 44 through St Louis and for other roads. But the money was unavailable because the White House wanted to cut spending and thus put a brake on inflation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York Board of Trade and the Mayor's Public Utilities Committee will hold a public meeting here next Wednesday on ways to combat the expected heating oil shortage in the city this winter. Milton Musicus, Municipal Services Administrator, said that the meeting would be held in his office in the Municipal Building, Chambers and Centre Streets, from 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M.

title: Amiable Side of Old England Is Shown at Morris Museum
description: MORRISTOWNThe Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences is presenting a quietly amiable view of The English Scenes, or more specifically, the Old English scene of hunts, happy country folk and fertile English countryside.

title: Robbery Suspect Stabbed By a Woman on East Side
description: An 18yearold robbery suspect was stabbed and seriously wounded by a woman who had gone to the assistance of her husband while he was grappling with the intruder in the apartment of a neighbor in an upper East Side apartment house early yesterday.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Capital's Green Book Cuts Watergate Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6For John Erlichman, H. R. Haldeman and the other fallen members of the Nixon White House, it's probably the least of their problems. But in a quiet decision, made over the summer in the discreet privacy of a private home, they were symbolically read out of Washington society.

title: Night or Day, Truffaut's the One
description: WHEN we are children we build sandcastles and snow men and marionette theaters, We have electric trains we can wreck at will without serious damage to any lives, limbs or trains. We play makebelieve games that give us power over the uncertain universe, which, otherwise, rules our lives without knowing we exist. In these things we bring reality to its knees so it can see us. Some children grow up to paint, to sculpt, to make constructions of aluminum and barbed wire, to write stories and novels and plays, to create movies.

title: Wage Raise Wins Dash, Pays $10.40
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 (AP)Wage Raise and Holding Pattern won the divisions of $47,324 World's Playground Stakes for 2yearolds today at Atlantic City.

title: Racetracks Feeling Pinch of Inflation And Competition From Nearby States
description: TRENTONInflation, legal offtrack betting parlors and increased competition for the horse players' dollar have combined for a parlay that is draining some of New Jersey's revenue from parimutuel betting.

title: SOVIET HINTS PLAN TO DRUM OUT CHINA
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6The Soviet Union gave a new hint today that it was laying plans for a possible effort to oust China from the world Communist movement.

title: Auburn Beats Ole Miss
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 6 (AP) Rick Neel, playing his first game at tailback, scampered 33 yards, for a touchdown with only 90 seconds left today to give Auburn a 147 Southeastern Conference victory over Mississippi.

title: New & Novel
description: Letters From Alf

title: Pitt Bows To Tulane By 24 to 6
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (UPI) Steve Foley threw a long touchdown pass and his older brother, Mike, caught one today, leading undefeated Tulane to an easy 246 football victory over Pitt.

title: Dr. Fray F. Marshall Marries Miss Lindsay Ray Wheatley
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 6 The Selwyn Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lindsay Ray Wheatley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haywood Wheatley of Charlotte, to Dr. Fray Francis Marshall. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Victor Fray Marshall of New York and Gordonsville, Va.

title: Yugoslav Quintet Tops Spain for Title
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Yugoslavia beat Spain, 7867, tonight to win the European basketball championship. The halftime score was 4331 in favor of the visitors.

title: Closing of City Highway Stirs Repercussions in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 6It took the partial closure of the West Side Highway to step up a political race in Westchester and focus attention on one of the county's big problemsIcommuter traffic.

title: Miss Baillie Is Betrothed
description: PAXTON, Mass., Oct. 6The Rev. Arlan A. Baillie, minister of the First Congregational Church in Worcester, and Mrs. Baillie have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Baillie, to Alan Richard Denzer Jr., son of Mr. Denzer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Mrs. Sheila M. Denzer of Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Writer In Residence
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. As an academic title writer in residence is of fairly recent vintage and illdefined prerequisites. Holders of the title have ranged from worldrenowned literary figures to aspiring unknowns more indisputably resident than writer. Seldom has the appointment been so fortunate as when the University of Virginia in the 1950's named Nobel Prize winner William Faulkner. Evidence of this was the fine volume Faulkner in the University, (University Press of Virginia, cloth $8.50; Random, paper $1.95) edited by Frederick L. Gwynn and Joseph L. Blotner, based on the taped record of Faulkner's comments to students and the University community on the craft of writing.

title: Summit, Without Wilson, Runs Victory String to 12
description: With its allstate halfback, Willie Wilson, watching from the sidelines, Summit established a scilool winning record yesterday with its 12th consecutive victory, a 277 decision over Madison Borough in Summit.

title: Seton Hall Coeds Sharing Men's Dorm
description: SOUTH ORANGEWhen the men's dormitory at Seton Hall University was built 22 years ago, women students were unknown and conservatism was the watchword. This fall, however, the 7,000student South Orange campus has begun a coed dormitory program. One floor of Old Boland Hall, the men's dormitory, is now inhabited by women for the first time.

title: A Visit, My Lord, to a Turkish Bath
description: ISTANBUL  A tourist in Istanbul must be endowed with fortitude. During a walk down Istiklal Caddesi, the narrow thoroughfare serpentining through the steep hills of the fashionable Beyoglu section, one gets continually bumped and elbowed by the crowds, pestered by importuning shop keepers, harassed by battalions of urchins selling newspapers, plastic toys and trays of breadsticks, and pursued by old men peddling apples and oranges, secondhand books and retouched photographs of Kemal Ataturk, Turkey's first president. And all the while the bumpertobumpier cars and dolmus (taxiscumbuses) grind along, honking, squealing, polluting. After a morning of sightseeing or shopping in this Byzantine bedlam, whether well endowed with fortitude or not, my lord and my lady are ready for their baths.

title: Brightwear for night life
description: Metallic threads

title: ENVOYS FORESAW MILITARY ACTION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6For the last month, diplomats in the Middle East have been talking of a possible military action by Egypt to increase pressure on Israel, the United States and the world community to make serious efforts to bring about a settlement in the area.

title: Isidore Grossman Dead at 88; Led Clothing Makers Exchange
description: Isidore Grossman, founder and former chairman of the Grossman Clothing Company and president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange from 1937 until 1961, died yesterday at his home, 1016 Fifth Avenue. He was 88 years old.

title: COLLEGE IS AIDED BY LITTLE DONORS
description: MOORHEAD, Minn., Oct. 6They started out looking for 400 little Carnegies who would give $1,000 each to build a college library.

title: The World Bank Since Bretton Woods
description: These books are both about an idea, perhaps more accurately a dream that marvelously captured the minds of Americans in the years following World War II. It was that the capital, technical and scientific experience and knowledge, gift for organization, energy and general Godgiven goodness of the people of the United States, if properly assisted by others, could rescue the poor of the world from their poverty. This, given mostly the money, could be accomplished quite rapidly.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN POLICE SLAYING
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn youth who had been out of jail only four months after serving time for armed robbery was arrested and accused yesterday of the slaying of a sanitation policeman, Leo White, during a holdup in a Brooklyn bar.

title: Miss Janet Crowell Bride of C.W. Herr
description: In the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Janet Dudley Crowell, daughter of Mrs. William deForrest Crowell of St. Louis and the late Mr. Crowell, became the bride of Cowles Whitehouse Herr. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Ryman Herr of Stanton, N. J.

title: A generous well of relaxed connoisseurship For Want of the Golderi City By Sacheverell Sitwell. 464 pp. New York: The John Day Co. $12.95.
description: If the Sitwells had not invented themselves, they would have been born in the usual way. Determined, as Sacheverell says, to leave mark, they did, Edith reciting Facade through a megaphone in 1923, Osbert debunking spiritualists, and Sacheverell  well, he was the quiet logistician, although on the evidence of this book he seems to have invented himself with an existentialist zeal beyond his sister and brother, like Kierkegaard a Janus bifrons, laughing with one face, weeping with the other. In fact, not eccentric at all.

title: War Power And Real Power
description: The House and the Senate have reconciled their differing versions of warpowers legislation, and the next move apparently will be President Nixon's veto. There is a good chance that the Senate will then override, but not much that the House will do the same. Even if Mr. Nixon prevails by a narrow margin in one house however, this is immensely important legislation, the first real step away from the imperial Presidency that gave us Vietnam and Watergate.

title: Agnew: Villain Or Victim?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6After the damaging disclosures of political and financial corruption in the last Presidential election, there was a natural demand in Washington and in the nation for punishment and reform. This is the critical point of Vice President Agnew's appeal to Congress, his complicated and often contradictory appeals to principles he ignored in the past, and his defiant challenge to his own Administration, whose tough battles he led in the first Nixon Administration.

title: Witcracks
description: Jokes and Jests From American Folklore. Collected by Alvin Schwartz. Illustrated by Glen Rounds. 128 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Company. Cloth, $4.95, paper, $1.95. (Ages 7 to 11)

title: Stricter Research Standards To Protect Prisoners Drafted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  A stew draft report by staff bers of the National Institutes of Health calls for strict ethical standards for medical research conducted at prisons, and Federal accreditation of the prisons themselves.

title: The Good Word: Four Hacks
description: Are all the blockbusting best sellers written by the same person? Not necessarily. The fact that all their authors give the exact same interview should not blind one to exotic varieties of plumage and even character. For instance.

title: Monuments Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) The White House has announced today President Nixon's appointment of Harvey A. Roffman, an Omaha advertising company executive, as a member of the American Battle Monuments Commission. The commission oversees the construction and maintenance of military cemeteries and memorials abroad as well as some military monuments in the United States.

title: Score to Give Business Counsel
description: LINCROFTA free counseling service on business problems is being offered by the Monmouth chapter of the Service Corps of Retired Executives at Brookdale Community College next month.

title: FROM SYNAGOGUE TO STAGING AREA
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 6Congregations at daylong Yom Kippur services here gradually thinned out as young worshipers were called away for military reserve duty.

title: Flipping Over Tokyo's Fish Market
description: UNDER the glare of naked light bulbs in Tokyo's vast Uogashi Fish Marketthe world's largest fish marketbrokers start their day peering into the slit bellies of the tuna, reckoning what each will bring at auction. Impatient laborers hauling carts loaded with fish turn the intersections of the market's narrow alleyways into a test of nerves with their shoving and shouting; barechested employes cleave carcasses with mallets and steel wedges, and women in rubber aprons shuck oysters and clams.

title: AUTO SHOW OFFERS CARS FOR SINGLES
description: Cars preferred by single men and women will be featured at the second Greater New York Automobile Show, which opens Oct. 20 at the New York Coliseum.

title: Taylor Twins Spark John Jay to 30th in Row
description: John Jay used a powerful offense and a stubborn defense as it recorded its 23d straight league triumph and 30th successive regular season victory yesterday, routing Mahopac, 41.0. Allen Taylor, the explosive allcounty running back, scored two touchdowns and threw a thirdquarter option pass to his twin brother, Bruce, for a 54yard scoring play. Allen his eight touchdowns and over 500 yards gained in just three games this season.

title: Patricia McCormick Bride of Robert Davis
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Oct. Miss Patricia Anne McCormick and Robert Michael Davis were married here this afternoon in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Albert Wickens performed the ceremony.

title: Tough Eli Defense Thwarts Raiders Late in Game
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6 (AP)  Yale, overcoming early game mistakes and sparked by a defense inspired by key plays from Willie Robinson and Rich Fehling, hung on to salvage a 2418 victory over Colgate today.

title: People and Business
description: By profession, 31yearold Ronald J. Orlick is an account executive with Edwards & Hanly, the stockbrokers, in its Red Bank office. But his hobby and part of his jobsomeday, he says, he may make it his businessis the prevention and detection of such business crimes as shoplifting, employe pilferage, embezzlement and badcheck cashing.

title: A catchall collection largely of detritus
description: Until I came across this book, I'm afraid I knew Ken Kesey only through Tom Wolfe's fine study, The Electric KoolAid Acid Test, and he seemed to me one of that burgeoning band of American writers who are their own most perfect work of art.

title: The Boston Murders
description: BOSTONA young white woman doused with gasoline and set on fire by six black youths.... An elderly white man stoned to death by a band of teenagers....

title: 2 Women Qualify As Firemen, But...
description: TRENTONWomen in New Jersey's firehouses? Sliding down poles, fighting fires, polishing equipmentin short, violating a sacred male preserve that has thus far withstood the female drive for absolute job equality?

title: Two Fronts in Mideast Fighting: Suez Canal and the Golan Heights
A Korean Seeking to Establish New Religion Starts U.S. Tour
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon of Seoul, Korea, founder of the Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity, which aims to create one world religion, has begun a tour of 21 American cities, giving his first lecture here.

title: Education
description: The 11thgraders were typical American teenagers in a typical suburban school in New Jersey. But the nature of their work, and the relative ease with which they performed it, amazed a visitor to their classroom last week.

title: Glen Weekend Starts, as Usual, Cevert, 29, With Grand Prix of the Mud Pit Killed in
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 6Burn it, burn it! chanted the crowd as late into the night motorcyclists shoved their bikes in and out of the giant mudpit known as The Bog on the west side of the United States Grand Prix race track here.

title: The Impact Of Drilling On Coasts
description: Between 40 and 100 billion barrels of recoverable oil is thought to lie buried beneath, the waters off the Atlantic Coast of the United States between Maine and Florida. It has lain there undisturbed for millions of years. No one was interested.

title: Can the Young Change Our Theater?
description: It is no news, of course, that there is a crisis in the American theater, particularly theater in New York, which has been deteriorating steadily since the end of World War II. This crisis seems particularly acute when you return, as I just have, from England, a country where the appetite for theater is voracious, where London alone produces four to eight new plays each week. If you look at the New York theater directory, you'll notice that it advertises only 18 productions, of which only eight are truly the property of Broadway; the rest either belong to Off Broadway, or to the institutional theaters in which they originated.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Residents of Kibbutz Near Golan Tell of Syrian Artillery Attack
description: NEAR THE ISRAELISYRIAN FRONTIER, Oct. 6Syrian artillery zeroed in on an Israeli farm cooperative here today from positions across the Golan heights ceasefire line more than 15 miles away.

title: Tight Mortgage Market Is Hurting Horne Sales
description: TOTOWA  Walt Rossler has seen better days. So have Sonia Gardner, Edward F. Weiss and Warren Hill.

title: Seaver Says Bench Hit Nothing Ball
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6For perhaps 15 minutes in the stunned silence Of the New York Mets' clubhouse, Tom Seaver walked alone, his head down, his face without expression, avoiding the newsmen who waited for him today after the Cincinnati Reds' 21 victory on home runs by Johnny Bench and Pete Rose.

title: What They Don't Know
description: MONTREALDuring my seventeen years' detention in Siberian slave labor camps and Rumanian jails, I met with a great number of Soviet and Rumanian intellectuals. In one Siberian camp alone, I remember a Czech professor of law, formerly a judge at the International Court at The Hague, the former dean of Moscow's school of architecture, a Rumanian professor of psychology and former Rockefeller scholar the exmetropolite of the Ukrainians of Catholic Rite, and a smattering of former Russian marshals and admirals.

title: Commentary on today's church
description: In the afterwash of Roman Catholic renewal, there trailed a wake of derelict magazines with sadly optimistic names, Good Work, Today, Insight, Continuum, whose postVatican II readers jumped ship at the first sign of trouble. AD 1970, for instance, foundered in its titular year. Rare then is the record of The Critic with a subscription list twice that of a decade ago. The Critic's literary origins are well preserved, but it is to its commentary on the Catholic Church of today that readers have responded with enthusiasm. Dan Hen's iconoclasms, Joel Wells's irreverencies and John McKenzie's total involvement with his church have given substance and flair to considerations elsewhere often pure froth or painfully esoteric.

title: Many Apply to Re Toll Taker Of 2Penny (Really 5c) Span
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 6 More than a dozen persons from many sections of the country have applied for the position of toll taker of the TwoPenny Foot Bridge, which last month was included in the National Registry of Historic Places.

title: Newark Dances the Bump, a Blend Of Old, New and, Some Say, Risque
description: NEWARKThe bump is sweeping Newark and creating shock waves throughout the state. The bump is a dance, and teenagers have claimed it for their own. It requires a degree of agility that is likely to bar it from all but the most athletic dancers over 30.

title: TV Address Of Mrs. Meir
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 6 (AP)Following is the text of the Israeli official English translation of Premier Golda Meir's radio and television address tonight:

title: Chile After Allende
description: SANTIAGOWhat this country needs, said the Minister of the Interior, Gen Oscar Bonilla Bradanovic, in a recent exposition of the Chilean junta's views, is political silence.

title: Fordham Is Winner By 18 to 17
description: Brian Murray scored twice in the second half to lead Fordham to all 1817 victory over Seton Hall at Jack Coffey Field yesterday in a Metropolitan Football Conference game.

title: 4 in Mayoral Race Halt for Yom Kippur
description: Campaigning by the city's four leading mayoral contenders halted yesterday to mark Yom Kippur. Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, Senator John J. Marchi, Representative Mario Biaggi and Controller Abraham D. Beame stopped public activities at sundown on Friday.

title: One Cuban Reported Killed In Exile Attack on 2 Boats
description: HAVANA, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Eleven Cuban fishermen whose boats were reported to have been attacked by Miamibased Cuban exiles have been rescued but a 12th man was fatally wounded and ?? went down with his burning boat, according to his companions.

title: The American way with pets
description: When Sanford and Jane Leigh moved their family from Central Park West to Los Angeles for an indeterminate stay recently, not the least of their concerns was their pug, Banjo. The dog, an integral member of the family, had been mishandled in his kennel in the cargo compartment on a previous flight to St. Thomas. Jane, therefore, checked out the several airlines that make flights to the Coast and booked tickets for the trip one month in advance in order to secure the one seat per cabin available to small pets carried on board as hand luggage. She also made an appointment with Banjo's doctor to have the dog examined and tranquilized before the journey.

title: EPISCOPAL BISHOP ACCEPTS ELECTION
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 6The Right Rev. John M. Allin, Bishop of Mississippi, formally accepted today his election as Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church and suggested that he would not back away from the programs for minority groups championed by the current Presiding Bishop, the Right Rev. John E. Hines.

title: 3 Start to Destroy Chinese Art and Rob Collector of $3,200
description: Three gunmen, posing as florists, forced their way into the East Side apartment of a noted scholar of Chinese art Friday night and threatened to destroy his collection unless he gave them money.

title: Membership Down, 39 Churches Assert Contributions Rise
description: The National Council of churches reports that 39 Protestant denominations in this country received more than $4billion in contributions from their members in 1972. The 39 churches included the 10 major Protestant bodies.

title: National Show Will Run First Indoor Grand Prix
description: There never has been an indoor Grand Prix event for jumpers at a horse show in the United States, but there will be one next month during the National Horse Show.

title: NILS S. DAHL
description: Nils S. Dahl, former general manager of the John T. Stanley Soap Company and vice president of the board of directors of Shulton, Inc., died yesterday at his home, 8801 Shore Road, Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

title: Anderson Nominates Herzog for Yankee Job
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6Billy Martin would have been the ideal man to succeed Ralph Houk as manager of the Yankees, in the judgment of Sparky Anderson, manager of the Reds. However, after being fired by Detroit, Martin signed with the Texas Rangers before Houk resigned.

title: The Moravian Village of Hope Is Marked as a Historic Site
description: HOPEIn 1769, the Moravian Church in Germany purchased 1,000 acres in this small Warren County township and sent church members from Bethlehem, Pa., to settle the area.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Sunday Observer
Miss McLaughlin to Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y. Oct. 6  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James W. McLaughlin of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geraldine Leslie McLaughlin, to Lawrence Richard Jenkyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vaun Lawrence Jenkyn, also of Scarsdale. The future bride's father is vice president and managing director of Union Carbide InterAmerica, Inc., in New York.

title: Tour of Historic Homes Set
description: WESTFIELD  A pile of 200yearold boards and logs, all carefully numbered, lies in the yard behind the MillerCory House, Westfield's colonial museum.

title: SEX DISCRIMINATION HELD EASIER TO CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Discrimination against women is much easier to overcome than discrimination against racial minorities, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, former charman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said today.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In our opinion Bennett Kremen's article on the General Motors Lordstown assembly plant [Lordstown Searching for a Better Way of Work, Sept. 2] is not representative of the situation in that plant.

title: Recordings
description: IT was probably Otto Klemperer's indomitable spirit in the face of physical adversity as much as his absorbing musical personality that endeared him so to the English music public during the last 20 years of his life. Simply to watch him lumber painfully to the podium and hew those granitic performances out of sheer will power must have touched a responsive chord in the British, whose empathy with the underdog is proverbial.

title: Computer Rent Program Under Siege
description: The city's computerized rent system for controlled apartments is approaching its second anniversary, still doggedly pursuing the dream of peace on the housing front.

title: Miss Vogelgesang to Wed
description: Mrs. Leopold R. Gellert of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carlyle Boone Vogelgesang, to Leonard Braden of London, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Braden. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Shepard Vogelgesang of Whitefield, N. H. She made her debut in 1962 at the Bachelors Cotillon in Baltimore and was graduated from the Rye Country Day School and Finch College.

title: Music
description: SHANGHAI. AS a gesture to the visiting Philadelphia Orchestra, a special performance of The WhiteHaired Girl was given on Sept. 21. It was indeed a gesture. The company of the Shanghai Dance School had to be assembled just for this occasion, and an orchestra had to be brought together.

title: The tempting of Father Bill
description: The Roman Catholic Church has changed more in the past 10 years than during any other decade in its history; its laity has changed, and the role of the priest has changed. The church before World War II was in a way the Catholic layman's country club, his educational institution, adviser, recreation director, his turf in a WASPish America. After the war, because of the G.I. Bill, great numbers of lay Catholics were exposed to higher education and became more discerning, questioning their priests about education; sacred affairs of the clergy and, in general, starting the ferment that was to come to fruition in the Second Vatican Council. The effect of Vatican U was to open up almost all the doctrines and practices of the church to questioning, and to subject many of them to change.

title: Trudeau to Go to China To Better Special Ties
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 6Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau leaves Monday for a sixday official visit to China designed to strengthen a relationship that many Canadians already regard as special.

title: Serious Shortage of Electricity Is Faced by Pacific Northwest
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 6The Pacific Northwest which relies on abundant and cheap electricity from the Columbia River turbines, is facing serious shortages this winter.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Penn State Sinks Air Force, 199
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Oct. 6Penn State's football team didn't quite reach Pike's Peak, but it didn't bust, either, as it ground out a businesslike 199 victory today over the Air Force Academy.

title: Publisher Wears Two Hats
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.George Caldwell, a senior editor of Stein & Day, a publishing house in Manhattan, has the best of two publishing worlds because he is also partner of a successful bookstore here.

title: Unconscious Man Rescued From East River By Police
description: A crowd of about 50 people watched the police rescue an unconscious 25yearold man from the East River yesterday and they cheered when the operation was completed.

title: V.A. Is Studying the Use of St. Alban's Hospital as 300Bed Nursing Home
description: The suitability of St. Albans Naval Hospital for use as a 300bed nursing home is under study by the Veterans Administration and a final report may be issued by the end of this month, according to two Congressmen.

title: Anne Noland Bride of R. A. Edwards 3d
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 6Miss Anne Kiefaber Noland and Richard Augustus Edwards 3d were married here this evening in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Francis Burke of St. Andrew's and the Rev. Howard Saunders of the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Hampton.

title: High Heels
description: The highheeled shoes for men that got such a rise from male consumers when they came on the scene in a big way last year have started to slump. The big news is now heavy bottoms, or platforms, which lift the whole body a couple of inches off the ground.

title: DEFECTS ARE FOUND IN OREGON DRUG LAW
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 6Oregon's new marijuana law, the nation's most lenient, has become effective with two incongruities that were overlooked by legislators.

title: Mahler
description: In an era when the symphony has been slowly losing its power to speak to our society, Gustav Mahler's great orchestral works have been gathering a massive audience. Perhaps his strongest following is among the youngprecisely those who find symphonic music pretentious, overstructured and pathetic. Mahler grooves, proclaimed the lapelbutton of an undergraduate Mahler Society suddenly emergent in the Berkeley student revolution. Recording companies seem to have, discovered an insatiable market for Mahler. Especially since the composer's centenary in 1960, the discs have been proliferating, including complete editions of the symphonies by Leonard Bernstein, Georg Sold and Rafael Kubelik. Meanwhile, an International Mahler Society has been getting down to fundamentals, publishing a critical edition of the composer's works.

title: 2Stroke Lead For Miss Haynie

But it isn't Mr. Macabie who answers the door. Instead, it is a babyfaced young man wearing horn  rimmed glasses, a scraggly heard, a blueandwhite striped buttondown shirt flapping outside his blue jeans in the fifties Sloppy Joe style, and tennis shoes.

Released on their own recognizance, Wednesday, pending a hearing, were: Capt. Russell McFarland and Patrolman Gary Lenzi, both of the Farrell police department, and Capt. Fred Madasz and Patrolman Thomas Jennings of Sharon.

title: Television
description: THE experience of sitting in a theater is in no way comparable to the experience of sitting in a room with a television set. title: The Unfinished Quest Of Richard Wright By Michel Fabre. Translated from the French by Isabel Barzun. Illustrated. 652 pp. New York William Morrow & Co. $15.
description: Michel Fabre's criticalbiography, The Unfinished Quest of Richard Wright, provides the kind of information that is indispensable for the serious study of any literature and culture. It is symptomatic of our times and our confusions that I did not say indispensable for the study of AfroAmerican or American literature. Fabre's approach and method transcend the mysticism, racism and polemic that have marred discussions of black writers throughout our national history. His book is a model for the kind of scholarship that might initiate constructive dialogue about the writing of black Americans and its relationship to American literature and culture.

description: The heaviest fighting in the Middle East since the 1967 war erupted yesterday on Israel's front lines with Egypt along the Suez Canal and Syria in the Golan heights.

title: Gardens
description: SPRING bulbs create a splash of color for the foundation planting of a house, where nothing but green shows for a great part of the year. Daffodils are showy against small  leaved evergreens and tallstemmed tulips stand out against yews or rhododendrons. Azaleas are a bit chancy in combination with bulbs, since blooming dates vary. This year's grand color combination may turn out to be next year's color clash.

description: State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, the DemocraticLiberal candidate for City Controller, just doesn't have the experience to qualify for the job and that's the real issue of the campaign, City Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn, his Republican opponent, said last week.

title: For a better understanding of female sexuality
description: A flood of material about womenfrom fliers and hastily mimeographed position papers to large scholarly tomes has appeared in the last few years. Some of these worksespecially those by Millett, Greer, Mitchell, Firestone and Johnstotnhave arisen from and contributed to the Women's Liberation Movement, providing it with a theoretical base. Along with these have come biological studies which are not really faminist works, but which gave the movement hard data to substantiate some of the theory. Masters and Johnson's now classic Human Sexual Response and Mary Jane Sherfey's The Nature and Evolution of Female Sexuality have probably done more to liberate woman's selfimage from the Freudian model than any books that emerged from the movement. A number of other works have hurriedly appeared in an attempt to jump on the lucrative liberation bandwagon and, disappointingly, Women and Sex appears to be one of them.

description: GULFPORT, Miss., Oct. 6 (UPI)The South Mississippi Sun, the first morning newspaper to be published in southern Mississippi, has made its debut.

title: Light box in the woods
description: It began with an elementary exercise in geometry, the combination of a long rectangle and a parallelogram. But what finally emerged was anything but simplea sophisticated, modern home of unusual form, inside and out. The architects, Mayers & Schiff, call this year  round vacation house in Westchester a parallel light box, a reference to its eastern facade set off between angled side walls and containing a huge, twostory window. This wall of windows, with its sweeping view of the surrounding forest, helps give the building one of its dominant characteristics, a feeling of openness. So does the spacious, twostory corridor that runs from the kitchen, past dining area and living room to the opposite end of the building, where the study is tucked in overhead. Along this corridor the architects have suspended strips of theater lights, painted a schoolbus yellow; at night they brighten the entire area, shining through the windows and lighting up the grounds beyond. Throughout, the supporting columns have been left freestanding, not enclosed in walls. This converts the lower level, in effect, into a single large room serving the functions of living room, dining room and kitchen. Besides the study, there are three bedrooms on the upper level. These open off a balcony which overlooks the lofty corridor. In addition to the openness of the house, the family especially likes the odd nooks and crannies which the geometry of the building has created: an alcove beside the fireplace, for example, and the upstairs studyloft. The bedrooms, too, have privacy and are closed off, with eyelevel windows (visible in the view of the west facade below). The house, containing approximately 2,400 square feet, stands on a high terrace of a steep oneacre site.

title: For a Coop Owner the Lessons Are Painful
description: Six years ago, I abdicated the ranks of the renters and joined the growing multitude of New York City cooperative apartment owners. I figured that my housing worries were overno more threat of constantly increasing rent or eventual eviction, no more troubles with surly landlords, overworked superintendents, unwilling handymen. Once and for all, I figured, I was gaining complete and efficient control over my housing destiny.

title: What's Doing in Tel Aviv Iv
description: HOTELSThere is no need to pull strings to get accommodations this fall or winter, except perhaps during Christmas week. The addition of 200 guest rooms at the Hilton and the completion of several new large hotels have increased the city's facilities by 25 per cent. Soine Israeli hoteliers in the unhappy position of having to promote business have slashed prices to $9$10 for bed and breakfast in topgrade hotels for, groups of 10 between Oct, 15 and Feb. 28 as part of a package deal. Another package tour, offered in the United States, includes air travel, four days of sightseeing and nine nights of bed with breakfast in fivestar hotels (the top class) for $549 and in fourstar hotels for $519. The offer is valid from November through February except for Christmas week.
