description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Three blacks were wounded, one critically, when police opened fire on a rioting crowd after a football match here tonight, a police spokesman said.

title: Alabama Truckers Plan New Protest Over Weight Limits
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. Following a demonstration in which nearly 100 big trucks encircled the Alabama Capitol around dawn yesterday, independent truckers in the state announced they would keep about 2,000 bulkhauling trucks off the road beginning Monday to protest the enforcement of the state's cargo weight laws.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: IAN INIMCOMB: AFTER THE BALLAltogether, the men were ... fighting a losing battle against the . . . new women! . . . Red Hot Momma could part a baldheaded man's hair in the middle. And HardHearted Hannah was discovered on the seashore actually pouring water on a drowning man.

title: KING HUSSEIN PUTS FORCES ON AN ALERT
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 6 (UPI)King Hussein placed the Jordanian armed forces on full alert today and conferred with the Presidents of Egypt and Syria by telephone, a Government spokesman said.

title: Parent and Child: A new approach to adoption and custody
description: By now it is axiomatic in the field of child development that healthy emotional and intellectual growththe ability to relate to others and to learn depends to a great extent on the establishment very early in life of a mutually gratifying, continuing relationship with a mothering figure who cares for and stimulates the infant. It is in this relationship that the child begins to develop security and trusta good feeling about himself and a sense that the world is worth moving out into and exploring. Psychologists have come to believe that if you start with these feelings you don't need much of anything else, and that without them, it doesn't much matter what else you have.

title: Lafayette Team Pins First Loss On Post, 28 to 12
description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 6Lafayette scored a touchdown in each quarter today to give C.W. Post its first loss of the season, 2812.

title: Cevert, French Driver, Killed at Watkins Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 6Francois Cevert, who lived as fast as he drove, was killed today on the circuit where he scored his first major victory in automobile racing.

title: Headliners
description: The photographs on John Rooney's Washington office wall include shots taken with two leading politicians when the Brooklyn Democrat first went to Congress: President Truman and Mayor William O'Dwyer. In the intervening years, four Presidents have come and gone but Mr. Rooney, now 69, has remained one of the most powerful men in Congress; his subcommittee polices the appropriations for the Departments of State, Commerce and Justice. In recent years, however, the conservative Mr. Rooney has been attacked in his home district by liberal challengers and even by some sections of the Brooklyn machine to which he belongs. Last week, some of the ailing Mr. Rooney's former backers wrote to tell him the organization would not support him for a 17th term in Congress. There was no comment from Mr. Rooney, not even whether he had read the letter.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Do not feed, prune roses; they must settle down for winter now and should not be fussed with until spring.... Continue bulb planting.... Start compost pile.... Most weeds will disappear with the frosts; don't worry over them in the lawn.... Tidy window boxes for winter by poking in sprigs of evergreens.

title: GOVERNOR LAUDS NIXON'S STATE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Governor Rockefeller said this week that the Nixon Administration had been just tremendous for New York State; praised the President's new housing proposalswhich were assailed last week by Mayor Lindsay  and defended the President's impoundment of Federal funds.

title: Ann O'Neill Bride of R. A. Mulderrig Jr.
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 6Miss Ann Louise O'Neill, a paralegal assistant for the New York law firm of Lord Day & Lord, was married here this afternoon to Robert Anthony Mulderrig Jr., a methods analyst for the First National City Leasing Corporation in New York.

title: Special Elections to Pick 6 State Legislators, 3 From City, Set for Next Month
description: Six special legislative elections, three in the citly, will be held on Nov. 6 because of the death, retirement or resignation of five Assemblymen and one State Senator.

title: Surplus With Socialism
description: The Russian wheat deal may have contributed to higher bread prices for United States housewives, but such sales are bringing a smile to economists who watch our balance of payments.

title: Books as Art Displayed
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  In January, 1913 the French poet Blaise Cendrars brought a poem, Prose du Transsiberien et de la petite Jehanne de France, to his friend, the artist, Sonia Delaunay, and together they decided to publish it in a most unusual way.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: Antierosion Costs High
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 6 (AP)Any successful attempt to stop erosion along the Gay Head Cliffs of Martha's Vineyard would cost up to $33 million and could not be justified, the Army Corps of Engineers reports.

title: Nixon Appeals for Veterans
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. (AP)President Nixon suggests that Veterans Day, Oct. 22, be a day of remembrance for those veterans who are in hospitals, a day on which our appreciation is expressed tangibly by our visits and our attention. In a proclamation issued yesterday from the Florida White House, Mr. Nixon urged special consideration for those killed or disabled in the nation's wars and personal help and encouragement to young veterans readjusting to civilian life.

title: I.R.A. CASE SUSPECT DENIED RELEASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6A Federal judge has denied. motions urging the release of a Vietnam veteran held in custody since June 25 for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury here on alleged gunrunning to the Irish Republican Army.

title: Mayor Auto Show Planned in Nassau
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.Auto Fair 74, described as the first complete showing in the New York metropolitan area of all foreign and domestic 1974 models will be held in the Exhibition Hall of the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum here next Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Approximately 200 automobiles are expected to be displayed.

title: WALL STREET
description: The banks are made of marble With a guard at every door And the vaults are filled with silver That the workers sweated for.

title: Watergate Hearings, Phase 2: The Tricks Were Dirty but Inept
description: WASHINGTONOver the summer, senior staff members of the Senate Watergate committee were touting the committee's forthcoming exploration of political dirty tricks. That phase of the panel's investigation, these lawyers said, would be even more explosive than the inquiry into the actual Watergate burglary. The testimony would show, they claimed privately, that the Republicans had systematically sabotaged the campaigns of the various candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year and had thus engineered the nomination of Senator George McGovern, supposedly the weakest possible opponent for President Nixon.

title: Syria Asserts Her Forces Have Taken Mt. Hermon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6Syrian forces today struck across the ceasefire line with Israel in the Golan heights in their first offensive since the sixday war six years ago, and a military spokesman in Damascus said the forces had succeeded in occupying a number of positions formerly held by Israel, including Mount Hermon.

title: State. Lists Transit Aid for City If Voters Approve the Bond Issue
description: State transportation officials, continuing their efforts to win the voters' backing for the transit bond issue, detailed yesterday a $9billion package of projects, including highspeed rail service to Albany and a 10year subsidy to help operate subways here.

title: U.S. ASKS A HALT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The United States appealed to Israel and Egypt today to halt the fighting.

title: Toni Singer Affianced
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., Oct. 6Mr. and Mrs. M. Scott Singer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Toni Karen Singer, to Jerome David Carr, son of Mrs. Morris Carr of Rochester and the late Mr. Carr.

title: Graham Hagey Weds Jingle Igleheart
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 6  Miss Jingle Igleheart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bridwell Igleheart, was married here this afternoon to Graham Chandler Hagey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Graham Hagey of Tryon, N.C. The Rev. Joseph W. Baus performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: REAGAN PROPOSAL VIEWED BY VOTERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6Four weeks from Tuesday Californians will vote in a special election that will cost about $19million for an expression of their view on a single issue.

title: Reagan Signs Bill Obliging Aides to List Investments
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Oct. 6 4121)  Gov. Ronald Reagan has signed a landmark conflictofinterest bill requiring California's elected public officials to disclose their investments.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The city plans to establish a gambling casino and among others the Hilton has applied for such a license, but no decision has yet been made. In the meantime, small private gambling clubs exist on some of the Kurfrstendamm's side streets where, as Dr. Wolff of the tourism office puts it, strangers can lose a lot of money.

title: Plantation rookery
description: Pods from the okra plant are the common ingredient in most of the thick soups called gumbos. Rich, pungent, stewlike concoctions, they can be made with poultry, game or shellfish. This blue crab and shrimpbased gumbo is adapted from a recipe in The Plantation Cookbook by The Junior League of New Orleans (Doubleday, 1972).

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN POLICE SLAYING
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn youth who had been out of jail only four months after serving time for armed robbery was arrested and accused yesterday of the slaying of a sanitation policeman, Leo White, during a holdup in a Brooklyn bar.

title: News of Conflict Given At Yom Kippur Prayers
description: Rabbis throughout the city interrupted solemn Yom Kippur services yesterday to tell their congregations about the outbreak of war in the Middle East and to offer special prayers for Israel.

title: Jane Tobin Married
description: Miss Jane Bernadette Tobin, daughter of Patrick J. Tobin of New York and Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mrs. Jane Jagemann Tobin, was married here yesterday afternoon to George Shaum Littell of New York, son of Mrs. George S. Littell of Dallas and the late Dr. Littell, a pediatrician. The Rev, Norman D. Stanton performed the ceremony in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. Mr. Littell is manager of distribution planning for the North American division of the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: Its not the win, but the point spread that matters
description: By Larry Merchant. 325 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.50.

title: Nassau Reports 11 Per Cent Reduction in Welfare doll Since First of Year
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  One of Nassau County's most pressing social and economic problems  welfare  has been reduced dramatically, according to Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive.

title: America's Art HeritageGoing, Going, Gone?
description: A JACKSON POLLOCk canvas that was bought 20 years ago for $6,000 is now sold to Australia's National Gallery in Canberra for an in credible $2million, the hightest price ever paid for an American work of art. A Euiopean collector purchases a Jasper Johns for $150,000 thus setting a record for that artist and placing him along with Willem de Kooning as one of the most expensive living American artists. Not until 15 years ago could Jasper Johns even sell a painting.

title: Nicklaus Shoots 69, Leads by 3
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Oct. 6I'm more aware of this tournament than others because I've been involved with it and the course. I want to play well, admitted Jack Nicklaus today after assuming a threestroke lead in the $125,000 OhioKings Island open.

title: P. J. Haynes Weds Nancy D. Foristel
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 6 Miss Nancy Doran Foristel and Patrick James Haynes were married here this afternoon in the Manhattanville College Chapel by the Rev. William McGowan, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Welfare Behind the Decline in The Rolls
description: Jule Sugarman was exultant. The welfare rolls, he announced, are down for the tenth successive month. Mr. Sugarman, the head of New York City's embattled Human Resources Administration, was holding a news conference in his office, and on exhibit was a chart containing the latest figures.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: Montgomery County K.C. allterrier show, Temple University Music Festival grounds, off Route 309 Expressway, Ambler, Pa.; 1,251 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: ARCHIE CAMERON NEW
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 6Archie Cameron New, a lawyer and prominent Mason, died Thursday at the Edgewood Nursing Home. He was 83 years old.

title: Ga. Tech Fights Back To Topple Army, 1410
description: ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 6Georgia Tech rallied from 3 points behind in the third period to take the lead and then rallied from 3 behind again in the fourth quarter and finally nailed down a 1410 victory over Army before 50,111 fans in Grant Field today.

title: Transit Seminars Are Being Offered
description: UNIONIn an, attempt to develop better public understanding of the complex transportation problem, the Office of Continuing Education at Newark state College in Union has made arrangements to bring in experts on four Tuesday evenings in October to discuss the issues involved.

title: ST. CROIX WRITES ASK STRONG STEPS
description: CHRISTIANSTED, Saint Croix, V.I. Oct. 6The white minority on this troubled resort island, shocked by three more killings, has begun to demand openly that the black government impose stringent new measures to end the violence.

title: Purged Yugoslav Official Is Sentenced to 2 Years
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6  Vojin Lukic, a Serb who was purged as Minister of the Interior in 1966, was sentenced today to two and a half years in prison for hostile propaganda involving criticism of Yugoslavia's economic and political policies.

title: Patricia Selden Attended by 7 At Her Nuptials
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 6Miss Patricia Selden and John Kearny McColloch were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn.

title: Regina Heldrich Bride of J. D. Stem
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 6.Kirkpatrick Chapel on the Rutgers University campus yesterday afternoon was the setting for the wedding of Miss Regina Lois Heldrich and J. David Stem. The Rev. Donald M. Endebrock of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Highland Park performed the ceremony.

title: An ExDump Bears Fruit
description: A former damp in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn has been transformed by a group of neighborhood children into a lush garden with fruits and vegetables.

title: L.I. Clinic to Aid Migrants
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.An old white frame house on treelined Roanoke Avenue here, which has served as headquarters for the Eastern and Brookhaven area offices of the Long Island Council of Churches, soon will be given an unusual new role.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Sarris on Orwell (Continued)

title: Mideast Explodes
description: From the first field intelligence reports of mobilizations along the IsraelSyria ceasefire line yesterday, it was clear that this was not just another spot flareup in the Middle East. Renewed warfare of a scale not seen since the Six Day War of 1967 erupted at a moment when it was least expected. Diplomats of both sides were present at the United Nations to attempt new probes toward peace talks. Instead, the guns, tanks and missilebearing aircraft preempted the troubled scene.

title: A New Sewer Unit. Tested in Princeton
description: PRINCETONAn individual home sewer system, one that could simplify home construction in rural areas, will be installed on an experimental basis in a Princeton Township house within the next two weeks. It is the first such installation on the East Coast. The disposal unitit was invented 11 years ago by a Colorado man, Arnold Monson  is called the Armon Individual Sewage Disposal System. Armon System of Colorado is the manufacturer.

title: Cornell GoatLine Stand Holds Lehigh to 77 Tie
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP) Dan Malone of Cornell raced 97 yards with the opening kickoff for a touchdown and the Big Red then used a fourthperiod goalline stand to preserve a 77 tie with Lehigh today.

title: Books: Is Corporate Power Waning?
description: CORPORATE POWER AND SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY. By Neil H. Jacoby. Macmillan. 302 pages. $10.

title: PALESTINIANS CLAIM ATTACKS ON ISRAELIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sunday, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Palestinian commandos ambushed a 12vehicle military convoy in the Latrun area of the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan River last night, the resistance movement announced here early today.

title: Hamilton Urges Speedy Action On the West Side City Center
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton, in an appraisal yesterday of the arguments for and against the proposed convention and exhibition center for the West Side of Manhattan, said that the Lindsay administration was certain that the Board of Estimate now had enough votes in favor of the center to pass it.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: A GALLSTONE PILL UNDERGOES TESTS
description: A new Mayo Clinic study has shown encouraging results from an experimental pill that dissolves gallstones, thus furtheringhopes that ultimately many of the 15 million Americans with gallstones might avoid gallbladder operations.

title: The rule of lawyers
description: The legal profession is a proud one, deeply enmeshed in our national history. The world's longestlived democracy is based on the rule of law. Many of our national leaders have been lawyers. Our Government etas largely been designed by lawyers, and, to a considerable degree, run by them. Lawyers are often our senior statesmen, advisers to Presidents. Supreme Court Justices have an aura given no other public official, except perhaps, a President. On the facade of the Justice Department building on Pennsylvania Avenue are carved the words, The Place of Justice is a Hallowed Place. Beneath that, the great steel doors, these days, are locked.

title: Homosexuals Spiraling Toward Acceptance?
description: Abruptly and somewhat mysteriously, Dr. Howard J. Brown quit in December, 1967, as Mayor Lindsay's first Health Services Administrator. There were rumors around City Hall that he had feared exposure as a homosexual. But that was long, long ago, in the 1960's, and it was not the type of thing one talked about in public.

title: Giants Approach Ciitical Point Agabist Packers at Yak Bowl
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6The autumn foliage is filled with a dying beauty around here, which should serve as a symbolic reminder for the New York Giants, who begin a makeorbreak. Phase, of their football schedule tomorrow afternoon against the Green Bay Packers at. Yale Bowl.

title: Blades Tied, 22, In Season Debut
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 6 (AP) New York's goaltender, Joe Junkin, kicked out 45 shots as the Golden Blades and the Cleveland Crusaders battled to a 2.2 overtime tie in the opening game of the World Hockey Association season tonight.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The combination of the changing life style of American women and inflation has adversely affected Seventh Avenue manufacturers who up to now have not seriously shifted to a diversified product mix.

title: Bench and Rose Provide Rx for a Sick Billingham
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6Jack Billingham was a sick man yesterday and he didn't feel strong as a lion this evening when shadows thickened on the spurious grass of Riverfront Stadium. Then Pete Rose and John Bench took charge of his case, and Jack walked to the clubhouse glowing with health.

title: Parade Today
description: The 37th annual Pulaski Parade, a tribute by PolishAmericans to the American Revolutionary War hero, Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, will be held on Fifth Avenue today, starting at 1 P.M. The parade will start at 26th Street, move up Fifth Avenue to 52d Street and then turn to Third Avenue, where it will end.

title: TWO HOLDUPS HIT 125TH ST. IN 2 DAYS
description: A liquor store was held up Friday night on the same block of West 125th Street where the owner of a toy store was slain the night before. The latest robbery came despite the assignment of extra policemen to the block.

title: Saved at Last
description: The NYC Opera's three new productionsthreatened by a 28day musicians' strikewill be sung this week at the State Theater

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayS.C.C.A. Grand Prix of America at Watkins Glen, N.Y., 2:30 P.M.

title: Margaret Livingston
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Oct. 6 Miss Margaret Livingston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Livingston Jr., was married here this afternoon to William Thomas Richard Howard, son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. R. Howard of Columbus, Ohio. The Revs. David Lowry and Frank Johnston performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: No Room for Evasion
description: In its brief insisting that the grand jury investigation of the allegations against Vice President Agnew go forward, the Justice Department has built a strong legal argument to buttress what is the only tenable position for the integrity of governmental process.

title: Hospital Will Give Free Eye Exams
description: MONTCLAIR  Free eye examinations will be given at Mountainside Hospital on Tuesday from 1 to 3 P.M.

title: IN BIHAR, PROMISE BUT NO PROGRESS
description: PATNA, India, Oct. 1Barefoot children in rags pick through garbage heaps hunting for scraps of food in the center of this state capital. The streets are muddy and cracked. The air is choked with dust.

title: I.O.C. Votes To Admit Women
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct., (AP)  The International Olympic Committee broke down an 80yearold barrier today and voted to have women members. But the committee, the supreme authority running the Olympic Games immediately elected four men.

title: Stockton: An Able Faculty Staffs a New College
description: POMONA  When Stockton State College first looked for a faculty for its opening here in September, 1971, it found that it had about 15 applicants for every job.

title: Queens Sports Center Proposed
description: Creation of a $275million sports complex on air rights over the Sunnyside, Queens, railroad yards of the Penn Central was proposed yesterday by the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Malverne Victor, 148; Holy Trinity Triumphs
description: Only four of the more than 60 public and private high schools in Nassau County met on the football field yesterday. Malverne defeated Roose velt, 148, in the only public school encounter, and Holy Trinity beat Chaminade, 2014, in a private school test. Many games in Nassau will be played Monday, a school holiday.

title: Dibbs Beats Newcombe in Tennis Upset
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 6 (UPI) Persistent Eddii Dibbs of Miami upset topseeded John Newcombe today in the $50,000 Forth Worth Colonial tennis tournament, 75, 16, 63.

title: Let My People In
description: MOSCOWMy hobby is an unusual one. I collect countries. When I was in school I would look at the map and never imagined I would ever get to such places as Katmandu or Fijijust as my sons wonder at pictures of Mars. My generation grew up in times when the most popular person at a party would be the rare fellow who had set foot across the border.

title: Scientists Study Bones of Briton Whose Gift Started Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UN) The bones of James Smithson, the Englishman whose fortune was used to found the Smithsonian Institution, were returned to his tomb yesterday after two days of study by scientists.

title: Budweiser, an Unwanted St. Bernard, Turns Out to Be Dog Hero of the Year
description: A St. Bernard who had been given away because he was said to be a biter is the American dog here of 1973. The 14monthold Saint, who answers to the name of Budweiser, charged into a blazing house to pull two little girls to safety.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Secretary of State Kissinger's complaints about Congressional tampering with the Administration's new born chivalry toward Russia suggest a worrisome indifference to the prerogatives of Congress.

title: Protest in Seoul
description: Remembering the fate of the late President Syngman Rhee, whose dictatorial regime was toppled by a student revolt, the present Korean Government and its supporters have reason to be apprehensive about last week's eruption of student protests in Seoul.

title: Chile Stages Widespread Raids On Key Supporters of Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 6Widespread raids and arrests continued throughout Chile today in the drive by the armed forces to find hidden arms and key supporters of the former leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: A GALLSTONE PILL UNDERGOES TESTS
description: A new Mayo Clinic study has shown encouraging results from an experimental pill that dissolves gallstones, thus furthering hopes that ultimately many of the 15 million Americans with gallstones might avoid gallbladder operations.

title: L.I. Village Police May Be on Way Out
description: MINEOLA, L.I.The Long Island village policeman is friendly, helpful, always handylike the pictures in an oldfashioned children's reader. But like those fading pictures, the village policeman may be on the way out.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Flyrod That Got Away
description: BREWSTER, Mass.Lulled into carelessness by hours of no action, I had rested my flyrod beside me in the canoe and was trolling the east shore of Little Cliff Pond when a sharp strike yanked the rod out of the canoe.

title: Croasdale's Long Runs Help Andover Triumph
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 6Dave Croasdale, a senior halfback, scored two touchdowns on long runs today to lead Andover Academy to a 200 triumph over Choate. The victory was Andover's second of the season while Choate evened its wonlost record at 11.

title: Middies Trounced By 447
description: NEWTON, Mass. Oct 6 (AP)  Boston College wrecked Navy with four pass interceptions and two fumble recoveries in the first half tonight en route to a 447 football victory. Gary Maraligi, a senior quarterback, shocked Navy with a 61yard touchdown run with the game just 2 minutes old.

title: Over $750,000 in Overcharges by Hotels Recovered
description: More than $750,000 in overcharges to guests of hotels, most of them in the city, has been recovered since the State Attorney General began a campaign to obtain refunds 30 months ago.

title: Leader of Gang in Brooklyn Is Seized in July 13 Slaying
description: The 18yearold leader of the Tomahawks, the largest street gang in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday and charged with homicide in the July 13 slaying of a bystander to an alleged gang shootout, the police reported.

title: By InterCity (N.J.) Bus
description: (Maplewood Equipment Company)

title: MARINER PHOTOS YIELD SITE NAMES
description: BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP)Mariner 9 photographs are giving scientists a look at hundreds of Martian features never seen before, and a group of astronomers has just given names to places there that our descendants may visit some day.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The heaviest fighting between Israeli and Arab forces since the 1967 war erupted on Israel's front lines with Egypt and Syria. Both sides said the other attacked first, but they agreed that Egyptian forces had crossed the Suez Canal and established footholds in the Israelioccupied Sinai Peninsula, while United Nations military observers reported that Syrian forces had attacked the Golan heights. Despite the scarcity of details and conflicting reports from different capitals, some observers feared the scale of the fighting indicated another allout war. However, there was no initial military action reported along Israel's borders with Jordan or Lebanon. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Yale Bowl Access Listed For GiantsPackers Game
description: The art of getting there always has been a challenging aspect of the New York Giants football games at the Yale Bowl in New Haven. Traffic moves slowly on the twolane access roads from the Connecticut Turnpike and the Wilbur Cross Parkway to the parking areas adjacent to the 59yearold stadium.

title: L.I. Potato, Fit for Any Budget, Is a Simple Delight
description: Even though potato acreage has been diminishing on Long Island, the local yield and quality have been good.

title: Industrial, Residential and Commercial Complex to Open in Suffolk
description: YAPHANK, L.I.The first elements of Long Island's first new towna planned community with residential, indmerrai, orrice, retail and recreational facilitieswill open here this month.

title: The Fire of Life
description: October's air can be crisp, its nights chill, and we warmblooded human beings quicken our steps as our pulse quickens. Autumn is an invigorating season. Our inner fires are ablaze with new energy. But in the insect world all around us the inner fires burn low, for the bugs and beetles approach the end of their time.

title: MONTE PROSER, 69, OF THE COPA, DEAD
description: NEWTOWN, Pa., Oct. 6Monte Proser, Broadway producer and nightclub impresario, died today at his home. He was 69 years old.

title: Chile: Still Off Course
description: Chile's military rulers are launching a worldwide publicity campaign to explain why they felt compelled to destroy the elected Government of President Allende and to try to purge the country of Marxist influences. They will discover, however, that their actions at home will always have far greater impact on their international standing than public relations efforts abroad.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES in September dropped 1.5 per cent to 140.2 per cent of the 1967 base, the largest monthly decline since February of 1948. Farm, processed food and feed prices fell 5.2 per cent during the month. . . . The Government has committed itself to a heating oil allocation plan to insure supply for home consumers and essential services. . . . The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected liquidation proposals made by the trustees of the Penn Central Railroad. It says carrier has enough money to carry it through the first quarter of 1974 and probably through the remainder of the year.

title: Music in Review
description: Hear America First, the imaginative and welcome concert series inaugurated at the Greenwich Mews Theater last year by Joseph Fennimore, has returned for a second season, this time at the New York Cultural Center.

title: U. S. and Egypt
description: CAIROIn a narrow sense the Egyptian decision was an economic one: The American bid for the construction of a $400million oil pipeline to run from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean was the cheaper and, the Egyptians thought, superior technically.

title: Soviet Cuts Into Shows With Mideast Bulletins
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6  Soviet broadcasters reacted with unusual seriousness and swiftness today to the outbreak Of fighting in the Middle East, presumably signaling a quick behindthescenes govenmental reaction as well.

title: Wesleyan Topples Bowdoin by 107
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 6 Wesleyan gained its second victory of the season today, defeating Bowdoin, 107.

title: Overseas Deadlines For Mail to Military
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  The Pentagon has announced deadlines ranging from Oct. 27 through Dec. 11 for sending Christmas mail to armed forces personnel overseas.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The nation is involved today in examining and seeking solutions to what is generally called our energy crisis, the shortage of certain types of fuels. This is one of the most complex technical problems the nation has ever faced.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST.NOMLABRETECHE, France, Oct. 6th Arnold Palmer's vacation in France this year has been no fun.

title: A panegyric for Western civilization
description: Kulubi is about a country ruled by a cunning runt who is above the law and whose possible successor is a corpulent nincompoop. This chief of state is a mosquito inflicting cultural economic and political malaria upon his nation; a coward who fears the population and travels about the country protected and concealed by maximum security. While millions starve, he and his cronies live in royal splendor. His lackeys collect gossip concerning political enemies in the name of national security. Deviant artists, intellectuals and authors are censored and satirists are arrested for singing subversive songs. Student rebellions are ruthlessly crushed. As Harry Comfort, an American writer, unconscious of his Jewish past would say, Ethiopia is a violent, savage, country.

title: LAW SCHOOL OPENS MODEL COURTROOM
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 6A $460,000 courtroom of the future was dedicated here today at the University of the Pacific's McGeorge School of Law.

title: Danbury Stays Unbeaten; New Canaan Wins, 3014
description: Danbury knocked Greenwich from the ranks of the unbeaten yesterday, 147, at Danbury in a battle of the West Division Fairfield County leaders. Danbury, now with a 30 wonlost record, is the only unbeaten team in the West with Greenwich dropping to 21.

title: The 90%. Rule Is One Target
description: Mrs. Randolph Humphrey owns a 10unit rentcontrolled apartment building in upper Manhattan. The building was constructed before the turn of the century.

title: Fair Lawn Buses Still Lack Seat Belts
description: FAIR LAWNA complicated maze of roadblocks continues to frustrate efforts by the Board of Education here to equip school buses with seat belts and emergency roof exits.

title: Drugs, Bets Amid X's and O's
description: Two of the many new books using pro football as a theme are causing considerable comment within that sport's establishment. One is a novel, North Dallas Forty by Pete Gent (Morrow, New York, $7.95), in which the alleged realism suggests a blooming drug culture among the National Football athletes. The other, The National Football Lottery by Larry Merchant (Holt, Rinehart, Winston, New York, $7.50), for the first time describes some dimensions of gambling on the games.

title: Stargazer
description: If one person's name could be shorthand for whatever has happened to art in the last 10 years, the owner of that name is Andy Warhol, born Andrew Warhola, the son of Czechoslovakian immigrant parents, his father a Pittsburgh steel worker and coal miner, himself the signer of works that include Campbell soup cans, Brillo boxes, silkscreened portraits of Marilyn Monroe and Jacqueline Kennedy, and films such as Sleep (six hours of a man sleeping), Empire (eight hours of the Empire State Building as seen from the 44th floor of the old TimeLife Building), The Chelsea Girls and Flesh and Trash? This description may sound circumstantial but so is Warhol. He can be critically surrounded but not really specified; for, as Stephen Koch's new book makes clear, the essence of Warhol's work is evasiveness. Talented, creative in himself, Warhol may be more important as an absorber of forces from the atmosphere, a rotating mirror or radar screen.

title: Arabs Increasing Pressure on Oil
description: BEIRUT, LebanonA few weeks ago, President Nixon warned radical leaders in oilproducing countries like Libya that they did not desist from their present tacticsusing oil as a political weapon to change United States policy toward Israel, expropriating American oil interests and raising pricesthey would lose the markets for their oil as surely as did Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, who presided over the naturalization of oil properties in Iran 20 years ago.

title: You are cordially invited to a comingout party for men only
description: The best little boy in the world never had wet dreams or masturbated; he always topped his class, honored mom and dad, deferred to elders and excelled in sports, except baseball. The BLBITW didn't want to mess around with girls. He wanted to be cowboys, like the Lone Ranger and Tonto, with Tommy, his summer camp bud dy, or Roger, his freshman roommate, who masturbated, or Hank, his sophomore roommate, who didn't. The best little boy in the world was a closet case who never read anything about homosexuality. The FBI would never trace the fingerprints on one of those books to me! Bachelor J. Edgar Hoover and his lifelong friend Clyde Tolson would have to be a lot more clever than to trip me up.

title: If Banks Can't Help Buyers, Sellers Can
description: Lawyers whose practices depend heavily upon singlefamily home sales have been scratching their heads of late and talking about unorthodox methods of financing such transactions when conventional mortgages are hard to find.

title: Bridge By Alan Truscott
description: A single bridge hand often mirrors the theme of a biographical novel. It may be a story of steady decline, in which a subject with every initial advantage sinks steadily into a pit of degradation and despair. Or it may be a success story in which the hero rises from highly unpromising beginnings to a pinnacle of wealth and triumph. Most readers are uncomfortable with gloom and tragedy they prefer to identify with a hero who parlays brains and judgment and fighting spirit and luck into a happy ending. So here is the bridgesuccess story of 1973.

title: Royal Blue Takes Title For Hunters
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6Royal Blue and Bernie Traurig played a familiar theme at the Philadelphia Horse Show today.

title: Lyndhurst's Balanced Attack Beats Dumont, 230
description: Unbeaten Lyndhurst moving with equal ability on the ground and through the air, defeated Dumont, 230, yesterday in Dumont.

title: News of the Screen
description: Otto Preminger, who may be busy staging Full Circle, his first play in some years, for a Broadway opening next month, is not ignoring the movies. The producerdirector has bought film rights to Rosebud, a novel to be published by Morrow next year, and he has joined with United Artists to bring it to the screen, according to Eric Pleskow, U.A.'s president.

title: Fur Shop Goes Back to '98
description: As children, Irving and Miriam Meshel would accompany their father, Henry, to the backwoods of upstate New York to choose wild muskrat skins and ranch minks for the Meshel fur shop in Brooklyn.

title: ECONOMIC CURBS IMPOSED IN CHI
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct, 6; The military junta announce a series of measures this wee that will produce a radical bell tightening among all economi groups. But that will hit th poorest Chileans hardest unles the Government is prepared subsidize their basic necessities

title: Ohio State Eleven Downs Washington State, 27 to 3
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 6 (AP)Bruce Elia, a substitute fullback scored a pair of touchdowns and Archie Griffin added two more as topranked Ohio State belted. Washington. State 27 to 3 here today.

title: The Two Sides Of Terrible Telly Savalas
description: WHERE do you go as an actor after you've played a religious fanatic/sex deviate, a variety of convicts and gangsters, sadistic army sergeants, o??y supercriminals and assorted unlovables ranging from Al Capone to Pontius Pilate? Well, first you march into the department of typecasting and tear up your monster card. Then you wait for the right kind of new role to come along.

title: The Puerto Ricans
description: The Puerto Ricans are a people born from the wedlock of hunger and colonialism. These two forces have shaped our 500 years of history. The ratio of resources to population made inevitable the role of poverty as a historical imperative. The impact of colonialism created a psychology of fear. Fear and misery, in turn, forced the acceptance of colonialism.

title: Pennsylvania Court Clears Way to Build Gettysburg Tower
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 6 The State Supreme Court has declared Pennsylvania's new environmental amendment too weak to stand alone, clearing he way for completion by next spring of a 307foot commercial observation tower overlooking the battlefield here.

title: Numismatics
description: ANOTHER book in the spotlight, two weeks in a row, but this time the book is not only excellent, it is being offered at a bargain price for a short time. Entitled Coinage of the Americas, the book is published by the American Numismatic Society and for orders postmarked by Oct. 15, the price is $7.20; after that, $8.50.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Sports of The Times

title: Should the Stage Be MoreOr LessLike Movies?
description: IT'S not going to happen this year, and probably not even next;, but one of these days the theater is not only going to come into its own again, it is going to be begged on beaded knee to come back and play the scene.

title: Stamps
description: THE first American stamp ever designed in needlepoint is a gay Christmas, tree done by Dolli Tingle, an artist of Westport, Conn., who drew upon the recollections of her youth to bedeck the tree with traditional ornaments of the past. In 1964 the Homemakers commemorative was designed by Norman Todhunter to simulate the needlework of an early American Sampler, but the design was not actually executed in needlepoint.

title: Nuclear Fuel
description: The Atomic Energy Commission has proposed, but Consolidated Edison seems illdisposed toward the giant 500foot high concrete airandwater cooling tower that the A.E.C.'s Hearing and Licensing Board has ordered Con Edison to build at its Indian Point power site along the Hudson River.

title: Legal Fights Seek to Stop Turnpike's Extension
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is facing three legal battles this month aimed at stopping construction of the proposed Alfred E. Driscoll Expressway. The 38mile, $315million turnpike extension would run from South Brunswick to Toms River, through Ocean, Monmouth and Middlesex Counties.

title: The Ghosts Of the Palace Will Not Go Away
description: At first we kids were mad when we saw that a building was replacing the empty lot on our street. It had been one of the few remaining open spaces in our pert of East Harlem and our favorite playground. Now we would have to trudge all the way over the Willis Avenue Bridge to the untracked Bronx to find its equal. True, there was still Mount Morris Park in our neighborhood, but getting there meant being challenged by the kids on every, block from Second Avenue to Fifth on the way. Besides, parks of those days were for looking, not for playing. Grownups watched your every move. There were no stones to throw, there was no junk to collect, and Keep Off the Grass signs were everywhere.

title: A. & P. Dreams
description: Charles G. Bluhdorn, his dreams of a tender offer for the great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company shattered, moved last week to reclaim control of his Bohack Corporation shares he had placed in trust to avoid conflict of interest charges.

title: Notes: On the Way To a Royal Wedding
description: THE songwriter who wrote A Foggy Day in London Town must have been there in November, the traditional month for the sort of day Londoners call peasoupers. Nowadays, of course, the city is not blanketed so often as it used to be by thick fog, because of its ban on solidfuel smoke, but even so the English are crossing their fingers and hoping that on at least three days next month there won't be any fog at all to obscure three special events. The procession to and from Westminster Abbey when Princess Anne marries Capt. Mark Phillips of the Queen's Dragoon Guards is one of them.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A Canadian land and development corporation is actively considering the construction of an officebuilding complex on a large tract off Interstate 287 near Cragwood Road in South Plainfield, N. J.

title: The Economic Scene
description: FROM many sides, evidence is gathering that consumer confidence and spendingthe mainsprings of economic activity in the United Stateshave been losing some of their resiliency. If this trend is sustained and broadened in the next few months, the longheralded business slowdown may develop greater momentum than generally envisioned.

title: Bar Keeps Flavor of Past
description: It's one big antique; a living antique! said a regular patron in describing the King's Pawn, a restored Gay 90's saloon in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: Concerts, operas, conductors and singers
description: David Cairns is the British writer on music to whom we are forever in debt for the English version of  the Berlioz Memoirs (Knopf, $12.50): a firstrate edition, which was badly needed, and a translaUm) so captivatingly, so inincredibly brilliant that it comes closer than one would have thought possible to projecting the rhythm, the very feel and taste of Berlioz's gay, histrionic, biting and abruptly elegiac prose ( a string of adjectives I borrow from George Steiner's New Statesman review). Record collectors know him as the admirable annotator of some of the big Philips albumsthe Colin Davis Berlioz series, of course, and also Mozart's Idomeneo. He is now working on a fulldress Berlioz bock, in honor of which he has cismfor up writing  music cismfor the Spectator, the New Statesman, the Financial Times and the Observerof which examples, dated 195770, are gathered in Responses.

title: Jets Face Herculean Task Against Dolphins Today
description: MIAMI, Oct. 6Now that their lives have become intertwined with the Metsthey can't use Shea Stadium until the Mets vacate itthe Jets arrived here today hoping they can ignite a Metlike comeback against the world Champion Dolphins.

title: Dennis Price, Actor, Dies; Appeared in Many Movies
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Dennis Price, actor, has died in a hospital at the age of 58, it was announced tonight.

title: The Eastern Railroad Puzzle
description: It is not at all unlikely that this Friday's hearing before Judge John P. Fullam in Philadelphia on what should be done about the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad will prove to be the first step in the nationalization of railroads in this country. The sequence could very well be this:

title: U Mass Upsets Rutgers; Syracuse Routed, 380
description: Oct. 6Massachusetts turned NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., two thirdquarter Rutgers fumbles into touchdowns and then made a stirring goalline stand in the last seconds upset Rutgers, previously undefeated, 2522, today before 11,000 fans in Rutgers Stadium.

title: Photography
description: FOR the past three years, the staff of the Floating Foundation of Photography that peripatetic purple houseboat currently docked at the South Street Seaport  has been developing an unprecedented program of photographic education within the prison system of the state of New York.

title: U.N. COUNCIL AIDES CONFER ON CRISIS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6The President of the Security Council, Sir Laurence McIntyre of Australia, opened formal consultations tonight with other members of the Council to seek their views on calling a Council meeting to deal with the fighting in the Middle East.

title: Bicentennial Plans Spurred by Cahill
description: TRENTONCriticizing the Federal Government for failing to play a major financial role in organizing the 200th anniversary of the American Revolution, Governor Cahill is going ahead with his own plans for celebrating the observance in New Jersey.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 260 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Puns and anagrams
description: ACROSS

title: Residents of Detroit Taking 5Week Strike by School Teachers in Their StrideFor the Time Being
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6One measure of the Detroit school teachers' strike might well be found in the way the Shaw brothers, 11yearold Scott and 8yearold Chris, reacted when a visitor approached them in their East Side Detroit neighborhood one morning this week.

title: Delaware Governor Scored by N.A.A.C.P. Leaders
description: DOVER, Del., Oct. 6Gov. Sherman W. Tribbitt was embroiled in a new racial dispute this week following withdrawal, of an invitation to the Governor; to attend the annual banquet of the Wilmington branch of the National Association for the, Advancement of Colored People.

title: PLEA TO INCREASE TUITIONS SCORED
description: A proposal by the Committee for Economic Development that public colleges more than double their tuition charges has stirred wide reaction, most of it negative.

title: Greece to Pay $4Million To Royal Family for Estates
description: ATHENS, Oct. 6The Greek Government announced today that it would pay $4million to the deposed King Constantine and his family fo rthe seizure of 10,000 acres of the former royal family's private estates in Greece.

title: Pilate's friend The Testament Of Theophilus
description: Many have taken in hand, as St. Luke would say, to make the New Testament saga more real to the modern reader by telling the story fictionally. Anatole France's The Governor of Judea, Ben Hur, The Robe, The Big Fisherman, and Quo Vadis? vary widely in literary quality, but the worst of them like the best find an immense readership, apparently because the subject is of universal and inexhaustible interest.

title: The Agnew Crisis
description: WASHINGTONThe criminal rovestigation of a Vice President in office was bound to be something of a political earthquake. Even so, the tremors in the case of Spiro T. Agnew that kept coming last week were placing such novel and unexpected stresses on the nations political and Constitutional equilibrium that not even the most seasoned experts could tell what lay ahead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Clouds Speckle the Condominium Horizon [Sept. 23] raised many interesting and valid points, but I found to be of particular interest the report that sufficient trained managerial talent simply does not exist on a national basis.

title: DEMOCRATS BREAK A RULES DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Democratic rule writers, trying to frame no quota guidelines for selection of their 1976 National Convention delegates, broke a deadlock today that had threatened to wipe out months of compromise efforts.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The Logarithmic Century

title: Arab Notes Sent to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6Following are texts pf letters from Foreign Minister Mohammed H. elZayyat of Egypt to Leopoldo Benites of Ecuador, President of the General Assembly, and from Haissam Kelani, the chief Syrian representative, to Sir Laurence McIntyre of Australia, President of the Security Council:

title: Miss Shattuck Vermont Bride Of F. M. Leta
description: EAST DORSET, Vt., Oct. 6 Miss Frances Jane Shattuck, a greatgranddaughter of the late Frank G. Shattuck, founder of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, confectionery manufacturer and restaurant chain under the name of Schrafft's, was married here this afternoon to Francis Michael Leta.

title: Schools in Freehold Have Growth Pains
description: FREEHOLDThis midstate borough and several surrounding communities are asking themselves questions about their schools these days as they search for what is being called their educational identities.

title: 19 Autistic Children Get Special Education
description: OCEAN TOWNSHIP Bright curtains are going up, toys are arriving and a play yard is being assembled in the backyard of a former convent on Wickapecka Drive in West Allenhurst where 19 autistic children will be going to school yearround and six days a week in an unusual New Jersey program.

title: Higher Salaries Found For Pentagon Civilians
description: WASHINTGON, Oct. 6 (AP) A Library of Congress study indicates that an increase in Defense Department civilian employes in higher pay grades has added $430million to Pentagon payroll costs since 1964.

title: Dropout Teacher Entertains Young
description: BLOOMFIELD  The children sat on the floor of the East Brunswick Free Public Library one recent Saturday morning watching in wideeyed fascination the antics of a man who looked remarkably like Errol Flynn dressed up as Robin Hood.

title: Wisconsin Wins, 3728;Sets Record
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 6 UPI)Wisconsin rolled up a record of 548 yards on the ground  with Billy Marek rushing for 226 and Ken Strach going for 184to defeat Wyoming, 3728 today.

title: News of the Stage
description: David Merrick, undiscouraged by the recent outoftown closing of his production of The One Night Stand, the Bruce Jay FriedmanJacques Levy comedy starring Tony Curtis, is moving ahead with plans to present Tennessee Williams's new The Red Devil Battery Sign before the end of this year.

title: Amanda, Dreaming
description: Amanda, Dreaming must be examined in three quite separate ways: as a case study, as an object and as a work of fiction.

title: Marchi Seeks Aid of Percy and Baker
description: The already strained relad tions between Governor Rockefeller and State Senator John[ J. Marchi, the Republican mayoral candidate, have deteriorated to the point where the. Marchi forces are enlisting the help of potential Presidentiali competitors of the Governor to raise funds on the Governor's own turf.

title: the traveler's world
description: AFEMALE reader takes sharp exception to the report I made in this column about my family's twoweek motor trip during which we did not once stop at a turnpike or roadside restaurant. I had thought that my wife and I and our two elder grandsons had enjoyed traveling in de luxe Travco motorhome, eating and drinking happily as we rode between campgrounds, enjoying particularly riding past those highway restaurants with their dull, inedible meals.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Cancels a Concert Here
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra yesterday canceled its concert scheduled for tomorrow evening at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center after musicians in the orchestra announced that they would not cross picket lines set up by the striking members of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Loss of Opener Fails to Shake Berra's Poise
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6His players were solemn and virtually silent but Yogi Berra, the New York Mets' manager, shrugged.

title: Marianne Woudhuysen Engaged
description: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 6Mr. and Mrs. Andries D. Woudhuysen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marianne Agnes Woudhuysen, to Kenneth James Penn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard James Penn of Southampton, England.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Fairbairn Is Star In Ranger Victory
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) Billy Fairbairn scored a pair Of goals tonight as the New York Rangers defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 42. It was Detroit's sixth loss in nine preseason games.

title: Brazil Sells 40,000 Tons Of Raw Sugar to Chileans
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 Brazil has sold Chile 40,000 tons of raw sugar in substitution of Cuban supplies, it was announced this week.

title: Party Season Is Under Way in Earnest
description: Summer lingered on, but the calendar said October, so the social season in New York simply had to get on its way. After all, everybody was back from Europe or the Hamptons or was tired of holing up in airconditioned apartments.

title: Air Pockets
description: Last year, the red ink at Pan American World Airways washed out Najeeb chief executive officer. In the Halaby as chairman and last few weeks, George Spater has been washed out of American Airlines and Samuel L. Higginbottom out of Eastern by similar deficit problems.

title: Elizabeth Austell, Smith '72, Married to William Straight
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 6Miss Elizabeth Austell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rhett Austell Jr., was married here this afternoon to William Seymour Straight, son of Brig. Gen. Clio Edwin Straight, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Straight of Cincinnati. The Rev. Adam Weir Craig performed the ceremony in the Scarborough Presbyterian Church.

title: Rituals as old as history
description: I think it is the spectacle of football that I like best. The turf shining a not quite believable green. The players prancing in colors that flash: blue and silver and yellow and purple and crimson. We like spectacles in America, parades, and movies bright with Western sunlight and chorus girls wearing their patches and wriggling against shimmering backdrop in Las Vegas.

title: Girl Scouts Set for Cookie Sale
description: PARAMUS  More than 7,500 Bergen County Girl Scouts will be donning white gloves and setting their caps at a perky angle on Tuesday, the opening day of their annual Sookie Sale. A second group of 7,500 will begin their rounds in April.

title: A SUMMER TERM OPPOSED AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6The Yale College Council, which represents all Yale undergraduates, agreed last week to oppose immediate establishment of a summer term at the school.

title: East Newark Finds Its Name Confusing
description: EAST NEWARK  This borough, the smallest in New Jersey, may get a new name.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 2 TO BE QUESTIONED ON '72 DIRTY TRICKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)  Two alleged political spies codenamed Sedan Chair II and Fat Jack will be quesHoned when the Senate Watergate committee resumes hearings Tuesday on 1912 campaign dirty tricks, a spokesman said today.

title: Angela Davis Asks Support for Political Prisoners
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 7With the trials of two black women charged with murder both scheduled to begin in New Jersey on Tuesday, Angela Davis called tonight for supporters to pack the courtrooms and stage courthouse demonstrations daily until charges against them are dropped.

title: Misreporting of Parents' Income Leads Yale to Cut Student Aid
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7Financialaid gift scholarships to Yale students were slashed by $100,000 this year after the university discovered that number of students or their parents had inaccurately reported their family incomes.

title: WILLIAM R. REINHARDT
description: William R. Reinhardt, staff secretary of the master printers section of the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York, Inc., and industrial relations head for nonunion shops here, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 51.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Levitt Criticizes A Welfare Center

title: Major Bills in Congress
description: Oct. 8, 1973 ENACTED

title: Levitt Scores Idling by Staff at Bronx Welfare Center
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday described widespread idling and unreasonable selfimposed work limits by employes at a city welfare center, while recipients lining up two and more hours at the center were turned away from help.

title: Village Romeo and Juliet Sparkles at City Opera
description: It is sometimes said that the New York City Opera thrives on adversity, and, as if to prove that contention. the company achieved the impossible last week by successfully introducing within a fourday period all three of the new productions it had planned for its current season at the New York State Cheater. The compression was necessitated by the orchestra strike that put the company out of business for four weeks.

title: Friends of 4 Watergate Convicts Appealing for Defense Funds
description: MIAMI, Oct. 7Friends of the four jailed Watergate conspirators from Miami have publicly appealed for funds to continue their legal defense.

title: Cairo Reports Advances
description: CAIRO, Monday, Oct. 8The Egyptian command declared late last night that Egyptian forces in large numbers were continuing to reach the eastern bank of the Suez Canal after a futile attempt by the Israelis yesterday afternoon to destroy Egyptian bridges and other means of crossing the waterway.

title: Uniroyal Plant Is Struck
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., Oct. (AP)The 1,700 members of the United Rubber Workers at the Uniroyal plant here went on strike early this morning in a contractual dispute. The strike was authorized by the local two weeks ago and negotiations were extended for an additional day when the deadline was reached Friday.

title: U.S. ASKS SESSION OF EN. COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The United States called today for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to bring an end to the heavy fighting between Israel, Egypt and Syria and to find a longterm solution to the Middle East crisis.

title: Drug Traffic Thriving Despite New Stiff Law
description: The state's new drug law has scared Ronnie, but it has not stopped him.

title: Scientists Study Mystery of 24 Pilot Whales That Died After Stranding Themselves on Carolina. Island Beac??
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Oct. 7 Scientists from the Smithsonian Institution worked here today to try to determine why 24 whales died after they stranded themselves on a private beach, despite efforts to save them.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: ARRESTS EXPECTED IN BOSTON SLAYING
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)Detectives said today that they expected arrests very shortly in the torch slaying of a young white woman in the predominantly black Dorchester section of the city.

title: Subways Lose Riders But Are on Time More
description: Five years ago the Metropolitan Transportation Authority took control of the city's troubled subways.

title: Deficit May Force Scout Unit to Sell Camp
description: NEWARK, Oct. 7Despite constantly growing enrollment of Boy Scouts in disadvantaged areas in the inner city, the Robert Treat Council of Scouts here is caught between increasing costs and diminishing funds.

title: HOUSTON VOTE BARS TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 7The formation of an authority to develop a rapid transit system and the imposition of a vehicle emissions tax to finance a pone tion of the project have been rejected here by a threetoon margin in a onecounty referendum.

title: Equity Funding Officials Still Sort Out Problems
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. Oct. 7  Six months after the dam broke at the Equity Funding Corporation of America, the bankrupt concern's officials are gradually selling assets, borrowing money for operating expenses, mapping a plan of reorganization and still trying to figure out how much and what kind of business the company did.

title: Jews Here Offer Prayer and Vow Support
description: Amplified chants of Am Israel Chai! (the people of Israel live!)boomed from banks of loudspeakers in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza yesterday.

title: 2D DAY OF COMBAT
description: The following article was compiled from dispatches from New York Times correspondents in Jerusalem, Cairo, Bet rut and Washington.

title: For Terrorist Bombers, A War Is Winding Down
description: Trrorist bombings in the United States, which reached unprecedented levels during 1969, 1970 and 1971, have declined more than 60 per cent, according to a study released over the weekend by the Conference Board.

title: City Ballet In TV Films In Germany
description: BERLINWho would lay out $1.7million to film ballet for television? Two German producers, Reiner Moritz and Karl Schmitz, have, and they expect to make money on it, but probably not in the United States.

title: FAIR TRADE LAW IS UNDER ATTACK
description: The state's controversial 38yearold Fair Trade law has some under renewed attack as opponents, joined for the first time by Governor Rockefeller, prepared for next year's legislative battle for its defeat.

title: Ohio Burglars Bag Boa
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct, 7 (UPI) Burglars at the Driftwood Pet Shop escaped yesterday with a variety of goods, including a boa constrictor, The police said the burglars had taken the cash register, 10 dogs, several birds and four large monkeys and the snake. They left behind a cougar and a vicious monkey. The pet shop estimated the loss at $5,000 and offered a $1,000 reward for the return of the pets.

title: MRS. THOMAS J. ROSS
description: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 7  Mrs. Marion Byrne Ross, wife of Thomas J. Ross, a public relations counsel, died today at her home at the Westchester Country Club. Her age was 78.

title: Nordiques Beat Whalers, 4 to 2
description: QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 7 (UPI)The Quebec Nordiques scored two goals in the third period tonight to defeat the New England Whalers, 42, in a World Hockey Association opener.

title: Why Pay More?
description: On an income of more than $200,000, Richard M. Nixon paid $792.81 in Federal income tax for 1970. The next year he paid $878.03. Those figures, published in The Providence JournalBulletin, have not been challenged. They are about the same as a family of three with an income of $7,500 to $8,500 would ordinarily have paid.

title: Kuala Lurnpur: Fending Off West
description: KUALA LUMPUR, MalaysiaWe are trying to discourage the bad aspects of Western culture, a reporter on a Malaylanguage newspaper tells a Western visitor, explaining with charm and no offense his Government's efforts to implant a Malaysian culture here.

title: Israel's Two Objectives
description: The Israeli Air Force, in what American military sources regard as a classic example of the use of tactical air power, appears to be moving methodically toward two key objectives.

title: Film Fete: Israel Why
description: Soldiers in a grove of orange trees; American visitors exclaiming delightedly over Jewish products in a supermarket; a grizzled exBerliner singing Communist songs from the nineteenthirties: Rosa Luxemburg, we want to hold your hand; children scrambling down a chalky hill to shout greetings at some Israeli Black Panthers; Arabs being frisked at a border, their hands raised meekly in the air; many old people  so many canes, limps, parched faces with seamed smiles.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: New Groups Pace Revived Market
description: The stock market has suddenly come alive with new groups of favorite issues after a long, harrowing period of depressed prices  and depressed investors.

title: CREDITOR OF PENNSY TO SEEK LINE'S SALE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) The largest creditor of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad plans to ask a Federal judge to order the final dismemberment and sale of the 19,000mile railroad, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today.

title: Mets Even Playoffs at 11 as Matlack Allows Two Singles in Conquering Reds, 50
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 7Jon Matlack pitched the New York Mets out from behind the eightball today with a tingling twohitter that stifled the Cincinnati Reds, 50, and squared the playoff for the National League pennant at one game apiece.

title: Japan After the Boom Years: A Disquieting Lassitude
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7If anything here symbolizes the Japanese economy, it is the streamlined Shinkansen, or bullet train, that streaks between Tokyo and Osaka with splitsecond timing.

title: Books of The Times
description: The female nude in art is a spiritual and sexual reflection of her original in life. If we trace her evolution, we find her moving in the direction of a greater variety of roles and an increased consciousness of self. You might say that she began as little more than a navel in the fertility symbols of prehistoric art. Early Egyptian nudes were poised, selfconfident and beautiful, but there was relatively little psychological suggestion in their portraits. Indian temple carvings rarely ventured beyond a dancer's grace and a robust eroticism. Classical Greek nudes were generally bland, healthy looking and reasonably proportioneda geneticist's golden mean. In the Middle Ages, the stingy breasts, swollen belly and artless posture of the nude connoted repression and the rationalization of childherring rather than beauty for beingundressed.

title: The Theater: Chekhov's The Seagull

Which, presumably, is why it is comparatively little produced, even though it became the emblem and insignia of the Moscow Art Theater.

title: COLLEGE RESULTS
Screen:' Ben-Gurion' Tribute Scans Israel History The Program
description: "Ben-Gurion Remembers," in which Israel's elder statesman discourses on his life and career, took on special and unexpected poignancy yesterday as Arab and Israeli armies battled again over a country he so devotedly helped put together. At one point, indeed, he reminisces with other Jewish leaders about crucial decisions and battles, as newsreel shots sketch out Israel's 25-year history.The result is an anniversary tribute to Israel and a good, thumbnail refresher course in history. But it is the personal exchanges of Mr. Ben-Gurion with such colleagues as Golda Meir, Moshe Dayan, Abba Eban and Zalman Shazar  wise, warm and wryly amusing  that make this movie so winning. As they recount sad, turbulent times, even noting personal dissensions, they reflect the detachment of key people who had significant jobs to do.The film takes the former Premier from Jaffa, where he landed from Russia, to the sites of the Six Day War. These scenes have been directed unpretentiously but effectively by Simon Hesera. Mr. Ben-Gurion interestingly postscripts some footage of his visits with American leaders, including a deferential young Richard M. Nixon.Of a smiling Dwight D. Eisenhower, he says, "A good man but I wouldn't have voted for him." Of John F. Kennedy: "Such a boy and one of their best Presidents."Near the film's end, Mr. Ben-Gurion is shown in his home library, in the desert kibbutz where he has retired, discussing his memoirs. And at the fade-out, and the most moving thing in this admirable close-up, the old man and a young Israeli boy talking together, cross a field toward the horizon.

title: Kinshasa: Extraordinary Congress
description: KINSHASA, ZaireFrom Sept. 10 to 23, this city below the equator of the Zaire (formerly the Congo) River was host to the Third Extraordinary Congress of the International Association of Art Critics. There were 120 delegates from every continent except Antarcticaor 150, or 190 depending on which estimate you feel like accepting. Accurate statistics on anything are hard to come by in Africa. There was a lot of talk, some of it valuable and some of it pointless, during two weeks that were partly one hell of a bash and partly just plain hell. It is fairly hellish, even if you don't have a case of African colic, to spend four hours crowded into an uninsulated, deafening trooptransport plane whose single cavernous compartment you share with too many passengers, some of them carrying goat carcasses, and a shipment of sides of raw beef piled atop your luggage.
