title: Once a Terror on the Gridiron, Rosey Grier Now Does Needlepoint for Fun and to Relax
description: There he sat, by the window in his Navarro Hotel suite, working on the needlepoint design of a wideeyed knock kneed green frog. He pulled the thread through the canvas, deftly, gently, and somehow it seemed hand to believe that this was really Roosevelt (Rosey) Grier, 6 feet 5 inches, 300 pounds heavy, and formerly one of the famed, ferocious front four of the New York Giants.

title: MRS. OLIVER W. REED
description: Mrs. Ellen Christine Sickeler Reed, retired vice president of the Republic Car Loading and Distributing Company and former president of the Women's Traffic Club of Greater New York, died Saturday in Fergus Falls, Minn., where she lived. Her age was 68. She was the widow of Oliver W. Reed.

title: Reds Think Of Changes In LineUp
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 7Impressed by the pitching of Jon Matlack and Tom Seaver for the New York Mets in the first two games of the National League playoffs, Sparky Anderson, the Cincinnati Reds' manager, today hinted at changes in his lineup for tomorrow's third game at Shea Stadium.

title: Pamela Hebert Takes Lead In Poppea at City Opera
description: The Saturday afternoon performance of Monteverdi's L'Incoronazione di Poppea by the New York City Opera offered a new Poppea in Pamela Hebert and a new Nerone in David Griffith. Neither really succeeded in doing justice to the music, or even in clouding memories of their predecessors in the parts.

title: Egypt Shows Two Men Called Israeli P.O.W.'s
description: CAIRO, Oct. 7 (AP)Foreign newsmen were shown two men described as Israeli prisoners of war at the Cairo television building today but were not permitted to talk to them.

title: Sidelights Of Conflict In Mideast
description: TUNIS, Tunisia, Oct. 7 (Reuters)President Habib Bourguiba announced today that Tunisia would send troops to the front in the Middle East conflict.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 50 striking high school teachers of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn demonstrated yesterday front of St. Francis of Assisi Church, 319 Maple Street, the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, where Bishop Francis J. Mugavero was celebrating a mass in honor the church's 75th anniversary.

title: Builders Report 8,000 Jobs For Minorities Here Since 1971
description: The building and construction industry said yesterday that a survey had indicated that almost 8,000 minority workers here had been employed by the industry since the beginning of 1971.

title: Padmini and Her Indian Dancers Base Program on the Classics
description: Padmini, a dancer from India residing in New York, performed with her company and musicians Saturday night at Carnegie Hall in a program sponsored by the Hindu Temple Society of New York and the Tamil Sangam of New York.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE Malor Division

title: High Prices and Supply Shortages Bother Business
description: High prices and continued shortages are bothering the businessmen who purchase materials and supplies for their companies, according to al weekend report.

title: Cooke Warns Catholics on Abortions
description: Cardinal Cooke warned Roman Catholics yesterday that any involvement with abortion would mean automatic excommunication.

title: Crime and Corrections
description: Nowhere has the negative Impact of confinement on the crime problem been more dramatically demonstrated than in Florida a few years ago when the Gideon decision overturned the convictions of offenders who had been denied attorneys. More than 1,000 convicts received immediate releases. A study compared this earlyrelease group with another group let out at about the same time after serving their full and longer terms. The recidivism rate of the Gideon group proved about half as great.

title: ANALYSTS SEE FED EASING ITS POLICY
description: Moneymarket analysts continue to find scraps of evidence suggesting an easing of credit policy on the part of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Matlack Reaction: Best Game I've Ever Pitched
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 7Relaxing at last today on a green couch against a gray wall in an unused room of the New York Mets' clubhouse, Jon Matlack deserved to be tired. But strangely, he had felt that way before his twohitter that stopped the Cincinnati Reds, 50, and evened the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: Workers at Ohio Plant Told to Stay Out Until Cause of Nerve Disease That Struck 138 Has Been Found
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 7Workers at the vinylmaterials plant of Borden, Inc., here were urged today by union leaders and a medical expert to stay off their jobs until the cause of a nerve disease that has stricken 138 of 950 production workers Is identified and eliminated.

title: SOVIET ENDORSES THE ARABS' CAUSE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7The Soviet Government tonight issued a carefully worded statement blaming Israel's expansionist, obstructionist policies for the current Middle East conflict.

title: Dennis Price, Actor, 58, Dead; Seen as Jeeves in TV Series
description: LONDON, Oct. 7  Dennis Price, the actor, died yesterday in Guernsey in the Channel Islands. He was 58 years old.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 7 In the midst of what will no doubt become known as the Yom Kippur war, Jerusalem is the eye of the hurricane.

title: IRAQ NATIONALIZES U.S. OIL INTERESTS
description: BAGHDAD, Oct. 7 (Reuters) Iraq announced today she was nationalizing the interests of two major United States oil companies, the Mobil Oil Corporation and the Exxon Corporation, in the country's oilfields.

title: Reagan Rules Out Running For 3d Term as Governor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said today he had burned his bridges and had no intention of seeking a third term.

title: A Robbery Suspect Flees From Guard While in Hospital
description: A wounded robbery suspect escaped from police custody in Jamaica Hospital yesterday afternoon when the officer guarding, the prisoner left his room briefly and asked a nurse to watch him, the police reported.

title: A National Coalition of RightWingers Strives for a Sandman Victory in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7Representatives of rightwing organizations from within and outside New Jersey are joining the campaign of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican nominee for Governor.

title: 38,000 Attend Concert At State Fairgrounds
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)More than 38,000 people paid $5.50 each to hear the Allman Brothers in concert today at the New Jersey State Fairgrounds.

title: ...And Catch 126
description: WASHINGTONThe Vietnamera veterans have been afflicted with more plagues than Job. They participated in a war most Americans wanted to forget. They faced the debilitation of drug addiction and the humiliation of postwar unemployment. Now, still another millstone around the necks of veterans has been brought to my attention by letters sent to me by former servicemen.

title: Arena Stage Plays Americana in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7Washington's Arena Stage won a warm reception from Moscow audiences by presenting two classic pieces of Americana, Inherit the Wind and Our Town, in the first American theatrical performances on the Soviet stage in memory.

title: Planned Tomatoes
description: There is a direct relationship between the quality of life and the quality of a city, and much of it has to do with the quality of planning. When highway approaches to a stadium take precedence over the city's last remnant of a farmer's market, and its disposition left to the tender mercies of private developmentas in the case of the Yankee Stadium renovationit is obvious that the plastic and commercial in food and life has taken over.

title: Peterson Sets Grand Prix Mark
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 7Jackie Stewart didn't race, Peter Revson didn't start and Ronnie Peterson looked James Hunt in the eye and won the $275,000 United States Grand Prix auto race by less than a second today.

title: YALE TEAM EDITS DOUGLASS PAPERS
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7  A group of Yale scholars will be spending the next eight years collecting and editing the papers of Frederick Douglass, the foremost black American of the 19th century.

title: The Miss and the Filly Beat the Mr.'s Gelding
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Oct. 7Mrs. Billie Jean King may have found the garrulous Bobby Riggs easy pickings in their recent tennis match in Houston's Astrodome, but this afternoon, Robyn Smith, the accomplishedfemale jockey, found Herve Filion no soft touch at Monticello Raceway.

title: Peterson Sets Grand Prix Mark
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 7Jackie Stewart didn't race, Peter Revson didn't start and Ronnie Peterson looked James Hunt in the eye and won the $275,000 United States Grand Prix auto race by less than a second today.

title: S.E.C. Policy Aims To Help Investors, Analysts Are Told
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 (AP)  Securities and Exchange Commission policies are aimed at helping the investor, not harming the financial analysts, an S.E.C. official told the Financial Analysts Federation's fall conference here today.

title: 3 Young Jews Attacked By Gang of 30 Youths
description: Three Jewish teenagers were jumped and beaten by a gang of some 30 youths last night as they emerged from a friedchicken outlet in an ArabAmerican neighborhood in Brooklyn Heights, the police reported.

title: When Bottle Flew From Shea Stands, Rose, Anderson, Other Reds Saw Red
description: Pete Rose and his manager, Sparky Anderson, couldn't agree if the bottle was Jack Daniel or Johnnie Walker, but whatever the label said, the bottle created a fuss at Shea Stadium yesterday that was cooled only after a fiveman Mets' peace delegation visited the battle zone.

title: A Little Money Can Purchase Enough to Eat
description: The writer of the following article, a member of the staff of The New York Times who was born in Hong Kong, made a 13day private visit to China earlier this year.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL UP 0.1% FOR WEEK
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,890,000 tons, a gain of 0.1 per cent over the 2,888,000 tons poured the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Soviet Displays Moderate Attitude, Confident of Eventual Political Settlement
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8  The Soviet Union today displayed a confident and moderate attitude toward the outbreak of ArabIsraeli fighting. Behind official statements and press commentaries on the fighting, there appeared to be a conviction that Arab military gains would put renewed pressure on Israel to make political concessions to obtain a longterm settlement in the region.

title: Uganda Buys Soviet Salt
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 8 (Agence FrancePresse) Uganda will buy 50,000 tons of salt from the Soviet Union under an agreement signed here today.

title: Feeney's Peace Party Calms LeftField Fans
description: It's a little late in the year for outdoor fights, but they had a lovely day for it at Shea Stadium. The National League's pennant playoff had been so orderly it could have been held in the aisle of a cathedralno errors, no difficult plays, no arguments and hardly any hitting or scoring.

title: JOSIAH GITT, 89, PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: HANOVER, Pa., Oct. 8Josiah W. Gitt, publisher of The York Gazette and Daily for 55 years until he sold it in 1970, died of cancer yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston. He was 89 years old.

title: Cairo Says It Has Raided Oil Fields Held by Israel
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, Oct. 9The Egyptian command announced last night that Egyptian troops had raided the Israelioccupied Egyptian oilfields at Balayim, on the Gulf of Suez, arid set large fires.

title: Subway Maintenance Is Better Than It Was
description: The collapse of a concrete tunnelceiling in which one subway passenger was killed and 1,000 other Flushingline riders were forced to wait 80 minutes for rescue in 115degree heat last Aug. 28 immediately revived questions about the safety and efficiency of New York City's subways.

title: Secretariat Sets Belmont Turf Record
Quick Senate Resolution Urges Withdrawals to CeaseFire Line
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Senate hastily approved a resolution today calling for a ceasefire in the Middle East and a return of Arab and Israeli forces to the positions they occupied before the outbreak of hostilities on Saturday.

title: Lancet Known 150 Years For Medical Crusading
description: LONDON, Oct. 5  When Dr. Thomas Wakley founded The Lancet, a medical journal, here in 1823, his purpose was to advance medical knowledge and reform British medicine. His zeal caused him to spend much of his life in court defending his exposs of nepotism and of misuse of privilege in the medical establishment and his practice of publishing the texts of lectures transcribed by medical students, who at that time paid professors about five pounds a lecture for required courses.

title: Redskins Turn Back Cowboys
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Oh, those Redskins! The nation's capital, short of heroes in the body politic these days, had 40 football players to cheer for tonight as the Washington team staged a brilliant comeback to defeat the Dallas Cowboys by 7 points and 1 yard of bitterly contested turf.

title: Conflict Brings Minor Disruptions in Oil Industry
description: Minor disruptions have begun to appear in the world oil trade in the wake of the renewal of hostilities between the Arabs and the Israelis, and industry executives and Government officials in many countries are waiting to see whether the Arab states will make a serious attempt to use oil as a weapon in the conflict or any political confrontation that follows. The Egyptians are reported to have attacked Israeliheld oil fields in the occupied Sinai, and if true it would be the most ominous event so far, in the oil situation. It would be the first direct attack by either side on oil production facilities in any of the conflicts thus far. If the Israelis retaliate it could mean major disruptions of supplies.

title: Tanaka Joins Brezhnev in Callfor Treaty
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8Premier Kakuei Tanaka, the first Japanese head of government to visit the Soviet Union since 1956, today joined Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party chief, in calling for a peace treaty between their nations to end World War II formally.

title: High School Sports
description: Lafayette scores 54 points, Jefferson 54 and Bayside 51. Their opponents total 12. Onesided scores have been common this season in the Public Schools Athletic League, which has a group of strong teams and a group of weak ones, with few in the middle.

title: Ice Cream Truck Kills Girl, 8, in Ronkonkoma, L.I.
description: RONKONKOMA, LI, Oct. 8  Eightyearold Leslie Ann Brandt was killed yesterday when she rolled down a hill into the path of a passing ice cream truck, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: Notes on People
description: Times do change, and so do the attitudes of labor leaders, Mayor Lindsay learned yesterday. The Mayor, whose first term began eight years ago with a citywide transit strike, was welcomed with a standing ovation by delegates to the convention of the Transport Workers Union, which called the strike.

title: T. J. HAMMERSTEIN
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 8 Theodore J. Hammerstein, former stage manager for Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 3d and grandson of the late Oscar Hammerstein, the producer, died Saturday of cancer at his summer home here. He was 72 years old and lived in Ardsley, N. Y.

title: CORPORATE BONDS CLIMB SLIGHTLY
description: Prices were firm in quiet trading yesterday in the corporate bond market. Government issues were not traded as the market observed the Columbus Day holiday. In the absence of any new offerings, the market for older corporate issues showed moderate advances from levels of last Friday. Ohio Edison's 8s, due 2003, were up as much as a point at 103. Gains of  point were made in the New Jersey Bell 7s, due 2013, and the New York Telephone 8.30s, due 2012.

title: Five Die in Fire
description: RACINE, WIS., Oct. 8 (UPI) Five persons, including three children, died Saturday in fire that the fire chief, Russell Anderson, said could probably have been doused with 10 gallons of water. Mr. Anderson said the probable cause of the blaze in the upper flat was careless use of smoking materials.

title: U.A.W. Talks Start Today
description: DETROIT, Oct. 8 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers Union said today that it would start contract negotiations tomorrow with the Eaton Corporation, manufacturers of valves, pumps, truck axles and other equipment and parts. The corporation employs 5,000 unionized workers in plants at Cleveland, Louisville, Battle Creek and Marshall, Mich., and West Allis, Wis.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Horses & Equipment 3995

title: Beame Sets Fast Pace for Candidates At Columbus Day Parade
description: In the distinctive body language of Columbus Day politics, Controller Abraham D. Beame came out yesterday as the frontwalker as well as the frontrunner among the four mayoral candidates.

title: Business briefs
description: After Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia concludes a prehearing conference today for a full hearing he has scheduled for Friday on the Penn Central Roalroad's plight, it is expected that the trustee of the New Haven Railroad will ask the judge to dismiss the Penn Central's trusteeship and put the railroad into equity receivership.

title: 29 Food Concerns Cited for Violations Of City Health Code
description: The Health Department yesterday cited 24 restaurants, two supermarkets, a grocery, a butcher shop and a fish store for violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Aquaculture Scrutinized For ProteinPoor Lands
description: Although until recently it was hoped that the protein needs of the developing world, with its rapidly increasing population, could be found in the sea, it is now believed by a number of marine biologists that a doubling of the seafood yield is the most that can be hoped for.

title: Bridge:Championship Play Going To Bermuda Starting Place
description: The present series of official world championships began in 1950 in the attractive midAtlantic island of Bermuda. In 19 months, a quarter of a century later, the Bermuda Bowl contest will return to its first home.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey; daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Interco, Inc. Is Seeking to Acquire Devon Apparel
description: Interco, Inc., announced yesterday it had entered into mernorandum of intent to acquire Devon Apparel, Inc., in an exchange of capital stock.

title: Boston's Irish Political Tradition Underscores a Judge's Troubles
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8They called him Smiler at Boston College, but today, Dorchester District Court Judge Jerome P. Troy is mostly biting his lower lip.

title: Soviet Jews Still Moving Through Austrian Camp
description: VIENNA, Oct. 8 (AP)Movement of Soviet Jews through Austria to Israel has not been affected by the Middle East war, an official of the Jewish Agency said today.

title: An American and a Chinese Scientist Term Joint Effort on Cells Successful
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 8An American scientist and a Chinese scientist have achieved new success in the study of cytology and genetics in joint research in Peking, according to a report by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

title: Youth Is Suspect in Atlanta In Sports Editor's Shooting
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 8 (UPI) Me police charged a juvenile tonight with pointing a pistol at another person in the same area where the sports editor of The Atlanta Constitution, Jesse Outlar, was shot yesterday as he was leaving the parking lot of Atlanta Stadium.

title: Israelis Back From Golan Tell of 2Day Tank Duel
description: TIBERIAS, Israel, Oct. 8The first two days of fighting in the Golan heights consisted of seesaw tank battles with small isolated Israeli units often surrounded by great concentrations of Syrian armor.

title: Market Place: Cloud Is Lifting For New Issues
description: Gone are the days when Wall Street was grinding out new issues so fast the public could not keep track in the roaring bull market of the nineteensixties.

title: People and Business
description: Gesualdo A. Costanza, who has just returned from Nairobi, Kenya, and the Middle East, has a new job awaiting him at the First National City Bank.

title: A Civilian Cabinet Is Installed in Greece
description: ATHENS, Oct. 8  Spyros Markezinis, a longtime politician and historian, was sworn in today as Premier of Greece's first allcivilian Cabinet since the 1967 army coup.

title: Army Official Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Herman R. Staudt of Florida to be Undersecretary of the Army, succeeding Kenneth E. BeLieu. Frank A. Shrontz of Washington state was confirmed as an Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, succeeding Philip N. Whittaker.

title: Abortion Ruling Protested
description: PROVIDENCE, Oct. 8 (AP)About 50,000 spectators gathered here yesterday for a threehour March for Life by 10,000 persons protesting United States Supreme Court rulings on abortion. The parade was sponsored by the Roman Catholic Knights of Columbus.

title: J.D.L. and Nazis Clash
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The police arrested 10 persons Saturday when members of the Jewish Defense League and the American Nazi party fought as the two groups picketed one another outside a Progressive Labor party bookstore.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: A collection of 52 poems by 27 Russian writers, first circulated in the Russian underground and later smuggled to Germany, will be published next month by Harper & Row under the title Poetry From the Russian Underground.

title: Advertising: Research Problems
description: For a number of reasons, most of them sociological, it is becoming increasingly difficult for researchers to get data from inhome interviews.

title: 20 Persons Flee A Tenement Fire On the East Side
description: A predawn fouralarm fire in a vacant East Side tenement building spread to three adjoining structures yesterday end raged out of control until the original building collapsed in a pile of charred rubble and the fire burned itself out.

title: Council's Late Light
description: After letting it languish in the shadows for two and a half years, the City Council's Committee on Standards and Ethics will finally get around today to considering a code of ethics for local lawmakers. Characteristically, this open government measure sponsored by Manhattan Councilman Carter Burden is scheduled for discussion in closed session. It merits overdue approval.

title: U.S., in U. N., Urges A Mideast Pullback To CeaseFire Line
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8The United States asked the Security Council tonight to bring an end to hostilities in the Middle East and to restore the ceasefire line that existed before the new war.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Preceded by largescale Israeli air strikes against Arab military airfields, Israeli units launched major counterattacks on two broad fronts and, according to an Israeli spokesman, drove the Egyptian and Syrian forces back to the 1967 ceasefire lines. Although Israeli forces had apparently succeeded in turning back Arab advances, the Israeli counterattack was encountering heavier resistance than expected. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Nixon to Meet Zaire Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)President Nixon will confer Wednesday with President Mobuto Sese Seko of Zaire, the White House announced today. President Mobuto is visiting the United States to address the United Nations General Assembly.

title: The Great Failure: I
description: Why things don't workI: The threeway light bulb.

title: Art Museum Stays Open Despite Strike
description: The Museum of Modern Art will be open today despite a strike called last night by its union of professional and administrative workers following a breakdown in statemediated contract talks.

title: Chess:
description: The referee often appears to have a soft job: After starting the clocks at the beginning of the playing session, he takes his seat on the stage, closer to the action than any spectator.

title: More Schools in Michigan Struck in Addition to Detroit
description: DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 8 (UPI) More than 1,600 teachers struck two Michigan school systems today, joining thousands of Detroit instructors who are staging the nation's largest school walkout.

title: Jordan Reports Downing 2 Israeli Planes But Is Expected to Stay Out of Way
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 8The Jordanian armed forces announced that they had shot down two Israeli planes that strayed into Jordan's airspace, but the incident was not believed to indicate any change in the Government's opposition to becoming involved in the Middle East fighting.

title: ADEN'S JETS FORCE BRITISH 747 DOWN
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  A British jumbo jet with 221 passengers and 19 crew members on board was forced by jet fighters to land here today.

title: Cuomo Designated Queens Ombudsman Before the P. S. C
description: Mario M, Cuomo, the Queen: lawyer who played an impor tant role in working out corn promises on the Forest Hill and Corona housing controver ties, was named yesterday a nonsalaried ombudsman, repre senting the people of Queens dealing with the Public Service Commission.

title: 18 Are Left Homeless By 2Alarm Harlem Fire
description: Eighteen people in three famlilies were left homeless last night when a smoky, twoalarm fire destroyed the first three floors of a partly occupied fivestory tenement in Harlem.

title: Opera: Tenor Successful as Conductor
description: Singers who become successful conductors must be almost as rare as conductors who become successful singers. The two callings, while presupposing certain similarities in temperament, require such different levels of musical training that the appearance of a tenor in the pit conducting the New York City Opera's La Traviata on Sunday afternoon raised eyebrows to the scalp level.

title: Secretariat Scores
description: Secretariat set another Belmont Park record yesterday in winning the $113,600 Man o'War Stakes' by five lengths in 2:25 4/5. Details, Page 55.

title: Interest and Ideology
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa The feeling is strong here among informed people in politics, business, the universities and the press that the showdown for South Africa is fast approaching. The next year or two, many think, will determine whether this unhappy land of wealth and apartheid will move toward a more decent and open society or become still more repressive and fascistic society that is likely to end in violence.

title: 160 Hawaii Prison Inmates Continue Strike for 3d Day
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 8 (UPI)Convicts at the Hawaii State Prison refused to eat or return to their cells today for the third consecutive day, while guards searched for weapons and drugs.

title: E.P.A. to Cut Aid to State For CleanWater Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Environmental Protection Agency plans to reverse its policy and give no preference in Federal aid to states that have contributed to local water pollutioncontrol projects.

title: Bache Rejects Merging
description: Bache & Co., Inc., the nation's secondlargest brokerage house, is exploring the possibility of becoming a financial holding company, taking on insurance and perhaps even savings and loan interests.

title: 2d Death Reported On L.I. by Sniffing OF Aerosol Vapors
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 8 The police reported today the apparent death of a second young person in Nassau County as a result of having sniffed an aerosol antisticking cooking substance to obtain a euphoric feeling.

title: Woman's Body Found in Park
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 8 (UPI)The nude body of an unidentifed young woman was found yesterday in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The woman was described as about age 20, 5 feet 5 inches tall, about 110 pounds, with blonde hair and gray eyes. Edward J. Krupinsky, who is in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office here, said that the agency was seeking the identity of the woman because and time of death was national park. He said that the cause andd time of death was not known. blonde hair and gray eyes. Edward J. Krupinsky, who is in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office here, said that the agency was seeking the identity of the woman because and time of death was national park. He said that the cause andd time of death was not known.

title: Demory is Undaunted on Jet Prospects
description: National Football League Properties, a subsidiary of the N.F.L., produces a variety of footballrelated items, such as scarves, mufflers, drinking glasses and binoculars. Maybe it could expand into a new area and produce an offense for the Jets.

title: FRANKLIN SPIER
description: Franklin Spier, founder in 1929 of the New York advertising agency bearing his name, who had been a promotion consultant to book publishers, died Saturday in Columbia Memorial Hospital, Hudson, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Kinderhook, N.Y.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Emeric Partos, Bergdorf Goodman's resident fur genius (he's dreamed up such fantasies as flowerpatterned mink), seems to have taken a turn for the practical.

title: It's Wine Time Upstate in Search for Best
description: GENEVA, N.Y.As the bright days and cool nights of fall in the Finger Lakes region ripen the grapes to perfection, Joe Bertino is stemming, crushing, pressing and fermenting them into 500 gallons of experimental wines, any one of which could someday improve the flavor of New York State winesand possibly the future of the $150million industry.

title: NeimanMarcus Plans Unit On Chicago's Michigan Blvd.
description: The NeimanMarcus Company, the Dallasbased fashion specialty store chain, is expected to announce its first inthecity store in Chicago on tomorrow. The large new unit will be situated on Michigan Boulevard, in the heart of the commercial district and only a few blocks from branches of Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor.

title: Soviet Economists Split On Flexibility for Plans
description: MOSCOW  The increasing contribution of foreign trade in the planned Soviet economy has raised the question among the nation's economists as to whether the present system of fiveyear plans is still the most effective way of charting the Soviet Union's longterm course.

title: Nicklaus Gives Prize To Charity
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Oct. 8 Jack Nicklaus won the OhioKings Island golf tournament today, then dramatically turned back the $25,000 check for first prize. He asked that $5,000 go to the Boy Scouts of America and the balance to establish a scholarship at Ohio State University to be named for his late father, Charles Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, who introduced Jack to golf as a youngster.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
Yugoslays Manage to Maintain Close Ties With East and West
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union planted a tree of friendship in a Belgrade park the week before last. Only time will tell whether the tree will take root or will wither, as have some planted there by foreign leaders.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS 2FRONT DRIVE BACK TO OLD CEASEFIRE LINES; EGYPTIANS CLAIM GAIN IN SINAI
description: TEL AVIV, Tuesday, Oct. 9 Reinforced Israeli units have opened major counterattacks on two broad fronts, throwing the Syrian and Egyptian. Armies back to the ceasefire lines in heavy fighting, a military spokesman said last night.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: TEACHER STRIKE ENDS IN HARRISON
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8The fiveweekold strike of teachers in Harrison ended today. Classes will return to normal tomorrow.

title: Kissinger Cites Risk in Pushing Soviet Too Hard on Emigration
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Sectetary of State Kissinger warned tonight that there were limits to how far the United States could press Soviet leaders for changes in their system without running the risk of reviving the cold war and increasing international tensions.

title: Stage: Twelfth Night
description: Of course there are patterns to the theater. A work such as Shakespeare's Twelfth Night is capable of innumerable interpretations.

title: Copper Up and Oil Stocks Off in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 8  The only commodity to show a marked increase in buying by commodity dealers here today was copper. With commodity markets in the United States closed because of the Columbus Day holiday, the London market was the major one open on the first trading day following the renewal of fighting in the Middle East.

title: An Unfettered Press
description: The freedom of the press is one of the proudest and most zealously guarded aspects of our national heritage. These are the opening words of a proclamation by President Nixon in honor of National Newspaper Week. The sentiments expressed in the Presidential message are consistent with the nation's historical traditions. They are regrettably less consistent with the practice of Mr. Nixon's own Administration.

title: Boy in Buggy Killed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) Samuel Austin, 8 years old, was killed when a car rammed the horsedrawn buggy in which he was taking a ride yesterday. His brother, Sean, 2, was injured.

title: DR. OTTO BRENDEL, ART HISTORIAN, 71
description: Dr. Otto J. Brendel, professor emeritus of art history and archeology at Columbia University and a leading, classical scholar, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 315 Riverside Drive. He would have been 72 years old tomorrow.

title: Marchi Is Planning To Talk to Agnew On Campaign Help
description: State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican mayoral candidate, plans to meet today with Vic President Agnew here to discuss possible aid to his campaign, aides to Mr. Marchi said last night.

title: CANADIAN AIRLINE SETS CHINA ROUTE
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaPassenger service between Vancouver and Shanghai, establishing the first direct commercial service from the Western hemisphere to China, is scheduled to begin before the end of the year by CP Air.

title: Arabs of Gaza Fearful, But Area Remains Calm

Booch, a professor at Western College in Oxford, Ohio, bought. 760 New York State Lottery tickets yesterday in hopes of winning part of the $5million the students say they need to pay off the college debt, and prevent a merger with nearby Miami University. The students raised the $380 for the tickets.

title: Screen: 'Land of Silence':The Program
description: Werner Herzog's "Land des Schweigens und der Dunkelheit" ("Land of Silence and Darkness"), which was shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center last night (and will be repeated tomorrow night), is described in the festival's program as "a film that speaks up for life, warmly and movingly."Only someone who has not seen any other Herzog films ("Even Dwarfs Started Small," "Fata Morgana") could accept this bland appraisal without flinching. Herzog speaking up for life, warmly and movingly? He may speak up for life, but it's through an acknowledgment of outrages, often lovingly inventoried. Herzog is not a simple film maker. The emotions evoked by his films arc never easily categorized, nor, I think, are they meant to be."Land of Silence and Darkness" is no exception. It seems, at its beginning, a rather conventional documentary about the efforts of a middle-aged German woman named Fini Straubinger, who went blind at 15 and deaf at 18, to help other blind-deaf people. Fini travels around Germany doing good with alarming self assurance.Her cheery efforts are most easily appreciated by people who've gone deaf and blind later in life, after they've had the use of those two senses. Later on we see the efforts fail totally with people who've been born blind and deaf, since theirs is a world incomprehensible to even a do-gooder with Fini's energy and optimism. This is the note that concludes the film, which is not exactly the philosophy of "The Sound of Music."Herzog is fascinated by grotesques, which he makes us see as object lessons in a perverse universe. A key to the irony with which Herzog invests this so-called warm and moving subject is contained in the film's title. As Fini tells us in the course of the movie, the deaf are not even allowed the comfort of silence: the head is full of strange buzzing and cracking sounds. The eyes, though incapable of seeing, are continually assaulted by lights, shadows and colors. Total darkness is a sighted person's poetic conceit.Herzog, one of the most talented of the new young German film directors, will one day make a movie that's as interesting to sit through as to argue about later. "Land of Silence and Darkness" is not it.

title: Chabrol's Juste Avant La Nuit Screened at Festival
description: JUSTE AVANT LA NUIT (Just Before Nightfall), directed by Claude Chabrot; screenplay (French with English subtitles) by Mr. Chabrol; based on the novel, The Thin Line, by Edward Ativah; produced by Andre Genoves; director of photography, Jean Rabier; editor, Jacques Gaillard; music, Pierre Jansen; a FrenchItalian coproduction by Les Films La Beetle, Columbia Pictures and Cinegai, distributed by Columbia Pictures. Running time: 107 minutes. At the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: 3 PROGRAMS HERE DENIED STATE AID
description: Three Lower East Side settlement houses declared yesterday that the state had refused to reimburse them for $640,330, or nearly half of the $1,373,504 they had spent tinder matching contracts for mentalhealth services in their area for the year ended last June 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Kissinger's Way: Let's Give It a Chance

title: METS WIN, 9 TO 2, AS FIGHT ERUPTS; LEAD PLAYOFF, 21
description: Fists, cups, beer cans, assorted debris and even whisky bottles filled the clamorous afternoon air at Shea Stadium yesterday as the Mets and their public fought the Cincinnati Reds in one of baseball's memorably riotous games.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Will 1976 Be Like '68 or '72?
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic party's 1968 convention in Chicago was bossridden and unrepresentative. But the 1972 convention in Miami Beach was quotaridden and therefore just as unrepresentative. So went the two extreme views in a controversy for which a party drafting committee has proposed a compromise.

title: U.S AND SOVIET DISCUSS MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union had indicated that it shared the American desire to limit the conflict in the Middle East.

title: The Need for NoMen
description: ANCHORAGE, AlaskaWhen President Nixon announced his first Cabinet on Dec. 11, 1968, he told the nation on television, I don't want a Cabinet of yesmen.

title: Mrs. Barbara Achenbach Wed To Philip A. Uzielli in Bermuda
description: Mrs. Barbara Borkland Achenbach and Philip A. Uzielli, both of Nevi York, were married yesterday afternoon in Hamilton, Bermuda. The ceremony was performed by Mrs. Valerie. Scott of the Registrar General's office.

title: BYRNE BACKS IN COLLEGE LOANS
description: UNION, Oct. 8Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, will propose soon, in a major statement on education policy, that state loans for college education be made available to dieincome families. The saylings and earnings of such families now exclude their sons and daughters from such financial assistance.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FORT LEE, Oct. 8  Senior tennis players, a hardfighting, nononsense group, are getting a little upset over Cal MacCracken, who won the New Jersey, title in the 45yearsandover division for the seventh time the other day. They are hoping that in the future he will pay more attention to his inventions than his court tactics.

title: CARBERY O'SHEA, 69, TAX LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: Carbery O'Shea, a lawyer and tax specialist, died Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 69 years old and also lived in Saltaire, Fire Island, L.I.

title: The Second Gun
description: Some seeds of doubt that Sirhan B. Sirhan was the sole assassin of Robert F. Kennedy that terrible day in 1968 have been developed into an arbor of testimony, allegations and accusations in The Seconfl Gun, which opened on Sunday at the TransLux East. And, if Theodore Charach and Gerard Alcan, producers of this featurelength compilation of color and blackandwhite interviews, reenactments, newsreels and photographs, are not conclusive in their contentions, their insistent presentation those doubts.

title: First Antiques Show of Season. Opens at Coliseum
description: The first antiques show of the fall season opened yesterday at the Coliseum for a run through Sunday. Its wares are old and new and inbetween. The fair is innovating with a special section of crafts by presentday artists.

title: U.S. Urges in U.N. That Mideast Lines Of '67 Be Restored
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8The United States asked the Security Council tonight to bring an end to hostilities in the Middle East and to restore the ceasefire line that existed before the new war.

title: American Y.C. Tops Canadians In Sailing Series
description: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 8The host American Yacht Club won its 19th annual international team match from the Royal Canadian Y.C. of Toronto; 3 races to 1, today. One other race was declared a draw in the threeoffive series sailed on Long Island Sound in Etchells22 Class sloops.

title: 150 Former Employes Of Regina, Inc., Sought
description: The State and Federal Labor Departments are trying to locate 150 former employes of Regina Footwear, Inc., of 810 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, who lost their jobs 19 months agothat is, since 1971.

title: DANISH DANCERS IN FLINDT TRIO
description: Least  common  denominator modern dance is engulfing the world. It does not have the characteristic crochets of any particular style such as Gratam's compressed middle or Humphrey's canted balances, but opts for a slinky torso and occasional expressionistic spasms interspersed with the stray double tour or entrechat six. Flemming Flindt's Trio, seen on A, Night to Remember Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, added another undistinguished piece to this groviing international canon.

title: Chinese Engaging in Importing Spree
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 8China has engaged in a major overseas buying campaign this year, with whole plants high on its shopping list and deferred payments a growing feature of its purchase arrangements.

title: New CrossSection XRays Insure High Precision
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Scientists here have developed a computer and Xray system capable of making quick, accurate crosssectional profiles of any part of the human body.

title: Name Cape Canaveral Is Restored by Board
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)  The Board of Geographic Names restored today the name Cape Canaveral to the Florida landmark that was changed to Cape Kennedy after the President's assassination in 1963.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Police Burn Marijuana
description: SMITHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 9 (UPI)A crowd of 200 persons gathered here today to watch the police set fire to an estimated $1million worth of marijuana they found last week.

title: Chrysler and U.A.W. Avert Walkouts in Detroit and Ohio
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9 (UPI)The United Auto Workers and the Chrysler Corporation reached agreement today at two more production plants, averting strikes hours before scheduled walkouts.

title: LE GRAN DEAL SET BY LUCKY STORES
description: Lucky Stores, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Le Gran Corporation, operator of jewelry departments in 45 of Lucky's membership department stores and retail jewelry outlets in seven other locations. Under the agreement, eighttenths of a share of Lucky Stores would be exchanged for, each Le Grant hare. The transaction is valued at over $12million. The agreement is subject to the approval of Le Gran's directors and shareholders and Lucky Stores' directors. Lucky Stores operates retail discount supermarkets, discount centers's membership department stores, drug stores and women's apparel stores.

title: JERSEY BOND SALE IS PUT OFF AGAIN
description: The underwriters for a $280million bond issue designed to Finance a race track and a new stadium for the New York Football Giants in the Hackensack Meadows yesterday put off the purchase of the securities. The postponement was the second in six months.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Selection of a jury in the murder trial of Joanne Deborah Chesimard and Clark Edward Squire, who are accused of having killed one of their companions and New Jersey state trooper on the New Jersey Turnpike on May 2, began yesterday in the Middlesex County Courthouse in New Brunswick.

title: HIGH COURT BARS TROOPER'S APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)The United States Supierne Court let stand today a courtmartial finding against a New Jersey state trooper who charged he had been made scapegoat because the murder of two college girls on Memorial Day weekend in 1969 went unsolved.

title: Request to Review Testimony on Deal In Grains Is Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Senate permanent subcommittee on investigations released today a letter asking a Justice Department review of testimony on Russian grain purchases from the United States, but transmission of the request was held up pending a closed meeting with minority members of the panel.

title: U.S. Aides See Eventual Israeli Victory
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9United States military officials said today that they believed that Israel would eventually defeat the Egyptian and Syrian forces, but only after tough, costly and perhaps prolonged fighting.

title: SAMUEL LAWNER
description: MT. KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 9 Samuel Lawner, who retired in 1958 as manager of Western Union's automatic telegraphic communications among cotton trading centers of the world, died yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital. His age was 85 and he lived here.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX FINISH DAY MIXED
description: Prices on the America Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday after a late selloff wiped out some of the earlier gains. Prices in the overthecounter market closed lower.

title: Klein Calls an Obsession With Watergate a Hazard
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 (UPI) Herbert G. Klein, former White House communciations director, said today that Watergate had violated American tradition and law but that overobsession with the scandal cart be a greater danger to the nation than the evils we seek to eradiacte.

title: Urban Planners' Seminar Puts Emphasis on Housing
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 9 What Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson called one of those yeasty periods when ideas are afloat wound up this afternoon when R. Buckminster Fuller concluded a seminar on urban affairs at the Lyndon B. Johnson Library with a declaration that the right approach should, be on the basis of how to make life a success.

title: Booker T. Gaither, 60, Dies; Model Cities Coordinator
description: Booker T. Gaither, coordinafor for the Model Cities program at the City Housing and Development Administration, died of cancer Sunday in Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 289 Convent Avenue.

title: Police Installing Alarms and Cameras in Stores
description: A subsidized system of surveillance cameras and holdup alarms for 3,600 stores on major shopping thoroughfares is being et up by the Police Department to protect the city's shopkeepers from robbery.

title: Byrne Decries State's Lack Of Guidelines on Zoning
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Oct. 9Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate, for Governor, today criticized the lack of stateplanning guidelines that enables judges and the courts to legislate local zoning ordinances.

title: Papers to Reduce Pages
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 9 (UPI) The VirginianPilot and LedgerStar said today that they would cut their Monday editions to eight pages, with no advertising, because of the newsprint shortage.

title: RESEARCH CURBS PROPOSED BY H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)The control Government proposed today new, broadened regulations to control medical experimentation on humans in research projects receiving Federal funds.

title: Bullet Taken From Heart
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)William Armstrong, shot in the heart during a holdup, was reported in stable condition today but on the danger list at University Hospital after the bullet was removed. He was customer in a grocery store Sunday night when he was shot by a holdup man.

title: HIGH COURT GETS C.B.S.CABLE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court today agreed to hand down a decision on a nineyear copyright battle between the cable television industry and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: BOND PRICES FIRM AFTER EARLY DROP
description: Corporate bond prices eased in early trading yesterday but recovered midway through the day to close firm in generally quiet activity.

title: Conspiracy Charge Denied
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct, 9 (UN) Ettore Zappi, 69 years old, pleaded not guilty today to conspiring to distribute obscene material and was ordered to stand trial Nov. 14. The New Yorker was indicted with eight other men last July by the Los Angeles County Grand Jury that heard testimony from a disgruntled former employe of the alleged pornography operation.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: RATTENNI, IN PRISON, GIVEN A 2D TERM
description: Nicholas A. Rattenni, a reputed Mafia leader in Westchester County who has been in prison since last April on threeyear sentence in a bribery case, was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to five years and fined $10.000 for conspiracy to fix a jury in another case.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Other News Of the War In Mideast
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 9Turkey has taken a neutral position on the Middle East war despite requests from the Arabs for support.

title: EPISCOPAL CANON ON DIVORCE EASED
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9Threats of excommunication and long waiting periods for divorced persons seeking remarriage were deleted today from the Canons of the Episcopal Church.

title: Open Burning Banned
description: ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP)Henry L. Diamond, Commissioner of the State Environmental Conservation Department, today announced the banning of open burning in the New York City metropolitan area, because of air stagnation. The ban, effective this afternoon, applies to all five boroughs, and Westchester, Rockland, Suffolk, Putnam, Orange, Dutchess and Ulster Counties.

title: Philharmonic Talks Resume But No Progress Is Made
description: Negotiations resumed yesterday after a weekend recess in an effort to resolve the twoweekold strike by Local 802 of the. American Federation of Musicians against the New York Philharmonic.

title: Fighting Seen Bolstering Jerusalem's HardLiners
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 9Informed sources said today that advance warning of the actual Arab at tack that began Saturday came too late to permit Israel to undertake a preemptive ground attack. This, the sources added, may have repuercussions in Is raeli political life. The latest fighting is also expected to strengthen the hands of hardline Israelis who oppose returning any substantial part of the Arab territories seized in the sixday war of 1967.

title: SLOAN FUND TO SPUR MINORITY ENGINEERS
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday a program designed to increase minority enrollment in engineering education.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RERUN D. W. Griffith's Birth of a Nation opened in New York at the Liberty Theater in March, 1915, with an unusually high, $2, top ticket price. The threehour film aroused indignation because of its heroic presentation of Ku Klux Klantype organizations and its portrayal of black people.

title: Senate, 828, Votes Tight U.S. Control Over Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Senate passed, tonight a major environmentalenergy bill establishing Federal standards for the strip mining of coal.

title: Redskins Have Long Way to Go
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9A 2 A.M. breakfast party at Zeibert's, the sports restaurant, after the game featured such diverse types as Eugene McCarthy and Mrs. Vince Lombardi and everyone was gahgah over the Redskins, who somehow had just beaten the Dallas Cowboys, 147, in a memorable football game. When George Allen, the coach, came in, they stood up and cheered him. Allen, using we for I as is his custom, responded with one of his gushing quotes: I don't think we've ever had a team that showed more character than tonight. We're so proud of the Redskins and what a game for the nation to see!

title: 4th Labor Leader Assassinated In Argentina's Factional Strife
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9 (AP)A labor leader was shot to death today in the resort city of Mar del Plata. It was the fourth assassination since the return to power of Juan D. Pern.

title: Arctic Oil and Gas Search Marks Tundra
description: INUVIK, Northwest Territories  Looking down from an airplane over the vast frozen expanses of Canada's Northwest Territories, a traveler's eye is caught repeatedly by a multitude of straight lines, in countless geometrical patterns, engraved in the mossy tundra below.

title: GOVERNOR, ON L.I., BACKS BOND ISSUE
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 9  Citing current shortages in food and in energy and anticipating a future decline in oil supply because of the war in the Middle East, Governor Rockefeller today urged passage of the state's $3.5billion bond issue to cope with growing transportation problems.

title: Continental Cuts Prime Rate
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP)A mediumsized Cleveland bank today joined a few other banks around the nation in lowering its prime lending rate on corporate loans. The Continental Bank of Cleveland said it was cutting its prime from 10 per cent to 9 per cent to encourage more business borrowing.

title: Chinese Foreign Minister Lays Aggression to Israel
description: PEKING, Oct. 9Chi Pengfei, the Chinese Foreign Minister, at a meeting today with the Syrian and Egyptian Ambassador and the Peking representative of the Palestine Liberation Organizations, condemned what he termed Israel's aggression.

title: Apparel Inquiry Is Transferred to City
description: The Justice Department's pricefixing investigation in the apparel industry has been shifted from Philadelphia to New York City, and informed sources believe that a new and possibly stiffer phase in the inquiry will begin shortly.

title: The Coldest War of All
description: PEKING  The first SinoRussian negotiation occurred in the seventeenth century at Nerchinsk. The Russians were represented by a Pole and the Chinese by two Jesuits. The envoys spoke Latin. Today, three centuries later, the two enormous neighbors have yet to discover a common language or policy.

title: Rose Was Helping Jets While Deflating Mets
description: Pete Rose had various reasons for wanting to win yesterday's fourth game of the National League playoffs. One seemed to come out of left field.

title: Indians Order Three 737's
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 9 (Reuters) Indian Airlines has placed orders with Boeing Aircraft Company in the United States for three more Boeing 737's to be delivered after next October.

title: People in Sports: Wilt Uses Ax
description: Wilt Chamberlain, new coach of the American Basketball Association's San Diego Conquistadors, made his first difficult decision this week by cutting three players David Brent, Ernie.Kusnyer and Chris McMurray  and said yesterday he felt bad about it.

title: Charleston Does Battle to Preserve Its Architectural and Cultural Past
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Oct. 6No city in the United States has done more to preserve and protect its rich architectural and cultural past than this threecenturiesold Southern port where a shot fired across the harbor at Fart Sumter started the Civil War. Aristocratic Charleston, quintessential stronghold of the American blueblood, was the first major municipality in the country to take an unyielding stand against the bulldozer, declaring flatly back in the nineteentwenties that new was not necessarily nice, bigger was not automatically better.

title: RICHARD MULLIGAN OF SURGICAL FIRM
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9Richard V. Mulligan, who retired in 1971 as a director and corporate vice president of Johnson & Johnson, surgical manufacturers here, and as Democratic County Chairman, died today at his home, 22 Dewey Drive. He was 67 years old and also lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: A's Beat Orioles, 21, on Homer in 11th
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 9 A longrange artillery shot produced by one of their sharpest smallcaliber weaponsa leadoff home run by Bert Campaneris in the 11th inninggave the Oakland A's a 21 victory over Baltimore today and a 21 lead in the threeoffivegame series for the American League championship.

title: A Suit Against The Times And a Subsidiary Is Settled
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 9  A settlement was announced today of a $2million suit brought by ComCorp, the Clevelandbased publisher of the Polk Shopper's Shopping News of Lakeland, Fla., against The New York Times and a subsidiary, The Lakeland Ledger.

title: STOCKS RETREAT ON PROFIT TAKING
description: The stock market encountered some mild profit taking yesterday after its spectacular runup since midSeptember. Volume remained heavy, with 19.44 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Campaneris Hit the Pitch He Waited forSlider
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 9 Getting the right pitch is supposed to be the basis of successful hitting, and Dagoberto Campaneris, the 31yearold, 155pound Cuban completing his 10th major league season, saw the right one in the 11th ining today.

title: WHEAT FUTURES CLIMB SHARPLY
description: War in the Middle East pushed corn, soybean and wheat prices sharply higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: 2 St. Croix Policemen Wounded In Newest Outbreak of Violence
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V. I., Oct. 9  Two policemen were wounded in a shotgun attack here early today as violence continued to plague this sunny resort island in the Caribbean.

title: Ukraine Sale Hints A Record Harvest Of Grain in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9The Soviet Union, eager to rebound from the disastrous grain harvest of last year, reported today a record grain sale to the Government by Ukrainian farmers, though abnormally cold weather continued to plague harvesting in Kazakhstan and western Siberia.

title: Red Smith
description: Pete Rose walked up to the plate, and for the first time since last Saturday he saw a righthander on the mound. A switchhitter, he took his stance on the firstbase side of the plate, bent almost double in a bellyache crouch with his jutting chin a yard or so above the ground. He had a blue golf glove on one hand, a glove of blue and soiled white on the other, and as he gripped the bat you could see sawdust oozing out between the fingers. He took a ball, fouled off a pitch, took another ball, missed a strike, hit another foul, Harry Sports Parker'S sixth pitch was up around the letters. Not the kind of pitch to throw of Rose, Parker said.

title: C. WILFRED JENKS, HEAD OF I.L.O., DIES
description: GENEVA, Oct. 9C. Wilfred Jenks, director general of the International Labor Organization, died today in Rome at the age of 64.

title: Use of Escrowed Funds By Pennsy Trustees Hit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 Attorneys for the trustee of the New Haven Railroad joined here today with counsel for institutional bond holders of the Penn Central Railroad to advise the Federal District Court in charge of the huge bankruptcy action that they would contest any further borrowing or use of escrowed funds by the Penn Central trustees to meet the railroad's operating expenses.

title: Education Panel Is Urged To Alter Decentralization
description: Changes in the city school decentralization law, which one speaker described as a Pandora's box of ambiguities, were urged yesterday at a hearing held by the Assembly's Education Committee.

title: Rose Is Happy Star Under Signs of the Met Fans
description: Some of the signs were vulgar, some were clever. All were critical mid expressed exactly the way most of the 50,786 fans fet about Pete Rose.

title: Resolution Backs Israel
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate passed resolution today supporting Israel and urging peace in the Middle East. The resolution was approved on a voice vote, withattack.

title: PRICE INCREASES SET BY SOHIO AND EXXON
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday that it had raised the price of gasoline at companyowned stations by one cent a gallon, and the wholesale price to dealers by 1.2 cents a gallon.

title: 800 Beach Channel Students to Go Down to the Sea in Classrooms
description: On a 15acre tract that was once part of Jamaica Bay, 800 students are starting a highschool career that will never lose sight, literally or intellectually, of the world of salt water.

title: Dance: Season's First Choreo Concert
description: At the New School, last night Choreographers Theater presented the first of its seventh season of ChoreoConcerts with premieres by Manuel Alum, Beverly Brown, Phyllis Lamhut and Gus Solomons Jr.

title: WAR OF ATTRITION
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Oct. 10A ranking spokesman for Israel's high command said last night that Israel had abandoned most of the BarLev Line along the Suez Canal but that the Israelis had nearly succeeded in clearing Syrian forces from the Golan heights.

title: SovietJapanese Talks Said to Meet Snag
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan reportedly ran into snags today in protracted talks on Japanese demands for the return, of four Pacific islands, as part of arrangements for a peace treaty for ending World War II.

title: The First Step of a Long Journey
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Ten years ago on Oct. 10, 1963the first important international agreement of the nuclear age went into effect, a treaty pledging the United States, the Soviet Union and more than ninety other countries to refrain from conducting nuclear tests in the atmosphere, in outer space or under water.

title: Seaver: Glad I'm Pitching
description: To the quiet of the Mets' clubhouse after their 21 loss yesterday, there were two television cameras but no cameramen. There were three wooden TV platforms, but nobody was on them. And the champagne, which had been iced for the occasion, had been returned to the Diamond Club upstairs.

title: Here Comes the NewOld Leo Fuchs
description: During the first two decades of this century, when Yiddish theater in New York was a great antidote to sweatshops, one of the battle cries of Second Avenue actors was: Cut my wages, but don't cut my part.

title: Japan's Music and Dance
description: TOKYO  One evening there was a performance of the world's oldest dance form, with men in dragon masks and elaborate ceremonial costumes moving through the slow and stately symbolism of Gagaku. The very next night came the turnofthecentury romanticism of the PtipaTchaikovsky Sleeping Beauty, with dancers in tutus and cavaliers in tights soaring over the stage in jets and complicated lifts.

title: Instructor Knows Young People Can Teach Each Other
description: The seven children were wriggling with expectation as the slender, quickmoving man flashed a card in front of one of the boys. The boy cried B, and was handed the B card. The man turned next to a girl. When she cried F, she got the F card.

title: Judge, Conceding Errors, To Review I.B.M. penalty
description: Federal Judge A. Sherman Christensen, who on Sept 17 found the International Business Machines Corporation in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act, announced yesterday that he had made substantial errors in computing the $352.5million in damages he had awarded the plaintiff in the case, the Telex Corporation.

title: Reports of Leads in Murder Fail To Reduce Anxiety in Flushing
description: Residents Residents of Crocheron Avenuea treelined quiet block of Seasoned onefamily homes and apartment houses in Flushing, Queensfound policemen patrolling their street yesterday morning.

title: Man Slain By a Knifer On the IND
description: An elderly man was stabbed to death on a subway car yesterday afternoon on an A train on the IND subway line in downtown Manhattan after he had engaged in a long argument with another passenger.

title: Lakers Triumph On 2dHalf Rally
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (UPI)Jerry West and Gail Goodrich sparked the Los Angeles takers to a 70point second half tonight and a 11797 victory over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Records: 2 Guitarists
description: Bucky Pizzarelli, the guitarist who can be heard these fall evenings at the Soerabaja, does not record frequently, but when he does his disks are of more than routine interest. He is on two current records that are absorbing displays of his virtuosity, his modesty and the rang of his interests.

title: Gen. Bonner Fellers Dies at 77; Planning Chief for MacArthur
description: Brig, Gen. Bonner, F. Fellers, an intelligence and planning specialist in World War II died of heart failure Sunday in Washington. He was 77 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Weinberger Drops Suggestion to End Medical Deductions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he had scrapped a suggestion for elimination of Federal income tax deductions for medical expenses as part of the Administration's national health insurance proposal.

title: City Bills Requiring Income Disclosure Voided by Counsel
description: Two bills that would, require top officeholders here and City Councilmen to disclose annually all outside income were ruled unconstitutional yesterday by the Corporation Counsel's office.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SECRET LIFE OF OUR TIMES: New Fiction From Esquire. Edited by Gordon Lish. Introduction by Tom Wolfe. 641 pages. Doubleday. $12.95.

title: Freeing by Judge Of 3 in Fatal Blaze Angers Detectives
description: An unusual decision by a Family Court judge to free three youths, charged with setting a fire that killed six persons, on the condition that the youths get out of town has angered the detectives who believed they had solved a difficult case and wanted to see the three punished.

title: Arbiter Backs Transfers From New Brunswick High
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9A hearing examiner for the State Department of Education recommended tonight that predominantly white North Brunswick and Milltown take their highschool sophomores out of overcrowded New Brunswick High school and put them in the new North Brunswick High School.

title: One More Trip to Post Possible for Secretariat
description: Were you in the stands in Chicago in 1932 when Babe Ruth pointed to the centerfield seats in the World Series against the Cubs and clouted a home run? Or were you a witness to the amazing upset registered by the New York Jets against the Baltimore Colts in the pro football Super Bowl game of 1969?

title: Senate, 828, Votes Tight U.S. Control Over Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Senate passed tonight a major environmentalenergy bill establishing Federal standards for the strip mining of coal.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There's no letup in sight. The rain of sweaters shows signs of continuing through next spring and summer. The latest deluge is from the Italian knitwear industry, which recently sent 80 representatives of MATT (for made in Italy) to New York to show their collections to buyers.

title: Step Ahead in Greece
description: For the first time in six and a half years, Greece has a Cabinet free of military men and a capable civilian Premier who is respected even by many of his lifelong political opponents. Even modest steps away from the oneman rule of President George Papadopoulos are welcome; they will take on substantial significance if they lead, as Premier Spyros Markezinis has promised, to the fairest election in Greek history next spring and the restoration of a pluralistic Parliament of even limited powers.

title: U.S. RATES PROPOSAL OPPOSED BY BANKERS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9  The American Bankers Association today opposed the Administra tion's proposal to phase out interstate ceilings on savings deposits in five and a half years.

title: Subway Crime Rises 26% And Patterns Are Changing
description: Crimes reported in the subway system rose by 26.4 per cent during the first eight months of this year compared with the same period last year, despite a citywide drop of 5.8 per cent in reported crimes.

title: Judge, Conceding Errors, To Review I.B.M Penalty
description: Federal Judge A. Sherman Christensen, who on Sept 17 found the International Business Machines Corporation in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act, announced yesterday that he had made substantial errors in computing the $352.5million in damages he had awarded the plaintiff in the case, the Telex Corporation.

title: High Court Bars White House Plea for Fast Impoundment Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Supreme Court rejected without comment today the Nixon Administration's request for an expedited ruling on the constitutionality of President Nixon's impoundment of funds appror priated by Congress.

title: Reds Top Metsin 12th, 21, Force Playoff to 5th Carne
description: Nobody threw any punches, but Pete Rose unloaded a haymaker home run in the 12th inning yesterday that gave the Cincinnati Reds a 2.1 victory over the New York Mets and put the National League penWant up for grabs this afternoon.

title: Man Slain By a Knifer On the IND
description: An elderly man was stabbed to death on a subway car yesterday afternoon on an A train on the IND subway line in downtown Manhattan after he had engaged in a long argument with another passenger.

title: Safety Commission Monitor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Consumer Product Safety Commission endorsed today the creation of a separate agency to monitor the actions of the commission and other Government agencies dealing with consumer matters.

title: TAKEOVER IS SET OF CERRO IN PERU
description: LIMA, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Peruvian holdings of the Cerro Corporation will be nationalized imminently, President Nan Velasco Alvarado announced tonight.

title: Rangers and Islanders open Tonight
Chinese Find Our Library Is as Overbooked as Theirs
description: A delegation of librarians from the People's Republic of China was given a grand tour of the New York Public Library yesterday and observe afterward that the National Library in Peking had the same primary problem as the library here: not enough room for the books.

title: DEPUTY TO ANKER NAMED BY BOARD
description: A 30yearold specialist in biophysics and urban planning was chosen yesterday as the new deputy chancellor of the city's school system, sources close to the Board of Education disclosed last night.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Rebozo Reportedly Tells Watergate Aide He Got $100,000 Hughes Gift for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Charles G. Rebozo, a close friend of President Nixon's, has told investigators of the Senate Watergate committee and the Internal Revenue Service that he accepted $100,000 in cash from agents of Howard R. Hughes in 1969 and 1970, according to Government officials.

title: Panther in Connecticut Jail Will Be Released, on Bail
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. Lonnie McLucas, one of the Black Panthers whose trial brought thousands of demonstrators to New Haven in 1970, will be released from prison tomorrow on bail.

title: 800 Beach Channel Students to Go Down to the Sea in Classrooms
description: On a 15acre tract that was once part of Jamaica Bay, 800 students are starting a highschool career that will never lose sight, literally or intellectually, of the world of salt water.

title: Man, 77., Is Said to Shoot 2, From Apartment in Harlem
description: A 77yearold man allegedly shot two passersby from the window of his Harlem apartment yesterday afternoon with a highpowered rifle and then insisted to arresting police officers that he wanted to talk to Mayor Lindsay.

title: Golan Heights Are Called Syrian Tank Graveyard
description: SAFAD, Israel, Oct. 9The Golan heights were described by Israeli commanders today as a vast graveyard of Syrian tanks and artillery pieces after the fourth and heaviest day of fighting on the northern front.

title: Smokers Who Seek Help to Quit Have Come a Long Way, Maybe
description: The Monday night Smoke Watchers group welcomes its new member, a teacher of interior design.

title: Chilean Coup Defended Before the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9Foreign Minister Ismael Huerta of Chile went before a halffilled General Assembly today to charge that the military junta that seized power in his country on Sept. 11 was the victim of a most false, most malevolent, most vicious and very wellorchestrated campaign.

title: A GEOTEK RECEIVER IS NAMED BY COURT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9United States District Judge William T. Sweigert today named Stuart M. Kaplan, a San Francisco attorney specializing in bankruptcy cases, as temporary receiver for the Geotek group of companies.

title: POLICE INSTALLING ALARMS IN STORES
description: A subsidized system of surveillance cameras and holdup alarms for 3,600 stores on major shopping thoroughfares is being set up by the Police Department to protect the city's shopkeepers from robbery.

title: Copters With Israeli Wounded Land at Hospital All Day Long
description: SAFAD, Israel, Oct. 9The human cost of Israeli military gains in the eastern Golan heights could be counted up today at a Government hospital in the ancient town of Safad, high in the Galilean hills.

title: Giants' Randy Johnson Quits Football
description: Randy Johnson, apparently tired of being the New York Giants' No. 2 quarterback behind Norm Snead, announced his retirement from pro football yesterday. But he left the door open for a possible return.

title: Rosewall Victor In Tokyo Tennis
description: TOKYO, Oct. 9 (AP)Ken Rosewall of Australia, Tom Gorman of Seattle and Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., advanced in the second round of the $60,000 Tokyo open tennis tournament today, but Vijay Amritraj, the 19yearold Indian, was ousted.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Selection of a jury in the murder trial of Joanne Deborah Chesimard and Clark Edward Squire, who are accused of having killed one of their companions and New Jersey state trooper on the New Jersey Turnpike on May 2, began yesterday in the Middlesex County Courthouse in New Brunswick.

title: DR. KARL SAX DIES; BOTANIST WAS 81
description: MEDIA, Pa., Oct 9  Dr. Karl Sax, professor emeritus of botany at Harvard University, who was a past president of the Genetics Society and a writer on population problems, died yesterday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: RESEARCHERS CITE A NEW HORMONE
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 9 (UPI) Researchers at the University of North Carolina annouced tonight the isolation of a new growthpromoting hormone in human blood.

title: Business Briefs
description: The net outflow of deposits from savings banks in the State of New York totaled $293million in September, compared with an outflow of $311million in August, the Savings Bank Association of New York State reported yesterday. The outflow last month exceeded a net deposit outflow of $168million in September of 1969, another year when shifting of savings deposits into marketable securities (disintermediation) was notable. The net outflow in July was $473million.

title: TROY ASKS REPEAL OF NICOTINE LEVY
description: A bill to repeal the city's tarandnicotine tax  which adds 1 to 4 cents to the price of a package of cigaretteswas introduced yesterday by Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr.

title: Hurricane Forms in Atlantic
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9 (UPI)  A rapidly increasing cyclone east of Bermuda tonight spawned the fourth hurricane of the season. The hurricane posed no immediate threat to Jand and was in the Atlantic about 550 miles east of Bermuda. The National Hurricane Center said that maximum winds were 80 miles an hour and that the hurricane was moving eastward at 25 miles an hour.

title: Carnegie Education Study Bids Universities Be Bold
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education, which has been Making the most extensive examination of America's colleges and universities to date, finished its task today, issuing a final list of recommendations and priorities.

title: Agnew's Office Called Possible Source of Leak
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9An internal Justice Department study indicates that one of the major sources of allegedly damaging news leaks against Vice President Agnew may have been the Vice President's own office or the White House.

title: Hillbilly Heritage
description: WHITESBURG, Ky.In driving the mountain roads of eastern Kentucky, one is immediately struck by the similarity to the Central Highlands of Vietnam. The horizon is one of endless rows of emerald ridges, those farthest away hazed blue in the eternal mountain mist. Even the gaping abandoned stripmine benches are reminiscent of defoliated convoy routes, fire bases and landing zones.

title: SOME PROGRESS SEEN IN OIL TALKS
description: VIENNA, Oct. 9Oil company representatives and ministers of oilexporting countries continued price negotiations for the second straight day today amid signs that some of their differences may be narrowing.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP)The yacht France I has been selected to represent France again in the eliminations for the right to challenge for the America's Cup in 1974, the French committee for the America's Cup announced today.

title: Boys' Parents Deny Guilt
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 9 (UPI)The parents of an 11yearold diabetic boy, who died when his insulin supply was cut off because of their belief in faith healing, pleaded not guilty today to charges of manslaughter and child abuse. The child, Wesley Parker, died Aug. 24 after his parents apparently were convinced that he had been cured by a faith healer of the Assembly of God Church.

title: Equity Financing
description: Friona Industries, Inc., said it filed an amended registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with its initial public offering of 450,000 common shares. Under the amended plan the company planned to sell 300,000 shares and selling stockholders 150,000 shares.
