The Shields Securities Corporation and Eppler, Guerin & Turner, Inc., would be joint managers of the underwriting group. The company, with headquarters in Friona, Texas, is engaged primarily in the manufacture and sale of commercial cattle feeds and feed supplements.

title: G.M. Plans Diesel Project In Detroit's Romulus Area
description: Plans for a major plant expansion in Romulus, a suburb of Detroit, were announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation: It is expected to lead to a significant increase in Diesel engine production,

title: Gains Reported in Belfast In New Talks on a Cabinet
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 9 (Reuters)Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders reported today considerable progress in a new round of talks designed to speed the formation of a cabinet, to govern Northern Ireland.

title: JEWS AND ARABS CONTRIBUTE HERE
description: A drive to recruit American volunteers to replace Israeli civilians called to battle stepped up here yesterday as New York area residents continued to demonstrate support for Israel with rallies and outpourings of money. Local spokesmen for the Arab side in the Middle East war also reported receiving pledges of aid.

title: Admiral Seeks Post
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 9 (AP) Rear Adm. Jeremiah A. Denton Jr., who was held prisoner during the Vietnam, war for seven and a half years, has asked that he, be selected the next commandant of the Armed Forces Staff College here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: An inconspicuous item in most local newspapers announced that the Supreme Court of the United States commenced its October 1973 term on Oct. 1, after a summer recess of more than three months. The announcement was coupled with the usual observations that the Court is swamped with work, setting forth the incessant statistics of a backlog of pending cases, and some periodicals noted the earlier proposal to create a superappellate court to think out the plethora of petitions for review of lowercourt decisions.

title: HIGH COURT BARS A TURNER REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  Glenn W. Turner, the FloriIda promoter, today lost his bid for a Supreme Court review of Government efforts to halt selling plans described by a lower court as a gigantic and successful fraud.

title: Court Orders Aids for SpanishSpeaking Voters
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9As a result of a suit brought by the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, voters among the 130,000 Puerto Ricans living in New Jersey will be able to cast ballots knowledgeably in November whether or not they read or speak English.

title: Judge Rules Navy Has to Discharge Ensign as Objector
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9 (AP)The Navy was ordered today in United States District Court to discharge Ens, Brucs M. Wright as a conscientious objector.

title: Not the Same as 1967
description: The use by Israeli spokesmen of the word attrition to describe the present phase of the Middle East war is considered by United States and other Western military sources as evidence that the conflict has assumed characteristics strikingly different from those, of the swift Israeli victory of 1967.

title: 8 Children in Family Killed In Blast and Fire in Home
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio (UPI) Oct. 9Eight children ranging from one to nine years of age were killed early today in an explosion and fire in a mobile home at Jerry City, a community of 500. about 10 miles south of here.

title: New Technique Repairs a Kidney Outside Body and Reimplants It
description: A team of Boston urologists has developed an experimental technique to excise a diseased kidney, repair it outside the body and then reimplant the undamaged portion the organ in the patient.

title: Universities in Exchange
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)The University of Massachusetts has signed a formal agreement with the University of Freiburg in West Germany for a partnership in exchanges of faculty and students and possibly research projects, it was announced today.

title: CostEffectiveness of Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaThe strongest internal pressures for breaking the grip of apartheid on South Africa are economic.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1973

title: RECORD SUBPOENAED ON NEW AGNEW HOME
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Federal grand jury investigating Vice President Agnew has subpoenaed the records on the Agnews' purchase of a $190,000 suburban home, the agent who handled the real estate transaction said tonight.

title: JohnsManville Constructs
description: The JohnsManville Corporation began construction yesterday of its new headquarters 17 miles southwest of Denver. The facility will provide office space for 1,600 employes and is expected to cost $43 million, It is scheduled for completion by the fal of 1976.

title: BADILLO ENDORSES FUCHSBERG IN RACE
description: Representative Herman Badillo, the Bronx Democrat, urged yesterday the election of Jacob D. Fuchsberg, his party's candidate for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, saying it would signal a new and hopeful period in the movement for judicial reform.

title: Pistons Bow, 101 to 100
Theater: Inside Politics
description: Political payoffs, chicanery, blackmail and backstabbing in high places (even in the White House)when Jay Broad's A Conflict of Interest was first presented at the Arena Stage in Washington in March of 1972, all this may have seemed somewhat remote, perhaps even a little unbelievable.

title: College for Adults
description: Spokesmen for American higher education have long been paying lip service to the idea of a broader responsibility than the teaching of 18yearold undergraduates. They have talked a great deal about their concern for older persons in search of that missed degree, or for women ready to return to the classroom after the children have been sent off to school. Rhetoric unfortunately was not often matched by practice.

title: ANNOUNCER'S WIFE DIES IN FIRE HERE
description: The wife of Frank Knight, a popular radio personality of the nineteenthirties and forties, was burned to death in a fire that swept the couple's East Side apartment last night. Mr. Knight was taken to Lenox Hill Hospital with severe burns and was in critical condition.

title: Klein Calls art Obsession With Watergate a Hazard
description: MEXICO CITY Oct. 9 (UPI) Herbert G. Klein, former White House communciations director, said today that Watergate had violated American tradition and law but that overobsession with the scandal can be a greater danger to the nation than the evils we sek to eradicate.

title: A SOVIET WALKOUT MARKS U.N.DEBATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9The Security Council sought again today to deal with the renewed war in the Middle East, but its debate was marked by angry exchanges and a Soviet walkout.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP)The yacht France I has been selected to represent France again in the eliminations for the right to challenge for the America's Cup in 1974, the French committee for the America's Cup announced today.

title: COURT LETS STAND CONVICTION OF HOFFA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court declined today to review the conviction of James R. Hoffa, former teamstern union president, on jury tampering.

title: AIR FARES RAISED 6% ON NORTH ATLANTIC
description: GENEVA, Oct. 9 (Reuters)Airlines belonging to the International Air Transport Association have reached agreement in Monaco on an average 6 per cent increase in fares on North Atlantic routes for the 10month period starting Jan. 1, association headquarters here announced today.

title: People and Business
description: Robert S. Beck, a former Whiz Kid at the Ford Motor Company, has been named president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the world's largest life. insurance concern, with assets of over $35billion.

title: City Begins Demolishing Women's Jail
description: Mayor Lindsay, with sledgehammer and crowbar, yesterday started the demolition of the Women's House of Detention in an atmosphere that had a strong campaign flavor for man who is a noncandidate.

title: Bill on Challenges to RadioTV Licenses Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  A House Commerce subcommittee approved legislation today that would permit broadcasters' licenses to be challenged by persons who propose to offer superior service.

title: Nixon Asks Heat Saving
description: President Nixon urged all householders yesterday to lower their thermostats by four degrees to help get the country through an oilshort winter. Details on Page 33.

title: Golar for Council Head
description: The President of the City Council of New York City is an office on the local level of government that comparable to the Vice Presidency on the national levl. In the event the mayoralty becomes vacant for any reason, the Council President becomes Mayor.

title: International Paper Lifts Profits 46%
description: The International Paper Company realized increases of 46 per cent in third quarter earnings and 57 per cent for the nine months on sales gains of 8 per cent and 10 per cent for the respective periods, the company's report disclosed yesterday. The results set records, with the ninemonth profit exceeding every year except the peak of $115.6million reached in 1969.

title: Arabs Said to Have Kept Plan From All but Chiefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 9 Western diplomats here are convinced that the Arabs, by keeping their plans, confined to a few top leaders, and through a rare miscalculation in Israeli intelligence, were able to achieve surprise in their attacks last Saturday in the early hours of the Middle East war.

title: Blades and Toros Battle to 33 Draw
description: TORONTO, Oct. 9 (UPI)Bob Jones and Brian Perry scored in a 62second span in the third period tonight to give the New York Golden Blades a 33 tie in the second W.H.A. deadlock for both teams. The teams failed to score in the 10minute overtime period.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Advertising: Which Vacationer?
description: Having the Bermuda Department of Tourism for a client presents an ad agency with an interesting challenge the island doesn't want to attract just anybody. In fact, the Government of the Crown Colony believes that some of the well published problems on other islands were induced by the quality of the visitors.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Clifford Questions Increase in Defense Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Former Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford today attacked the Nixon Administration's defense policies in general, and the current dfense budget in particular, as all but oblivious to the great changes taking place in the world around us.

title: Suspect Is Seized In 100 Burglaries At Hotels in City
description: A man the police said today they were certain had committed at least a hundred burglaries in some of the city's better, hotels was arrested yesterday in his East Side apartment by detectives backed by shotgunwielding police officers.

title: From Bad to Worse . . . .
description: Israeli air attacks on Damascus and in the neighborhood of Cairo mark an ominous escalation in a war that could go precipitately from bad tip worsefor the Middle East and the worldunless the United Nations stops playing petty politics and fulfills its peacekeeping responsibilities at once.

title: GENESCO TO SELL KRESS AND UNITS
description: Genesco, Inc., the apparel industry's largest company, has decided to sell the S. H. Kress varietystore division and its Sanremo men's clothing operation in Italy. It will also close about 100 women's footwear stores and dispose of five European apparel subsidiaries.

title: Seven in Florida Convicted of Smuggling Marijuana
description: GAINSVILLE, Fla., Oct. (AP)  Seven Florida men arrested in March in what Federal agents said was one of the nation's largest marijuana seizures were found guilty tonight of smuggling charges.

title: Sandman Campaign
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9How can the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, a formidable campaigner who seems to have all the big issues going for him, also seem to be trailing badly in the election that is four weeks from today? The question is beginning haunt some of New Jersey's leading Republicans and plague some of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s most vociferous supporters.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Attacks MinorityJob Plan In Building Industry
description: The New York Plan, designed to increase the number of minority workers in the construction industry, was attacked in Federal Court here yesterday as a violation of equalemployment rights.

title: NEWSPAPER UNION ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: A: civil complaint by the Federal Government charged yesterday that the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union here deprived black workers of equa employment opportunities guaranteed by the Civil Right Act of 1964.

title: The Hidden Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9The latest Middle East crisis between Israel and the Arab states has produced an even more important crisis between the United States and the Soviet Union, and between the United States and the Communist Government of China.

title: U. S. Says Moscow Bids Other Arabs Aid Egypt and Syria
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Administration officials said today that although the Soviet Union had avoided direct involvement in the Middle East crisis, it was actively encouraging other Arab Governments to lend support to Egypt and Syria.

title: Nixon Asks Householders to Save Heat by Lowering Thermostat 4 Degrees
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9President Nixon, in a patriotic appear for the united action of all Americans, urged householders today to lower their thermostat settings by four degress to help get the country through an oilshort winter.

title: GOSLOW POLICY ON NEW RCA UNIT
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday a goslow policy in the introduction of its SelectaVision magnetic tape video recorder system. William C. Hittinger, executive vice president of consumer and solid state electronics operations, said field tests would begin in the first quarter of 1974. Earlier this year RCA said it expected to begin actual marketing of the system late this year.

title: Policeman and Gunman Slain As 3 Try to Hold Up Bronx Bar
description: An offduty police officer was shot to death and a robber was slain in a blazing gun battle early today neighbor hood bar in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Brooklyn High School Closes After Racial Clash in Morning
description: Classes were dismissed at noon yesterday at Franklin D. Roosevelt High School in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn after a disturbance near the school involving six white teenagers who do not attend the school and two black students.

title: Football Ratings WRITERS' POLL
description: The to 20, with points figured on a 2011316141210987654321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlosttied records through games of last Saturday.

title: CRUELTY IS CHARGED TO A HORSEHANDLER
description: CHAMPLAIN, N. Y., Oct. 9 (UPI) A Canadian was arrested today after the state police and officials from the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals investigated a holding area where 400 to 500 horses were being readied for shipment to Canada.

title: Redskins Have Long Way to Go
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9A 2 A.M. breakfast party at Zeibert's, the sports restaurant, after the game featured such diverse types as Eugene McCarthy and Mrs. Vince Lombardi and everyone was gahgah over the Redskins, who somehow had just beaten the Dallas Cowboys, 147, in a memorable football game. When George Allen, the coach, came in, they stood up and cheered him.

title: Nixon Asks Heat Saving
description: President Nixon urged all householders yesterday to lower their thermostats by four degrees to help get the country through an oilshort winter. Details on Page 33.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Hanover Plans Coast Unit
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that it had received Federal Reserve approval to establish the Manufacturers Hanover Bank International (Los Angeles), which would offer international banking services.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LITTLE FALLS, Oct. 9Unless your name, is Buddy Dial, you probably don't remember a former New York Giant named Joe Biscaha, pronounced BASANHA, because Biscaha disappeared from the world of pro football as quietly and mysteriously as he arrived. The boy from Pope Pius High of Passaic played one season with the Giants1959  then was gone.

title: CAIRO CONFIDENT
description: CAIRO, Wednesday, Oct. 10 Egypt pumped armor and infantry across the Suez Canal for the fourth day yesterday, the Cairo radio said, amid indications that the Egyptian command was adhering to it initial plan in spite of Israeli counterattacks.

title: 7 DIE IN PLANE CRASH ON MICHIGAN STREET
description: INKSTER, Mich., Oct. 9 (AP) At least seven persons were killed when a twinengined airplane crashed in a heavily populated area, of this Detroit suburb tonight, the police said.

title: Notes on People
description: Jean Westwood, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced her intention to run for the seat held by Senator Wallace Bennett, Republican of Dtah, when he retires next year. Mrs. Westwood told the Arizona Women's Political Caucus in Tucson that Senator George McGovern, the Presidential candidate she served while head of the committee, is expected to back her candidacy. Mrs. Westwood resigned as party chairman last December.

title: SEX WITH PATIENTS DENIED BY DOCTORS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) A California psythiatric team that surveyed sexual behavior in the medical practice of Los Angeles area doctors reports that one in 20 physicians confirmed having bad sexual relations with patients.

title: A SOVIET WALKOUT MARKS U.N. DEBATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9The Security Council sought again today to deal with the renewed war in the Middle East, but its debate was marked by angry exchanges and a Soviet walkout.

title: Milo Unit Files Chapter XI
description: The Milo Electronics Corporation of Syosset, L.I., announced yesterday that its subsidiary, Milo of California, Inc., in San Diego had filed a petition of bankruptcy under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in the Couthern District of California and will submit a plan of arrangement to its creditors. Milo of California operates retail stores selling electronic products and components.

title: Reds Top Mets in 12th, 21, Force Playoff to 5th Game
description: Nobody threw any punches, but Pete Rose unloaded a haymaker home run in the 12th inning yesterday that gave the Cincinnati Reds a 21 victory over the New York Mets and put the National League pennant up for grabs this afternoon.

title: U. S. Says Moscow Bids Other Arabs Aid Egypt and Syria
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Administrtion officials said today that although the Soviet Union had avoided direct involvement in the Middle East crisis, it was actively encouraging other Arab governments to lend support to Egypt and Syria.

title: AGNEW CHARGES HOUSING FAILURE
Volkswagen Motor To be WaterCooled In SomeCars Here
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9Stuart Perkins, president of Volkswagen of America, said today that the company would introduce in January the first of what he calls a new generation of Volkswagens, a car with a frontwheel drive and watercooled engine, to be called the Dasher.

title: POLICEMEN GUILTY IN DRUG CASE HERE
description: Two New York policemen were found guilty last night by a Manhattan jury of burglary, attempted grand larceny and attempted criminal possession of dangerous drugs in connection with what the prosecution described as a ripping off of narcotics peddlers.

title: WAR OF ATTRITION
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Oct. 10A ranking spokesman for Israel's high command said last night that Israel had abandoned most of the BarLev Line along the Suez Canal but that the Israelis had nearly succeeded in clearing Syrian forces from the Golan heights.

title: As Demand Swells, Second Homes Become Costly and Scarce
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9  Are you still dreaming of that little cottage on the beach, or that mountainside cabin near a trout brook, that weekend hideaway where the pressure of just staying alive can be defeated?

title: Beckwith, Tried in Slaying Of Evers, Indicted by Jury
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9 (AP) Byron De La Beckwith was indicted today by the Federal grand jury on three counts of violating the Federal Gun Control Act. The indictment is in connection with a ticking time bomb police found in Mr. Beckwith's car last month as he drove into New Orleans.

title: Bridge: TwoWay Guess for a Queen Results in a Strange Situation
description: One of the strangest situations that can arise in play concerns the everyday twoway guess for a queen. You finesse against one opponent, successfully. You then repeat the finesse, but against the other defender. Remarkably, this also succeeds. Nobody has made an errorin fact both sides have played extremely well.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Film Fete: Andrei Rublev' From Russia Is Shown The Cast
description: Andrei Rublev (circa 1360-1430) is the Russian monk who is credited with having liberated Russian icon painting from Byzantine traditions of severity and estheticism to create a distinctly Russian art, warmer and more poetic than the work that came before. His life, of which only the most general details are known, is the take-off point for the massive, oddly elliptical Russian film that was shown last night at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center and will be shown there again tonight."Andrei Rublev" has had a curious history. Verifying facts about it is only slightly less difficult than authenticating some of the paintings that have been attributed to Rublev.This much is known: the film, which was being shown privately in Moscow in 1967, was presented out of competition at the 1969 Cannes Film Festival by the owner of the French distribution rights but against the official wishes of the Russians, who reportedly felt that one of its themesthe artist trying to make sense within a brutalizing worldhad embarrassing contemporary parallels.When it was shown at Cannes, the film was almost three hours, although it was said to have been cut. Last night at Alice Tully Hall, the running time was 2 hours and 26 minutes. This should be pointed out, I think, to explain the certain disadvantage under which we must judge it. How much of the film's highly praised free form is the intention of the director or simply a result of an editor's itchy fingers? I'm not sure.The film I saw was free in narrative form, all right, but almost DeMille-heavy in style. This is most apparent in the huge spectacle scenes that show us the Tartars pillaging and raping with great, old-fashioned gusto ("I saw a town," one Tartar chief explains to another, "and couldn't resist"), and, at another point, drop Andrei into the midst of a pagan orgy where, it seems, he suffers a fate more provocative than death. That is, for a monk.The film is presented in a series of separate chapters, or panels, not unlike those in an iconostasis, that especially Russian collection of icons (developed in Rublev's day) that form a screen between the sanctuary of a church and the nave. In some panels Andrei (Anatoli Solonitzine) is barely visible, a minor character; in others he is in the foreground although he is seldom more than the passive recorder of the events around him, as we are.In this fashion, I assume, we are meant to share the passions, sorrows and doubts that shaped the artist, but since there always seems to be more going on in the head of the film's director than in the head of the man playing Andrei, the system did not work for me. I wondered, for example, how the director got a horse to fall down stairs. Was the horse hurt? That sort of question takes precedence over questions of esthetics.Andrei Tarkovsky, the director whose "My Name Is Ivan" was released here in 1963, spares us most of the usual movie-nonsense talk about art and the artist, and he never once shows us Andrei's trying to decide whether to use blue paint or green. He also has created a couple of impressive individual sequences, including the preparations for, and casting of, a giant church bell, and the opening sequence in which Andrei witnesses the desperate revels of a group of peasants who have taken refuge in a barn during a storm.Unfortunately, Tarkovsky also has a particularly Russian eye for movie lyricism, which is not very interesting: a fondness for sun-created halos, rain, snow, rushing streams and air filled with dandelion fluff, all those clichs that more frequently evoke the moviemaker's fatigue than his poetic sensibility.However, I hedge my comments in the knowledge that I've not seen the film that Tarkovsky made. This "Andrei Rublev" says not much more about the trials of the artist than does Truffaut's "Day for Night," which manages the feat without any impalings and with no dandelion fluff.

title: BERNARD H. LAWSON
description: Bernard H. Lawson, a lawyer who became president of Lawson Associates, fundraising counsel to many philanthropic and religious institutions, died Monday in Phoenixville, Pa. A former resident of Old Westbury, L.I., he had lived in Chester Springs, Pa., since 1966.

title: Research Ship Sails
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Oct 9 (AP)The topsail schooner Westward sailed today for Spain and North Africa on a threemonths voyage of research and study. Nineteen high school and college students and seven instructors were aboard. The voyage is sponsored by the Sailing Education Association.

title: Rainfall in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (UPI) A weak storm system moved across southern California yesterday, dampening Los Angeles with 0.02 of an inch of rainfall and breaking the longest dry spell in the city's history. It was on March 28six, months agothat the last measurable precipitation was recorded in the city.

title: Kibbutz Digs In, Town Is Dispirited
description: GVAT, Israel, Oct. 9  A 1,000pound Sovietbuilt missile fired from Syria struck the central area of this kibbutz near Nazareth early this morning and devastated the onestory buildings in which 270 children usually sleep.

title: Excerpts From Israeli General's Talk
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 9 (UPI)Following are excerpts from remarks made in English today at a news conference by Maj. Gen. Aharon Yariv, special adviser, to the Chief of Staff:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Subway Crime Rises 26% And Patterns Are Changing
description: Crimes reported in the subway system rose by 26.4 per cent during the first eight months of this year compared with the same period last year, despite a citywide drop of 5.8 per cent in reported crimes.

title: U.S. Aides See Eventual Israeli Victory
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 United States military officials said today that they believed that Israel would eventually defeat the Egyptian and Syrian forces, but only after tough, costly and perhaps prolonged fighting.

title: Arbiter Backs Transfers At New Brunswick High
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9A hearing examiner for the State Department of Education recommended tonight that predominantly white North Brunswick and Milltown take their highschool sophomores out of overcrowded New Brunswick High School and put them in the new North Brunswick. High School.

title: Budget Commission Hears Familiar Campaign Theme
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, expecting to hear the four major mayoral candidates talk about the city's expense budget, heard instead a recitation of familiar political positions yesterday.

title: Newark Council Head Admits Tax Guilt, But Says He Intends to Retain His Post
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9  City Council President Louis M. Turco pleaded guilty today to Federal incometax charges that could send him to prison for four years. He then announced that he intended to continue in his Council post.

title: Fuel Independents Tell of Being Squeezed by Major Oil Companies
description: Independent gasoline and heatingoil distributors from around the state asserted here yesterday that major oil companies were using the reported petroleum shortage to shield efforts to force them out of business and to secure the market for industryowned dealers.

title: War and Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 When President Nixon stepped onto the South Lawn of the White, House today to welcome President Flix HouphouetBoigny of the Ivory Coast to this country, there seemed to be a new spring in his walk and more selfassurance in his manner than had been evident for a number of months.

title: Defeat of Bishops by Makarios Strengthens His Hold on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct 1Making full use of the state machinery he controls as President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios has emerged victorious, from a yearlong confrontation with bishops and priests who opposed his political stance and tried to force his ouster.

title: Vote Imperils Season Start
description: DENVER, Oct. 9 (UPI)The American Basketball Association's Players Association voted today to strike on the eve of the start of the 197374 regular season.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Golan Heights Are Called Syrian Tank Graveyard
description: SAFAD, Israel, Oct. 9The Golan heights were described by Israeli commanders today as a vast graveyard of Syrian tanks and artillery pieces after the fourth and heaviest day of fighting on the northern front.

title: CAIRO CONFIDENT
description: CAIRO, Wednesday, Oct. 10 Egypt pumped armor and infantry across the Suez Canal for the fourth day yesterday, the Cairo radio said, amid indications that the Egyptian command was adhering to its initial plan in spite of Israeli counterattacks.

title: T.W.U. Assails Nixon on Civil Rights
description: Delegates to the Transport Workers Union convention here Sharply criticized the Nixon Administration yesterday for its performance in the civil rights area, but a woman delegate chided them for omitting any reference to sex in the resolution.

title: A Summary of Some of the Actions Taken as the U.S. Supreme Court Convenes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Among the actions taken today by the Supreme Court were the following:

title: Fumes Kill Two on Ship
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9 (AP) Two men were killed today by fumes from an insecticide when they entered a ship to inspect a grain shipment that had been fumigated. They were identified by a Port Authority spokesman as Edwin R, Fitzgerald Jr., 19 years old, and Nolan Pritchard.

title: National City Bank Sets Profit Records
description: The First National City Corporation, the nation's second largest banking concern, reported record earnings yesterday for the third quarter and first nine months of 1973 and a higher rate of return on its stockholder investment. However, the profit margin for the nine months was down to 8.8 per rent from 10.4 per cent for the nine months in 1972.

title: H.R.A CHIEF CITES RELIEF ROIL DROP
description: The city was depicted yesterday as the only one of nine major urban areas to show a decline in welfare caseloads during the first nine or 10 months of the fiscal year ended last June 30.

title: Sister Rosetta Tharpe Is Dead; Top Gospel Singer Since 1930's
description: Mrs. Rosetta Tharpe Morrison, who as Sister Rosetta Tharpe was one of the first gospel singers to gain wide recognition outside the Negro churches of the Deep South, died yesterday in Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia, where she made her home. She was 57 years old.

title: TOKYO AND SEOUL HARDEN POSITIONS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7 The scene is deceptively quiet. Down the deserted side street in the Tonggyo, or Eastern Bridge, section of the city, Kim Dae Jung is confined to his modest home behind the high brick wall.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: NEWARK OFFICIAL ADMITS TAX GUILT
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9  City Council President Louis M. Turco pleaded guilty today to Federal incometax charges that could send him to prison for four years. He then announced that he intended to continue in his Council post.

title: Planning Body, in Effort to Preserve Madison Avenue, Will Seek 18Story Height Limit
description: Citing planned construction of five big apartment houses along the largely residential stretch of Madison Avenue between 61st and 96th Streets, the City Planning Commission chairman, John E. Zuccotti, announced yesterday plans to bar such construction in the future.

title: Long Strike Expected At Modern Museum
description: The Museum of Modern Art was struck yesterday by its union of professional and administrative workers, who set up roundtheclock picket lines outside the entrances and at a truckdelivery platform.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SEES PROFIT DROP
description: Earnings of Procter & Gamble in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 may be down as much as 7 per cent from the year earlier period although sales may be up as much as 19 per cent, Howard Morgens, chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Cincinnati.

title: Saxbe Is Third G.O.P. Senator To Forgo Reelection Bid in '74
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Senator William B. Saxbe of Ohio, an often outspoken Republican, today became the third Republican Senator to announce that he will not rein for reelection in 1974.

title: MRS. ELIZABETH GRAY
description: Mrs. Elizabeth W. Gray, an associate professor of home economics at Pratt Institute from 1930 to 1948, when she retired, died Monday at Brooklyn Hospital. Her age was 81 and she lived at 160 Henry Street.

title: People and Business
description: Hugh F. Owens, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been nominated to be chairman of the Securities Investor Protectibn Corporation, the threeyearold organization that administers an insurance fund providing for limited investor protection against brokeragefirm failures.

title: Recital: Schubert Cycle
description: Schubert wrote 11 piano sonatas, or 23, or some number in between, depending upon which edition you pick up or which expert you consult. The problem is that only three of the sonatas were published in his lifetime, and many others were either discovered later strewn through his other piano works or left in various stages of fragmentation.

title: Moscow Collector to Sell AvantGarde Art in West
description: George Costakis, who is wellknown in international art circles as one of the most important private collectors of Russian avantgarde art in the Soviet Union, disclosed to a small audience of scholars, collectors and dealers at the Guggenheim Museum on Tuesday evening that a small portion of his coveted collection will be sold in the West.

title: Colombo Taken to Hospital From Family Retreat Upstate
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Oct. 10  Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed underworld figure who was shot down at an ItalianAmerican unity rally in 1971 and left paralyzed, was reported in satisfactory condition today at a hospital here.

title: Penn Central Derailment Holds Up 40,000 Riders
description: More than 40,000 commuters, were delayed up to four hours yesterday morning after a Penn Central train jumped the tracks in the Bronx and smashed into a 30foot high steel tower beside the tracks.

title: Crown Zellerbach, St. Regis, Scott Set Records in Quarter
SUSPECT IS CALLED PUSSYCAT BURGLAR
description: A man who was arraigned yesterday was accused of being the pussycat burglar who had terrorized residents in the Riverdale section of the Bronx for the last two years.

title: Market Averages
description: Wednesday, October 10, 1973 NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: Boston Prelate Asks Calm
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Huthberto Cardinal Medeiros, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, has urged Catholics to join with their neighbors to ease racial tension in the city. Racial tensions have been high here since a white woman was burned to death, allegedly at the instigation of black youths, and a white man was stabbed to death, reportedly by some black youths.

title: The Dam Cracks
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10The Vice President of the United States resigns and is sentenced for a felony: It is shattering news for a troubled country. But it also carries a profoundly important reassurance.

title: Texts of Charge Against Vice President and of Grand Jury Criminal Information
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10Following are the texts of United States Attorney George Beall's statement of the charge to which Vice President Agnew pleaded no contest and of a criminal information returned by the Federal grand jury against Mr. Agnew:

title: Mays Thankful of Chance to Do His Bit
description: Champagne is a sparkling wine named for the French province where it was first produced. It is pale amber in color, contains about 12 per cent alcohol by volume and should he served chilled in longstemmed, widemouthed glasses. The Bible warns us against excessive ingestion: At the last it biteth like a serpent and stingeth like an adder.Proverbs 23:32.

title: Shades Drawn at the Agnews' $190,000 Suburban Maryland Home
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 The big fieldstone house at the corner of Sunset and Shadow in the wellupholstered suburb of Kenwood had the shades drawn to the sills at 10 of its 12 front windows today.

title: The Two Faces of Chile's New Era: A Fearful Woman and a Relieved One
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 9Chile, nearly a month after the military coup against President Salvador Allende Gossens, can be summed up in a tale of two women: a winner and a loser.

title: GOING OUT
description: SHE The Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, now starting its fourth season, usually has its eye on the various communities in its. Lower East Side bailiwicktheater presentations of interest to blacks, Spanishspeakers and Jews (in English).

title: Prospective Juror in Chesimard Case Barred for Racial Attitude
description: NEW BRUNWICK, N. J., Oct. 10The first member of a pool of 450 prospective jurors in the trial of two blacks charged with killing a New Jersey state trooper was disqualified by the trial judge here today on the ground that his attitudes about race and police might prevent a fair trial.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: One of the highlights of this year's 30th anniversary season celebrating the contributions of the City Center of Music and Drama to the cultural life of New York City will be a Fanfare Gala and ball. A retrospective performance, in which City Center constituents will participate, will be held at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street, on Oct. 29.

title: SUBWAY LINK GAINS WITH MIDTOWN WORK
description: IND and BMT subway lines will move closer to a midtown link today when construction workers break through concrete walls at the north end of the station at 57th Street and Avenue of the Americas.

title: Two Washington Papers And Three Unions Agree
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) Representatives of the Washington Publishers Association and three craft unions at the Washington Post and the Washington StarNews have reached a tentative agreement on new contracts.

title: Consumer Notes
description: If you plan to keep your thermostat four degrees lower this winter to save fuel, as suggested by President Nixon, perhaps you are also looking for other ways to save on energyand money. It has been suggested that cutting down on lighting is one way. It is easy just to turn off lights; but how about the lights you do use?

title: HOUSE VOTE BACKS CAPITAL ENCLAVE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The House voted tonight to carve a federally run national capital enclave out of Washington, D.C., and turn the rest of the city largely over to selfgovernment.

title: Soviet Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (Reuters) . The Soviet Union today launched an artificial satellite for continued space research, the Tass press agency announced.

title: Chrysler Dispute Settled; U.A.W. Turns to Ford
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10 (UPI) The United Automobile Workers cleared up its last major dispute with the Chrysler Corporation today, then turned its full negotiating attention to the Ford Motor Company.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Destiny's Darlings, the New York Mets, went skedaddling into the World Series yesterday in their usual preposterous and improbable fashion. They survived their suddendeath, fifthgame playoff against the Cincinnati Reds, presumably a superior ball club. But no one in the insane and wildly emotional crowd at Shea Stadium asked to inspect Redleg credentials. They just went crazy the split second the game had ended.

title: BUDGE RULES PACT IN EFFECT AT TIMES
description: State Supreme Court Justice Vincent J. Massi ruled yesterday that a labor contract, forbidding strikes or interference with operations, continued in effect between The New. York Times and Typographical Union No. 6.

title: BROTHER J. DOHERTY
description: Brother James Doherty, principal of St. Cecilia's, a Roman Catholic grammar school here since 1970, died of cancer Tuesday at the Abraham Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx. He was 34 years old.

title: Sandman People Charge Dirty Tricks
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10  The Republicans managing Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s campaign for Governor charged today that the campaign forces of Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate, had broken into Sandman headquarters, maliciously destroyed Sandman campaign material and launched a whispering campaign to create personal suspicion about the Sandman family. Asked if they had any evidence to support their charges, the Republicans said they did not.

title: Orioles Win, Tie Playoffs
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 10 On the brink of elimination with three innings to go, trailing 40 and having made only two singles off Vida Blue, the Baltimore Orioles struck back today on a gametying home run by Andy Etchebarren and a gamewinning clout by Bobby Grich for a 54 victory over the Oakland A's that extended the American championship series to a fifth and final game tomorrow.

title: Discount Ticket Center Found To Be a Theatergoing Stimulus
description: The Times Square Theater Center, the discount ticket outlet set up at Broadway and 47th Street last June, has added substantially to theater audiences here, a survey of 825 center patrons shows.

title: Aluminum Wire Gains
description: The Aluminum Association reported yesterday that August shipments of aluminum insulated or covered wire and cable totaled an estimated 42.1 million pounds, or 30.3 per cent more than the 32.3 million pounds shipped in the like 1972 month. This was also 19.6 per cent higher than the estimated July shipments of 35.2 million pounds.

title: Rangers Top Wings, 41, In Popein Debut as Coach
description: With a fluid, commanding style, the Rangers brought Coach Larry Popein victory in his first game behind a National Hockey League bench last night in a 41 decision over the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

title: Agnew Plea Ends 65 Days Of Insisting on Innocence
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10Vice President Agnew ended today 65 days of defiant insistence that he was innocent of any wrongdoing by pleading no contest to a charge of cheating the Government of $13,551.47 on his. Federal income tax pay ment for 1967, his first year as Governor of Maryland. Then he resigned his Federal office.

title: Man Who Attacked Stennis Is Given 15Year Sentence
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) John Marshall, 22 years old, was sentenced to 15 years in a Federal youth corrections center today for his part in the robbery and shooting of Senator John, C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, last January.

title: Rangers Top Wings, 41, In Popein Debut as Coach
description: With a fluid, commanding style, the Rangers brought Coach Larry Popein victory in his first game behind a National Hockey League bench last night in a 41 decision over the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

title: MAX FELDMAN
description: BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 10Max Feldman, vice president and founder of the F & A Distributing Company, wholesalers of liquor, died at his home here yesterday. His age was 83.

title: Sears Not Expected to Equal Spring's Sales Gain This Fall
description: Arthur M. Wood, chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Co., said yesterday in New York that Sears would not match the 15 per cent sales rise this fall that its spring volume recorded over the same 1972 period, despite the fact that national business remains strong.

title: Reds Irritated by Met Fans
description: With bats in their hands, the Cincinnati Reds filed through the runway from their dugout to their clubhouse yesterday, while out on the field at Shea Stadium, thousands celebrants swarmed.

title: New Charges Accuse Three Of Diverting Pennsy Funds
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) The Philadelphia District Attorney, Arlen Specter, said today that he would seek new charges against three men accused of diverting $21million of the Penn Central Company's funds for their own gain.

title: AIDE SAYS ISRAEL EXPECTED ATTACK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Israel's Ambassador to the United States, Simcha Dinitz, said at a meeting of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations yesterday that Israel knew she would be attacked several days before she actually was by the Syrians and Egyptians.

title: THAILAND PULLOUT SUSPENDED BY U.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 10 (AP)The United States has agreed to suspend temporarily the withdrawal of American forces from Thailand, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said at a news conference today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Noting increased Wage costs, the State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized an electric and gas rate rise for the Long Island Lighting Company, its second five months. The company expects to receive $3,758,000 more a year from the higher electric rates and $1,467,000 from the higher gas rates. This would be on top of an $11,766,000 electric rate increase and $3,408,000 gas rate increase allowed in May.

title: Boston Teachers Vote Pact
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP)Members of the Boston Teachers Union ratified today a new oneyear contract with the Boston School Committee. The proposal will now go before the school committee tomorrow for a formal vote. The proposed contract calls for a 5 per cent costofliving salary increase. Teachers have been working without a contract since Sept. 1.

title: E.P.A. Opposes Permanent Approval For Oyster Creek AtomicPower Plant
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is opposed to the granting of permanent operating approval to the Oyster Creek nuclear generating plant until thermalpollution probems are minimized and radiation emitted by the plant is reduced to the lowest practicable levels.

title: A BRITISH DIPLOMAT ABDUCTED IN MEXICO
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Oct. 10 (AP)Four gunmen broke into the home of Britain's honorary consul in Guadalajara this morning and kidnapped him, the police reported.

title: Chess:
description: I don't know why the average player gives so little attendon to the end game, since the vast majority of games are decided by winning material and exploiting it there.

title: Erving Gets 42 Points, But Nets Bow by 11899
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 10George McGinnis scored 8 straight points in the closing four minutes tonight to enable the Indiana Pacers to spoil the debuts of Julius Erving as a player and Kevin Loughery as a coach of the York ork Nets as the American Basketball Association opened its seventh season.

title: Other News Of the War In Mideast
description: LONDON, Oct. 10  Britain announced an embargo today on arms sales to the opposing sides in the Middle East war.

title: Watergate Panel Gets First Direct Evidence About Political Tricks Played by Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Senate Watergate Committee heard today its first direct widence of what Republican vitnesses have called political irty tricks by supporters of Democratic Presidential candiiates.

title: Contract Talks Break Off At Canada Newsprint Plant
description: ST. CATHERINES, Ont., Oct. 10 (AP)Contract talks broke off today between union and management officials of the Ontario Paper Company newsprint plant in nearby Thorold.

title: MeatPrice Drop Continues to Push Food Costs Down
description: Food prices in the city went down 0.8 per cent last week for the second successive week, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Israel Claiming Heights
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday, Oct. 11 Israel said last night that the Syrian Army on the Golan heights had been driven back to the 1967 ceasefire line, but Israeli forces fighting the Egyptians clearly seemed to have suspended a counterattack aimed at pushing them from the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

title: Dr. Moos Will Head Find for Republic And Study Center
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Dr. Malcolm C. Moos, who was an administrative assistant to President Eisenhower, has resigned as chancellor of the University of Mini sots to accept the position, of chairman of the hoard of the Fund for the Republic in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: 2 Legal Procedures Resolved the Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Spiro T. Agnew has resolved the criminal case against him by using two procedures long recognized in the law and long relied upon by both defendants and prosecutors. Those procedures have also been long questioned and criticized, for they are both devices through which defendants avoid the full force of the law.

title: PROFESSOR BACKS LIMITED DRUG USE
description: Albany, Oct. 10A state university professor startled a legislative panel here today by saying that we are trying to teach a sensible, reasonable use of drugs.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Two Unfrocked Eastern Priests Plead Guilty in BookTheft Case
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10Two unfrocked Eastern Orthodox priests who had been stealing ancient books, atlases and manuscripts from Yale Library for years and selling them to rare book dealers in New York and Chicago pleaded guilty today to a conspiracy charge. The priests promised to do their best to recall which books they had taken and what they had done with them.

title: Relief Supervisor, Physician and Model Charged With $268,000 Welfare Fraud
description: A welfare supervisor, a physician who is an assistant professor of clinical obstetrics and gynecology at Columbia University and a fashion model were charged yesterday with the theft of $268,000 in city funds in what was described as a sophisticated, unique conspiracy.

title: CORPORATE MERGERS OFF 14% IN QUARTER
description: The number of corporate mergers declined 14 per cent in the third quarter despite the improvement in the stock market since midAugust, W. T. Grimm & Co., specialists in corporate mergers, have announced.

title: Equity Financing
description: Bancal Investors, a real estate investment trust, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. an initial public offering of 1,500,000 shares of beneficial interest to be sold through Dean Witter and Paine, Webber. The trust will be advised by Bancal Advisors, Inc., with 88 per cent owned by the Bancal TriState Corporation, a bank holding company whose principal subsidiary is the Bank of California.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1973
description: I hereby resign the office of Vice President of the United States, effective immediately. With that terse statement delivered to the Secretary of State at 2:05 P.M., Spiro T. Agnew became the second Vice President in the nation's history to resign from office. His resignation, part of an agreement to avoid prosecution and possible imprisonment on a number of Federal charges, was followed by his conviction on a single count of income tax evasion, for which he was fined $10,000 and sentenced to three years on probation. In a dramatic statement read to the court in Baltimore, Mr. Agnew, who pleaded no contest to the tax charger denied other wrongdoing and said that avoiding a protracted legal fight was in the national interest. [Page 1, Columns 78; Text, P. 1.]

title: Business Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  The Chromalloy American Corporation said today it had received a bid from China to prepare proposals for the design, construction and operation of a pallpoint pen plant in. China.

title: Guns of Settlement
description: To fathom the new war in the Middle East, one must think in Middle East terms. A ceasefire, today, is simply inconceivable. Both Arabs and Israelis are, for the time being, thinking of partial or total victory.

title: AgnewNixon Exchange
description: October 10, 1973

title: Soviet Rebuffs Tanaka on Islands Issue
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan left the Soviet Union today voicing disappointment over Soviet intransigence over terms for a World War II peace treaty and warning that this would affect SovietJapanese relations.

title: Week Honors the Danes
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday designated this week as Danish Remembrance Week in New York City in honor of the Danish effort to save the lives of more than 8,000 Jews during the Nazi occupation. The heroic action of thousands upon thousands of Danes in defying death at the hhands of the Gestapo to save their Jewish neighbors was a shining example of Man's concern for men, the Mayor said.

title: Noise, Graffiti and Air Grate On Riders of City Subways
description: Deafening noise, unchecked graffiti and often fetid air that raises questions of pollution make the New York subways one of the city's most hostile environments. But attempts to improve the subway environment run into problems of how to do it and where to get the money.

title: Police Seek Purse Snatchers
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Some 15 policemen volunteered today to spend offduty hours patrolling an area plagued by purse snatchings and robberies in the last week. Sgt. Peter Gernat said the volunteer patrolmen will be making rounds of the area, especially around shopping centers, during the day and early evening hours.

title: I. B. M. NET RISES; BURROUGHS GAINS
description: The news was good yesterday for the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Civil Defense Unit Elects
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 10 (AP)  A Towson, Md., man was chosen presidentelect of the Civil Defense Council yesterday at the organization's 22d annual conference here. Walter D. Hyle Jr., Civil Defense director for Baltimore County in Maryland.

title: CONGRESS TO VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10President Nixon began his search today for a successor to Vice President Agnew amid indications that he will face stiff resistance from Congress if he chooses anyone who might qualify as a strong Republican candidate in 1976.

title: Agnew's HalfBrother Dies
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 (AP)W. Roy Pollard, halfbrother of Spiro T. Agnew, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 65. Mr. Pollard retired last year as manager of agency administration for the Monumenal Life Insurance Company. After the death of his father, Mr. Pollard's mother was married to Theodore S. Agnew, Mr. Agnew's father.

title: British Court Fines a Union For Defying EndStrike Edict
description: LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP)Britain's Industrial Relations Court tined the nation's second largest trade union $240,000 today in a test case.

title: FIND IN NORTH SEA ADDS TO RESERVE
description: LONDON, Oct 10A maim new oil discovery has significantly expanded the proven reserves of the North Sea and may eventually have an im pact on the sensitive balance of power among the world's petroleumproducing nations.

title: Ludwig von Mises, Economist, Author and Teacher, Dies at 92
description: Ludwig von Mises, one of the Foremost economists of this century, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 92. He lived at 777 West End Avenue.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Strike Called Against Union Of State Civil Service Aides
description: ALBANY, Oct. 10 (UPI) The union representing 64 field workers for the Civil Service Employes Association went on strike against the labor organization of state workers today in a contract dispute centering on money.

title: Trudeau Arrives in Peking, Begins Talks With Chou
description: PEKING, Oct. 10 (Canadian Press)Pierre Elliott Trudeau today became the first Canadian Prime Minister to visit China He began talks with Premier Chou Enlai.

title: MRS. WILLIAM HUIE
description: HARTSELLE, Ala., Oct. 10 (AP)Mrs. Ruth Puckett Huie, wife of William Bradford Huie, the novelist, died today of cancer in a Birmingham hospital. She was 64 years old.

title: Soviet Could Spur Move to Aid Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Administration officials said today that they believed the Soviet Union was airlifting military equipment to resupply the forces of Egypt and Syria.

title: President Urges Scientists to Help Nation Become SelfSufficient in Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Citing the uncertainty of oil supplies from the Middle East, President Nixon said today that the nation must become entirely selfsufficient in energy.

title: A New Problem for President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10For the seventeenth time in 184 years, the republic is without a Vice President, and the immediate question is how President Nixon will approach the choice of someone to succeed Spiro Agnew for the next three years and three months. Eight times during these 184 years, a Vice President has succeded to the Presidency in midterm, and with another war in progress in the Mideast, the Administration weakened by scandals and resignations, and the people troubled by internal dissension and inflation, Mr. Nixon's decision will come at a particularly solemn moment.

title: Dow Tumbles by 13.62 After Resignation
description: The sudden resignation of Vice President Agnew touched off a sharp burst of selling yesterday in Wall street.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Israelis With Military Training Are Called Home From the U. S.
description: The Israeli Government has summoned home from the New York area a few Israelis with special military training, but most of the several thousand Israelis working or vacationing here have not been recalled for the war, an Israeli official said yesterday.

title: Met City Explodes With Joy
description: Sirens went off on Fifth Avenue. Bus drivers on Queens Boulevard blew their horns. Tabloids were shredded and dropped from East Side apartment windows. Victory beer flowed at the Avenue U Bar in Sheepshead Bay and at New York University's Loeb Student Center.

title: Procedure Now Exists to Fill Vacancy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The problem facing Mr. Nixon and Congresshow to fill a VicePresidential vacancyhas been a recurrent one in United States history, but for the first time, a procedure now exists for filling the vacancy.

title: For the Fans, Game Was Over Before the Last Out
description: The wife of one Cincinnati official was knocked down and stepped on. The wife of another official had her hair pulled as she walked down the steps of the Reds' dugout. Phil Gagliano, a Reds' reserve, punched the youngster who pulled her hair. A 6yearold girl was hurried through the dugout, her face dirty from having been shoved into the dirt.

title: Connecticut Black Panther Released on $15,000 Bond
description: MONTVILLE, Conn., Oct. 10 (AP)  Lonnie McLucas, convicted of conspiracy to murder in the 1970 Black Panther trials, was released from jail today after his attorney posted a $15,000 bond.

title: The Agnew Tragedy...
description: The drama of Spiro Agnew has reached its appointed end. For him, the sad denouement in a Baltimore courtroom concluded his sudden, steep descent from occupant of the second highest constitutional office to convicted criminala descent that began two months ago with the official warning from a Federal prosecutor that he was under investigation on grave charges.

title: Construction Accord Signed
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 10 (AP) Representatives of 13 unions land the National Constructors Association have signed an agreement aimed to reduce strikes and increase production in the construction industry. The agreement bans illegal strikes, work stoppages, lockouts, standby crews and featherbedding. It also calls for final and binding arbitration of disputes, a provision not included in an earlier agreement that expired last year.

title: From a Man Who
description: WASHINGTONNearly a year has passed since the 1972 Presidential election. On that disappointing night in November, I assured my supporters that while we did not prevail at the ballot box, the ideas we stood for would prevail. This is my faith today. I believe that both the open procedures and the essential values advanced in our campaign represent the best hope for the American future.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SOYBEANS UP
description: The weather took over as the main reason for higher prices of corn and soybeans yesterday, indicating that traders had already discounted the Mideast war news.

title: Ordham Five in Tourney
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 UPI)  The 13th annual ?? Colliege Athletic reference Quaker City basball tournament will be ??at the Palestra Dec. 26with Cincinnati, Calinia, Harvard and Fordham the eightteam field for first time, officials an?? today. Other en?? include Pennsylvania, State, Temple and St. adventure.

title: EVIDENCE SHOWS GIFTS TO AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, Oct 10Spiro T. Agnew, in three elective offices including the VicePresidency, asked for and accepted cash payments totaling more than $100,000, according to the evidence gathered against him by the United States Attorneys in Baltimore.

title: British Tories Convene
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10 (UPI)The governing conservative party opened its annual conference here today. It heard that there was a strong possibility that Prime Minister Heath would call a general election within the next 12 months.

title: Advertising: In Lunch
description: There was a lot of lunchtime activity at the Time & Life Building yesterdaysome of it even had to do with Time.

title: NIXON WAR CURB VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Against the backdrop of renewed war in the Middle East, the Senate approved today a compromise bill limiting the power of the President to commit the armed forces to foreign hostilities without Congressional approval. The vote was 75 to 20.

title: HAROLD A. SMITH
description: ORIENT POINT, L. I., Oct. 10  Harold A. Smith, a public relations executive, died today of cancer at Eastern Long Island Hospital, Greenport. He was 65 years old and lived here.

title: No Article
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: I.R.S. to Make It Easier For Election Fund Checkoff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). In a stipulation settling a court suit, the Internal Revenue Service has agreed to make it easier for taxpayers to earmark $1 of their Federal income taxes for financing Presidential election campaign.

title: Connecticut Veterans Score School Board on Flag Pledge
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 10 (UPI)  The Connecticut Veterans of Foreign Wars today condemned the actions by school officials that allowed students at Masuk High School in Monroe to refuse to pledge allegiance to the American flag.

title: Experts Feel War Is Expanding Ominously
description: The dimensions of the Middle East war have expanded ominously, according to qualified United States and British military sources.

title: Boeing Receives Order
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday it had received an order for two of its 747SF (special performance) widebodied aircraft and options for an additional two planes from. Iran Air Lines. The SP is a shorter and more economical aircraft than the standard 747. Iran Air also placed orders for three 727200s, an extended version of the standard trijet. The orders including spare parts involve some $90million.

title: EGYPT'S BUILDUP IS TERMED RAPID
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10Intelligence reports reaching Western embassies here estimate that the Egyptians have succeeded in moving about 50,000 troops across the Suez Canal since the outbreak of the new Middle East war Saturday.

title: DIPLOMAT ROBBED AT HAITIAN MISSION
description: A welldressed gunman posing as the deliverer of a telegram forced his way into the Haitian Mission to the United Nations last night, bound a diplomat and stolen an undetermined amount of cash from him, the police reported.

title: GRAIN STOCKPILING ASKED BY U.N. BODY
description: ROME, Oct. 10The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today; called for international action to, build up stocks of grains to make sure the world has enough food in times of bad crops or natural disasters.

title: Fined for Animal Cruelty
description: CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Oct, 10 (AP)A Canadian man pleaded guilty today to a charge of cruelty to animals after state police found horses in a pen here without adequate food and water. Roger LaReau, 48 years old of St. Mathias, Quebec, was fined $300 by Judge Armond Favreau of Champlain.

title: Death Penalty Bill Passed By Massachusetts Senate
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)The Massachusetts Senate gave initial approval yesterday to its version of legislation making the death penalty mandatory in firstdegree murder sentences. The vote 20 to 11, came after four hours of debate.

title: I.R.S. Sees Nothing to Prevent New Tax Cases Against Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Former Vice President Agnew's plea of no contest today in the incometax evasion case against him could mark only the beginning of difficulties for him with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: SUCCOTH BOOTH FIRE ON VASSAR'S CAMPUS
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 10 A booth commemorating the Jewish festival of Succoth, or the Feast of Tabernacles, was burned early today on the Vassar College campus, and the campus police were investigating the possibility of arson.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Blues
description: EDGAR TOWN, Mass.If solitude and no sound save the cries of gulls and terns, and the surf unrolling on miles of empty beach is what you crave when you are angling, Wasque Point on Chappaquiddick when bluefish are running is no place for you.

title: Nissan Motor Aids Harvard
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Ltd., of Japan, manufacturer of Datsun cars and trucks, has given $1million to Harvard University toward the establishment of the Japan Institute, the university announced yesterday. The Japan Institute would be established at Harvard for the expansion of research and teaching on Japan.

title: UNIT STUDIES USE OF HUGHES'S GIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Senate Watergate committee is investigating the possibility that $100,000 given by Howard R. Hughes was used to helppay for President Nixon's San Clemente home, a committee source said today.

title: Agnew Plea Ends 65 Days Of Insisting on Innocence
description: BALTIMORE, Oct, 10Vice President Agnew ended today 65 days of defiant insistence that he was innocent of any wrongdoing by pleading no contest to a charge of cheating the Government of $13,551.47 on his Federal income tax payment for 1967, his first year as Governor of Maryland. Then he resigned his Federal office.

title: 840 Pakistanis Go Home
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Oct. 10 (Reuters)The second phase of the repatriation of Pakistani) war prisoners started today) when 840 crossed the Wagha border checkpoint. Some 12,000 war prisoners and civilian internees are expected to return home this month.

title: Pakistan Condemns Israelis
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 10 A Foreign Office spokesman in Islamabad said today that Pakistan condemned what he called indiscriminate bombing of cities and killing of civilians in Syria and Egypt by Israel.

title: Amin Says War Confirms His View on Hitler and Jews
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 10 (UPI)President Idi Amin said today he was convinced he was right when he said last year that Adolf Hitler was correct in killing six million Jews in World War II.

title: Soviet Could Spur Move to Aid Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Administration officials said today that they believed the Soviet Union was airlifting military equipment to resupply the forces of Egypt and Syria.

title: U.S. Says It Had Authority To Try Kerner While in Office
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UPI)The Government argued today that it had the right to bring United States Appeals Court Judge Otto Kerner to trial even though he was not impeached beforehand.

title: Syracuse Man Gets Life
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 10 (AP)A Syracuse man was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison today in the rapeslaying of a suburban Syracuse housewife. Onondaga County Court Judge Albert Orenstein sentenced Charles D. Askew, 21 years old, to 20 years in prison on a count of firstdegree rape and 25 years to life on each of two counts in the slaying of Judith A. Giannino, 30, of Lyncourt Feb, 9.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Rickles, Foe of '71 Bond, Backs New State Transportation Issue
description: Robert N. Rickles, former city Air Resources Commissioner who reached the end of the line with Mayor Lindsay, for refusing to support the illfated $2.5billion transportation bond issue in 1971, made a turnaround yesterday.

title: Jordan Calls Up Her Reserves, Mobilizes for the War Effort
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Jordan's Higher De fense Council announced today that it was calling up reservists and mobilizing all of the country's resources for the war effort.

title: VICTOR M. ONET
description: ST. JAMES, L. I., Oct. 10Victor M. Onet, vice president of the General Builders Supply Corporation of New York, died of a heart attack yesterday near his home here. His age was 74.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Eased As Mideast Activity Is Weighed
description: Prices eased in the corporate bond market yesterday as traders assessed developments in the Middle East.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With the Middle East Once More Aflame...

title: American Export Meeting Is Adjourned Until, Today
description: American Export Industries, Inc., yesterday adjourned until 2 P.M. today a stockholders' meeting at which shareholders are being asked to approve a recapitalization plan.

title: Judith Norell Gives First of 3 Recitals On the Harpsichord
description: Judith Norell, a harpsichordist who has given several recitals here in the last twoandahalf years, is presenting a series of three concerts this season entitled The Harpsichord in the 18th Century. The first, a solo recital, took place at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night and was devoted to works by J. S. Bach, C. P. E. Bach, Nicolsa Siret, Fransois Couperin and Mozart.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: A major topic of conversation, at the moment, in the neighboring Union County towns of Scotch Plains and westfield is schoolboy football.

title: On Mister Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The man who carried the standard against permissiveness copped a plea today, and in return for his resignation, the judge and the Justice Department permitted him to go free.

title: EXPORTERS OP OIL SEE ACCORD NEAR
description: VIENNA, Oct. 10Principal negotiators met secretly today as representatives of oil exporting countries reported an agreement on higher prices for crude oil might be near.

title: NEW POLICE UNIT ASKED FOR PARKS
description: A bill that would create a special police force for the city's parks met with stiff op position yesterday from the Parks Administrator and the Police Commissioner, both of whom asserted that the Police Department was best equipped and trained to fight crime in the parks.

title: Judge Orders Fine, 3 Years' Probation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Spiro T. Agnew resigned Vice President of the United States today under an agreement with the Department of Justice to admit evasion Federal income taxes and avoid imprisonment.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Texts of Statements Read in U.S. District Court by Richardson, Agnew and Hoffman
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10  Following are the texts of statements read in United Slates District Court here today by Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson, Vice President Agnew and Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman in connection with the sentencing of Mr. Agnew:

title: Weather Service Continues His AirStagnation Advisory
description: The National Weather Service yesterday continued its airstagnation advisory for another 24 hours until noon today.

title: Members of Congress, Stunned by Agnew's Move, Desert Floor for News Tickers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Congress was thunderstruck to day by Vice President Agnew's resignation.

title: CHOICE OF REAGAN CALLED UNLIKELY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10Two reasons make it improbable that President Nixon will nominate Gov. Ronald Reagan as Vice President, in the view of political observers here.

title: 2 Accused of Bank Holdup
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 10 (AP)  Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested John G, Coughlin, 30 years old, and Peter A. Pepe, 33, of New Haven yesterday on charges of having held up the Empire National Bank in Hyde Park, N.Y., last October. Officials said $31,000 was taken in the robbery.

title: A Chronology of Events in Agnew Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Following is a chronology of events leading to Vice President Agnew's resignation:

title: Israel Claiming Heights
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday, Oct. 11 Israel said last night that the Syrian Army on the Golan heights had been driven back to the 1967 ceasefire line, but Israeli forces fighting the Egyptians clearly seemed to have suspended a counterattack aimed at pushing them from the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

title: TWO CREATE DANCES ON BILL AT CUBICULO
description: One can only conclude that Reka Feketekuty's enthusiasm for creating dances is mistaken after seeing her joint concert with Thomas Holt on Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo. She has a talent for meaningless elaboration of gesture, but none for shaping a dance.

title: 17% ON ELPARE NEED INELIGIBLE
description: A new state checkup yesterday estimated 17.6 per cent of welfare family cases statewide were ineligible, far above the state's first such checkup, which reported 11.5 per cent ineligibility in the last half of 1972.

title: Charles Eisler, 89, Holder Of Patents for Glass Items
description: EAST ORANGE, Oct. 10Charles Eisler, president of the Eisler Engineering Company, which he founded in Newark 53 years ago, died Monday at his home here. His age was 89.

title: U.N.'s AntiIsrael Tone
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10The Security Council met yesterday in an atmosphere filled with hostility toward Israel.

title: ROCKEFELLER SAID TO BE AVAILABLE
description: Governor Rockfeller would accept the Vice Presidency it it were offered to him with no qualifications, some of the Governor's closest advisers said yesterday.

title: Mets in World Series; Defeat Reds for Flag
description: The New York Mets completed their sixweek odyssey from last place to the National League pennant yesterday when they overpowered the favored Cincinnati Reds, 72, in a tumultuous game that rocked and almost ruined Shea Stadium.

title: Cambodian Premier Tells Nation on TV That He Is Quitting
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Premier In Tam announced today that he had submitted his resignation to President Lon Nol. He gave no reason for his decision.

title: Ron Johnson Drills With Giants Again
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 10The New York Giants countered the departure of one Johnson (Randy) with the return of another (Ron) today. Ron changed his program from running up the stadium steps at Roosevelt Stadium to running plays in pass patterns in a Giant offense that has sagged noticeably.

title: Emergency Court Backs Gasoline Price Ceilings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals upheld on today the Government's Phase a ceilings on retail gasoline prices.

title: FEAR EXPRESSED ON SCHOOL RULING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 10School officials here expressed fear today that a decision by a State Department of Education examiner to allow white suburban students to transfer out of the overcrowded New Brunswick High School might set back the cause of racial integration throughout New Jersey.

title: Text of Mrs. Meir's Address to Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Following is the official text, translated from the Hebrew, of an address by Premier Golda Meir on television:

title: People in Sports: Wilt Is Boxed Out by Judge
description: Professional basketball will not be able to see Wilt Chamberlain play this year, according to a ruling yesterday by a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles, unless he plays for the Los Angeles Lakers. Judge Campbell Lucas issued a temporary restraining order while details of the injunction were worked out.

title: Detective and 2 TV Men Beaten At Funeral of Mafia Chief's Son
description: Two television cameramen and a police detective were severely beaten yesterday morning outside a Brooklyn church at the funeral of Leonard Vario, son of the reputed Mafia leader Paul Vario.

title: Personal Finance: Easing Travel Plans
description: Who is responsible for disrupted travel plans? Suppose you believe you have a reservation at the Xanadu Plaza and the desk clerk professes never to have heard of you or your travel agent. Can you force the travel agent, the wholesaler who puts together a travel package deal, the carrier or the hotel to make amends?

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yestenday was:

title: Irresponsibility ...
description: We shall resist aggressive foreign policies. Dtente cannot survive irresponsibility in any area, including the Middle East. When Secretary of State Kissinger first pronounced those words in a speech two days after Egypt and Syria had begun their assault on Israel, a subordinate quickly denied that they were intended either as an accusation of irresponsibility by the Soviet Union in the Middle East or as a warning to Moscow against the possible consequences of Soviet intervention.

title: Sandman Aides Lay Dirty Tricks to Byrne Men
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10  The Repulicans managing Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s campaign for Governor charged today that the campaign forces of Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate, had broken into Sandman headquarters, maliciously destroyed Sandman campaign material and launched a whispering campaign to create personal suspicion about the Sandman family. Asked if they had any evidence to support their charges, the Republicans said they did not.

title: Dance: Dream Opens Joffrey Season
