description: A little later than usual, and for a little shorter than usual, but the Joffrey Ballet is back at the City Center 55 Street Theater. The season this time is only four weeks, so rush.

title: Love Urges Deregulation Of Natural Gas Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  John A. Love, President Nixon's energy adviser, called today for the deregulation of the price of natural gas to help solve the fuel shortage problem.

title: Nominee as Adviser Emphasizes Need for Consistency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 William J. Fellner, President Nixon's nominee to the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that controlling inflation requires a consistent Government policy of forcing slowdowns in the economy whenever the rate of inflation exceeds a preestablished acceptable level.

title: Big Board Seat Price Up
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday a memship was sold late Tuesday for $155,000, up $5,000 from the previous sale on Oct. 4.

title: Mixed Reaction Expressed on Stepdown
description: Businessmen expressed shock and dismay yesterday by the news that Vice President Agnew had resigned and pleaded no contest to charges of income tax evasion.

title: CERRO TAKEOVER IS NOT IMMINENT
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 10 (Reuters) President Juan Velasco Alarado was incorrectly reported in a Reuters dispatch yesterday as having said that the Peruvian assets of the Cerro Corporation would be nationalized imminently.

title: Citizens Union Shift on Controller Gives Support to Goldin, Not Lewisohn
description: The board of directors of the Citizens Union, in an unusual action, has reversed the over. whelming endorsement of Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn for City Controller and has endorsed State Senator Harrison J. Goldin.

title: New Show Helps Clarify Miro's Art
description: Torn, between love and duty, and unable to tell which was which, this reporter crossed the picket line at the Museum a Modern Art a couple of days ago to take a look at the new Mir exhibition, which open to the public yesterday in spite of the current strike by the Professional and Administrative Staff Association (PASTA) of the museum. Some staff. members closely connected with the exhibition and its catalogue were out there in the line, but after half an hour's amicable discussion they gave me their blessing in the form of a PASTA button as a kind of moral press pass.

title: Bomb Explodes in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 10 (UPI)A bomb exploded near a gasoline station in Belfast today causing little! damage and no casualties, the police said, Protestant extremists claimed responsibility for planting the bomb.

title: QUARTER NET OFF AT WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday lower net income for the third quarter and nine months despite higher sales in both periods.

title: Flames Tie Islanders On 2dPeriod Goal, 11
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP)John Stewart's goal late in the second period tonight gave the Atlanta Flames a 11 deadlock with the New York Islanders in the National Hockey League season opener for both teams.

title: Hunch Betting of Baseball Fans Fails
description: Their money was at the Belmont windows but their hearts were at Shea Stadium yesterday as 13,270 racegoers followed the baseball scores flashed on the tote board and vainly searched for hunch bets.

title: COST OF TRAINING DOCTORS STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10It costs $16,300 to $26,400 a year to educate a medical student in the United States, the Association of American Medical Schools said in a report today.

title: O.S.A. Says Agnew Office Made Overtures on Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Arthur F. Sampson, administrator of the General Services Administration, said today that Vice President Agnew's office, on a number of occasions, had urged his agency to select certain companies for Government contracts.

title: Cards Drop Maynard, Pros' No. 1 Receiver
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals today released Don Maynard; the National Football League's career leading receiver in boht catches and yardage.

title: The Arab Shift on Oil
description: VIENNA, Oct. 10The frustrations of Arab leaders in resolving their problems with Israel have caused them to concentrate increasingly on their vast oil reserves as the ultiate means for forcing the United States to modify or even abandon its support of Israel. There, is nothing new about the fact that much of the world's oil comes from the sands and shallow offshore waters of the Middle East. What is new is the realization by the United States and other industrial consumer countries that over the next few years, until alternative sources of energy are within economic reach, there could well be a gap between ever rising demands for oil and the supply.

title: $80,000 in Dresses Stolen From Truck in Park Slope
description: Three men hijacked a truck in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday and stole $80,000 worth of dresses, the police reported.

title: Prayer and Tears at Jerusalem Wall
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 10A silvery full moon rose over the Western Wall this evening at the start of the festival, of Succoth, one of the most joyous in the Jewish year.

title: Marijuana Burned
description: SMITHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10 (UPI)A crowd of about 200 persons gathered yesterday to watch police put the torch to an estimated $1million worth of marijuana they found last week. The plants were doused with kerosene and set ablaze behind the jail on the DeKalb County Courthouse square.

title: California Bar Is Ordered to Admit ExDissident
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10The California State Supreme Court has ordered admission to the state bar for Daniel M. Siegel, a law graduate of the University of California and a leader in the 1969 dispute over a People's Park.

title: Books of The Times
description: Economics may well be the dismal science, but there's nothing less dismal than a good book about money. And in a decade that's produced an unusual number of good ones, John Brooks's latest, The GoGo Years, seems to me one of the best. For if Adam Smith's reports flew us on eyeopening joy rides straight through the heart of the Wall Street jungle  if The Times of London Insight team slithered exuberantly to the very bottom of Bernie Cornfeld's swamp in Do You Sincerely Want to Be Rich?then Mr. Brooks's new book is a luxurious 747 flight from which we can suddenly discern the entire terrain of the stock market in the nineteensixties. Oh, I know there are grounds for flagging ms night to a stop before it takes off: some will say that Wall Street no longer deserves to be viewed as a mirror of American society; others will worry about Mr. Brooks's admiration for the political middleoftheroaders who helped to bail the Street out of bankruptcy in the early seventies (if principles lying somewhere between conservatism and liberalism can still be characterized as middle of the road); and still others will wonder at the note of wistfulness with which Mr. Brooks wonders if the Wall Street he once knew and loved (sort of) is now dying.

title: Critical View of Fashion Strikes a Responsive Chord
description: An article by Gloria Emerson describing the slavishness of women toward the fashion trend of the moment, published on the Family Style Page last Friday, generated scores of letters that applauded the points raised. Two dissenters telephoned. Following is a sampling of the letters received.

title: Publisher of New Haven Papers Buys Gannett's Hartford Times
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10  The Hartford Himes was sold today by the Gannett Company for $8million to the Register Publishing Company of New Haven publishers of The New Haven Register and The New Haven JournalCourier.

title: Mrs. John Kunkle, 95, Dies; Former Missionary in China
description: Mrs. Julia Mitchell Kunkle, a former missionary in China with her late husband, the Rev. 1Dr. John Stewart Kunkle, died Monday in Claremont, Calif. She was 95 years old.

title: Judge to Reconsider Banishing 3 Youths Who Set Fatal Fire
description: A Family Court judge said last night that he would consider reversing his decision to banish from New York State three youths found guilty of setting a tenement fire on May 8 that killed six persons.

title: Opera: A Faulty Faust
description: Since the New York City Opera's production of Faust has been designed with brilliant economy by Ming Cho Lee and staged with provocative imagination by Frank Corsaro, it can only be wished that the company had the right singers to go into it. The season's first performance of the Gounod work Tuesday night at the New York State Theater was often a sorry affair vocally.

title: Panel Lays Race Tensions to Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10A yearold report issued by the United States Civil Rights Commission says that national, state and local leaders were responsible for continuing racial tension in Cairo, Ill.

title: Colgate Asks 19 Students To Come Back From Israel
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 10 (UPI)Colgate University, for the second time in three days, has asked a study group staying in Israel to return to the United States at the earliest possible secure moment.

title: Space Engineer in the Dog World
description: The standard schnauzer, with his arched eyebrows, bristly mustache and luxuriant whiskers, is a rugged individualist. He doesn't take kindly to being a kennel dog, but wants to be in the house with the family. As a result, there are few large kennels. Most of our members, said Burton Yamada, president of the Standard Schnauzer Club of America, have only one or two dogs.

title: MRS. THOMAS MOONEY
description: Mrs. Sarah C. Mooney, widow of Thomas P. Mooney and mother of George A. Mooney, chairman of the Washington Heights Federal Sayings and Loan Association and former State Superintendent of. Banks, died yesterday at the Dover, (N. J.) General Hospital. Her age was 86. She leaves two other sons, Robert and Joseph.

title: AgnewNixon Exchange
description: October 10, 1973

title: Retail Sales Drop by 0.9%
description: September retail sales dipped 0.9 per cent below the August level in the second consecutive monthly decline, the Department of Commerce announced yesterday. Sales in August had dropped 1.3 per cent below July.

title: Resistant Rice Plants Sought for Asia
description: LOS BANOS, the Philippines, Oct. 5Such overused terms as miracle rice and the green revolution are voiced these days by the experts here at the International Rice Research Institute with the kind of irony that used to be reserved for the light at the end of the tunnel in Vietnam.

title: Leasco Seeks Name Mate
description: The Leasco Corporation said yesterday it would ask its shareholders to approve a change in the company's name to the Reliance Group, Inc. to give greater recognition to its chief operating subsidiary, the Reliance Insurance Companies, as well as to its position as a financial services company.

title: Jets Acquire Van Galder As a Backup Quarterback
description: In an effort to solve their critical quarterback shortage, the New York Jets yesterday picked up Tim Van Galder, a free agent and a former St. Louis Cardinals signalcaller. Although the Jets do not have to officially sign Van Galder until after today's workout, he's likely to stay with them.

title: Secret Service Chief Estimates Security at Two Nixon Estates Adds $500,000 to $10Million U.S. Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 The head of the Secret Service testified today that personnel costs to safeguard President Nixon's private residences at Key Biscayne, Fla., and San Clemente, Calif., added as much as $500,000 a year to the $10million in Federal funds already disclosed as having been spent on the two homes.

title: Whitlam Acts to End Rifts in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 10 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, facing deep political trouble, has announced that he will relinquish his secondary post of Minister of Foreign Affairs after his trip to Japan and China later this month.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Senator John J. Marchi urged yesterday that the state's socalled Sullivan Law be amended to provide mandatory prison for anyone in possession of firearm in the commission of crime.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: Baltimore vs. Oakland

title: Council Bars Some Price Rises Sought by Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10For the first time since January. the Cost of Living Council denied corporate price increases today on the basis of its profitmargin regulation.

title: Mets in World Series; Defeat Reds for Flag
description: The New York Mets completed their sixweek odyssey from last place to the National League pennant yesterday when they overpowered the favored Cincinnati Reds, 72, in a tumultuous game that rocked and almost ruined Shea Stadium.

title: Notes on People
description: Lenore Hershey was named editor of Ladies' Home Journal yesterday, succeeding John Mack Carter. Mrs. Hershey, who has been executive editor of the 90yearold magazine since last May, joined it in 1968. She will be its eighth editor and the second woman to hold the post. The other was the first editor, Louisa Knapp Curtis, wife of the founder, Cyrus H. K. Curtis.

title: Brunch Tries to Show U.N. Members That Americans Are Far From Ugly
description: Willard Warnock finished mixing the Sangria and plopped himself down onto the bright blue sofa, next to one of the guests of honor.

title: Executive Compensation Up
description: Compensation of corporate financial executives rose 8.7 per cent during 1972, the Financial Executives Institute said yesterday, These increases were within the guidelines established by the Federal Government, the institute said, because salary increases averaged only 5,9 per cent.

title: Newton Loses in High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Black Panther party leader Huey P. Newton has been denied a hearing by the Supreme Court on his contention that a police search that turned up a loaded gun was illegal. The high court declined yesterday to hear an appeal by Newton and a party member, Robert L. Bay, in their attempt to have the evidence obtained by the search ruled inadmissible.

title: A 10Mile Egyptian Gain
description: IN THE SINAI PENINSULA, Oct. 10  Egyptian soldiers, tanks and equipment are continuing to pour across the Suez Canal, a group of Western correspondents confirmed from the battle area today.

title: MERGER DEAL SET BY GENERAL HOST
description: Cook United, Inc., and the General Host Corporation said they had reached agreement in principle on basic terms of a proposed merger. Last week the two companies said they were conducting preliminary discussions. Under the proposal, General Host would issue one share of a new General Host voting convertible preferred stock for every share of Cook common. The preferred would have a cumulative annual dividend rate of 55 cents and would be convertible into one share of General Host common stock. Under the agreement, General Host would acquire Cook United.

title: A 10Mile Egyptian Gain
description: IN THE SINAI PENINSULA, Oct. 10  Egyptian solders, tanks and equipment are continuing to pour across the Suez Canal, a group of Western correspondents confirmed from the battle area today.

title: TV: Solid C.B.S. Fare
description: Prime time on the Columbia Broadcasting System network begins tonight at 8 with the exceptionally dependable The Waltons. At 9, Jackie Gleason returns with a typically splashy comedymusic special. And at 10, C.B.S. News takes over for an unusually touching hour in a documentary called A Boy Named Terry Egan.

title: $3,000 IS MISSING AT POLICE OFFICE
description: Despite the adoption of elaborate new safeguards following the disclosure last December of the theft of $73million worth of heroin and cocaine from the New York Police Department, $3,000 worth of cash apparently was stolen from the department's property clerk within the last week.

title: Train Kills Suffolk Man
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I., Oct. 10 (UPI)A 39yearold man was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train and killed at oclock last night while he was walking on the tracks near the station here, Suffolk County Police reported. They identified the victim as George Paynton of 25 Mulford Street, Patchogue, and said he was a patient at the Central Islip State Hospital.

title: Court Clears the Way On Bid for Texasgulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 (AP)A United States appeals court opened the way today for the Canada Development Corporation to proceed with its plan to purchase a controlling block of shares of Texasgulf, Inc.

title: JUDGE ACTS TO FREE FUNDS ON POLLUTION
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 10United States District Judge Jack Roberts has issued a summary judgment ordering the Nixon Administration to fully allocate impounded funds for water pollution control construction grants to the states.

title: MEN'S BAR SAYS IT'S ONLY A NAME
description: Would a men's bar that serves women be less discriminatory against them by any other name?

title: HEAD OF POLICE QUITS IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10  Police Superintendent James B. Conlisk Jr., under renewed fire after 19 police officers were convicted last week of extortion and perjury, submitted his resignation today.

title: EVIDENCE SHOWS GIFTS TO AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10Spiro T. Agnew, in three elective offices including the Vice Presidency, asked for and accepted cash payments totaling more than $100,000, according to the evidence gathered against him by the United States Attorneys in Baltimore.

title: CONGRESS TO VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10President Nixon began his search today for a successor to Vice President Agnew amid indications that he will face stiff resistance from Congress if he chooses anyone who might qualify as a strong Republican candidate in 1976.

title: SKELETON CALLED MISSING WOMAN'S
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 10The Nassau County police today identified the skeleton found in a wooded area of North Hills yesterday as that of Mary Ellen O'Callaghan, who had been reported missing by the New York City and Nassau police five months ago.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Source of Salmonella Is Sought

title: BigPower Efforts Termed Key to Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Nixon Administration officials said today that direct SovietAmerican discussions seemed to hold the key to an early settlement of the Middle East crisis.

title: Big Artillery and Air Battles Mark Syrian Retreat in Golan
description: RAFID, on the Golan Heights, Oct. 10Israeli tanks and planes continued to hammer the Syrian Army today, breaking through the ceasefire line into Syrian territory for the first time in five days of fighting.

title: McLaughlin, City Aide, Named To Head Suffolk Health Agency
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 10Dr. Mary C. McLaughlin, the deputy director of the New York City Health Services Administration, has agreed to take on the job as the first head of Sufolk County's newly created health superagency.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Wins Court Stay on Press Curb
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Inquirer won a stay today of a Federal judge's order banning the press from publishing background criminal information about a perjury trial defendant.

title: Two Held in a Double Street Gang Stabbing on Lower East Side
description: The police have arrested two men in a double stabbing in a street gang dispute on the Lower East Side, and have made two additional arrests of members of a leftist political group charged with interfering with the police.

title: Events Today
description: CARRIAGE TRADE, a silent film by Warren Sonbert, at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: BYRNE TO COUNTER APATHY OF VOTER
description: UNION, Oct. 10Ackno?? edging the existence of some voter apathy in an elective year that does not offer a con test for the Presidency, aide to Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, said today that Mr. Byrne would step up his street campaigning and public exposure.

title: Space Engineer in the Dog World
description: The standard schnauzer, with his arched eyebrows, bristly mustache and luxuriant whiskers, is a rugged individualist. He doesn't take kindly to being a kennel dog, but wants to be in the house with the family. As a result, there are few large kennels. Most of our members, said Burton Yamada, president of the Standard Schnauzer Club of America, have only one or two dogs.

title: MORE HELP IS URGED FOR BLACK VETERANS
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 10 (AP) Black veterans largely have been ignored by state and local governments, the Connecticut National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said in a report today.

title: GROUP REPORTS DOWNING COPTER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (AP)A group calling itself the August Seventh Guerrilla Movement has claimed responsibility for the sniper attack last week on an Oakland police helicopter in which two officers were killed.

title: Cahill Subjects Projects To Environment Studies
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10Gover nor Cahill has issued an executive order requiring state departments and agencies to file environmental impact studies for all major projects, the Governor's office announced today.

title: In Co Twirling Needles, And Out Comes a Tooth
description: PISCATAWAY, Oct. 10A 20yearold dental hygienist had a wisdom tooth extracted today, with acupuncture instead of traditional pain killers as the anesthetic.

title: The Farms Are in New Jersey, but the Crop Is Pure Chinese
description: CRANBURY, N. J.The weather has been kind, and either the sunshine or the aluminum foil laid between the rows has discouraged the aphids. As a result, New Jersey is harvesting what looks like a record crop of bok toy.

title: Southern Railway Sets Order
description: The Southern Railway announced yesterday it had placed orders with Pullman Standard, a division of Pullman, Inc., for 1,800 new general purpose box cars costing $35million. The delivery of the cars would begin in January and be completed in the second quarter of next year.

title: Texas Court Bars Resentencing Under Eased Law on Marijuana
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 10 The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals struck down as unconstitutional today legislation that would have allowed persons convicted under Texas' stringent old marijuana law to be resentenced under a new liberalized statute.

title: Shaheen Dedicates Canada Refinery
description: COME BY CHANCE, Newfoundland, Oct. 10John M. Shaheen, the New York City millionaire with extensive oil holdings, today dedicated the first of the three refineries that he is building in eastern Canada at a total cost of $730million.

title: Modern Art Strike Mediation Delayed
description: Pickets marched for the second day outside the Museum of Modern Art yesterday, and a state mediator said he would not call the two sides together until he saw some possibility of meaningful negotiations.

title: Tomorrow the World
description: The incredible Mets did it again. By clobbering the Cincinnati Reds in the decisive game of the National League playoff, New York's miracle men have fought their way into the World Series.

title: JURY CONVICTS 3 IN HEROIN TRIAL
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10A Federal Court jury tonight returned guilty verdicts against two men and a woman charged in a smuggling conspiracy case.

title: Agnew's Resignation Casts Pall Over the Campaign of Sandman
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10  The resignation of Vice President Agnew cast a heavy pall this evening over the Republican gubernatorial campaign of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.

title: Judge Says Nixon Must Give States Clean Water Funds
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 10 (UPI) A Federal judge, rejecting President Nixon's claim of sovereign immunity, has ordered the President to turn over to the states $6billion in water pollution control funds that he impounded last year.

title: G.O.P. Legislator Backs DelBello for Executive
description: YONKERS, Oct. 9The race for County Executive in Westchester took an unexpected turn today when Assemblyman J. Edward Meyer, a Republican, endorsed the Democratic candidate, Makor Alfred B. DelBello of Yonkers.

title: Farmers Market Revived After 72 Years
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 10Along the curbs of a short block at the center of the city every Tuesday this summer a tradition that died 72 years ago came alive againa booming farmer's market.

title: Air Battles Rage Over Syria as Israeli Warplanes Strike at Airfields and Ports
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct 10Syrian warplanes, reinforced by Iraqi jets, today battled waves of Israeli fighterbombers that struck at air bases, ports and oil refineries.

title: Iraqi Air and Ground Forces Reported in War on 2 Fronts
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10The Iraqi military command announced today that its air and ground forces had joined the war against Israel and were taking an active part in the fighting on both fronts.

title: U.N. COUNCIL FAVORS A DELAY ON MIDEAST
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10Members of the Security Council expressed reluctance today to hold another open meeting while Middle East military reports showed that Israel and the Arab countries appeared determined to go on fighting.

title: COPPER COMPANIES DENY CHILE TALKS
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Anaconda Company said in separate statements yesterday that they had no negotiations with Chilean authorities on compensation for their expropriated properties in Chile.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF ON AGNEW ACTION
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange, up early in the day, dropped sharply at the close with the announcement of the resignation of Vice President Agnew. The overthecounter market reacted in similar fashion.

title: I.R.S. Sees Nothing to Prevent New Tax Cases Against Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 10Former Vice President Agnew's plea of no contest today in the incometax evasion case against him could mark only the beginning of difficulties for him with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Judge Orders Fine, 3 Years' Probation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Spiro T. Agnew resigned as vice President of the United States today under an agreement with the Department of Justice to admit evasion of Federal income taxes and avoid imprisonment.

title: A Vice President Who Extolled the Old Virtues
description: Until his trouble, the life of Spiro Theodore Agnew seemed to be a cliche American story. It was the tale of a man whose father and kin came from the remote, rugged hills and rock of the Peloponnesus in Southtern Greece. The father wanted to escape the dreariness of his life as a notary public, and so, in 1911, set sail for the United States, where Mr. Agnew was born and rose to be Vice President of the United States.

title: Bridge: Duplicate Play Is Traced To 19thCentury Whist Ace
description: A century ago the great authority on whist, the ancestor of bridge, was Henry Jones of London, who chose the pseudonym Cavendish. One of his most significant contributions seemed trivial at the time.

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterday a decline in operating earnings in the third quarter as the spread between the rates it paid for funds and the rates it earned on loans and securities narrowed.

title: Persistent Graffiti Anger Lindsay on Subway Tour
description: Mayor Lindsay took a midtown walk yesterday to observe traffic conditions, but a subway ride on the Lexington Avenue IRT Line from Grand Central to Brooklyn Bridge aroused his indignation about widespread graffiti on trains and stations.

title: Star of XMovie Subpoenaed
description: COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10 (UPI)Linda Lovelace, star of the Xrated movie Deep Throat, has been subpoenaed to appear at an obscenity trial here in United States District Court. The trial involves obscenity charges against Stanley Marks, owner of the Cinema X Theater in Newport, Ky.; Harry Mohoney and Guy Weir of Michigan; the American Amusement Company, Inc.; and The American News Company, Inc., both of Durand, Mich. Deep Throat was seized in a raid on the theater last Feb. 27.

title: Yancey's 65 Paces Golf By 2 Shots
description: INZAIMACHI, Japan, Oct. 11 (UPI)Bert Yancey of the United States carded a sixunderpar 65 and took a twostroke lead today in the first round of the $300,000 Taiheyo Pacific Club Masters golftournament.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SOYBEANS UP
description: An accumulation of overnight buy orders resulted in a strong opening for prices of soybeans on the Chicago Board of Trade. The November contract that had closed at $6.36 soon jumped the 20centabushel limit to $6.56 before profit taking cut the gains. At the close the delivery was $6.50.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Notes on People
description: From now on, said Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, there will be an open stance policy by which the F.B.I. will deal with the press.

title: Musicians Talks Broken Off
description: James J. McFadden, a state mediator, said yesterday that formal talks between striking musicians and the New York Philharmonic Society had broken off. Representatives from both sides had resumed negotiations Tuesday in the 16dayold strike. Mr. McFadden said he would report to Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, before taking any further steps.

title: Talks on Pipeline Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI)  HouseSenate negotiations on differing bills to permit construction of the transAlaska oil pipeline will be completed early next week two key negotiators said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.T. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: An Apparently Stoical Agnew Attends Family Funeral
description: RANDALLSTOWN, Md., Oct. 11The funeral of his halfbrother brought Spiro T. Agnew back to his beginnings in suburban Baltimore today. On the surface, little had changed.

title: COSTS OF MEDICARE CO IMP $103MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Twentythree million aged and disabled persons on Medicare will have to pay an additional $103million for hospital care next year, according to new Government figures.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO RETAKE POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. today denounced what he called excessive executive power for foreign affairs and urged Congress to reassert its primary responsibility for the determination of substantive foreign policy.

title: Tomorrow Is Last Day To Register for Voting
description: Tomorrow is the final day to register for the Nov. 6 elections in the state.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: U,S ARID TO DEFER MAJORRIS HELP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 The United States is supplying Israel with ammunition and missiles, officials said today, but it is reported to be holding back on any decision on a largescale resupply program as it continues to hope that military and diplomatic factors will bring the Middle East conflict to an end.

title: FUEL RATION PLAN DRAWN UP BY CITY
description: Heating and hot water to 600,000 tenants in cityowned housing would be sharply curtailed under contingency plans adopted by the Housing Authority for periods of severe fuel shortages.

title: The Dance: The Joffrey in Its General Repertory
description: The Joffrey Ballet moved into its general repertory at the City Center 55th Street Theater with the smoothness of a RollsRoyce changing gearshould a RollsRoyce ever have to. After a first night that offered the successful New York premiere of its production of Ashton's The Dream, the company last night relied upon two proven audience favorites, Kettentanz and Deuce Coupe, and a revival of Facade, a work not seen for two or three season.

title: Matlack Slated to Open Series for Mets
description: Within an hour after the Oakland A's had won the American League pennant yesterday, the New York Mets reassembled and headed for California for the World Serieswhile work crews tried to repair the battlefield left behind at Shea Stadium.

title: Golden Gate's Toll Of Suicides kises To 500, Then 501
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (UPI)The Golden Gate Bridge, long a lure to suicides, has claimed its 500th and 501st victims.

title: Agnew Bargaining Began on Sept. 13
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11As early as Sept. 13and despite vehement later denialsSpiro T. Agnew informed the Justice Department through his lawyers that he was prepared to resign from the Vice President's office in exchange for an end of the Government's criminal prosecution of him, sources close to Mr. Agnew said today.

title: Fire in Oceanside Destroys Boat Showroom and Shop
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Oct. 11 (UPI) Fire destroyed a onestory combination boat show room and repair shop here late Iasi night, the county police reported.

title: Warburg Rites on Monday
description: A memorial service for Frederick M. Warburg, investment banker, sportsman and philanthropist, will be held Monday) at 11.30 A.M., in Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street. Mr. Warburg, who was formerly senior partner of Kuhn Loeb & Co., dies Jtily 10 in Winchester, Va., at the age of 75.

title: People and Business
description: David A. Orr has been designated as the next chairman of Unilever, Ltd., the part of the giant BritishDutch consumer package goods company with headquarters in England.

title: Seagull Author Seeks Ban Against Film of His Book
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 11 (UPI) Attorneys for novelist Richard Bach said today that they would seek an injunction against release of the film version of the author's bestselling book, Jonathan Livingston Seagull.

title: Woman Jailed Again for Trying to Block Sewer Line
description: HACKETTSTOWN, Oct. 11A Hackettstown woman who has fought for six years against efforts to connect a sewer on her property to the town's sewer remained in the Warren County Jail today as workers for the Hackettstown Municipal Utilities Authority began connection work on her property.

title: Arab and Jewish Groups Stage Rallies in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Jewish and Arab groups staged rival rallies spurred by the Middle East war today in front of the White House.

title: Mara: Only Passing Interest in Randy
description: Randy Johnson's market value as a quarterback may have dropped sharply with his decision to leave the New York Giants this week.

title: Oakland Wins Pennant
description: The Oakland A's won the American League pennant yesterday by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 30, behind the fivehit pitching of Jim (Catfish) Hunter. The A's will meet the New York Mets in the opener of the 70th World Series in Oakland tomorrow. Details on Page 53.

title: Texts of Syrian Communiques on War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11 (AP)Following, in unofficial. English translation, are some texts of military communiques issued by Syria today:

title: Police Promotions Today
description: Promotion exercises for 44 members of the Police Department will be held today at 11 A.M. on the mall of the new Police Headquarters at 1 Police Plaza. Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley will attend.

title: Americans in Laos Seeking Word of Kin Missing in War
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 11 (AP)A group of Americans seeking information about relatives missing in action in Lads arrived in Vientiane today.

title: Israeli Gain in Mobility Is Seen
description: Israel's successes against Syria can have a striking effect on the military and political development of the Middle East war. By establishing ground and air superiority on the northern front, the. Israelis, United States and British analysts believe, have achieved a greater freedom of maneuver on all fronts. Politically, the Golan heights advance is likely to have the maximum impact on Jordon, still out of the battle but with her armed forces mobilizing. Israeli forces moving off the heights are now not only within striking distance of the Syrian capital, Damascus, but also on or near Jordan's northern frontier 40 to 50 miles from Amman, the capital.

title: Future of Stock Markets: A Global Assessment
description: Officials of stock exchanges around the world met this week behind closed doors at the New York Stock Exchange to debate their problems and explore future opportunities for cooperation.

title: Giants, Jets Face Another Rough Sunday
description: The big game on Sunday is in Los Angeles where the Cowboys take on the surprise team, the unbeaten Rams. Channel 2 will not televise that contest here, bat if you have the antenna capability you Can pick it up from Channel 3, Hartford, or Channel 10, Philadelphia, at 4 P.M. Channel 2 will televise, the Giants against the Redskins at New Haven, 1 P.M. Channel 4 will bring you the Jets at New England, also 1 P.M. before the Weed Series game in Oakland. The Giants and Jets are underdogs. Here is a preview of all games with monlosttied records in parentheses:

title: Cevert Rites Draw Racers
description: PARIS, Oct. 11 (AP)  A crowd of mourners attended St. Pierre de Neuilly Church here today for the funeral of Francois Cevert, the autoracing driver killed Saturday on the race course at Watkins Glen, N. Y. Among the autoracing figures attending were Mr. Cevert's team manager, Ken Tyrrell; his teammate, Jackie Stewart, and fellow racing drivers, including Graham Hill, Emerson Fittipaldi, Denis Hulme and Jody Scheckter.

title: FOOTBALL TONIGHT
Sports News Briefs
description: The Liggett & Myers Company announced yesterday that it would no longer sponsor the $250,000 United Sates Professional matchplay championship and the Liggett & Myers open on the pro golf tour next year. The tourneys were played at the MacGregor Downs Country Club, Cary, N. C., this year after Pinehurst, N.C., had been the site for the two previous years.

title: Arthur Menken, Photographer For War Newsreels, Dies at 70
description: Arthur Menken, a forme newsreel photographer and explorer, died at his home in Florence, Italy, Wednesday, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Byrne, in Debate With Sandman, Calls for Integrity in Government
description: TRENTON. Oct 11Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, declared; today that the need for integrity in government was an issue that should weigh heavily in the determination of next month's election.

title: G.O.P. WOMEN HURT BY AGNEW ACTION
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11Almost two weeks ago, Dorothy Goodknight heard Spiro T. Agnew tell a cheering convention of Republican women here that he was innocent of all criminal charges against him and would refuse to resign, even if indicted.

title: Hawks Conquer Lakers, 129102
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 11 (AP)Lou Hudson, who finished with 34 points, keyed a thirdperiod Atlanta rally and led the Hawks to a 129102 National BasketballAssociation victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: Baltimore vs. Oakland

title: First Contingent of 80 Pathet Lao Officials Arrives in Vientiane
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Friday, Oct. 12A first contingent of 80 Pathet Lao officials and troops arrived here today aboard Soviet airliners from Hanoi to begin work on the creation of a Laotian coalition government under the terms of the Laotian peace agreement.

title: Mead Net Rose 120% in Quarter
description: Profits of a widely diversified field of businesses are matching or exceeding the gains of the two previous quarters this year, according to the first flood of three and ninemonth financial statements reported yesterday. The Pabst Brewing Company and Magnavox were the only two major companies reporting yesterday to show a decline in earnings.

title: Blacks, Citing Perjury, Ask Turco to Quit Newark Post
description: NEWARK, Oct. 11Black leaders expressed strong opposition today to Council President Louis M. Turco's continued presence on the Council. They acted two days after Mr. Turco pleaded guilty to Federal incometax charges.

title: Arab Diplomats Explain Aims of Limited War
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Arab diplomats stationed here said today that the aim of their limited war was to establish a new equilibrium in the Middle East by compelling Israel to withdraw from at least part of the territory she captured in 1967.

title: The Man Who Vetoed the Idea of Nudie Frutti Ice Cream
description: BURBANK, Calif.If you have ever had cause to wonder about such things as ice creams named. Here Comes the Fudge, or Red, White and Blueberry, or Pink Bubble Gum, well, there is a man behind the madness.

title: Many Tourists Going to Israel Cancel Trips Because of War
description: The war in the Middle East has caused postponement or cancellation of many, but by no means all, trips to Israel by American tourists.

title: ISRAELIS PUSH 6 MILES INTO SYRIA, WRECKING DOZENS OF FOE'S TANKS; REPORTS FROM SINAI VARY WIDELY
description: ON THE CEASEFIRE LINE, in the Golan Heights, Oct. 11A large Israeli armored force pushed out of the Golan heights in the direction of Damascus today, smashing through Syrian defenses and leaving dozens of burning Syrian tanks in its wake.

title: Pop Music: Smoothness In Leslie Uggams Songs
description: Leslie Uggams, who has long since shrugged off, Sing Along With Mitch background, is one of those flamboyant theatrical sylists beloved of the nightclub situation, which requires much flash, a little filigree and nothing to boggle the mind. Even Miss Uggams's women's lib references were painless.

title: New Nickel Refinery Opens
description: The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., formally opened yesterday its $140million nickel refinery at Sudbury, Ontario. The new refinery and related facilities have an annual capacity of 100million pounds of nickel pellets and 25million pounds of nickel and nickeliron powders.

title: WASHBASIN QUOTA IS CURBED BY COURT
description: ALBANY, Oct. 11 (AP)An appeals court has ruled against a new Federal standard requiring an increase in the number of wash basins available in business offices and industrial plants.

title: League of Women Voters Starts Equal Rights Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11 (AP)  The League of Women Voters has opened a nationwide campaign to raise money for the Equal Rights Amendment, which must win approval of eight more states by 1979 if it is to become part of the Constitution.

title: Sheriffs at Upstate School
description: AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 11 (UPI) Cayuga County Sheriff's deputies were on duty today at Auburn High School following a fight between black and white students. Peter kachris, principal of the school, said about 20 students were involved in an outdoor brawl yesterday during the noon hour. Two persons, a teacher trying to break up the (fracas, and a black girl, were injured.

title: Transcript of the Attorney General's News Conference on Agnew Resignation
description: Following is a transcript of a news conference in Washington yesterday by Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson and United States Attorney George Beall of Maryland as recorded by The New York Times. Some questions have been paraphrased because portions of them were inaudible.

title: Senators Favor Joint Hearings on Agnew Successor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Senate leaders failed to reach agreement today on procedures to confirm a successor to former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, but they did suggest holding joint hearings with the House to screen President Nixon's nominee.

title: 3 Filipinos Seize Airliner Briefly; Hostage Frees It
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 11 Three young Filipinos hijacked a plane in the Philippines today and flew it to Hong Kong with the president of the airline as hostage.

title: Lewisohn for Controller
description: As New York City's chief fiscal officer, the Controller serves as a valuable check on actions and policies of the Mayor, reviewing proposed municipal budgets, examining spending priorities, suggesting modifications and economies. The Controller has an ongoing responsibility to investigate agencies and programs and to spur efficiency. He manages the city's vast sinking and, trust funds.

title: Loan Bias Against Women Cited; A Banker Denies It Is Top Policy
description: The president of the New York State Bankers Association, Howard Cross, conceded yesterday that banks might discriminate against women in making loans, but he said that the men at the top were not responsible.

title: Head of du Pont Protests Denial of Price Increase
description: Charley B. McCoy, chairman of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., yesterday protested to the Cost of Living Council against the council's denial of a prenotified price increase for photographic equipment, which the Government agency said would have caused the company to exceed its baseperiod profit margin.

title: SLATER IN TALKS FOR HORIZON CORP.
description: Slater, Walker of America, Inc., announced yesterday that it was holding discussions to acquire the Horizon Corporation, developer and builder of new home communities, primarily in the Southwest.

title: TV: C.B.S. Dracula Film Loses Bite
description: Even with a good color production and chilling portions, tonight's madeforTV Dracula can't touch the old Hollywood tingler, a homescreen perennial, or England's Horror of Dracula, best of the theater followups. And Jack Palance, gritting his fangs in agony and occasionally roaring like King Kong, is no Bela Lugosi or Christopher Lee. The new British enterprise, running two hours with commercials (and let's hope they're not for tomato juice or toothpaste), starts at 9 over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: Put Ingredients on Label, Cosmetics Makers Told
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (Reuters)The Food and Drug Administration today ordered manufacturers of all cosmetics to list ingredients on product labels and report complaints received about their products to the Government twice yearly.

title: Agnew's Status Unsettled in Areas of His Civil Rights and Any Future Litigation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Spiro T. Agnew's plea yesterday of no contest to a tax evasion charge left him, as one of his lawyers put it today, with a judgment of conviction. But what that conviction means, in terms of any further legal proceedings and what rights he loses or retains, neither the lawyer nor anyone else seemed to know for certain.

title: OFFICIALS DEBATE REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 One year after President Nixon signed it into law, revenue sharing was praised and condemned today in the first national public scrutiniy of the program that sends Federal funds back to local communities.

title: U.S. SAID TO DEFER MAJOR ARMS NEIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 The United States is supplying Israel with ammunition and missiles, officials said today, but it is reported to be holding back on any decision on a largescale resupply program as it continues to hope that military and diplomatic factors will bring the Middle East conflict to an end.

title: They Don't Do It Like They Used To
description: So the World Series is upon us, and a lot of it will be played at night, and millions and millions of people will be watching it on television, those parts of it, at least, that are allowed to come through between commercials.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 11Rutgers and Lafayette have played each other in football 68 times since 1882, with Rutgers holding a 38291 wonlosttied record. Since 1945, Rutgers has won 26 of 29 games and when the two meet again Saturday, Rutgers will count on the running attack. With a runner like Jim Jennings, no one blames the Scarlet.

title: Seoul University Disciplines 97 Students for Protests
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 11Seoul National University announced disciplinary action today against 97 students for staging antiGovernment demonstrations last week. Twentythree were expelled.

title: PRESS LAW UPHELD ON USING REPLIES
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP)  The Florida Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its ruling that newspapers must print the response of political, candidates to critical editorials.

title: Search Resumes for Sailors,
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., Oct. 11 (AP)The Coast Guard resumed its search today for two persons and their 19foot sailboat, which capsized last night, the Coast Guard said. The identities of the persons were not released. A spokesman at the New Haven, Conn., Coast Guard station said the boat had capsized near the Nissequogue River in Smithtown Bay on Long Island's north shore.

title: Music: Ohlsson Bravura
description: Garrick Ohlsson earned his international reputation as a contestant, winning the 1970 Chopin competition in Warsaw. Since that time the tall pianist has made a career of astounding audiences with his powerhouse technique and bravura style. His recital at Hunter College Playhouse on Wednesday night did not break that pattern.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Oct. 11 were:

title: Boy, 4, Attacked With Acid, Regains Sight in One Eye
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 11 (UPI)  Joshua Miele of Brooklyn, the 4yearold victim of an acid attack, regained partial sight in one eye and was able to walk yesterday. However, doctors at Brooke Army Medical Center said the boy was still seriously ill in the burn ward.

title: Stocks Stage Rally; Dow Climbs by 15.5
description: The stock market staged a strong rally yesterday, in an abrupt turnabout from the pounding it took in the final hour on Wednesday when the sudden resignation of Vice President Agnew caught investors by surprise.

title: THE TOLL IN CHILE MAY NOW BE 2,000
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11More than 2,000 people may have been killed in the month since a military coup toppled the Marxist coalition government in Chile.

title: Senate Unit Backs Parker
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Daniel Parker to be the new foreign aid administrator. Mr. Parker, chairman of the Parker Pen Company, is to succeed John A. Hannah, who has retired as administrator of the Agency for International Development.

title: Bedlam at Turtle Bay
description: Secretary General Waldheim's somber appeal for United Nations action to stop the fighting and press for real peace in the Middle East has as much chance of being heard as a whisper in Bedlam.

title: AUSTRALIA ALLOWS POLES EXHIBIT HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Beginning here, late this month, Americans will ha re their last opportunity to view Jackson Pollock's Blue Poles before it becomes part of the collection of the Australian National Gallery in Canberra.

title: Agnew Cops a Plea
description: Spiro T. Agnew has copped a plea and bargained himself out of going to jail. Conceding incometax evasion and the acceptance of money gifts outside his official salary, while the Justice Department dropped numerous other criminal charges against him, Mr. Agnew is getting off with a $10,000 fine, a suspended sentence and a Dear Ted letter from the President. That, apparently, is what the public trust is worth to the Nixon Administration that made this deal.

title: Conferees Approve $21Billion For Weapons Procurement Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) House and Senate conferees abandoned today a Democratic budgetcutting drive and approved a $21.3billion weapons procurement bill: The sum is higher than either house had previously approved.

title: Even Partying, The Lindsays Have the City On Their Minds
description: It was just another evening for John and Mary Lindsay, though it could have been called the Night of the Skyline.

title: Other News Of the War In Mideast
description: ATHENS, Oct. 11The Foreign Ministry announced today that it would protest the sinking of a Greek freighter during an Israeli raid against the Syrian port of Latakia early yesterday in which two crewmen were killed and seven slightly injured.

title: Aluminum Workers' Goal
description: PITTSBURG, Oct. 11 (UPI)Delegates to a United Steelworkers' Aluminum Conference adopted today a  contract proposal demanding very substantial wage increases and cost of living escalator for pensions to counter inflation.

title: Stocks on Amex Rise Sharply; Counter Market Also Recovers
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange registered yesterday their sharpest gains since the exchange instituted its new marketvalue index last Sept. 4. A similar situation prevailed in the overthecounter market as evidently both markets recovered from the shock of Vice President Agnew's resignation.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Summary

title: Feb. 25 Start Asked for Racing
CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Newport News Shipbuilding & Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of Tenneco, Inc., received a $32.8million Navy contract for overhaul and conversion of the submarine Woodrow Wilson to the Poseidon missile

title: Boston Symphony Is Heard in Faust
description: The first of the, major Berlioz offerings to be presented here this season was the Boston Symphony Orchestra's performance of La Damnation de Faust, given Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Seiji Ozawa. (The New York Philharmonic has announced this same work for next month, and the Metropolitan Opera will introduce its production of Berlioz's Les Troyens on Oct. 22.)

title: Satyajit Ray's Moving 'Distant Thunder':The Cast
description: The Bengali countryside is almost heavy with color, with golds, yellows, umbers, and especially with the greens of the rice fields. The village is tranquil. Caste is observed. It is part of the order of things. Occasionally groups of airplanes are heard overhead, but they are as remote as the war that, according to a village elder, "the king is fighting with the Germans and the Japanese." One villager reports the Germans have captured Singapore, but he is corrected. It's the Japanese who have captured Singapore, the man is told.Aside from a shortage of kerosene, the war, at first, doesn't seem to have much effect on the villagers in Satyajit Ray's fine, elegiac new film, "Distant Thunder" (Ashani Sanket). The movie, which has the impact of an epic without seeming to mean to, was shown last night at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. It will be presented there again tonight."Distant Thunder" has all sorts of connections with Ray's great Apu Trilogyits village setting, its leading actor, Soumitra Chatterji, who played the title role in "The World of Apu," and its source material. The new film, like the Apu Trilogy, is based on a novel by Bibhuti Bhusan Bannerji. It is, however, very different from those early films.It is the work of a director who has learned the value of narrative economy to such an extent that "Distant Thunder," which is set against the backdrop of the "manmade" famine that wiped out 5 million people in 1943, has the simplicity of a fable.Though its field of vision is narrow, more or less confined to the social awakening of a young village Brahmin and his pretty, naive wife, the sweep of the film is so vast that, at the end, you feel as if you'd witnessed the events from a satellite. You've somehow been able to see simultaneously the curvature of the earth and the insects on the blades of field grass."Distant Thunder" is about Gangacharan (Mr. Chatterji), the only Brahmin in his village, a solemn and rather pompous young man who accepts the responsibilities as well as the privileges of caste. As teacher, physician and priest he looks forward to the material rewards due him. When Ananga, his wife, asks him if he really can ward off cholera through spells, for which neighboring villagers will pay him handsomely, he replies that, in addition to the spells, he will pass on to the villagers the practical information from his hygiene encyclopedia.As the war-induced rice shortage becomes increasingly acute, the tranquillity of the village is destroyed. Life-long trusts are betrayed. Civil order falls apart. At the same time, the famine prompts some remarkable instances of love and compassion. The self-assured Gangacharan, who wears black-rim spectacles and carries a black umbrella, is at first angry when his wife proposes that she go to work to earn rice for them. Then he says quietly: "If we have to humble ourselves, it's best we do it together."As the scramble to survive humiliates some of Ray's characters, it ennobles others, including Gangacharan who, towards the end, has begun to question the social system that he has always accepted as given and right. In the context of the film, this is a revolutionary conversion, and a most moving one.Ray has chosen to photograph the film in rich, warm colors, the effect of which is not to soften the focus of the film but to sharpen it. The course of terrible events seems that much more vivid in landscapes of relentless beauty.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Despite the refusal of United States military spokesmen in Saigon to reveal the quantity of Americansupplied munitions the Thieu army is consuming [news story Oct. 3], there is no mystery whatsoever regarding its flagrant violations of the ceasefire agreement or the American Government's total responsibility for paying for the protraction of the Vietnam war.

title: Parking Eased for Succoth
description: The Traffic Department announced that all alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations would be suspended today, the first day of the Jewish holiday of Succoth, and tomorrow. Parking meter and No standing regulations will be in effect.

title: Books Today
description: A Gastronomic Murder, by Alexandra Roudybush; His Burial Too, by Catherine Aird; The Old Friend, by Van Siller (Doubleday, $4.95 each). Crime Club detective stories.

title: Screen
description: CARRIAGE TRADE, a 60minute, silent compilation of travels, home movies and documents by Warren Sonbert. At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: Traditional Reserve of Race for Chief Judge Is Lost in the Current Campaign
description: The campaign for chief judge of the state, possibly the bitterest judicial campaign in the state's history, has involved personal attacks of a nature seldom present in a judicial race, divided the city's legal community and prompted a number of Democratic defections.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Liggett & Myers Company announced yesterday that it would no longer sponsor the $250,000 United States Professional matchplay championship and the Liggett & Myers open on the pro golf tour next year. The tourneys were played at the MacGregor Downs Country Club, Cary, N. C., this year after Pinehurst, N.C., had been the site for the two previous years.

title: Hair Marks Milestone Outside London Theater
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters)The cast of the rock musical Hair gave its 2,000th performance todayoutside the theater that housed it for almost five years.

title: Supermarkets Reported Offering Spectacular Discounts on Beef
description: A survey of the city's supermarkets by the State Agriculture Department yesterday reported spectacular sales on beef here this week in an apparent effort to entice the consumer back to meat.

title: Merrill Lynch Sees Profit Rising Above 8c a Share
description: The Septemberquarter earnings of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., which will be issued next Tuesday, will be substantially higher than the $2.8million, or cents a share, reported in the June quarter this year, accordMg to Donald T. Regan, chairman.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame promised Harlem merchants yesterday that he would help this community and coinmunities throughout our city that are victimized by a few residents who ignore the law.

title: Permanent Yale Tree Is Planted in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI)  A 38foot permanent national. Christmas tree, which is intended to grow and prosper in sight of the White House, was planted. today.

title: Sandman's Plans to Use TV Held Snagged by Finances
description: TRENTON, Oct. 14  Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr's Republican campaign for Governor of New Jersey was reported running into heavy debt tonight.

title: Klan Plans to Raise Fund For Defense of Beckwith
description: DENHAM SPRING, La., Oct. 11 (UPI)The Louisiana Ku Klux Klan said yesterday it was raising a defense fund for Byron De La Beckwith, who has been charged with bringing a bomb into the state.

title: ROBERT BUECHNER
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 11 Robert Buechner, former personnet manager for Batten, Barton Durstine & Osborn, Inc., the advertising agency, died today at Lawrence Hospital. His age was 73, and he lived here.

title: TV: Splendid Coverage of Agnew's Resignation
description: The resignation and sentencing of Spiro T. Agnew gave the networks an opportunity to display television news at its best. The chance was seized and, for the most part, impressively realized.

title: 3d Youth Held in Boston In Man's Death by Stabbing
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)A 16yearold youth has been charged in the stabbing death of Louis Barba, 65 years old, of Boston's Dorchester section. Mr. Barba was killed last week in an incident that also involved his being struck by stones.

title: Mrs. Otto Kerner, 67, Wife Of ExGovernor of Illinois
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Oct. 11 (AP)Mrs. Helena Cermak Kerner, wife of Federal Judge Otto Kerner, died yesterday at their summer home here. She was 67 years old.

title: Oakland Wins Pennant
description: The Oakland A's won the American League pennant yesterday by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 30, behind the fivehit pitching of Jim (Catfish) Hunter. The A's will meet the New York Mets in the opener of the 70th World Series in Oakland tomorrow. Details on Page 53.

title: Light at End of New Tunnel
description: Fortyfive feet under the Avenue of the Americans, a jaunty William J. Ronan blasted through a twofoot wall with a jackhammer yesterday for a symbolic linkup of the existing subway system and the new tunneling under Central Park.

title: 3 Behavioral Science Pioneers Win Nobel Prize for Medicine
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11The Nobel Prize in the category Of Physiology or Medicine for 1973 was awarded here today to three pioneers in the relatively new science of ethologythe comparative study of behavior.

title: 11 Disqualified as Jurors In ChesimardSquire Case
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 11A Middlesex County judge today disqualified en masse 11 prospective jurors in the case of a state trooper's slaying after one of them told the judge that some members of the panel had discussed accounts of the slaying in the press.

title: Market Place: Responsibility For Accounting
description: Some months ago, that arbiter of how corporations prepare their financial statements and report their profits the Accounting Principles Boardwent out of business. That board, an arm of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, had a stormy career.

title: NATO PROPOSALS GIVEN BY FRANCE
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 11France has proposed that any new declaration of Atlantic alliance principles be limited to questions of defense.

title: Dining Out: No Accounting for Taste
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Mrs. Chisholm and Basil' Paterson Support Beame's Candidacy
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm and Basil A. Paterson, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, yesterday joined the growing ranks of prominent black Democrats supporting Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.

title: A's Are Proud but Quiet; Orioles Show Composure
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 11 Pride and satisfaction on one Side, composure and wellcontrolled disappointment on the other, with plenty of maturity on both. Those were the prevailing lockerroom tones today after Oakland had beaten Baltimore for the American League championship, 30, in the 167th and final game to count in the standings.

title: United Airlines Triples Its ThreeMonth Earnings
description: UAL, Inc., reported yesterday that its subsidiary, United Air Lines, the world's largest air transportation system, nearly tripled Its profits in the three months to Sept. 30. The company's showing was better than had generally been expected by Wall Street observers.

title: Bridge:
description: Doubling games or slam which the opponents clearly expected to make is a fruitless exercise. The potential loss is always much greater than the potential gain, and the double often serves to turn a gain into a loss. Such doubles are therefore designed to direct a winning lead, rather than to enlarge the possible penalty.

title: Mrs. Johnson Hostess For Highway Awards
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Oct. 11 The towering stalks of yellow Maximilian daisies planted as a part of Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's highway beautification program decorated highways leading to the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park today.

title: Armed Cubans Try To Thwart Chilean Speaking at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11  Foreign Minister Raul Roa of Cuba and some Cuban representatives with pistols under their jackets rushed toward the General Assembly rostrum last night protesting a speech by a Chilean diplomat. They were stopped by other delegates and United Nations guards.

title: MRS. ARTHUR K. PECK
description: Mrs. Christine Crane Crunden Peck, wife of Arthur K. Peck, a broker and former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at their home on Ocean Avenue in Cedarhurst, L. I. She was 73 years old.

title: Finland Gives Paavo Nurmi Funeral for a National Hero
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 11 (AP)Paavo Nurmi, the world famous distance runner of the nineteentwenties and thirties, who died here Oct. 2 at the age of 76, today received a state funeral for a national hero.

title: KISSINGER GIVEN TRADE BILL DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Secretary of State Kissinger asked the House leadership today to postpone next week's scheduled vote on the Administration's trade bill because of concern that its antiSoviet amendments might upset discussions with the Russians on ending the Middle East crisis.

title: $1,000 Fine for Stolen TV's
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 11A man accused of storing 51 stolen color television sets at his home was fined $1,000 today and placed on three years' probation. He is James Avoli, 53 years old, of nearby Geneva. He was sentenced in Ontario County Court after pleading guilty to criminal possession.

title: Armed Cubans Try To Thwart Chilean Speaking at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11  Foreign Minister Raid Roa of Cuba and some Cuban representatives with pistols under their jackets rushed toward the General Assembly, rostrum last night protesting a speech by a Chilean diplomat., They were stopped by other delegates and United Nations guards.

title: People in Sports: Kerry Melville Signs With Boston Net Team
description: Kerry Melville of Australia, the thirdranked woman tennis player, signed a threeyear contract yesterday with the Bostor entry in World Team tennis. Terms were not disclosed, but Ray Ciccolo, the club president, said the amount obviously was enough to make Kerry happy.

title: OVERSEAS TROOP CUT DROPPED FROM BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) House and Senate negotiators today dropped a Senateapproved proposal to bring home 110,000 American troops from overseas as they reached agreement on a $21.3billion defense authorization bill.

title: Protecting a Treasure
description: In voting to establish the Big Cypress National Preserve, the House of Representatives made an invaluable contribution last week to the saving of the Everglades. The unique subtropical environment which has made the Everglades National Park a worldfamous treasure has already been dangerously drained of its waters by developments and canals to the north and west. Without the preservation of the Big Cypress Swamp, which accounts for 56 per cent of the water entering the park from beyond its boundaries, the destruction of more than half the park could be only a question of time.

title: New Jet Passer Reports News, Then Makes Some
description: Tim Van Galder was in perfect position to find out quickly what was happening in the quarterback market on weekends.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary distribution of 271,283 shares of Holiday Inns, Inc., common at 24 was made yesterday by Goldman, Sachs. The company's stock closed at 24, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: LEE C. WILLFAMS
description: Lee C. Williams, former director of systems and methods for Hearst magazines, with which he had been associated for 38 years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 75 years old and lived at 2 Sutton Place.

title: A.T.&T. APPEALS SATELLITE. RULING
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company appealed yesterday against a Federal Communications Commission decision of Sept. 12 that would allow the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation to use domestic communications satellites to offer longdistance phone service for the continental United States and Hawaii, thus ending the monopoly of this service held by A. T. & T.'s Long Lines department.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Effort to Bar Sports Complex Alleged

title: Weiskopf Advances In Title Golf
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 11All the players that were behind won, and in those wildly fluctuating early holes today the man who appeared surest of being beaten was Tom Weiskopf, who is defending his title in the Piccadilly world match play championship.

title: Israelis Announce a Breakthrough in Syria, but Say Little About Suez Front
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 11The Is??aeli command announced tonight that its forces had broken through Syrian lines and advanced about six miles toward Damascus, but it said little about ground action along the Suez front.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Chu Chu Padilla, 136 pounds, Bisbee, Ariz., knocked out Jeff Lucas, 144, Las Vegas, 9 rounds.

title: The Pop Life
description: Broadway's Palate Theater is obviously finding music profitable  the box office opens Monday for the threeweek Bette Midler season (which looks set for sellbut status), and this is preseded by four evenings with the singer Vicki Carr, starting Oct. 25.

title: BOND PRICES DIP AND THEN CLIME
description: Corporate bonds dipped in early trading yesterday but recovered slightly to close steady in slow trading. Natural Gas Pipeline 8.35s, due 1993, were down  and New Jersey Bell 7s, due 2013, were off . New York Telephone 8.30s, due 2012, were up . Consolidated Edison's new 8.40s, due 2003, offered at par, were quoted at 100 to yield 7.37 per cent. The Government market was also subdued, with no action by the Federal Reserve. Federal funds were quoted in a range of 10 to 10 per cent. Noting the absence of any repurchase agreements by the Fed, one dealer said that this level of Federal funds appeared to be satisfactory to the Federal Reserve.

title: Episcopal Parley Urges Mild Penalty For Marijuana Use
description: LOUISVILLE, Oct. 11 (AP)Representatives of the Episcopal Church urged today that the mere possession or personal use of marijuana be considered Imp more than a misdemeanor.

title: 7 Black Militants Seized in Shooting Of Brooklyn Man
description: MINEOLA, LI, Oct. 11Seven black militantsincluding Sonny Carsonwho allegedly shot a Brooklyn man and left him for dead in Roosevelt, L.I., were arrested by the Nassau County police today.

title: Cairo Claims Tank Victory; Rather Quiet, Israel Says
description: CAIRO, Oct. 11The Egyptlien command reported today I that the Israelis had lost 26 tanks and armored vehicles in the southern sector of the Sinai front. The tank battle lasted from noon yesterday. throughout the night and until midday today, the cornmand said.

title: Tanaka Is Home, Confident Of SovietJapanese Plans
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Premier Kakuei Tanaka, returning from a vist to three Western European capitals and the Soviet Union, expressed confidence today that joint SovietJapanese projects for developing Siberian natural resources would progress.

title: LocalLevel Obstinacy
description: While the political significance of the situations can hardly be compared, Vice President Agnew's decision to resign the nation's second highest office just before pleading no contest to a charge of income  tax evasion is in glaring contrast to developments on the local level in New Jersey.

title: G. O.P. GIVES IDEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11President Nixon held intensive consultations with his staff and with political leaders today on whom he should nominate as Vice President and then flew to his mountaintop retreat at Camp David, Md., to make his decision.

title: F.D.A. Will Approve Controversial Injectable Contraceptive Drug for Restricted Use by Prescription
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 The Food and Drug Administration has decided to approve for limited prescription use a controversial, injectable contraceptive drug called DepoProvera.

description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11The Nobel Prize in the category of Physiology or Medicine for 1973 was awarded here today to three pioneers in the relatively new science of ethologythe comparative study of behavior.

title: U.S. OffshoreLease Shift Urged to Spur Gas Output
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 A senior antitrust official recommended today changes in the Government's method of selling offshore mineral leases in order to give smaller oil and gas producers a better chance to win some of the acreage.

title: Sketches at Three Nobel Laureates
description: Dr. Lorenz does not consider apocryphal the tale that King Solomon spoke to the animals in their own language, for, he says, I can do it myself. Like Dr. Tinbergen, his observations of, animal behavior also began when he was a boy who explored the wild and brought home its creatures.

title: New Plays Find a Home on the Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum, received a letter recently from a disgruntled playgoer. The woman had just seen The Tooth of Crime by Sam Shepard, a noisy play about the rivalry between two rock stars, and she wrote:

title: Builder Is Allowed 3 Excess, Stories In a Deal on Rent
description: The City Planning Commission approved late Wednesday night a plan under which the developer of a 36story luxury apartment house on Second Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets, would be allowed to retain the three top floors, constructed without the necessary prior approval of both the commission and the Board of Estimate.

title: OIL TALKS CONTINUE ON PRICE INCREASES
description: VIENNA, Oct. 11Secret negotiations over a new round of petroleum price increases continued today amid speculation that an agreement would be signed this week.

title: Usual Reserve Lost In Chief Judge Race
description: The campaign for chief judge of the state, possibly the bitterest judicial campaign in the state's history, has involved personal attacks of a nature seldom present in a judicial race, divided the city's legal community and prompted a number of Democratic defections.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Chu. Chu Padilla, 136 pounds, Bisbee, Ariz., knocked out Jeff Lucas, 144, Las Vegas, 9 rounds.

title: Blades Lose to Cougars, 43, Here
description: The New York Golden Blades brought their new ice show to Madison Square Garden last night. Under new management, with a new name and eight new skaters, the World Hockey Association team was handed its first defeat of the young season by the Chicago Cougars, 43.

title: OIL EXPLORATION IN ATLANTIC URGED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 Citing the hostilities in the Middle East and the energy crisis as compelling reasons, representatives of industry, labor, utilities and state governments called today for an immediate exploration of the Atlantic Continental Shelf for oil and natural gas deposits.

description: Winning numbers drawn on Oct. 11 were:

title: Gang Members Play Roles in Film on Sonny Carson
description: Champ, who is the Supreme President of the Tomahawks in Brownsville now that the incumbent is in jail on homicide charges, is spending these fall days on the Brooklyn streets in an unlookedfor pursuitacting in a Hollywood movie.

title: As Nixon Asks Help in Finding Agnew's Successor, Some Feel He Has Already Decided
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11President Nixon has asked Congressional and party leaders for help in choosing successor to Spiro T. Agnew.

title: A Nation Reacts: Regret, Glee and Plea for Reform
description: A nation without a Vice President responded yesterday to Spiro T. Agnew's resignation with expressions ranging from glee to regret, and with calls for reforms and a restoration of confidence in government and the political processes.

title: Seasonal Bluefish
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame promised Harlem merchants yesterday that he would help this community and cornmunities throughout our city that are victimized by a few residents who ignore the law.

title: Agreement on Amtrak Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11SenateHouse conferees reached agreement today on legislation that would provide $154.3million in Federal funds for operation of the nation's rail passenger service, Amtrak, during the current fiscal year.

title: U.S. ACCUSES CANADA OF DUMPING LEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11 (Canadian Press)Imports of primary lead from Canada, valued about $18million a year, are being sold at les than fair value in the United States, the United States Treasury Department ruled today.

title: Commager Would End Post
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 11 (AP)Herry Steele Commager, the historian, said yesterday that the resignation of Vice President Agnew might afford a good opportunity to consider abolishing the office of Vice President. The Vice President doesn't do anything except preside over the Senate, and the Senate can pick a presiding officer, the Amherst College professor said.

title: Students Protest Condition Of Stony Brook Housing
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 11 Six studentgovernment leaders and other students at the State University Center here presented about 25 cockroaches to the housing office today to protest what they called inadequate housing conditions. The cockroaches had been collected from residential and academic buildings, the students said.

title: President Reportedly Took Initiative on Agnew Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11President Nixon reportedly initiated the secret legal negotiations that led yesterday to the sudden resignation of Spiro T. Agnew from the VicePresidency and his dramatic conviction on a charge of Federal income tax evasion.

title: Both Sides Putting Pressure on Jordan
