description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 11King Hussein of Jordan is in continuous contact with the Governments or Egypt and Syria, high Jordanian officials affirmed today, but there was no indication in this watchful and wary capital of whether Jordan would enter the war.About half a dozen Israeli ets flew over the capital tolight. Antiaircraft guns opened up, the gun flashes briefly iluminating minarets, It looked to watchers on the ground as ?? one jet had been hit, but it was still flying as it disappaeared westward.

title: 21 SEIZED UPSTATE ON NARCOTIC CHARGE
description: State and local policemen arrested at least 21 persons on drugsale charges in adjoining Albany and Schenectady Counties yesterday in an effort to stem the flow of heroin and cocaine. Seven persons were arrested in Schenectady and 14 were reported seized in Albany. The alleged sales were said to have taken place before Sept. I, when the state's new drug law went into effect.

title: Syria Claims 80 Jets
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11 Syrian military communiqus said that more than 80 Israeli planes were shot down today as new attacks by Israeli fighterbombers and missile boats damaged port cities, oil terminals and military bases.

title: Both Sides Putting Pressure on Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan,, Oct. 11King Hussein of Jordan is in continuous contact with the Governments of Egypt and Syria, high Jordanian officials affirmed today, but there was no indication in this watchful and wary capital of whether Jordan would enter the war.

title: TEACHER RECALLS KILLINGS AT KENT
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 11(AP) A, former Kent State University student who says he was with Terrence Norman, an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on the day of the Kent State killings, said yesterday that Mr. Norman had not fired a shot that supposedly brought on an Ohio National Guard fusillade.

title: Rubber Companies Favor Change in Tire Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  The Rubber Manufacturers Association has urged the Government to, drop provisions for measuring tire traction under grading standards proposed for shoppers' use.

title: Vacancy in U.S. Court Stirs Dispute Between Weicker and Legal Establishment
description: Washington, Oct. 11A 23month vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals in New York has touched off an angry dispute between Senator Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, and the Justice Department, the American Bar Association and the Federal judiciary.

title: Los Angeles Preparing Its Bid for '80 Olympics
description: Los Angeles has begun preparations to challenge Moscow as host for the 1980 Olympic Games. The city's intentions were contained in a Sept. 28 letter from Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles to the United States Olympic Committee.

title: An Apparently Stoical Agnew Attends Family Funeral
description: RANDALLSTOWN, Md., Oct. 11The funeral of his halfbrother brought Spiro T. Agnew back to his beginnings in suburban Baltimore today. On the surface, little had changed.

title: Ruling Entitles Fuchsberg To Second Line on Ballot
description: ALBANY, Oct. 11Supreme Court Justice Russell G. Hunt ruled today that Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic candidate for chief judge of the Court of Appeals, was entitled to a second line on the ballot in the November election.

title: With All Due Reverent Speed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The Agnew Affair, following the Eagleton Affair, suggests again that the normal procedures for selecting VicePresidential candidates in America have been almost criminally negligent, so maybe they should be examined before President Nixon picks a successor to Mr. Agnew.

title: FREE USE OF CAR BY MACKELL CITED
description: Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, accepted the free use of a car for about seven months from AvisRentACar System, Inc., two years before approving a criminal prosecution that benefated Avis, according to testimony presented yesterday to the State Select Committee on Crime.

title: 4 Civic Groups File Suit On Manpower Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI)Four community groups asked a Federal court today to block the Department of Labor's transfer of job training and manpower programs to state and local governments.

title: Sudan Is Said to Send Troops to Sinai Front
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10 (UPI)The Sudan was reported today to have joined the Middle Sast fighting on the Sinai front.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: KABARETT Many Americans are probably most familiar with the night life of the preHitler. Weimar Republic through the movie Cabaret. It all seems longgone, but the people who lived it are still with us, many of them in New York, including Wolfgang Roth, the scenic director who worked with Piscator and Brecht before immigrating here in 1939 and later working in this country's theater and opera.

title: Administration to Disclose Plan For Mandatory Fuel Allocation
description: WASHINGTON, (UPI)John Love, the Government's director of energy policy, said today that a plan for the mandatory allocation of home heating oil, jet aircraft fuel and similar fuels would be announced tomorrow.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Children's Zoo Closing for Repairs

title: Jury Clears Two Men in Attack on School Buses in Ozone Park Last Year
description: An allwhite jury yesterday acquitted two men charged with the attack last year on two school buses carrying black and Puerto Rican students to a junior high school in Ozone Park, Queens.

title: Protectionist Moves On Trade Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) President Nixon told an audience of businessmen today that enactment of protectionist trade legislation would be terribly shortsighted and potentially disastrous.

title: Earnings for R.C.A. Show 14% Gain
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday gains in sales and earnings for the third quarter and first nine months of the year. New highs were achieved in sales for both periods as well as in earnings for the nine months.

title: Hitachi Planning to Start Manufacturing in the U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (UPI) The Hitachi Sales Corporation of America, subsidiary of the Japanbased industrial giant, Hitachi, Ltd., announced today the start of largescale manufacturing operations in the United States.

title: State Criticizes, City Defends Brooklyn Nursing Home
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger yesterday denounced a Browns ville nursing home as a shockfrig horrorwhile the City Health Department retorted that nursing care was above average and the home's owner denied every charge.

title: MAN SHOT BATTLING CENTRAL PARK THUG
description: A 25yearold New Jersey man was shot in the foot yesterday afternoon as he foiled a holdup attempt while walking in Central Park near Fifth Avenue and 76th Street, the police reported.

title: Basketball Tonight
description: RADIOWHN, 7:35 P.M.

title: Yale Foes: Brown and Fumbles
description: There's many a slip twixt quarterback and running back, particularly in the Yale backfield, and Carmen Cozza is looking for some bulldog tape to correct the situation.

title: O'Dwyer Backs Proposal For Queens Sports Center
description: Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic candidate for City Council President, came out in favor yesterday of the newly announced plans for a sports complex in Sunnyside, Queens, and opposed the location and financing of the West Side con vention center.

title: Waldheim Warns Security Council of the Gravest Consequences in Mideast War
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11Secretary General Waldheim warned the Security Council today that the war in the Middle East posed the gravest consequences not only for the region itself, but for the world community as a whole.

title: Resignation Ends a Court Test On Disclosure of News Sources
description: The resignation of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew ended what was shaping up as a classic court test of the First Amendment guarantee of freedom of the press  a new battle over the reporter's right to protect the anonymity of news sources.

title: 65 Block Security Plans Win Approval of Police
description: The Police Department yesterday approved 65 security programs proposed by bloc associations around the city. The total cost of the programs will he $189,455.

title: Hunter Pitches 5Hitter for Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 11For the second year in succession, the Oakland A's won the American League championship in the fifth game of the interdivision playoff by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 30, today as Jim (Catfish) Hunter pitched a fivehitter for his second victory of the series.

title: Books of The Times
description: TEMPORARY KINGS. By Anthony Powell. 280 pages. Little, Brown. $6.95.

title: Business Briefs
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 11 (UPI)Australia has completed a wheat deal with China worth more than $600million at current international prices, Dr. Jim Cairns, Overseas Trade Minister, announced today.

title: Chilean Leader Sets Social Peace as Essential Aim
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, the leader of Chile's military junta, declared today that the armed forces would withdraw from the government only when the country has achieved the social peace necessary for progress and economic development.

title: NIXON HOMES STIR SPENDING DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The head of the deneral Services Administration conceded today that his agency had made mistakes in spending Federal money at President Nixon's private homes, among them cutting the President's grass and trimming weeds at public expense.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: GROMYKO THANKED BY 4 ARAB ENVOYS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11  Four Arab ambassadors met today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and thanked him for the allround assistance and support rendered by Moscow to the Arab cause.

title: Defense Fund for Agnew Still Accepting Donations
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP)The defense fund for Spiro T. Agnew, which was established by W. Clement Stone, the insurance executive, is still accepting contributions to help defray legal costs, a spokesman for Mr. Stone said today.

title: Report Says Governor Helped Breitel's Race, but Not Marchi's
description: Governor Rockefeller and his wife contributed $6,000 to the Republican Court of Appeals campaign two months ago but have yet to donate to State Senator John J. Marchi's G.O.P. mayoral campaign.

title: The Agnew Bargain
description: The accommodation reached between the Justice Department and lawyers for former Vice President Agnew is a unique political act. The settlement can well be defended because Mr. Agnew's position as the nation's standby President made it urgently desirable to get him out of office as soon as possible once all doubt of his unfitness had vanished. He was able to use that leverage to escape the lengthy prison term that his crimes merited.

title: Report Says Governor Helped Breitel's Race, but Not Marches
description: Governor Rockefeller and his wife contributed $6,000 to the Republican Court of Appeals campaign two months ago but have yet to donate to State Senator John J. Marchi's G.O.P. mayoral campaign.

title: MARYLAND AWAITS THE NEXT TARGET
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11  The grand jury investigation of political corruption in Maryland that led to the resignation of Spiro T. Agnew as Vice President is expected to continue here, and the question is who will be the next target?

title: RED CROSS URGING CODE ON CIVILIANS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 11  The International Committee of the Red Cross called on the Middle East belligerents today to become the first nations to commit themselves to farreaching rules of warfare designed to protect civilians from military operations.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: G.O.P. GIVES IDEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 President Nixon held intensive consultations with his staff and with political leaders today on whom he should nominate as Vice President and then flew to his mountaintop retreat at Camp David, Md., to ?? his decision.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GAY HEAD, Mass.More than 100 yards offshore on the smooth waters of Menemsha Bight, a curious, rippling, fanshaped disturbance developed and moved rapidly toward the beach.

title: The Subway Prospect: Better Service, Fewer Riders and Clam or for Subsidy
description: Within a decade the New York City Transit Authority ?? likely to clatter past two mile stones: The first major ne?? subway lines In more than 4?? years will open and the Transi?? Authority's deficit could approach $1billion a year.

title: O'Hagan Now Fire Commissioner
description: John T. O'Hagan was sworn in yesterday as Fire Commissioner to succeed Robert O. Lowery.

title: Modern Museum's Film Series At Standstill Because of Strike
description: The film program of the Museum of Modern Art has been virtually crippled since the start of a strike there Tuesday by the museum's union of professional and administrative workers. Seven of eight scheduled films have been canceled, though the museum itself remains open.

title: Utility Expansion Is Set
description: The Cincinnati Gas and Eletric Company said yesterday it was part of a group of utilities that planned to spend about $900million for electric generating facilities over the next five years. Others in the group are the Colubmus & Southern Ohio Electric Company and the Dayton Power & Light Company.

title: At Festival Time, Holy Indian City of Benares Throbs With Hindu Pilgrims
description: BENARES, India, Oct. 7Crows flutter above the filmy waters of the Ganges. Bells tinkle. Old women in saris sit beside the river, shaking finger cymbals, beating drums, chanting in praise of the gods. The air is sweet and heavy with the scent of joss sticks and jasmine and musty smoke.

title: Baboon Undergoes Surgery
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 11 (UPI)An unusual patient, a oneyearold baboon, underwent a 30minute operation at Children's Hospital here yesterday to remove a cataract from his right eye. Doctors said that Alfred, the baboon, was resting comfortably, although it will be a couple of days before they know if the surgery was successful.

title: MITCHELL'S MOVE ON TAPES OPPOSED
description: Federal prosecutors argued yesterday that attorneys for John N. Mitchell were trying to damage or dismiss the criminal case against the former Attorney General by introducing the momentous constitutional issue of White House tape recordings.

title: The President's Integrity
description: WASHINGTONIn the course of the consideration by the United States Senate in 1937 of President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the number of justices he could appoint to the United States Supreme Court (the Courtpacking plan), an incident arose which may shed some light on the present efforts of Congress and the special prosecutor to obtain the tapes of private conversations held by the President in the White House.

title: President Reportedly Took Initiative on Agnew Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11President Nixon reportedly initiated the secret legal negotiations that led yesterday to the sudden resignation of Spiro T. Agnew from the VicePresidency and his dramatic conviction on a charge of Federal income tax evasion.

title: EDUCATORS ARGUE GOVERNMENT ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11A continuous debate over the extent to which government can and should influence the policies of colleges and universities was threaded through speeches and discussions here today at the annual meeting of the American Council on Education.

title: Watson Wins Golf After Extra Hole
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 11Bob Watson of Wykagyl won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association seniors' championship today by defeating Doug Ford of Spook Rock with a par 4 on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff at Briar Hall Golf and Country Club. They tied at 141, one under par, in the 36hole, $2,500 tournament.

title: An Independent Attorney General Elliot Lee Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11It may have been with a feeling of dja vu that Elliot Lee Richardson orchestrated the prosecution of Spiro T. Agnew for cheating on his income taxes. Twelve years ago, the handsome, 6foot Attorney General for the state of Massachusetts initiated the prosecution of Bernard Goldfine, the influence peddler who stained the Eisenhower Administration.

title: Agnew's Senate Staff On Payroll for 30 Days
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI)The Senate voted today to keep former Vice President Agnew's staff on the payroll for 30 days to help him wind up his affairs.

title: Advertising: Shift at Agency
description: Walter W. Bregman, the tough, young president and chief operating officer of Norman, Craig & Kummel, is leaving the agency and is being replaced by Thomas K. Myers, who has been executive vice president. The announcement was made by Norman B. Norman, chairman, who isn't as young but is most probably tougher.

title: Cairo Claims Tank Victory; Rather Quiet, Israel Says
description: CAIRO, Friday, Oct. 12 Egyptian and Israeli tanks fought an allbight battle in the Sinai desert, resulting in heavy losses on the Israeli side, a military spokesman in Cairo reported yesterday.

title: Tigers GetHouk As Pilot
description: Ralph Houk became the best paid and most secure manager in Detroit Tiger history yesterday, but perhaps even more important to him, he regained the freedom that had beep diluted this year with the Yankees.

title: New Fairfield Zone Board Bars Candlewood Lake Development
description: NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 11The zoning commission of this former resort community turned down last night a controversial proposal to build an economically and racially integrated new town of 8,000 on the shores of Candlewood Lake here.

title: Press Club of Omaha Retains Agnew Room
description: OMAHA, Oct. 11 (UPI)The Omaha Press Club said today that Spiro T. Agnew's name would remain on its press room despite his resignation as Vice President.

title: Yale Foes: Brown and Fumbles
description: There's many a slip 'twixt quarterback and running back, particularly in the Yale backfield, and Carmen Cozza is looking for some bulldog tape to correct the situation.

title: KROGH IS INDICTED FOR LIES TO PANEL ON ELLSBERG CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11A Federal grand jury today indicted Egil Krogh Jr., the former Presidential aide who directed the White House plumbers, on two counts of false declaration in a case growing out of the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: New Director Is Named By Dallas Arts Museum
description: The appointment of Harry S. Parker 3d as director of the Dallas Museum of Fine Arts was announced yesterday by John D. Murchison, chairman of the museum's board of trustees.

title: Barkatullah Khan Dies; Rafasthan's Minister, 53
description: NEW DELHI, Oct 11Barkatullah Khan, chief minister of Rajasthan State, died of a heart attack today in Jaipur, the state capital, He was 53 years old.

title: Jews Here, on Succoth Holiday, Offer Prayers for Israeli Safety
description: In synagogues throughout the metropolitan area yesterday worshippers carrying palm branches voiced prayers for Israel's security in the Middle East hostilities.

title: RISE IN PATH FARE REJECTED BY I.C.C.
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected yesterday the proposal by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to raise fares on the PATH commuter line to 50 cents from 30 cents.

title: Agnew Is Defended In Ancestral Home, A Town in Greece
description: GARGALIANOI, Greece, Oct. 11 (UPI)Residents of Spiro T. Agnew's ancestral home town rallied today to the deefnse of the former Vice President.

title: State Grant for Ossining
description: ALBANY, Oct. 11 (UPI)The State Housing Commissioner, Lee Goodwin, said today that she had appfoved a $133,041 state urban renewal capitalgrant contract for Oisimng's neighborhood development program. The 201acre site encompasses the central business district and surrounding residential areas, bounded by Highland Avenue, James Street and the Hudson River.

title: Light at End of New Tunnel
description: Fortyfive feet under the Avenue of the Americans, jaunty William J. Ronan blasted through a twofoot wall with a jackhammer yesterday for a symbolic linkup of the existing subway system and the new tunneling under Central Park.

title: AREA BANKS LIFT MORTGAGE RATES
description: Several banks and lending institutions in the area moved quickly yesterday to raise their interest rates on mortgages to the new 8 per cent ceiling allowed by the New York Banking Board.

title: Intercity Truck Tonnage Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage in the latest week was 5.7 per cent above the corresponding week of last] year. Based on a weekly survey of 35 metropolitan areas, increased tonnage was reported at 25 localities. The ??ail carloading report will be out tomorrow because of the Colum bus Day holiday this week.

title: Parking Eased for Succoth
description: The Traffic Department announced that all alternatesideofthestreet pvking regulations would be suspended today, the first day of the Jewish holiday of Succoth, and today and tomorrow because of the Jewish holiday of Succoth. Parking meter and No standing regulations will be in effect.

title: U.S. Jet Crashes in Spain
description: ZARAGOZA, Spain, Oct. 11 (UPI)A United States Air Force F4E Phantom jet crashed today on a training mission at bomb and gunnery range 45 miles northwest of the Zaragoza air base, the air force said. The two crew members, Col. Edward J. Campbell and Capt. Daniel M. McAuliffe, ejected from the aircraft and were listed in good condition.

title: World Hockey Assn
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Egyptian Communiques
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11 (AP)Following, in unofficial translation, are the texts of military communiqus issued by Egypt today:

title: Governor Pushed for Vice President
description: The state Republican chairman, Richard Rosenbaum, was busy on the telephone with his counterparts in other states yesterday, talking up the name of Governor Rockefeller for Vice President.

title: Director of McGovem's Campaign Says Acts of Sabotage Divided the Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Frank Mankiewicz, who was Senator George McGovern's political director last year, said today that the sabotage activities paid for by President Nixon's reelection committee had succeeded in sharply dividing the candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Credit Eases as Loan Demand Declines
Red Smith
description: Early in New York's love affair with the Mets, Dick Young of the Daily News gave those peculiar fans a name that stuckthe New Breed. Perhaps it has stuck too long. The sort of creatures who ornamented Shea Stadium this week, meaning those who aimed glassware and garbage at Pete Rose's skull and those who vandalized the park on the pretext of celebrating a pennant for the Mets they aren't bred. They're just found under rocks. And on that saccharine note let us turn away from baseball for one day.

title: DR. DONALD PREAR, A PESTICIDE EXPERT
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 11Dr. Donald E. H. Frear, who retired in 1969 as professor of chemical pesticides at Pennsylvania State University, died today at the age of 67.

title: No Man's Land in Golan Is Strewn with War Debris
description: BASSA, Golan Heights, Oct. 11  Israeli and Syrian troops Faced each other across an 800yardwide no man's land today after four days of bitter fighting that left the terrain littered with destroyed tanks and the ugly debris of battle.

title: KROGH IS INDICTED FOR LIES TO PANEL ON ELLEN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11A Federal grand jury today indicted Egil Krogh Jr., the former Presidential aide who directed the White House plumbers, on two counts of false declaration in a case growing out of the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Donald P. Ross, 71, Dies; Delaware Park Chairman
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 11 (AP)Donald P. Ross, chairman of Delaware Park race track, died here today at the age of 71.

title: The Subway Prospect: Better Service, Fewer Riders and Clamor for Subsidy
description: Within a decade the New York City Transit Authority is likely to clatter past two milestones: The first major new subway lines in more than 40 years will open and the Transit Authority's deficit could approach $1billion a year.

title: I.C.C. Rejects Rise In PATH's Fares
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected yesterday the proposal by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to raise fares on the PATH commuter line to 50 cents from 30 cents.

title: Israel Reports Capture Of New SovietMade Tanks
description: TEL AVIV Oct. 11 (Reuters) Israel has captured several Sovietmade T62: tanks, the first of their kind to fall into Western hands, a military spokesman said today.

title: McIntire Says C.I.A. Also Broadcasts From Sea
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 11The Rev. Dr. Carl D. McIntire said today that if the Federal District Court here did not lift its temporary injunction against his pirateship broadcasts he would subpoena top Government officials to prove that the Central Intelligence Agency also used the high seas for unlicensed broadcasts.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $956million, up 9 per cent from the yearearlier, $877million. Total retail store sales were about $9.71billion, up 11 per cent from last year's $8.78billion.

title: Brief Session on Arms Curb
description: GENEVA, Oct. 12 (Reuters)Soviet and American delegates negotiating a new treaty to curb strategic offensive weapons met for one hour at the United States mission here today, conference sources said. It was their shortest session since, the talks on limiting strategic,

title: WINE TALK
description: ST. EMILION, France  If this year's grape crop in France is the largest in 50 years, as most of the experts are predicting, some of the thanks must go to Kintilla Heussoff.

title: British Tories Publicly Cheery but Privately Uneasy
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 12  When the main television news came on in the hotel bar, delegates at the annual Conservative party conference fell silent. Of the halfhour on the British Broadcasting Corporation network, only three and !a half minutes were devoted to the Tory rhetoric of the day, with the rest going to the Middle East war and Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Districting Bill Is Sighed; Council Will Grow to 43
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday signed the City, Council's latest reapportionment bill that increases the legislative body from 37 to 43 for the purpose of increasing minority representation.

title: Champagne Stakes in Split Divisions
description: Twenty 2yearolds were entered at Belmont Park yesterday for today's 102d Champagne Stakes, and it didn't take long for the punsters to start talking about a split of champagne.

title: CORN PRICES FALL; SOYBEANS SLUMP
description: Profit taking depressed prices of corn and soybeans yesterday, and observers believed it was inspired by a report of five days of good weather expected in the areas of the Midwest where the two crops are being harvested.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT IRAQIS IN COMBAT
description: TEL AVIV, Saturady, Oct. 13 Israeli forces advancing into Syria from the Golan heights have encountered a contingent of Iraqi troops on the from lines, Israeli military spokesmen said yesterday.

title: W. A. Leidesdorf Weds Miriam Salazar
description: Miss Miriam V. Salazar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Salazar of Bogota, Colombia, was married here yesterday afternoon to William Alfred Leidesdorf, son of Mrs. Joan W. Leidesdorf and Arthur D. Leidesdorf, both of New York. The Rev. James Cleary performed the ceremony in the Our Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Austrian Skier Hurt
description: VIENNA, Oct. 12 (AP). David Wwilling, Austria's successful male skier last season, was injured today while training with the national team on Mount Kitisteinhorn. He suffered a brain concussion and a neck injury.

title: Weiskopf, Miller Beaten in English Golf
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 12The year of Tom Weiskopf came to an end tonight. It's over with, he said. I'm done.

title: Game I Today: les Matlack vs. Holtzman
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 12  The 70th World Series will start here tomorrow between two teams that have only recently grown out of longestablished images of futility: the New York Mets and the Oakland Athletics.

title: McCann, Ex49er Punter, Gets A Tryout as Bianchard Burns
description: JERSEL CITY, Oct. 12Tom Blanchard was surprised at being promoted to backup quarterback for the New York Giants earlier this week. He was even more stunned today at the prospect of being demoted as the club's No. 1 punter for Sunday's game against the Washington Redskins at Yale Bowl.

title: Jordan Is Reported Resisting Pressure to Join War
description: SHUNAT NIMRIM, Jordan, Oct. 12  Highly placed Jordanian informants reported today that despite pressure from other Aab countries, Jordanian authorities are simply not in favor of plunging their country into war with Israel.

title: Bethlehem Steel Planning Sheet and Strip Price Rise
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday it planned to raise prices on certain sheet and strip steel products effective with shipments on Jan. 1. This would be the second half of a twostage increase granted by the Cost of Living Council on major flatrolled steel products. The first phase went into effect on Oct. 1. Other large steel companies indicated yesterday they were studying the Bethlehem move but none followed Its lead.

title: Unemployment Is Costly
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. (UPI)California will pay out about $640million this year in unemployment benefits, an average of $60 a week for each unemployed worker, the Department of Health and Welfare reports.

title: From Calder, Gay, Spidery Forms
description: At the age of 75, Alexnder Calder is hale and hearty and actively engaged in working on some of the largest public commissions of his career. The exhibition of Works in Progress, now on view at the Perls Galleries, 1016 Madison near 79th Street, features models and photographs for several sculptural commissions now under wayamong them a 45foothigh black spidery form for the Security National Bank in Los Angeles and similarly large projects for the Chicago Federal Center and for I.M. Pei's addition to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, as well as the 50foothigh bright red stabile, a Stegosaurus, which was formally dedicated last Wednesday at the Burr Memorial Mall in Hartford.

title: Sewing Machine Works Without Threads or Needles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 12 An ultrasonic sewing machine works without threads, needles or bobbins. It is used in making men's and women's clothing, mattress, pads, curtains, blood filters and other things. The manufacturer, the Branson Sonic Power Company, Dan bury, Conn., received Patent 3,764,442 this week, assigned by Frank Parry, a consultant. The machine is for industrial rather than home use, as its basic cost is $2,500 and it works best on synthetic materials such as nylon and polyester, not on pure cotton silk.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Dance
description: A telltale sign that a performingarts group is more sure of itself than the past comes when it is actually caught in the act of having fun.

title: Festive N. Y. U. Event: Opening of a Library
description: The bakers worked through the night to produce 11,000 assorted cookies. Seven hundred and twenty bottles of California champagne were ordered, That plus 100 gallons of fruit punch, 100 gallons of coffee and 25 gallons of tea were the ingredients last night for one of the biggest bashes everh eld in Greenwich Village.

title: A Happy Ending for May
Buckley Calls on Nixon to Help Israel
description: Senator James L. Buckley yesterday called on the Nixon Administration to aid Israel with vital military equipment to cope with Soviet shipments of the latest types of material to Egypt and Syria.

title: SOCIALIST UNIT IS FOUNDED HERE
description: David Lewis, leader of the New Democratic party, which governs three of Canada's 10 provinces and holds the balance, of power in Parliament, came here yesterday to endorse a new American Socialist effort led by the author Michael Harrington.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 3 Freighters Sunk
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 12  Syrian air defenses today shot down 35 Israeli planes that attacked military air bases around this capital and other targets, according to a military spoiesman.

title: The Man With the Trunk on His Head
description: A vault, according to our New York City, Tax Collector, is that portion of a basement tinder the, public sidewalk. Every business using such a vault is obliged to pay a; tax governed by the depth, height and width of the chamber.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment prohibiting strip mining where the Federal Government owns the mineral rights but the surface rights are privately owner, which passed, 53 to 33, Oct. 8.

title: Put Ingredients on Label, Cosmetics Makers Told
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (Reuters)The Food and Drug Administration Thursday ordered manufacturers of all cosmetics to list ingredients on product labels and report complaints received about their products to the Government twice yearly.

title: MOVE IS SURPRISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Gerald Rudolph Ford of Michigan, the 60yearold minority leader of the House of Reprosentatives, was nominated by President Nixon tonight to be the 40th Vice President of the United States.

title: Gettysburg for Sale?
description: The second battle of Gettysburg is being fought in the Pennsylvania courts to prevent a private entrepreneur from putting up a 300foot, skyblue steel observation tower which he calls a classroom in the sky and historians call a desecration and an insult to past and future. The National Park Service, instead of acting with characteristic toughness, has compromised as part of a deal to protect several sacred acres.

title: Familiarity Results in Suspect's Capture
description: A man who allegedly robbed a Harlem liquor store last week for the second time in eight days was arrested this week is he ate at a lunch counter a few doors away from the scene of the crime.

title: Mays Plays If Staub Is Sidelined
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 12  If Rusty Staub can't play tomorrow, Willie Mays will start for the New York Mets in the first game of the World Series. Staub tested his sore shoulder in today's workout and felt pretty good, but it remained to be seen how it would feel overnight.

title: 65 Block Security Plans Win Approval of Police
description: The Police Department flpproved Thursday 65 security programs proposed by block associations around the city. The total cost of the programs will be $189,455.

title: Israel Is Accused in U.N. Of Sinking a Soviet Ship
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12The Soviet Union accused Israel today of barbarous attacks on nonmilitary targets and demanded that they be stopped at once.

title: The Legendary Treasure White Sands Missile Range
description: WHITE SANDS, N.M.  Lost treasure stories are a dime a dozen in the Southwest. But when the Army; Air Force; the White House; Congressmen; New Mexico's Governor and F. Lee Bailey and dozens of other lawyers get into a single treasure saga, only confusion and rumors remain cheap.

title: I.B.M. ASKS SPEED ON TELEX APPEAL
description: The International Business Machines Corporation filed a memorandum yesterday in Federal District Court in Tulsa, Okla., asking the court to help expedite appellate consideration of Judge A. Sherman Christensen's Sept. 17 decision finding I.B.M. in violation of the antitrust laws in a case brought by the Telex Corporation, a manufacturer of pheripheral equipment for computers.

title: Soviet Party Journal Renews Attack on Sakharov
description: MOSCOW, Oct 12  The leading Soviet Communist party political journal has unleashed a new attack against Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident nufear physicist, accusing him of runaway antiSovietism that poisons the international atmosphere.

title: Rangers, Islanders in Action Tonight
description: For those New York fanatics who think hockey is the only sport and are oblivious to the World Series, they have two games going for them tonight.

title: Rival Stadium Plans Stir a Bistate Furor
description: A bitter behind  the  scenes struggle has developed between New York and New Jersey over a proposed Sunnyside, Queens, sport complex that has the strong backing, of Governor Rockefeller and that could effectively kill a similar New Jersey race track and football stadium.

title: Harvester Pact to Expire
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UPI)International Harvester said yesterday that the United Automobile Worker's had set Oct. 18 as the termination date of its labor contract covering about 40,500 company workers. The contract was to expire at midnight Sept. 30 but was extended while negotiations continued fo ra new pact.

title: Small Toes, Wisdom Teeth Are Said to Be On Way Outs
description: EDMONTON, Alberta (AP)Humans gradually are losing their small toes and wisdom teeth, said Dr. Phillip Tobis, of the University of Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: Up Front Near the Canal: War of Fixed Positions
description: IN THE NORTHERN SINAI DESERT, Oct. 12The northum end of the Suez Canal lies 15 miles away, and the Egyptian forward lines are a few miles nearer. Gunfire booms in the distance, and when an air raid siren howls nobody at an operational headquarters is in a hurry to take cover.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Senate Unit Backs Parker
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Daniel Parker to be the new foreign aid administrator. Mr. Parker, chairman of the Parker Pen Company, Is to succeed John A. Hannah, who has retired as administrator of the Agency for International Development.

title: Woman Becomes President Of an Army College Class
description: FT. LEAVENWORTH, Kan. (UPI)Another male tradition has fallen. A woman is president of the army's Command and General Staff College class.

title: Walter Audisio Dies in Italy; Partisan Executed Mussolini
description: ROME, Oct. 12  Walter Audisio, the Communist partisan who claimed credit for the execution of Italy's World War II Fascist dictator, Benito Mussolini, died here last night at the age of 64.

title: BRITISH RIDGE CALLS A CIGARETTE ALMS
description: LONDON (UPI)Is asking a passerby for a cigarette begging? It is, a London court ruled, and sentenced Robert McLerie to a month in jail.

title: Gradual PhaseOut Sought For WagePrice Controls
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 12Treasury Secretary George P. Scultz said today that the Nixon Administration was trying to work out a gradual, industrybyindustry approach to decontrol of prices and wages.

title: HEALTH SERVICES ASK $130MILLION
description: The Health Services Administration yesterday requested $130million in capital budget funds for 197374, of which $12.9million would go toward construction of new hospitals in Washington Heights and the East New York section of Brooklyn and a new 650bed tower at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn.

title: Miss Byrne Bride Of David M. Grant
description: Miss Elizabeth Mary Byrne, daughter of Mrs. Thomas James Byrne of Drexel Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Byrne, was married here yesterday to David M. Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Glauberman of Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Pontiac Police Fired On
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Oct, 12 (UPI)Patrolmen from four squad cars were fired on from three different directions last night while investigating a shooting incident on the city's South Side, the police said today. No injuries were reported in the incident in this city 25 miles northwest of Detroit.

title: Other Mideast War News
description: CAIRO, Oct. 12A worried and sometimes angry group of almost 300 American tourists were told today by the chief United States diplomatic official here that the Government had chartered a Greek ship to take most of them out of Egypt early next week.

title: HOUSE VOTES A RISE IN SCHOOL LUNCH AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a compromise bil !that would increase Federal aid to the school lunch program by 25 per cent.

title: MIDWEST FLOODS LEAVE SEVEN DEAD
description: At least seven persons were known dead yesterday and thousands remained homeless as residents of five Middle Western states began to dig out from three days of heavy rains.

title: On the Wrong Track?
description: As a solution for New York horse racing's problems, the proposed $275million Sunnyside, Queens, sports complex looks more like pie in the sky than like downtoearth medicine.

title: A Search for More Victims In Texas Ends in Failure
description: District attorney said yesterday that the discovery of extra bones had prompted a search for more victims of the Houston mass murders on a Gulf Coast island where four bodies have been found.

title: Thailand Plans a Lottery With Use of Movie Tickets
description: BANGKOK, Thailand (AP)The Thai government says it wants to start a lottery using movie tickets.

title: DR. I. T. DONALDSON
description: Dr. Isaiah Theodore Donaldson, a member of the city's Department of Social Services who trained dental assistants and was field supervisor for dental clinics throughout the city, died Wednesday at the Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived at 485 Lenox Avenue.

title: Mel Davis Agrees to Pact; Knicks Play Here Tonight
description: The Knicks invested heavily in their future yesterday when they finally came to terms with Mel Davis of St. Johns, their No. 1 draft choice. The 6foot6inch 225pounder is expected to learn enough this season to fill the shoes of Dave DeBusschere when the AllStar forward retires at the end of the season.

title: Hiram Walker Raises Earnings
Excerpt From Opinion of Court of Appeals on Examination of Presidential Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Following are excerpts from the opinion of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on the issue of court examination of Presidential tapes and opinion of Judges George E. MacKinnon and Malcolm R. Wilkey concurring and dissenting in part:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., Oct. 12 (AP)The Amateur Athletic Union restored today the amateur standing of the late Jim Thorpe, who starred in the 1912 Olympics only to be stripped of his gold medals on allegations that he was a professioal. The board of governors of the A.A.U. today moved to restore Thorpe as an amateur for the period of 190912.

title: Violence Hurting St. Croix Tourism
description: CHRISTIANSTED, Saint Croix, V. I., Oct. 12The rains come almost daily now and the afternoons have turned muggy, but it is neither the rain nor the uncomfortable heat that is the growing concern on this resort island in the Caribbean.

title: Soutine Works Displayed In a Moving Exhibition
description: For the inauguration of its spacious new galleries and offices at 40 West 57th Street, the Marlborough Gallery has mounted a large retrospective exhibition of the paintings of Chaim Soutine, one of the masters of the School of Paris. Organized by Maurice: Tuchman, the senior curator of modern art at the Los Angeles County, Museum of Art, who is one of our leading authorities on Soutine's work the show con sists of 78 paintings dating from 1916 to 1942 Soutine died in 1943 at the age of 50.

title: Mother of 3 Stabs the Pilot But He Lands Plane Safely
description: GROSSE ILE, Mich., Oct. 12 (UPI)A mother apparently bent on killing herself and her three, children wrestled and stabbed the pilot of a chartered plane today.

title: Egyptian Armored Car Joins IsraelisFatally
description: TEL AVIV, Oct, 12 (AP)The Israeli state radio said today that an Egyptian armoroed troop carrier got lost in the Sinai Desert during the night and joined an Israeli tank column by mistake.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 12When the New York Mets won the National League pennant Wednesday, the champagne on their uniforms hadn't dried yet when Ruhe Walker looked into Yogi Berra's office. Surrounded by newsmen and wellwishers, the Mets' manager glanced up.

title: FREE BUS SERVICE FOR ELDERLY SLATED
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Oct. 12 (AP) A free bus service for senior citizens in eleven rural towns surrounding this Burlington County community is scheduled to go into operation Monday.

title: Screen: Women in Love:The Cast
description: "My heart is sore as if it had been stabbed": that kind of imagery may pass in Germany, but stab-wise New Yorkers know that wounded hearts don't lounge around, they go to Bellevue. Even those who love pain will be frustrated by "The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant," shown last night at the New York Film Festival.Throughout, the cruelty creaks and the sobs sound forcedyou might call it sawdust suffering. Petra (Margit Carstensen), a successful fashion designer, plays slavemaster to her secretary, barking out orders"Get my shoes!"in a style that fails to match Joan Crawford's in "The Best of Everything."The slave winces with mute gratitude until their stable relationship is disrupted by a younger woman. Then the secretary's typewriter clatters with agitation while Petra seduces the newcomer. You can see the next scene coming like an avalanche: there's going to be a role reversal here. So Petra becomes a slave to the sulky model who says she needs men "from time to time" and soon returns to her husband.In response, Petra gets sloshed all over a white fur floor, stamps on her antique tea set, announces that she'd like to die, to sleep . . . (no, she's not going to dream), and ruins her own birthday party. Hung over, she resolves to be nicer to her secretary, who exits at onceapparently appalled by even a hint of kindness."Bitter Tears" almost contributes to film historyit's like an anthology of movie chestnuts culled from the last 50 years. It would be even more enlightening if the director (R. W. Fassbinder) had been born in the eighteen-nineties instead of 1945. Still, we get a flood of lavish facial expressions from silent movies. The actresses grin or smoulder extravagantly, heave their shoulders high in poignant shrugs. There's also the old gimmick of peering intently into a mirror while making a long slow speech about the past.And obviously, Mr. Fass-binder, thinks that women flirt like mastodons. Every gesture, each glance, any phrase is freighted with significanceeven "Would you . . . like coffee" or "I used to like ... mathematics." And eyes have to freeze between the simplest of sentences. But my favorite relic from bad old pictures is the (deeply emotional) monologue delivered by someone who has her cheek pressed against the upper back of the lucky listener, while the latter stares into space. This occurs three times in the movie, surely a record for the shoulder blade as amplifier.All the right props are presenta Siamese cat, baldheaded unclothed mannequins, a quasi-Renaissance mural of far-flung nudes more wigs than you ever saw at a demolition sale, plus seasonable slave clothes: metallic breast cups, throttling gold collars, a bare back with a latticework of chains. And there's traditional wisdom, too, such as: "A woman has her trumps, but she has to play them." Or, "Where terror reigns, markind is puny." And, "Everyyone needs consolation."Clearly, the director was awash in his fantasies about lesbianism. He worked hard on decadence (gin at breakfast, fur on anything,) and strugged to create a lush, weird setting for inevitable remorse. He wants the audience to remember how terribly unnatural, this all is. Hence, his women look like no one you'd ever meet, and he has filmed them under lighting that makes them look pastier and stranger than anyone encountered by flashlight in a sewer.Despite a few lines like "Woman must fight for her place in this world," don't let it be rumored that this is a liberated movie. Instead, it should be regarded as a chronicle of blunders that film-makers have repeated throughout the decades.

title: To Our Readers
description: Distribution of this issue of The New York Times was delayed by work stoppages by the printers' union in defiance of a court order. The stoppages also made it necessary to reduce coverage of the news. Details, Page 24.

title: People in Sports: Sparky Ashamed
description: After 24 hours of meditation, Sparky Anderson, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, has changed his mind. After the pennantwinning game Wednesday, when the Met fans went wild, Sparky said: I'm ashamed I live in this country, and I'm not too sure New York is in this country. New York ought to be the next atomic bombtesting ground.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threejudge Federal Court in the Southern District yesterday told six prisoners serving life terms in the Green Haven State Prison that they did not have a constitutional right to marry. The prisoners had filed suit challenging new legislation passed last spring that granted all prisoners, except those serving life sentences, the right to marry. The New York Civil Liberties Union, lawyers for the prisoners, said the decision would be appealed.

title: Agnew Foe Not Surprised
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 12 (UPI) One of two 1972 Republican National Convention delegates to vote against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's nomination said yesterday that he was not surprised by Mr. Agnew's resignation. State Representative Wayne Whitehead of Eugene, who along with Oregon Secretary of State Clay Myers voted against Mr. Agnew, said, It was apparent from Agnew's unfounded criticism of the, press that he was apparently trying to hide something.

title: A ShaggyDog Story With Mysterious Ending
description: WAKAYAMA, Japan (AP) A small shaggy dog was spotted on a street with a paperwrapped package in its mouth.

title: Girls in Oregon Swim Club Have It All Over the Boys
description: THE DALLES, Ore. (UPI)Five girls on the Dalles Summer Swim Club have left no doubt about which sex has more endurance.

title: U.N. School Shuns the Mideast Issue
description: While the United Nations Security Council sat in chambers consumed in bitter debate over the raging Middle East war, a half mile down the East River at the school that serves the children of many of the delegates and Secretariat members, the issue was snuffled yesterday under an uneasy moratorium.

title: WOMAN RUNNING FOR CHURN POST
description: A 53yearold theologian and ecumenist who is also a champion of women's rights stands a good chance of becoming the first woman general secretary of the National Council of Churches.

title: $1,035,872 Raised for Byrne Drive, Nearly Triple the Amount for Sandman
description: TRENTON, Oct. 12  The Democratic gubernatorial campagin of Bendan T. Byrne, has raised nearly three times as much money as that attracted by the campaign of his Republican rival, Charles W. Sandman Jr., it was disclosed in campaign financial statements filed today.

title: Nat'l. Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHTS GAMES

title: JOSEPH J. M'NICHOLAS
description: Joseph J. McNicholas, assistant principal of biology and general science at John Adams High School, Ozone Park, Queens, died Thursday night at his home in Queens Village, Queens. He was 55 years old.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose sharply again yesterday in steppedup trading. The same conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: TorontoKen Buchanan, 134 pounds, Scotland, knocked out Frankie Ontero, 137; Miami, 6 rounds.

title: Ivy Race Begins in Earnest
description: Those eight unpredictable Ivy League teams have their first full afternoon of league action today under circumstances that few, if any, fans of the ancient group expected just three weeks ago.

title: A Cabot Will Use 1496 Permit For Some DutyFree Importing
description: LONDON (AP)Some time during 1976 a retired Royal Air Force officer plans to bring in a few kegs of tobacco and half a dozen bottles of liquor from North America without paying any duty.

title: Bridge: His Idea of Unseen Hands Must Guide Defender's Play
description: When attempting to construct a mental picture of the unseen hands, a defender must make sure that his reconstruction is consistent with the bidding and play up to that point. West failed in this difficult task on the diagramed deal from the Summer National Championships, but his failure would not have been fatal if his partner had kept his head.

title: Kissinger Appoints 9 Top Aides, 2 From Outside the Department
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Secretary of State Kissinger announced nine toplevel appointments today in what initally appeared to be a modest reorganization in the State Department.

title: Week of War
description: The Yom Kippur War in the Middle East is a week old today with no immediate end in sight. This time it was the Arabs who achieved surprise as Egypt and Syria attacked simultaneously on the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, a time when Israeli vigilance and readiness were at relatively low ebb. Thousands have already been killed and wounded, the losses of both sides in planes, tanks and other expensive equipment are staggering.

title: 3 NETWORKS SEEK TO COVER HEARING
description: Officials of the three major networks yesterday asked the Congressional leadership for permission to cover the confirmation hearings on the new Vice President, including upprecedented live coverage of the floor debates in the Senate and House of Representatives.

title: A's Pitchers Will Get Their Chances at Bat
description: The designated hitter, used all season by the Oakland A's in winning the American League pennant, will not be permitted in the World Series, which will be played under, the traditional baseball rules still employed by the National League.

title: Weicker Wants Testimony From Former F.B.I. Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, asked today that a former F.B.I. official be called to testify at the Watergate hearings about activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that might have affected the 1972 Presidential race.

title: The Junta's Challenge, in Chile
description: Many nonChileans have a deep affection for the Chilean people and a profound respect for the nation and its institutions. Aware that the Allende Government permitted or deliberately contrived to create a situation of nearchaos politically, economically and socially, there was a measure of understanding if not approval of the decision of the Chilean military to seize power in an unconstitutional coup d'etat. Those who knew and admired the highly professional Chilean military officer corps, it appears mistakenly, expected a more intelligent and humane approach to the amelioration of harsh problems created in large measure by the doctrinaire and incompetent Allende regime. But there is now widespread revulsion at reports of mass killings and other violations of human rights.

title: Judas Elephants on Loan
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP)India is making a heavy loan to Malaysia  four elephants. The trained pachyderms will be used as bait to, lure cropruining wild elephants into traps, a game warden said.

title: Nixon's Address and Remarks by Ford
description: Following is a transcript of the address by President Nixon last night in Washington nominating Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan to be Vice President and of Mr. Ford's response, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Aluminum Workers' Goal
description: PITTSBURG, Oct, 11 (UPI)Delegates to a United Steelworkers' Aluminum Conference adopted Thursday a contract proposal demanding very sub stantial wage increases and a cost of living escalator for pensions to counter inflation.

title: Egypt Says Men and Gear Still Pour Across Canal
description: CAIRO, Saturday, Oct. 13Egyptian forces continued for the seventh day yesterday to pour men and heavy equipment across the Suez canal to make the area secure against recapture by Israeli forces, according to Egyptian military communiqus.

title: Big Board Delays Texasgulf Trading
description: The New York Stock Exchange delayed trading yesterday in the common stock of Texasgulf, Inc., pending clarification of circumstances regarding the tender offer for 10 million shares made by The Canada Development Corporation at $29 a share on July 25. Oa July 25 Texasgulf stock closed at 26. Shortly before the close of trading yesterday, a block of 60,000 Texasgulf shares, traded at 30, off . Earlier yesterday, the exchange said that an inquiry it conducted indicated that a dispute existed on the right of Texasgulf stockholders to withdraw their shares tendered through Oct. 5 and not withdrawn prior to the close of XU business Oct. 10.

title: Craig an Astro Coach
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The Houston Astros announced today that Roger Craig had been named pitching coach for 1974. Hub Kittle, who had the job this year, will remain as one of the Astros' coaches.

title: Israeli Losses to Date Called Below '67 Toll
description: TEL AVIV. Oct. 12  Israeli Army sources said today that losses to date had been lower than the 780 Israelis killed during the sikday war in 1967.

title: Antiques: Shakers' Skill
description: Today's Shaker buffs face few of the problems that Mr. and Mrs. Edward Deming Andrews did when they began their prestigious collection exactly 50 years ago. Then there were no museum exhibitions, illustrated textbooks or experts to guide them. Of only minimal assistance, too, were the few surviving members of the communal sect in steady decline since it had peaked at 6,000 members in 1850.

title: Federal Controls Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Nixon Administration reluctantly adopted today a mandatory allocation program governing the wholesale distribution of home heating oil.

title: McGovern Offers a Commodities Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) Senator George McGovern, DemocratSouth Dakota, introduced today a tough, comprehensive bill that would make radical changes in the regulation of commoditiesutures trading in the United States for the first time in 37 years.

title: Lakers Wilt With Chamberlain Gone
description: The first signs of the trouble that many National Basketball Association fans believe is in store for, the Los Angeles Lakers this season popped up Thursday night in Atlanta. Without Wilt Chamberlain, Jim McMillian and were trounced, 129102, as Keith Erickson, the Lakers the Hawks scored their secand impressive victory.

title: The Gentlemen in Red
description: DURBAN, South Africa (AP) The head of a necktie company said men who wear red clothing appear sexier to women. He predicted that reddish hues would take an important place in mens fashions throughout the 1970's.

title: Peron Installed as President of Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 12 (AP)Juan D. Pern received the blue and white presidential sash today in the same pink mansion he was forced to abandon 18 years ago by a military coup.

title: Regime Weakens as Cambodian Quits
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 12The resignation of Premier In Tam, though unlikely to have any immediate effect on the nature of the Government or the course of events in Cambodia, is nevertheless one more sign of the deterioration of popular support for the Government of President Lon Nol.

title: People and Business
description: The Vice Presidency has been much in the news and James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has just been elected vice president of the Stock Exchanges. So Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, speaking at a dinner this week given by the Amex for the participants in the federation's 12th general assembly in New York, said as he looked at his counterpart at the Big Board: Mr. Needham's selection also poses a happy dilemma for me. I have been in the habit of greeting him as Mr. Chairman. I will now with complete impunity be able to say Mr. Vice President.

title: FRANCIS RANDOLPH, BROKER, COLLECTOR
description: Francis F. Randolph, an investment broker and manager, who was a director or trustee of many corporations and institutions, died yesterday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 129 East 69th Street.

title: TALKS COLLAPSE ON OILTRICE RISE
description: VIENNA, Oct. 12Negotiations have broken down between the major Western oil companies and oilexporting countries of the Persian Gulf, which are seeking higher prices for crude oil.

title: Trees in Middle of Frisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, (AP) Eighty redwood trees have been planted in the middle of the financial district as part of a $250,000 park in front of the Transamerica Building. The trees should grow to a height of 200 feet in about 50 or 60 years.

title: BLACKS OPENING A HOUSING COOP
description: EAST ORAGNE, Oct. 12 A cooperative town house complex of 247 units, described by its sponsors as one of the largest housing projects in the country developed by blacks, opens officially here tomorrow. Sixty families are already living there.

title: The New Game of OneDownsmanship
description: In middle class America, the revolution of rising expectations has run outyou will excuse the expressionof gas: In its place, it seems; has come something very differentin fact so different it is actually the opposite. Bigger is no longer better, faster no longer the measure, growth no longer the goal. Just when we had all learned from our young people that to be anywhere we had to be with itmow we find the only real way to be with it is to be without it.

title: Candidates' Day
description: The four major candidates for Mayor took part yesterday in a tepid debate marked by an occasional angry outburst as to who was best qualified to solve the crime problem.

title: Castro Dancers Fill Program With Shopping Cart of Styles
description: The Alonso Castro Dance Company is a shopping cart of styles  a little Spanish, a breath of soul, suggestions of ballet and allpurpose moderndance movement. The choreography is equally electric and generally undistinguished. The company presented a collection of works on Thursday evening at the Theater of Riverside Church.

title: 6 NATIONS PLANNING TO BUG NORTH SEA
description: LONDON (AP)Six European governments are collabOrating in a scheme to bug the North Sea and listen in its current movements work. If the water borne devices Northern Europe lower land masses should be better prepared against intrusion by the sea.

title: Corruption by Contract
description: The fall of Spiro T. Agnew, however poignant in personal terms, is no longer a national concern; but the systematic corruption in the award of public contracts, which gave that tragedy its origins, should be very much a concern at all levels of government and in all areas of the country.

title: CHILE ANNOUNCES MORE EXECUTIONS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 12The military Government announced last night that six people had been executed by soldiers after they allegedly attacked a noncommissioned officer and then tried to flee.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: President's Choice Gerald Rudolph Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12When Vice President Agnew was castigated on the floor of the House of Representatives two years ago as being an intellectual sadist, the buffoon of the year and a clown, the Republican who rose to his defense was the minority leader, Gerald Rudolph Ford.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1973
description: President Nixon said he would nominate Gerald R. Ford, the House minority leader, to succeed Spiro T. Agnew as Vice President of the United States. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, Page 19.]

title: DOG'S LIFE IS SAVED WITH A PACEMAKER
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. (AP)Only a short time ago, Ginger, a 10yearold female Boston terrier belonging to Mrs. Dorothy Brown, had little chance of surviving because of a heart ailment.

title: ORIGINAL CABINET OF NIXON IS GONE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)  With the resignation on Wednesday of Spiro T. Agnew as Vice President, President Nixon's entire original Cabinet has left office.

title: Closer Cooperation Is Predicted For Government and Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, the chancellor of the State University of New York, predicted here today that actions by courts and legislatures would force closer cooperation betwen the Government and colleges in making highr educational policies.

title: GOING OUT
description: HUSH For the several months of summer Central Park has reverberated to ock'n'roll, symphonies, operas, noisily joyous celebrationsand enough is too much already. That's why Quiet Day will be observed over there all day today (if it rains loudly, try tomorrow). The park will hummaybe hohum is more quiet with all sorts of free activities that make no sound and demand no applause. Theoretically, at least, because some of them are acoustically debatable.

title: Stocks Reach the Highest Point Since Last Spring
description: The stock market closed yesterday at its highest level since last spring, despite afternoon profit taking that trimmed early strong gains.

title: Amtrack Will Double Fleet Of Corridor Metroliners
description: Amtrak, the nationwide rail passenger system, announced yesterday that it would virtually double its fleet of Metroliner cars and extend highspeed Metroliner service from New York to Boston.

title: Chinese Art in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY (AP)  The Nelson Art Gallery here, with one of the top three Chinese Art Collections in America, holds a Neolithic pot that dates to 3500 B.C.

title: Hill People in Vietnam Battle to Keep Land
description: BAN ME THUOT, South Vietnam, Oct. 7In Ban Me Thuotthe overgrown village of Thuot's Fatherland is a principal concern, for the montagnards of the Central Highlands are afraid they are losing theirs slowly, ineluctably, to the thrusting lowland Vietnamese. In the name of economis development, decrees enacted in Saigon have given outsiders, who somehow tend to be big businessmen, highranking civil servants and officers like Air Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, rights to virgin land.

title: Agnew to Make Televised Talk To the Nation on Monday Night
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Spiro T. Agnew has asked broadcast networks for time to address the nation Monday night.

title: Kissinger Says U.S. and Soviet Have Acted to Keep War Restricted to Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Middle East war had the potentialities for getting out of hand and involving great powers but that so far the United States and the Soviet Union had acted to prevent it from doing so.

title: Low Italian Dudgeon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12In the old days, which extended from 1492 to a year or so ago, Oct. 12 was Columbus Day. In the lateAmerican spirit of excess in all thingsthe national motto should be changed from In God We Trust to Excessior! the Day has become a 72hour weekend which drifts back and forth on the October calendar. This year, for example, the Columbus Day weekend occurred on Oct. 6, 7 and 8.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Confirmation Encounters an Obstacle in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Young Democratic liberals in the Senate succeeded late today in blocking automatic referral of the VicePresidential nomination to the Rules Committee, a basically conservative panel.

title: LABOR IN NORWAY TO FORM CABINET
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 12 (UPI)  Premier Lars Korvald and his nonSocialist coalition resigned today, and Trygve Bratteli, the leader of the Labor party, agreed to form a government.

title: Dr. Gerald Jameison Dies; N.Y. Hospital Psychiatrist
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y., Oct. 12Dr. Gerald R. Jameison a retired New York psychiatrist who formerly headed the women's division of New York HospitalCornell Medical Center's Westchester Division in White Plains, died today at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Capture of Capital Thought Unlikely
description: EL QUNEITRA, on the Golan Heights, Oct. 12Parts of the Syrian Army appeared to be in full retreat today as the Israeli Army advanced to within 18 miles of the Syrian capital of Damascus.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Faculty Spelling Lesson
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) Del Campo High School recently had its 100 parking spaces marked faculty in white paint, but all of them came out misspelled as faculity, with an extra i.

title: Nixon Praises Newsboys
description: WASHINGTON, Ict. 10 (UPI) President Nixon today praised the youths who carry newspapers in a message for tomorrow, Newspaper Carrier Day. The newspaper route is one of the best training grounds for, millions of young Americans, Mr. Nixon said. In communities across the nation, countless illustrious Americans share the common bond of hitying traveled the newspaper mute on the way to their successful careers.

title: A HUMPHREY GROUP CITED ON 1972 GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (Reuters)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's 1972 campaign organization failed to disclose $456,732 in contributions until more than a year after he lost his hid for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the Federal Elections Office reported today.

title: Theater: The Tempest
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12To do The Tempest full justice on stage would probably require the conjuring genius and imaginative resources of a prosperowhich is why we do not see it as often as other Shakespeare. To its credit, the Yale Repertory Theater has made a serious attempt to harness this masterpiece. The company opened its season last night with a lavish production, codirected by Alvin Epstein and Moni Yakim.

title: Mrs. Johnson Hostess For Highway Awards
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Oct. 11 The towering stalks of yellow Maximilian daisies planted as a part of Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's highway beautification program decorated highways leading to the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park Thursday.

title: Princess Anne Rides Show Victor
description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 12 (AP)  Princess Anne scored a decisive victory in the Horse of the Year show today an Goodwill, the horse that thre her in the European championships at Kiev.

title: JUDGES RULE 52
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 12In what it called an unavoidable and extraordinary ruling, the United States Court of Appeals held tonight that President Nixon must turn over to the Federal District Court here the disputed White House tape recordings possibly bearing on Watergate crimes.

title: NO NEED 15 SEEN TO CLOSE PENNSY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 Federal District Judge John P. Fullam who is overseeing the Penn Central Railroad's bankruptcy proceedings, said today that he believed there was no immediate need for the huge carrier to cease its operations.

title: An Illuminating Accident
description: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 12 (AP)Last night's football game between Western Connecticut State and Newark State was postponed until tomorrow afternoon. The truck carrying lights to the field was involved in an accident.

title: On Maoist Modesty
description: PEKINGSome years ago when visiting an Algerian cooperative near Blida I was struck by a slogan emblazoned in large letters: Long live revolutionary modesty. Since revolution is normally dynamic and immodest, this seemed paradoxical.

title: Congratulations to Ford Offered by Rockefeller
description: Governor Rockefeller, who had been considered a strong contender to be nominated as Vice President, offered his heartiest congratulations tonight to President Nixon's choice for the post, Gerald R. Ford, House minority leader, according to United Press International.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Long knitted mufflers with ends flying. Multiple sweaters. Cuffed pants. Leather or fake leather jackets. Basic black. Newest trends in women's clothes? No. In men's.

title: Photo of Poe Brings Record $9,250
description: A daguerreotype of Edgar Allan Poe has brought $9,250 at a Chicago public auction. The buyer, George R. Rinhart, president of the Rinhart Galleries, Inc., 62 West 834 Street; claimed that it was the highest amount ever paid, at auction for a single photogyaph. The previous auction record for a photograph was $2,000 paid last year at a Sotheby Parke Bernet auction for a deguerreotype of Henry D. Thoreau. The daguerreotype of Poe 180949) is believed to have been taken in 1848. Mr. Rinhart noted that Poe died just a few years before introduction: of the wetplate glassnegative form of photography. The daguerreotype has a protective glass covering and is encased with a velvet lining between two bookstyle leather covers.

title: Senate Confirms Resor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Stanley R. Resor, former Secretary of the Army, to be the United States representative with the rank of Ambassador in negotiations for troop reductions in Europe.

title: Agnew Retains Free Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Senate passed a measure today to permit official business mail from the office of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew to be sent under the frank of the Secertary of the Senate until Nov. 10.

title: He Loses as His Horse Wins
description: RENTON, Wash., (UPI) Dr. James Furuwaka had sheepish look, as he stood in the winner's circle beside his horse, Coco's Pal, at Longacres Race Track. The reason: He got mixed up at the betting window and put his money on someone else's horse.

title: Wild Elephant Kills 11
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP)  A, wild elephant bolted from the jungles of Zaire across the border into Sudan, killing 11 persons, Egypt's Middle East News Agency reported from the Sudanese capital of Khartoum.

title: Art: Small, Strong Scuffitures by Goto
description: Joseph Goto, who is surely one of the best American sculptors at work today, has had five New York oneman shows, the latest of them in 1966. But memories are short, and his new snow at the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, comes as a surprise. The surprise is not in the 23 exhibited sculptures themselves, for none of them postdate 1966. The surprise is that sculptures of such strength and individuality once seen, could have become halfforgotten.

title: Ford for Vice President
description: Heavily beset by the exposure of Spiro Agnew's criminality, by fresh rumors of scandal concerning his own financial affairs, and by the still unresolved Watergate issues, Mr. Nixon has taken the easy way out of his Vice Presidential problem. In choosing Representative Gerald Ford of Michigan, the House Minority Leader, Mr. Nixon settled, for a nominee whom he has good reason to believe will gain easy confirmation and cause him no serious political problems.

title: Rolling Laboratory Checks On Vienna's Environment
description: VIENNA (AP)  A rolling laboratory equipped with the most modern technical devices is now cruising through the Austrian capital to speed up and facilitate the enforcement of the new environmental laws.

title: CANDIDATE QUITS CLEVELAND RACE
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 12  In a surprise move, James M. Carney dropped out of the race for Mayor of Cleveland last night. He cited personal reasons for his action.

title: Leaving Behind the Stoned Out Years
description: IOWA CITYBecause of my job I spend more time with kids in their twenties than most men of my age. I also have three of my own, and so I often wonder what they're expecting of life and how that differs from my own expectations of twentyfive years ago.

title: Yancey Sets Pace With 135
description: INZAI, Japan, Oct. 12 (AP) Bert Yancey of Hanover, Pa., carded a oneunderpar 70 today and maintained a twostroke lead after two rounds of the $300,000 Pacific Masters golf tournament. His 36hole total was 135.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)  The Administration sent to Congress today a proposed reorganization of the country's financial institutions that would do away with many of the present differences between banks and savings and loan associations. There was one major change the proposed bill from what had previously been announced. This is a truth in savings feature requiring financial institutions to provide more information to depositors.

title: Butz Renews Fertilizer Bid
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 12 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz renewed today his public appeal for lifting of Federal price controls on fertilizers. Butz, in a speech prepared for a convention of the National Newspaper Association, said the action was needed to insure adequate fertilizer supplies so farmers can help hold down food prices by increasing production next year.

title: First in the State
description: The State Public Service Commission Certified yesterday that a major shortage in home and industrial fuel oils existed for Long Islandthe first region in the state to be declared an oil insufficient area.

title: A Federal Annuity Missed by Agnew By Only 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Spiro T. Agnew failed by three months to become eligible for a civil service annuity that would have been worth about $15,000 a year to him once he reached the age of 62 years.

title: WALTER A. HYMAN
description: Walter A: Hyman, stage producer and business associate of Dustin Hoffman, the actor, for the last five years, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, 983 Park Avenue. He was 51 years old.

title: NASA Consultant to the City Is Finding DowntoEarth Uses for Space Technology
description: Tucked away in a cubicle office on the 11th floor of the Municipal Buding, Abe Karen spins futuristic fantasies about a spaceage city.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: States Raise Costs of Fighting Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that the states had estimated it would cost them $60.7billion to build the necessary sewage treatment and other waste water facilities to take care of their population through 1990 nearly three times higher than a similar estimate made in 1971.

title: Laos Capital Relaxed as Reds Arrive
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 12Armed Communist troops began arriving in Vientiane today, but the people of this rustic little capital were concerned only with the current boatracing festival on the Mekong River.

title: Tentative Hearing Oct. 23 an Removal of W. A. Boyle
