description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)  Justice Department sources said today that as a precautionary measure Oct. 23 has been tentatively reserved for a Federal hearing involving the removal of W. A. Boyle to Pittsburgh, where he faces Federal conspiracy charges.

title: YELLOWSTONE PARK ENDS ELK HAND OUT
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., (AP) An offer of free elks from Yellowstone National Park to private individuals is no longer effect here, the National Park Service reports.

title: House Passes Restrictions on President's WarMaking Powers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Despite new warnings of a veto, the House passed today and sent to President Nixon a compromise war powers bill aimed at limiting Presidential authority to send the armed forces into foreign hostilities without Congressional approval.

title: Agnew Prosecution Took Pains TO Prepare a LockedUp Case
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 12It started modestly.

title: Campus Notes
description: Protest demonstrations are rare on campuses this fallat least for students, if not for their parentsbut a proposal to arm security guards at the State University of Buffalo has resulted in controversy, a sitin and a protest march.

title: Government Control of Jet Fuel May Lead to 10% Cut in Flights
description: The Government's mandatory allocation of jet fuel is likely to lead to cutbacks of up to 10 per cent in domestic airline service, industry experts estimated yesterday.

title: Miss Ghriskey Has Nuptials
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 12Miss Marcia Markley Ghriskey was married here this noon to DeWitt Linn sage Jr., president of Krainin & Sage, a New York film production company. The Rev. Harold Bassage performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Williamson Ghriskey.

title: TV Review
description: One of the jays of latenight television is a rerun of something like Double Indemnity, that hardboiled Hollywood classic of 1946, shining like bygone gold. It has now been remade for television, God knows why. Prepare for 90 minutes of nostalgic wincing tonight, starting at 8:30 over the American Broadcasting Company network. Why, why, why did the do it?

title: Gimbel Brothers Plans to Name New Chairman of Division Here
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., plans to name Robert R. Broadbent, executive vice president of the Higbee Company, Cleveland departmentstore chain, as chairman and chief executive officer of the Gimbel New York division. He is expected to form a new twoman top management team for the division, in which Paul Salomone will continue as president.

title: Southern U. Deaths Are Laid by N.E.A. To Administrators
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 12 (UPI)  The National Education Association said that administrators were responsible for the confrontation that resulted in the killings of two black students during a demonstration on Nov. 16, 1972. The report said the adininistrators were to blame because they had ordered the untimely and extraordinary ariests of leaders of the student protest.

title: TIMES PRINTERS DEFY COURT BANS
description: Members of the typographical union employed at The New York Times held meetings during working time yesterday, preventing publication of the first edition, reducing news coverage and delaying The Times's report of President Nixon's announcement of his choice for Vice President.

title: Rule of Law
description: The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has found no merit in President Nixon's claim that the powers of his office entitle him to withhold the White House tapes from special prosecutor Archibald Cox and the grand jury investigating the Watergate breakin. In upholding the earlier ruling by Chief District Judge John J. Sirica, the sevenjudge panel summed up its estimate of the extraordinary immunities and broad discretionary powers claimed by Mr. Nixon with the crisp comment: These are invitations to refashion the Constitution and we reject them.

title: HARDIE PHILLIP, 86, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 12 Hardie. Phillip, designer of the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York City, died Wednesday at his home in Laguna Hills. He was 86 years old.

title: Surviving Babies Improve
description: DENVER, Oct. 16 (AP)The condition of the five surviving Stanek sextuplets continued to improve today, a hospital spokesman said. The six babies of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Stanek were born Sept. 16. Two days later, one of the two girls died.

title: September Decline Listed In Corn and Wheat Crops
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The size of the 1973 corn and wheat crops, a key to the outlook for future food supplies and prices, decreased fractionally during September but was still at a record high, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Dr. Spock Tells Why He No Longer Sings in Praise of Him
description: Dr. Spock is changing his pronouns! After 27 years, 201 printings, 23,445,781 copies sold, Baby and Child Care is about to be liberated from the tyranny of infantile male chauvinism.

title: Manzone Is Victor By 8 Shots on 147
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Oct. 12 Jim Manzone of Hampton Golf Club matched par 71 today for a winning 147 in the 36hole Long Island Senior Golf Association championship over the 6,780yard course at Southward Ho Country Club.

title: Girls in Military Academy Bring Back Civil War Days
description: BOONVILLE, Mo. (AP)The Kemper Military Academy here admitted girls this fill for the first time since the Civil War, school officials announced.

title: Wirt Hatcher, Developed Brands for Philip Morris
description: Wirt Hargrove Hatcher, who retired in 1962 as a senior vice president of Philip Morris, Inc., died Thursday in Richmond, where he lived. His age was 79.

title: PATH FARE PLAN IS RESUBMITTED
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey asked the Interstate Commerce Cornmission yesterday to reconsider its decision made on Thursday, denying a proposed increase in the PATH commuter fare to 50 cents from 30 cents.

title: HUGHES AIDE TELLS OF CAMPAIGN GIFT
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 (UPI) A top official of the Howard Hughes organization testified today that he gave $100,000 to Charles G. Rebozo for President Nixon's campaign fund.

title: Trucks Escape Stringent Pollution Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Many a pedestrian, engulfed in fumes, smoke and soot from a passing truck or bus, has wondered if anyone is trying to stop the noxious belching.

title: Dance: Joffrey Favorites
description: The Joffrey Ballet moved into its general repertory at the City Center 55th Street Theater with the smoothness of a RollsRoyce changing gearshould a RollsRoyce ever have to. After a first night that offered the successful New York premiere of its production of Ashton's The Dream, the company Thursday night relied upon two proven audience favorites, Kettentanz and Deuce Coupe, and a revival of Facade, a work not seen for two three seasons.

title: EARNINGS UP 12 AT HANOVER CORP.
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, parent of the country's fourth biggest bank, reported yesterday that its operating earnings during the, third quartera period when interest rates on loans reached record levelsrose almost 12 per cent.

title: G.S.A. Paid Nixon Home Bills Ordered by Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The General Services Administration repeatedly spent public funds for improvements and other projects at President Nixon's San Clemente home that were originally ordered by Mr. Nixon's personal attorney and private architect, acording to evidence presented to a Congressional investigating committee today.

title: New Treatment of Burns
description: TOKYO (AP)  Chinese doctors are using an herb known as ilex chinensis sims to treat serious burns, a Peking broadcast said. The herb is said to form a crust on the surface of the burn and prevent the loss of body fluids through the wound.

title: McGovern Urges Creation Of A National Food Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)  Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, proposed today the creation of a national food bank to supply the nutritional needs of disaster victims.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOW TO BE YOUR OWN BEST FRIEND. By Mildred Newman and Bernard Berkowitz with Jean Owen. Random House. 56 pages. $4.95.

title: Congress and G.O.P. Committee Favored Ford in Informal Poll
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12An informal poll by The New York Times, taken before it was known when President Nixon would anounce his choice for Vice President, showed that the House minority leader, Gerald R. Ford, was the favored candidate in Congress  among Republicans in the House in particular  and in the Republican National Committee.

title: Ironin White Bread Doubled by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The Food and Drug Administration ordered the nation's bakeries today to double the iron content of white bread to reduce the growing problem of irondeficiency anemia.

title: Medical Director Ur es Attitude Toward Alcoholics
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn. (UPI) You say the alcoholic you know is morally bankrupt, weakwilled, insensitive, disorderly, and irresponsible?

title: France Opens University Catering to Senior Citizens
description: TOULOUSE, France (UPI)A university exclusively for elderly citizens has opened its doors and counts an enIrollment of 1,000 students, university officials said.

title: CHOICE IS PRAISED BY BOTH PARTIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Congressional Democrats and Republicans received President Nixon's choice of Gerald R. Ford to be Vice President with widespread enthusiasm tonight.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: WILLIAM R. KING
description: BOSTON, Oct. 12 (AP)William R. King, former New England sports editor for The Associated Press, died Wednesday at Massachusetts General Hospital. His age was 75.

title: First Event at New Police Headquarters: Promotions
description: Fortyfour police officers were promoted to higher rank yesterday in a brief ceremony at the eastern end of the pedestrian mall in front of the new Police Headquarters, adjacent to the Municipal Building.

title: Mall Playhouse Is Thriving
description: PARAMUSThe Playhouse on the Mall, a suburban theater set in the midst of the shopping center here, has sold 5,000 subscriptions for the coming season.

title: Rutgers Plans Police Institute
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  An institute for police officers, bank executives, lawyers, computer managers and highway and criminaljustice planners will be held at Rutgers University on Oct. 26.

title: Lumberjacks Grow Scarce as an Easier Life Beckons
description: SPECULATOR, N.Y., Oct. 13 An American legend is dying. Lumberjacks  those burly folk heroes who could tear apart great logging centers like the Devil's Halfacre district in Bangor, Me., with a lust fired by lonely months in the woodsare becoming scarce.

title: A Setting for Speculation and Suspense
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13This city, always a hotbed of political rumor, went nearly apoplectic with speculation, suspense and surmise while waiting for President Nixon to announce his choice for a new Vice President yesterday.

title: The art of bankruptcy for fun and profit
description: Perhaps it is the incurable romantic in the writer combined with our current sexual savagery that has made him woo the thief. After all, what are we but a marginal lot, illequipped for modern times, devoid of useful skills, left to roam pathetically with a quiver full of quills.

title: The War At Home
description: America in the sixties was a country torn apart. In the early years of the decade, the liberals newly in power were beginning to stick their hard noses into the Tar Baby of Vietnam; at the end, much of a generation, beginning in idealism, was profoundly disillusioned with American institutions.

title: Gaiedens
description: THOSE who are interested in growing plants and who enjoy good food eventually find themselves fascinated with gourmet cooking. And what splendid recipe does not include herbs?

title: A 2County G.O.P. Dilemma
description: TRENTONIn one of the most unusual legislative elections in New Jersey's history, former State Senator James M. Turner is running for reelection even though he has been sentenced to five years in prison.

title: China's 24th
description: The Chinese People's Republic celebrated its 24th anniversary in low key recently. It has been suggested that the failure of the Peking leadership to make a public appearance such as used to be traditional on this occasion, reflects continuing bitter political tensions at the peak of Chinese power. This hypothesis can be neither proved nor refuted by the evidence available to the West. However, other Aspects of Chinese society are visible and can be inspected directly.

title: New & Novel
description: Tread Softly In This Place

title: EXCITY AIDE SAYS HE QUIT IN DISPUTE
description: A formerdeputy city adntinistratar has charged that he was forced out of office last summer because of his refusal to drop a fouryear study that called for reforms in the propertytaxassessment system.

title: Never Too Young to Be a Director
description: YOUTH is having its day in Hollywood. The hottest hits of the seasonAmerican Graffiti, Bang the Drum Slowly, Dillinger, Heavy Traffichave all been turned out by new directors in their twenties or early thirties. And based upon its glowing reception at the New York Film Festival, Mean Streetsthe work of 30yearold Martin Scorsesewill have moviegoers lining up at Cinema I, where it begins a run today. (Vincent Canby discussed it on Page 1.)

title: Child to the Ferraras
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ferrara of Kenmore, N.Y., on Sept. 22 in Children's Hospital, Buffalo.

title: 5 WESTERN NEWSMEN DETAINED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13.  Soviet policemen today detained five Western correspondents observing a demonstration by three Soviet Jews who were demanding a chance to go to Israel to, share the fate of our country at this crucial hour.

title: DETECTIVE WOUNDS GUNMAN IN CHELSEA
description: An offduty police detective shot and critically wounded a man who fired at him after allegedly robbing a supermarket in the Chelsea area of Manhattan yesterday afternoon.

title: Michigan Triumphs, 310; Pitt Upsets W. Virginia
description: Michigan Triumphs, 310; Pitt Upsets W. Virginia

title: Chess: Playing the Last Round First Might Ease the Strain a Bit
description: Mikhail Botvinnik, a former world champion, once suggested that the last round of tournaments be eliminated. Throughout his long and illustrious career, the Russian grandmaster has had ample opportunity to observe the tragicomic blunders resulting from staking everything on one last, desperate attempt to win.

title: W. German Team to Ride U.S. Circuit
description: West Germany is sending a strong fourman team to the North American indoor circuit this year. The squad, announced yesterday, consists of Hans Gunter Winkler, Alwin Schockemoehle and his younger brother, Paul, and Fritz Ligges.

title: School Board Issues Guidelines On Spending by Local Units
description: The city Board of Education has issued interim guidelines intended to prevent possible abuses in spending by the decentralized community school boards.

title: BURRS ASKS SHIFT IN CONTROL SETUP
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct 13 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, recommended today that wageprice controls be replaced by a review board with more limited powers to intervene in the economy.

title: Federal Jury Investigating Report of $10,000 Payoff to Mafia by Faberge to Settle. Jersey Strike
description: A Federol grand jury in Manhattan is investigating charges that Faberg, Inc., the cormetics conglomerate, paid 41 Mafia member $10,000 to help the company settle a strike at one of its plants in New Jersey.

title: Egyptians Said to Consolidate Positions in Sinai as More Troops Cross Canal
description: CAIRO, Oct. 13  Egyptian forces in the Sinai were reported today to be consolidating their easternmost positions. More troops and equipment were crossing to the east bank of the canal.

title: AUTOMOBILE SHOW TO OPEN SATURDAY
description: The second Greater New York Automobile Show opens Saturday for a nineday run at the Coliseum.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Liver Patient Awaits Aid of Donor for a Transplant
description: For John Lund, suffering from cancer of the liver, a liver transplant offers the only chance of survival. It is a slim chance, but it is the only hope that the 47yearold Mr. Lund has, and he is determined to take the risk.

title: Project May Ease Garbage Tag
description: WEST ORANGE  This suburban Essex County community is pioneering a program in reclamation that may save it as much as $150,000 on its next garbagecollection contract. The project involves the curbside pickup of paper and glass.

title: Met Fans Behave In Strange Park
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 13 Visitors from Shea Stadium, and, here were some with their bedsheet banners in the centerfield bleachers, must have felt like strangers in a very strange land today as they watched Oakland's overdressed A's elbow the New York Mets aside in the opening match of the great rounders tournament. Nobody threw anything, nobody hit anybody, nobody smashed the furniture or swore or grabbed anybody else by the eyeballs.

title: Erving Gets 32, Nets Win, 111107
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 13The New York Nets lost a 13point lead, then recovered and beat the Carolina Cougars, 111107, tonight at the Charlotte Coliseum. The loss was the first for the Cougars.

title: PREMIER COURTS GREEK OPPOSITION
description: ATHENS, Oct. 13Spyros Markezinis, Greece's new Premier, plans to open a dialogue next reek with leading opponents of the regime to induce them to take part in the next general elections.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE selling of a city as a major tourist attraction is a subtle, longrange, operation, sometimes done at such a distance from the city and in such a low key that potential travelers do not realize they are being sold or where the sales pitch originated. New York City is one of the world's major tourist attractions but it has suffered from a tarnished image in domestic and international media and from an especially bad pounding by television comics and latenight talk shows about street crime. So in recent years its tourism leaders have been trying to sell the city back to the American tourist as an exciting, entertaining and safe place to visit.

title: Nominee's Day: A Dip, Briefing and a Parade
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Gerald R. Ford rose before dawn today, while most of the city was still sleeping, and went for a swim.

title: Paris Meat Shop Chain Thriving on Low Prices
description: PARISAt good dinner parties in London, guests perfunctorily compliment the hostess and quickly pass on to other things; in Paris little notebooks are brought out to take down the name and address of her butcher.

title: The World as an Audience
description: It is difficult for an artist today not to feel that his contributions are Marginal or superfluous to a social pattern that relegates his to the field of entertainment. The efforts of such artists as Picasso, Pound, Chaplin, Sartre and Mishima to concern themselves with world problems are greeted with suspicion if not derision. The many people who stil believe that the artist should confine himself to esthetics seem to forget that Verdi's, Beethoven's and Mozart's operas made strong political statements just as Goya, Picasso and Titian did in their paintings and Dante, Voltaire and Tolstoy in their writings.

title: Hunterdon Streak Ends With Stalled Late Drive
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., Oct. 13Hackettstown stopped a Hunterdon Central touchdown drive inside the yard line in the last minute of play today and scored a 1410 victory, snapping Hunterdon Central's 13game winning streak.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame, Democratic candidate for Mayor; said yesterday that one of his first acts if elected would be to establish a city department to coordinate aid to the elderly.

title: A marquise for the millions
description: My husband, Jean, loves chocolate almost as much as he loves his wife, I suspect. A most unusual Frenchman: Instead of finishing his evening meal with a bit of cheese, Jean prefers a chocolate dessert365 days of the year. And this has inspired me to build a repertoire of chocolate concoctions to appease his appetite. The marquise glacee, an elegant molded chocolate mousse, ranks high in his favor. And in mine as well, since it does not take long to prepare and may be made several days in advance of serving. Its name comes from a mold, In moule le marquise, which referred to the parasol, to marquise, that protected the fair complexions of wellborn ladies from the sun. This was before the craze for being tan, of course. The mold, I believe, is no longer made, although one may occasionally find a marquise among the odds and ends in the Flea Market. Myself, I use a simple stainlesssteel mixing bowl. I suggest topping the marquise glacie with a flourish of whipped cream, For more elegance, decorate the cream with chocolate shavings and candied violets. Another variation is to accompany it with a coffeeflavored custard sauce. Or the marquise may be served plain. It is rich enough.

title: A Fordfor the Future?
description: The Ford nomination is the greatest anticlimax since 1964 when Lyndon Johnson, after months of speculation, intrigue and horseplay, chose plain old Hubert Humphrey who had been there all along. The most important thing about Mr. Nixon's choice is that Gerald Ford will become the first formally scrutinized Vice President in history. Maybe he should not be the last.

title: Leaking Gasoline Enters Sewer System in Maine
description: WOODLAND, Me., Oct. 13 (AP)A gasoline leak on U.S. 1 has penetrated the sewer system of this eastern Maine town, the Coast Guard reported today.

title: Musicians Consider Strike in Cleveland For Parking Space
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 13A dispute over parking spaces for the 110 members of the Cleveland Orchestra may halt the orchestra's 197374 season.

title: Western Military Men Question Value of a Total Israeli Victory
description: After eight days of heavy fighting, senior United States and other Western military authorities believe Israel holds the initiative in the Middle East war, but question whether she can afford total victory.

title: Watergate
description: WASHINGTONIt was the big namesMitchell, Haldeman, Ehrlichmen, Deanthat made the Senate Watergate hearings so compelling last summer, and, when the inquiry turned to lesser lights this fall, interest in the proceedings seemed to be petering out. The hearings were taken off daytime television and relegated to the back pages of the newspapers. Senators on the panel skipped whole days of testimony, leaving staff members to fill them in afterward on what was said. And the secondfloor rotunda of the old Senate Office Building, where lines of tourists once coiled waiting for admission to the caucus room, became almost empty.

title: DAVID CLIFF, 66, DIES; EXDIRECTOR OF A.L.A
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UPI) David H. Clift, executive director emeritus of the American Library Association, died Thursday en route from Frankfurt, Germany, to Chicago. He was 66 years old.

title: TUNISIAN IS OPEN TO A PEACE ROLE
description: MORNAG, Tunisia, Oct. 13President Habib Bourguiba, who tried last summer to get the Arabs and Israelis to negotiate, said today he was ready to try again if he receives any encouragement from the Israeli side.

title: Rebels in Portuguese Guinea Cite Diplomatic Gains
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Oct. 12Representatives of the African nationalist guerrillas who proclaimed independence last month in part of Portuguese Guinea, south of here, say they expect their action to help build increasing international condemnation of Portugal.

title: Bonnie Brower Fiancee of W. K. Whyte
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 13 The engagement of Miss Bonnie. Kay Brower to William Kirby Whyte, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Whyte of Washington, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Brower of Westfield. A wedding in May is planned.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an error in information supplied by the Suffolk County Board of Elections the name of the Democratic candidate for the County Legislature in the 12th District was given incorrectly last week. The candidate is William A. McShane of Deer Park.

title: Penalty on Last Play Helps Save Westfield's Streak
description: A penalty on a finalplay touchdown pass by Scotch Plains preserved New Jersey's record unbeaten streak yesterday as Westfield emerged with a 147 victory in Westfield.

title: Marjorie Higgins to Wed
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 13Miss Marjorie McLean Higgins and Daniel Budd Evans, students at Sandford University, plan to be married in the spring.

title: In an Oregon Suburb, the Reaction to Ford Is Really to Nixon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 13As President Nixon began to speak to the nation last night, a crowd gathered around a televisions set in the J. C. Penney store in Lloyd Center here, one of the huge shopping malls that have replaced downtown and the corner bar in suburban America. The first comment came from a girl who snapped: Now if they impeach him, it would be perfect!

title: Two Council Sessions Scheduled This Week
description: Following are City Council meetings that are open to the public this week:

title: Two more about McGovernthe best and the worst
description: The Long Shot George McGovern Runs for President. By Gordon. L. Weil. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $8.95.

title: The excess of power
description: President Nixon in his second, State of the Union message to the present Congress requested  perhaps demanded is the better wordthat the Congress not undertake to reduce or limit the powers of the Presidential office. One of the possible restraints that he clearly had in mind was the War Powers Act authored by Senator Jacob K. Javits, with the acknowledged assistance of Senators Stennis, Eagleton, Bentsen and Taft, and sponsored by 59 Senators. When Senators of the differing stripes of the five authors of the bill are combined with 54 other Senators, it is clear why the President should be concorned that he will have to face the need for signing or vetoing the bill, however confident he may be that the House of Representatives will, in its usual pusillanimous fashion, refuse to override a veto.

title: MobileHome Owners Battle for Rights
description: Taking a cue from militant apartment dwellers, the owners of mobile homes in the metropolitan area are forming associations to negotiate with their landlords, the operators of mobilehome parks, and to press for legislative action to insure their rights.

title: Miss Dannehower Bride of R. P. Seelig
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 13In the FirstPark Baptist Church here this afternoon, Miss Christine Read Dannehower, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Lane Dannehower Jr. of Edison, was married to Rodney Preston Seelig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Seelig 2d of North Caldwell. The Rev. Homer L. Trickett performed the ceremony.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: CHICAGO  It was lunchtime and three businessmen sat around the restaurant table at Mr. Kelly's sipping coffee and talking shop. Around them a few dozen other men in business suits were finishing their buffet meal in the carpeted elegance of the big dining room where hushed conversations mingled with silverware clinking on plates.

title: Photography
Why, in 1973, a Black Art Show?
description: ALMOST five years have passed since black artists raised their voices and picket signs in protest again the Whitney Museum of American Art for excluding them in its 1968 survey of art created in the nineteenthirties, a period when black artists began to emerge in impressive numbers. Since then, however, not only did the Whitney stage a mammoth black group show in 1970 (as well as seven subsequent oneman exhibitions in its small, groundfloor gallery), virtually every other major museum in the country followed suit (the Metropolitan opted for the inglorious spectacle, Harlem on My Mind. The latest to join the roster is the New York Cultural Center, where Blacks: USA: 1973 is being presented through Oct. 28.

title: SHOP TALK
description: BOGOTA  The Bergen County Art Galleries, a privately owned shop here, has specialized in cut glass, china and fine European paintings for 22 years. Its owners, Albert and Gizella Siklosi, had 30 years of collecting behind them before they became dealers, and, after they opened their shop, they continued to buy art objects for themselves.

title: Rescuers Work to Save 6 Trapped in French Dredge
description: SANGATTE, France, Oct. 13 (UPI)Rescuers said today that they would use explosives only as a last resort to free six or seven seamen trapped more than 50 hours within th steel hull of a capsized French dredge.

title: CRISIS IS TOPIC FOR PROFESSORS
description: A blueribbon assembly of university professors from 14 freeworld countries will meet in Venice today to discuss, and publicize, what they see as the crisis of the universityeroding campus autonomy, po litical influence on curriculums, degradation of standards and usurpation of power by students and others not teachers.

title: Cornell Downs Princeton 4th. Time in Row, 376
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 13Cornell's football machine, one of the preseason choices to capture Ivy League honors, creaked during the early phases of its 56th meeting with Princeton today. Once it gained momentum, however, it had no difficulty wheeling to an 376 victory.

title: Balzac By V. S. Pritchett. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.
description: In a famous essay Henry James called Balzac the master of us all . . . the very type and model of the projector and creator; so when I think, either with envy or with terror, of the nature and the effort of the Novelist, I think of something that reaches its highest expression in him. Yet as V. S. Pritchett reminds us in this new illustrated biography, Balzac often seemed like a figure from a fairy tale: the secretary of the Russian Embassy in Paris described him as a little fat man, greasy, with the face of a baker, the clothes of a cobbler, the hide of a cooper, the manners of a stocking salesman and the smock of an innkeeper. One awestruck young novelist Saw him as a goodhumored wild boar, his paunch quivering with laughter and whose fullblooded lips exposed scattered teeth like fangs. But it's a gay young provincial hosiess who wins Pritchett's praise for the very best portrait of Balzac in action:

title: Dance
description: THIS has been the quietest start to the New York dance season in years. Largely this is because of the Joffrey Ballet, having had much of its customary support removed by the New York City Center, has had to curtail its sixweek season to four weeks, and then, also through financial stringencies, we lost our customary September dance season in Central Park.

Ford to he Vice President for the next three years. But the party officials were divided over whether the nomination made Mr. Ford a leading candidate for the Presidency in 1976.

description: PRINCETON  The Princeton University Athletic Department is offering several footballticket discounts this fall in an effort to reverse a trend of dwindling attendance and revive what was once a thriving entertainment attraction.

Yesterday Joe Roche kicked a field goal from 25yards out with 18 seconds remaining to give Mepham a 96, South Shore Division II victory over Wantagh.

title: BAGHDAD LOSSES PUT AT 70 TANKS
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 13Israel claimed today to have wiped out the bulk of an Iraqi division in a major tank and artillery battle some 12 miles inside Syria.

title: The Shame of Shea Stadium
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 13When a celebration occurs at Shea Stadium, the only rule is mob rule. Tragedy is inevitable some day. When it occurs, it will be on the conscience of the New York Mets management. If the Mets win the World Series at Shea Stadium next week, tragedy will be lurking in the aisles leading to the field, as it did Wednesday when the Mets eliminated the Cincinnati Reds in the playoff for the National League pennant. In the chaos that The Times erupted, about 30 people required firstaid treatment, five required hospital treatment. Only five, shrugged an apologist for the Mets' rowdies. But it was five too many. Winning a pennant was once an occasion in New York for happiness and pride. Now it's an excuse for lawlessness and fear. Two weeks ago, when Henry Aaron was being ignored, Atlanta appeared to be the disgrace of baseball. Atlanta deserves an apology. The shame of Shea Stadium is the disgrace of baseball.

title: Israeli Force Said to Be Consolidating Flanks
description: DURIN, Syria, Oct. 13 Syrian forces fired heavy and persistent artillery barrages today at Israeli troops deployed around the small city of Sassa, about 20 to 21 miles from the Syrian capital of Damascus.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 13 (UPI)The world's major food produces must work together to rebuild international food reserves and help developing nations expand their own farm production, a government spokesman said today.

Some demographers may agree with her position and some certainly do not, among whom may be listed the undersigned.

Most often, tomatoes and peaches are the featured items. But in this part of New Jersey, where acre upon acre of undeveloped land greets the motorist, the signs on roadside stands announce: Indian Corn and Gourds for Sale,

description: THE exhibition of figures an masks that the Museum of Prim tive Art has mounted as a memoris to the late Robert Goldwater, i?? former director and mentor, is not, ?? exhibitions go these days, very large It numbers 27 objects, most of then small enough to hold in one's hand and it occupies the museum's sma?? firstfloor galleries without exactl crowding them. Yet it is a superb ex hibition, and one altogether appropriat?? to the name it is designed to honor.

title: Cartoon vision and Brownsville reality
description: LOS ANGELES. More spice from the makers of Fritz the Cat, the advertisements for Ralph Bakshi's new cartoon movie, Heavy Traffic, proclaim with a curious vagueness. The copywriters may not know all there is to know about Bakshi's 1972 Fritz the Cat; the first Xrated adult cartoon, but they are aware that it cost only $1million to make and is expected to earn $30million at box offices worldwide. Heavy Traffic has also been given an X rating. But defining the film as spicy is like capsulizing John Osborne's play Look Back in Anger as seamy, or Robert Rauschenberg's popart collages as downbeat. In content and style, Bakshi has written and directed on a scale that does not allow a ready grasp of his accomplishment.

description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Steve Foley passed 3 yards to his brother, Mike, for a touchdown with 10 seconds left to play today to give Tulane a 2417 victory over Duke.

title: Take a Walk Down Mean Streets
description: AMERICAN moviemaking can't be in such a sorry state after all, not when it can produce three films by new directors as gifted and as particularly American as Ralph Bakshi (Heavy Traffic), George Lucas (American Graffiti) and Martin Scorsese (Mean Streets). Each of these films is the director's second or third feature, which is worth emphasizing in an era and an art in which a man's debut is likely to be his entire career. Making movies is expensiveeven cheap ones. The film industry is notoriously impatient with promising beginners. They had better deliver the goods in a hurry or it's a quick hustle out a back door into an alley called oblivion. The first films of each of these directorsBakshi's Fritz The Cat, Lucas's THX1138 and Scorsese's Who's That Knocking at My Door? and Boxcar Bertha  were respectfully received but, with the exception of Fritz The Cat, they caused no great stir with the public. Thus it is encouraging that the directors somehow managed to go on.

title: The wisest and the justest and the best
description: Hannah is immeasureably more than the wife of the late Protestant Theologian Paul who died in 1965. She is a poet, a witch, a lover and a mystic. Now full of years, she has lived a life crammed with giddy risks, jarring changes, bitter humiliations (some at the hands of her husband) and many, many joys. Her autobiography is a manyfaceted collage of surreal fanatasies and erotic dreams, of journal excerpts and poetry, of clawing anger and fathomless love. There is not a sentimental sentence in the book, and it is very, very candid indeed. Some disciples of Tillich may indeed feel the book is entirely too candid, or at least premature. I do not. Tillidh was my teacher, and I admired him without measure. But after Leading this unadorned account of what it was like to try to live with him, I now know and respect him more than ever.

title: Secrets of lowcost building
description: Building has become next to impossible for most people because of skyrocketing construction costs. Lumber has gone up 40 to 100 per cent. Land prices have inflated right along with hamburger prices. Mortgages and construction loans have dried up. And yetpeople are building houses. The tvio shown here originally cost under $15,000 (about $22,000 today but still a bargain). Plus plenty of imagination and hard work. (Since labor accounts for up to 60 per cent of the average building budget, doingityourself or with your friends is a tremendous costwhittler.) The silo on this page and the builder's shell structure opposite were both prefabricated buildings that were adapted by the owners. Next week, we will show three lowcost, architectdesigned houses that can be builtor mostly builtby the owner. One of them, the cottage at right, is being built singlehandedly by a young woman. Mr. and Mrs. Louis Audette purchased a standard grain silo from the Unadilla Silo Company for $2,300 in 1969 (today it would cost approximately $2,600) and put it up on their site in Marlboro, Vt., themselves with friends on weekends. To the basic barrel, the Audettes added dormer windows and slit windows in the front walls, a floor and stairwell between the levels. The house is not electrified as the family enjoys a typical 19thcentury farm existence on weekends. The total cost including the outside well and a ha/fmi/e road was $4,700. They plan to add on another silo drum for a large living room in the future. Shocked by custom building costs, Architect Ronald Kolbe and his wife stopped at a roadside builder's model display of homes to see what made the shell houses so cheap. (Some models started at $6,900). The answer, they found, was strict adherence to standard lumberyard items and installation, which allowed the builder to let out, work to small subcontractors with no supervision and low overhead. Kolbe designed a house for their site in Springs, Long Island, that stayed within these limitations and had the shell builder put it up. Their twobedroom weekend house, insulated for yearround use, cost them $15,000 when completed in 1969. (He estimates that it would cost $22,000 to build a comparable house today.) That figure included the septic tank, rough grading of the site and the prefab fireplace. The ground level of concrete blocks (now overgrown with vines) offers space for a future studio. The deck overhang forms a carport.

title: Trends
description: WASHINGTONThe White House embarked last week on an exercise to make the nation energyconscious as part of an effort to relieve the shortage. The campaign to curb America's traditionally profligate use of energy focuses attention on such facts as these:

title: October Evening
description: The sun sets early now, even.by daylightsaving time, earlier than since the end of March, and we have Jong autumn evenings. Evenings with the chill of October on them, a coolness, not yet a biting cold. The moon, the Hunter's Moon just past the full, rises only an hour and a half after sunset tonight, and back in the hills the coon dogs will be out and running.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Her Face Her Fortune
description: WALKING down Fifth Avenue with a woman whose face stops traffic isn't easy. Schlee must have known the feeling as he strolled with Garbo. Miller must have known it when strolling with Monroe. Even Paris must have known it with Helen. You turn into an invisible mortal at the side of Venus. And so it is, walking with Anna Myrtle Swoyer. Every, few, feet, people stop to stare or to pay, her compliments. I love your commercials, says one passerby. You just slay me, another.

title: Headliners
description: Usually, the Nobel Prize for medicine honors discoveries in basic physiologic processes or animal research that relates directly to specific himan diseases. But last week the selection committee departed from the pattern and awarded the 1973 prize to three pioneers in the relatively new science of ethology, the comparative study of behavior. The winning zoologists are Dr. Karl von Frisch, 86, an Austrian bee expert now retired in Munich; Dr. Konrad Lorenz, 69, an Austrian formerly of the Max Planck Institute in Germany and author of the wellknown book, On Aggression, and Dr. Nikolaas Vnbergen, 66, a Dutchborn professor at Oxford University. Their research has taught man what can be learned from patching the birds and the bees, particularly, the committee said, for possible means of adapting environment to the biological equipment of man with the aim of preventing maladaptation and disease.

title: T.W. U. to Seek Wage Increase And a LivingCost Clause Here
description: The Transport Workers Union, which will begin negotiations for a new contract with the Transit Authority early next Year, has set a substantial wage increase and costofliving clause as toppriority goals.

title: Labor Federation to Meet
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 13 (UPI) The A.F.L C I.O. opens its biennial convention next week. About 1,000 delegates from more than 100 member unions will convene Thursday in the grand ballroom of the Americana Hotel.

title: Gross Leads Riverdale Triumph
description: Jonathan Gross, a senior quarterback, scored one touchdown, passed for another, kicked a 25yard field goal and booted 3 extra points yesterday in Riverdale's 38.0 victory over Xavier at Mount St. Michael in the Bronx. It was the fourth straight triumph this season for Riverdale and the 10th in the last two seasons.

title: Fancy Bulbs for Indoors
description: MOST homeowners Piave enjoyed the prespring promise of potted daffodils, narcissus and hyacinth bulbs forced on a window sill. Why not expand horizons and consider the wealth of bulbs to be found in South African flora?

title: LIFE TERM IMPOSED ON VERMONT KILLER
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 13 (AP)A term of life in prison has been imposed on a 26yearold Manchester man who pleaded guilty to murder last December of the Manchester town police chief, Dana Thompson.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Again, FullScale War
description: CAIROIt was not possible for the Arabs to gaze across the ceasefire line indefinitely at their own land, Sir Alec DouglasHome, the British Foreign Secretary said Friday in a bit of hindsight. Yet this was precisely what the Egyptians and the Syrians had been doing for the last six years and what they thought the world poweers had condemned them to forever.

title: A's Beat Mets, 21, in First Game of the World Series
description: With both their runs unearned, the Oakland A's wonthe opening game of baseball's 70th World Series, 21, from the New York Mets before a crowd of 46,021 in the OaklandAlameda County Stadium yesterday.

title: Harvard Is Easy Victor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 14Harvard's football team, heraided as No. 1 in the nation on defense, ran up a 570 score on Columbia today. It was the most points scored by Harvard against Columbia in their 96year series.

title: Chamber Music Back Home
description: HACKENSACK  Chamber music in the home, which is said to be making a strong comebak, will be heard throughout Bergen County this fall and winter. Two concert series  one sponsored by the county's Y.M.Y.W.H.A. and the other by the Walden Trio, a nonprofit allwomen's group that will performwill be presented in the homes of Bergen residents.

title: Son to the Kinghams
description: A son was born to Capt. T. Barry Kingham, Judge Advocate General's Corps, U.S.A., and Mrs. Kinghtun of New York and Alexandria, Va., on Aug. 31 in Walter Reed Hospital in Washington.

title: A Child's History of America
description: A Child's History of America reads like some last Grand Tour. It is a loosely assembled, honestly staggering record of certain journeys taken mainly in 1968, mainly in Eastern and Western Europe. They were an inquiry and an escape; they are offered by their author Charles Newman not only for their own saka but as one of his ways of.being American and collecting himself. It is easier to feel sorry for Europe than to pity ourselves. They copy our unborn bourgeoisie; we mimic their dead revolutionaries. We yearn for their past, they simulate our future.

title: Mrs. Van Nimwegen Remarried
description: MILTON, Mass., Oct. 13Mrs. Sarah Faxon Van Nimwegen and Laurence Sheldon Johnson, both of New York, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. John R. Graham, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morrison Faxon, parents of the bride, whose husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. F. Walker Johnson of Swampscott.

title: News of the Screen
Bridge
description: Those who enjoy intellectual recreations are not limited to bridge. It is not surprising that many bridgeplayers also favor backgammon, chess, poker, or go, the Oriental game. Of these, backgammon has attracted such a wide following in recent years that it is common to see the game being played in bridge clubs and at tournaments. Some tournament organizers have attempted to bar backgammon games from the playing area.

title: Laura G. Nagle Plans Wedding To Navy Ensign
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Oct. 13Miss Laura Greer Nagle and Ens. Marc Burt Wilson, U.S.N., will be married in December.

title: CAHILL REAFFIRMS PLAN ON STADIUM
description: TRENTON, Oct 13Governor Cahill reaffirmed New Jersey's commitment today to build a sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands despite what he called the transparent, diversionary tactics of those who apparently fear the economic success the complex would create.

title: New High School Sports Federation for New York
description: A statewide scholastic athletic association that for the first time includes all high schools in New York State has been created to enhance the educational and athletic opportunities of participating youngsters.

title: Villemure Foils Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13The young and rebuilt Pittsburgh Penguins were taught a convincing lesson in the National Hockey League tonight as the New York Rangers shelled them, 82, at the Civic Arena before 11,220 fans.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Two years and two months ago the Department of Justice and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation settled three antitrust cases pending in the Federal courts. The settlement climaxed months of hard bargaining by both tides and resulted in one of the largest and most complex corporate divestitures in the history of American business.

title: Creative accountants, greedy investors, and nearly catastrophe
description: Accountancy is dull. But it is dull for very good reasons. It's dull because the job of accountants is to hew to the rules when everybody else is ready to junk those rules as just so many obstacles to a more novel and exciting future. In the late 1960's, John Brooks writes in The GoGo Years, [corporate] management kept pressing the accountants mesmerizing them with new and exciting subtleties; the accountants responded by starting to think of themselves as members of the corporate team, bending the rules to suit those subtleties, thinking legalistically rather than conscientiously, discussing the creative aspects of their jobs in staid professional journals. The loss of perspective by accountants well symbolizes one of the maddest periods in Wall Street history.

title: HELEN H. MERRICK
description: Helen Hynson Merrick, who retired a year ago as an editor of Grolier, Inc., where she had worked for 30 years, died Thursday in Doylestown, Pa. Her age was 67.

title: Industrial Democracy in Sweden
HONG KONG FLU VIRUS MAY HIT THIS WINTER
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Hong Kong flu bug that felled millions of Americans in the influenza epidemic of 196869 may reappear this winter in a new guise.

title: Ballet: Remembrances'
description: It is six years since Robert Joffrey startled the world of dance with his multimedia ballet Astarte. Since then, occupied with the daily tasks of directing the Joffrey Ballet, he has been inactive as a choreographer. On Friday night he broke this creative silence with a new ballet, Remembrances, the first world premiere of the company's current season at the. City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: BOUTIQUE IS ADDED TO A TOLL BRIDGE
description: LACKAWAXEN, Pa., Oct. 13 The owners of a bridge across the Delaware River here have added a gift shop, but otherwise they're planning to keep th structure pretty much the way it was built by John Roebling in 1848.

title: Mark Rein to Marry Miss Denice Helman
description: Miss Denice Barbara Helman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Gilbert Helman of New York and Hewlett Bay Park, L. I., plans to he married in December to Mark Alan Rein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rein of Brooklyn. The The parents of the future bride have announced the engagement.

title: For Princess Anne's Nuptials
description: AROYAL figure who has often manifested the force and imperiousness of old regal traditions is Princess Anne of Britain, who is being married on Nov. 14 to Mark Phillips of the Queen's Dragoons. The occasion is being mirked philatelically by Greit Britain, the colonies and territories and the stampissuing isles of the waters around Britain.

title: A's Are Careful Not to Celebrate
description: OAKLAND, Calif. Oct. 13 There was no celebrating going on in the Oakland clubhouse after the A's had won the first game of the World Series. Their scout reports specifically forbade it, and the A's are very proud, of their scouting reports.

title: League Offers Clues to Election
description: TRENTON  For the first time in its history, the League of Women Voters of New Jersey has compiled the voting records of New Jersey legislators on key measures.

title: Manasquan and Brick Roll On
description: Manasquan, again displaying a balanced running attack, powered to its 14th consecutive victory, a 288 decision over Monmouth Regional in Manasquan yesterday.

title: John R. Green, 60, Dies; Headed Police Motor Unit
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., Oct. 13John R. Green, who retired in 1971 as deputy chief inspector in charge of the Motor Transport Unit of the New York Police Department, died yesterday of a heart ailment At his home in Eaton's Neck. He was 60 years old.

title: Kings Point Crew Wins Race Here
description: The Kings Point freshman eightoared crew sprinted in the last 100 meters yesterday to win the intermediateeight race of the Columbus Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Orchard Beach Lagoon. The Mariners crossed the line half a length ahead of a fastclosing New York A.C. intermediate crew, which was hauling them down every stroke. Fort Schuyler was third, with the Kings Point B crew fourth and Manhattan last.

title: GUERRILLAS SHELL TOWNS IN ISRAEL
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, Oct. 13Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, called on its guerrilla members when war broke out to join in the fighting against Israel. The response has been nightly rocket attacks on Israeli towns and settlements along the Lebanese border and occasional attempts by small groups to raid Israeli territory.

title: Portmeirion: A Holiday Village With a Bold Personal Signature
description: WHILE touring Italy as a young man, Sir Clough WilliamsEllis discovered Portofino, fell head over heels in love with it, and resolved to create an equally enchanting seaside village rather closer to home.

title: Britain's Heath Announces He Will Visit Peking in 1974
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 13 (AP)Prime Minister Heath announced today that he would visit China in the first week of next year.

title: Other Candidates To Vie in Debate
description: BRANCHBURGTwo gubernatorial candidates with opposite social views  A. Howard Freund of the American party and Kenneth Newcomb of the Communist partywill debate Wednesday before, a sociology class at Somerset County College.

title: On Parkway, Information Is There for Asking
description: MONTVALE  Those motorists who stop at the first Travel Information Center to be opened on the Garden State Parkway are surprised to find that they can get lot more than maps.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Manhattan Culture Bus Loop, started by the Transit Authority on Sept. 1 as an experiment, will be continued indefinitely, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The announcement said that the culture bus has been an almost instant success with New Yorkers and visitors and its continuance was voted by the M.T.A. board. The service operates on weekends and holidays and enables passengers to visit many of the city's institutions for a single $1 fare that permits users to get on and off buses as many times as they please. It operates on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

title: NASSAU HOSPITAL TO BE DEDICATED
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 13  Nassau County's new 562million Dynamic Care Building of the County Medical Center here, described by county officials as one of the largest and most modern municipally owned hospitals in the nation, will be dedicated at 1 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Syrian Says American Jet Is Downed
description: PARIS, Oct. 13 (Reuters)A Syrian Embassy spokesman said today that a Phantom jet bearing United States Air Force markings and piloted by an American who had fought in Vietnam was shot down yesterday over Damascus.

title: Jefferson Makes John Jay Fourth Victim
description: The powerful Jefferson running attack overwhelmed John Jay, 526, in onleague game at Jefferson Field yesterday. It was the fourth straight victory for the Jeffs, three in Brooklyn Division I Public Schools Athletic League competition.

title: Plainfield Gets Code To Curb BreakIns
description: PLAINFIELDIn an effort to reduce the number of breakins here, Plainfield has become what is believed to he the first community in the state to adopt a Burglary Prevention Code.

title: A Proud Taste for Scarlet and Miniver
description: Whatever happened to dear Henry and Eleanor? You remember the Plantagenets. Second marriages are always so difficult, especially when the woman is older. Of course locking her up in a tower for 15 years was a little extreme, but the rulership biz is very demanding and she certainly wasn't a good influence on those boys....

title: M.I.T. Gets Study Grant.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Oct. 13 (AP)  Massachusetts Institute of Technology has received a $968,000 grant from the United States Agency for International Development to conduct a study of longrange development for six droughtstricken countries in West Africa. The nations are Chad, Niger, Upper Volta, Mali, Mauritania and Senegal.

title: Engine for Air Force F15 Passes Test on Third Try
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) The engine designed for the Air Force F15 Eagle fighter passed a 150hour endurance test on the third try, the Pentagon said today. Success in the test last night cleared the way for approval of a production contract with Pratt & Whitney Corporation, maker of the engine.

title: C. W. Post Routs St. Peter's, 750
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Oct. 13 C.W, Post, playing without Ed Powers, the nation's leading college division passer, went to a ground game and overpowered a hapless St. Peter's football team, 750, today. The victory was Post's fourth in five outings this year and second in two Metropolitan Conference games. St. Peter's has not won in five games.

title: Deborah Taussig to Marry Nov. 17
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J. Oct. 13Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Taussig of Englewood and Point o' Woods, Fire Island, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Torrey Taussig, to Thomas Peter Vaida, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Vaida of Worcester, Mass.

title: Hillsborough Wins Battle of Unbeatens
description: Twin brothers, Lou and Charlie Quirico, provided the impetus yesterday as Hillsborough defeated Princeton, 3321, in a battle of unbeaten teams at Princeton.

title: Monmouth College To Hear Symphony
description: WEST LONG BRANCHMonmouth College has scheduled a program of special events designed to mark both its 40th anniversary year and the opening of a new, $3.9million College Center.

title: Rockefeller Still Seeking the Presidency
description: Frustrated in his fourth bid for national office, Governor Rockefeller is undaunted and will try again in 1976, his top aides and advisers said yesterday.

title: Egypt Reports U.S. Violation
description: CAIRO, Oct. 13The Egyptian command reported tonight that two reconnaisance planes of a type owned only by the United States violated Egyptian air space at midday today. Egypt later delivered a strong protest to the official United States representative here.

title: Can Colleges Teach Theater?
description: WHEN I graduated from college 25 years ago, I got right into the parade of young hopeful actors and knocked on all the casting directors' doors. What've you done? they quite reasonably asked. Well, I played some pretty good parts in college: I played the 80yearold Firs in The Cherry Orchard; I played Grandpa in You Can't Take It With Youoh my, I was fine! All that white shoe polish in my hair.

title: Lila Lee Wolff a Bride
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, Mass., Oct. 13Miss Lila, Lee Wolff of Stony Creek, Conn., was married here this morning to James M. Wilkinson 3d of New Haven, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilkinson Jr. of Summit, N. J. The bride's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Ezra Wolff of Mount Washington and Manhasset, L. I.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Jordan said it had sent a detachment of its beat troops to the Syrian defense against Israel. The announcement came after a week of heavy pressure from Arab leaders for King Hussein to commit troops to the Middle East conflict. It was unclear how many troops had been sent to Syria or whether the move would lead to the opening of a new front against Israel. Some European diplomats in Amman described the move as a largely symbolic gesture designed to keep potential Arab critics from denouncing Jordan for not having taken part in the war. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, P. 24.]

title: A loner who believed in the common man
description: The public career of Henry Agard Wallace spanned all of the New Deal and postNew Deal years from 1933 to 1949. With the possible exception of Harry Hopkins he was the most durable, and certainly one of the most conspicuous, political figures of that highly politicized generation. He was a Cabinet minister twiceover, a Vice President, and at the end a candidate for the Presidency itself. Yet he was, withal, about as untalented and unperceptive a politician apolitical is probably the word as the times produced.

title: Farmingdale Tops Mineola, 28 to 0
description: Farmingdale has picked up a habit or starting slow, but the Dalers are finishing as fast as ever. Yesterday Farmingdalmingdale scored 22 points in the second halt to defeat Mineola, 280, for its 23rd victory in a row. The last time Fapningdale lost Was November 14, 1971, to Port Washington, 2018. Port Washington plays Farmingdale in two Weeks.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market kept moving higher last week to extend a tremendous rally despite two jolting news eventsthe outbreak of fighting in the Middle East and the surprise resignation of Vice President Agnew. Tradcontinued heavy.

title: AUSTIN BRIGGS, 65, ILLUSTRATOR, DIES
description: Austin Briggs, a leading illustrator and commercial artist, died Wednesday of leukemia and complications at his home in Paris. He was 65 years old and formerly lived in Redding, Conn.

title: What's Opened at the Movies?
description: DAY FOR NIGHT (LA NUIT AMERICAINE), directed by Frangois Truffaut from a screenplay by JeanLouis Richard, Suzanne Schiffman and Truffaut, got 17 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gehnis, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Andrew Sarris, Village, Voice; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/ World; Robert Hatch, The Nation; Jay Cocks, Time), 1 mixed (Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic) and 1 negative (Pauline Kael, New Yorker). At the Fine Arts.

title: BOND ISSUE'S FATE CALLED DOUBTFUL
description: Governor Rockefeller's $3.5billion transportation bond issue proposal is in serious trouble with the voters, according to a sampling of political and community leaders across the state.

title: Our Arctic will never be the same
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska. Summer flared abruptly as May became June on America's remote and wild northern rim. The thick ice on the rivers went out with a squealing roar audible for miles. The great herds of caribou funnelled up through the precipitous passes of the spiny Brooks Range to the south, following the retreating snow to summer feeding and calving grounds on the North Slope. The unsetting summer sun soared and dipped in the crystal sky, often obscured by dank fogs from the Beaufort Sea and the thin cold rain. But slowly the sun burned through the ice of the countless lakes that riddle the flat, boggy land and the lakes bred billions of buzzing mosquitos. Wildflowers bloomed, giving the dun tundra a flush of color. Soon the waterfowl returned, ducks and geese in small dark clouds against the sky and white swans in pairs. At the sea's edge the division between land and water, often imperceptible to the untrained eye in the white  wilderness of winter, became clear: The pack ice withdrew Sullenly from the shore, revealing the brooding black water below. But the ice was always, there, just on the horizon, and even On the warmest days, when the thermometer nudged the sixties, the merest breeze was Chill with winter.

title: Westfield Greefs Plan 2 Gala Days
description: WESTFIELDA halfton of lamb will be served to sitdown or takeout diners at festival to be held at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church here next Friday and Saturday.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Miller Ayre to Wed Susan B. Sherk
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13F. Allen Sherk, headmaster of the Hopkins Grammar Day Prospect Hill School, and Mrs. Sherk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Bradley Sherk, to Miller Haldane Ayre of St. John's, Newfoundland, where his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. M. Ayre, also reside. The wedding is planned for Dec. 27 in St. John's.

title: For Minor Crimes, Instant Probation?
description: TRENTONAn urban legislator has proposed to halve the number of criminal court cases in New. Jersey by allowing prosecutors to place minor offenders on immediate probation.

title: N.C. State Overcomes Maryland
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Dave Buckey, North Carolina State quarterback, led his team to a 2422 victory today over a Maryland team beset by quarterbacking problems that marred its tough defense.

title: U.S. SUPPLIES OF OIL TERMED INADEQUATE
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 13 (AP)The Oil & Gas Journal said today that there was not enough oil available in the United States to cover a major emergency in the event Arabian oil was cut off because of the Middle East war.

title: Festival for Elderly
description: A festival for the elderly will be held from Tuesday through Thursday at the East Elmhurst branch of the Queens Borough Public library. The events, which will run from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at 95.06 Astoria Boulevard, will include health tests, information on Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and food stamps, and arts and crafts.

title: Y in Essex Offers A Festival of Arts
description: WEST ORANGE TheY.M.Y.W.H.A. of Metropoitan New Jersey is offering a diverse program of concerts, lectures, plays, movies and dance companies in its 197374 Festival of the Arts.

title: Susan Pelland Wed To John Sullivan Jr.
description: Miss Susan Lee Pelland, a model, was married here yesterday afternoon to John McNamee Sullivan Jr., an assistant to the executive vice president of Gerli & Co., a New York textile company of which his grandfather, Paolino Gerli, is board chairman. The ceremony was performed the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More by Msgr. James G. Wildens.

title: CATHOLIC IN ULSTER KILLED GIVING HELP
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 13 (AP)A Roman Catholic was killed last night helping to save the life of a Protestant in Northern Ireland's sectarian warfare, the police said today.

title: President or Sovereign?
description: The powers of the Presidency have never been static or neatly defined. Support for a strong Chief Executive grows during times of uncertainty and crisis. The great Depression, World War H and the emergence in the last three decades of the United States as superpower in a world of uneasy nuclear balance have inevitably given enormous new responsibilities and prerogatives to the White House. The dimension of these changes makes it particularly important that the nation remember is literally founded on the rejection of absolute power in the hands of any man.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Newark Exhibit Recalls '76
description: NEWARKHow New Jersey was reluctantly drawn into the American Revolution, and the stateN history as one of the major battlegrounds of the conflict, will be shown in an exhibit that opens tomorrow at the Newark Public Library, 5 Washington Street.

title: GEORGE STEERS, 66, LED SANFORIZED CO.
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 13 George A. Steers, who retired last year as president of the Sanforized Company, a division of Cluett, Peabody & Company, Inc., the Arrow shirtmakers, died here today of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 16 Greystone Road.

title: New Role for Curator
description: Henry Grunthal, described by his associates as a walking numismatic encyclopedia and a man who knows a great deal about a great deal and something about everything, retired last month as the curator of medic, val and modern European coins of the American Numismatic Society, completing 20 yeary of service on the A.N.S. staff. His legendary expertise will continue to be available on a consultative basis. Mr. Grunthal's duties will be shared by Hillel Kaslove and Jeremiah D. Brady. The A.N.S. will, of course, continue as this country's and one of the world's outstanding centers of numismatic scholarship, but there is general agreement that the place just won't be the same without him. As one associate put it, What is there to say about a man who can unerringly tell a fake from a geniune coin by whether it feels cold or warm in his handeven though he refuses to reveal which is which!

title: CHESTER PUGSLEY
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct, 13Chester De Witt Pugsley, a lawyer and phinanthropist who had endowed the Harvard Law School and many other universities with scholarships for foreign students studying international law, died here Monday. He was 86 years old.

title: Better Players Are Expected to Attract Bigger Crowds in W.H.A's 2d Season
description: It doesn't seem possible that two major hockey leagues could improve at the same time  but that's what has happened. Although many ob severs didn't believe there is enough talent to go around, the World Hockey Association apparently has strengthened itself, much as the National Hockey League has.

title: Bergen Opponents Concur on Issues
description: TENAFLY  Here in the 37th Legislative District, perhaps the most politically sophisticated one in New Jersey, the two candidates for State Senator are essentially liberals with minimal differences between them on the issues.

title: Nutley Makes Cafone's Score Stand in 70 Victory at Montclair
description: Nutley scored on Mike Cafone's 36yard run in the second quarter yesterday and made it pay off in a 70 victory over Montclair in a battle between New Jersey's top unbeaten teams in Montclair. More than 6,000 fans watched.

title: A Comment on the Week
description: Richard Nixon used to exult in what he called his historic firsts in the Presidency. Last week, he was shattering a precedent a day as he supervised the resignation of his Vice President and invoked the newest Amendment to the Constitution to try to anoint another. But this time the President strained to present these extraordinary events as almost routine.

title: Soviet Hails Egypt's Gain, Citing Arms and Training
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13The Soing Defense Ministry, report ing that five divisions of Egyptian troops had moved in to the Sinai Peninsula, today hailed the strong showing of an Egyptian Army well trained and equipped with modern arms by the Soviet Union.

title: AROUND THE
description: Pick green tomatoes before frost; wrap them newspaper and store in a cool dry place to ripen gradually indoors.... Lift and store tubers, corms, etc., of tuberous begonias, gladiolus, dahlias... . Continue spraying of roses for black spot, crabapples for scab with benlate according to directicins.... Plant bulbs.

title: Labor Union Chiefs Promise to Support Israel's Histadrut
description: Leaders of major American labor unions pledged financial and moral support yesterday to Histadrut, Israel's general labor federation.

title: Marianne Nanna to Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 13 Miss Marianne Therese Nanna and James M. Zinkand 2d plan to be married here on Nov. 10. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Nanna. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Zinkand of Orrville, Ohio.

title: Essex Hikers Step Up Pace
description: SOUTH ORANGE  Walkers shepherded by the Essex County Park Commission are striding all over New Jersey this year, and the distances they are covering are the longest since the county's hiking program began in 1967.

title: The mystery
description: When I got to New York, they were having an election. I was told that several men actually wanted to be mayor. Their names were Beaune, Biaggi, Blumenthal and March l It sounded more Eke a law firm than a political campaign.

title: Composer Makes Others' Music Playable
description: WHEN Musica Aeterna opens its season on Oct. 27 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Frederic Waldman will lead, among other things, a Sinfonia concertante in flat for violin, viola and orchestra by Ignaz Josenh Pleyel, a composer who is best known as the founder of the famous French pianomaking company. The soloists will be Jaime Laredo and Walter Trampler. But additionally important to the performance is a behindthescenes composer, Douglas Townsend, who digs up such unusual works as the Pleyel and makes them playable. This is, he says, the way I support my family. My primary motive Is to get music performed that I think worthwhile. Sometimes I have prepared a work on speculation, such as a Christmas oratorio by Gossec, which I think is a jewel. But I also get paid for preparing material, thank goodness.

title: Class Action Suit Filed To End Marijuana Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) A class action suit was filed this week to eliminate the nation's laws prohibiting private possession and use of marijuana. The suit asserts that the laws are unconstitutional.

title: Trenton State Tops Nichols
description: TRENTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Trenton State scored in the second and, third periods today to hand Nichols College its first football defeat of the season, 143. Each team new has a 41 wonlost record.

title: A women's prison has a nonlogic of its own
description: The inmates are robbers, addicts, forgers, murderers. They are considered threats to society, and sometimes, threats to one another. They are locked behind bars, regimented, disciplined for the slightest infraction of prison rules. And how do they know the prison rules? On the wall of the dining room, in best summercamp style, a neatlylettered sign spells one thus:

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Severalmonths before he actually announced his plans to leave the Johnson Administration, Walter W. Heller told Spine friends, I have to get out while I still have some reputation left with my peers. After all, I have to spend the rest of my, life in my profession.

title: Ohio State Rolls, 240, To 4 in Row
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 13 (AP)Archie Griffin rushed for 169 yards on. 29 carries and Ohio State's defense smothered Wisconsin's vaunted rushing attack as the Buckeyes rolled to a 240 victory today, their fourth triumph in four starts.

title: The Hell in Paradise of Malcolm Lowry
description: MALCOLM LOWRY'S Under the Volcano, a novel first published in 1947 and now widely regarded as a masterpiece, describes the last 12 hours on earth of brilliant dipsomaniac who is destroying himself through alcohol. Suffering from an acute paralysis of will, Geoffrey Firmin, a minor British consul In Mexico, cuts himself off from those who want to help himhis wife, Yvonne, his half brother Hugh, and his boyhood friend Jacques Laruelle  and plunges deeper and deeper into a mescalsoaked hell that climaxes with his murder by proFascist police. The story, which takes place shortly after the outbreak of World War II (on Nov. 2, celebrated annually throughout Mexico as the Day of the Dead), is profoundly symbolic of man's fall from grace in a world whose natural laws of order and human interrelatedness he has chosen to ignore, defy and transgress.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Nuptials in June Set By Catherine Blank
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 13The engagement of Miss Catherine Ann Blank, a senior at Barnard College, to Erwin Mermelstein, a Columbia College senior, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Blank, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr, and Mrs. Joseph Mermelstein of Brooklyn, New York.

title: The tejanos are the bad.guys
description: So Far From Heaven is a novel about life and laughter in the contemporary state (such as it is) of New Mexico. Richard Bradford deals but lightly; light as a sopapillawith the ethnic conflict between chicano and gringo, the cultural conflict between hippie and straight, the racial conflict between Texans and human beings. All this, of course, is the basic stuff of New Mexican stew, a simmering potful of rattlesnake slumgullion. Tasty but dangerous. Mr. Bradford seasons these irreconcilable ingredients with salt, chili and satire.

title: Left to right, faith to doubt, but still a good man
description: In 1915, when he was 19 and about to become a senior at Harvard, John Dos Passos fell in loveapparently in a nice waywith a boy of 15 named Rumsey Marvin whom he met by chance during a summer jaunt to the Far West. Through the next 10 or so years, when they saw each other very little, Dos Passos sent frequent exuberant letters to Rummy dear describing his own wartime adventures in France and Italy and his postwar travels through a turbulent, dangerous Middle East. With affectionate freedom he poured out his zest for writers and writing, his hopes and fears for mankind.

title: On Paper or Key Punch Card, Rams Look Strong
description: Whom do you like in the National Football League's big game at Los Angeles today, the Rams or the Cowboys? The Rams, unbeaten in the Western Division of the National Conference with a twogame lead over San Francisco, have made a thin onepoint favorite. Apart from being an admitted Ram fan, Bud Goode likes Los Angeles, and as usual he backs up his choice with with numbers. The Rams are first in the league in precentage of pass completions, 73.6, said the renowned sports computer analyst by telephone from Los Angeles. They are No. 1 in fewest punts per game, three. That means they are controlling the ball.

title: New Socialist Group Plans to Work Within Democratic Party
description: Members of a new Socialist movement being formed here this weekend adopted as their general perspective yesterday the idea that they should work within the existing Democratic party.

title: Cattlemen Joining Forces to Check Increasing Thefts of Livestock
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13The rural roads of Missouri's Clay County, lonely and sparsely traveled after dark, were carrying new drivers this week.

title: Yin Spoke Only Chinese, Ormandy Only English
description: IT was interesting to watch, the other week, the one and only rehearsal of the Yellow River Concerto. The Philadelphia Orchestra naturally wanted to play at least one Chinese work on its tour of the People's Republic, but there was not much to choose from. The only piece  literally the only piece of Chinese music  that would fit into the format of a program turned out to be the communallycomposed work named Yellow River Concerto. It was in lour short movements, and the entire work did not take more than 20 minutes. It also called for a piano soloist, and that was fine. A Chinese pianist could be used.

title: The New Plays
description: CROWN MATRIMONIAL, a play by Royce Ryton, got six favorable reviews (Watts, Post; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Bookspan, WPIXTV; Probst, WNBCRadio; Gill, New Yorker), six mixed (Barnes, Times; Lewis, Bergen Record; Sanders, WABCTV; Novick, Village Voice; Clurman, Nation; Stasio, Cue) and nine unfavorable reviews (Watt, News; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Gayer, UPI; Harris, WCBSTV; Alvin Klein, WNYCRadio; Kalem, Time; Kroll, Newsweek; Simon, New York).

title: The Evidence Was Damning
description: BALTIMORE  The tall, wellbuilt, wellgroomed man stood stock still, his unmoving hands straight at his side, the central figure in a crowded, fifthfloor courtroom in the Old Post Office buildingwalnut paneling, blue Carpet, oversized brass eagles atop the two American flags flanking the bench.

title: Hofstra Conquers Fordham
description: Hofstra scored twice In the third quarter today and defeated Fordham 200 at Jack Coffey Field. The victory moved the Flying Dutchmen into first place in the Metropolitan Football Conference.

title: Art In and Out of Step in Soho
