description: NEW YORK'S Soho is back in business for the season, this time with fully 33 galleries where a few years ago therewere none. It's an odd phenomenon, Soho is, a major demogiaphic and cornmercial movement of artengaged people in a period curiously devoid of dominant movements in art itself. Maybe the two facts are somehow related. Their coincidence, in any case, makes for some troubling overtones In an art situation superficially flourishing.

title: Arab and Jew: Each Is the Other
description: During 1970 and 1971 a reasonably articulate Arab in the United States would frequently be asked to participate in public discussions on, the Middle East question. On one occasion I was preceded to the lectern by an Israeli speaker who, I thought then, had the lack of irony to say that it was the Arabs that had always seen themselves as the chosen people.

title: College for Poor Shifting Policies.
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I. Long Island's poor people's college will begin major changes in admissions policy and academic programs next year In response to pressures to make room for the more typical students from the Island's community colleges.

title: About reincarnation (sort of), chickens (sort of), travel (sort of)
description: On the morning of the day he died, so the story goes, Yukio Mishima finished his tetralogy, which bears the overall title, The Sea of Fertility. He put down his pen and went with a group of his sokeerfollowers (he had a private army) to the Japanese Army Headquarters in Tokyo where he harangued, the officers and men from a balcony. He advocated a coup and a return to the imperial values of patriotic militarism. His listeners were not particularly impressed. Mishima went inside, knelt down and ripped his belly open in the traditional way required for seppuku  vulgarly known as harakiri. He was still halfalive; one of his own men struck his head off, putting an end to him. He was 45 and perhaps the most famous of his country's writers.

title: Rockefeller Pledges $50,000
description: SALEM, W. Va., Oct. 13 (AP) New York's Governor Rockefeller has pledged a personal gift of $50,000 to Salem College in support of the Jennings Randolph Year, being celebiated by the small college.

title: Jail JobRelease Is a Success in Morris
description: MORRISTOWNContrary to experience elsewhere in the state, Morris County has more Job opportunities for jail inmates than candidates eligible to fill them.

title: Sailing Lead Trimmed
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 13 (UPI) San Diego's Lowell North, seeking an unprecedented fourth world title, finished sixth today, in the Star class world sailing championships and saw his overall lead shaved to 3 points. North had 200 points going itno tomorrow's final and Bill Buchan had 217.

title: Youths Rally to Aid The Cause of Israel
description: Four students held the corners of a large Israeli flag last Monday on the campus of Hofstra University and passersby dropped in coins and dollar bills. By the end of the day more than $700 had been dropped into the flag for the Israel Emergency Fund of the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Belgium Halts Mideast Arms
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 13 (Reuters) The Belgian Government today suspended all deliveries of arms to countries involved in the Middle East conflict.

title: Nancy Powers to Wed Next Month
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., Oct. 13 The engagement of Miss Nancy Powers to Amos Rogers Little 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Little Jr. of Helena, Mont., and Jackson Hole, Wyo., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Austin Jay Powers Jr. A late November wedding is planned.

title: Betty Field, 19181973
description: BETTY FIELD was never a star; she was far too busy being ones of our most solidly professional actress to bother. She did not have time for glamour  indeed she was never glamorousbecause cultivating glamour would have taken away from her great love, and that was perfecting her craft as one of our theater's most gifted, but unfortunately underrated, actresses.

title: Point of View
description: Three weeks agog President Nixon announced a new direction for the nation's housing programs for the poor: the housingallowance concept. Since then, the Department of Housing and Urban Development has hedged Its commitment to the program with a variety of additions, conditions and exceptions. But the future is clear. Housing allowances will provide the rhetoric, if not the substance, of HUD's policy on lowincome housing for what remains of this administration.

title: Wood Field and Stream: Seafood That Isn't Fish
description: During a Nova Scotia fishing trip in August I was reminded of the food value of Irish moss, a common seaweed.

title: Still the Bible of the American kitchen
description: A charming young waitress assured me the other evening that the topping before me was real whipped cream, out of an aerosol can. Clearly, a whole generation of. Americans has lost touch with the food of our forebears. So this handsome, enlarged facsimile edition of the first Fannie Farmer cookbook is valuable as a return to sources. Yet even in 1896, the worm was in the apple.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Probably the most contentious issue in the recent strike by the United Automobile Workers against the Chrysler Corporation was the issue of compulsory overtime.

title: Trial on Maryland Dinner For Agnew Is Postponed
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 13 (AP)The conspiracy trial of the Salute to Ted Agnew Night Committee, scheduled to open Monday in Anne Arundel Country Circuit Court, has been postponed until Nov. 19.

title: Born free, lazy and selfish
description: Whether reposing serenely before the New York Public Library or roaring from the screen in an MGM epic or lifting the scepter in a royal emblem, the lion has been for centuries the world's undisputed symbol of nobility and majesty.

title: No Rest for Giants Today: Redskins Visit Yale Bowl
description: NEWHAVEN, Oct. 13 The Washington Redskins and Coach George Allen in Yale Bowl: it's enough to make you cry, isn't it?

title: Canadiens Shape Up as Class of a MoreBalanced N.
description: Following the trauma of the World Hockey Association raiding parties, the National Hockey League has retrenched and is likely to offer its finest, most exciting, most competitive play in years.

title: Special Buses Set For Music Tonight
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Buses from seven points in Nassau and Queens will provide special service to the Nassau Colisuem here tonight for a lowpriced concert in memory of George Gershwin, the composer, who was born 75 year ago. He died in 1937.

title: Beats Marsh on 40th Hole
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 13In a soddendeath finish that went to the 40th hole, Gary Player won his fifth Piccadilly world matchplay golf championship today, beating Graham Marsh of Australia, the surprise finalist.

title: Letters: More Delights Of the Vermont Scene
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea Union Sells Building to Hospital
description: The National Maritime Union will move out of its headquarters in Greenwich Village, at the end of October and sell the building to the nearby St. Vincent's Medical Center.

title: 450 Drivers Seek Titles
description: DENVER, Oct. 13 (UPI)A total of 450 drivers was guaranteed starting positions by the Sports Car Club of America today for the $120,000; American Road Race of Chimpions at Guinesville, Ga., Oct.28 to Nov. 4. Twentyone national championship class titles were at stake.

title: Edith H. Brewster Is Betrothed
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., Oct. 13Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Brewster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Hutchinson Brewster, to Douglas Stafford Scarff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Scarff of Philadelphia and Winhall, Vt.

title: Canaan Rallies To Tie
description: Undefeated New Canaan staged a fourthquarter rally to salvage a 1616 tie with Greenwich yesterday. New Canaan, with a 401 wonlosttied record, is still the East Division leader in Fairfield County, while oncebeaten Greenwich is in third place in the West.

title: What's Doing in Hawaii
description: SPECIAL  October is Hawaii's time to celebrate with a series of Aloha Week festivals. The islands of Kauai and Molokai are celebrating this week, and Oahu starts its festival on Friday. The celebrations are a cornucopia of fragrant flowers, mellifluous music and tempestuous theatrics. There are floats, dances and pageants reminiscent of monarchy days (the return to which some Hawaiians would apparently welcome, judging by the prevalence of Restore the Monarchy bumper stickers). Most Aloha Week events are free to wearers of a $2 ribbon, which can be purchased, among other places, at stands in Waikiki and downtown Honolulu or from Aloha Week Hawaii, Inc., 680 Ala Moana Blvd., Honolulu, phone 5371994. Oahu's Aloha Week begins with a pageant at Iolani Palace on King Street in downtown Honolulu. Be ready for hordes of shrillvoiced lei sellers hawking armloads of heady plumiera, gorgeous orchids and aromatic carnations. On the big island of Hawaii, islandgrown produce and flowers and locally made arts and crafts will be exhibited during the Hawaii County Fair from Wednesday through Sunday. Hawaii Island will also be the site of the Kona Coffee Festival Nov. 1017. Molokai, known as the friendly isle, plays host next Sunday to the MolokaitoOahu Canoe Race, a grueling endrurance test that recalls the***old war games of ancient Hawaii.

title: Miss Deborah Halpern Is Engaged to Lawyer
description: Miss Deborah Halpern of Brooklyn plans to be married in December to Alan Silverman at the East Midwood Jewish Center there. Rabbi Harry Halpern, spiritual leader of the center, has announced the engagement of his daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Silverman of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.

title: Body of Woman Is Found In a Trunk in LI. Sound
description: The body of a woman in her early 30's was found yesterday in a trunk floating in Long Island Sound four miles northeast of the Coast Guard station in Eaton's Neck, L. I., and two miles south of Stamford, Conn.

title: Rockets Triumph Over Knicks, 8685
description: After playing sluggishly for the first 24 minutes, the New York Knickerbockers came alive last night, but it was too little and too late. The Houston Rockets fought off a stiff fourthquarter rally to win, 8685, before a crowd of 17,601 in Madison Square Garden.

title: RITAH BLUE IS DEAD; PRODUCER, CRITIC, 68
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 13 Mrs. Rita Hassan Blue, an actress, producer and drama critic, who was artist in residence in the theater department of the University of Bridgeport for the last five years, died today at her home here. Her age was 68.

title: Utopia No, But It Will Do
description: It was hardly VE day, nor the equal of a joyfultearful, 1940's New Year's Eve celebration in Times Square; in truth (though there are those who will dispute it) it did not even stimulate memories of Bobby Thomson's singular home run.

title: Wisconsin Life Trip
description: Along 194, between Madison and. Minneapolis, there is a large sign near the Black River Falls exit, promising an escape from the ordinary? It is a tourist lure to the hunting, swimming, boating pleasures to be found in the Black River State Forest and the surrounding area, not at all the kind of escape from the ordinaryinto madness, violence, incendiarismthat Michael Lesy chroni cled in Wisconsin Death Trip (pantheon, cloth $15, paper $5.95), his blurred portrait of Black River Falls in the 1890's. I am one of the few reviewers who refused to buy Lesy's gimmicky book at face value (see North American Review, fall, 1973), and in the course of clobbering his book, I developed a distant fondness for a Wisconsin town I had never seen. When I turned off I94 not long ago, it was not to escape anything, except perhaps a lingering suspicion that I had shaken off too quickly, Lesy's insistence that By the end of the nineteenth century, country towns had become charnel houses and the counties that surrounded them had become places of dry bones. was in search of the ordinary. And I found it.

title: Daily News Endorses Beame for Mayoralty
description: The New York News today endorsed the candidacy of Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

title: Hussein in the War
description: Acting under extreme pressure from other Arab countries and from firebrands in Jordan itself, King Hussein finally sent his troops into the ArabIsrael war yesterday But for the moment it seems that he did the minimum that he had to in order to provide some release front the pressures on him. He sent an undisclosed number of elite troops to fight in Syria while pointedly refraining from using: his entire army to attack Israel across the two countries' long common border. Presumably the King is hopindthat the Israelis will accept his move into the war as a token gesture and spare Jordan itself any direct participation in the fighting.

title: CHESIMARD TRIAI, IS MOYING SLOWLY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 13The first trial involving alleged members of what the police have called the Black Liberation Army goes into its second week Monday after four days of jury selection that led to the seating of only two jurors.

title: Home Improvement
description: ONE quick, and effective Way to modernize and improve an old house is to replace all the windows with complete new units that will not only look better and be easier to open and close, they will also help to greatly lower heating and cooling costs, and can serve to substantially reduce maintenance costs for years to come.

title: U.S. Jets Crash Kills Three
description: ANSBACH, Germany, Oct. 13 (AP)  A United States Air Force F4 Phantom jet crashed and struck an American an mored personnel carrier today, apparently killing at least three men, a United States military spokesman said.

title: U.S.Reported Ready to Replace Some Jet Fighters Lost by Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The United States is preparing to ship jet fighter planes to Israel to replace some of those lost in the first week of the Middle East war, Administration officials said today.

title: Correction
description: A story in The Week in Review of Oct. 7 concerning a proposed cooling tower at a Consolidated Edison Company nuclear power plant at Indian Point incorrectly stated that the intervener in a case before the Atomic Energy Commission was the Natural Resources Defense Council. The intervener was the Hudson River Fishermen's Association, which was represented by the Defense Council.

title: Pitchers for Today's Game
description: Jerry Koosman is a lefthanded Minnesotan who teemed with Torn Seaver to form the backbone of a pitching staff that turned the Mets from a national joke to a champion from 1969 on. At first he was basically a fastball pitcher, like Seaver, but various physical ailments in 1970 and 1971 hastened his ae velopment into a head?' pitcher, who now relies more on changing speeds, and breaking pitches, although he can still fire the ball when he needs to. He made 35 starts this season and had a 2.84 earnedrun average, and although his wonlost record was 1415, it was 61 after midAugust and he won his only playoff start Cincinnati.

title: Gall E. Herman Engaged to Steven. Geier
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 13Miss Gail Ellen Hernian and Steven Scott Geier, graduate students at Duke University, plan to be married in March.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The following letters are in response to a Point of View article published Sept. 2 and entitled, Needed: City Policy on Housing Welfare Recipients. The article, by Martin Hochbaum, a staff member of the American Jewish Congress, argued that the city uses an almost entirely shortterm approach in housing welfare tenants. It contended that such tenants should not be concentrated in poverty areas and that the substitution of flat housing grants for the rental payments now included in wel fare checks would encourage thrift and flexibility and curb the inflation of rents. Clara Fox is director of the Housing Department of United Neighborhood Houses. Edward Sulzberger is president of the Metropolitan Fair. Rent Committee.

title: JORDAN MOVES FORCE INTO SYRIA; ISRAEL CLAIMS SMASHING OF IRAQIS; THRUST TOWARD DAMASCUS HALTS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 13The Jordanian command announced today that it had begun moving a detachment of its best military formations to Syria to help in the defense of that land.

title: Planners Approve Housing For Aged
description: A controversial major housing development for the elderly scheduled for construction at 91st Street and Shore Road in Bay Ridge received the approval of the City Planning Commission Wednesday at a meeting that lasted until nearly midnight.

title: U.S. Getting a List Of Sewer Projects
description: TRENTONA priority list for financing and constructing 140 sewerage projects throughout the state at a cost of about $400thillion will be submitted this week to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for final approval.

title: Temporary Kings
description: Temporary Kings is the last but one of the 12 volumes that will make up Anthony Powell's rich novel sequence A Dance to the Music of Time, which chronicles 50 years in the life of its narrator, Nicholas Jenkins, and in the process a good deal of modern English social history.

title: Field Hockey Ass'n
description: NORTHERN DIVISION STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: Laurie Ann Haves To Be Wed Nov. 25
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Oct. 13  Miss Laurie Ann Haves, assistant to the director of planning for Rockville, Md., plans to be married Nov. 25 to Earl Mark Ferguson, assistant to the president of Golkin & Pinchuck of Rockville, builders and real estate developers in the Washington area.

title: Marching Kashmiri Youths Denounce Israel and U.S.
description: SPINIGAR, Kashmir, Oct 13  Several hundred Kashmiri Moslem youths marched throgh the city yesterday, demonstrating against Israeli aggression.

title: TRIBE'S SOVEREIGNTY IS DEFINED BY COURT
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Oct. 13The blunt fact is that an Indian tribe is sovereign to the extent that the United States permits it to be sovereignneither more nor less, said Federal District Judge Russell E. Smith this week in a ruling that denied a Blackfoot Indian tribal claim to the right to allow slot machine gambling on the Blackfoot reservation in Northwestern Montana.

title: MUSICIAN IS SLAIN ON THE WEST SIDE
description: A 42yearold music arranger was fettered and murdered early yesterday morning, when, the police said, he and his singerwife surprised two masked and armed burglars in their apartment near Lincoln Center.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN this space a year ago we suggested that the International Monetary Fund had ended its annual meeting in Washington with a rallying cry of, Next year in Nairobi. This year's meeting in the capital of Kenya was seen as a target date for an agreement, as Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz put it, on the main outlines of a new system for reforming the fixedrate monetary order which was dealt its death blow in 1971.

title: Miss Barbara Mary Liebmann Married to Dennis Kent Lynn
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 13  The Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church was the setting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Barbara Mary Liebmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Liebmann of Westport, to Dennis Kent Lynn. He is the son of Mrs. George F. Lynn 2d of Oneonta, N.Y., and the late Mr. Lynn.

title: Texas Student Leaders Protest The Use of Secret Drug Agents
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 13The use of undercover narcotics agents on the University of Texas campus and allegations of wiretaps on the phones of faculty members and students have aroused student leaders.

title: Trudeau Meets With Mao; Trade Agreement Signed
description: PEKING, Oct. 13 (UPI)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudead of Canada signed a trade agreement today with Pz'emier Chou Enlai and conferred almost two hours with Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Ecuador Troupe Presents Folk Dances
description: Supper club entertainment of modest accomplishment, presented with enormous goodwill, characterized Friday evening's program of the Ballet Naciondl de Ecuador at Hunter College The group was small in size and limited in repertory.

title: Adelphi To Study Ethics
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.Because of student concern over the alleged rampant disregard of ethics in public life, Adelphia University will start a sixmonthlong inquiry this month into whether ethics are obsolete.

title: 9 Women Join Boston Police
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Nine women, one a former model and five of them former school teachers, have been, sworn in as Boston police officers. Police Commissioner Robert J. di Grazia said that policewomen can do the job as well or sometimes even better than the male officers. The nine were sworn in Wednesday.

title: Stamps
description: QUEEN JULIANA has given the Netherlands a quarter century of staunch nonroyalist rule, as befits a ruler in this time of twilight for monarchy.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery dumber yesterday was:

title: News Summary and Index
DRIVE TO RELEASE POLISH JEW GAINS
description: Success appears to be near in a long campaign to enable Leopold Trepper, who ran an antiNazi underground organization for the Soviet Union in Europe before and during World War II, to emigrate from Poland.

title: GiantRedskin Statistics
OldTimey Music in Bergen
description: WESTWOOD  In four years, Howard LaMell has changed from a man whoie only musical outlet was playing a harmonica for fun to a musical activist with a rabid interest in at least two causes and an instrumental range that has grown to include a fiddle and a mandolin.

title: 1972 Scoring Leader Has 10 Touchdowns
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct, 13Last year's leading scorer In Nassau County football, Kevin Mannix, is back at his old stand, turning out touchdowns at a prolific rate. He added four more to his growing collection today as his visiting Syosset team blasted Bethpage, 500.

title: What Makes The Grande Bouffe Different From a Porno Movie?
description: FOUR men spend a weekend eating themselves to death in a grim, overciecorated mansion: the conceit has the imprint of an allegory by Buuel, the echo of wild house parties in Italian movies of a decade ago, the teasing metaphysics of a Last Year, at Marienbad. Four men tied to a brotherhood pact that tests endurance the premise is also a kinky Coritinental variation on Deliverance.

title: The Tapes
description: Though the President is elected by nationwide ballot, and is often said to represent all the people, he does not embody the nation's sovereignty. He is not above the law's commands.From the Appeals Court opinion on the President's tapes.

title: Milan Boots a Grounder, Leading to 2Run Third
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 13 Baseball rang up the curtain on its 70th World Series today with a glittering cast that ranged from the traveling Missouri mule to the New York Mets, who treated the Oakland A's to a 21 victory in the opening game on two unearned runs.

title: Washington Cathedral Asks Visitors to Give
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Washingion Cathedral is planning to ask weekday visitors to contribute $1 each to help defray the cost of upkeep.

title: 2 Nurses Open Suffolk Clinic To Give Primary Health Care
description: Behind the curtainedoff windows of the store with the new sign, two nurses are making health care history. They have declared themselves nursing practitioners and consultants, and are among the first in the country to open a fulltime, practice and clinic offering primary health care for their own patients.

title: Pollution Unit Being Expanded
description: TRENTON  The state's Bureau of Water Pollution Control, which was criticized earlier this year for not doing enough to prevent the mounting pollution of New Jersey's waterways, will undergo complete reorganization and expansion at a cost of $1million.

title: Cevert's Death May Hasten Stewart's Retirement
description: In the often cruel world of auto racing, the legacy of Franois Cevert sometimes seems only a place on the Tyrrell Formula One team. Or maybe two. After the popular Frenchman was killed eight days ago in practice for the United States Grand Prix, the talk of Watkins Glen was not about Cevertone doesn't talk about the dead until the race is overbut about Cevert's teammate, Jackie Stewart, and who would drive for Ken Tyrrell next season. Cevert is dead; auto racing and life go on. Both are often callous.

title: Ford Fraternity Brothers Have Been Prominent
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP)Fraternity brothers of the VicePresidential nominee, Gerald R. Ford, do not need name tags for reunions.

title: Jersey City PATH Terminal to Open
description: JERSEY CITY  Giant cranes are still swinging 54ton precast concrete girders into place at the new Journal Square Transportation Center, but the rapidtransit rail station in the $80millioncomplex is virtually set for a Nov. 4 opening.

title: Not Crime in the Streets, but Crime in City Halls, Is a Major Issue in Five Mayoral Races Around the State
description: Crime in City Hall, not in the street, is a loud campaign cry in five of six mayoral races outside of New York City where politicians have often pointed to the city as a symbol of municipal corruption.

title: Woman Is Elected to Top Post In National Council of Churches
description: For the first time, the National Council of Churches yes. terday elected a woman as its general secretary, one of the highest and most prestigious religious posts in the United States.

title: A. Middleton Gammell Fiance Of Nellie L. Taft, a Teacher
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 13The engagement of Miss Nellie Leaman Taft to A. Middleton Gammell has been announced by the future bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Carmichael Haydock. Miss Taft is a daughter also of the late Hulbert Taft Jr.

title: Alfred 176 Victor As Bzdak Excels
description: ALFRED, N. Y., Oct. 13The Alfred Saxons defeated St. Lawrence, 17.6, in a homecoming game today, with Henry Bzdak running for 175 yards to lead the Alfred attack. Bzdak brought his Alfred career record to 2,601 yards and scored one touchdown.

title: FORD GOES HOME TO JOIN A PARADE
description: CEDAR SPRINGS, Mich., Oct. 13 Representative Gerald R. Ford observed a custom of attending a parade in honor of red flannel underwear in his home district today, less than 24 hours after President Nixon had nominated him as the nation's 40th Vice President.

title: Ann C. von Gal to Be Wed in December
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Vreeland von Gal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mis Ann Carrol von Gal, to Richard Clare Bush, son of Ivan Paul Bush of Lansing, Mich., and the late Mrs. Bush. The wedding is planned for Dec. 22.

title: Flyers Score by 60
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 13 The Broad Street Bullies, as the Philadelphia Flyers enjoy calling themselves, showed the Islanders tonight they can also play it straight as they routed the New Yorkers, 6.0.

title: JESUITS RECEIVE PAPAL WARNING
description: ROME, Oct. 13The Jesuit order disclosed this week that it had received a stern warning from Pope Paul VI to shun innovations that might lead it astray.

title: Hiroshima Happened Before He Was Born. Still ...
description: A day in the life of Hiro shima, August, 1945 People gather by, th?? edge of the water. One man is fishing. Another read the newspaper. Elsewhere two youths are fighting, a pregnant woman finishes he chores, a postman delivers the mail. Children play hopscotch on the sidewalk. A painter sets up a ladder to work. The elegiac music conveys a sense of nostalgia for everyday life, for a serenity that can never be reclaimed.

title: Use of Contradictions
description: PEKINGThis ancient capital, has never been, an international city. Even now, despite China's steadily increasing world role, the foreign community is astonishingly small. There area few nonChinese Commercial representatives stationed here, a handful of newspaperman, and a curious mixture of foreign residents.

title: Wall Street Slims Down
description: Six months ago, this was a jumping, jiving noisy place, said John P. Romeo, a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, as he surveyed one of the vast working floors where the firm's buy and sell orders are transmitted to the New York Stock Exchange. Look at it now.

title: Southeast Asia
description: SAIGON  While the world's attention has shifted elsewhere, the war here sputters along at a deadly clip, blocking the political accommodation envisaged by the Paris peace agreements last January. And In the last few weeks, both sides have begun to crank up their rhetoric as well as their armed actions.

title: Maloney Golf Victor
description: SUTTON, Mass., Oct. 13 (AP)Paul Maloney of Southern Connecticut captured the individual title and Central Connecticut took the team prize for the third time in four years today in the Eastern College Athletic Conference golf tournament. Maloney carded a fourover par 76 in leading a field of 57 at the Pleasant Valley Country Club.

title: Nixon Speech on Nominee Had 4 Endings
description: WASHINGTON Oct 13 President Nixon asked his speechwriters for drafts of speeches with four different endings as he prepared earlier this week to announde his choice for Vice President to succeedd Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Recordings
description: PEOPLE who collect and restore antiques sometimes develop a Faustian kind of fanaticism about what to others seems only a quaint hobby. And why not, since what they are trying to do is to outwit time, to deny its cold rule over us all. The fascination with historically authentic musical performance and with original instruments, which has been growing steadily throughout this century, has similarly Faustian overtones.

title: New and Recommended
description: HARRIET SAID, by Beryl Bainbridge. (Braziller, $5.95.) A thriller of corrupt childhood in which each element advances the whole and which tells of two girls wreaking revenge upon the adult world.

title: Newcombe, Rosewall Gain Final.
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13 (AP) Two Australians, John Newcombe and Ken Rosewall, registered straightset victories today and moved into the final of the $60,000 Tokyo open tennis tournament.

title: LOUIS JOFFE
description: Louis Joffe, a retired lawyer and former secretary of RKO Theaters and of the Glen Alden Corporation, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.

title: UFFICIALS CHARGED IN SOVIET GEORGIA
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13The Georgian Communist party's leader. ship has extended its purge of governmental organs to include the dismissal of the minister of justice and chief judge of the People's Court in the Adzharskaya autonomous region with. in Georgia.

title: LITTON PAYMENTS BY NAVY WILL ET
description: The Government has won an important skirmish in its legal struggle to delay further payments to Litton Industries for behind  schedule construction work on five LHA amphibiousassault ships. The result is halt, for now at least, in Navy payments of more than $3million a week to Litton.

title: QUAKE PREDICTION GETS NEW IMPETUS
description: New hope for earthquake prediction in areas where quakes are caused by side slippage of crustal rock has been raised by the examination of records made in Japan before the Matsushiro earthquakes of 1965.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Here are these three killers: personable, honest college men, patriotic Americans. They work as a team, disposing of people for a fee. Unfortunately, as honest Americans, they have to pay taxes on earned income and taxes are eating them up. So they go to a smart lawyer with the idea of going public. With their growth record (and even greater growth potential) there surely should be some interest in their proposition.

title: Miss Seilern Is Fiancee Of Guy G. Rutherfurd Jr.
description: Count and Countess Franz Joseph von Seilern und Aspang of Vienna and Litschau, Austria, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Therese Seilern und Aspang of New York, to Guy G. Rutherfurd Jr., an investment counselor at. White, Weld & Co. here.

title: When the Foliage Falls . . .
description: LIVINGSTON  Suburban communities are girding for the annual task of disposing of mountains of leaves without harming the ecology. In most areas, the job gets under way in a week or so.

title: Whelan's Aerials Pace Exeter to 316 Decision
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 13Bill Whelan, a senior quarterback, threw for three touthdowns, two to Jim Bullock, and ran for another in a 316 Exeter victory over Mount Hermon. It was the first victory in three games for Exeter and the second loss in three games for Mount Hermon.

title: At Jamaica Bay Yacht Club, Shoe's on Other Foot
description: Although they may not carry discriminatory bylaws on their books, it is no secret that many private yacht clubs practice a form of exclusivity through selfselection. In Port Washing. ton, L. I., for example, three yacht clubs sit side by side on Manhasset Bayone with a predominantly Catholic membership, another with predominantly Protestant membership and the third predominantly Jewish.

title: Sensual Grace on the Stage
description: She looks so enraptured up there on stage, so utterly and seductively in love, this svelte young woman in the fleshcolored bodysuit gracefully undulating her way through the most sensuous of movements.

title: The U.N.: Only A Scorekeeper
description: UNITED NATIONS  The reports from the United Nations military truce observers in the Middle East began flowing into the headquarters here in the early morning hours of Oct. 6. Egyptian ground forces have crossed the Suez Canal.... Syrian forces have crossed [the ceasefire lines] in the vicinity of Quneitra. . . . Once again the United Nations had failed to keep the peace. Once again the Security Council became the scene of a bitter and sterile debate.

title: The Very Private Pritzkers
description: The Pritzkers? Who are they? That's what New York's inbred publishing world has been asking for the last three weeks. Late in the afternoon of Sunday, Sept. 23, David J. Mahoney, the publicitysavvy chairman of Norton Simon, Inc., announced that he had sold McCall's, the women's magazine, to Ref co Enterprises, ltd., for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Peace and War
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon proclaimed it a new beginning for America and hilt announcement on Friday that Gerald R. Ford was the ideal choice to become Vice. President of the United States had the staged exuberancethe rhetorical flourish, the televised gaiety, the pretense of suspenseof a political convention moving confidently toward national triumph.

title: Robert Thomas, 64, Dies; ExPresident of Firestone
description: AKRON, Ohio Oct. 13 (UPI) Robert D. Thomas, who retired as president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Comipany last year, died Thursday night at City Hospital here, He was 64 years old.

title: Cougars Are Beaten By Whalers
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Thirdperiod goals by Tim Sheehy, Rick Ley, Toni Webster, and Mike Byers spelled the difference today as, the New England Whalers beat the Chicago Cougars, 64, in the World Hockey Association.

title: Syrians Report Downing of 20 Israeli Aircraft
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 13Highly reliable sources here contended today that Syrian troops had contained an Israeli advance from the Golan heights up the road toward Damascus, preventing a breakthrough to the Syrian capital.

title: Enlistments in September Fall Short of Goal by 16%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)The Defense Department fell 16 per cent short of its volunteer enlistment goal for the armed services in September, it was announced yesterday.

title: Georgia Capitol to Get First Black Portraits
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 13 (UPI)For the first time in state history, portraits of prominent black Georgians will hang in the State Capitol along with those of such historic figures as Alexander Stephens, Vice President of the Confederacy.

title: TV Series on Retirement Is Produced by Foundation
description: A television series on retirement planning, entitled Ready or Not, has been produced by the Manpower Education Institute, a private, nonprofit foundation with headquarters here.

title: Jenkins Sparkles At Clifton
description: Powerful Clifton received a fourtouchdown performance from its 5foot10inch, 185pound halfback, Jim Jenkins, and routed Teaneck, 470, yesterday in Clifton for its 13th consecutive victory, fourth this season.

title: Obsessions of the Past
description: When President Nixon nominated Representative Gerald Ford of Michigan as successor to the departed Vice President Agnew last week, he called it, vital that we turn away from the obsessions of the past and turn to, the great challenges of the future. Few Americans will disagree with Mr. Nixon's call for a new beginning but the President does little to encourage hopein the soundness of the directions he will point by dismissing the dismaying developments of recent months as a matter of obsessions.

title: Mrs. Anne Pepper to Be Wed Nov. 24
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Mrs. Anne Emmet Pepper and Stacy Barcroft Lloyd 3d plan to be married here Nov. 24.

title: Penn State Trounces Army, 543, for 5th Victory
description: UNIVERSITY. PARK, Pa., Oct. 13If Penn State played a service academy football team every week, the Nittany Lions might not lose another game for years to come.

title: As If By Magic By Angus Wilson. 415 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $8.95.
description: The opening pages of Angus Wilson's new novel seem to be about chickens, at least in their various human disguises. One character, Alexandra, is scratching and pecking around a church hall as she performs a mime about poultry. Hamo Langmuir, the prim hero of the book, is accused of pursuing chicken pubescent boysthough in fact, as he indignantly explains, be goes for young men in roughly the 16 to 20yearold range. His Cockney sidekick, irredeemably heterosexual, courts chicks of still another variety.

title: The naked plate
description: William Burroughs's latest: a disappointing novel, of uneven parts; a sketchy miscellany of short stories, scenarios, poems and fragments linked only by the slenderest threads of repetition and continuity and occasional consistencies of tone. No novelist has demonstrated less regard than Burroughs for concerns of plot and characterization; they invade his work only rarely; in no place are they sustained. And never in his fiction has there been less to supplant them than in Exterminator!

title: Lutherans Planning a United Service
description: TRENTON  In what has been described as a historic first for New Jersey, Lutherans of three separate Lutheran Church bodies will join in worship at an allLutheran reformation service.

title: Trial For 9 Memphis Police
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 13 (AP)Nine police officers will go on trial Monday in the death of Elton Hayes, a I7yearOld black who died two years ago while in, custody. The youth died following a highspeed chase that ended at a police roadblock. The police at first said he died of injuries received when the pickup truck bounced into a ditch, but a medical examiner's autopsy findings showed he died of a blow or blows to his head which crushed his Skull.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In developing the past, present and future fee structure for brokers, I find it very difficult to understand why selling around lot (100 shares) at $50 a share is any different in terms of work effort than the sale of 1,006 shares at $50 a share.

title: 3 Share 2d in Japan
description: INZAI, Japan, Oct. 13 (AP)  Bert Yancey, playing through strong winds; shot a twooverpar 73 today and held a :onestroke lead after three rounds of the $300,000 Pacific Club Masters golf tournament.

title: Test of Smaller Tax Starts Tomorrow at Aqueduct Meet
description: Playing the horses will become a little less costly for New Yorkers tomorrow when Aqueduct opens its extended fall meeting with a reduced parimutuel tax.

title: Something good out of Watergate?
description: The White House, was once and will be againa great place for a young man to work. I did it myself and have never been sorry. Fate was kind and my age was right: It was Harry Truman's White House, and I worked for Charlie MurphyCharles S. Murphy, to give him his due. He was the President's Special Counsel, successor to Clark Clifford in that post and one of Truman's senior aides. Working for Murphy and with him for the President was a fine experience, as unlike Egil Krogh's or Gordon Strachan's as day from night A story illustrates what made it so, and the story is a starting point for looking at the Presidency now, by light of Watergate.

title: Hearing Set On Plan By Lilco To Expand
description: SYOSSET, L.I. A report on the proposed expansion of the Long Island Lighting Company's generating plant at Glenwood Landing is expected to be presented to the Environmental Commission of the. Town of Oyster Bay by Oct. 30.

title: Daughter Represents Nixon
description: CARTHAGE, Tenn, Oct. 131 (AP)Tricia Nixon Cox deputized for her father, the Presi dent, today at the dedications of the $75.5million Cordell Hull Locks and Dam near here. Mr. Nixon had canceled his scheduled appearance because of the war in the Middle East.

title: Construction of Nursing Homes in City Is Sharply Curtailed by New Policy of Planning Commission
description: The construction of nursing homes in the city has been sharply curtailed under a new policy of the Planning Commission aimed at stemming the continued concentration of the facilities in certain neighborhoods.

title: Brewster Reviews a Decade at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13Kingman Brewster Jr. yesterday marked the 10th anniversary of his appointment as Yale University's president and, at this time for reflection, he said, One of the things you ask yourself when you've been in a job this long is, How much capacity for selfrenewal have you got?'

title: ZODIAC! Yaaaaaay Teeeeeam!!
description: WITH the gridiron season in full swing and commanding an increasing share of the TV audience, the football leagues recently commissioned an astrologer to explore the horoscopes and viewing habits of today's TV football fans to determine whether the zodiac ranks with the Nielsens as an accurate source of information about the home audience. Here are some early horoscopic highlights of that study taken from the astrologer's case files. The names of the subjects are being withheld to protect the astrologer.

title: FORD'S NOMINATION SENT TO CONGREESS HE BARS '76 RACE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 President Nixon's nominatior of Gerald R. Ford to be the 40t1 Vice President of the United States was submitted to Congress today amid promises that the Senate and House would make thorough investigations before acting on his confirmation.

title: Justices Bar Hargis Tax Plea; Religious Groups Fear Impact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Supreme Court rejected this week an appeal that sought to restore the tax exemption of the Rev. Billy Hargis and his Christian Crusade.

title: Searching for the Lost. Chord of Harmony in Japan
description: HARMONY, it is said, is the essence of Japanese culture and society, yet nothing is less conducive to harmonious living than teeming, sprawling, polluted Tokyo, city of 10 million people with 22 million more on the outskirts. Tokyo dogs have such blackened lungs that four out of five, according to 2,000 autopsies performed on dead strays, died of pollution. The landscape, as well as the smog, make the eyes smart. On one block the eye Is assaulted by a skyscraper, a pagoda, a tiokytacky parking garage, a circular modern hotel with a revolving restaurant, and a fastfoodfranchiseall clashing, all uglifying through dissonance, and each diluting whatever strength or beauty the others possess.

title: SEARCH CONTINUED FOR PEKING MAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 13A Chicago investment broker's yearlong search for the Peking Man fossils, missing since 1941, brought him to Taiwan last week, but the broker, Christopher G. Janus, left for Hong Kong without making any progress in locating the 400,000yearold remains.

title: Bridgeport Victor Over Wagner, 217
description: Mitchell Sanders, a quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for another yesterday as the University of Bridgeport registered a 217 victory over Wagner College at Fischer Memorial Field.

title: A Queen and a KingBut Where's the Battle Royal?
description: SOMETIMES people make drama for other people. That's what Eileen Herlie and George Grizzard are doing in Crown Matrimonial, the lacquered new British import at the Helen Hayes. In theory, Miss Herlie and Mr. Grizzard have the leading roles and, in theory, they're at it tooth and nailpolished tooth, sheathed nailall. evening. Miss Herlie is playing that Queen Mary who couldn't tolerate the notion of a twicedivorced woman solemnly married to a King of England, and Mr. Grizzard is the all'swelllostforlove Duke of Windsor, briefly Edward VIII. Both, being fine actors, are fine.

title: Married or Not, Couples Living Together Have Similar Problems
description: Sixmonth old Nicholas LobelWeiss was lying on his pink blanket gurgling happily as his parents, Bonnie Lobel and Arnold Weiss, tried to remember the date of their wedding.

title: Numismatics
description: TOMOROW is the deadline for ordering the 1973 uncirculated 40 per cent silver Eisenhower dollars. Orders postmarked after Oct. 15 will be returned. In its announcement of the cutoff date, the Bureau of the Mint stated that it would discontinue the acceptance of orders on Oct. 15, so collectors would be wise to regard today as the deadline for mailing.

title: 53Foot Schooner Wins Race for Mayor's Cup
description: With an aptness that seemed strange for such a delightfully unorthodox regatta, a graceful staysail schooner named Bounding Home swept across the finish line ahead of 25 competitors yesterday in the seventh annual schooner race for the Mayor's Cup.

title: PHNOM PENH CONVOY ARRIVES BY HIGHWAY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 13 (UPI)A convoy containing new military vehicles, food and lumber arived without incident on Route 4 today, the second day after Government troops reopened the supply route between the Cambodian capital an dthe port of Kompong Som.

title: 10 Injured as London Police Battle 300 at Leftist Protest
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (Reuters) Ten persons were injured today when policemen and leftwing demonstrators clashed in front of a building where the small rightwing National Front party was holding its annual congress.

title: QUESTIONS
description: If you have's question or know the answer to a question asked in these columns, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped, selfaddressed envelope.

title: Parking Lot Moves Ahead in Brooklyn
description: Construction of a controversial metered parking lot planned for Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues and Avenue II in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, will begin, according to a spokesman for the Department of Public Works, as soon as the land is vacated.

title: WALL STREET
description: People are always asking Wall Street reporters for tips on the stock market, The idea, of course, is that reporters talk with research analysts, company executives and various financial bigwigs, In the process picking up hints on tomorrow's hot stockthe one that's going to climb to telephone numbers.

title: The Stardust Kid By Pat Richowc. 251 pp.New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $6.95.
description: If you still twist your radio dial late at night in bemused hope of catching a remote airshot of Tommy Dorsey, then maybe this rawly nostalgic novel of the early forties will ring your chimes. It follows the budding career of redheaded Mike Riley through highschool life in Connor City, Neb., where he rises from Junior Band to R.O.T.C. Band to nonunion and underage lead trumpeting with the local swing orchestra (Mairsy Doats for the kiddies at the Royal Theatre Saturday matinee).

title: Pennsylvania Liquor Higher
description: HARRISBURG, Oct. 13 (AP) 1The Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board has announced the third round of price increases this year, effective Oct. 24. The increases Thursday affect 174 wines and liquors sold in state stores. The liquor board's announcement attributed the increased costs to the continual inflationary squeeze.

title: DR. GEORGE H. BISHOP
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (UPI)Dr. George H. Bishop, a researcher into the mechanism of nerve impulse and a member of the National Academy of Sciences, died Thursday at a hospital here after a stroke, He was 84 years old.

title: BEALL WON'T GIVE UP EVIDENCE ON AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13George Beall, the United States Attorney here, does not plan to turn over secret evidence to three state's attorneys who are seeking to determine if they should open their own investigations of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Fish CoOp in Florida Benefits Elderly Buyers
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP)  Elderly residents here are buying fish at 25 cents a pouhd from a nonprofit cooperative for older people and the proteinrich food is selling faster than the coop can stock its freezers.

title: A.E.C. Liaison Aide Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  Donald R. Cotter of New Mexico was confirmed by the Senate today to be chairman of the Military Liaison Committee to the Atomic Energy Commission. He succeeds Carl Walske, who resigned.

title: Unbeaten Bayside Stops Clinton, 308
description: It didn't take Bayside long to mar Clinton's unscored upon record yesterday as the Public Schools Athletic League rivals clashed in an interdivision game in the Bronx. Pierre Davis, a Bayside halfback, raced 17 yards for a touchdown on the third play of the game and Bayside went on to win, 308. The victory was the fourth straight for unbeaten Bayside.

title: Israel Under Fire
description: WASHINGTONThe first week of what the Arabs call the October War has ended with Israel's survival apparently, assured but little else certain in the Middle East. Of the dozens of questions that await an answer, the bones that have aroused most attention are these:

title: HANDICAPPED AIM FOR NORMAL LIVES
description: Handicapped persons must be able to function as normal human beings within the urban system and any segregation of them should be rejected outright except for extreme clinical cases.

title: RICHMOND ACCEPTS SCHOOL DECISION
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 13  This city, after losing again in the Supreme Court, appears ready to accept, for the time being, the fact of mostly black public schools.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: TODAY'S GAMES Washington vs. N.Y. Giants, at New Haven, 1 P.M.

title: Threat Delays Soviet Flight
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 13 (Reuters)An anonymouse bomb threat caused a Soviet TU134 airliner carrying 65 passengers to be delayed for almost four hours at the Stuttgart airport today. The police said that the threat was telephoned to the Soviet Embassy in Bonn. The airliner later continued its flight to Moscow.

title: REFORM PROPOSED IN FIGHT ON CRIME
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, has issued a call for reform of the criminal justice system that would involve intensive citizen participation, greater use of communitybased alternatives to prison and a recasting of police forces rather than putting more policemen in the streets.

title: Jordanian Communique on Role in War
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 13Following, in official translation from the Arabic, is the text of a communiqu issued by the Jordanian Government today and disseminated by the Jordanian news agency:

title: Music
description: MIGNON DUNN finally did itgot herself an opening night and mopped up. It was like the return of the native at the Met's opening on Sept. 17 when the lusty mezzo from Memphis burned up the stage as Azucena, demented gypsy lady of Verdi's Il Trovatore, walked away with an armload of critical paeans, and at long last came into her own as an artist to be reckoned with15 years and 45 roles after coming to the Metropolitan.

title: The O'Neill Home Turns 75
description: A house, like a human, may be expected to have achieved a stable character by the age of 75 and to have pretty much secured a settled identity. The house Eugene O'Neill occupied on Point O'Rocks Lane in. Marblehead Neck, Mass., has this year reached that reassuring age. Perhaps its present impressive dimensions insulate it against any future shock of change.

title: INDIAN SECT STIRS A BITTER DISPUTE
description: PATNA, India, Oct. 13On a muddy road on the fringe of this city, men in orange robes and turbans sit in a deserted headquarters and nervously discuss the path of bliss.

title: On the commune, correct thinking helps
description: KWANG LI PEOPLE'S COMMUNE, China. Chen Chifun and his family have not forgotten that they are middle peasants. Nearly 25 years ago, before the Communists came to their village, Sui Kang, in a poor, remote area of China's Kwangtung Province the Chen family enjoyed relative prosperity. Because they owned land for their farming needs, they met the qualifications of middle peasants in the Chinese Communist party's 1930 and 1950 classifications of rural society. They did not lease nd to tenants or hire others to farm it for them, as landlords and rich peasants did. Nor did they pay tribute to others, like lowermiddle peasants, who owned some, but not all of their land; poor peasants, who rented all the land they tilled, or the lowest on the scale, farm laborers, who depended on manual labor for their existence. In preCommunist China, being a middle S peasant was a relatively prestigious and often comfortable status.

title: Booze, Bellehops and Other Freebies for the Briefcase Brigade
description: I HAVE never been to Gaithersburg, Md., and, although the local Chamber of Commerce may demand my head for saying so, I can't think of any reason to go there. Unless, of course, one has business with the National Bureau of Standards, which has a 20building complex including a threestoryhigh testing, machine of some sort, scattered around 580 acres a couple of miles west of town. Still, Gaithersburg, which is near Washington, D. C., and has fewer than 5,000 residents, supports a Holiday Inn that boasts of what it calls the world's plushiest hotel or motel suite. The motel's eighthfloor Presidential suite, designed for tired executives, has seven rooms and four baths and a rental rate of $1,400 a day. It comes with a few extras, of course, such as a circular, motorized tilting and vibrating bed that has a headboard equipped with taps dispensing Scotch and soda, bourbon and water, and martinis, but a businessman would have to be awfully tired to justify a tab like that on his expense account.

title: News of the Camera World
description: ASERIES of evening levtures, entitled Photography: Points of View, will be presented at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, during October and November. The first lecture will be a talk by Peter C. Bunnell, McAlpin Professor of the History of Photography and Modern Art, Princeton University. It will take place on Wednesday, Oct. 24 at 8 P.M. and will be entitled The Mirror of Reflection: Thoughts on Meaning in Photographs.

title: Carnegie Reports
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education came into being in 1967, its charge was to study the financing of America's colleges and universities. Gradually, as a host of problems beset academia, the commission widened its area of concern Last week, after having its final say in a report entitled Priorities for Action, the panel went out of business.

title: Made Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Deadline Nears on Decision on L.I. Fuel Oil Needs
description: One scenario goes like this On Oct. 19, long Island runs out of all industrial fuel oils. To keep the lights burning and the dishwashers running, home fuel oil supplies are diverted to some industries. Oil companies begin rationing thee cutting off residential customens as the winter grows colder. Thermostats and turned down to 50 degrees at night, schools and government buidings close, brownouts occur for the first time in the Middle of January, fuel oil trucks are hijacked and a black market begins.

title: Who Needs Donuts?
description: Maybe Mark Alan Stamaty suffers from horri vacuii  fear of open spaces. If so, he faces the demon courageously. The graphic world he creates in Who Needs Donuts? is of dazzling and outrageous proportions. On every page you see crazed details of a phantasmagoric urban life squeezed into drawings between drawings. Within this incredible display of endlessly amusing minutiae, there are undoubtedly included some moments beyond the reach of many children. Also, some of the leading, characters are grimacing in a downright Groszian way. If Stamaty's is a strange vision, it is nonetheless underlined by humor and an inspired sense of the absurd.

title: Art
description: ZAIRE, the recently renamed African republic that most people still think of as the Congo, seemed an unlikely spot for a world convention of art critics when it was announced early this year that AICA (Association International des Critiques d'Art) would hold its 1973 meeting there. But about 150 AICAns from just about everywhere  a loose estimate including a percentage of ringersassembled in Kinshasa, the capital city, for a couple of weeks last month for a series of conferences, shindigs and sidetrips with the announced theme AICA Meets Africa, to which many of the delegates would have added, on the was home,  head on.

title: 6 Killed Near Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (UPI) A fivevehicle collision on Irrterstate 95 here killed six persons, five of them fellow workers at the Philadelphia State Hospital. The victims last night were Harry Sharkus, 39 years old, of Cornwells Heights, Pa., and Lorenzo Butler, 42, Sandra Savage, 22, William Robinson, 21, and Henry Abney, 54, all of Philadelphia, the hospital workers. The sixth victim was i dentified as Juan Pedro Cash, 22, of Philadelphia.

title: How to Bring Up a Pheasant
description: ROCKPORT  The pheasanthunting season opens on Saturdly, Nov. 10, and Duncan Buntain is ready.

title: La Zanzara Takes Handicap for Fillies
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP)La Zanzara, an Englishbred ridden by Bill Shoemaker, ran down Sandy Blue, the favorite, in the stretch to win the $33,550 Linda Vista Handicap today at Santa Anita's Oak Tree meeting.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Area Improvement Group Tries the Friendly Approach
description: A Brooklyn group treated 25 sanitationmen and their wives to a champagne cocktail party and a concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last Thursday night.

title: Anne L. Rahilly Bride in Jersey Of Paul Barrett
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 13  Miss Anne Lawrence Rahilly, daughter of Mrs. Bernard John Rahilly and the late Mr. Rahilly, was married here this afternoon to Paul Welles Barrett. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Riker Barrett of Plainfield.

title: Mary Stronk Fiancee Of A. C. Merryman 4th
description: BRANFORD, Conn., Oct. 13Miss Mary Elizabeth Stronk, an editor with Travel Weekly in New York, plans to be married Oct. 27 to Andrew Curtis Merryman 4th, director of the corporate communications division of MBA Communications, a New York publishing company, of which he also is vice president.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayRace of Champions, 300mille modified sportsman stock car 300mile event at Trenton (N.J.) Speedway, 2 P.M.

title: Officials Say Narcotics Hot Line Is Working
description: ALBANY, Oct. 13A selfdescribed drug addict, breathing irregularly and supposedly bleeding from stab wounds, walked into a phone booth in New York City the other day and dialed 6953387, the state's hot line for drug informants.

title: Recital to Benefit State Arts Council
description: UNIONAn allNew Jersey college faculty recital has been scheduled by the New Jersey Council of Music Chairmen as a benefit concert for the State Council on the Arts. The concert will be presented at 3 P.M. next Sunday at Newark State College.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WESTERN OIL COMPANY NEGOTIATIONS called for a twoweek adjournment in price talks with the six Persian Gulf members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The companies and Abu Dhabi, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar and Saudi Arabia are trying to reach an agreement on oil price increases, but company officials said the price claims lodged by the six countries are substantially higher than the increases offered by the companies. . . . Iraq nationalized oil interests of the Near East Development Corporation, owned by Mobil Oil and Exxon.

title: Arabs Compare War and '68 Tet Drive
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13After eight days of fighting, Arab analysts continue to feel that there is going to be a prolonged war in which the Arab side enjoys economic, tactical and psychological advantages over Israel.

title: GREECE REAFFIRMS NEUTRALITY IN WAR
description: ATHENS, Oct. 13Greece reaffirmed today her neutrality in the Middle East conflict and barred the use of her land, sea and air space for any warrelated activity.

title: Back to nature, an identity crisis, survival problems
description: The Island

title: Clarkstown North Stays Undefeatal
description: Clarkstown North posted tits fourth victory of the season and retained its undefeated status yesterday by downing Pearl River, 1813.

title: White House Is Studying Tapes Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The constituitional confrontation between the President and the judiciary continued unabated today, with the White House declining to say whether Mr. Nixon would comply with yesterday's decision by the Court of Appeals that he must give up the Watergate tapes.

title: HIGHWATER FIGHT IN MIDWEST SWIFTS
description: The sun shone on floodstricken sections of Oklahoma, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska and Iowa yesterday as the battle against high water shifted from creeks and tributaries to the Kansas and Missouri Rivers, The Associated Press reported.

title: Do With Me What You Will By Joyce Carol Oates. 561 pp. New York: Vanguard Press.$7.95.
description: Joyce Carol Oates's novels are grinding, brutal, harsh. She is the mistress of panic, knowing its taste, its first sharp darts, the new pulses it surprises on the body, with an alarming thoroughness. No one, not even Lawrence, has so given the novel over to extreme states of feeling. She writes from within psyches that are like prehistoric organisms, creatures all spines and terrible soft undersides, engaging in love that is like hatred, combat that is like love, mercifully separating reengaging. . . .

title: Josephine Curran, Student, Is Fiancee
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 13Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Curran of Amhurst have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Anne Curran, to Thomas George Stemberg of Chicago, son of Mrs. Oscar Michael Stemberg of Vienna and the late Mr. Stemberg. The wedding is planned for spring.

title: Poll Finds Blacks in 25% of City Jobs
description: A survey of city government employes reported yesterday that blacks had risen to hold 25 per cent of the municipal jobs, better than their 21 per cent of the population.

title: Arthur Daley
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 13I live here, man, said Willie Milys, somewhat astonished that someone should ask, him what it was like to return to the Bay Area after spending a season and a half with the New York Mets. Thus wis he capping a career that began with the,New York Giants, later the San Francisco. Giants. His home is at Athertore in the suburbs, where the rich people, live. Whether or not he actually was home out here will be disputed by the Mays loyalists. To them he was always New York from his first day as a Giant in 1951, even though Horace Stonehame shanghaied him to San Francisco in 195g. Then the Mets sprang him in one of baseball's most sentimental gestures so that he could finish his days among those fans who loved him most.

title: Panthers 357 Victors
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 13 (AP)Bill Daniels, a quarterback, scored two firsthalf touchdowns and Tony Dorsett, a freshman tailback, added three scoring runs in the secondhalf today as underdog Pitt drubbed West Virginia, 357.

title: Isabelle Pettit Sets Nov. 24 Bridal
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Oct. 13William Schuyler Pettit, president of Ursinus College, and Mrs. Pettit have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabelle Schuyler Pettit, to Robert Foster Seeman of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford B. Seeman of Hancock, N. H., formerly of Pelham, N. Y.

title: Notes: Virgin Island Tourism in Decline
description: IT is no surprise to learn that travel to the United States Virgin Islands, especially the island of St. Croix, has dropped off considerably in the last 13 months, a period that has seen rash of killings on St. Croix.

title: Paperbacks
description: FICTION

title: Patricia Grafmueller Is Wed to Paul Buddenhagen
description: Miss Patricia Riker Grafmueller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Grafmueller of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Paul Selkregg Buddenhagen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Buddenhagen of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Frederick Hill performed the ceremony in St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: Coast Guard Routs Wesleyan by 279
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn,, Oct. 13Five costly pass interceptions, three of them leading directly to Coast Guard touchdowns, contributed to a 279 victory by the Cadets over Wesleyan University today.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: The World
description: The proud and sensitive Japanese were stung. Here was the Japanese Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka, on a longplanned visit to Moscow, and the Soviet leader, Leonid Brezhnev, was absent from a lunch given by the Japanese party, as well as from a Bolshoi Ballet performance he had agreed to attend. It may well have been pressing Middle East problems that kept Mr. Brezhnev away, rather than a deliberate effort to snub Mr. Tanaka, but as one Japanese observer conscious of his nation's limited military power put it, If Nixon or Brandt were in Moscow, Brezhnev would have found the time to attend.

title: Irish Survive 4 Fumbles And Subdue Rice, 280
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)Wayne Bullock scored twice on 1yard bursts and Tom Clemetns tossed a 21yard touchdown pass tonight to lead ninth  ranked Notre Dame to a 280 triumph over Rice University.

title: Tennessee Sets Back Ga. Tech
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13 (UPI)Condredge Holloway, a scrambling quarterback, turned busted plays into two touchdowns today as Tennessee beat Georgia Tech, 2014.

title: 3 Sisters Attend Diana L. Beach At Her Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 13 Miss Diana Lee Beach and the Rev. Dr. John Romig Johnson were married here this afternoon in St, Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill, the rector, and the Rev. Franklin E. Vilas Jr. of Trinity Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Minister's Lectures on Family Life and Youth Draw Thousands
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 13 Church people have been packing auditoriums In a number of cities to listen to one man give 32 hours of lectures in six days on youth conflicts and principles of family life.

title: Wally Muller's a Boys Cut Up Cake and Old Touches
description: From all over the country they came, many of them sparse of hair and paunch of stomach, peering at lapel nametags and passing on or exploding into slaps of recognition.

title: Fumbles Hurt Mich. State
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 13. (UPI)Dave Brown returned a punt 53 yards for a touchdown, Gil Chapman went round end for a 53yard touchdown and Dennis Franklin, an injured quarterback, surprised everybody by throwing passes on a rainy day today to give fourthrated Michigan a 310 victory over crossstate rival Michigan State, which fumbled the ball nine times.

title: Chile
description: At a heavily guarded ceremony marking the first month of military rule in Chile, junta leader Gen, Augusto Pinochet Ugarte last week reiterated the new Government's aim. It is to achieve the social peace necessary Mr:progress and economic development.

title: Friday Night Roundup: Erving Paces Nets to 116105 Victory Over Squires
description: BASKETBALL

title: S.R. Johnson to Wed Saundra Ferriera
description: BELMAR, N. J., Oct. 13Miss Saundra Y. Ferriera and Stephen R. Johnson plan to be married Dec. 23 in Belmar, where Mrs. Reginald Ferriera, mother of the bridetobe, has announced the engagement. The future bridegroom is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Ross Johnson of St. Albans, Queens.

title: Financing the Boom in Farming
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.Farmers across the country are mobilizing the resources they need to expand production and meet the swelling worldwide demand for agricultural products.

title: Art Museum At Princeton Expanding Its Vistas
description: PRINCETONThe Princeton University Art Museum is starting off the 197374 academic year with a new director, a new chairman of the school's Department of Art and Archeology and, last but not least, a new president of the small, but increasingly active, operation known as the Friends of the Art Museum.

title: EUROPEAN CITIES STUDIED BY PANEL
description: Members of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City have returned from a threeweek factfinding trip to Europe with sheets of notes, a suitcase full of taped interviews, and some firmer convictions about how to go about restructuring the city's government.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A study of the earthquake situation in California. Fried describes the 1971 earthquake in the Los Angeles area, then delves deeper into the causes of earthquakes in general, how they are measured and so on. He details the planning  or rather lack of it  in California calculated to deal with future earthquakes and gives the impression that Californians are not worried. There is an interesting chapter on the psychological reactions to the last earthquake  marriages broke up; people fell into deep depressions; subconscious guilt surfaced. A good survey that should be on every bedside table in California.

title: Irvington Wins, 210, as Jones and Defense Excel
description: Undefeated Irvington breezed to a surprisingly easy 210 victory over Byram Hills yesterday as Ken Jones scored three touchdowns and rushed for 110 yards. But it was the defensive unit, too, which rose to the ocacsion and helped Irvington to its seventh straight victory. Joe Pais was in on 13 tackles and Luke Sears had a hand in nine. Sears picked up a fumble in the second quarter and ran 30 yards to set up the first Irvington score, a 12 yard run by Jones.

title: Battle of Trees Renewed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sal Palermo and their neighbors who live in the English Tudor homes on 68th Avenue in Forest Hills, have been battling for more than two years to save the trees on their street, but they are not sure whether they are winning or losing.

title: 9 MEDALS OF HONOR TO BE GIVEN BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) President Nixon will present Medals of Honor on Monday to nine men cited for conspicuous gallantry in Vietnam at the risk of their lives.

title: Aw, Shucks, Do We Finally Have a Hit Series Here?
description: WHEN James Stewart first came stammering across a television screen, only a season or so ago, he was playingplaying at, reallya college professor getting into cute situations with his TVbright family. Shown without a canned laugh track, the series was heavy with warm integrity. Unfortunately, it was even heavier with banality and boredom.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Arlen Development Company has signed a joint venture with Ronald J. Parr to develop the major shopping center and regional mall at the 1,700acre Parr Village complex in Brookhaven, L. I.

title: The Region
description: While the New York metropolitan region is little more than an aggregation of diverse and independent communities, stretching across three states, it offers a strikingly uniform tableau in at least one dimensionthis year's elections which, while predominantly local, share significantly common ground.

title: Orchestra Aims at Professionalism
description: From community chorus to orchestra for the community that is the road being taken by the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra.

title: Milian Bewails His Error, Saying Ball Didn't Hop
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 13Occasionally, the goat of a World Series game will hide in the privacy of the trainer's room when the newsmen arrive in the clubhouse. But with the dignity and style that symbolize his reputation as one of baseball's best fielding second baserinen, Felix Milian of the New York Mets faced his inquisition today.

title: It Will Not Down
description: BOSTON, Oct. 14For more than a year now, from the first smell of the Watergate coverup through the decline and fall of Spiro Agnew, a question has haunted the politics of this country: Is there any way to restore the faith of Americans, their belief in their leaders and themselves, while Richard Nixon remains President?

title: Wingate Prep Disrupted By Building Renovations
description: When the students at Wingate Prep in Brooklyn returned to their minischool this fall, they anticipated a freshly renovated building in which to continue their rather unusual education.

title: Dr. Jeffrey Kessler Marries Miss Lauren Jane Goldberg
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Oct. 14The Community Syncgogue was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lauren Jane Goldberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldberg, to Dr. Jeffrey T. Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving K. Kessler of Moorestown, N. J. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg Performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary Index MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1973
description: Egyptian communiqus said yesterday that Egyptian forces had destroyed 150 Israeli tanks and shot down at least 44 Israeli aircraft in an allday offensive along the Sinai front. The communiqus claitned that large areas of the desert had been occupied. The offensive came after a threeday lull in the fighting during which large amounts of men and equipment were moved across the Suez Canal. [Page 1, Cols. 68.]

title: The Theater: A Modem Master Builder
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14In The Master Builder, which last night opened the season at the Long Wharf Theater, Henrik Ibsen confronts an aging artist, a former rebel who has settled into a life of apparent success that only barely conceals inward anguish and defeat. Halyard Solness a builder, but a man clearly patterned after the author in his later years, is barren of new ideas and fearful of the assumption of powerhis powerby youth.

title: Other War Developments
description: In Washington, high American officials and wellplaced diplomats said neither the Israelis nor the Arabs showed any interest in a ceasefire. Thus Washington has coneludedthat no solution of the crisis will be possible until the fighting stops. On Capitol Hill, a political battle seemed to be forming over President Nixon's Middle East policy. [Pages 16 and 21.]

title: TV and Radio to Carry Agnew Speech Tonight
description: Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's address to the nation tonight, his, first public appearance since he resigned as a result of federal taxevasion charges, will be attired live over at least two of the thre major television and radio networks.

title: NATO AIDE CAUTIONS ARABS ON HALT IN OIL
description: BOHN, Oct. 14 (UPI)Joseph M. A. H. Luns, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was quoted today as saying that halting by the Arab countries of oil shipments to the West would come close to being hostile act.

title: Dear Mr. Agnew:
description: How could a man who made courage a household word lose his? How could one of this decade's shrewdest leaders make a dumb mistake such as you did in quitting and accepting a criminal conviction? If you had stood your ground as you promised the public you would, I give you my opinion that your chances for legal and political survival were excellent.

title: City Eligible for $900.2Million in Construction Loans
description: New York City will be able to borrow $900.2million for new public construction next year, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: Nixon to Meet With African
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) President Nixon has arranged to meet tomorrow with President Sangoule Lamizana of Upper Volta to discuss the effects of the severe drought in West Africa, the White House said today.

title: A '68 Lunch Spawned Gift From Hughes to Nixon
description: In the summer of 1968 three men met for lunch in a Washington restaurant. That meeting set in motion a gift of $100,000 in cash from Howard R. Hughes to Richard M. Nixon.

title: Women's 2Year Project Gives Town a Services Guide
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, Oct. 14Anyone who doubts that volunteers can be effective should take a look at a 61page booklet entitled. Survey of Services, and subtitled Health Services, Financial Aid, Consumer Assistance, Legal Services for Residents of Madison Township.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECT PRIMERATE CUT
description: Short  term money  market rates continued to ease last week, leading some observers to expect one of the major moneycenter commercial banks would reduce its prime lending rate from 10 per cent.

title: McGraw Not Too Tired to Bunt
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 14 In the 12th inning of today's tempestuous World Series game, Tug McGraw was tired. But he didn't know it.

title: Reporters' Notebook: Some Israelis Commute to War
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 14At a dusty, sun  blasted Israeli base somewhere in the Sinai, as the press officers described it, the commander of the southern front, Maj. Gen. Shmuel Gonen, informed a delegation of a hundred reporters yesterday that they couldn't see the Suez front where Egyptian forces drove the Israelis east from the canal last weekend.

title: Mets Get 4 Runs in 12th to Beat A's, 107, and Even Series at 11
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 14 In the longest and maybe the loosest game in the 70year history of the World Series, the New York Mets scored four runs in the 12th inning today to defeat the Oakland A's, 107, and tie the Series at one game apiece.

title: Donna Parsekian Bride
description: CRESSKILL, N. J., Oct. 14 Miss Donna Lynn Parsekian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ned J.
