title: 47% in Gallup Poll Back Israel; No Opinion Total High at 25%
description: Fortyseven per cent of Americans responding to a Gallup Poll survey on attitudes toward the Middle East hostilities supported Israel, while 6 per cent backed the Arabs and 22 per cent backed neither side. The rest, 25 per cent, expressed no opinion, according to results released yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Guidce GOING OUT

title: Lilly Files Patent Suit
description: Eli Lilly & Co. announced yesterday that it had filed suit in the Federal District Court in Detroit against the BASF Wyandotte Corporation and its West German parent company, charging the companies with violating Lilly's United States patent covering the use of Treflan and related herbicides. BASF Wyandotte said that its herbicide, known as Basalin, did not infringe any patent.

title: La Boheme Given With Little Vitality At the City Opera
description: The performance of La Bohme put on by the New York City Opera on Sunday night was noteworthy for being the first of the season, but not for much else. Some of the ingredients of idiomatic Puccini were present, but flaccid conducting by Giuseppe Morelli and an unpersuasive Rodolfo by Herman Malamood continually hobbled the performance.

title: Trial in Deaths of 8 Women
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 15 (UPI)Edmund Kemper 3d, 24 years old, went on trial today in the slayings of his mother and seven other women in the Santa Cruz area during a yearlong period.

title: GAS PRICE RISES APPROVED AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The Cost of Living Council, in a twopart concession to gasoline retailers, authorized a new round of price increases today and said that starting Nov. 1 it would let the retailers raise their pump prices any time their wholesale cost of gasoline went up.

title: War Passes Through a Town in Syria
description: KHADAR, Syria, Oct. 15The war came to this village of ancient stone houses last Thursday, killing four villagers, wounding five or six and driving out the Syrian Army.

title: Grand Jury Substitute Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania, introduced today a proposed Constitutional amendment that would eliminate the Federal grand jury system. The proposal would permit the Attorney General or a United States attorney to file a complaint of criminal action instead of asking for an indictment from a jury.

title: Egypt This Time: Dignity Is Replacing Humiliation
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15In March of A.D. 624by the Western calendar  a group of 300 newly converted Moslems under the leadership of the Prophet Mohammed defeated an enemy group of nonconverted Arabs from Mecca at a place, in presentday Saudi Arabia called Badr.

title: Davis Joins Knicks for Game Tonight
description: The Knicks activated Mel Davis, their No. 1 draft choice from St. John's yesterday, and placed Dennis Bell on waivers. The move had nothing to do with New York's major problemputting points on the scoreboard. Davis worked out with the Knicks at Pace College for the first time yesterday, but is not yet ready to play any length of time.

title: PartTime WorkersMaking Inroads Into a FullTime World
description: The parttime job: Once it was the stepchild of industry, the housewife's panacea for boredom, the breadwinner's source of supplemental income. Now by virtue of a slow but steady revolution, the permanent (but less than 35houraweek) position is beginning to achieve the status of Career.

title: A Tendency To Ignore the Law
description: One of the few Nixon Administration officials unstained by the Watergate and related scandals recalled recently that he had frequently noticed and feared a tendency in the HeidemanEhrlichman White House toward ignoring or breaking the law. He cited the following episode, which happened well before the June, 1971, breakin at the Democratic National Committee.

title: A SAUDI THREAT ON OIL REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Saudi Arabian Oil Minister was reported today to have told Western oil executives that if the United States overtly undertook to resupply Israel's fighting crudeoil production by 10 ing forces, Saudi Arabia would per cent at once and by 5 per cent a month thereafter.

title: A British Deserter Is Sentenced For Killing 4 Catholics in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  A British Army deserter who joined the Protestant paramilitary Ulster Defense Association was sentenced to life imprisonment today for four murders and 11 armed robberies.

title: PLEDGE BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15The Soviet Union pledged tonight to assist in every way the Arab effort to recapture territory seized by Israel in 1967 and charged that Western foes of improved SovietAmerican relations were trying to use the ArabIsraeli conflict to sow mistrust between the two great powers.

title: Meany Hints Teamster Accord With Chavez May Be Near End
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 15 (AP) George Meany indicated today that the tentative peace agreement with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for settling the California farm worker dispute might be falling apart.

title: Puerto Rican Voting Aid
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) The city has agreed to provide translators and ballots printed in Spanish for Puerto Rican residents voting in the Nov. 6 general election.

title: Monteath Dayton, 76, Importer Of Rare and Exotic Woods, Dies
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 15  Monteath Thornton Dayton, board chairman of the J. H. Monteath Company of the Bronx, importer of rare and exotic woods and dealers in domestic woods, died yesterday in South Nassau Community Hospital, Oceanside. He was 76 years old and lived here.

title: 12 Million Virgin Forest Acres Due for Protective Study
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Twelve million acres of virgin national forest will be protected from timber and mining companies while the lands are studied for possible inclusion in the national wilderness preservation system, the Forest Service announced today.

title: Dr. Daniele Petrucci, Kept Test Tube Embryo Alive
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Oct. 15 (UPI)  Prof. Daniele Petrucci, who made medical history in 1961 by keeping a testtube embryo alive outside the human body for nearly one month, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 51 years old.

title: Coast Guard Investigates Slaying of Black Seaman
description: CAPE MAY, Oct. 15One seaman from North Carolina was shot to death and another seriously wounded on the dance floor of the enlisted men's club at the Coast Guard training center here Saturday night.

title: U.S. Accuses Major Landlord of Bias
description: The Department of Justice, chargin discrimination against blacks in apartment rentals, brought suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday against the Trump Management Corporation, a major owner and manager of real estate here.

title: Wood, C. B. S.TV Head, Defends Mature Shows
description: Robert D. Wood, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network, defended the presentation of controversial entertainment programing in a speech prepared for delivery to the Better Business Bureau in Nashville this afternoon. Mr. Wood said the mature subject matter of certain programs that some viewers have found objectionble grows out of a C.B.S. commitment to participate in the present and to raise television from the escapist, lowestcommondenominator mentality that had earned the medium the reputation vast wasteland.

title: CharterBus Aid Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) Private operators of charter buses would be protected from competition by Governmentaided city transit systems under terms of a bill passed by the House today. The bill requires recipients of Federal grants for urban transit to agree they will not engage in unfair or destructive competition with private operators of forhire buses.

title: Piton, Fernandez Win
description: Undefeated Oscar Piton of Argentina, weighing 139, won a unanimous 104round decision from Bennie Huartes, 140, of Puerto Rico last night at the Felt Forum. Chris Fernandez, 141, Dominican Republic, decisioned Saoul Mamby, 138, of New York in another 10rounder.

title: Israel Reports Remnants Of Iraqi Unit Out of Action
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15  The Israeli command said today that its forces had taken out of action the remnants of an Iraqi division sent to Syria to help combat the Israeli push from the Golan heights toward Damascus.

title: C130 Cargo Plane Crashes Into Mountain in Arkansas
description: FORT SMITH, Ark, Oct. 15 (AP)A C130 cargo plane, flying a training mission with a crew of seven out of the Little Rock Air Force Base, crashed and burned on Sugar Loaf Mountain, 20 miles south of here tonight the Air Force said.

title: Charleston Group Wins Battle To Save a 19thCentury Block
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 15 The Save Charleston Foundation announced today that it had won a battle to prevent the demolition of a block of 19thcentury buildings here that had been planned as the site of a midrise condominium.

title: Italy Bandits Get $299,000
description: NAPLES, Italy, Oct. 15 (AP) Four masked bandits armed with submachine guns and pistols held up a bank van on highway on the outskirts of Naples today and made off with $299,200, the police reported.

title: U.S. FORGOES TRIAL OF WEATHERMEN
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15The Government decided to drop a major case against 15 Weathermen radicals here rather than undergo a searching court hearing on how it had obtained its evidence.

title: Upper Volta Chief Gets Nixon's Promise of Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)President Nixon met for 40 minutes today with Piesident Sangoul Lamizana of Upper Volta and promised continued United States assistance to droughtstricken areas of Central Africa.

title: Fischer to Retire as Head Of Teachers College by '75
description: John H. Fischer, president of Columbia University's Teachers College since 1962, has announced that he will retire no later than 1975, and before then if a successor is named.

title: High School Sports
description: New Utrecht and Lafayette are the leading contenders for the title in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn Division I. But an ineligible player may cause the Utes forfeit their tie game with Lafayette and lose a chance for the division football crown.

title: SANDMAN ENTERS DISPUTE IN BERGEN
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, Oct. 15This threesquaremile bedroom community in Bergen County today became a symbol of home rule in the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign.

title: PLEDGE BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15The Soviet Union pledged tonight to assist in every way the Arab effort to recapture territory seized by Israel in 1967 and charged that Western foes of improved SovietAmerican relations were trying to use the ArabIsraeli conflict to sow mistrust between the two great powers.

title: DALEY CHALLENGED FOR MAYOR IN 1975
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15William S. Singer, the independent Democratic alderman who organized the unseating of Mayor Richard J. Daley and his regular party delegates at last year's national Democratic covention announced today that he would run against the Mayor in the 1975 Democratic primary.

title: The War's Duration Could Hinge on Battle in the Sinai
description: The great trial of strength between the Israelis and Egyptians in the Sinai Peninsula is regarded by United States and other military sources as a key to the war's duration and scope.

title: High Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Among the actions taken by the Supreme Court today were the following:

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDING

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number, yesterday was:

title: Integrity of Kennedy Doubted By 43% in Harris Survey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  A plurality of Americans polled do not trust the integrity of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, the Louis Harris Survey reported today.

title: Paper Outlook Tied to Economy
description: United States papermaking capacity is expected to increase by 4.8 million tons to about 70 million tons a year by 1976, but whether the additional supply will meet demand will depend on the rest of the economy.

title: Steel Output Slips 0.3%
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 13 totaled 2,882,000 tons, a decline of 0.3 per cent from the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index slipped to 118.1 from 118.5 a week earlier.

title: Stengel, 83, Gets to Series Here, but A's Mule, 14, Is Unable to Make the Trip
description: Once almost an annual festival here, the World Series returns to New York tonight for the first time in four years, and for the first time after dark. Not a fly ball too soon.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon yesterday nominated Russell W. Peterson, former Governer of Delaware, to be chairman of the Council on Enrivonmental Quality, at a salary of $42,500 a year. The nomination is subject to Senate confirmation. Mr. Peterson, who was Governor from 1969 to 1973, will succeed Russell E. Train as head of the agency created in 1969 to develop national policies to improve the environment. Mr. Train now heads the Environmental Protection Agency, which can enforce policies in the field.

title: Douglas Says Johnson Told Him. His Own Telephone Was Tapped
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court declared in an opinion today that he had once been told by Lyndon B. Johnson that the late President's telephone had been tapped, and Mr. Douglas voiced his own belief that the conference room of this Court has been bugged.

title: Major Landlord Accused Of Antiblack Bias in City
description: The Department of Justice, charging discrimination against blacks in apartment rentals, brought suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday against the Trump Management Corporation, a major owner and manager of real estate here.

title: GOVERNOR APPOINTS 3 FISCAL ADVISERS
description: ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP)Governor Rockefeller has appointed three members to the State Council of Economic Advisers  the chief ecnomist for I.B.M., a finance professor and an economic research executive.

title: VOLKSWAGEN RAISES PRICES FOR PORSCHE
description: Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased prices on its 1974 model Porsche sports cars by an average of 17 per cent. The increases range from $630 to $1,600 a car.

title: Israel Reports Remnants Of Iraqi Unit Out of Action
description: TEL AVIV, Oct, 15  The Israeli command said today that its forces had taken out of action the remnants of an Iraqi division sent to Syria to help combat the Israeli push from the Golan heights toward Damascus:

title: 17 Seized in Betting Raids
description: ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP) The police arrested 17 persons on gambling charges over the weekend in simultaneous raids in Fulton, Schenectady, Saratoga and. Albany counties. The defendants were accused of bookmaking, taking sports bets and running a numbers game.

title: Pitcairn Islander Dies
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 15 (UPI)  Theodore Young, a fifthgeneration descendant of one of the H.M.S. Bounty mutineers, died Friday on Pitcairn Island, it was reported today. He was 85 years old.

title: Assessment of Giants' Breakdown Shows Lack of Balance, Confidence, Preparation
description: What's wrong with the New York Giants? How could a team that looked so sweet in a perfect preseason turn so sour during the regular season?

title: Students Gain Control in Thai Uprising
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 15 Tens of thousands of students and other civilians overwhelmed the last police forces in Bangkok today, leaving the Thai capital under almost complete control of the insurgents.

title: New Foreign Cars Are Scarce Despite Cost
Penn Central Acts To Avert Stoppage Over Rail Defects
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, with onefifth of its 38,000 miles of track considered unsafe, averted what it called a catastrophic stoppage of all its trains today by implementing immediate emergency measures.

title: Group Presses for Ecological Study of New Center
description: A coalition of environmentalists accused the Convention Center Corporation yesterday of delaying the start of a required environmental statement for the proposed West Side convention center.

title: After the Agnew Resignation
description: To the Editor: The only shock concerning the resignation of Vice President Agnew is that he is not in jail.

title: STOCKS TUMBLE ON PROFIT TAKING
description: The stock market tumbled yesterday from its lofty heights amid profit taking and some nervous selling touched off by both domestic and foreign developments.

title: The Mayor and a Chorus of Kin Honor Beverly Sills
description: When she was seven years old, Beverly Sills sat on Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia's knee. That was just after she had sung an Italian aria for his honor.

title: Elfish Warns Subways Impair Hearing
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administrator, Herbert Elfish, warned yesterday that the subways were so noisy that anyone taking a 20minute ride suffered impairment of hearing for 40 minutes afterward and that anyone who used the subways for 25 to 30 years suffered permanent impairment of hearing.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Sharp, downthelimit price declines marked wheat, corn and soybean trading yesterday, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Students Gain Control in Thai Uprising
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Oct. 16  Hundreds of thousands of Thai students and other demonstrators supported by; the King completed the ouster of the military Government last night when Thailand's former leaders left for exile abroad. The ripttorn streets of Bangkok began returning to normal almost immediately.

title: Bar Group Backing 6Man Jury Option In Civil Court Cases
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15 (AP) The State Bar Association supported today a proposal for six member juries for Civil Court cases, but not as an absolute substitute for the traditional 12member juries.

title: Mets Prep are Maximum Security for Tonight
description: In a mixed scene of glitter and maximum security, New York's first World Series in four years will move into Shea Stadium tonight with the Mets and Oakland A's deadlocked at one game apiece.

title: Ohio U.F.O.'s Stir Skepticism
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP)Astronomy exeperts and Air Force officials said today they were not taking seriously reports of unidentified flying objects in central Ohio over three counties had said earlier that they were investigating reports o fa huge amber light that was said to have hovered over sseveral areas and to have landed, broken fences and killed a cow.

title: New Foreign Cars Are Scarce Despite Cost
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15  For the distributors and dealers of foreign cars, the big problem is not their rising prices but their scarcity. Even so, they expect sales of the 1974 models to be higher than this year's totals.

title: Bridge: Adventurous Player Leaps To 6 Spades, and Succeeds
description: The proposition that rubberbridge luck evens up in the long run is misleading at best. Its chief value is for winners attempting to console losers and persuade them to return for another beating on another occasion.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: $700,000 Collection Of Art to Be Given To Swedish Museum
description: A $700,000 collection of paintings and sculptures by New York artists who came to prominence in the nineteensixties will be presented to Stockholm's Moderna Museet, the Swedish National Museum of Modern Art, by a group of American and Swedish arts patrons.

title: Kheel Renews Appeal to Voters To Back Transportation Bonds
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator and masstransit advocate, opened a new appeal to the voters yesterday for passage of Governor Rockefeller's proposed transportation bond issue, arguing that the alternative to the bond issue is stagnation.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD AT 2 LABOR PLANTS
description: KENORA, Ont. Oct. 15 (UPI) A tentative agreement has been reached between the Ontario Minnesota Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd. and 1,500employes whose three month strike has shut down two Ontario plants, the United Paperworkers International Union announced today.

title: Trudeau's Position Shaky As Parliament Reconvenes
description: OTTOWA, Oct. 15  The Canadian Parliament reconvened today, in an atmosphere of continued uncertainty about the future of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's minority Government.

title: ESPAGNOL DANCED BY JOFFREY TROUPE
description: Grand Pas espagnol has the sparkling necessities of a balletic bon bontunefully obvious music, three friendly couples and a modicum of wit slyly inserted by its creator, Benjamin Harkarvy. It is a tribute to 19thcentury Russian style and was performed with bright good humor Sunday afternoon by the City Center Joffrey Ballet, on a program that also included Kettentanz, Secret Places and Facade.

title: TRANSPORTS LAND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The United States announced today that it had begun resupplying Israel with military equipment to prevent what it termed a massive airlift to Egypt and Syria by the Soviet Union from upsetting the military balance in the Middle East.

title: Power Authority Challenged
description: ATHENS, N. Y., Oct. 15 (AP) Four Greene County residents, in a brief filed in State Supreme Court in Albany, have challenged the New York State Power Authority's use of private property without compensation for owners. The authority has been conducting feasibility studies on their properties for a proposed nuclear power plant site.

title: Navy Is Urged to Lower Enlistee Physical Standard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Navy could fill its recruiting quotas and increase the intelligence at its forces by relaxing physical standards intead of mental standards, representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said yesterday.

title: Broadbent Joining Gimbels In 2 Top Executive Posts
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., has announced that Robert R. Broadbent will join the Gimbel New York division as chairman and chief executive officer, confirming a report recently carried in The New York Times. Mr. Broadbent will be part of a new divisional management team with Paul Salomon, who continues as president.

title: Deputy School Chancellor Bars An AllAmerican Ethnic Role
description: Asserting that he was here not to become part of an allAmerican ?? team, but to do a job, Dr. Bernard R. Gifford, the city school system's new Deputy Chancellor, said yesterday that he would try to improve business operations so that the educators would be free to concentrate on improving the education of children.

title: Mets Prepare Maximum Security for Tonight
description: In a mixed scene of glitter and maximum security, New York's first World Series in four years will move into Shea Stadium tonight with the Mets and Oakland A's deadlocked at one game apiece.

title: Wounded Israelis Say Egypt Treats Them Well
description: CAIRO, Oct 15 (AP)Gideon Goldmann, a 22yearold Israeli infantryman, was in the last month of a threeyear army hitch when a bullet hit his foot on the second day of the Middle East war.

title: Telephone Poll Gives Rime a 3to1 Margin
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic mayoral candidate, is running ahead of his closest opponent by a margin of nearly 3 to 1, according to a telephone poll for WCBSTV.

title: FED VOTED IN JULY FOR TIGHT MONEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee voted at its July 17 meeting to continue its relatively tight monetary policy, the minutes of the meeting, released today, showed.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Campbell Wed To Stephen Wilson in Vermont
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Oct. 15 Mrs. Elizabeth de Cravioto Campbell, widow of Orland Campbell, the portrait painter and art research scholar, of Point O'View, Manchester, and New York, was married at her home here this afternoon to Stephen A. Wilson of Oaky Farm Plantation, Springfield, Ga., a widower and retired vice president and general counsel of Oakite Products, Inc. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jerome J. Hevey of the Congregational Church.

title: Ticonderoga Ending Career
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 15  The aircraft carrier Ticonderoga ends a 28year military career tomorrow. After a decommissioning ceremony Nov. 16, the Navy expects to sell her for scrap.

title: Agnew Says He Quit to Aid Nixon in Restoring Trust
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Spiro T. Agnew declared tonight that he had resigned the VicePresidency solely to permit President Nixon to restore unimpaired confidence and implicit trust in that high office.

title: Russians Allow Western Psychiatrists to See Two Mental Hospitals
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15  Soviet authorities permitted Western psychiatrists to visit two Soviet mental institutions today in an effort to rebut charges that dissenters were being improperly held there.

title: U.S. Sets Up Jersey Unit to Curb Frauds in Ads and Mail Orders
description: NEWARK, Oct. 15 (AP)Reacting to a flood of complaints about fraudulent advertising and mailorder cheats, the United State's Attorney's office today announced the formation of a special Consumer Protection Unit to bring criminal and civil cases against consumer fraud.

title: The Mayor and a Chorus of Kin Honor Beverly Sills
description: When she was seven years old, Beverly Sills sat on Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia's knee. That was just after she had sung an Italian aria for his honor.

title: News Summery and Index
description: International

title: St. Louis Man Held for Jury In Industrial Espionage Case
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)  A St. Louis man was held for Federal grand jury today on charges that he allegedly tried to sell trade secrets of a major chemical company to another concern.

title: PANTHER HELD UNFIT AS NEW LONDON AIDE
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 15 (AP)  The city manager here has said that a former Black Panther, Lonnie McLucas, is not a desirable volunter youth counselor in the city's Youth Servce Bureau.

title: EDMUND CHESTER, 75, EXDIRECTORAT C.B.S.
description: MOUNT DORA, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP)Edmund Chester, a former news executive with The Assocated Press and the Columbia Broadcasting System, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: Coast Guard Studies Shooting of 2 Blacks By a Fellow Seaman
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., Oct. 15One seaman from North Carolina was shot to death and another seriously wounded on the dance floor of the enlisted men's club at the Coast Guard training center here Saturday night.

title: DIVIDEND IS RAISED BY CHESSIE SYSTEM
description: Chessie System, Inc., the holding company that owns the Chesapeake & OhioBaltimore & Ohio Railroad system, yesterday increased its dividend for the fourth quarter to 90 cents a share, from the recent regular rate of 75 cents.

title: Suffolk Seeks to Acquire and Preserve 30,000 Acres, Half of Its Farmland
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 15 Suffolk County plans to own or control more than half of the 58,000 acres of farmland on eastern Long Island within the next decade, according to a detailed proposal for a farmlandacquisition program presented today by the County Executive.

title: Music: Slovak Ensemble
description: The Slovak Chamber Orchestra, a youthful and vivacious group of 12 musicians, showed in its New York debut at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon that it can stand up to the world's better ensembles of its type and give little, if any, quarter. The orchestra, founded by Bohdan Warchal in 1960, is an offshoot of the Slovak Philharmonic.

title: Chile Orders Expulsion Of 4 Foreign Newsmen
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 15Chilean authorities ordered the expulsion of four foreign newsmen today and questionedtwo others in what appears to be general tightening of controls over the news.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Homosexual CivilRights Group Is Announced by ExCity Aide
description: Two weeks after he publicly disclosed that he is a homosexual, Dr. Howard J. Brown, a former city Health Services Administrator, announced yesterday the formation of a new national civilrights organization for homosexual men and women.

title: Trading Surge Ends Deficit Operation
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest investment houses, said yesterday it earned a slight profit in the quarter ended Sept. 30, primarily because of an upturn in the last month.

title: Pitchers for 3d Game
description: Tom Seaver, known as Tom Terrific, is usually referred to by professional baseball people in all seriousness as the best pitcher around today. An earlier generation would have tagged him Jack Armstrong, AllAmerican Boy, or Frank Merriwell. For consistent excellence over his seven major league seasons, the righthanded 28yearold Californian has a record no one else can match: 135 victories with only 76 defeats, with an earnedrun average never higher than 2.92 for any season, over 200 strikeouts in all but his first season. He is a power pitchersuper fastball, excellent curvewith outstanding control, who has averaged fewer than two walks and more than six strikeouts a game. This season, finishing with a 1910 record (and a 2.08 earnedran average with 251 strikeouts), he suffered from a tender shoulder during September, which trimmed his velocity a bit. But in the playoffs against Cincinnati, he lost, 21, and won the deciding game, 72. In the 1969 World Series, he split two decisions, losing 41, and winning, 2.1, in 10 innings. He is also an outstanding hitter for a pitcher.

title: State Honors Mrs. Hewitt
description: Jean Hewitt, a food reporter for The New York Times and restaurant reviewer for the paper's New Jersey editions, has been named Food Cornmunicator of the Year by the New Jersey Department of Agriculture on behalf of the state's agricultural, industry. A citation was presented to Mrs. Hewitt by the New Jersey assistant secretary of agriculture, William E. Kenny, at a dinner at the Seaview Country Club, Absecon, last Thursday.

title: A. E.C. Steps Up Protection of the Ingredients of Nuclear Bombs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The Atomic Energy Commission, which last week ordered its guards to shoot to kill or injure anyone tampering with its military weapons, announced today that it was taking protective steps on the civilian side of nuclear energy as well.

title: HANS O. HOFMANN
description: Hans O. Hofmann, an artist and former member of the board of directors of the Artists Equity Association died Sunday at New York Hospital. He was in his late 70's and lived at 233 West 20th Street.

title: Mediation Session Fails to End Musicians' Strike
description: A negotiating session yesterday failed to resolve the threeweek strike by union musicians against the New York Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Congress Votes to Replace 1923 Hospital at West Pint
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Oct. 15 (AP) The mouse of Representatives has approved and sent to the President authorization for the construction of a $25million hospital at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: BRITISH UNIT BUYS WESTERN REALTY
description: Capital and Counties Property Company, Ltd., of Britain, announced yesterday it had purchased a 62 per cent interest in Western Realty Projects, Ltd., of Vancouver, British Columbia, for just under $48miIlion.

title: Book Fair Wordier Than Ever
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 15The German book dealers assembled for the big book fair here ironically awarded their peace prize to the socalled Club of Rome, an international think tank that, among other things, commissioned the report on The Limits of Growth.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Records for the cost of roast beef and chicken dinners were set here during August, the regional Bureau of Labor, Statistics reported yesterday, $8 and $6.23, respectively, for a family of four. This followed increases of 38 cents and $1, respectively, over July.

title: Chicago's First Ward Has a Ball, But It Wasn't a '90's Bacchanal
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15Neither Bathhouse John Coughlin nor Hinky Dink Kenna would have thought of it as a lalapalooza, as Hinky Dink once described the First Ward ball while the Decency League types were sputtering indignation, calling it a saturnal orgy, a vile, dissolute affair and a bawdy Dionysian festival.

title: Sales Set a Record
description: Record sales and earnings were announced yesterday by the Xerox Corporation for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: Egypt, Responding to Diplomats, Outlines Some of Her Conditions for a CeaseFire
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15Egypt has told Western European countries in response to inquiries that she will accept a ceasefire in the present fighting only if she obtains ironclad guarantees that Israel will withdraw behind the lines existing before the 1967 war.

title: War Passes Through a Syrian Village
description: KHADAR, Syria, Oct. 15The war came to this village of ancient stone houses last Thursday, killing four villagers, wounding five or six and driving out the Syrian Army.

title: 2,000 Marines to Go To Bolster Sixth Fleet
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Oct. 16 (Reuters)The United States today will send a force of about 2,000 marines to bolster the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean as a result of the Middle East crisis, a Defense Department spokesman said.

title: BONDS FOR STADIUM MAY NEED STATE AID
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15 (AP)An influential member of the New Jersey Senate said today he was prepared to vote for a pledge of the state's credit behind bonds for the new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Democratic Leaders Speak Softly to Deprive Bearne's Rivals of Bossism Issue
description: The Democratic bossesoften a major issue in mayoral campaigns  are keeping a low profile in the current fracas.

title: BUCKLEY SCORES AGNEW POSITION
description: Leaders of the state Conservative partywho cheered speech by Spiro T. Agnew at their annual dinner a year ago, watched the televised explanation of his nodefense plea to tax evasion last night in silence.

title: Icelandic Leader And Heath Concur In Fishing Dispute
description: LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) Premier Olafur Johannesson of Iceland and Prime Minister Heath of Britain agreed today to work toward an interim agreement in the 14month fishing dispute between their two countries, a British spokesman said, The decision came in talks that opened between the two leaders at 10 Downing Street.

title: TV: N.B.C.'s Brash Tomorrow Aims to Provoke
description: For years, though it may seem like centuries, the National Broadcasting Company has been attempting to inform TV watchers with Today and to tickle them with Tonight. In terms of network revenues, the shows have been successful. Now, evidently, N.B.C. will attempt to provoke with Tomorrow, a new hourlong talk show featuring Tom Snyder as host.

title: How Safe Is the City? Statistics Can Mislead
description: In comparison with the 25 largest cities in the United States, New York City ranks 12th in homicide, 2d in robbery, 17th in rape and 23d in larceny, according to the most recent reported crime statistics compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Csonka Helps Dolphins Win, 179
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (UPI) Larry Csonka scored a pair of touchdowns on 2yard runs tonight to lead the Miami Dolphins to a 179 victory over the Cleveland Browns. The Dolphins moved into a firstplace tie with Buffalo in the American Football Conference Eastern Division.

title: Pitchers for 4th Game
description: JON MATLACK is probably the most highly re spected young lefthanded pitcher in the National, League. Last year he was rookie of the year; this year, after having suffered a skull fracture and lost several lowscore games the first half of the season, he was New York's most effective pitcher during the drive from last place to first. He is 23 years old, from West Chester, Pa. With only a 1416 wonlost record, he shut out the Reds in the playoff, then lost the first Series 21.

title: Youth Charged in Shooting
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (UPI) A 16yearold youth has been charged with armed robbery and aggravated assault in the shooting of the Atlanta Constititution's sports editor, Jesse Outlar. Mr. Outlar, who was shot in the abdomen and robbed of his briefcase as he left Atlanta Stadium, is reported in satisfactory condition at a local hospital. The police did not identify the youth.

title: Sketches of Winners
description: Born 50 years ago in Furth, Germany. . . . Escaped Hitler's attack on Jews by fleeing to London in 1938 with his parents . . . moved to the United States to an apartment in the Fort George area of Upper Manhattan . . . enrolled in George Washington High School where he maintained an A average in night classes after working all day in a shaving brush factory . . . Began studies at City College to be an accountant but was drafted in 1943 . . . emerged as sergeant from Army counterintelligence corps. . . . Entered Harvard . . . received a bachelor's degree summa cum laude in 1950 . . . won four scholarships and two more Harvard degrees. . . . First book entitled Nuclear Weapons and Foreign Policy, an outgrowth of work with Council on Foreign Relations studying threat of Soviet action. . . . Began long association with Governor Rockefeller in 1957 as director of Rockefeller Brothers Fund's special studies project . . . was his adviser as he vied with Richard Nixon for the Republican nomination in 1968. . . . Met Mr. Nixon at a party at home of Clare Boothe Luce. . . . Mr Nixon said he knew Mr. Kissinger for it long time through his writings, especially 1957 book on nuclear weapons. . . . Rose quickly in stature as the President's foreign policy adviser. . . . Named Secretary of State in August. . . . Known as brisk and demanding teacher at Harvard from which he took a leave of absence to serve in Nixon Administration . . . graying and spectacled, stands 5 feet 9 inches tall and retains a trace of Germanic accent. . . divorced, has two children.

title: Atlanta Elects a Black Mayor, But Hosea Williams Is Deleated
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16A black man was elected today as Mayor of Atlanta, the commercial and cultural center of the Old Confederacy that only a decade ago was quarreling over the admission of a handful of black children into the public schools.

description: BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP)A threeyear study by a Boston University sociologist, James E. Teele, indicates that black children bused to predominantly white schools here showed significant improvement in reading scores.

title: Screen: 'Paper Chase':Adaptation of Osborn Novel Is at Columbia I The Cast
description: It's usually possible to tell whether a film is any good or not within the first 15 minutes, certainly within the first half-hour. "The Paper Chase," directed by James Bridges and adapted by him from John Jay Osborn Jr.'s novel, is different. It takes longer, almost the entire film."The Paper Chase," which opened yesterday at the Columbia I Theater, doesn't go wrong exactly. It goes slowly soft like a waxwork on a hot day, losing the shape and substance that at the beginning have rightfully engaged our attention.The film is about the trials and triumphs of a bright young Harvard Law School student named Hart (Timothy Bottoms) during his first year of combat in Cambridge. Hart is from the Middle West (University of Minnesota), and finds himself initially intimidated and then challenged by the history and traditions of the Ivy League fortress.Hart is a very appealing, very rare sort of fellow to find in an American film these days. He's actually interested in learning, not just for the material rewards that may follow, but for the power of the intellect to impose order on the chaos that most of us muddle through. Hart's hero is Professor Kingsfield, a brilliant, irascible old professor of contract law, marvelously well played by the theatrical and film producer-director-writer John Houseman.On the first day of classes, Kingsfield haughtily informs the students that they've come to him with their heads full of mush and that he intends to train their minds. It isn't many movies that even acknowledge the existence of a mind, much less take it seriously.Kingsfield has what is, in effect, a contract with his students, an agreement to turn them into first-class lawyers in return for their dedication to learning. He pushes them, bullies them, ridicules them, "Fill this classroom with your intelteligence," he tells Hart, who gets sick to his stomach. He treats the students as if they were abstractions. There's no sentiment in his discipline.So far so good. But then the movie itself shows symptoms of the kind of sentimentality you know people like Kingsfield (and probably Hart, too) would have no patience with. Hart begins an affair with Susan (Lindsay Wagner) a pretty, independent girl who turns out to be Kingsfield's daughter and a rather inconsistent fictional character.Susan, the estranged wife of an earlier law school student, a drop-out with whom she's been bumming around Europe, spends most of her time scolding Hart for his obsessive scholasticism, though she has earlier told Hart she was fed up with her rootless, disorganized life with her husband.At this point "The Paper Chase" gets stickier and stickier. Even Hart's awe of the law, at first so refreshing, becomes soppy. You begin to suspect him to be the sort who weeps at the sight of books, but never reads them.There's a dreadful subplot involving a boy who isn't going to pass (remember the kid who used to get washed-out of flight training school in Air Force movies of the thirties and forties?) and a romantic soundtrack score, toned up from time to time with snatches of Bach, that makes the score for "Love Story" sound like Mozart.It takes a long while for "The Paper Chase" to disintegrate, and there are some funny, intelligent sequences along the way, but by the end it has melted into a blob of clichs.

title: Ozu's 'Late Autumn' Like a Day in the Sun:The Cast
description: "I'm happy as I am": you might not think that a radical sentence, but it's the challenge hurled in Yasujiro Ozu's marvelous "Late Autumn" by a young woman who's just cheerfully announcing that she's not ready for marriage. Her seniors respond with shocked determination and commit themselves to selecting a husband at once.The situation that sets so many feelings aboil is ironically simple. A recently dead man's male friends are worried about the future of his widow (whom they all mooned over when young) and her daughter. The well-meaning meddlers become disruptive intruders as they try to make matches for the daughter, then for the mother. Meanwhile, both women cling to the quite blameless freedoms that they've been enjoying on their own."Late Autumn," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker, was made in 1960. (Ozu died in 1963.) Hence the struggles between the generations pre-date the clashes of the late nineteen-sixties. However, Ozu's extraordinary sensitivity makes them deeply dramatic, all the more so because these gentle, reflective persons seem to have led unruffled lives.The young woman at first appears submissive; then rebels against the notion of an arranged marriage to a stranger. But later she seems more traditional and old-fashioned than her elders, when she violently protests against a rumored remarriage for her mother. She insists that it would be "filthy" and "disgusting," because it would dishonor her father's memory.This is a creature caught between the past and the present. Her modern self rejects the conception of marriage as a mere exercise in forebearance. She also devastates older listeners when she remarks that love and marriage don't always go together. Yet, when facing the fact that her mother might embrace a new life, she's horribly upset by the rift with old conventions.Despite the headshakes of parents deploring their, disobedient children, plus their admission that the newest generation has nothing in common with themselves when young, Ozu also shows that the children's approval is terribly important to the adults. Moreover, the offspring are acutely possessive of their parentsa startling concept for an American audience.The theme of Westernization is subtle throughout. Of course, there are bottles of Johnny Walker and infinite plaid fabrics, inevitable motor bikes and T-shifts. But there are also telling moments when young women in collegiate clothes alternate between the tiny, floating steps conditioned by wearing kimonos and striding freely in their high heels and Western skirts. Again, you sense that Ozu was studying a generation in transitionthose who were often torn between traditions and the powerful instinct that it was time to overturn them. And the older generation's efforts to sculpture the young only clench the latter's resistance to the models offered to them.Since Ozu concentrates so much on the interior consciousness, "Late Autumn" is closer to fiction than to film. As usual, Ozu uses a fairly stationary camera, which rests on the faces of those who are talking.Love is hardly mentioned when the subject of marriage arises. But enormous affection between parents and children, and among old friends, is revealed as it rarely is on screen: often, it's shown through the small jokes that intimates make at one another's expense.Finally, the daughter marries. The mother, asserting that she "can't start all over again from scratch," eludes the pressures from her well-wishers, and smiles at the solitude ahead of her. Beautifully acted throughout, especially by Setsuko Hara as the mother, and Yoko Tsukasa as the daughter, "Late Autumn" stresses that people can't forcibly control the lives of others, not even in the name of fond intentions.
