title: Missiles Blunt Thrust of Traditional TankPlane Team
description: The Middle East war is unlikely to produce new Pattons or Rommels, in the view of military authorities, because surfacetoair missiles have blunted the thrust of the tankandfighterbomber team that since 1940 has dominated offensive tactics.

title: Maoism Seen From Its Cradle
description: YENAN, China  Maoism holds a position in contemporary China which is the equivalent of both political doctrine and ideology, almost a religion. The new party constitution specifically defines MarxismLeninismMao Tsetung thought as the theoretical basis guiding its thinking. A plenum agreed: Mao Tsetungs thought should be taken as the guide for action.

title: Opposition in Britain Says Arms Cutoff Hurts Israel
description: LONDON, Oct. 16  Harold Wilson, the leader of the Labor party Opposition, urged today that the British Government lift its embargo on arms sales in the Middle East, arguing that it operated against Israel.

title: Retired Publisher Honored
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)Joe W. Seacrest, retired copublisher of The Lincoln (Neb.) Journal, received Monday the 1973 Minnesota Award for Distinguished Service in Journalism. The University of Minnesota School of Journalism has offered the award since 1947.

title: Coyote Traps Softened
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (UPI)  The jaws of steel traps, being planted across sheepgrazing areas during the fall lambing season, are lined with foam rubber, the County Agriculture Department said today. The idea is not only to catch the coyotes that stockmen say destroy the lambs but also to protect from serious harm the other animals that get trapped. The department gave the project the name Operation Tender Trap.

title: Black Africa Split Over Stand Toward Israel and Arab Nations
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 15 The independent subSahara nations have condemned Israel for not giving up lands captured during the sixday war in 1967.

title: Most of Truce Terms Still to Be Carried Out
description: PARIS, Oct. 16The Nobel Prize Committee, announcing its peace award to Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho to day, stressed the moral responsibility of all involved to see that the ceasefire negotiated by the American and the North Vietnamese will lead to a lasting peace for the warstricken peoples of Indochina.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 2 YOUTHS HUNTED IN HOLDUP KILLING
description: With only scanty clues, the police searched yesterday for two teenagers who were seen fleeing following the fatal shooting late Monday of a father of four in front of his Brooklyn home.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Public Reaction to Agnew Talk Is Found to Be Mostly Negative
description: Greg Icard of Buffalo who is unemployed, summed up public reaction to Spiro T. Agnew's speech Monday night. I didn't believe a word, Mr. Icard said. If he wasn't guilty, why did he resign?

title: Knicks Subdue Braves
description: The Knicks defeated Buffalo last night, 11791, at Madison Square Garden and gave Ernie DiGregorio, the Braves' highpriced rookie, a lesson in defense he never learned at Providence College.

title: ICELAND REACHES ACCORD IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP)The leaders of Britain and Iceland agreed today to settle the dispute over fishing rights in Iceland's fishing zone, British officials said. The agreement is conditional on the approval of the two governments.

title: New Cabinet Named As Bangkok Quiets
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 16  The new Premier today named a largely civilian Cabinet as Bangkok returned to seminormality in the wake of bloody student protests that felled the military Government of Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn.

title: Conflict Over Soviet Ties Widens in Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Current relations between the United States and the Soviet Union became an issue of apparent controversy within the Administration today.

title: Tainted Prosecution
description: Yet another Federal prosecution against domestic dissident groups has been allowed to collapse, rather than risk a judicial probe into the methods by which Government investigators built their evidence.

title: Brown Tops Changes in Ivy Form
description: For most of the previous 17 seasons of roundrobin play in the Ivy League, Harvard, Princeton, Yale and Dartmouth regarded the league as their own private hunting preserve.

title: Marchi Boycotts Police Ceremonies
description: State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday boycotted the police parade and the dedication ceremonies for the new Police Head quarters, near City Hall, calling them public relations gestures by Mayor Lindsay.

title: BUILDERS SEEKING AID ON MORTGAGES
description: CHERRY HILL, Oct. 16 (UPI) A group representing home builders and related industries called today for changes in lending laws to release addition funds to the tight mortgage market.

title: School Board in Kalamazoo To Appeal on Segregation
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 16 (AP)The Kalamazoo school board voted yesterday to appeal a Grand Rapids Federal court decision charging the schools with segregation.

title: TV's Minority Employment on Rise, Survey Shows
description: The television industry, usually under attack by publicinterest groups received praises yesterday from the Office of Communication of the United Church of Christ for making impressive forward strides in the hiring of blacks, Spanishsurnamed American and other ethnic minorities.

title: Rally Speakers Say Israeli Stand Is Like Fight on Civil Rights
description: Five hundred people at a unionsponsored rally for Israel in Astor Place yesterday heard speakers liken Israel's wartime struggle to the civil rights movement of minorities in the United States.

title: Senate Passes Compromise On the School Lunch Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) A compromise bill increasing, the Federal contribution to school lunches was approved by the Senate today.

title: PRICES IRREGULAR FOR COMMODITIES
description: The intensifying crisis in the Middle East moved what brokers call world commodities sharply higher in price yesterday. In the group were cocoa, sugar, silver and copperall items that move in world trade and are widely imported by many nations.

title: Reading, Pa., Businesses Hit as Fires Follow Blasts
description: READING, Pa., Oct. 16. (AP) A factory outlet shoe store and a van belonging to another store were burned in separate fires today that city officials said were ignited by Molotov cocktails.

title: Bishop Urges 4 in Race To End Manhattanopia
description: The Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn, has called on the four mayoral candidates to pay attention to the needs of Brooklyn and Queens, not just Manhattan.

title: BYRNE AIDE BARS A PATH FARE RISE
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 16 A Spokesman for Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, sharply. citicized today warnings by two New Jersey commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that proposed rail extensions to Kennedy and Newark Airports deended on a 20cent fare increase on the PATH transHudon tube system.

title: Hunt to Use Issue Pivotal for Ellsberg
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 16 Improper Government conduct, the issue that destroyed the Government's case against Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, will be raised by E. Howard Hunt Jr. in efforts to win a new trial.

title: Mr. Agnew's Farewell
description: There would be greater pathos in the fate of Spiro Agnew if his had been a fall from grace rather than from arrogance. Many Americans, after witnessing the incongruous White House festivities in celebration of the nomination of Mr. Agnew's successor, might have found it possible to sympathize with any forthright statement by the former Vice President.

title: Israeli Press Curb Illustrates Problems in Coverage of War
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel, Oct. 16  military authorities today barred newsmen from the Sinai Peninsula, where a major battle of the war remains to be fought.

title: EVICTION DISPUTE NOW ETHICS ISSUE
description: A top official of the citys Economic Development Administration, which played a leading role in the controversial expansion of a papermachine manufacturing company in the Northside section of Brooklyn, has resigned to join the company as a top executive.

title: THOMAS LAURITSEN, NUCLEAR PHYSICIST
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 16 (AP)Dr. Thomas Lauritsen, a nuclear physicist and professor at California Institute of Technology, died today in Huntington Memorial Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: Muted Soviet Reaction
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16 Despite the outcry in influential circles in the United States that the new. Soyiet  American relationship is rapidly becoming the major casualty of the Middle East war, Moscow is taking calm, stoical view.

title: The Cost of Putting Footprints in Sands of Time
description: Aside from the tax laws, the most powerful stimulus to philanthropy in this country is the long established custom of naming things for big givers.

title: Parade and Moments of Nostalgia Mark Dedication of City Police Headquarters
description: In a daylong display of civic pride, the city dedicated its police headquarters yesterday and paid tribute to its police officers.

title: MUSEUMS TO TALK ABOUT ART SALES
description: At the invitation of the state Attorney General, some 40 local and upstate museums are expected to take part Friday in a conference that grew out of one controversy and will, a number of museum officials predict, stir up a hectic one on its own.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLUBBY Last December, with much clat and hoarse hofannahs, a new nightclub, Reno Sweeney, opened for business at 126 West 13th Street (2421366). In a world where success often threatens disappointment, it is pleasant to report that Reno Sweeney lives up to its advance billing, one of the nicer places to go out for an evening that fall's between starchy uptown formal and Village descamisado.

title: Islanders and Kings Play 44 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 16 As the last second ticked away tonight, Brian Spencer of the Islanders was hauled down illegally by the Los Angeles Kings' Gilles Marotte as the New Yorker streaked goalward.

title: A UTILITY AGREES ON JOB EQUALITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company had agreed to hire and upgrade women and minorities in all of its managerial, physical and technical jobs.

title: State's Chancellor of Higher Education Sees Sharp Fall in College Enrollment
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16 (AP) The Chancellor of Higher Education, Ralph A. Dungan, predicted today that there would be a sharp decline in New Jersey college enrollment.

title: H.E.W. Appoints Official
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) John D. Young of the Office of Management and Budget was appointed today assistant secretarycontroller for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. He succeeds James B. Cardwell, who will be sworn in Oct. 24 as Commissioner of the Social Security Administration.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Dip as New Issues Appear
description: Corporate bond prices eased yesterday in moderate trading as credit markets began digesting several large new financings.

title: TRIAL OPENS HERE FOR MACKELL AIDE
description: Joseph N. Monty, the former chief rackets investigator in the Queens District Attorney's office, went on trial in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday on charges of using his position to extort cash and the free use of cars from the Avis RentACar System.

title: People in Sports: Mrs. Court Ill
description: Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia, suffering from a stomach inflammation, withdrew yesterday from the $11.0,000 Virginia Slims championship tennis tournament in Boca Raton, Fla. Mrs. Court, 31 years old, was admitted to Boca Raton Community Hospital with a condition diagnosed as viral gastroenteritis. She was reported uncomfortable, but in satisfactory condition.

title: Angered Grote Stearns Quietly
description: Silently, his eyes flashing, Jerry Grote hurried through the runway from the New York Mets' dugout to the clubhouse. The catcher, whose passed ball positioned the Oakland A's winning run in their 32 victory last night, walked quickly to his locker. Without a word, he began to take off his uniform.

title: Gene Krupa, Revolutionary Drummer, Dies
description: Gene Krupa, who changed the drummer in jazz bands from a timekeeper to a soloist through his flamboyant performances in Benny Goodman's orchestra in the nineteenthirties, died yesterday at his home in Yonkers. He was 64 years old.

title: OTTO E. STURM
description: Otto E. Sturm, a news features editor for the United Press International, died Monday at Flushing Hospital of heart attack. His age was 67 and he lived at 14935 29th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: YOUTH JOBLESSNESS HIT FOURYEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) A record number of youths had jobs last summer and the youth unemployment rate was at its lowest level in four years, the Labor Department says.

title: SHOP TALK
description: They've finally raised blue jeans to the level of art. Who has? Serendipity 3.

title: Timetable on Namath Revised: Return by Nov. 11 Seen Possible
description: The progess report on the Jets two injured quarterbacks, Joe Namath and Al Woodall, has been good this week, but the team will still have to depend on Bill Demory, backed up by Tim Van Gelder, to run the offense in the game Sunday in Pittsburgh against the Steelers.

title: Private Hospitals Reportedly Charging Patients Too Much for Use of Phones
description: An inquiry being conducted by the State Attorney General's office has found that private hospitals are overcharging patients hundreds of thousands of dollars a year in excess telephone fees.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Charles H. Percy gave the press a generous pat on the back yesterday, saying it had been vindicated by Watergate.

title: JORDAN IS FACING FOOD SHORTAGES
description: AINALPASHA, Jordan, Oct. 16Freighters carrying food and other supplies to the Jordanian port of Aqaba have reportedly been diverted to Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to avoid Israeli air strikes.

title: Israel Sends a Task Force Behind the Egyptian Lines
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 16  Israel announced today that a task force had crossed to the west bank of the Suez Canal to attack Egyptian artillery, missile sites and tanks.

title: Agreement on Compromise on Alaska Pipeline Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) Final agreement on a compromise bill to clear the way for construction of the transAlaska oil pipeline was delayed today when House and Senate negotiators decided to reconsider a key provision.

title: Environmental Defense Group Suing Federal Agency to Prevent the Use of Irrigation Water for Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Environmental Defense Fund charged today that the Federal Bureau of Reclamation had been planning to sell to coalrelated industries water that had been earmarked by Congress for irrigation.

title: PREMIER IS FIRM
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 16Premier Golda Meir told a special session of Israel's Parliament today that the war would end when we have succeeded in beating the enemy.

title: Once Upon a Time There Was a Little Glympf
Body of Lynford Lardner Jr., Golf Leader, Found in River
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 16 (AP)The body of Lynford Lardne Jr., 58 years old, president of the United States Golf Association and a director of the Western Golf Association, was pulled from the Milwaukee River today.

title: Soviet Said to Stress Interest in Permanent Peace
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16The Soviet leaders were reported today to have emphasized in private talks with Premier Anker Jorgensen of Denmark their keen interest in finding a permanent settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: WAR ATROCITIES CITED AT HEARING
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16G.I. euphemisms for instruments of destruction used in Vietnam filled a courtroom here today as a halfdozen young former servicemen testified about incidents in which Vietnamese civilians were abused or killed by Americans.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Wider Role for Auditors Is Urged by S.E.C. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (Reuters)  Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that accountants should take more responsibility for corporate financial information.

title: Penn Central Granted U.S. Stay On Freight Track Safety Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) The Federal Railroad Administration told the Penn Central Railroad today that it would not have to meet Federal track safety standards for freight operations immediately but refused a request to exempt passenger operations also.

title: MARKETS ABROAD ARE CALM ON WAR
description: PARIS, Oct. 16The reaction of Europe's financial markets to the fourth ArabIsraeli war has been surprisingly calm so far.

title: Ethics Issue Raised In Evictions by City
description: A top official of the city's Economic Development Administration, which played a leading role in the controversial expansion of a papermachine manufacturing company in the Northside section of Brooklyn, has resigned to join the company as a top executive.

title: Bridge:
description: International observers ??ere impressed last May ??ith the fine performance of the young and talented Brazilian team in Guaruja, Brazil. They challenged strongly for a place in the playoff final, but had to be content with third position in the roundrobin qualifying stage, behind Italy and the Aces.

title: Ashe and Borg Toppled In Spanish Net Upsets
description: MADRID, Oct. 16 (Reuters) Arthur Ashe of the United States and 17yearold Bjorn Borg of Swedn were upset today in the second round of the Spanish International Tennis Tournament.

title: Three Placed on Probation For ExpenseAccount Plot
description: A former employe of The New York Times was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation and ordered to pay back $7,500 to the paper by Justice Gerald P. Culkin in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: PARLEY PROPOSED
description: CAIRO, Oct. 16  President Anwar elSadat called today for a ceasefire in the Middle East war coupled with an immediate Israeli withdrawal from territories seized in 1967. He proposed that the truce be followed by an international peace conference at the United Nations.

title: 2 Negotiators With Mutual Respect
description: PARIS, Oct. 16The Nobel Prize Committee today called the two diplomatic opponents who shared the prize negotiators with talents and will that could remove distrust and create the necessary mutual respect for obtaining an agreement.

title: Ethics Issue Raised In Evictions by City
description: A top official of the city's Economic Development Administration, which played a leading role in the controversial expansion of a papermachine manufacturing company in the Northside section of Brooklyn, has resigned to join the company as a top executive.

title: Chase Manhattan Reports 18% Rise In Operating Net
Justices Assail Nadjari's Remarks
description: A committee of State Supreme Court justices yesterday denounced Maurice H. Nadjari, the anticorruption prosecutor, for having made what the justices termed intemperate statements that besmirch the general reputation of the courts without specifics.

title: Pros Trying More Field Goals
description: In Monday night's game, in which Miami defeated Cleveland, 179, how many field goals were attempted and made and how many touchdowns were scored? The answers are seven, four and two. They tell a person somefiling. Fewer touchdowns are being scored in the National Football League this season. More field goals are being attempted and with greater success. Usually the field goal is about as exciting as a foul ball, except one in overtime of a playoff game or one blocked in a Super Bowl after which the kicker attempts a forward pass. The touchdown is the essence of pro football, a business.

title: Sheltering Arms
description: One of New York's venerable organizations observes its 150th anniversary today. When the New York Asylum for LyingIn Women was founded in 1823, the city's population was not quite 150,000, and it was acutely perilous to be both poor and Regnant. Across the years this service merged and developed and changed with the needs of the eight million. Today, as the Sheltering Arms Childress Service, this multifunction, interracial agency is still caring for disadvantaged youngsters. Through projects in Harlem, daycare centers, clinical centers mid adoption services, Sheltering Arms is reaching into the pockets of poverty and despair and providing a chance that would otherwise be nonexistent for deprived children in the neighborhoods of New York.

title: Minority Labor Government Assumes Office in Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 16 (UPI)The Labor party leader, Trygve M. Bratteli, and his minority Government took office today after a brief ceremony at the royal palace.

title: Coast Hikers Find 4 Bodies Believed Kidnapping Victims
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 16 (UPI)The bodies of four persons presumed kidnapped froom a home were found by hikers this afternoon in the Lost Lake area of the San Bernardino Mountains. Two suspects were in custody.

title: BIDS
description: NEW YORK CITY TRANSIT AUTHORITY CONTRACT T81 TRACKS AND CONTRACT RAIL FOR ROUTE 131ASECTION 1, EAST 63rd STREET, EAST RIVER AND 41st AVENUE, F.D.R. DRIVE TO VERNON BOULEVARD, BOROUGHS OF MANHATTAN AND QUEENS

title: Scores Obtainable By Dialing 9991313
description: Sportsphone will provide scores of the World Series games on telephone number 9991313. They will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: MRS. BERNARD WOLFMAN
description: Mrs. Zelda Wolfman, who was active in political and social causes, died yesterday of cancer at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 45 years old.

title: Bishop Urges 4 in Race To End Manhattanopia
description: The Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn, has called on the four mayoral candidates to pay attention to the needs of Brooklyn and Queens, not just Manhkttan.

title: SCHOOLS TO FOCUS ON REFURBISHING
description: In a sharp change of policy, the Board of Education announced yesterday that it planned to concentrate more on rehabilitating old schools than on building new ones, and that it was undertaking a review of construction projects carried over from previous budgets to see if they were still needed.

title: Saigon's Vice President III
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 16 (UPI)Vice President Tran Van Huang of South Vietnam has been hospitalized in serious condition, Government sources sai dtoday. Mr. Huang, who is 70 years old, was elected Vice President in 1972. He previously served as Premier twice.

title: Strange Radio Pulses Reported by Moscow
description: Amid reports from at least six American states that unidentified flying objecs had been seen and even been visited, Moscow reported last night the detection of radio signals that may have originated with another civilization.

title: Quakers Ask a CeaseFire And Arms Cutoff in Mideast
description: American and Canadian Quaker groups called yesterday for a ceasefire in the Middle East and a halt to the delivery of military suplies to both Israel and the Arab nations.

title: Nixon Flies to Camp David; Returns to Capital Today
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Oct. 16 (UPI)  President Nixon unexpectedly flew to his Camp David retreat in the Maryland mountains today for an overnight stay with his family.

title: JOHN BRICK, WROTE HISTORICAL NOVELS
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 16, John Brick, historical novelist who wrote 17 books and served as vice president of the Author's Guild, died yesterday of an aneurysm at the George Washington Hospital in Washington. He was 51 years old and lived here.

title: Bodies of 7 Air Force Men Found in Arkansas Crash
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 16 (UPI)Air Force rescue, teams, searching through rough, brushy terrain, recovered early today seven bodies from the burnedout hulk of a C130 cargo transport that crashed into a fogenshrouded peak last night.

title: OTB Still Spells Trouble at Trots
description: Between offtrack betting and offtrack investigations, Roosevelt Raceway had what the railbirds call a rough trip during its summer meet that ended last night.

title: A's Wives Irked by LongRange Seats
description: While most fans in the sellout World Series crowd at Shea Stadium remained calm last nightunlike the behavior of many fans during last week's playoffsone group of visitors from Oakland seethed and exploded. But they didn't throw bottles and cans, only incensed words and mean looks.

title: Bugging Suspicions Of Douglas Rebutted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI)The chief of the Supreme Court's security guard said today that years of checking have never turned up a breach of security in the Court building.

title: Rhodes of Arizona Is Leading Race for Post of Minority Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Representative John J. Rhodes, a conservative Republican from Arizona, emerged with what appeared to be a commanding lead today to succeed Gerald R. Ford, the Vice Presidentdesignate, as the House minority leader.

title: An Albany Toiler With Style
description: Governor Rockefeller lost a lawyer and gained a commissioner yesterday as he named Howard Shapiro, a 34yearold toiler in the Governor's counsel's office, to be chairman of the State Commission of Investigation.

title: A Second Culture Bus to Loop Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan
description: A culture loop bus serving Brooklyn and lower Manhattan will be instituted by the Transit Authority on Saturday morning, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Megaro Heads Newark Council Frank G. Megaro, a North Ward Councilman in Newark, was elected president of that city's City Council yesterday, replacing Louis M. Turco, who stepped down after pleading guilty to Federal income tax charges. Mr. Megaro, a Democrat, was elected by a vote of 7 to 2.

title: COMPUTER DEAL BEING DISCUSSED
description: National Computer Rental, Ltd., a unit of the Flying Tiger Corporation, announced yesterday it was negotiating to acquire the financially troubled Boothe Computer Corporation.

title: Buffalo Judgeship Off Ballot
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 16 (UPI) The Appellate Division yesterday upheld a decision by Supreme Court Justice Roger T. Cook keeping Buffalo's newly created 13th city court judgeship off the ballot in November. However, the city received permission to go to the Court of Appeals and Corporation Counsel Anthony. Manguso said he would ask the high court before Thursday to overturn the decision.

title: Nobel War Prize
description: Into the ranks of visionaries from Woodrow Wilson to Ralph Bunche, Albert Schweitzer and Dag Hammarskjold, Norway's Nobel Committee has chosen to admit two practicing diplomats of the present day whose mastery of the delicate arts of negotiation is unquestioned, but whose contributions to the cause of peace are much less clear.

title: U.S. Rushing 25 Phantom Jets to Israel Replacing Some Lost in Mideast War
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The United States is rushing about 25 F4 Phantom jets to Israel to replace some of the supersonic fighterbombers lost by the Israeli Air Force in the war, Administration officials said today.

title: Jobless Rate Rises in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 16 (UPDDespite a decline in the number of people seeking work, the unemployment rate in Canada rose from 5.5 per cent to 6 per cent in September, it was reported today.

title: Texas Plans Court Fight Over Pollution Controls
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 16The state of Texas will fight the Environmental Protection Agency in court over the agency's proposed antipollution controls on cars and buses in Texas cities.

title: FRED YOUNG DIES; EXSTATE JUDGE
description: ALBANY, Oct. 16Fred A. Young, former presiding judge of the State Court of Claims and regarded by his colleagues as the complete poiltician, died last night of cancer at the Albany Medical Center. He was 39 years old.

title: Atlanta Elects a Black Mayor, First in a Major Southern City
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16A black man was elected today as Mayor of Atlanta, the commercial and cultural center of the Old Confederacy that only a decade ago was quarreling over the admission of a handful of black children into the public schools.

title: Parasites in Ears Caused Beaching of Pilot Whales
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 16 (UPI) Officials said today that autopsies indicated that parasites in the inner ear caused about 35 pilot whales to beach themIselves near Harkers Island last (week.

title: HOUSE VOTE KEEPS CURB ON CRUDE OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The House defeated decisively tonight an attempt to exclude crude oil from a bill that would require a Federal supply allocation program for all petroleum supplies, from the well to the gasoline pump and the beating oil truck.

title: Doctor Immigration Is Termed Harmful In U.S. and Abroad
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP)Immigration of doctors to the United States must be stopped, a Harvard professor, Dr. Richard Warren, says.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: SANDMAN PLEDGES ASSAULT ON CRIME
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16Pledging to be the toughest law enforcement guy you ever saw, Charles W. Sandman Jr. brought his Republican gubernatorial campaign today to this city's important business community.

title: DOMESTIC HELPER SETS OFF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16A Congressional subcommittee is investigating the disclosure that Deputy Attorney General Wild Liam D. Ruckelshaus and his wife imported a young Finnish woman to help out in their household in apparent violation of immigration laws.

title: PARLEY PROPOSED
description: CAIRO, Oct. 16  President Anwar elSadat called today for a ceasefire in the Middle East war coupled with an immediate Israeli withdrawal from territories seized in 1967. He proposed that the truce be followed by an international peace conference at the United Nations.

title: LEFTIST PARTY WINS ELECTION IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 16 (UP1)The leftofcenter Republican People's party won its first national election in 23 years today, but failed to win a parliamentary majority.

title: EMIL PRAEGER, 81, ENGINEER, IS DEAF
description: Emil H. Praeger, a civil engineer and innovator of design concepts, died today at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 81 years old and lived at 104 Grosvenor Street in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Wedding Held Here For Mrs. McMahon
description: Mrs. Margaret Finlayson McMahon and James J. Loeb, both of New York, were married here yesterday evening in the Wollman Pavilion of Lenox Hill Hospital, where the bridegroom is recovering from an illness. Judge Millard L. Midonick of the Family Court performed the ceremony.

title: Full U.S. Services For Menominees Passed by House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) In what was described as a reversal of United States policy toward Indians, the House voted today to restore full Government services to the Menominee Tribe of Wisconsin.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For the fourth time since its creation, Israel is engaged in battle with the neighboring Arab world. It is a battle which is uneven in two respects.

title: Advertising: Investor Formats
description: The general upturn in the stock market over recent Months  a situation that could lead to the return of many small investors to the markethas not escaped the notice of those who publish, or would like to publish, magazines aimed at the little guy.

title: Fair Hearing Is Ordered For Man Seeking Parole
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16 (AP)United States District Court judge ruled yesterday that parole authorities must grant a fair hearing to a man who says he was denied an early parole because he was falsely branded a member of the Mafia.

title: Political Feud To Aid Charities
description: The Israeli Red Cross and other charities will benefit from one of the most heated political feuds in town  the continuing hassle between the Brooklyn Democratic and Republican leaders, Meade H. Esposito and George Clark Jr., respectively.

title: John Hemphill Jr. Dies at 32; A Times Editor in Washington
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16John W. Hemphill Jr., an assistant news editor in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, died early today at The Johns Hopkins University Hospital. He was 32 years old.

title: Japanese Composers Seeking a Style
description: TOKYOThe seven leading avantgarde Japanese composers who have banded together under the, name of transonic are looking for a style. Serialism, that international phenomenon of the postwar age, has failed them. Nationalism, they say, holds no hope. The old godsBoulez, Stockhausen and Cageare tired, and no new gods have appeared.

title: Byrne Has Big Margin, A Telephone Poll Finds
description: Brendan T, Byrne, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, is running ahead of his Republican opponent, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr,, by a nearly 2to1 margin, according to a telephone poll by WCBSTV.

title: Israel Sends a Task Force Behind the Egyptian Lines
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 16  Israel announced today that a task force had crossed to the west bank of the Suez Canal to attack Egyptian artillery, missile sites and tanks.

title: A's Defeat Mets, 32, in 11th And Take 21 Lead in Series
description: Baseball's 70th World Series moved into New York last night as the Mets and Oakland A's took over the stage of Shea Stadium for a 3hour struggle that the A's finally won, 32, in the 11th inning.

title: Sobel, 37, Is Appointed EmanuEl Senior Rabbi
description: Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel was named senior rabbi and spiritual leader of Temple EmanuEl yesterday. At the age of 37 he is the youngest rabbi in the history of the 128yearold temple, the world's largest Jewish Reform congregation.

title: PREMIER IS FIRM
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 16Premier Golda Meir told a special session of Israel's Parliament today that the war would end when we have succeeded in beating the enemy.

title: Forecasts Missing the Mark
description: The President's Council of Economic Advisers seriously underesttimated the total increase in the gross national product in 1973. They said it would grow to about $1,267billion from $1,152billion in 1972. The actual G.N.P. level this year is more likely to be about $1,285billion.

title: Mrs. Everett Is Padres' New Angel
description: The mysterious backer whose money may keep the San Diego Padres from moving to Washington is Mrs. Marjorie Lindheimer Everett, the largest stockholder in the Hollywood Park race track. If the club's 15year lease on San Diego Stadium can be restructured to her satisfaction and if the National League approves her, she will buy in as a major partner of C. Arnholt Smith, the present owner.

title: 4 Fishermen Are Rescued
description: BOSTON, Oct. 17 (AP)Four fishermen from Gloucester were rescued in good condition early today when their boat sank in the Atlantic 85 miles east of Chatham, the Coast Guard said. The men were taken from their sinking boat, the Sea Horse, by the East German fishing trawler Johannes Becker and later transferred to a Coast Guard cutter.

title: Lawyers for Miss Chesimard, Citing Jurors' Bias, Ask Mistrial
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 17  Lawyers for Joanne D. Chesimard, 26 years old, and Clark E. Squire, 36, yesterday moved for a mistrial in the triar involving the death of a New Jersey state trooper after the jury selection process revealed that there had been widespread discussion of the case and expressions of racial prejudice among the pool of prospective jurors.

title: Charles H. Dorsey Jr. Dies; ExEditor on Baltimore Sun
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (AP)Charles. H. Dorsey Jr., retired vice president of the A. S. Abell Company and former managing editor of The Baltimore Sun, died last night. He was 69 years old.

title: Film: Belmondo, a Bogart of His Own, in 'Inheritor':The Cast
description: How the French love usat least, a number of their movies say they do. New York has the glamour now, not Paris; indeed, the filming of the French capital in "The Inheritor," which opened last night at the 68th St. Playhouse and the UA Eastside Cinema, tries to make their city look as much like ours as possible. Glass buildings, clamorous demolition and construction, cranes, chrome reflected in chrome: it's our shiniest surfaces that beguile some Europeans.You no longer hear them accusing us of forcing the most commercial aspects of our culture on them. Instead, they reproduce the trappings eagerlyin the name of the vitality we're said to have.Along with exultant shots of administrators striding through a factory, there are enthusiastic references to "la technique Kennedy," and a Harvard degree is as flashy a product as the pocket calculators that the French tycoons brandish. Yet, one of the charms of this movie is that we can enjoy the borrowed slickness, because it has been romanticized by uncritical French eyes.No shabbiness here, no urban glut or rot, no apathy or fatigue; the American style projected by director Philippe Labro evokes a confident, glossy world of action where everything is new.This delightful thriller casts Jean-Paul Belmondo against type: as a businessman combatting the murderous intrigues of international financiers. (He's also supposed to have a radical concern for the rights of workers, but we can't believe thatsince this is a hymn to capitalism.)Belmondo at 40, buttoned into an executive suit? Yet he's the same headlong ruffian we first saw in "Breathless," and when he impatiently rips a Band-Aid off his bullet wound, the calculated incongruity of his role seems almost like a joke between him and the audience. And he still pulls down the corners of his mouth in the quick, disgusted smile that Bogart used.More than ever, we can see what he learned from (and loved in) Bogart's acting. But he's never been a mimic. Instead, a living talent has perpetuated certain qualities of a dead one, while continuing to flourish on his own.There's always that wide stripe of lunacy in Belmondo: the resilient clown prepared to be outrageous, ready to throw a stinkbomb or to provide pratfalls for others, and that trait has nothing to do with Bogart. But although we will see many apings of Belmondo, it's doubtful that anyone will catch the spark of Bogart preserved in him.Seduced by history, the director did make one slip: one of Belmondo's girlfriends (Maureen Kerwin) is made to imitate Lauren Bacall in "To Have and Have Not." But she can't even inhale like Bacall, let alone touch her performance.However, I'll forgive anything for one detail in this picture: at the graveyard where Belmondo's father is being buried, a sinister figure appears with one hand sunk in the pocket of his trench coat. Moviegoers over 4 know what that means: there's a gun that's about to shoot. Then the hand pulls out . . . a package of cigarettes. (Again, the French learned that from us. The apparent assassin is revealed to be an investigative reporter, who soon displays the heroism inseparable from his profession.This exuberant entertainment has a silly, sham-tragic ending. But until then it throbs with the energy and the rueful gaiety that Belmondo brings to almost any part, and that's worth even the cost of tickets these days.

title: Inquiry Sought on Transit Suppliers
description: The city has asked the Justice Department to investigate whether two major suppliers of the Transit Authority have engaged in collusive bidding practices since the early nineteensixties, a source in the Corporation Counsel's office said last night.

title: CHAIN FOOD PRICING CRITICIZED BY BUTZ
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Supermarkets have been fattening their profit margins instead of cutting beef and pork prices following recent drops in wholesale cattle and hog prices, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today.

title: Antibiotics Abuse Cited in 2 Journals
description: Misuse of antibiotic drugs has had a devastating effect on the ecology of hospital infections, caused Americans needlessly to suffer toxic reactions, led to misdiagnoses and aggravated the rising costs of health care, according to doctors writing in the current issues of two medical journals.

title: Atlanta's Next Mayor Maynard Holbrook Jackson

But Mr. Jackson, who yesterday becarne the first black Mayor of Atlanta, is such a physically imposing man at 6 feet 3 inches and 300 pounds that the analogy never rang true, particularly since his defeated opponent, Mayor Sam Massell, is 5 feet 6 inches and 150 pounds.

title: Prices of Stocks Decline; Dow Drops 4.89 to 962.52

When the impersonation fits the contours of the public personalitytough, driving, ambitious, shrewd, selfmockingthe performance can be effective as it was in Funny Girl, and as it is for a short spale of time in her new film, Sydney Pollack's The Way We Were. The movie opened yesterday at the Loews State and Tower East Theaters.

He said he had advised the President that there would be a serious, though probably unsuccessful, movement to impeach him if he refused to obey a Supreme Court order to produce the tapes.

It was the second game and the Mets Won it in 12 innings, but Jerry was removed in the third after having been clobbered for six hits and three runs. Over the season he compiled a 1415 wonlost record, but was 61 after midAugust in a fine finish. He had a 2.84 earnedrun average, and beat the Reds in his only playoff start. In the 1969 Series he was credited with two victories.
