title: Hoboken Is Rebuilding To Stem 20Year Exodus
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 17 It used to be that all of our customers lived in Hoboken, now more than 50 per cent of them live in the suburbs, Vincent Amato observed today.

title: Yes on Transport Bonds Urged by Citizens Union
description: The Citizens Union yesterday urged a yes vote on the transportation bond issue in the November election saying the whole state will benefit from the renewed economic strength likely to result from an improved transportation system.

title: MOSCOW INITIATIVE
description: CAIRO, Oct. 17The Soviet Union has begun highlevel efforts to persuade Syria and Egypt to use their military successes as a lever to bring about a settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict by diplomatic means, informed diplomats said here today.

title: An Underground Graffitist Pleads From Hospital: the Spraying
description: He is a 16yearold Columbia College freshman who as leader of a 50member group of graffiti painters led nighttime forays into subway tunnels to paint entire trains with ornate designs.

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, received yesterday an $18.6million contract from the Navy for oceanographic research.

title: SILVER FUTURES RETREAT IN PRICE
description: Hints of the possibility of a winding down of the Middle East war led to some selling in commodities like silver and copper.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The Miami Dolphins have been leading the National Football League this season in the number of noshows their home games, the purchasers of tickets who failed use them. The reason for such absences? It's been too hot in Florida for what has been regarded as a cold weather sport.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHODUNIT it's no mundane happenstance when you assemble in one room the keenest minds in, the crime business, from E. A. Poe to Ross Macdonald, by way of Edgar Wallace, Wilkie Collins, Anthony Trollope, Dashiell Hanriett, Gypsy Rose Lee (remember The GString Murders?), Agatha Christie and just about anyone else of note who ever dabbled in undercover, betweencover crime. This aggregation of literary crime perpetrators is represented by their work, not their persons, in the new exhibition in that citadel of book fanciers, the Grolier Society, 47 East 60th Street (TE 86690).

title: 3 CONERNS PLEAD GUILTY ON GIFTS TO 72 NIXON DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 17American Airlines, Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company pleaded guilty today to making illegal contributions to President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign.

title: Authorization for a Strike Backed by Top Guild Panel
description: John E. Deegan, executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild here, said yesterday that the union's executive committee had recommended that strike action against The Daily News and The New York Times be authorized by the Guild's Representative Assembly.

title: SOVIET SAID TO GET ORBIT VIEW OF WAR
description: The Soviet Union has orbited four reconnaissance satellites in less than two weeks, an unusual launching rate that is being interpreted in Washington as evidence of Soviet efforts to monitor the Middle East war almost continuously with cameras.

title: EUROPEAN PARLEY AVOIDING MIDEAST
description: GENEVA, Oct. 17  The Middle East war is casting a shadow over the 35nation security conference here, but representatives of East, West and the nonaligned say all sides are determined to carry on with sessions as usual as long as possible.

title: BYRNE RULES OUT POLITICS IN COURT
description: CRANFORD, Oct. 17Brendan T. Byrne urged the expansion of local auxiliary police forces today and called for the appointment of judges and prosecutors on a nonpartisan basis.

title: Market Place: Of S.I.P.C. System Of Reimbursing
description: This is the first of a series of three articles.

title: Series Standing, Figures
description: FOURTHGAME STATISTICS

title: A NEW COURT PLAN SOUGHT BY GARVEN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 17 (UPI)A conference of judges received a proposal from ailing Chief Justice Pierre P. Garven today for creation of criminal district courts that would deal with minor crimes.

title: Soviet Letter on Sakharov
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of an open letter from Mstislav V. Keldysh, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, to Philip Handler, president of the American National Academy of Sciences:

title: Storm Is Gaining Strength Off Jamaica's Western Tip
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 17 (UPI)A depression in the northwest Caribbean, with winds of 30 to 35 miles an hour, was strengthening rapidly late today, and the National Hurricane Center said it could turn into a hurricane.

title: FREIGHT STOPPAGE ANGERS OFFICIALS
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 17A day without freight trains on some of the secondary lines in Connecticut has left state officials angry and fearful of the effects that a longer shutdown would have on industry, jobs, road traffic and even cleanair standards.

title: Debt Ceiling Move Awaited
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Capitol Hill sources said today that they expected the Nixon Administration to ask Congress to increase the $465billion public debt ceiling to $480billion through June 30, 1974.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
50 Million Bushels of Oats Listed as Disaster Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Complying with a Congressional directive, the Agriculture Department designated today tO million bushels of Governmentowned oats as a disaster reserve to be sold at cut rates to farmers hit by droughts, floods or other emergencies.

title: Theater: David Storey's Contractor
description: It is five years since the Chelsea Theater Center took itself up from Manhattan to become the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn and eventually one of Americas leading theaters. Last night it came back to Manhattanwhere it has built a new long  term and handsome home in a discarded church on Ninth Avenue and 43d Street.

title: Mother of 4 Found Slain On Street in Woodhaven
description: A 39yearold Queens waitress, the mother of four children, was found murdered on the street yesterday morning in a quiet, residential area of Woodhaven, three blocks from her home.

title: Traffic Dip and High Expenses Limit Airlines' Net
description: Disappointing traffic results and sharply higher operating costs retricted earnings of both Trans World Airlines, the nation's second largest airline, and of American Airlines, the third largest, in the September quarter. But the period was a record one for Braniff Airways, the ninth largest in the industry, in part because of its sharply increased South American traffic.

title: MOSCOW INITIATIVE
description: CAIRO, Oct. 17The Soviet Union has begun highlevel efforts to persuade Syria and Egypt to use their military successes as a lever to bring about a settlement of the ArabIsrael conflict by diplomatic means, informed diplomats said here today.

title: U. S. to Lease New Offshore Wells in Gulf
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) The Department of Interior plans to permit the drilling of offshore oil wells along the coasts of Florida, Alabama and Mississippi to provide more energy sources.

title: CRISES THREATEN 2 S.I. HOSPITALS
description: Two of Staten Island's three nonprofit voluntary hospitals are in critical condition and say they may be forced to close.

title: People in Sports: Elder Has Masters Path
description: Lee Elder who will be among the Americans taking part in the. $51,800 Wills Masters that gets under way in Australia today, said he was competing on the Aussies' golf circuit in the hope it would enable him to become the first black to play in the. United States Masters tournament. If I win the Australian open next, week in Brisbane, he said, they'll have to invite me to play in the Masters.

title: City Aide Negotiated Job While Involved in Company's Northside Relocation Plans
description: Paul Levine, a former Economic Development Administration official, was negotiating a job with the S & S Corrugated Paper Machinery Company while he was involved in plans to relocate residents fighting the plant's expansion, it was revealed yesterday.

title: Biaggi Cool to Transport Bonds
description: Governor Rockefeller's $3.5billion transportation bond issue ran into more trouble yesterday as another New York City mayoral candidate expressed reservations about it.

title: Syrian Refugees of '67 Hopeful Of Returning to Golan Heights
description: SNEIBEH, Syria, Oct. 17 The peasant families at a refugee camp that was bombed last week while Syrian and Israeli lets battled in the sky are feelin hopeful about returning to their lands on the Golan heights from which they were driven in 1967.

title: 2D STOCK OFFER IS SET BY A.T. & T.
description: For the second time this year the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has announced plans to issue $500million of cumulative, nonconvertitle preferred shares.

title: Robber Finds Victim Is as Broke as He Is
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 17 (UPI)  A young robber changed his mind in the middle of a holdup.

title: Continental Illinois Corp. Posts 19% Rise in Operating Earnings
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, the banking concern that owns the largest bank between New York and San Francisco, reported yesterday that thirdquarter operating earnings increased 19 per cent.

title: REV. EDWIN NIES, MINISTER TO DEAF
description: The Rev. Edwin W. Nies, who became deaf as a child, was a dentist for 35 years and then was ordained to the Protestant Episcopal priesthood at the age of 60, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 70 Haven Avenue.

title: Randy Johnson to Rejoin Giants Today After 9Day Retirement
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17Randy Johnson will rejoin the New York Giants tomorrow afternoon, nine days after he announced his retirement from pro football.

title: A CONGRESS DELAY ON FORD EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17For Gerald R. Ford, the cheering has all but stopped, and the flood of congratulations has dwindled to little more than a trickle. Ahead lies perhaps the most sweeping investigation ever made of an American political figure.

title: Mets Even Series at 2All With a 61 Conquest of A's
description: Mike Andrews, the prodigal son of Oakland, returned to the fold last night to a standing ovation from 54,817 persons in wintry Shea Stadium and it was indisputably the social highlight of the 70th World Series.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: New Jersey Sports
description: If there would be a single high school football coach in New Jersey who could lay claim to the toughest job ahead in the second half of the season, Hackensack's Mike Miello might be the top candidate for the role.

title: Books of The Times
description: BALZAC. By V. S. Pritchett. 272 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $15.

title: Health Violations In 36 Food Places Charged by the City
description: The Health Department has made public the names of 36 more restaurants and food stores accused of having violated the city's Health Code after their owners had failed to correct infractions noted in two inspections.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Cawley Retirement Policy Upheld

title: Chief of Police in Dallas Quits Post
description: DALLAS, Oct. 17  Police Chief Frank Dyson resigned unexpectedly today amid controversy over hg handling of a riot in the central business district last summer.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1973

title: Gen. Gilbert Woodward Dies; Army's lnspectorGeneral, 56
description: LONDON, Oct. 17Maj. Gen. Gilbert H. Woodward, U.S.A., who represented the nation in delicate peace negotiations with Communists in North Korea and North Vietnam, died here today after having collapsed on flight from Washington to London. His age was 56.

title: SCIENTISTS BACK EXHAUST CONTROL
description: Experts on the effects of air pollution on human health are giving little support to pleas from the automobile and petroleum industries that controls on car exhaust be frozen at the levels achieved with 1974 models.

title: Staub's Hot Bat Makes the Pain Go Away
description: In his 11th major league season, skilled at age 29 after the frustration of apprenticeship in Houston and Montreal with two expansion teams, Rusty Staub emerged at a World Series hero last night in the New York Mets' 61 victory.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 1.25million shares of the Florida Power & Light Company common at $36.50 was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Merrill Lynch. The company's stock closed unchanged at $36.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COURT ASKED TO BAR PROJECT IN QUEENS
description: Thomas F. Galvin, the RepublicanConservative candidate for City Council President, asked the State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday to stop construction of the controversial lowincome housing project in Forest Hills until new bids were obtained.

title: Mets Turn Back A's, 61, And Tie Series at 2 Each
description: Despite all the clamor in the wings, the World Series continued in wintry Shea Stadium last night and the New York Mets cut through both the cold and the clubhouse gossip with three runs in the first inning and went on to defeat the Oakland A's, 61.

title: Hoboken in Midst of Rebuilding Boom to Stem 20Year Exodus
description: HOBOKEN N. J., Oct. 17 It used to be that all of our customers lived in Hoboken, now more than 50 per cent of them live in the suburbs, Vincent Amato observed today.

title: ISRAELI REJECTS SADAT PEACE BID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17Foreign Minister Abbe Eban of Israel today uncompromisingly rejected the Egyptian proposal for a ceasefire offered yesterday by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: The Oil Gambit
description: The Arabs have brought their oil weapon into play in the Mideast war, but cautiously and in a manner that leaves the way open for diplomatic cooperation.

title: DETROIT SCHOOLS WILL OPEN TODAY
description: DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP)Teachers in Detroit, the nation's fifth largest school district, returned to work today and all schools are to open tomorrow for the first time this fall.

title: Police Innovation Puts Cart Under Horse
description: That old cry of Get a horse! is producing a new kind of response from the Police Department, which has started trailering the nags to crimesaddled areas of the city for use by mounted police.

title: Equine Encephalitis Takes Girl's Life After Six Years
description: WEYMOUTH, Mass., Oct. 17 (AP)  Mary McNamara, 15 years old, of Braintree has died of equine encephalitis after a sixyear battle against the disease.

title: It Was a Disney PartyBut Where Were All the Children?
description: Betsy von Furstenberg kissed Donald Duck, Karen Stern waltzed with Flower the skunk and Dr. Robert Atkins, the diet doctor, refused to touch the rather fattening hors d'oeuvres.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TREND OF GROWTH IN NET CONTINUES
description: Earnings reports from several companies in the metals, chemicals and forestproducts industries yesterday tended to confirm the leadership of these three groups in thirdquarter gains.

title: A's Wives Get Field Seats
description: It was an honest mistake, insisted a harried Jim Hunt, the Oakland A's traveling secretary, as he tried to explain to the ballplayers yesterday why their wives had been seated in the uppermost tier at Shea Stadium Tuesday, night.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the most famous crewcuts in recent times is no more. H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, showed up at United States District Court in Washington yesterday with his hair grown out several inches longer than the closecropped style he wore for years.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 100 Scholars Warn Universities' Crisis Has Not Been Ended
description: VENICE, Oct. 17  More than 100 educators and scholars from the United States and 14 other countries warned in statement today against the illusion that the crisis of the universities had abated.

title: Drug Prevention Week Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  President Nixon today designated next week as Drug Abuse Prevention Week. The President said in his proclamation that antidrug efforts demonstrate that we can eliminate drug abuse as America's public enemy number one and that we are on the way to meeting that objective.

title: A Syrian Village Encounter Reflects Mideast's Plight
description: JABA, Syria, Oct. 17The Israeli Army overran this little Syrian village several days ago and, not far away, fought a major battle with an Iraqi division. Most of the approximately 2,000 inhabitants of Jaba fled, but about 200 men, women and children stayed behind.

title: Church in Philippines Becoming A Focus of Opposition to Marcos
description: BACCILOD, the Philippines, Oct. 13  To the consternation of many conservative bishops, the Roman Catholic Church is becoming an increas, ingly important focus of resistance to the martiallaw Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Williams Will Quit A's
description: Dick Williams, manager of the Oakland A's, has told his players he will resign after the World Series no matter which team wins. He will probably become manager of the New York Yankees if Charles O. Finley, owner of the A's, lets him out of the remaining two years of his threeyear contract.

title: City Bestows Accolade On a Cheerful Miss Gish
description: Lillian Gish, who has criticized herself for living too much in tomorrows, enjoyed a yesterday that she said she would remember always. This is a tremendous honor, Your Honor, said, the actress of the silent screen, smiling at Mayor Lindsay as he awarded her the Handel Medallion for achievement in the arts.

title: Harvester Talks Resume
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UPI) The United Auto Workers and the International Harvester Company resumed contract negotiations today with a strike deadline less than a day away. The union president, Leonard Woodcock, arrived in Chicago to lea dunion negotiations for a threeyear contract covering 40,856 workers at 38 Harvester facilities in 11 states.

title: House Votes to Require U. S. Control on Crude Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The House overwhelmingly approved today a bill that would require the Government to play a broad supervisory role in the distribution of crude oil and petroleum products.

title: Stink Bomb Fouls Up IRT
description: A stink bomb was set off yesterday on an IRT train at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue, forcing officials to take the train out of service and causing rushhour delays of 15 minutes. Transit Authority Officials said no one was hurt in the incident at 5:30 P.M. on the uptown express line.

title: More Compact Cars Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Representative. Glenn Anderson, Democrat of California, introduced legislation today to force the Government to buy more compact cars, to help conserve the nation's fuel supply. His proposal would require Federal agencies, when they replace older sedans, to insure that 70 per cent of the cars purchased in 1974 obtain 17 miles per gallon.

title: Works From Scull's Collection Of New York Art Coon Auction
description: Fifty paintings, sculptures an constructions by the most notable artists of the New York School, all from the collection of Robert C. Scull, will be auctioned tonight at Sotheby Parke Bernet. theby Parke Bernet.

title: U.S. CHIEF TARGET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17the Arab oilproducing nations proclaimed tonight a monthly cut in exports of oil, with the burden to fall on the United States and other nations considered to be unfriendly to the Arab cause.

title: People and Business Nation Is Found Overautornated
description: Dr. Simon Ramo, vice chairman and chief scientist of TRW, Inc., believes that the United States is overautomating Its society and using technology for convenience rather than applying it to solve urgent problems.

title: Lardner's Death Is Golf Shock
description: The United States Golf, Association, ruling, organization for the game, is without a president following the tragic death of Lynford Lardner Jr.

title: Watershed in Britain?
description: In fine oratorical fettle at the recent conference the British Labor party, Harold Wilson noted tartly that the newspapers were publishing no opinion polls while it was on. His implication was that the proTory press feared that an uptotheminute poll would show Labor with a big lead over the governing Conservatives.

title: Pajamas for Posterity
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)The Smithsonian Institution is looking for some secandhand clothing but don't send just anything you find stashed away in the attic.

title: From Little Italy to Big  Time Movies
description: When the gifted young film director Martin Scorsese walks along the narrow pavements of Little Italy on the Lower East Sideon Mulberry Street or Mott and Elizabeth between Houston and Spring Streetshe is treading close to the center of his universe, a place that is his, first by right of long residence, second by right of survival.

title: NO NEW MOVE SEEN TO EXTRADITE VESCO
description: The American Embassy in Costa Rica said yesterday that was unaware of any new attempt to extradite Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier who moves in and out of that Central American nation.

title: High School Sports
description: Football is a way of life at Far Rockaway, and it is Jack Kerchman who made it that way. The Sea Horses, last season's Public Schools Athletic League champion, meet Bayside Saturday in a game that should decide the winner in the Queens Division and a semifinal berth for the city title.

title: Hundreds of Tanks Clash In Struggle for Suez Area
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 17Hundreds of Israeli and Egyptian tanks clashed today in huge battles that appeared to signal the beginning of a climactic struggle for control of the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

title: SHOP TALK
description: She'll sell you the shirt off her backor the jacket or the jeans, for that matter. Carmen Vincent has found herself doing just that when people stop to ask about the studded jeans outfits she sometimes wears. (Once a friend insisted on having the pants she was wearing and didn't want to wait for a pair to be made to order.)

title: Restaurant Row Makes Debut on 46th Street
description: Colorful flags whipped in the wind outside 16 New York restaurants and baroque chamber music was played in the garden of one of them yesterday as Mayor Lindsay officially designated 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues as Restaurant Row.

title: Blades' Six Can't Meet A Payday
description: The Golden Blades, who started their second World Hockey Association season with a new name, new colors and an image, found themselves yesterday with the same old problemmoney.

title: PUTT TO ACQUIRE A THEATER GROUP
description: The American Broadcasting Companies; Inc., said it had agreed in principle to sell its Northern group of motion picture theaters to Plitt Theaters, Inc., for $25million in cash. The Northern group operates 123 theaters. American Broadcasting will continue to operate 264 motion picture theaters in its Southern group of theaters. The Southern group of theaters provides American Broadcasting with more than 80 per cent of its motion picture profits.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up at OneYear Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.The Treasury sold today $1.8billion of oneyear bills at an average rate of 7.13 per cent, down sharply from the 8.06 per cent it incurred last month. The rate was the lowest for a oneyear bill sale since May when it was 6,82 per cent.

title: Sandman Promises a Cut In Local Tax for Elderly
description: JAMESBURG, Oct. 17 Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, said today he would exempt elderly people from a major portion of their local realestate taxes if he was elected.

title: Robber Who Won Historic Case Is Poured Guilty on Drug Charge
description: A convicted robber whose appeal from that conviction in 1965 developed into a landmark case on the admissibility of confessions was found guilty in a newer, unrelated case yesterdayfor possession of drugs.

title: SENATORS ASSAIL O.P.I.C. OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17A Senate Foreign Relations subCommittee called today for the termination of a Government program under which companies investing in underdeveloped countries can buy Government insurance against expropriation and other risks.

title: Forest Fire Threat Cited
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 17 (AP)  New Hampshire is facing an extremely critical threat of forest fires because of the state's dryness. John Sargent of the state Forest Fire Service asked state municipalities yesterday to stop issuing burning permits and stop burning rubbish at town dumps.

title: A MILK PRICE RISE IS OPPOSED BY U.S
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17In what officials privately termed a victory over the dairy interests, the Cost of Living Council reported today that the Agriculture Department had opposed an increase this winter in fluid milk prices paid to farmers.

title: ERVIN PANEL LOSES IN SUIT FOR TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Chief Judge John J. Sirica ruled today that the United States District Court here lacked jurisdiction to handle the Senate Watergate committee's request for President Nixon's secret tape recordings.

title: BILL FOR MILITARY BLOCKED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17In an unusual rebuff to the leadership of two of its major committeesArmed Services and Rulesthe House blocked today immediate consideration of a compromise $21.3billion military procurement bill.

title: Oil as an Arab Weapon
description: PARIS, Oct. 17An oil embargo is a doubleedged sword, which is why the Arab oil states meeting in Kuwait have had trouble agreeing on ways to use it.

title: Hundreds of Tanks Clash In Struggle for Suez Area
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 17Hundreds of Israeli and Egyptian tanks clashed today in huge battles that appeared to signal the beginning of a climactic struggle for control of the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

title: CUBA GUNMAN SHOT 2 DIPLOMATS FREED
description: HAVANA, Thursday, Oct. 18 (Reuters)An anticastro gunman was shot and captured and twodiplomats he had held hostage for more than 24 hours were released yesterday.

title: Advertising: What's in a Name
description: There is efficiency in advertising dollars gained by using an umbrella name or established brand name.

title: AMTRAK COMPROMISE APROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) The House passed today a compromise. Amtrak authorization bill that would keep all present passenger train routes operating at least until next summer and grant Amtrak greater independence from the executive branch.

title: Charles Lowy, Fined in '48 For Arms Cache for Israel
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 17  Charles Lowry of Deal, president of an express and storage company bearing his name, died yesterday at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. His age was 81.

title: Chess: Down and Up With Portisch, Or Getting Even in Spades
description: All that Lajos Portisch needed was a draw in the last round of the Brazil Interzonal to assure himself of a firstplace tie with Enrique Mecking and a berth in the candidates' matches to pick ?? challenger for Bobby ischer.

title: Oil as an Arab Weapon
description: PARIS, Oct. 17An oil embargo is a doubleedged sword, which is why the Arab oil states meeting in Kuwait have had trouble agreeing on ways to use it.

title: ATTACK ON FAMILY LAID TO 2 OFFICERS
description: Two Housing Authority police officers were arrested yesterday and charged with beating four members of a Bronx family last July, then arresting them on false charges to cover their actions.

title: ERVIN PANEL LOSES IN SUIT FOR TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Chief Judge John J. Sirica ruled today that the United States District Court here lacked jurisdiction to handle the Senate Watergate committee's request for President Nixon's secret tape recordings.

title: Chile's Highest Jurist Affirms His Support for Military Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 17The President of the Supreme Court of Chile has affirmed his support for the military coup d'tat that toppled the legally elected Marxist coalition Government last month.

title: PROSECUTORS PLAN MEETING ON AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17Three of the State's Attorneys here plan to meet next Friday to determine whether to proceed with an investigation of former Vice President Agnew in connection with possible kickbacks.

title: Andrews, Back in A's Uniform, Says Finley's Pleas Pressured Him Out of It
description: Mike Andrews gave his side of the story yesterday, in an emotionchoked voice, to Commissioner Bowie Kuhn in private and a little later to the public in a hastily called news conference, and it boiled down to this:

title: High School Sitdown Asks Control Over Student Fees
description: Seeking full control over the spending of student fees, such as General Organization dues, about 600 students at Samuel Gompers Vocational and Technical High School staged a morning sitdown yesterday in the auditorium of the school, at 455 Southern Boulevard in the Bronx.

title: The $100,0O0 Question
description: Mystery is dear to the heart of Howard R. Hughes, the eccentric industrialist, but even by his standards there are too many mysteries surrounding the $100,000 in cash Mr. Hughes transmitted to Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend. The uncontested fact appears to be that the money was handed over in two equal installments in 1969 and 1970 by a Hughes associate. It was subsequently stored by Mr. Rebozo in a safe deposit box and finally returned by an unspecified route earlier this year.

title: TV: Impressive Start for A.B.C. News CloseUp
Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: City's Major Bar Groups Move to Settle Dispute on Rating Court Candidates
description: Leaders of the city's major bar associations will meet on Staten Island in two weeks in an effort to end their clash over the screening of judicial candidates.

title: U.S. Pair Skaters Win
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Oct. 18 (Reuters)  Louis Stoval and Vicky Handyside of the United Stales won the pairs figure skating title in the world roller skating championships that began here tonight. April Powell and Allen Abe Blass, another American pair, took second place.

title: Gunman Slays 2 on Herald Sq.
description: A crated gunman killed two passergby and wounded two other men An crowded 34th Street in midtown Manhattan Yesterday before he himself was mortally wounded in a gun battle with a retired detective and a garmentindustry executive.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 18Rutger's lone objective was to stop Lafayette's outside running last week, but when the Scarlet Knights meet Delaware Saturday they will have more than one objective because the Blue Hens have an awesome machine that works a lot of ways.

title: A New Opera in a New Opera House
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 18The Canadian Opera Company is celebrating its 25th anniversary, and one of the byproducts has been an opera by Charles Wilson named Heloise and Abelard. Commissioned by the Canadian Opera Company, this opera, to a libretto by Eugene Benson, had its world premiere in Toronto early in September. Last night it was given for the first time here at the National Arts Center.

title: Survey Finds Profits Up 24%
description: The First National City Bank reported yesterday that a preliminary survey of leading corporations indicated that profits in the third quarter of this year were up 24 per cent from the same quarter last year.

title: WEEDEN'S EARNINGS ADVANCE IN QUARTER
description: Weeden & Co. announced yesterday that it earned $843,000, or 49 cents a share, after extraordinary items in the last quarter of its fiscal year ended Sept. 30 compared with $697,000, or 40 cents a share, in the 1972 period. Excluding the effect of an accounting change, the fourthquarter results this year showed a profit of $8,000, or 1 cent a share. Weeden trades securities for its own account as a market maker.

title: Matthew Says Diverted Funds From Medicaid Aided Patients
description: The defense for Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, who is charged with misappropriating $450,000 in Medicaid funds, told a State Supreme Court jury in Queens yesterday that while he was not denying that some Medicaid funds were used for other businesses, the businesses were created to give jobs to patients as part of their treatment.

title: Cairo's Mood Remains Confident and Serene
description: CAIRO, Oct. 18The people of Cairo are continuing to display the confidence and relaxed serenity that they have shown since the start of the war.

title: Laver Bows To Mottram In Tennis
description: MADRID, Oct. 18 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia, the topseeded player, was upset today by Christopher Mottram of Britain, 36, 75, 62, in the quarterfinals of the international Melia tennis tournament.

title: Kuwait Will Resume Subsidy to Jordan
description: EL QATRANA, Jordan, Oct. 18Kuwait has announced that she has decided to resume paying $46million a year into Jordan's budget, now that Jordan has entered the ArabIsraeli war. The decision was welcomed today by both the Jordanian Government and people.

title: Singer Pleads Not Guilty
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., Oct. 18 (UPI)  Toriano Jackson, 19 years old, of the Jackson Five singing group, pleaded not guilty in Superior Court yesterday to a charge of receiving stolen property, and was ordered to stand trial Dec. 5. He and two others were arrested in April in connection with burglaries at more than 50homes.

title: Tavel Play: Gymnastics For Tongue
description: SECRETS OF THE CITIZENS CORRECTION COMMITTEE, a play by Ronald Tavel. Directed by John Chapman; set ting by Charles Cosler; lighting by David Andrews; costumes by Catherine Scandalis; graphics by Bill Plympton; stage manager, Charles Embry. Presented by Theater at St. Clement's, Kevin O'Connor, artistic director. At 423 West 46th Street.

title: Music: Slack Idomeneo
description: Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society have performed many a useful service to this city's musical life in the group's quartercentury of existence. But the concert version of Mozart's Idomeneo that they put together on Wednesday night at Town Hall fell far short of being useful to anyone. It was poorly prepared, sloppily played and inadequately sting affair that could not have won many friends for Mozart's most neglected important opera.

title: Newspaper Deal Announced
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP)Gannett Company, Inc., the newspaper group, announced today an agreement in principle to acquire the Oregon Statesman and The Capital Journal in Salem, Ore. The morning and Sunday Oregon Statesman and the evening Capital Journal have a combined daily circulation, of 70,000 and Sunday circulation of 46,000.

title: HouseSenate Conferees Back Compromise on Alaska Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)  HouseSenate conferees reached agreement today on legislation approving construction of a 789mile oil pipeline across Alaska from the North Slope to the southern coast.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Search for Ruffed Grouse
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N.H.Although at least half of the forest's leaves were still aloft  flaunting their yellow, russet and gold under a drab October skyit was one of the days I had chosen to hunt for ruffed grouse, and I went forth.

title: Dispute on Death Penalty
description: BOSTON, Oct 18 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate has voted not to concur with House amendments to a bill restoring the death penalty. The bill was sent yesterday to a conference committee of the two branches where differences, possibly, will be ironed out.

title: MEADOW COMPLEX FACES NEW DELAY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 18  The $280million bond issue to finance the construction of al sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands will be delayed until after the gubernatorial election in New Jersey next month, financial sources reported today.

title: Watch Out, Demory, Here Comes Mean Joe Greene
description: The Jets will have the early television audience to themselves Sunday as they play their sixth straight game on the road (No. 12, counting preseason games), meeting the Steelers in Pittsburgh (Channel 4, 1 P.M.). The Giants' game at Dallas follows (Channel 2, 4 P.M.), but it will have competition as Channel 4 completes its doubleheader, Kansas City at Cincinnati, also at 4 P.M., provided the World Series is over. With both clubs playoff contenders, which New York teams are not, this contest is importantif not a key game, then a lowkey one. Here is a preview of all games, with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: City Sues to Bar FoodSales Plan Held Illegal
description: The city has asked the State Supreme Court to compel the operators of an alleged pyramid sales scheme to repay more than $3.7million allegedly hoodwinked from 800 victims here, as well as $400,000 in fines. Most of the victims were Puerto Ricans who were not fluent in English.

title: The Israeli Bridgehead
description: The reinforcement and expansion of the Israeli bridgehead west of the Suez Canal appears to United States and other Western military sources as an audacious but risky tactical stroke designed to loosen Egypt's grip on the Sinai bridgehead. The effect of the thrust by Israel across the canal probably will not be evident for several days. The area penetrated heavily manned by Egyptian troops and the Israeli force is under severe pressure. Success there by the Israelis, these sources suggested, could be the key unlocking the whole Egyptian position.

title: News Guild Asks Meany To Lift Nonunion TV Ban
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 18 The president of the Newspaper Guild, Charles A. Perlik Jr., wrote a letter to George Meany today asking him to reconsider his decision yesterday to bar nonunion television camera crews from covering the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention here.

title: Oil and Glamour Stocks Climb as Market Drops
description: Domestic oils and select glamour issues moved higher yesterday in a market that started out firm and then weakened in late trading to close with a modest decline. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange stepped up to 19.21 million shares from Wednesday's 18.6 million shares.

title: Pole Post to Petty In NASCAR Race
description: ROCKINGHAM, N. C., Oct. 18 (AP)Richard Petty drove a mile at 135.748 miles an hour today and captured the pole position for the $107,500 American 500 stock car race. Petty, 38 years old and winner of just over $1.4 million in prize money in 14 years, needed only 26.969 seconds to take his Dodge around the steeply banked North Carolina Motor Speedway, a racecourse he knows well.

title: HARVESTER COMPANY IS STRUCK BY U.A.W.
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 18(AP) The United Auto Workers struck the International Harvester Company today at 25 operational facilities in 11 states.

title: MEADOW COMPLEX FACES NEW DEWY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 18  The $280million bond issue to linance the construction of a sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands will be delayed until after the gubernatorial election in New Jersey next month, financial sources reported today.

title: WOMAN HIJACKS JET IN FRANCE, IS KILLED
description: MARSEILLES, France, Oct. 18 (AP)A woman with a rifle hijacked a French jet on a flight from Paris to Nice today and demanded to be taken to Cairo. Policemen who boarded the plane at Marseilles tried to disarm her but she opened fire and was fatally wounded in the return fire.

title: 2 Bombs Explode in Bank At Union Sq., Injuring 10
description: Two pipe bombs exploded without warning in a crowded bank off Union Square yesterday, injuring at least 10 perSons, blowing out 10 of the bank's windows and sending lunchtime strollers and shoppers fleeing for cover.

title: People and Business
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., the holding company that owns Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., has named, as expected, George L Shinn as its new president and chief operating officer. He will take over the position on Jan. 1, 1974, when Ned B. Ball will retire at the age of 65.

title: Nondriver Wins Appeal For Unemployment Pay
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 18 (AP)  The State Department of Employment Security has been ordered to pay unemployment benefits to a woman who had been denied them because she did not drive a car.

title: ARAB BID FOR LOAN IN WEST REPORTED
description: PARIS, Oct. 18  Highly placed European banking sources say that a major Arab oilexporting nation has been sounding out Western banks for a big loan.

title: Far North Gas Pipeline Is Tested
description: SANS SAULT, Northwest TerritoriesBefore spending $5billion on a technically unprecedented engineering project it is considered good form to find out if it is going to work.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: DOWN EAST The Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn (6364100) is taking on a distinctly Nipponese coloration these days. First of all, some two dozen Shingon monks, direct from triumphs in France and Iran, take over the stage at 7:30 tonight, 8 tomorrow and 2 on Sunday. The monks, whose sect, according to their advance man, practices one of the esoteric forms of Buddhism, dating from the 9th century, will offer programs of ancient rituals and traditions.

title: U.S. and French Divers Describe Exploration of Atlantic Abyss
description: PARIS, Oct. 18The most ambitious and prolonged exploration at great depths of the bottom of the sea was described here today by the men who made repeated plunges into the black abyss that bisects the Atlantic Ocean.

title: TV: Searching Look at The Israelis
description: Tonight, at 10 o'clock, the Columbia Broadcasting System is preempting one scheduled news specialThe Corporation  with another The Israelis. With most of the filming completed in June, The Israelis was scheduled for presentation in December as part of a running C.B.S. News series of studies on national character (e.g., The Italians with Luigi Barzini.)

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Jones Gets Shot Edge With 65
description: NARA, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) Grier Jones, with some dramatic putting, carded a seven  under  par 65 today and took the firstround lead in the 150,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: Bank Found Insolvent
description: The United States National Bank of San Diego, whose principal stockholder, C. Arnholt Smith, is under Federal investigation, has been declared insolvent by the Controller of the Currency. The Crocker Bank of San Francisco has offered to take over the troubled hank. Page 61.

title: 3 MEETINGS HEED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Egypt announced tonight that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union had held three long meetings in Cairo with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, presumably to discuss a diplomatic approach to settling the Middle East crisis.

title: Staff of Watergate Panel Will Meet With Scholars
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP)Staff members of the Senate Watergate Committee and A number of scholars will meet here in December to consider the deeper constitutional implications of the Watergate affair.

title: JAPAN IS STUNNED BY ARAB OIL CUTS
description: TOKYO, Oct. 18Japan has been stunned two days in a row with the decisions by six Persian Gulf nations to increase oil prices 21 per cent and by Arab nations to cut back oil production 5 per cent every month to bring pressure on Israel and the nations that support her.

title: Advertising: Flapjacks on TV
description: Ragstoriches stories by thistime are rather old hat, but boozetobatter ones? Well, that's something else again.

title: Bank Robber Sentence Due
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 18 (UPI)James Wesley Akers, a member of a secret group described by one member as leftwing fascists, will be sentenced on Nov. 13 for charges involving firearms.

title: Uganda President's Note.
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct, 18 (UPI)President Idi Amin sent a message to the Organization of African Unity today saying that liberation forces were near Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, the Uganda radio said. General Amin has just returned from a trip to the Middle East.

title: A's Are in a Precarious Spot, But Confidence Hasn't Sagged
description: The Oakland A's have been winners and they have been losers, and they know from experience that win or lose, winning is better. But beyond that they seemed monumentally undisturbed by the fact that they must win the last two games to be played in Oakland to retain the World Series title they've borne so proudly since last year.

title: Access to San Clemente Tax Data Is Demanded
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP)California officials demanded total access today to property tax records of President Nixon's estate at San Clemente.

title: Judge Levies $50,000 Damages on Allegheny Airlines for Bumping Nader
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  A Federal district judge levied $50,000 damages against Allegheny Airlines today for bumping the consumer advocate Ralph Nader from a flight and, in his ruling, accused the airline industry of consistently overbooking its flights and intentionally concealing the practice from the public.

title: Yale Hopes Superstition Helps End Losing Streak
description: Samson had his locks clipped and lost his strength. But Yale University's linebackers, led by Capt. Gary Wilhelm, went to the barbershop last Monday hoping to change the Samson story. Jack Sellati, Tim Knowles and Brent Kirk followed Wilhelm's example, and two defensive coaches, Paul Amodio and Buddy Amendola, also got short haircuts. The players and the coaches are hoping to change Yale's luck, especially on defense. In three games this season the Elis have given up an average of 408 yards per game, a figure hardly in the style of Coach Carmen Cozza's previous eight Yale squads.

title: HEAD OF PRINTERS ALERTED ON TALKS
description: Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6, made a new plea to his international union yesterday for release from the current contract so that the local could, if necessary, take strike action to obtain new agreements with the city's major newspapers.

title: Triple Pays a Record $19,759 On 6411 Finish at Aqueduct
description: Numbers added up to good news for horseplayers and management alike yesterday at Aqueduct, where the triple produced a record payoff of $19,759 and the taxreduction experiment continued to increase business.

title: Maxwell' Plum to Take Over and Transform TavernontheGreen
description: Maxwell's Plum, the chic East Side restaurant that is, a favorite meeting place for singles, has been granted a city franchise to take over the TavernontheGreen in Central Park just off West 67th Street.

title: Howzer' Shown at the Whitney Museum:The Cast
description: The fantasies about the world in the minds of youngsters is explored with delicacy and compassion in "Howzer," which began a two-week premiere engagement yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. While its probing into the inner drives of a runaway brother and sister may not be especially deep, this first film effort of Kenneth Laurence, its writer-director, his colleagues and a willing cast is an arresting illustration of a serious, if simple, theme executed with polish and dedication.In essence, "Howzer" concentrates on the adventures of 12-year-old Howard (Howzer) and 14-year-old Debora, who flee from seeming parental restraints and comfortable, middle-class suburbia toward the glorious horizons of Los Angeles via comfortable Pullman accommodations. What they discover, of course, is that the world is not so safe as home nor so beautiful as their dreams or the mountain country they travel after leaving the train.A viewer might reasonably question the extraordinary nature of the people and experiences that finally shake and traumatize these innocents. Very few kids, after all, are likely to run into a moody hunter and his adult, retarded son. Nor are they likely to be befriended by a hippy amateur artist and his girl, who run a lonely tavern where they are exposed to death for the first time.One might also wonder about the somewhat thin reasons for their trek west. School, it's intimated, is a bore for Howzer. Debora is equally disenchanted. Mom and Dad don't understand, etc.But Edmund Gilbert and Allyn Ann McLerie make believable parents fumbling for communication with their laconic children. And in making their debuts, Peter Desiante, as Howzer, who never loses his yen for freedom, and Melissa Stocking, who does, are impressively natural and curious as the wandering offspring.As professionals, Royal Dano, William Gray, Virgil Frye and Olive Deering as the hunter his son, the artist and his girl, contribute smooth, low-key portrayals of unusual types.The small world of Howzer and company, as seen through Bruce Logan's scenic color photography, is slightly flawed, but it is worth watching.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Shortage of Chlorine Reported; New York and Newark Affected
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The chairman of a House subcommittee on health and environment disclosed today evidence of a potentially serious chlorine shortage that could affect the nation's municipal water supplies sewage treatment and public and private swimming pools.

title: HIGHER RATE ASKED FOR SAVINGS, BONDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UN)  Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz proposed today that Congress remove the 5 per cent. interest ceiling on United States savings bonds and allow the rate to float upward with market conditions.

title: Cooke Is Replacing Shafer as the Head of Teleprompter
description: Jack Kent Cooke, the wealthy California sportsman and largest shareholder in Teleprompter, Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive of the troubled company, replacing a former Pennsylvania governor, Raymond P. Shafer, it was announced yesterday.

title: Browns Lose Linebacker
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 (UPI)  Billy Andrews, the Cleveland Browns defensive captain and linebacker, will undergo back surgery for a herniated disk, the club announced today.

title: About New York
description: Violence went public in New York yesterday. In the morning, a gunman on 34th Street killed two people and wounded two others before someone else killed him, and in the afternoon two pipe bombs went off in a bank on 14th Street and left 10 people torn and bleeding.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: RISE IN OIL PRICES SEEMS A RECORD
description: While the attention of the world was focused on the ArabIsraeli conflict and the announcement of an oil production cutback by the Arab countries, Persian Gulf petroleum producers have quietly imposed what appears to be the largest price increase in the history of the industry.

title: IRWIN UNTERMYER, 87, RETIRED JUDGE, DIES
description: Irwin Untermyer, former Associate Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department of the state's Supreme Court, died yesterday at his home, 960 Fifth Avenue. He was 87 years old.

title: Chilean Junta's Plans Gladden Farmers
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 18A leader of the conservative private farthers' association in Temuco, a fertile agrarian center 400 miles south of the capital, sat in his office two weeks after the military coup d'tat and explained to a visitor the extensive plans to rebuild the area's agriculture.

title: Asia Is On Its Way to the Bronx Zoo
description: A monorail, With expert lecturers, will be the style in which visitors to the Bronx Zoo's projected 40  acre Asiatic wildlife complex will watch kinodo dragons, Siberian tigers, elephants, rhinocerous, giant bats, mouse deer, the largest wild cattle in the world and other exotic creatures from the Arabian Peninsula to Java.

title: Approval of 13.8% Rise in Rates Lessens the Plight of Polyclinic,
description: The 13.8 per cent rate increase granted by the Cost of Living Council to French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center. did not solve all our problems, Stanley Salmen, president of the center, said yesterday, but will allow us to take steps to avoid final bankruptcy and seek financing for the projected $43million conversion of the former New Yorker Hotel.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: By The Associated Press

title: Nobel for U.S. Economist; Australian Writer Chosen
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18Wassily Leontief, the Russianborn Harvard economist, and Patrick White, the Australian novelist, won Nobel honors today.

title: Milstein Concert Put Off
description: Because of illness, the Carnegie Hall concert tonight by Nathan Milstein, violinist, has been postponed until Thursday, Nov. 8. Two postponements of recitals scheduled for next week have also been announcedSviatoslav Richter, pianist, from Monday to Nov. 19 at Avery Fisher Hall, and Monserrat Caball, soprano, from Oct. 27 to Jan. 20 at Carnegie Hall.

title: Richardson Acts to Consolidate Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson is putting into effect a partial reorganization of the Justice Department designed to give him a tighter rein over the department's various components, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which, under the late J. Edgar Hoover, had maintained almost total independence for more than 40 years.

title: PRIEST WINS RIGHT TO SUE HIS BISHOP
description: MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Oct. 18 (AP)  A former Roman Catholic priest active in the Cairo civil rights movement has won the right to sue his bishop for failing to provide funds for support of himself and his church.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 4 in Coast Guard Cleared of Plot

title: Mets Beat A's, 20, Lead World Series by 3 Games to 2
description: New York ended its threeday involvement with the 70th World Series without riot or ruin last night as the Mets defeated the Oakland A's, 20, and took the Series lead for the first time.

title: CATHOLICS SCORE MARRIAGE COURTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The professional association of Roman Catholic ecclesiastical lawyers said today that the marriage courts they administered were incapable of meeting the realistic needs of American Catholics and should be replaced.

title: Pregnant Whale Has Infection
description: Frances, the New York Aquarium'precious, pregnant beluga whale, is sick, but aquarium officials believe that like thousands of New Yorkers she has nothing more serious than an upper respiratory infection.

description: NEW YORK

title: Novels Full of Life
description: The admirer of the perfectly rendered novel, of Flaubert's Madame Bovary, will not feel fully satisfied with the novels of Patrick White.

title: Browns Lose Linebacker
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 (UPI)  Billy Andrews, the Cleveland Browns' defensive captain and linebacker, will undergo back surgery for a herniated disk, the club announced today.

title: Lillian Reis Pleads Guilty
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP)Lillian Reis, 43yearoid former showgirl, pleaded guilty in Federal Court to charges of possession and possession with intent to distribute quantities of methamphetamine. No date was set for sentencing.

title: Prices Advance on Amex and Counter
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange opened lower yesterday but later in the session changed direction and closed higher in steppedup trading. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Public Confidence Issue
description: NEWARK, Oct. 18Brendan T. Byrne urged today the establishment of a special prosecutor's section in the State Attorney General's office to concentrate on the investigation of corruption in government.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: 11,000 Pupils Out in Protest of Fuentes Ouster
description: More than 11,000 of the 17,125 pupils in Community School District I were absent yesterday as word spread throughout the Lower East Side about the boycott, that is to begin formally today in protest of the suspension of Luis Fuentes, the district superintendent.

title: CHILE IS EXPELLING ANOTHER NEWSMAN
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 18Chilean military authorties ordered the expulsion of Bo Sourander, Latin American correspondent for the leading Swedish Daily, Dagens Nyheter, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: In Consideration of the Arab View
description: WASHINGTONThere seems to be little understanding in this country, and even less certainty, of what the Arabs are seeking and are capable of achieving by their fresh round of fighting against Israel for which the two warring parties are paying such an exorbitant price, in terms of human life and havoc.

title: Guerrillas Seize a Beirut Bank, Demand 10Million for the War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, Oct. 19Hurling a grenade and firing a fusillade of shots, five guerrillas stormed into the Bank of America office here yesterday, fought a twohour gun battle with soldiers across the street and, holding 20 or 25 bank employes as hostages, threatened to blow up the building if their demands were not met.

title: Cards' Metcalf Injured
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (UPI) Terry Metcalf, the leading rusher for the St. Louis Cardinals this season, will miss next Sunday's game against the Redskins at Washington because of twisted knee, the Cardinals said today. Metcalf would be replaced in the starting lineup by Don Shy and his place on the roster would be taken by Jim Otis.

title: METALS CONCERNS IN MIXED RESULTS
description: The Aluminum Company of America sold and shipped more aluminum in the first nine months than in any comparable period, while the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., had its highest sales in the first nine months.

title: In Search of Real Italian Food
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: LEVINE VOWS TO QUIT IF HE BROKE LAW
description: Paul Levine, the former Economic Development Administration official, said yesterday that he would resign his position with the S & S Corrugated Paper Machinery Company if the Board of Ethics ruled that he broke the law in taking the job.

title: Walt Kelly, Pogo Creator, Dies
description: Walt Kelly, the cartoonist who created a penandink menagerie of Okefenokee Swamp characters in the nationally syndicated strip Pogo, died of diabetes complications early yesterday at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital in Hollywood. He was 60 years old.

title: Tams Win As Jones Sparkles
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 16 (UPI)Wilbert Jone's and Johnny Neumann combined for 41 points tonight in leading the Memphis Tams to a 9381 victory over the San Antonio Spurs in an American Basketball Association game.

title: TWO TAKE $55,000 IN HOLDUP OF STORE
description: A gunman and an accomplice made off with more than $55,000 in merchandise and checks last night in a holdup of the Imperial Galleries, a store that sells jewelry and other gift articles at Seventh Avenue and 52d Stret, the police reported.

title: FORD ON THE DAIS AT SMITH DINNER
description: Vice Presidentdesignate Gerald R. Ford pledged last night to work toward ending partisanship and polarization in relations between President Nixon and the Congress.

title: Coup Against Fuentes
description: The nomination last year of Luis Fuentes as superintendent of Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side was vehemently opposed by a number of responsible organizations on the grounds that he had repeatedly been guilty of racially and ethnically divisive statements. This newspaper shared this widespread concern over Mr. Fuentes' attitudes, over ambiguities his professional record and over the coercive tactics used by his supporters in forcing through his appointment.

title: Maxwell's Plum to Take Over and Transform, TavernontheGreen
description: Maxwell's Plum, the chic East Side restaurant that is a favorite Meeting place for singles, has been granted, a city franchise to take over the TavertontheGreen in Central. Park just off West 67th Street.

description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 18 George Meany, organized labor's top spokesman, said today that the people of the United States had reached the verdict that President Nixon was responsible for the dark shadow of shame over the spirit of America.

title: A Repeat of Juvenile Court Is Postponed by P. B.
description: The repeat telecast of Fred Wiseman's lengthy documentary of judicial response to youthful offences, Juvenile Court, will be a few months lateif, indeed, it can be repeated at all.

title: Wright Home to Be Bought
description: CANTON, N.Y., Oct. 18 (UPI)The Home of a 19thcentury Governor will be purchased by the St. Lawrence County Historical Association, which has been raising money for the residence, according to the association. The association said yesterday a fund campaign had realized about $65,000 of its $100,000 goal and the sum was enough to buy the Silas Wright home.

title: Value of Dollar Changed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (Reuters)The Treasury Department said that it formally notified the International Monetary Fund of a change in the par value of the dollar, implementing the 10 per cent devaluation proposed on Feb. 12 and ratified by Congress on Oct. 13. Effective at 12:01 A.M. (local time) today the value of the dollar is officially changed to 42.22 per fine troy ounce from $38 per fine troy ounce. This is equal to 0.828948 special drawing right.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1,01billion up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $926million. Total retail store sales were about $9.72billion increase of 9 per cent over last year's $8.93billion.

title: Women Behind Bars
description: WASHINGTON  Another one of those crime commission reports appeered this week, this one by a federally financed group of local and state criminal justice officials. To the surprise of no one who has studied the matter even cursorily, it recommended that fewer people be sent to prison, and for shorter terms, and that state and local governments stop building these human warehouses, most of which are inhumane, expensive and factories of crime.

title: TAPES DISCUSSED WITH RICHARDSON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 President Nixon's attorneys have met with Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson to discuss the court battles over the Watergate tapes, the White House disclosed today.

title: Saudis Cut Oil Output 10% To Put Pressure on U.S.
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 18Saudi Arabia, the Arab world's largest oilproducing nation, announced tonight it was cutting back oil production by 10 per cent immediately in an attempt to put pressure on the United States to reduce its support for Israel.

title: MacPhail Is Rumored Ready to Leave Yanks for Cronin's League Presidency
description: While baseball people continued to talk about the probability of Dick Williams becoming a new Yankee manager, indications arose last night that Lee MacPhail, the Yankee general manager, would leave to become president of the American League.

title: Flow of Soviet Jews Is Undiminished
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18The Middle East war has caused no in terruption or slowdown in the flow of Soviet Jews bound for Israel, Jewish sources said tonight.

title: Parents Wrongly Identified Dead Girl as Daughter
description: The body of a teenaged girl, found dead of an overdose of methadone three weeks ago and buried by a Long Island City couple as their estranged daughter, was identified yesterday as that of another missing girl.

title: On a Sinai Tour, a Close Brush With Egyptian Guns
description: IN THE SINAI, Oct. 18  Stop the car! the Israeli officer yelled when the first Egyptian artillery shells crashed alongside the road. Stop it and get out!

title: Leontief's Contribution
description: Long before giant electronic computers were available to solve the scores of simultaneous questions that make up an inputoutput model of the national economy, Wassily Leontief was slaving away to assemble and compute the data that would show precisely how the American economy fits together and works the inputoutput method of economic analysis.

title: Bank Found Insolvent
description: The United States National Bank of San Diego, whose principal stockholder, C. Arnhold Smith, is under Federal investigation, has been declared insolvent in what is believed to be the largest insolvency in American banking history. The Crocker Bank has offered to take over the troubled bank. Page 61.

description: The Univac division of the Sperry Rand Corporation has introduced a new family of computers that it contended would outperform similarly priced machines produced by the International Business Machines Corporation.

description: Frances, the New York Aquarium's precious, pregnant beluga whale, is sick, but aquarium officials believe that, like thousands of New Yorkers, she has nothing more, serious than an upper respiratory infection.

description: KOMPONG CHAM, Cambodia, Oct. 7Theth Brageth was a sailor in the small Cambodian Navy.

title: DR. AILDRED M'DONALD
description: Dr. Aildred A. MacDonald, a pediatrician who served for 27 years as associate professor of pediatrics at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died yesterday in Sea View Hospital, S.I., after a long illness. Dr. MacDonald, who lived at 220 Cabrini Boulevard, was 76 years old.

title: Tire Industry Seeking a Delay In System to Grade Tread Life
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The tire manufacturing industry is seeking a delay at least until mid1975 in the establishment of a uniform system for grading the tread life of automobile tires.

title: SHOP TALK
description: I'm Mrs. Raymond Kravis from Tulsa, Oklahoma, said the woman in the sleeveless black coat with the cape back as she stepped up to shake hands with Bill Blass, at Lord & Taylor. I see your things in Jackson's at home. I think it's so nice to meet the designer.

title: Meat Loaf or Calamari for the Weekend Chef
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: The Israeli Bridgehead
description: The reinforcement and expansion of the Israeli bridgehead west of the Suez Canal appears to United States and other Western military sources as an audadotia but risky tap,. tical stroke designeil to loosen Egypt's grip on the Sinai bridgehead. The effect of the thrust by Israel across the canal probably will not be evident for several days. The area penetrated is heavily manned by Egyptian troops and the Israeli force is under severe pressure. Success there by the Israelis, these sources suggested, could be the key unlocking the whole Egyptian position.

title: The Pop Life
description: The world vinyl shortage is beginning to affect the record industry. At least two major recording companies have been forced to postpone or delay forthcoming releases because of rationing of coaltarbased vinyl, essential in record manufacture.

title: Newspaper Deal Announced
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP)Gannett Company, Inc., the newspaper group, anflounced today an agreement in principle to acquire the Oregon Statesman and The Capital Journal in Salem, Ore.

title: Nader Bests Airline
description: A Federal judge in Washington accused the airlines of consistently overbooking their seats as he levied $50,000 in damages against Allegheny Airlines yesterday for bumping Ralph Nader from a flight. Details on Page 12.

title: Two F.P.C. Economists at a Senate Panel Hearing Challenge Industry's Figures on Natural Gas Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18In another round of running debate about whether the natural gas industry understates its reserves, two Federal Power Commission economists challenged before Congress today the reliability of statistics compiled by their own agency.

title: The Hidden Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Despite America's massive airlift of planes and ammunition to Israel, it would be mistake to assume that the Nixon Administration's objective is to assure another spectacular Israeli victory in the Middle East war.

title: People in Sports: Phils Trade Brett to Pirates
description: The Philadelphia Phillies traded Ken Brett, a lefthanded pitcher, yesterday to the Pittsburgh Pirates, but there was no money involved, just Dave Cash. The 25yearold Cash, considered one of the best fielding second basemen in the National League, batted 271 this season, hit two homers and batted in 31 runs. Cash said he was happy with the trade, since he would have the chance to play every day. He said Danny Ozark, the Phils' manager, had told him by phone to be ready to play 160 games.

title: Capitals' Rookie Hurt
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)Nick Weatherspoon, Capital Bullets' rookie forward, suffered a broken right hand in practice yesterday. The team announced today he would be lost for four weeks. He joins Wes Unseld, Archie Clark and Tom Patterson on the injury list.

title: Jets Flown by North Koreans Are Reported in Clash With Israelis Over Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Jets piloted by North Koreans clashed with Israeli jets in the Middle East war today, according to a United States official.

title: A Sampling of Inexpensive Cosmetics: Many Get High Rating
description: It isn't necessarily true that the more expensive a product, the better it is, but to date no one has been able to measure the psychological effect of the $80 bed sheet, the $35 designer scarf or the $10 face cream. The war between logic and emotions is a constant one and nowhere are the skirmishes more trequent than in the beauty industry, a colossus that caters to an estimated 60million women.

title: Streetcar to End Run
description: A Streetcar Named Desire, the Tennessee Williams play starring Lois Nettleton, will end its run at the St. James Theater after the Sunday matinee, having given a total of 20 performances. It was staged by Jules Irving, who transferred it from the Vivian Beaumont Theater by arrangement with Lincoln Center.

title: Dance: After the Fall
description: After Eden, John Butler's view of Adam and Eve after their psychoanalysis, remains one of the hits of the City Center Joffrey Ballet repertory. In its first appearance of the season Wednesday night at the City Center, Starr Danias and Dennis Wayne gave the pas de deux another of their usual resoundingly good performances.

title: 5 in Bronx Youth Gangs Indicted In Merchant Protection Racket
description: Scores of shopkeepers in the South Bronx have been terrorized by street gangs into paying protection money to escape beatings, arson and robbery.

title: Policemen Kill an Indian Leader Wanted on a Fugitive Warrant
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., Oct. 18 (AP)Pedro Bissonette, an American Indian Movement leader in the siege of Wounded Knee, was shot and killed last night by policemen seeking him on a fugitive warrant, the authorities said today.

title: Nader Bests Airline
description: A federal judge in Washington accused the airlines of consistently overbooking their seats as he levied $50,000 in damages against Allegheny Airlines yesterday for bumping Ralph Nader from a flight. Details on Page 12.

title: Justice Pierre P. Garven Dies; Headed Jersey Supreme Court
description: TEANECK, N. J., Friday, Oct. 19Chief Justice Pierre P. Garven of the New Jersey Supreme Court died early this morning at Holy Name Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 18 (AP)About $22million in state and Federal funds is needed to stage the 1980 Winter Olympics here, according to the Rev. J. Bernard Fell, sports director of the Olympic Bid Committee.

title: BUSINESS SHIFTS SOURCE OF FUNDS
description: Bank loans to corporations have taken a definite downward turn, and companies have stepped up their borrowing in the commercial paper market by a record amount in recent weeks. Interest rates on commercial paper, meanwhile, have declined week by week to the point that banks may decide sooner than expected to lower the base rate they charge on corporate loans.

title: Nobel for U.S. Economist; Australian Writer Chosen
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18Wassily Leontief, the Russianborn Harvard economist, and Patrick White, the Australian novelist, won Nobel honors today.

title: Knicks Set to Continue Domination of Cavaliers
description: The New York Knicks take to the road for the first time this season in a National Basketball Association game tonight in Cleveland and Coach Red Holzman is hoping the Cavaliers continue to be no more than a doormat for his team.

title: Bridge: Mets Action Not Limited To World Series This Week
description: Mention the Mets to any New Yorker, especially at World Series time, and his thoughts fly to Shea Stadium. Unless, perhaps, he happens to be a bridge enthusiast, for whom the Mets may suggest the annual Metropolitan championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which begin today at the New Bridge Association, which begin today at the New York Hilton.

title: League Controls Blades
description: The World Hockey Association took possession of the financially troubled New York Golden Blades last night after the Blades' management had failed to meet the $40,000 player payroll that had been due on Monday.

title: 2 BOMBS EXPLODE IN UNION SQ. BANK
description: Two pipe bombs exploded without warning in a crowded bank off Union Square yesterday, injuring at least 10 persons, blowing out 10 of the bank's windows and sending lunchtime strollers and shoppers fleeing for cover.

title: VETERANS CRITICAL OF BAD DISCHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18A group of Vietnam veterans who received less than honorable military discharges said today that the bad discharges were a result of their opposition to, the Vietnam war and racism! in the armed forces and had stigmatized them for life.

title: New Treasurer Picked By Metropolitan Opera
description: James S. Smith was elected treasurer of the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday at the monthly meeting of the company's board of directors. He succeeds James F. Jaffray who resigned last month after five years in the position.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLOSE OFF AGAIN
description: For the fifth session in a row, soybean futures prices dropped sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade. The harvest is under way and as long as the weather continues to be good prices traditionally are weak. This reflects a large amount of hedge selling as the record crop moves to local elevators.

title: Eaton, Set to Retire, Wants Wider Role With Chessie
description: Cyrus S. Eaton, whose retirement as chairman of Chessie System, Inc., was announced on Oct. 5, is understood to feel that the Chessie stock he controls entitles him to more of a voice in the company's affairs than the present management appears to intend to allowhim. Mr. Eaton asserts that he and his associates and friends control more than 500,000 shares of the stock of the sizable conglomerate, which is the parent of the Chesapeake & OhioBaltimore & Ohio Railroad System.

title: Veteran Voids DoorbellRinging Curb
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 18  A 27yearold law student and Vietnam war veteran won the right in Bergen County Court today to ring doorbells in the borough of Oradell to seek votes without registering with the Police Department.

title: STUDY OF COMET PLANNED BY NASA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed plans today for intensive scienific observations this winter of the comet Kohoutek, which is expected to give earth a spectacular display around Christmas.

title: BRITISH PARLIAMENT SUPPORTS ARMS BAN
description: LONDON, Oct. 18The British Government defeated tonight a strong challenge to its imposition of an embargo on arms supplies to Israel.

title: Avon Aides Are Sued for Stock Sales
description: Twentyfour officers and directors of Avon Products, Inc., the cosmetics company, were accused here yesterday in a stockholder suit of having sold Or acquiesced in the sale of Avon stock on the basis of inside information.

title: Goodyear Profit Off 32% on Sales Rise
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire producer, reported yesterday a sharp drop in thirdquarter earnings despite record sales.

title: Tropical Storm Expected To Miss Southeast Florida
description: MIAMI, Oct. 18 (AP)The National Hurricane Center said tonight that tropical storm Gilda, which has forced the evacuation of thousands in Cuba, would barely miss southeast Florida.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Commonwealth National Realty Trust filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an initial public offering of 1.25million shares of beneficial interest.

title: MAJOR SINAI CLASH
description: CAIRO, Oct. 18Egypt said today that a ferocious tank battle was being fought in the central sector of the Sinai front, involving large concentrations of tanks, other mechanized forces and planes on both sides.

title: Censorious Labor
description: George Meany's recently proclaimed enthusiasm for the right to dissent is illserved by his current decision to exclude camera crews of most Miami television stations from the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention because they have chosen not to be represented by a union. Censorship by union card is no more tolerable than any other brand. Mr. Meany, an exuberant practitioner of free speech in his own right, will do well to take the advice of Charles A. Perlik, president of The Newspaper Guild, and recognize that free speech and free press are violated by his ban.

title: Laver Bows To Mottram In Tennis
description: MADRID, Oct. 18 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia, the topseeded player, was upset today by Christopher Mottram of Britain, 36, 75, 62, in the quarterfinals of the international Melia tennis tournament.

title: Business Briefs
description: The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company managed to trim its loss somewhat in September, according to the trustees' report issued yesterday.

description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1973
