title: Donaldson, Jenrette Profit Declined in the 3d Quarter
description: Net income in the third quarter of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, members of the New York Stock Exchange, fell to $1.43million, or 18 cents a share, from $1.86million, or 24 cents a share, in the like period last year, Revenues rose to $19,40million from $11.11million.

title: Jury Panel of 650 Dismissed By Court in Chesimard Trial
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 18Middlesex County Judge John E. Bachman dismissed 650 persons from consideration as jurors in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Squire today after seven days of the selection process had shown that, contrary to court instructions, many had read about and discussed the case.

description: A crazed gunman killed two passersby and wounded two other men in crowded 34th Street in midtown Manhattan yesterday before he himself was mortally wounded in a gun battle with a retired detective and a garmentindustry executive.

title: Real G.N.P. Growth Was3.6% in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The nation's total output of goods and services grew by 3.6 per cent in the July to September quarter, the Commerce Department reported today. The relatively small increase was welcomed by a leading departmental economist as a sign that the national economy was off the overheated track.

title: Butz Opposes FarmExport Cut
description: Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz took a strong stand here yesterday against export controls on farm products as means of holding down food prices.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct, 18 (Reuters)  Yugoslavia said today that she was permitting Soviet flights over her territory to deliver supplies to the Arab side in the Middle East war.

title: Israelis See CeaseFire Only After Arab Defeat
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 18Israeli officials said tonight that they had received no new ceasefire proposals from President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and that they thought it unlikely that any new peace moves Would result from Soviet pressure on the Egyptians.

title: Boiardo's Daughter Killed While Cleaning a Window
description: LIVINGSTON, Oct. 18The 7yearold daughter of Ruggiero Boiardo, a patriarch of organized crime in New Jersey, was found dead yesterday at her home on her father's 29acre compound here, apparently the victim of a freakish accident.

title: McGraw Wins Guess Game
description: Bouncing toward the New York Mets' dugout last night after having stranded three Oakland A's runners in the seventh inning by fooling Bert Campaneris with a called third strike, Tug. McGraw noticed Mayor Lindsay holding a sign that proclaimed, Ya Gotta Believe, the team's battle cry.

title: M.I.T. Tuition Up $250
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP)The Massachusetts Institute of Technology will increase tuition $250, making the academic year costs $3,350 starting with the summer session next year.

description: A pilot project to generate cultural activities in lower Manhattan and eventually in other city neighborhoods was announced yesterday by the Carnegie Hall Corporation and Pace University.

description: TOWSON, Md., Oct. 18 (AP) The Baltimore County Bar Association has begun an investigation to determine whether disciplinary action will be taken against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Economist Who Speculates in Ideas
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 The winner of this year's Nobel Prize in economics is a bouncy engaging Russian migr, a scholar of small physical but enormous intellectual stature who gets as much excitement from snaring a big river trout as from leading a seminar in advanced economic theory. Since he arrived at Harvard as an instructor 42 years ago, Wassily Leontief and his highpitched heavily accented voice, craggy features and forceful didactic personality have become almost as much a Harvard fixture as the statue of John Harvard in the Yard.

title: Kennedy Seeks Ford Pledge on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that Congress should refuse to confirm Gerald R. Ford as Vice President unless he states that President Nixon should obey court orders to release White House tapes.

title: Saudis Cut Oil Output 10% To Put Pressure on U.S.
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 18 Saudi Arabia, the Arab world's largest oilproducing nation, announced tonight she was cutting back oil production by 10 per cent immediately in an attempt to put pressure on the United States to reduce its support for Israel.

title: 3 MEETINGS HELD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Egypt announced tonight that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union had held three long meetings in Cairo with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, presumably to discuss a diplomatic approach to settling the Middle East crisis.

title: NoTax Vow Stressed
description: CHERRY HILL, Oct. 18 Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican gubernatorial candidate, stepped up today his personal attack on his Democratic opponent, Brendan T. Byrne, as pollsters continued to find voters apathetic about he Nov. 6 election.

title: Jones Gets Shot Edge With a 65
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) Grier Jones, with some dramatic putting, carded a seven  under  par 65 today and took the firstround lead in the $150,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: Cards' Metcalf Injured
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (UPI) Terry Metcalf, the leading rusher for the St. Louis Cardinals this season, will miss next Sunday's game against the Redskins at Washington because of a twisted knee, the Cardinals said today. Metcalf would be replaced in the starting lineup by Don Shy and his place on the roster would be taken by Jim Otis.

title: ' I. F. Stone's Weekly' Is a Film Delight
description: It's only 62 minutes long. It was photographed in black and white with a religious austerity. It has no theme music. It is a documentary, and its title sounds like something glimpsed on an index card at the Public Library.Yet Jerry Bruck Jr.'s "I. F. Stone's Weekly," which opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, is such a thorough delight it left me feeling the way other people said they felt after seeing "The Sound of Music." That is, quite high.I should admit that "The Sound of Music" depressed me. It evoked civilization's imminent collapse. It made me think of the Chinese Communists and suspect that they'd be taking us over sooner rather than later. What was the use of thought or reason? Our minds have already turned into mashed potatoes.Or have they?Not, I think, as long as Isadore Feinstein Stone is on the American scene, passionately exposing the fallacies, double-talk and ignorance of the various rascals in Government, elected, appointed or there simply because of being someone's friend.I. F. Stone, now 66, has been a maverick all his life, a Communist anarchist in his youth, once described as "a strident voice of illiberalism" by Spiro T. Agnew, and now self-defined as a counter-revolutionary.Through it all, he has been the ferocious conscience of American journalists and those American citizens who would listen to him in person or who subscribed to his newsletter, which he started in 1952 and finally folded in 1971, when he moved his often dumfounded prose to the New York Review of Books."I. F. Stone's Weekly" is no dopey paean to a great man. Supplemented by a modest, informative commentary spoken by Tom Wicker, the film presents Izzy Stone straight, with all his eccentricities and enthusiasms intact, in interviews, in public speeches and even walking down to the corner to stuff a week's issue into the post box.We listen to Izzy describe a hilarious early confrontation with the Atomic Energy Commission (about underground testing), requiring him to make a visit to some seismology experts in the Commerce Department's Coast and Geodetic Survey. "They were so glad to see a reporter. I don't think they'd seen a reporter since there was a tremble from Mount Ararat, when Noah's Ark landed."He describes the danger for Washington correspondents who become pals with statesmen ("You begin to understand there are certain things the public ought not to know"). He talks about his own lean years as a blacklisted reporter and the genesis of his weekly, through which he taught all the rest of us how to find stories within stories, through inconsistencies, through information inadvertently made public but unnoticed by other reporters.The film brilliantly succeeds in communicating Stone's near-obsessive interest in truth and his optimism. The war in Vietnam, he suggests, and the survival of the Vietnamese people through years of bombing have re-established "the primacy of man in an age of technology."Toward the end Stone tells a group of students: "I really have so much fun I ought to be arrested." There is more to that statement than sentimental fondness for his profession. A cub reporter, he says, may get so excited covering a big fire that he forgets that something really it burning.As Jerry Bruck Jr. is lucky to have a subject as dynamic as Stone, so is Stone lucky to have a young film maker as persistent and as obsessed, in his way, as Bruck. "I.F. Stone's Weekly" has been three years in the making, on a shoestring, and in bits and pieces. The result is a rare film, a fitting tribute to a man who never gives up.

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18The Soviet Union lifted some of the secrecy from its space program today to permit George M. Low, deputy administrator of the American space program, and some of his aides to become the first foreigners to visit the main Soviet space mission control center outside Moscow.

Scull, at an auction last night that possessed as much decorum as postgame activities at Shea Stadium.

description: ATHENS, Oct. 18  Greece's allcivilian Government moved today to set, the stage for fair and free elections soon by ordering the stateowned radio and television to drop all political comments and all state and semistate organizations to stop discriminating against unfriendly newspapers.

description: This week's decline in corporate bond prices ended yesterday as several seasoned utility issues registered modest, gains in quiet trading.

title: HOUSE TAX PANEL WEIGHS REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Some key members of the House Ways and Means Committee disclosed today their plans to try to couple an increase in Social Security benefits with enough tax reform to pay for it.

title: Screen: For Anglophiles:' Optimist' Tells Tale of the Other London
description: Before proceeding to review "The Optimists," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, there are a few confessions I feel obligated to make.I am an unabashed Anglophile.I have been carrying on a torrid love affair with London for 18 years and expect it to endure for the rest of my life.I have recently been thinking about trying to lay my hands on some recordings of old English music hall tunes.Having said all that, I can now comfortably go on to say that I wallowed with porcine delight in "The Optimists." Its principal ingredients are an old busker (street entertainer) with a head full of music hall songs and jests, a couple of slum children and their poverty-calloused parents, a pair of dogs and London itself.A little bit of it is the London of touriststhe West End; but much of it is London south of the river, the London of Thames-side garbage dumps, looming power stations, squalid housing erected some 80 years ago and the new council flats that are the hope of a more comfortable life for thousands of people. And the director of photography Larry Pizer, has caught it all, and more, with a loving eye.On the level of story, "The Optimists," with songs and music by Lionel Bart, is the sort of old-fashioned excursion into sentiment that ought to warm the hearts of parents in search of that elusive piece of merchandise that goes under the name of good family entertainment.Peter Sellers, with a wardrobe of old music hall clothes, a talented but aged dog named Bella and a pram he pushes around London, plays the lonely, idiosyncratic old busker. And commendably, he submerges himself sufficiently in the part to allow old Sam to have a life of his own.David Daker and Marjorie as a London schoolgirl recruited for her role, is pure enchantment as the elder of the two children (John Chaffey plays her little brother) who befriend the busker and learn from him a little bit about the magic of life.David Daker and Marjorie Yates are letter-perfect in the thankless roles of the parents too busy surviving to worry about magic."People like you bring kids into the world, don't know what they're all about," Sellers says. On that subject, this film succeeds better than most.

title: Model of Capitol Damaged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) A 69yearold plaster model of the United States Capitol on display in the Capitol rotunda was slightly damaged today when a man threw a brief case through the glass case around the model. The Capitol police arrested Beachley L. Wright, 26 years old, of Washington D.C.

title: MAJOR SINAI CLASH
description: CAIRO, Oct. 18Egypt said today that a ferocious tank battle was being fought in the central sector of the Sinai front, involving large concentrations of tanks, other mechanized forces and planes on both sides.

title: GENE KRUPA FUNERAL IS HELD IN YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Oct. 18  This morning in a small parish chute here, Gene Krupa's friends and family came to bid farewell to the drummer who had revolutionized his art.

title: Judicial Moderation
description: The rejection by Chief District Judge Sirica of the Senate Watergate committee's request for the withheld White House tapes provides fresh evidence that the Federal courts, have been exercising maximum circumspection in their efforts to avoid the confrontation President Nixon seems determined to thrust upon them.

title: Leontief's Law
description: The award of the Nobel Prize in economic science to Prof. Wassily Leontief of Harvard is what coverers of the World Series call a natural. He invented a concept that made it theoretically possible to study the flows of production among all industriestracing out the farthest and least obvious impacts of major events, such as wars or energy shortages. He made this concept into a useful tool by the long and arduous work of developingand encouraging others to developthe necessary mathematics and essential data to describe real interindustry relationships, not merely the possible outcomes based on theoretical assumptions.

title: Red Smith
description: No matter who winds up with the rounders championship, and it is getting more and more evident that neither team can win, the 70th World Series will be treasured in history as the occasion when Charles O. Finley got his comeuppance. The egregious busher who owns the Oakland A's may be too insensitive to realize it yet, but when 54,817 baseball fans stood up to applaud Mike Andrews Wednesday night, they were also deriding the man who had tried to shove Andrews around. Now the big shaving soap opera returns to Oakland and daytime television, and if the customers in the Bay Area have the sense of fairness that sometimes distinguishes the clientele in Payson Place, Finley will get the same reception out there.

title: D'Ambrosio Widens Pa. Riding Lead
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. Oct. 18 (AP)  Tony D'Ambrosio, aboard Sympatico, triumphed again tonight at the 28th annual Pennsylvania National Horse Show before a crowd of 4,500.

title: There Is Style And Style
description: AUSTIN, TexasFrom my vantage point here at the bottom of the. Republic, I don't see any Great Changes coming from our Washington leadership.

title: Chile to Return Seized Companies to Their Owners
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 19The vast majority of United States companies brought under state control without compensation by the recently deposed Marxist coalition Government may be returned to their former management.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Milton Delano was 11 or 12 years old when a retired whaling captain taught him how to etch whales' teeth.

title: Carroll Heads Inner Circle
description: Maurice Carroll of The New York Times last night was elected president of the Inne Circle, an organization of past and present political writer and City Hall newsmen, at it annual installation dinner a the Roosevelt Hotel. John Toscano of The Daily News was elected vice president; John Mulligan of the Associated Press, treasurer, and Ralph Penza of WCBSTV, secretary Bert Kindig of United Press. In ternational, retiring president was elected chairman of the executive committee.

title: The Banker's Friend ...
description: Close personal friendship with the President of the United States carries with it a special obligation to avoid even the appearance that such a relationship might be exploited for personal, gain. By the same token, the integrity of the nation's highest office requires scrupulous avoidance on the part of the President of even the semblance of any obligation to his friends, especially when they are also his financial benefactors.

title: Soviet Missile Chief Killed In Plane Crash, Tass Says
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 19  Lieut. Gen. Fyodor M. Bondarenko, commander of the Soviet Air Defense Missile Forces, died in a plane crash near Moscow last Saturday, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: CHILE TO RETURN SEIZED COMPANIES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 19The vast majority of United States companies brought under state control without compensation by the recently deposed Marxist coalition Government may be returned to their former management.

title: Randy Johnson, on His Return, Is Not Sorry for Leaving Giants
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 19Randy Johnson found a new locker, some new plays and a new pass catcher, Brad Van Pelt, upon his return today to the New York Giants.

title: MISTRIAL RULED IN STURGIS CASE
description: MIAMI, Oct. 19A mistrial was declared in Federal District Court here today in a stolencar case in which one of the accused was Frank A. Sturgis, a convicted Watergate burglar.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Authorities in Newark disclosed yesterday that Black Muslim literature had been found in the pockets of two young black men whose decapitated bodies were found Thursday.

title: There Were Apples for Pickers in MidHudson Valley
description: CLAVERACK, N.Y., Oct. 19  Applepickers have been flocking to the midHudson Valley during the last few weeks, gathering almost the ripe apples from the trees in pickyourown orchards here.

title: ExCity Housing Aide Is Guilty Of Accepting a $1,500 Bribe
description: Charles S. Kee, former assistant commissioner in the Department of Housing and Maintenance and the socalled Mayor of Chinatown, was found guilty of conspiracy and bribereceiving charges in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: A Quiet City Campaign
description: Beyond the personalities of the candidates, there are no major arguments to spark the campaign. Representative Mario Biaggi sounded as if he was talking about a fraternity brother instead of a political opponent as he discussed Controller Abraham D. Beame recently. He's a nice man; he's been a good Controller and we're good friends. The Biaggi bouquets were sympomatic of what most politicians contend is the dullest major, campaign in recent history. Candidates don't have to be mean to be Mayor, but it makes for a livelier campaign. Instead, Mr. Beame has been called a nice man so often in this campaign that it sounds like a title.

title: One Museum on View at Another
description: Masterworks from the Museum of the American Indian, which opened to the public yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum, surely marks the first time that a New York museum, or a museum anywhere, has staged a major exhibition of works borrowed from another museum about half an hour away by taxi. It's a beautiful show, too, filled with sculpture and artifacts of such high quality, and often of such rarity, that a lot of New Yorkers who have visited all the other major museums across the country and in Europe are going to wonder where the Museum of thp American Indian, Heye Foundation (its full title), has been all their lives.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1973

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 19Tomorrow the World Series resumes here, where the left fielders and center fielders can't see a fly ball because of the low October sun. For three nights, the World Series was played in the October chill of New York, where a starting pitcher's arm stiffens after six or seven innings. Baseball advertises the World Series as its showcase event. But this year it has been a torture chamber for the players. It's wrong to embarrass outfielders. It's worse to jeopardize a pitcher's career. But the authorities of baseball don't appear concerned. Instead, they persist in stretching the season too long. In less than two weeks, November will be here. November. They're also unable to resist the extra TV money for the night games. Sooner or later, the Montreal Expos will be playing in the World Series. Game called, blizzard. Hopefully. Then again, they just might try to play in a blizzard.

title: FRANK T. M'CLURE, PHYCISIST, 57, DIES
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Oct. 19 (AP)  Dr. Frank T. McClure inventor of the Navy's satellite navigation system and an authority on combustion, rockets and guidedmissile technology, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

title: Salvaging Peace
description: Reports that the Soviet Union has proposed to Washington a plan for international peacekeeping in the Middle East, backed by bigpower guarantees of national borders, offer hope that a more secure and enduring peace may yet be salvaged from the fourth ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: 133 Gives Golf Lead To Schlee
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 19 (AP) John Schlee ripped five more strokes off par with a brilliant 67 today and moved into the secondround lead of the $150,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: Newark Council, in a Raucous Session, Votes to Keep Turco Despite Guilty Plea
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19The Newark City Council, voting along racial lines in a tumultuous meeting, rejected today a motion to have Councilman Louis M. Turco forfeit his seat because of his plea of guilty to Federal income tax charges.

title: Lefkowitz Meets Museum Chiefs on Art Disposal
description: Museum officials representing art and historical institutions throughout the state of New York told Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday that public disclosure of the disposal of art works by museums would seriously impair their ability to better and refine their collections.

title: Focus Shifts to Suez
description: Despite heavy and continued Egyptian counterattacks, apparently including tanks from the Cairo garrison, Israeli operations west, of the Suez Canal semi to be succeeding to the point where Western Military sources believe that the focus of the war has switched from the Sinai battle to control of the canal. Israeli forces, are reported to have pushed 15 miles into Egypt and to about 50 miles from Cairo The cost of what began as a diversion and is now a major front, according to all reports, combatant and neutral, has been heavy.

title: People and Business
description: James O. Leet, a former president of Northeast Airlines, has apparently moved into the No. 2 position at Pan American World Airways.

title: Lasker Award to Magnuson
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 19 (AP)Senator Warren G. Magnuson received the Lasker Public Service Award last night for the crucial legislative leadership guaranteeing that the major types of cancer will be conquered in his lifetime.

title: COURT REBUFFED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 President Nixon refused tonight to accept the order by the United States Court of Appeals to surrender the Watergate tapes, declined to take an appeal to the Supreme Court and ordered the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, to drop the case.

title: Portuguese Paper Closes
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 19 (AP)Diario de Noticias, the only Portuguese daily newspaper in America, published its last edition today. The publisher, Joao R. Rocha, blamed the closing on the newsprint shortage, rising taxes and falling readership.

title: The President's Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19President Nixon's chief justification for the action he nounced tonight on the disputed Watergate tapes was, in his words, his desire to avoid any possibility of a constitutional crisis. But the effect of his decision, to constitutional experts interviewed immediately following his statement, was that the President had instead created the biggest constitutional crisis of this already in crisisridden year.

title: Floyd's Markheim, Well Sung, Opens Club's Opera Series
description: Opera has come to the Manhattan Theater Club, a small but vigorous complex of tiny theaters in a town house at 321 East 73d Street. Carlisle Floyd's Markheim is the first in a series of operas planned for this season, and judging from the high quality on display Thursday night, it should he an exciting adjunct to the club's activities.

title: Dean Statement on Flea
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Following is a statement that John W. Dean 3d distributed to the press after his guilty plea today in the United States District Court here:

title: Army No Match for Irish
description: The Four Horsemen of Notre Dame were just sprightly Irish colts in 1922, the last year that Notre Dame and Army met in a football game at West Point. Jim Crowley, Don Miller, Harry Stuhldreher and Elmer Layden did not play as a unit for Notre Dame that day but they all shared in the action as the powerful teams battled to a scoreless tie before about 15,000 fans on a field adjoining the West Point Parade Grounds.

title: Ousted Premier Is Said to Plan An Eventual Return to Thailand
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The former Premier of Thailand, ousted by rebellious students, plans to go back to his country when conditions there return to normal, his soninlaw said today.

title: People in Sports: Hawley Is Up
description: Sandy Hawley is riding high. The jockey had five winners at Woodbine, Toronto, on Thursday to lift his total for the year to 404. He thus became the first rider in North America to reach that number in each of two seasons. I'm going for the 500, said Hawley, who last year was aboard 452 winners, when he was the leading rider on the continent. He has piloted 1,806 winners during his fiveyear career.

title: 15MILE GAIN CITED
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 19Israeli forces drove some 15 miles into Egypt today, knocking out artillery and missile batteries and expanding their bridgehead on the western side of the Suez Canal, a military spokesman reported.

title: U.S. Steel in Accord To Pay Back Taxes
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday it would pay approximately $96million in back taxes to settle a longstanding legal battle with the Justice Department over excess profits taxes in question since 1950.

title: Ford Home Town Conservative, Politically and Theologically
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 19  At Zondervan's religious bookstore in downtown Grand Rapids, where the stereo set plays What a Friend We Have in Jesus, the best seller these days is a volume called Satan is Alive and Well on Planet Earth. He may be, but if so, he is having a tough time of it in Grand Rapidsa city of stern values and stanch Republican conservatism; a dutiful, blond people of Dutch ancestry; a sparkling clean city of 200,000 people where one can fish for salmon in the rapids of the Grand River, right in the middle of town, and pheasants run across suburban streets; the center of the district that has sent Vice President designate Gerald R. lord to Congress for the last quarter of a century.

title: Music: Ameling Sings Wolf Songs, French Works
description: Outside the opera houses there is probably no soprano who has made more major appearances in New York in the last three years than Elly Ameling. Nevertheless, this gifted Dutch singer has not worn out her welcome. One reason is that she is still expanding her repertory and therefore continues to have something fresh to offer.

title: Censors Are Active on Both Sides in Mideast War
description: Censorship of news dispatches is practiced by both sides in the ArabIsraeli war.

title: 21 IN CHILE EXECUTED IN WEEK, JUNTA SAYS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 19The military Government said today that 21 people were executed this week.

title: Arab Emirate Said to Seek Big Bank Loan in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 19Abu Dhabi, one of the major Arab oil producers, has been negotiating here this week to obtain a multimilliondollar bank loan, according to highly placed community.

title: Polaroid Plummets Despite Explanation
description: The Polaroid Corporation invited more than 150 analysts to the Science Museum in Cambridge, Mass., Thursday for a presentation clearly designed to inspire confidence that the pictureinminutes camera and film maker was progressing well with its revolutionary new SX70 cameras.

title: Ford Says Nixon Will Veto Bills That Would Exceed Budget Goal
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 19 (AP)President Nixon will continue to veto bills and to impound funds if Congress passes budgetbreaking legislation, Vice Presidentdesignate Gerald R. Ford said today.

title: OLIVIA STAPP SINGS ANNA BOLENA ROLE
description: Henry VIII of England was notorious for the multiplicity of his wives. The New York City Opera, in its presentation of Anna Bolena, is compounding the situation.

title: Museum Chiefs Meet to Discuss Art Disposal
description: Museum officials representing art and historical institutions throughout the state of New York told Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday that public disclosure of the disposal of art works by museums would seriously impair their ability to better and refine their collections.

title: American Surgeons Elect
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP)Dr. Charles McLaughlin of Omaha is the new presidentelect of the American College of Surgeons. A professor of surgery at the University of Nebraska, he will succeed Dr. Claude E. Welch, professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School.

title: Helen Childs Boyden, 90, Dies; Teacher at Deerfield 50 Years
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 19Mrs. Helen Childs Boyden, instructor of science and mathematics at Deerfield Academy, for most of the years from 1905 to 1968, and widow of Frank L. Boyden, principal of the academy from 1902 to 1968, died today, at her home here. She was 90 years old.

title: Gaullists in Bitter Debate On Basic Issues of Policy,
description: PARIS, Oct. 19The dominant Gaullist party, in power sine President Charles de Gaulle created the Fifth Republic in 1958, is roiling with an increasingly sharp internal argument. The very meaning of Gaullism has become an open question.

title: Monsanto Reports 192% Rise in Profits
description: The Monsanto Company, leading chemical company, reported yesterday an increase in earnings in the third quarter of 192 per cent.

title: DONALD NEWHOUSE NEWSPAPER OFFICIAL
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 19 (AP)  Donald R. Newhouse, general manager of the Springfield newspapers, died yesterday during heart surgery at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. His age was 54.

title: Bank Holdup Suspect Seized
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP)  Acting on an anonymouse tip, the state police raided an apartment here last night and arrested a man on bank robbery charges. Tropers identified him as David Wronk, 24 years old. They said they had recovered a revolver and some of the nearly $4,400 taken in an armed robbery Wednesday of the Chester National Bank in the Orange County community of Otisville.

title: Citizens Group Warns of Peril To Children From '74 Car Belts
description: DETROIT, Oct. 19 (UPI)The Federal safety law that requires adults to buckle up seat and shoulder belts before they drive away in a 1974 car may be a hazard for children.

title: Nobel Peace Prize Is Drawing Taunts and Debate
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 19The wags in Stockholm are saying that people ought to save their comic books because the next winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature might be Walt Disney.

title: Hospital on S.I. Votes to Close As Its Employes Picket Outside
description: The board of directors of Richmond Memorial Hosiptal and Health Center on Staten Island voted last night to suspend operations at the 53yearold institution.

title: Progress in Turkey
description: After thirty months under martial law and military domination, Turkey has taken a long stride toward restoration of fullfledged civilian government with an election that produced an upset. The Republican People's party, reorganized and redirected toward Western Europe's Social Democrats, finished well in front of the Justice party of former Premier Suleyman Demirel.

title: Tourists Leave Mideast at Last; Some Report Side Trip to War
description: MARSEILLES, France, Oct. 19 (UPI)A group of 830 tourists stranded in Egypt for eight days by the Middle East war arrived from Alexandria, Egypt, today aboard a French liner.

title: A More Relaxed Byrne Shows Humorous Side
description: TRENTON, Oct. 19There still are days on the campaign trail when Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, tell the same joke five different times to five different audiences without altering his delivery an iota.

title: Corporate Profile
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 The Crocker Bank, which has just become the owner of the scandalridden United States National Bank in San Diego, has traditionally been known here as the staid, old Republican bank of San Francisco.

title: American Dies as Beirut Quells Rebels
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19The siege of the Bank of America branch seized by leftist guerrillas here yesterday ended today with policemen and army commandos fighting their way in to rescue 39 hostages. Before the battle ended, the guerrillas killed an American hostage.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FIRST DEADLY SIN. By Lawrence Sanders. 566 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $8.95. PLEASE PASS THE GUILT. By Rex Stout. 150 pages. The Viking Press. $5.95.

title: A Windfall for Airlines
description: The projected oil shortage this winter has proved, in roundabout way, to be a windland fall for the nation's major airlines. Although the implications are not completely clear, industry experts believe that the fuel shortage could help to set in motion a fundamental change in how America's air transport system operates. It depends on one's point of view whether this is good or bad. The airlines are using the emergency jet fuel allocation program promulgated by the White House last week to accelerate something that they have been striving for anyway: Federal sanction of airline agreements that limit, by prearrangement, the number of jets that competing airlines fly on the same route.

title: PROSECUTOR FIRM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special Watergate prosecutor, declared tonight that he would not accept President Nixon's order that he cease his attempts to obtain the White House tapes through judicial action.

title: HENRY C. HOHNS
description: Henry C. Hohns, who retired in 1968 as vice president and sales manager of Charles Scribner's Sons, the book publishers, died Monday in an automobile accident in South Salem, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Medford Lakes, N.J.

title: Beirut Bank Retaken, American Is Killed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19The siege of the Bank of America branch seized by leftist guerrillas here yesterday ended today with policemen and army commandos fighting their way in to rescue 39 hostages. Before the battle ended, the guerrillas killed an American hostage.

title: HARRISON L. REINKE
description: SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 19Harrison L. Reinke, headmaster of the Fay School from 1942 until his retirement in 1969, died yesterday at his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: Mercer Public Works Official Is Indicted on Extortion Charge
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19A superintendent of public works and buildings for Mercer County was charged with extortion and with having filed a false income tax for 1968, according to an announcement today by United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern.

title: Food Price Drop Limits Climb in Consumer Index
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Food prices fell in September for the first time this year, and as a result the Consumer Price Index posted a comparatively small rise, the Government reported today.

title: KNEEL IS INVITED TO PAPERS TALKS
description: The head of the city's typographical union told members of its New York Times unit yesterday that he had agreed to join with the management of The Times in asking Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, to assist in the union's negotiations with the city's major newspapers.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOG DAY The East River Kennel Club is a nonorganization consisting of two dog lovers who have gotten together with the BideAWee Home, an established shelter group, and will put on a dog show tomorrow from 2 to 5 P.M. on the hill by the East River between 85th and 86th Streets in Carl Schurz Park.

title: Austin V. Wood Dies at 80, Publisher of Ogden Chain
description: WHEELING, W. V., Oct. 19 (AP)  Austin V. Wood, executive vice president and publisher of Ogden Newspapers, Inc., died Friday at the age of 80.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FIRST DEADLY SIN. By Lawrence Sanders. 566 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $8.95. PLEASE PASS THE GUILT. By Rex Stout. 150 pages. The Viking Press. $5.95.

title: KISSINGER ON WAY TO MOSCOW TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Oct. 20President Nixon early this morning dispatched Secretary of State Kissinger on a mission to Moscow to discuss with Soviet leaders means to end hostilities in the Middle East.

title: Those Not Called Are Restless At Top Israeli Research School
description: REHOVOT, Israel, Oct. 18Israeli officials describe the present state of mobilization of the country's manpower as less than total, and it is, compared with the 1967 war. But here, on the parklike campus of the Weizmann Institute, the measure of even a partial mobilization can be taken.

title: Forms Filled With Fantasy and Energy
description: The two exhibitions of new work by the American painter Al Held, currently occupying both of the Andr Emmerich galleriesuptown at 41 East 57th Street, downtown at 420 West Broadway constitute an event of uncommon interest. In these new paintings, some of the recently established pieties of abstract paintings are given an unusual twist. We are suddenly made to see certain formsespecially the geometrical forms of the minimalistsin a new way.

title: Neighbors Jam Brooklyn Church To Mourn Murdered Father of 4
description: Eugene T. Grieshaber, 41yearold father of four who died on his doorstep after being shot by muggers, was mourned yesterday by friends and neighbors who jammed St. Sylvester's Roman Catholic Church at Grant and McKinley Avenues, Brooklyn, far his funeral.

title: COPPER DECLINES ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Rumors involving the Middle East war led to substantial price declines for three metalscopper, platinum and silver yesterday. Traders do not like to be in a skittish market over a long weekend and there will be no futures trading in the three metals here on Monday because of Veterans Day. Therefore, there was a large amount of profit taking and liquidation of long positions.

title: Burned Body Is Found
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP)  A meter man on his rounds yesterday discovered the burned body of a woman, the police said. The police identified the woman as Jeane Saine Sain, 43 years old.

title: Israel Says Red Cross Visits 845 Prisoners
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 19 (Reuters)Israel announced tonight that representatives of the International Red Cross were allowed today to visit 845 Egyptian, Syrian and Iraqi prisoners of war held in camps here.

title: New London's New Mall Fights Decay in Downtown
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 18State Street, the onceelegant promenade here that has fallen victim in recent years to the, flight to the suburbs, the fear of crime and the lure of the shopping center, is being reborn this week as a bright new pedestrian mall that merchants and city officials believe will spearhead the revitalization of this 327yearold former whaling capital.

title: Egypt Minimizes Threat Of Israelis
description: CAIRO, Oct. 19Egyptian officials said tonight that an Israeli tank column that crossed to the west bank of the Suez Canal yesterday was no longer a serious threat.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dr. D. B. Louria (letter of Sept. 14) finds no evidence that heroinaddicted criminals are excessively responsible for the upsurge in urban violence. He opposes regressive and punitive approaches for this group and criticizes police failure to differentiate between heroin use and dependence.

title: Dean Pleads Guilty in Deal; Will Aid the Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19John W. Dean 3d, the former counsel to President Nixon, pleaded guilty today to plotting to cover up the truth about the Watergate breakin.

title: Tropical Storm Hits Bahamas; Threat to Florida Is Diminished
description: MIAMI, Oct. 19 (AP)Tropical Storm Gilda veered to the northeast away from the Florida coast today and lashed the Bahamas with winds of 65 miles an hour and heavy rains.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: McAFEE, N. J., Oct. 19Football is still in the air and the colorful leaves on the maples and oaks still cling to the branches in this northern New Jersey ski country. Nevertheless, Mrs. Anna Fitzgerald has been getting ready for winter since last August.

title: Arid, Forbidding Sinai: A Backdrop to History
description: The Sinai Peninsula is a triangular land bridge joiningand separatingAsia and Africa.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Seaport Museum Plans Big Expansion
description: The South Street Seaport Museum disclosed yesterday an ambitious plan for development that, through a combination of restoration and new construction, will bring seven square blocks of exhibitions, commercial facilities and housing to its riverfront site south of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Women Who Feel Uncomfortable About Success
description: KERHONKSEN, N.Y.The 20 women, weekending recently in this Catskills community, all had at least two things in common  they were feminists and they owned their own businesses.

title: Splitting Bridge a Concern Of Community in Brooklyn
description: A bridge complex that carries a major avenue and a subway line over an open railroad cut in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn appears to be splitting apart, causing concern among nearby residents and disputes among public agencies, the railroad and a construction company over who is responsible for repair.

title: Chris Evert Gets Semifinal Berth
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 19 (Reuters)  Topseeded Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., advanced to the semifinals of the $110,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today at the Boca Raton Hotel and Club by defeating seventhseeded Julie Heldman of Houston, Tex., 62, 64.

title: WOMAN FOUND SLAIN IDENTIFIED AS SINGER
description: MIDDLETOWN, Oct. 19 The seminude body of a darkhaired woman found in a wooded area of Middletown Township was identified yesterday as that of Judith A. Golub, 22 years old, of 364 East 49th Street, Brooklyn. According to the police Mrs. Golub, a singer, was strangled with plastic tubing sometime before midnight Tuesday. She was last seen at 10 P.M. that evening at the Copper Top, a popular roadside bar, on Route 35, where she and her husband Mitchell were engaged as a singing guitar team.

title: Authors and Actors Fill Shubert Alley In Rally for Israel
description: With the background of a large sign, Broadway for Israel, authors and entertainers of stage, screen and television gathered in Shubert Alley last night in support of Israel in the Middle East war.

title: Jackson and Kennedy Assail President
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 19 Two prospective Democratic Presidential candidates, Senators Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetti, resumed today the massive attacks on President Nixon that have been the dominant theme of the labor federation's convention here.

title: TWO UNIONS JAM LA GUARDIA ROADS
description: A 150car motorcade assembled by employes of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey crawled in circles around the ramps and roadways of La Guardia Airport late yesterday in a job action that, for more than an hour, clogged traffic in defiance of a court order.

title: Egypt. Minimizes Threat Of Israelis on West Bank
description: CAIRO, Oct. 19Egyptian officials said tonight that an Israeli tank column that crossed to the west bank of the Suez Canal yesterday was no longer a serious threat.

title: Tanzania Breaks With Israel
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct, 19Tanzania today became the seventh African country to break relations with Israel this month and the 14th since Uganda did on March 30 last year. A Tanzanian statement accused Israel of aggression in the Mideast.

title: Drop in Prime Rate Helps. As Big Board Prices Rise
description: The longawaited cut in the prime lending rate by several of the nation's largest banks helped the stock market to produce a modest gain yesterday after two days of easing prices.

title: WILLARD W. COLE
description: OAK PARK, Ill., Oct. 19Willard W. Cole, former president of the retail stores division of Cluett, Peabody & Co., Inc., and chairman of the board of Lytton's, a Chicago specialty store, died today at a hospital here. He was 65 years old.

title: NEW ACTION ON I.T.T. SOUGHT BY NADER
description: BRIDGEPORT, Oct. 19Ralph Nader again petitioned Federal court today to reopen the case of the controversial merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: Blackout Doesn't Dim Life in Tel Aviv Cafes
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 19With the guns booming hundreds of miles away, the colorful outdoor cafes of Tel Aviv's Dizengoff Street were overflowing this preSabbath afternoon. The cafes have continued to do a brisk business even at night, when determined cafesitters convert to candlelight during the rigorously enforced blackout.

title: MORRIS EDER DEAD; A RETIRED JUSTICE
description: Former Justice Morris Eder of the State Supreme Court, First Judicial District, embracing New York and Bronx Counties, died yesterday in his sleep at his home, 24 Fifth Avenue. He was 86 years old.

title: At Least 8 Are Killed as Truck Hits a Bus on Jersey Turnpike
description: BORDENTOWN, N. J., Saturday. Oct. 20At least eight persons were killed and 13 were injuredperhaps nine of them critically  last night when a tractortrailer loaded with meat collided head on with a New Yorkbound Greyhound bus on the New Jersey Turnpike near here.

title: Youth Seized on LSD Charge
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 19 (UPI)Erie County sheriff's deputies said today that they confiscated more than 100 LSD tablets and arrested an 18yearold Buffalo youth in West Seneca late yesterday. The pills were confiscated when the deputies stopped a car for a routine check.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Richard M. Rosenbaum, the Republican state chairman, visited State Senator John J. Marchi's mayoral campaign headquarters yesterday to spread balm but not money.

title: Way to Improve Stereo Sound Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Two Columbia Broadcasting System engineers believe the concert hall can now really be brought into the living room. Equipment they have invented for the purpose is to be introduced at a news conference in New York late next month. Donald R. Sauvey, vice president and general manager of Electro Music, a Week C.B.S. unit in Pasadena, Calif., and Paul H. Sharp, a staff electronics engineer, were granted Patent 3,766,317 this week.

title: Syrians Putting War Aims Ahead of Economic Ones
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 19 The cost of Syria's war effort, and the damage already caused by Israeli bombing attacks, represent a heavy blow to the development plans of this relatively poor country.

title: Senator Baker Hails Nixon's Plan to Turn Over Authenticated Version of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The senior. Republican on the Senate Watergate committed hailed tonight President Nixon's proposal to turn over an authenticated version of the White House tapes to the in vestigating committee.

title: Cutoff in Oil to U.S. Ordered by Libya
description: Libya fired a doublebarrel blast of her oil weapon yesterday by ordering a cutoff of all shipments of crude oil and petroleum products to the United States and almost doubling prices for other importers.

title: An Artist in a Class by Himself
description: Although he rose to prominence as one of the brighter stars of British pop art, in the nineteensixties, David Hockney has emerged as an artist in a class by himself. In his paintings and prints of the last decade, he has begun to seem more a lively and sometimes caustic observer of the pop scenea kind of latterday Hogarth of the pop lifestylerather than a rankandfile pop artist.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on conference report CD oft bill limiting the President's 25. power to commit troops to hos 26. tilities in foreign countries, which 27. passed, 238 to 123, Oct. 12. 28.

title: Most Markets Open Monday
description: Major stock exchanges will he open on Monday, Veterans Day. However, commodity markets in Chicago and New York, as well as New York foreign exchange markets, will be closed.

title: Mets Look to Seaver to Finish World Series Today
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 19Yogi Berra flew back to California today for what he hoped would be the final game of a season that he had spent chiefly in denying that he was the incompetent manager of a hopeless team.

title: ROLLO L. DE WILTON
description: Rollo L. De Wilton, a retired editor at the Macmillan Company, died Tuesday at his apartment at 200 West 20th Street. He was 89 years old.

title: Merger Deal Is Proposed By Florida National Banks
description: An agreement for the proposed acquisition by Florida National Banks of Florida, Inc., of seven banks owned by the Charter Bankshares Corporation was announced yesterday.

title: DelBello in Westchester
description: The choice is clear in the Westchester race for County Executive between Yonkers Mayor Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat, and County Clerk Edward N. Vetrano, a Republican. Mayor DelBello has been an active, enlightened municipal leader who has earned esteem for stemming the spreading blight in Yonkers, revitalizing community areas, providing residents with improved public service while eliminating a budgetary deficit and holding down local taxes. Mr. Vetrano's lone accomplishment is winning his party's crowded primary as the faithful representative of its most backwardlooking element.

title: Freedom in Retreat
description: Grim news confronted members of the InterAmerican Press Association at its annual meeting in Boston this week. German Ornes of the Dominican Republic, chairman of the association's Committee on Freedom of the Press and Information, told the delegates that a genuinely free press now exists in only four LatinAmerican countries. And in two of theseArgentina and Guyana the threat of government interference is rising.

title: The Spirit of Issimomism
description: Flippant, impertinent, childish and unworthy questions which, like so many childish questions, may madden those who try to answer them and which are, therefore, perhaps best dealt with by a snarled, Beat it, kid!, other things in life being just as important as children:

title: N.B.C. Sues to End Ban On Jersey Court Sketches
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it had filed suit in a New Jersey Federal Court challenging the constitutionality of a state court ruling forbidding artists from making courtroom sketches.

title: Zachary Taylor House On Market in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19 (UPI)A house once owned by Zachary Taylor, the 12th President of the United States, has been placed on the market at a price of $126,000.

title: 100th Homicide in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The 100th homicide victim in Boston this year was recorded today when a Brockton man was shot and killed in Park Square. John C. Rhoden, 49 years old, was shot three times in the chest by a man he asked to move from in front of his car, the police said.

title: PROFITS AT EXXON SOAR 80 PER CENT
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum company, yesterday estimated that its thirdquarter earnings soared 80 per cent to $638million from $353million a year earlier.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Art: Show of Pioneers of Abstraction
description: If a show can be called a sleeper only three days after opening, that's the word for Pioneers of American Abstraction at the Andrew Crispo Gallery, 41 East 57th Street. It isn't all that abstract, the artists being Oscar Bluemner, Stuart Davis, Charles Demuth, Arthur Dove, John Marin, Georgia O'Keeffe, Charles Sheeler, Joseph Stella and Max Weber  and these not always at their most abstract even so. Fully half the pictures could as easily serve for a show called Prophets of HardEdge Realism, if you wanted to force a point. These would include the Sheelers, the Demuths and most of the O'Keeffes.

title: Series Pitchers Today
description: TOM SEAVER, a righthander, is making his second start Of the Series, having pitched in the third game Tuesday night at Shea Stadium. Frequently called, by the experts the best pitcher around today, the Met ace is known for his fastball, breaking curve and outstanding control. Against the A's, he walked only one man. Seaver, who averaged more than six strikeouts a game during the season, did even better against Oakland, fanning 12 in eight innings. The score was tied at 2all when he left for a pinchhitter. Seaver finished the regular season with a 1910 record and a 2.08 earnedrun average, with 251 strikeouts. A tender shoulder in September slowed his speed a bit.

title: Brigde: Card Players' Performances Are Not Entirely Consistent
description: Bridgeplayers do not give entirely consistent performances, any more than do race horses or sports stars or actors who occasionally rise to great heights or sink to unexpected depths. A player of moderate experience can look like a beginner and look like an expert, even within the confines of a single deal.

title: If a Tree Has Business With the Sky
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y.The horsechestnut leaves browned and fell in August. Along the September highway trees too soon finished drooped in a wrap of their own burlap. The sugar maples are holding their leaves too long, Why? They say it means a severe winter when the trees don't drop their leaves, when the squirrels store extra nuts, when the sheep grow thicker coats, when earthworms blink.

title: High School Notes
description: The financially ailing Harlem Prep will get a new chance to survive next week when Chancellor Irving Anker sends to the Board of Education a resolution supporting the school's efforts to be absorbed into the regular system as a city high school.

title: TWO UNIONS JAM LA GUARDIA ROADS
description: A 150car motorcade assembled by employes of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey crawled in circles around the ramps and roadways of La Guardia Airport late yesterday in a job action that, for more than an hour, clogged traffic in defiance of a court order.

title: Business Briefs
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 17 (AP)The amount of damages to be assessed against the International Business Machines Corporation in the Telex Corporation's antitrust suit against the giant computer maker will be revised downward before the complex suit goes to the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit. Federal District Court Judge A. Sherman Christensen said today.

title: Chinese Food For China
description: SIAN, China  Probably China's greatest internal preoccupation is the race between food supply and population growth. In this land of statistical secrecy it is hard to arrive at definitive conclusions. Yet there is every sign that, despite their increasing number, the Chinese people are being better fed. I have talked with farmers on two communes, one in Peking and one in this province of Shensi, and they seemingly confirm that despite poor weather this year, China will reap a bumper crop.

title: Major Banks Lower Prime Rate to 9%
description: The prime rate was cut yesterday for the first time since January, 1972.

title: 15MILE GAIN CITED
LOSS IS $8.4MILLION AT DUPONT WALSTON
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., one of several large brokerage firms that vies for the title of second largest after Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith, Inc., reported yesterday that it had operated in the three months ended Aug. 31 at a loss of $8.4million. This did not include $1.5million reserved for doubtful accounts, nor $2.7million of extraordinary items of expense and losses resulting from the realignment of duPont Walston and duPont Glore Forgan.

title: EXSENATOR AIDS BOMBER'S DEFENSE
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19Former Senator Ernest Gruening of Alaska called all acts of resistance to the Vietnam war fully justified in whatever form they take in testimony here today at the presentencing hearing for Karleton Armstrong, who has pleaded guilty, to bombing a university research center.

title: SANDMAN COURTS ORGANIZED LABOR
description: HILLSIDE, Oct. 19 Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. took his appeal for votes today to the rank and file of organized labor, whose leaders are lined up solidly behind his Democratic rival, Brendan T. Byrne.

title: OLIVIA ST APP SINGS ANNA BOLENA ROLE
description: Henry VIII of England was notorious for the multiplicity of his wives. The New York City Opera, in its presentation of Anna Bolena, is compounding the situation.

title: Carreras, Tenor, Replaced
description: Jose Carreras, who was scheduled to sing the leading tenor role in Massenet's Manon with the New York City Opera tomorrow night, is Ill. He will be replaced by Guiseppe Campora.

title: ANDERSON DENIES MARYLAND GUILT
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 (AP)N. Dale Anderson, who succeeded Spiro T. Agnew as Baltimore County Executive, pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges related to alleged kickbacks from contractors in return for government business.

title: Floyd's Markheim, Well Sung, Opens Club's Opera Series
description: Opera has come to the Manhattan Theater Club, a small but, vigorous complex of tiny theaters in a town house at 321 East. 73d Street. Carlisle Floyd's Markheim is the first in a series of operas planned for this season, and judging from the high quality on display Thursday night, it should be an exciting adjunct to the club's activities.

title: RATINGS FLAG WON BY WORLD SERIES
description: The World Series on the National Broadcasting Company, not unexpectedly, dominated primetime television this week and wrecked the program strategies of the other networks.

title: PARENTS' CONVICTION IN SLAYING IS UPHELD
description: ALBANY, Oct. 19 (AP)The convictions of Charles and Marlene Henson in the 1970 death of their 4yearold son, Kip, have been upheld by the state's highest court.

title: Music: Ameling Sings at Tully Hall
description: Outside the opera houses there is probably no soprano who has made more major appearances in New York in the last three years than Elly Ameling. Nevertheless, this gifted Dutch singer has not worn out her welcome, One reason is that she is still expanding her repertory and therefore continues to have something fresh to offer.

title: COUNTER STOCKS AND AMEX ARE UP
description: Prices finished higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market spurred by the news that a number of the nation's large banks had lowered their prime lending rate.

title: Penn Downs Lehigh, 2720, for 34th Time in a Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19Footballs were expected to fill the air at Franklin Field tonight as the University of Pennsylvania faced Lehigh. The night game, a nonIvy League affair for the Quakers, was the second in the school's football history, which dates to 1876.

title: Coast Judge Refuses to Dismiss 2 Charges Against Ehrlichman
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19. (UPI) Judge James G. Kolts of the Superior Court refused today to dismiss charges of conspiracy and burglary against John D. Ehrlichmann and three other former White House aides.

title: Judge Returns Fuentes to School Post
description: A Federal judge yesterday reinstated Luis Fuentes as superintendent of Community School District 1, pending the outcome of a suit challenging the validity of last spring's school board elections in that Lower East Side district.

title: Antiques: Gaudi's Style
description: Reactions to Antoni Gaudi's designs usually run to extremes. They are loathed or lionized, dismissed immediately exhaustively examined to understand every detail that issued from the Spanish architect's unorthodox and prodigious mind.

title: Plea Is Made for More Black Educators
description: Local boards of education in Northern cities can expect Federal lawsuits to be brought against them as part of an effort to increase the number of black educators in public, schools, an official of the National Education Association said here yesterday.

title: Eban Leaves U.N. for Israel To Join CabinetLevel Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minigter, left New York this evening for Israel, where he will participate in Cabinetlevel consultations.

title: FREDERICK MAUER
description: MATAWAN, N. J., Oct. 19Frederick Mauer, who retired in 1970 as president of the Monmouth Container Corporation, a division of the Container Corporation of America, died yesterday at his home here, His age was 66.

title: Arms Meeting in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Oct. 19 (UPI)United States and Soviet negotiators today held their 42d meeting in the second round of the strategic arms limitation talks. The next meeting is scheduled for Tuesday.

title: ExCity Housing Aide Is Guilty Of Accepting a $1.400 Bribe
description: Charles S. Kee, former assistant commissioner in the Department of Housing and Maintenance and the socalled Mayor of Chinatown, was found guilty of conspiracy and bribereceiving charges in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 19  Johnny Roche left the bench and scored 14 points in the second half, spoiled the homecoming of Butch Van Breda Kolff, the Memphis coach, and led the New York Nets to a 10188, victory in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Margaret Anderson Dies at 82; Founded Little Review in 1914
description: PARIS, Oct. 19Margaret C. Anderson, who introduced works by Joyce, Eliot, Yeats, Pound, Hemingway and other writers in the avantegarde, in The Little Review, which she founded in 1914, died at Le Cannet, France, last night after a long illness. She was 82 years old.

title: ACTIVITY UP A BIT IN SHORT INTEREST
description: The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose slightly in the latest month. The exchange reported yesterday that as of the close of business on the settlement date of Oct. 15, reflecting transactions through Oct. 8, the shares in the short interest increased to 16,915,545 shares from 16,844,252 shares on Sept. 14.

title: PROSECUTION ASKS MITCHELL DELAY
description: The prosecution, in a surprise move, requested yesterday a postponement of the scheduled trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stens in Federal District Court here.

title: Army No Match for Irish
description: The Four Horsemen of Notre Dame were just sprightly Irish colts in 1922, the last year that Notre Dame and Army met in a football game at West Point. Jim Crowley, Don Miller, Harry Stuhldreher and Elmer Layden did not play as a unit for Notre Dame that day but they all shared in the action as the powerful teams battled to a scoreless tie before about 15,000 fans on a field adjoining the West Point Grounds.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)There is little evidence to support the professional football players' complaint that artificial turf causes more serious injuries than natural grass, the Consumer Products Safety Commission said today.

title: Food Price Drop Limits Climb in Consumer Index
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Food prices fell in September for the first time this year, and as a result the Consumer Price Index posted a comparatively small rise, the Government reported today.

title: Notes on People
description: Gustav Heinemann, President of West Germany, was struck in the face and knocked to the floor yesterday by a knifecarrying man, who was later described as mentally disturbed. Dr. Heinemann, who is 74 years old, was shaken up but otherwise unharmed.

title: Music: Nilsson Ovation
description: The Program

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A $750,000 bikeway leading to Jones Beach on both: sides of the Wantagh Parkway will be built by next sun mer if the state's $3.5billion transportation bond issue is approved, according to Henry L. Diamond, Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conser, vation. Mr. Diamond, who is also a member of the Long Island State Park Commission, which operates Jones Beach, said the proposed bike route would run four and a hall miles, from Merrick Road to Parking Lot 4 at the beach.

title: Dean Can't Get Passport, Locked in White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI)John W. Dean 3d, former Presidential counsel was unable to surrender his passport to a Federal judge today after he pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy in the Watergate coverup.

title: The Screen: Robbers vs. Robbers
description: The Cast

title: Miami Bows By 307 to Houston
description: MIAMI, Oct. 19 (AP)Fourteenthranked Houston opened up Miami's defense on the secondhalf passing of D. C. Nobles tonight and rolled to a 307 victory after breaking a 77 deadlock with two thirdperiod touchdowns in 20 seconds.

title: For Families, Brooklyn Lies Between City and Suburbs
description: Bruce Porter sat in the parlor of his Brooklyn brownstone wearing a paintsplotched work shirt and the look of a man who has spent too many years stripping walls and would rather not talk about it.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: House Votes Extension for Unit Aiding SpanishSpeaking People
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The House voted yesterday to extend the life of a Cabinetlevel advocacy committee for Spanishspeaking persons but put restrictions on its political activities. The bill went to the Senate which refered it to committee.

title: RICHARDSON CALLED ALBERT ABOUT AGNEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Speaker of the House, Carl Albert, Democrat of Oklahoma, disclosed today that he received a phone call from Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson only minutes after former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew made a personal appearance at the Capitol asking for a Congressional inquiry into the charges against him.

title: The Proof's in Running For Linda's Chief Today
description: Aaron Jones, the Oregon lumber magnate who bought Linda's Chief for $1.8million last summer, will be in town today to see whether his presence can make the colt run again. Linda's Chief, rated highly among this year's crop of 3yearolds, is among the 10 listed for today's 104th running of the Jerome Handicap at Aqueduct Jones has yet to see the colt win a stakes event under his colors, but he did see him score a sixlength victory in au allowance exhibition at Monmouth Park last July.

title: Strikers List 2 Concerts
description: Members of the New York Philharmonic, on strike against the orchestra management, will take part In two benefits. One is a program of chamber music on behalf of strikers against the Museum of Modern Art, to be given next Thursday at 8 P.M, at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street. The ful ]orchestra will play for its own strike fund in Carnegie Hall at 8 P.M. on Oct. 29, under the direction of Leon Barzin.

title: Carr Given Center Role By Rangers
description: In their fashions, New York's three hockey teams will be attempting to prove different things tonight.

title: At Insolvent Bank, It's Business Almost as Usual
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 19The United States National Bank ?? San Diego, declared insolvens yesterday, opened its 63 offices for business this morning at branches of the Crocker Bank of San Francisco.

title: On to Disneyland and the Real Unreality
description: I have to go to Disneyland. I mean I really do have to go. For years when my children begged me to take them, I gave them a nice round uh huh designed to shut them up. I couldn't explain to them that I saw Snow White and the Cowardly Lion and the alligators every morning. That there were no fantasies in California that had not seen in New York. Besides, it was too tiringbeing jostled by strangers who might not want to remain that way; having a female bus burner with, seams in her stockings strike up a friendly conversation with me just to talk about her devoted black baby sitter; and me listening with a nod and a smile hoping that my contempt (which I am able to express only by refusing to enlighten herby encouraging her, in fact, to remain obtuse and white and gothic) will be permanent. I could never explain, so we never went.

title: Text of Nixon's Statement on the Watergate Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Following is the text of President Nixon's statement today on the Watergate tapes:

title: WINE TALK
description: BORDEAUX, FranceThe morning air is crisp in the Medoc and the sound of the hunters' guns is muffled by the mist that clings in the woods and lowlands. The vineyards, except for a few in the Sauterne and Barsac, are empty because the 1973 harvest is over.

title: S.E.C. Is Studying Banks' Stock Plans
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI) Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Cora mission, said today the S.E.C. had decided to try to determine whether bank stock investment plans were illegally infringing on the securities industry.

title: Police Get No Calls in Killing of Brooklyn Man
description: Twentyfour hours after they set up a special telephone number 4697895 to receive information about the brutal killing of a 70yearold man, the detectives of the 12th District Homicide Squad in Brooklyn were still waiting last night for their first call.

title: C. A. Smith, Nixon's Ally, Seeing Empire in Eclipse
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 19The mounting legal troubles of C. Arnholt Smith, who for years basked in the civic accolade of Mr. San Diego of the Century, were blamed today for the insolvency of his United States National Bank and the overnight acquisition of assets by the Crocker Bank of San Francisco.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Nixon Asks $2.2Billion in Emergency Aid for Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 President Nixon asked Congress today for $2.2billion in emergency military aid for Israel. He said it was needed to maintain that military balance and achieve stability to the Middle East.

title: At Least 8 Die on Jersey Pike In Crash of Bus and Meat Van
description: At least eight and possibly 15 people were killed last night in a crash when a tractortrailer loaded with meat collided with a Greyhound bus on the New Jersey Turnpike between Bordentown and Hightstown.

title: Cox Charges Illegal Gift to Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Dwayne O. Andreas, a soybean industry executive, was formally accused by the special Watergate prosecutor today of having consented to $100,000 in illegal corporate contributions to the 1968 Presidential campaign of Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: The President's Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19President Nixon's chief justification for the action he announced tonight on the disputed Watergate tapes was, in his words, his, desire to avoid any possibility of a constitutional crisis. But the effect of his decision, to constitutional experts interviewed immediately following his statement, was that the President had instead created the biggest constitutional crisis of this already crisisridden year.

title: NEW JERSEY I
description: TRENTON, Oct. 19Alfred N. Beadleston ordered today tough new restrictions on all dumping of outofstate garbage in New Jersey. The move by the President of the State Senate, who is in charge of the State House while Governor Cahill is in Europe, followed mounting protests by New Jersey communities that they are being overwhelmed by trash and waste hauled from New York and Pennsylvania.

title: LastMinute Pass by Penn Defeats Lehigh, 2720
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19Kim McQuilken, Lehigh University's pro quarterback prospect, put on an aerial show tonight in Franklin Field, but the senior from Allentown, Pa., was overshadowed by Penn's junior passer, Marty Vaughn.

title: Cutoff in Oil to U.S. Ordered by Libya
description: Libya fired a doublebarrel blast of her oil weapon yesterday by ordering a cutoff of all shipments of crude oil and petroleum products to the United States and almost doubling prices for other importers.

title: Cost of Home Food Dips 1.2% After 10 Months of Increases
description: After 10 consecutive months of price increases, the cost of food for the home went down by 1.2 per cent between August and September in the metropolitan area, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: The News Is Read Between the Lines in Manila
description: MANILA, Oct. 16All the newspapers the other morning had big frontpage headlines on the arrest of the dreaded NoNo Ituriaga, the alleged hatchetman of a notorious robberykidnap gang that had been operating in upperclass neighborhoods here.

title: First AmericanMade Car Meets '75 Fumes Standard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that an Americanmade automobile with a Japanese engine modification had become the first Am.ricnmade car to meet 1975 exhaust control standards.

title: Ford and U.A.W. Gloomy On Pact by Monday Target
description: DETROIT, Oct. 19 (UPI)Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers ruled out today the possibility of a contract settlement by Monday's artificial deadline, leaving the No. 2 auto maker on notice of a possible strike at 10 A.M. next Friday.

title: PROSECUTOR FIRM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special Watergate prosecutor, declared tonight that he would not accept President Nixon's order that he cease his attempts to obtain the White House tapes through judicial action.

title: ATLANTIC COAST FOOTBALL
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: DALLAS POLICE CHIEF REPLACED BY DEPUTY
description: DALLAS, Oct. 19The No. man in the Dallas Police Department, Donald A. Byrd, was appointed today to replace Chief Frank Dyson, who resigned unexpectedly on Wednesday.

title: COURT REBUFFED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 President Nixon refused tonight to accept the order by the United States Court of Appeals to surrender the Watergate tapes, declined to take an appeal to the Supreme Court and ordered the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, to drop the case.

title: Thai Revolt Leaves the King at Center Stage
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 19 Thai students emerged as an important political force in the overthrow of the military Government of Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn last weekend. Less noticed, the uprising brought to the political foreground Thailand's remarkable 45yearold constitutional monarch, King Phumiphol Aduldet.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 19Typically enough, the New York Knicks followed a hallowed tradition of four National Basketball Association seasons by beating the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight at Cleveland Arena. New York's 17th victory in 18 meetings with the Cays, however, was an anything  but  routine 2point triumph, 9290. The issue was in doubt until the final two seconds.

title: REV. WILLIAM R. BOOTH
description: MARYKNOLL, N. Y., Oct. 19 The Rev. William R. Booth, Maryknoll missionary for 48 years, died here last Monday at the headquarters of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America. He was 74 years old.

title: RECORDS STUDIED AT BOMBED BANK
description: While the bombdamaged Union Square branch of the Central Savings Bank remained closed yesterday, the police and Feueral agents began examining records of the branch's 35,000 savings accounts, seeking clues to any disgruntled depositor who might have been motivated to set off the pipe bomb that injured 10 people there Thursday afternoon.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale of these shortterm securities. The average rate for threemonth bills in this week's sale is 6.959 per cent down from 7,19 per cent last week, while the average rate for sixmonth bills in this week's sale is 6.951, down from 7.24 last week.

title: Brokerage Employe Said to Have Bilked 48 Investors by Mail
description: Troubled that his loan investment scheme was about to crack and shatter plans for his daughter's approaching wedding, a brokerage house customer's man surrendered yesterday to Federal authorities in Brooklyn to face charges of fraudulently using the mail to cheat investors out of $770,000.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Newark Council, in a Raucous Session, Votes to Keep Turco Despite Guilty Plea
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19  The Newark City Council, voting along racial lines in a tumultuous meeting, rejected today a motion to have Councilman touis M. Turco forfeit his seat because of his plea of guilty to Federal income tax charges.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Fire in Harrison Paper Company Is Kept From Oil and Gas Tanks
description: HARRISON, Oct 19A fire that swept through a paperstorage warehouse in the heart of the industrial section of this city directly across the Passaic River from downtown Newark sent columns of thick black smoke into this morning's skies.

title: WAR ALTERS LIFE IN REFUGEE CAMP
description: BEQAA REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan, Oct. 20The billiard parlor is padlocked, the movie theater is shut, and dust devils spin across empty playing fields.

title: Nebraska Interception Defeats Kansas, 10 to 9
description: LINCOLIN, Neb., Oct. 20 (AP)Bob Nelson intercepted a pass by David Jaynes in the fourth quarter today, giving Rich Sanger a chance to kick the winning 28yard field goal as Nebraska forged a 109 Big Eight victory over Kansas.

title: Public Hearing Set On Phone, Charges In Some Hospitals
