description: ALBANY, Oct. 20A public hearing into fees that private hospitals charge patients for telephone service will be conducted in Albapy On Nov. 20, the Public Service Commission said yesterday.

title: Numismatics
description: ANEW collector or casual observer walking through the bourse areas of many coin shows, or thumbing through some of the coin hobby newspapers and magazines, would have good reason to conclude that numismatics had somehow come to mean mostly silver bullion offered for sale to an investmenthungry public in the form of silver coins in bulk, industrialsize bars and ingots, special medal sets andmost pernicious of alllittle one ounce silver ingots stamped with political, patriotic, natureloving or other designs that are supposed to make the ingots worth five to ten times more than an ounce of pure silver actually cost.

title: Music
description: WHETHER or not the public takes to it, the Metropolitan Opera's staging of Berlioz's Les Troyens will be the big event of the entire New York music season. When Rafael Kubelik brings down his baton tomorrow night the old Metropolitan Opera will be rectifying one of the major omissions in its history. One can well understand why the great, massive opera was not done generations ago, for no opera house anywhere had Les Troyens in its repertory. But the last decade has seen fullscale performances in London and elsewhere, and it was nothing short of scandalous that the Metropolitan expressed no interest in one of the colossal operatic conceptions of all time.

title: Pitt Subdues B.C., 2814; 2 for Dorsett
description: NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP)  Pittsburgh's freshman sensation, Tony Dorsett, and its junior quarterback, Bill Daniels scored two touchdowns apiece today as Pitt scored a 2814 football victory over Boston College.

title: Elizabeth Muhlfeld Married to Artist
description: TENAFLY, N.J., Oct. 20In the Episcopal Church of the Atonement here this afternoon Miss Elizabeth Bearss Muhlfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bearss Muhlfeld, was married to O'Neal Ingram, son of Mrs. Sam L. Cox of Cleveland, Miss., and the late Walter K. Ingram of Greenwood,. Miss. The Rev. Henry Powers performed the ceremony.

title: SHIP UNIONS PLAN BOYCOTT OF SOVIET
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 20 The A.F.L.C.I.O. maritime unions served notice today that within 72 hours they will boycott all ships engaged in trade with the Soviet Union unless Moscow stops supplying aid to the Arab nations to use against Israel.

title: Detour for the RV Industry
description: Jack Anderson, superintendent of Yellowstone National Park, was driving through the park last July when he looked around and realized that at least half the people entering the park were coming in recreation vehicles. Not cars, he said later, but campertrucks, motor homes or trailers.

title: Notes: SixDay Cruises On a Hudson River Sloop
description: WANT a different sort of short vacation? One that should make you glow outside and in? Well, next month a handful of peopleyou can be among them if you act fastwill be sailing the Hudson River for six days at a time and striking a blow for ecology in the process. Sailing, incidentally, is the operative word since the sixday cruises there will be three of them, limited to 10 passengers eachwill be aboard the sloop Clearwater, that famous replica of a Hudson River sailing vessel of the eighteensixties.

title: Unbeaten U .S .C. Downs Oregon, 3110
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (AP)Pat Haden threw for two touchdowns and ran for another, guiding the ?? en Southern California Trojans over Oregon, 3110, today in a Pacific8 Conference football game.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Daylight Saving Times

title: Drab Scene of Futility On Old CeaseFire Line
description: JAVA, Syria, Oct. 20On the Golan heights and eastward into Syria, there are two groups of people whose lot has been futility these last few weeks: the Arab villagers who live there and the United Nations truce supervision team.

title: Jacqueline E. Trescott Is Married
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Miss Jacqueline Elaine Trescott, a reporter for The Washington StarNews, was married here this afternoon. to Paul Robinson Hathaway, director of university relations and publications for Howard University. The Rev. David H. Eaton performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church. A reception was held at the Museum of African Art.

title: ALABAMA CHARGES PLOT TO KILL AIDE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 20The Alabama authorities have charged an employe of north Alabama coal company with conspiracy to assassinate William J. Baxley, the attorney general of Alabama, who has been embroiled in a controversy with the trucking industry over enforcement of the state's highway weight limit laws.

title: EDUCATION BOARD REVARED AT TOP
description: Joseph Monserrat, a member of the Board of Education and Its president twice in the last five years, frequently describes the New York City school system as one of the largest corporations in the country.

title: MEDICAL COURSE OF 3 YEARS TRIED
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct 20 (UPI)Mike McCoy spends nearly all his waking hours14 hours a day, seven days a weekporing over medical textbooks and peering at microscope slides. He feels that even this is not enough study time.

title: 20Year01d Girl From the City Is Slain at University of Denver
description: A 20yearold woman student from Manhattan was stabbed to death early yesterday outside her apartment near the University of Denver in Colorado.

title: New Rochelle's Burst Pays Off
description: New Rochelle used a 31point burst in the third quarter to topple White Plains, 3815, yesterday. George Greene, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns, and Bob Mangels and Lester Gordon also went over during the spree.

title: Life Is Dreary for Fat Mice
description: Overweight mice live only half as long as mice of norMal weight and many of them develop diabetes. They also become sluggish, inactive, almost totally sterile and have a low sex drive, according to a Brooklyn College study. However, when fat mice are slimmed down by withdrawing their food supply, their life span increases, they become active, and their reproductive capability beCranes about normal.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (LEONTINE) YOUNG: THE FRACTURED FAMILY  It is impossible to imagine what a society without family would be like: The idea seems better adapted to bees or ants than to people. Wellregulated automatons running the machines of an Orwellian world might be the outcome.

title: A's Will Start New LineUp Today
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20The Oakland A's will try to win the championship of the baseball world today with a lineup that has not played in any of its previous 173 games this year.

title: The Interlock Snarl
description: Before long, someone will start calling other people Safety chauvinists. This may be the year, thanks to the interlock system.

title: M.I.T. Officials Defend Science and Technology
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP)Science and technology must not be blamed for today's woes, the president and the chancellor of the Massachusetts Institute of. Technology said here in their annual report.

title: Agnew's Farewell
description: WASHINGTONFarewell, said forlorn Spiro T. Agnew over three television networks Monday night. But the former Vice President, a convicted felon, stripped of office, the familiar American flag pin missing from his lapel, was not yet ready to go quietly, or to bring any sharp finality to the strange criminal case that wrecked him, His purposes seemed mixed and unclear but whether he intended to or not, his speech served to fan the embers of resentment, to test again the conspiracy theory that he had been framed by bribe brokers and Federal prosecutors, convicted by a conscienceless press and an unrealistic postWatergate political morality. unclear but whether he intended to or not, his speech served to fan the embers of resentment, to test again the conspiracy theory that he had been framed by bribe brokers and Federal prosecutors, convicted by a conscienceless press and an unrealistic postWatergate political morality.

title: Stennis Says Tapes Audit Depended on Ervin Consent
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Senator John C. Stennis said today that he had agreed to listen to the Watergate tapes and judge President Nixon's summary of them only after he had been assured that Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. had accepted the President's solution.

title: Bomb Suspect Posts Bond
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20 (UPI)Byron de la Beckwith, tried twice but never convicted of murdering Medgar Evans, the civil rights leader, was freed on $25,000 bond yesterday, three weeks after his arrest for allegedly carrying a live time bomb across state lines.

title: Sports Editor Recovers
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20 (UPI)Jesse Outlar, sports editor of the Atlanta Constitution, has been released from Piedmont Hospital after being wounded in a shooting at Atlanta Stadium, on Oct. 8. The shooting occurred in the stadium parking lot several hours after the Atlanta FalconsSan Francisco 49ers football game.

title: Balanced Scoring Gives Morristown 5th Victory
description: Four players scored touchdowns as unbeaten Morristown made Hanover Park its fifth victim, 296, in Morristown yesterday. Hanover Park has a 32 wonlost mark.

title: Ziegler Statement and Texts of Letters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Following are the texts of the statement by Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, regarding President Nixon's decision to discharge Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, and William D. Ruckelshaus, the Deputy Attorney General; a letter of resignation from Elliot L. Richardson, the Attorney General, to President Nixon and the President's reply to Mr. Richardson; Mr. Nixon's letter to Robert H. Bork, the Solicitor General, and Mr. Bork's letter to Mr. Cox, and Mr. Ruckelshaus's letter of resignation to the President:

title: Burns Guides Danbury To Sixth in Row, 2012
description: Undefeated Danbury, the state's fourthranked team, struggled to its sixth victory by downing Stamford's. Black Knights, 2012 yesterday. The Hatters are the only unbeaten and untied squad in the Fairfield County Conference.

title: BestinShow Often Turns Out to Be Long Shot in the Dark at This Time of Year
description: Dog shows ending in the dusk or at night, with no floodlights, are causing great distress among exhibitors and spectators. There have been several close calls during the last month, with bestinshow awards named minutes before nightfall. Westbury, Lehigh Valley, Northwestern Connecticut, and Rock Creek, among others, escaped darkness with some 10 minutes to spare.

title: Stamps
description: TWENTYFIVE years ago, when the hopes for a better world glowed brighter, the United Nations adopted and proclaimed a Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

title: ULSTER TERRORISTS AID WOUNDED VICTIM
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct, 20 (UPI)A Roman Catholic woman told the police today that four masked gunmen pulled her husband out of their car in Lurgan, 15 miles southwest of Belfast, shot him at pointblank range, then put him back in the car and allowed her to drive him to a hospital. He is reported in critical condition.

title: Audience Will Help To Judge Film Fete
description: One of the major American festivals of independent films will be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next month.

title: Hospital Seeks Aid From Communities
description: A Committee of Concerned Employes at Community Hospital of Brooklyn, which is already in bankruptcy and struggling to continue operations, has set up a hospital tour and meeting at 7:30P.M. Thursday, to enlist the support of the 10 communities the hospital serves.

title: Stewart Drove for Auto Racing Safety
description: Willie Mays will never again make a basket catch, Muhammad All no longer floats like a butterfly and now Jackie Stewart will never again take a checkered flag.

title: For Cambodia, Rehabilitation Is Painful, Lonely Effort
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 8Cambodia's suffering is a lonely suffering.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Profit taking in the face of jitters aroused by the Middle East fighting characterized the stock market last weeka period that saw gains by numerous domestic oil stocks and large declines by certain glamour issues.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Fur Trade Center Building at 333 Seventh Avenue has been acquired through a stock transfer by 333 Seventh Avenue Associates, an investment group headed by Richard A. Bernstein, a principal in Pease & Elliman, Inc., the real estate firm.

title: Journalism Fund Gets Head
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Howard Bray, a former reporter and Government official, was appointed this week as executive director of the Fund for Investigative Journalism, which provides foundationsupported aid to investigative reporters.

title: 2 Thrown to Deaths
description: Two young women, sisters from the Caribbean island of Grenada, were thrown to their deaths from a Manhattan hotel window yesterday. Their suspected killer, a musician from Trinidad, apparently walked in front of a subway train later and was killed. Details on Page 73.

title: Art
description: THE second week in October, 1973, wasn't exactly the most encouraging ever for an art reporter who likes his job but now and then hits a low and wonders whether his beat is really awfully important in comparison with those of his colleagues who cover such things as social Problems, politics and wars.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Ugandan to Return Visit
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Oct. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)President Idi Amin of Uganda will pay an official visit around Nov. 15, Foreign Minister Joseph Potolot said yesterday. The visit will repay one made to Uganda by President JeanBedel Bokassa last year.

title: Princeton Wins First By 3721
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 20Princeton followed Coach Bob Casciola's pregame plan to the letter today and the Tiger football team upset Colgate, 3721.

title: Mrs. Schlesinger Has Son
description: A son was born last Sunday to Mr. and Mrs. Michael Schlesinger of. Crestwood, N.Y., at the Albert Einstein Hospital in the Bronx. The child has been named Phillip Henry. Mrs. Schlesinger, whose husband is a lawyer in New York, is the former Miss Lauren Berkley of Little, Falls, N. J.

title: Soviet Says Nuclear, Reactor Is Supplying Power to Arctic Region
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20  The Soviet Union disclosed today that the world's first nuclear reactor within the Arctic Circle was now supplying millions of kilowatthours of electricity each month to the underdeveloped polar regions around Murmansk.

title: The StarSpangled Banner; Illustrated by Peter Spier. Unpaged. New York: Doubleday & Co. $5.95. (Ages 5 and Up)
description: Peter Spier, do you know what might be said by some as a result of this book? That youre a flagwaving superpatriot, man, you're way out of step. Maybe they'll say: If you want to make the scene you've got to have a healthy contempt for patriotism, pull down the statues and the pedestals, too. Land of the free and home of the brave? Rubbish! Burn the flag! Come on, you know we've denuded our forests, gouged scars in the earth, defrauded the poor, lacerated the land and left neon sores of Finger Lick'n Good, Dine & Dance, Dew Drop Inn.

title: A Matron Defies Political Odds
description: PRINCETON  A wealthy Princeton matron, a Democrat who was a leader in Senator George McGovern's, campaign in New Jersey last year, is involved in another underdog race: her own campaign for the State Senate.

title: Less Rigid Districting Plan Ordered for Texas by Panel
description: DALLAS, Oct. 20 (AP)A threejudge Federal panel has acceded to Supreme Court directives and has ordered a United States House reapportionpient plan for Texas that is less, rigid than one the same jurists adopted earlier.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP)Charles O. Finley insists he was right in trying to replace Mike Andrews on the Oakland Athletics baseball team.

description: Unbeaten Nutley, preparing for next Saturday's big meeting with Westfield, powered to a 280 victory over victoryless Columbia in Nutley yesterday.

description: Some days I feel as if two kings were playing chess while their pawns bled.

description: TORONTO, Oct. 20You've gotta believe the Toronto Maple Leafs, one of the most dismal teams in the National Hockey League last season, beat the Rangers, 3.2, tonight and replaced the New Yorkers as East Division leaders.

description: POMONAStudents and faculty members at Stockton State College conceived, and are now producing, what is believed to be the first statewide educationaltelevision course.

description: The city's Department of Marine and Aviation took a major step last week toward planning for the overhaul of controversial Flushing Airport in Queens by announcing that it would seek half a million dollars in capital funds to conduct an engineering and design, study there.

description: Boca Raton, Fla.  Elisha Obed, 148 pounds, The Bahamas, knocked out Jose Melendex, 148, Puerto Rico, 8 rounds.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 20Sterling Mackay Palm, an architect who designed department stores, hospitals and houses, died yesterday at the Nassau County Medical Center, Plainview division. He was 79 years old and lived at 180 Hilton Avenue.

title: To O'Neill, She Was Wife, Mistress, Mother, Nurse
description: IT is accidental, but entirely appropriate, that Eugene O'Neill's The Iceman Cometh, both as a new film and as a stage revival, should appear at this particular time, The producers of neither venture were aware that their scheduling coincided with the 20th anniversary of O'Neill's death on Nov. 27, The American Film Theatre's movie version of The Iceman Cometh will open Oct. 29 and the Circle in the Square production will open Dec. 13.

title: Where Greasy Gates Grow
description: ROCKAWAY Township The names trip off the tongue with the homely cadence of a folk song: Greasy Gate, Grimes Golden, Northern Spy, Newtown Pippen, Sheep Nose, Sutton.

title: Lennon Fights to Stay
description: John Lennon filed suit yesterday in Manhattan Federal Court as part of his fight against deportation from the United States, The 33yearold former Beetle asked the court to force the Immigration and Naturalization Service to produce the records under which deportation decisions are made.

title: GARBAGE TRUCKS ARE KEPT ROLLING
description: The Department of Sanitation has reported dramatic gains in keeping its equipment operating to keep the city's streets clean.

title: Trends
description: LONDONAfter a long summer recess, the House Commons returned to work last week all set for a politically hot winter. There is a faint smell of national elections in the air and, at this point, it's not a welcome aroma for the ruling Conservatives of the opposition Labor party. For, as they sometimes say at Aqueduct, there doesn't seem to be a horse in the race that could win.

title: Tests to Be Given To Find TaySachs
description: SPRINGFIELDIn an effort to identify those Jewish couples who may be carriers of the rare, but always fatal, TaySachs disease, a mass screening program will be held next Sunday at Temple Shary Shalom. The six hour project will get under Way at 10 A.M.

title: HEALTH UNIT STIRS LOUISIANA INQUIRY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20 Louisiana's statewide family planning program is fighting for its life before a Federal grand jury here and in negotiations with the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: A 21st Century Master Plan Guides Southampton
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.With its meticulously preserved colonial houses, vast potato fields and ornate estates that sweep down over shrinking dunes to the ocean, Southampton hardly seems the proper setting for radical innovation. Yet for three years now, this bucolic, 19thcentury town has been tryingnot always successfully to live with a pioneering, 21stcentury master plan.

title: 6 GROUPS WILL SET GOALS ON ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20It an effort to impart more mo. mentum to Government energy programs, John A. Love, dime for of the President's Energy Policy Office, has, organized six interagency study groups. Mr. Love disclosed this in an interview this week with correspondents and editors of The New York Times.

title: Subsistence U.S.A.
description: Commiserating recently with a literary chronicler, and critic, I said I thought his talents deserved a time less nondescript to interpret, that we seem to lack even one writer of coherent genius, and see few books of exceptional distinction, and that, even without his chronicler's bent, I was discouraged by it. He didn't disagree, but tried to put the best face on the matter by saying this is a time of transition in writing and maybe interesting for that. I said it is a time of transition in everything but writingand could scarcely be more interestingbut that in writing it is a time of waiting.

title: Paterson Catholics Back Hispanic Unit
description: PATERSON  Spanish speaking clergy and lay leaders hi the Paterson Roman Catholic Diocese are proposing the creation of a Hispanic center here that would serve the cultural and everyday needs of some 75,000 Spanishspeaking Catholics in the diocese.

title: Wedding on Coast For Mrs. Vandellos
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 20Mrs. Iraida Vandellos of Santa Monica and Boris Pushkarev, vice president for research and planning for the Regional Plan Association in New York, were married this morning by Judge Frank Kearney of the Municipal Court in the Santa Barbara Courthouse.

title: In Search of Ali Mahmoud An American Woman in Egypt. By Vivian Gornick. 343 pp. New York: Saturday Review Press. $8.95.
description: In February, 1971, Vivian Gotnick, journalist, Jew, 35, unor better, demarried, flew to Cairo, not really in search of the friend and lover Ali Mahmoud from whom she had parted, for he was still in America, but in search of the culture that had made him, against all odds, so familiar and close in reactions and sensitivity to herself. How could this masculine, Arabicspeaking product of the Moslem world be the person with whom, above all others, she could' joke and laugh, size up a situation, exchange exasperatingmother stories, talk of them as opposed to us, relate joint family barbarisms, refer to the ghetto? Between them, she felt, lay peculiarly and startlingly, the camaraderie of the outsider. But were they joined by something more positive than simply a difference from them, the insiders? With her own curiosity supported by a book contract, she went to see. This is the book contracted for, and it is splendid: deeply perceptive, brilliantly alive and, just as a travel book, though it is more than that, full of graphic scenes of life from a world both strange and*familiar.

title: Feminists Here Urge: Make Money, Not Coffee
description: Make money, not coffee, the sign said, and many of the secretaries and other women office workers who stopped at the sidewalk table seemed to think that was an excellent idea.

title: Dance
description: THERE was a time, during the City Center financial crisis last, summer, when it seemed possible that the Joffrey Ballet would be a victim of that incredibility gap of what the arts cost to run in this country and how much is available to run them. The company behaved with commendable fiscal responsibility, cut back its New York seasonwhich is a veil regrettable thing for New York and has more or less gotten itself back into financial shape, at least for the moment. But, like almost everything else in the arts in these days of galloping inflation, the Joffrey Ballet is still underfunded.

title: Chinese Students Upheld On Copying During Exam
description: PEKING, Oct. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Communist party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao yesterday devoted a full page to high school students in Shanghai who aroused controversy by demanding the right to copy during examinations.

description: ALBANY, Oct 20Raymond T. Shuler, the State Commissioner of Transportation, is making his political debut in what most observers here think is the toughest election contest of the yearselling the $3.5billion transportation bond issue to the public.

title: Oakland Is Trying to Stop the Clock
description: OAKLAND  We've developed considerably in the last 20 years, said a woman in a shopping center on Ramapo Valley Road, but we still codsider ourselves as being completely rural. Why, not so long ago, a woman visiting the Municipal Building ran over a copperhead snake in the parking lot there, and we have lots of deer and rattlesnakes on much of the land here. Sure, the population has increased tremendously, but much of the land in Oakland has not been developed because that's what most of us here wanted. I don't know how long we can keep it this way.

description: Tennis buffs, regardless of whether they rooted for Billie Jean King or Bobby Riggs, will tell you that their sport is among the fastestgrowing one in the nation, An enterprising New Jersey company could not be happier.

description: Preliminary trials to select the United States yacht to defend the America's Cup in 1974 will be held in Long Island Sound starting June 3, The New York Yacht Club announced yesterday.

description: Sixty per cent of all complaints by consumers in the state about insurance settlements or policy provisions involve automobile insurance, according to the State Insurance Department.

title: Regina Stein, Bruce Wilson Plan Wedding
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Jess Stein have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Regina Beth Stein, to Bruce Wilson. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. H. Van Rensselaer Wilson of Brooklyn.

description: Stephen Sondheim is composing the music and lyrics for a new version of Aristophanes's satirical classic The Frogs for the Yale Repertory Theater, it was announced by Robert Brustein, dean of the Yale Drama School and director of the repertory theater.

description: CLEVELAND, Oct 20 (AP)Ten writein candidates have filed to oppose the Incumbent Republican, Ralph J. Perk in the Cleveland mayoral race, giving the general election Nov. 6 more than twice as many candidates as the primary.

title: A tragic heroine
description: The Confessions of Lady Nijo, awakened now in a carefully annotated translation by Karen Brazell, slept for six and a half centuries in the Imperial Household Library in Tokyo, its existence unknown even to Japanese readers in its complete form until 1966. Beginning with her years as an Emperor's favorite, Lady Nijo recorded her life 250 years after Lady Murasaki wrote The Tale of Genji in the 11th century. She is a younger sister, actually and literarily, in this sorority of highly placed ladies of sensibility in the imperial courts.

title: Discharge of Cox Makes Future of Inquiry or I.T.T. Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 One of the major cases pending before the office of Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Justice Department, was that of possible perjury and obstruction of justice in connection with the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: OUTCRY IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20For the first time tonight, members of the Democratic and Republican leadership of the House of Representatives began talking publicly and seriously about impeaching President Nixon.

title: Vanderbilt Stuns Georgia On 4 Field Goals by 1814
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 20 (UPI) Hawkins Golden kicked four field goals today, twb of them in the last five minutes, and Lonnie Sadler ran for 109 yards to lead Vanderbilt to an 1814 upset of its Southeastern Conference foe, Georgia.

title: BORK TAKES OVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20President Nixon, reacting angrily tonight to refusals to obey his orders, dismissed the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, abolished Mr. Cox's office, accepted the resignation of Elliot L. Richardson, the Attorney General, and discharged William D. Ruckelshaus, the Deputy Attorney General.

title: Soutine: The Art Of the Outsider
description: IN no other painter of the School of Paris does the analytical intelligencethe celebrated mesure that is often saw to be the very essence of the French esthetic sensibilityseem as threatened or as desperately modified as it is in the work of Chaim Soutine. In Soutine's art, we are made instantly and acutely aware of an expressive urgency that has little commerce with, and even less patience for, the more ratiocinative aspects of artistic intelligence. The headlong energy, the compulsion to realize a vision at any cost, the paroxysm of feeling that lies at the center of every pictorial effortthe characteristic attack (and attack is the right word in this case) that Soutine brings to his canvas makes every encounter with his art a highly charged experience.

title: After Volvo, Who's Next?
description: With Volvo having decided to take the plunge and assemble automobiles in the United States, can other foreign car producers be far behind?

title: How to Impeach With Honor
description: WASHINGTON  On Sunday, Oct. 14, the American Civil Liberties Union inserted a fullpage ad in The New York Times, detailing why it is necessary to impeach President Nixon and how it can be done. Four days later, from that ad alone, the A.C.L.U. had received 873 pieces of mail, 810 of them favorable to impeachment, 751 volunteering services in the cause, and 410 containing contributions totaling $10,835.25.

title: ACTIVIST IN ITALY WINS EIER JOB BACK
description: ROME, Oct 20  A woman activist who is promoting a union of Italian prostitutes won a round in her running battle with officialdom this week.

description: MADRID, Oct. 20 (AP)Flash floods fed by torrential rains awept through parts of southern Spain last night and today, killing at least 93 people, officials said. More than 100 persons are missing and hundreds are stranded in flooded towns.

title: A Proper Revolution

Overnight, a nation that had always been in the grip of army generals and their powerful police services was being run by students, Boy Scouts and professionally respected but generally unknown civilian officials.

R,, Oct. 20 (AP)The condition of Pablo Casals worsened this morning, a family spokesman said; The 96yearold cellist and conductor has been in highly critical condition in a hospital in Rio Piedras for the last six days. Casals suffered a heart attack last month. Complications involving his lungs and kidneys set in this week.

title: Sydney's Opera? Staggering
description: WHAT is it like to conduct in the new $140million Sydney Opera House? An obvious person to ask is Lorin Maazel, who led his Cleveland Orchestra in four concerts there during the recent inaugural week. His reply to the query began cautiously. Acoustically it is not unsatisfactory, he said. I think that is a fairly accurate description. It is, to a certain extent, a concert hall in the round. There are people in back and in front of the orchestra. One would expect such a hall not to be satisfactory, and in fact I expected much worse. But the players in the or chestra could hear one another, and there was enough reverberation to produce a fairly elegant sound. At least it did function to a quite satisfactory degree and it will attract major performers. It is spectacular and has great architectural splendor, even though it was built from the outside in. And they have managed to resolve some of the pivotal problems rather successfully.

title: DRUG CLINIC SEEKS NEW QUARTERS
description: The West Side Drug Rehabilitation Center, Which treats 26 residential youths and 75 outpatients in an abandoned threestory garage at Columbus Avenue and 108th Street, is looking for new quarters amid charges that it has been the victim of institutional expansion and community ignorance.

title: Jane Moore, 1970 Debutante, Bride of Roy Goodrich Cary
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 20Miss Jane Moore, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oliver Semon Moore of New York and East Hampton, was married here this afternoon to Roy Goodrich Cary, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vaughn Cary. The ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Chirch was performed by, the Rev. Samuel Davis.

title: Dinner theaters are booming. Are they the way Broadway will survive?
description: IN the middle of nowhereapproximately 15 miles outside Hartford, Conn.there stands a large, sturdy, somewhat grim barnlike structure, flanked by an enormous parking lot. The sight is not particularly inviting, despite the country setting of grass, trees, and the distant rise of the Connecticut and Massachusetts hills.

title: Stevie Wonder Is a Whole Gang
description: S America clearly. At the center of his music is the sound of what is the sound of what is real, the nation day to night as lived by contemporary Blood.

title: More secrets of lowcost building
description: The high price of building is driving many wouldbe home owners to doitthemselves. Last week we showed two imaginative solutions to the problem of escalating costs: a grain silo converted for living (labor supplied by the owners and their friends) and a builder's shell adapted to the owners' needs. Others have asked architects to design houses for their particular way of life that are simple enough to be constructed by amateurs. Architect David Sellers designed two houses (this page and bottom of opposite page) to be built almost completely by the owners. Architect Peter Samton, who designed the third house, dispensed with all tricky details so that local university students could do most of the carpentry. He also advised the owners to have the house built offseason (from late fall to early spring in the Northeast) to save on labor costs.

title: Reagan Leads, Rockefeller Is 2d In Gallup Poll on '76 Nomination
description: Gov. Ronald Reagan of Califorma is now the prime candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: AROUND THE
description: Tuck in gardens for the winter ahead.... Finish planting and harvest chores.... Work on the compost pile and add leaves, weeds, etc.

title: Letters of Anton Chekhov
description: According to the Russian Formalists, duplication is central to the artistic process. In the episodes of an adventure novel, or in Dostoevsky's brothers, Chekhov's sisters and Tolstoy's siblings, the juxtaposition of narrative elements essentially similar permits the exposure of telling differences. Duplication of another sort has become a feature of Slavistics in the last 20 years. Most of the prose written by Solzhenitsyn and Bulgakov has appeared simultaneously in at least two translations, offering zealous scholars an opportunity for comparative study that has produced lively exchanges.

title: Miss Cassandra E. Hopkins Married to R. Breck Denny
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Oct. 20Miss Cassandra Ewing Hopkins and R. Breck Denny were married here this afternoon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. John C. Harper, rector of St. John's. Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, Washington.

title: Missouri Newspaper Using Metric System
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 20 A smallcity daily newspaper published by the School of Journalism at the University of Missouri has switched to the metric system. The Columbia Missourian now gives virtually all measures in articles, weather, birth announce ments and sports in metric units, with the English equivalents appearing in parentheses.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Cox's News Conference on Nixon's Decision on Tapes
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the news conference in Washington yesterday by Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Yvonne Schot Becomes Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 20Miss Yzvonne Rieke Schot, daughter of Mrs. Hendrik J. Schot of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Mr. Schot, was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Heron Hannan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hannan of New Canaan.

title: Bayside Turns Back Far Rockaway for 5th Straight, 26 to 12
description: Bayside, bidding for a return to prominence in the Public Schools Athletic League, yesterday defeated Far Rockaway, the 1972 champion, 2612, in a Queens league game at Bayside. The victory, fifth in as many starts, gave the unbeaten Commodores a P.S.A.L. record of 4.0.

title: VENUE PLEA DUE IN JERSEY TRIAL
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 20When the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Squire resumes on Tuesday, lawyers for the defendants intend to ask Superior Court Judge Leon Gerofsky to grant the change of venue he denied in pretrial sessions.

title: Brooklyn, Queens Subway Riders Are Declining
Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20After the phone rings in the New York Mets' bull pen for Tug McGraw to start warming up, the little lefthander appears to be the essence of energy.

title: KRUTCH AWARD GOES TO ROGER PETERSON
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20Roger Tory Peterson, who has been the author or coauthor of 15 field guides and books on birds, was presented tonight with the annual Joseph Wood Krutch Award by the Humane Society of the United States.

title: Catholics and Remarriage
description: WASHINGTONPamela S. had been married nine years when her husband abandoned her and their two children for another woman. Several years later she fell in love with another man, but they hesitated to marry. Both were devout Roman Catholics, and church marriage courts do not recognize desertion as a ground for annulment. You just can't live in sin, said Pamela. I would never have gone to the sacraments again.

title: Mary R. Forrest Bay State Bride Of C. B. Creamer
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 20St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Rita Forrest and Christopher Barrett Creamer. The Rev: Robert H. Stafford performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: If, the textile industry needed a man for all seasons, it has found one in Efraim Arazi, a young Israeli who has brought electronic engineering and management skills, as well as highly imaginative thinking, to fighting the desperation resulting from high raw material prices in a lagging market.

title: Win or Lose, Egyptians Have New Army Image
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20Whatever the outcome of the battle with Israel, the image of the Egyptian Army has changed dramatically.

title: Russian poems, Russian memoirs, Russian letters
description: In a note explaining his method of translation, Stanley Kunitz compares himself to the man of Franz Kafka's cruel fancy who, fettered by two chains that keep him suspended between earth and heaven, refuses to admit that he cannot get to either of them: If he heads for earth, his heavenly chain throttles him; if he heads for heaven, his earthly chain pulls him back. The image is apt. In the name of earthy exactitude, the translator may kill a poem by turning it into prose, but if he reaches heavenward to grasp its poetic essence, he will be pulled back by the knowledge that he has distorted its sense. So Mr. Kunitz, recognizing that Akhmatova's poems, like Pushkin's, do not depend on imitable effects but exist in the purity and exactness of their diction ... the subtlety of their rhythmic modulations, the integrity of their form, persists nevertheless in a venture he knows to be impossible, because he is one of those poets who are moved to record what [they] have heard, and to try to give it back in the language that [they] love.

title: Andover Overwhelms Mount Hermon, 5615
description: MT. HERMON, Mass., Oct. 20Chris Doherty, a 6foot1inch; 215pound fullback, led unbeaten Andover to 5615 rout of Mount Hermon today. Doherty scored four touchdowns in Andover's fourth victory, three on runs.

title: Marilyn Sibley Bride of Dr. Brant Fries
description: ALFRED, N.Y., Oct, 20 Miss Marilyn Sue Sibley, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Myron Knight Sibley of Alfred, was married here at home this afternoon to Dr. Brant Elias Fries. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Harman Fries of New York.

title: Crimson Triumphs, 2115
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 20Two Ivy League football powers, Harvard and Cornell, matched their undefeated records today before about 20,000 fans at Schoellkopf Field. Harvard continued its fourgame streak, winning, 2115, for its second victory in the league.Both teams had come off impressive triumphsCornell running over Princeton, 376, and Harvard walloping Columbia, 570  and the welldrilled squads showed why from the outset. Flashy, opportunistic, rugged on defense and possessing touchdown potential on any given play, they ran the ball up and down the field.

title: New Plant Spurs Community Action
description: PALISADES PARK  In this pleasant community just now being touched by the tints of autumnal change, there is a Christmas spirit in the air.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Richard Memorial Hospital and Health Center on Staten Island began the process of phasing out yesterday as the hospital moved toward its projected closing on Tuesday. The announced closing is the result of an impasse in contract negotiations between the hospital and Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Workers Union.

title: Candidate Calls Middle Class the No. 1 Issue
description: Thomat F. Galvin RepublicanConsersative candidate for City Council president, says he believes that maintaining middleclass neighborhoods as a means of keeping the residents from fleeing the city is the No. 1 political issue in this year's citywide campaign.

title: 6,000 Miles in a '29 Bentley
description: On April 15, 1971, four of us set out from Rawalpindi with a 1929 Bentley and a 1964 Riley intent on reaching Englandif we made it to the Khyber Pass and the Afghanistan border safely.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: William Henry Donaldson, chairman of the brokerage house of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., is about to take his first step into the political arena. And already speculation about his second step has begun.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: AS WAR RAGED in the Middle East, Saudi Arabia reduced oil production by 10 per cent and threatened to cut off all oil supplies to the United States to pressure it to reduce aid to Israel. Libya cut off all oil shipments to the U.S. Other Arab ollproducing nations proclaimed a cutback of oll exports by 5 per cent a month, with the burden to fall on the United States and other nations considered mfriendly to the Arab cause. Persian Gulf Oil producers quietly imposed what appears to be the highest price increase in history of the industry.... The House of Representatives passed an Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act, providing for the Government to supervise distribution of crude oil and petroleum products.

title: 1830 Brooklynites Had Familiar Complaints
description: One thing that many of today's Brooklyn residents have in common with Brook the belief past generations is the belief thatlocal government has failed to plan adequately for the needs of the community. Indeed, on April 29, 1830, Alden Spooner, editor of The Long Island. Star, began a series of articles they were entitled Our Village  in which he hoped to stimulate action by the Village Trustees to resolve longstanding issues.

title: Isn't It Enough to Show MurderMust We Celebrate It?
description: PEOPLE who never go to movies are always complaining about the abundance of sex on screen, but the truth is that almost no major American films have dealt, seriously and intensively with adult sexual relationships or changing sexual mores. Even before the recent disastrous Supreme Court decision, there were no American movie equivalents of Last Tango in Paris  or even of Claude Berri's comedy, Le Sex Shop.

title: Georgetown Downs Manhattan, 4216
description: Jim Chesley, 150pound defensive back, intercepted two Manhattan passes and returned them for touchdowns yesterday to help Georgetown post a 4216 victory over Manhattan in club football at Mount St. Michael Field in the Bronx.

title: Queens Ragamuffins in Dress Review
description: It looked like an Invasion by Halloween runaways. Smeared with Indian war paint, sporting feathered, flowered hats they stomped, skipped, were tamed by the arm of an older brother or sister, or were pushed along in strollers.

title: Miss Grenley Has Nuptials
description: TACOMA, Wash. Oct. 20Miss Laurie EnidPolk Grenley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Grenley, was married here this afternoon to John Hellen, a corporate bond trader with. Weeden & Inc., in New York. He is the son of Rudolph O. Hallen of Worcester, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Mrs. Ruth E. Hallen.

title: CHILE EXPELLING 3 FOREIGN PRIESTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 20The Chilean military authorities today ordered the expulsion of three foreign priests.

title: SAKHAROV ATTACKED IN THE SOVIET PRESS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (Reuters) Andrei Sakharov was subject to a barrageof abuse in the Soviet Press today, accused of being a scoundrel, an apologist for imperialism and a racist.

title: Music Is Old Hat to Bayonne Family
description: BAYONNE  In Bayonne, Morreale means music.

title: A Southern Country Boy Who Made It as an Auto Worker
description: DETROITBack in the late forties, when Corner Coins was just a kid mining coal in the hills of eastern Kentucky and spending too much money on moonshine, he never dreamed life could be so good.

title: Imports' Invasion Unabated
description: There's no stopping those spunky little imported cars in the American marketplacecertainly not in 1973 and maybe not in 1974 either.

title: Nader Victorious
description: WASHINGTONSome day it will happen, of course, that Ralph Nader, his lance rounded and ineffective from constant use, will attack An Institution with gusto but without success, and fall defeated at its polished feet. When that happens, there will be a sort of emotional autopsy performed on Mr. Nader to see not only what made him tick but what made him explode so often.

title: Oil Shortage
description: WASHINGTONThe House of Representatives voted against oil shortages last week and Arab states voted for them. Inasmuch as the Arabs, not Congress, control most of Middle East oil production, there was no doubt where the balance of power lay.

title: Paul Robeson Revisited
description: For nearly a quarter of a century Paul Robeson's name has been a great whisper and a greater silence in black America. Phi Beta Kappa and twice winner of AllAmerican football honors at Rutgers, graduate of Columbia  Law School and fluent in more than 20 languages, Robeson was for three decades hailed as one of the greatest singers and actors in the world. Among Americans of the 1930's, only Franklin Roosevelt was said to have been better known, internationally than he. Though an entire generation of Americans has come to maturity without having heard of him, Robeson. was once almost as noted for his radical defense of the rights of the oppressed as for his virtuoso artistry.

title: ...and an Auto Executive Who Grew Up With the Industry
description: DETROIT  In the office of Loren R. Papenguth in the executive headquarters of the Cadillac Division of The General Motors Corporation, little things hint at what kind of man the occupant is.

title: Michigan Trounces Wisconsin
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 20 (AP)Michigan ran up a 28.0 lead over Big Ten rival Wisconsin today before the Badgers scored, and then rolled to a 35.6 victory.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Ed McBain has written scads of procedurals about the 87th Precinct, set in a mythical metropolis that has five boroughs and an overworked police force. His latest is HAIL TO THE CHIEF (Random, $5.95), and with it he has, in some ways, broken his usual format.

title: NIXON'S TAPE OFFER NOT MADE TO SIRICA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court here said today that President Nixon's offer of a summary of the White House tapes had not been made to him.

description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20 (UPI) The Pittsburgh PostGazette, the city's only morning newspaper, announced today an increase in the single copy price from 10 cents to 15 cents, tive Monday.

description: WASHINGTONAt least one bright spot for consumers in these inflationary times is the discount offered by many insurance companies on their automobile collision insurance premium's.

title: Jack Benny Tosses Out First BallBelatedly
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP)Jack Benny, invited to throw out the first ball at today's World Series game, tried to keep it instead.

description: Group taxiriding from airports, railroad and bus terminals under the direction of the City Taxi and Limousine Commission is expected to be put into effect early next year.

title: Lafayette Defeats John Jay, 26 to 20
description: Lafayette, the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League Division I leader, needed a late lastquarter rally yesterday to defeat John Jay 2620, at Lafayette Field. It was the fifth straight triumph for the Frenchies, who were paced to victory by the passing of Angelo Grillo and the running of Larry Goldstein, a senior halfback, John Jay has yet to win this season.

title: MPG's the Thing
description: Once styling sold cars: tailfins as high as an elephant's eye, gaudy grilles and chrome as thick as good bouillabaisse.

title: Mets Favored By Precedent
DECARLO OF MAFIA DEAD OF CANCER
description: Angelo DeCarlo, a onetime powerful Mafia leader who was granted executive clemency by President Nixon last Christmas because he was suffering froth terminal cancer, died yesterday at his home in Mountainside, N. J. He was 71 years old.

title: The Inspection Hurdle
description: Inspection is a crisp, antisepticsounding word whose mere utterance suggests that problems have thereby been solved.

title: Bill on Federal Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, has introduced legislation that would end the Government's practice of awarding contracts without bids, and said he was acting in the light of former Vice President Agnew's case.

title: Searches and Seizures
description: Stanley Elkin's remarkable novels Boswell, A Bad Man and The Dick Gibson Showhave had rich critical praise, and his name usually turns up on lists of the most interesting younger writers. But it's my impression that he has been more praised than read, and this collection of three new novellas should provide the uninitiated with an ideal introduction to his art even as it confirms addicts like me in our belief that no American novelist tells us more about where we are and what we're doing to ourselves.

title: Passaic Vaiiey Upsets Hackensack, 97
description: Mike Suglia, a junior end, kicked a 20yard field goal with 1 minute 18 seconds to play yesterday and gave unbeaten Passaic Valley a 97 victory over Hackensack in Little Falls.

title: Donald Hoyt Marries Carol Lee Augustis
description: Miss Carol Lee Augustis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Augustis of Yonkers, was married here yesterday afternoon to Donald Byrne Hoyt, Judicial Clerk for the Court of Common Pleas of York County, Pa. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Hoyt of Concord, Mass.

title: The biggest Baltimore loser of all time
description: BALTIMORE. There was always something about it that felt wrong, but only now do we see what it was. As preacher of the Nixonian crusade against permissiveness, Spiro T. Agnew was absurdly miscast. He was too much the Baltimorean for such righteous work.

title: RICHARDSON QUITS OVER ORDER ON COX
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Elliot L. Richardson resigned as Attorney General tonight, saying that he could not carry out President Nixon's order to discharge Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, in the light of his earlier pledge to provide Mr. Cox with full authority to contest Presidential claims of executive privilege.

title: Fordharn Sets Back Johns Hopkins, 1310
description: Art White, a freshman wingback, scored on a 31yard delayed pass play in the fourth quarter to give Fordham a 1310 victory over Johns Hopkins at Jack Coffey Field yesterday.

title: Funeral Home Business Will Be Studied by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, c Oct. 20 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission announced this week a pilot study of the funeral home business, which It said may expand into a nationwide investigation to determine whether undertakers are taking advantage of the bereaved by charging inflated prices and selling unneeded services.

title: Naples Mayor and 2 Aides Face Inquiry on Corruption
description: NAPLES, ITALY, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The Mayor, Deputy Mayor and former public health official of Naples have all been warned that they are under investigation in connection with possible corruption charges following Italy's cholera outbreak, judicial officials said today.

title: Apartments
description: On scores of construction sites across the city, from the shores of Jamaica Bay in southern Brooklyn to the hilly reaches of the Bronx, on fringearea land that was underutilized and slumarea sites that were long abused, the din of housing being built or renovated heralds the hope of new and better homes for tens of thousands of New Yorkers.

description: TENAFLY  Housewives and others will get an insight into New Options for Women at an allday conference to be held at the Middle School here on Nov. 3.

title: Gasoline Mileage Data From Tests of 1974 Automobiles
Booker T. Washington's Role Is Reconsidered

title: Mailbox: The Shame of Shea Stadium
description: Last Sunday, in a column entitled The Shame of Shea Stadium, Dave Anderson castigated the young Mets fans who rushed onto the field after the Mets had beaten the Cincinnati Reds for the National League pennant. Several spectators were injured, others were frightened and parts of the field were torn up.

title: Town Seeks to Save History
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I.The Town of Oyster Bay, which was formed 320 years ago, is seeking to preserve for future generations buildings or places of special historical or esthetic interest.

title: The everybody dress
description: It's almost as hard to find a dress for the daylight hours as it is to find a good cup of coffee. But there's one fashion that could fit into almost everybody's wardrobethe tent dress. It's cut with a flare that lets you move (and conceals bulges) and it looks right all day long. The tent dress may be the old faithful of the winter season.

title: The sufferings of a highachiever
description: This is the man who with Neil Armstrong was first on the moon. And this is a technologist who at M.I.T. and NASA did important work on orbital rendezvous. But Col. Buzz Aldrin has tried to put the emphasis elsewhere in recounting what he calls the most significant voyage of my life. This voyage is, of course, what happened when he returned to earth after Apollo 11, and it is a story of lost bearings, domestic trouble, nervous breakdown and Aldrin's effort to locate himself again.

title: Conference to Aid Hispanic Women
description: NEWARK  An allday Conference For and By SpanishSpeaking Women will be held next Saturday at the Robeson Campus Center of Rutgers University, 350 High Street.

title: 300,000 Pupils Get Tests on Two R's
description: TRENTONAn unusual. program of testing the reading and mathematical skills of some 300,000 New Jersey public school students ends Tuesday, but state officials event.

title: Chess: Time Waits For No Man, Especially Not Efim Geller
description: Efim Geller has lately fallen into some of the most pathetic timepressure misfortunes since time limits were instituted for tournament play more than a century ago. The Soviet grandmaster, paired with Peter Biyiasas of Canada in the Brazil Interzonal, forfeited after failing to come up with his 40th move in the one minute remaining for it.

title: 10 Die in Brazil Jet Crash
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  At least 10 persons were killed and more than 30 injured today when a Brazilian fighter jet hit a cluster of adobe huts on the outskirts of Fortaleza, capital of the northeastern state of Ceara.

title: STAMFORD KEEPS PUPILLUNCH BAN
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 20National School Lunch Week has come and gone and for the third school year in a row there still are no lunches being served to this city's 20,000 pupils.

title: Klein Endorses Bond Issue
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., Oct; 20Suffolk County Executife John V. N. Klein endorsed the state's $3.5billion transportation bond issue today and announced that he would make a threeday campaign swing next week through five upstate citiesUtica, Buffalo, Syracuse, Binghamton, and Goshento campaign for its passage. Mr. Klein said that in his campaign appearances upstate he would also be urging a vote against a ballot proposition that would enable the formation of a third county, Peconic on eastern Long Island.

title: The Movie That Made The Festival Memorable
description: KIT, 25, wearing blue jeans, a Tshirt and a panama hat, drives the big Buick sedan across the prairies towards Montana. Beside him on the front seat is Holly, 15, who is on the verge of being pretty though she still looks something like a cookie that hasn't yet been baked. The country is so flat you think Columbus was wrong. To pass the time, Holly reads aloud from a movie magazine. 'Rumor: Frank Sinatra and Rita Hayworth are in love, Fact: Yes, but not with each other.

title: Will the Moody Blues LastLike Beethoven and Berlin?
description: REMEMBER a few years back when Marshall McLuhan was becoming a household name and we all decided that the printed word was dead, murdered by the visual media? Well, it seems that while we weren't looking, the same sort of thing has been happening to music.

title: Bridge
description: It is perhaps a pity that cardplayers have abandoned the colorful oldfashioned word knave, which still has some currency in England, in favor of jack. Knave was common in Shakespeare's day, and was still the preferred form half a century ago. It lost ground for the purely practical reason that it cannot be abbreviated to K without creating problems in printed diagrams. Jack can become J without ambiguity, and is therefore superior. Some early bridge books used the clumsy contraction Kn.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The formidable outer coverings of certain delectable naturalfoods, among them the quahog or hardshelled clam, and the oyster, defy the clumsy thrusts of the novice harvester who, in desperation, often attacks them with a hammer or a tire iron.

title: Education
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  Everybody loves to watch a baby, but not many infants get quite as much attention as the ones in this suburVan community. They are being examined at every stage of their young lives and pampered with the latest in expert knowledge on childrearing and development.

title: Turkish Politics
description: ANKARAAfter 31 months, martial law was lifted in Turkey, as Turks prepared to go to the polls for last Sunday's general elections. The results were unexpected. Once elections were assured, the question had seemed to be whether former Premier Suleyman Demirel, who had been ousted by a military coup by communiqu in 1971, would be accepted by the armed forces as Premier of a Justice party center Government. But the winner was the leftofcenter Republican People's Party, whose new leader, Bulent Ecevit, had promised the voters what Mr. Demirel could not: I will not, he had said, put Turkey into a position where the military feels it must intervene.

title: Recordings
description: OF all the strange paradoxes and perversities that dot France's cultural history, the phenomenon of Grand Opera as it developed in the mid19th century is one of the most peculiar. Paris was the operatic center of the world at the timea triumph at the Opra was the ultimate goal any composer could hope for. Yet among the many spectaculars written for La Grande Boutique (as Berlioz derisively called it), only three operas survive today as updisputed masterpieces, the odd fact being that two of them are by Italians (Rossini's William Tell and Verdi's Don Carlos) and one by a Frenchman who never saw his complete work staged there (Berlioz's Les Troyens). Even the Opra's most successful composer.

title: Malverne Surprises Elmont, 2813
description: Room at the top? There is apparently plenty of it in Nassau County South Shore Division III. After yesterday's action, which included Malverne's 2813 upset of undefeated Elmont, six of the 10 teams in the division had only one defeat.

title: Boston U. Is Routed By Temple
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP)Marty Ginestra, a second  string quarterback, came off the Temple berich to throw two secondquarter touchdown passes today and lead the Owls to victory over Boston University, 3515.

title: Nordiques Win From Blades, 81
description: QUEBEC, Oct. 20 (UPI) The Quebec Nordiques scored four goals in the first seven minutes of the opening period tonight and went on to defeat the New York Golden Blades, 8 to 1, in a World Hockey Association game.

description: The City Council will hold the following public hearings at City Hall this week:

title: Nancy Allen Sets Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Nancy Gardner Allen to Harold Edwin Brewer has been announced here by her mother, Mrs. John Joseph Allen. The wedding is planned for Nov. 24 in the Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady of Mercy in Madrid.

title: A.B.A. Head Criticizes Nixon's Order to Cox
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Chesterfield Smith, president of the American Bar Association, said today that President Nixon's instructions to Archibald Cox challenged the American system of justice.

title: Private Gallery Exhibitions
description: As the fall season gets under way, a number of New Jersey's private art galleries are offering oneman exhibitions by resident and outofstate painters and sculptors.

title: Frances Almanza Wed
description: Miss Frances Almanza, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Almahza of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jerry Saperstein, son of Mrs. Abe Saperstein of Lincolnwood, Ill., and Surfside, Fla., and the late Mr. Saperstein, founder of the Harlem Globe Trotters. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Sullivan performed the ceremony aboard the Italian liner Michelangelo at the Hudson River Pier. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Twins and an anthem
description: Both of these books about the mentally handicapped are sensitive, real and very different. In Me Too the reader sees the exceptional child from the outside, in Twyla, from the inside.

title: Richard Smith Weds Candace Crawford in Suburb
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 20In the Reformed Church here this afternoon, Miss Candace Curtright Crawford, daughter of Mrs. Wilbur L. Cross 3d of Bronxville and Homer Crawford of New York, was married to Richard Alan Smith. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Perry Smith of Plattsburgh.

title: Catholic schools are committing suicide
description: In a certain city there are three Roman Catholic schools:

title: Mrs. H. H. Kung, 85, Dies; SisterinLaw of Chiang
description: Mrs. H. H. Kung, sisterinlaw of Chiang Kaishek, the president of Nationalist China, died here last night after a lengthy stay at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for an undisclosed illness. She was 85 years old.

title: Hunters Find Bound Body
description: LOCH SHELDRAKE, N. Y., Oct. 20The decomposed body of a white man in his late 50's was found here today by hunters. According to the Fallsburg Town Police Chief, Seymour Farber, the unidentified person had his arms and legs bound behind him with a heavy nylon cord.Dr. Sidney Schiff, the. Sullivan County coroner, who performed an autopsy but declined to state, the cause of death. Dr. Schiff said the man had been dead for at least four months.

title: Housing Moratorium Postpones Hopes in Roslyn
description: ROSLYN, LI.The Federal Government's new housing policy calls for a moratorium on subsidized housing and to the residents of an urban renewal project here, the policy is a suspension of their planned escape from heatless hovels and ramshackle rooming houses.

title: Christian Scholars And Communists Weigh Cooperation
description: ROME, Oct. 20  Christian and Communist scholars discussed the possibilities of collaboration in a symposium in Moscow last month.

title: Historians Cite Peebles I.
description: ALBANY, Oct. 20 (UPI)Pebbles Island, a 132acre isle at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk Rivers, has been accepted for listing in the National Register of Historic places, it was announced to day. The state is buying the island for $600,000 as a state park site. Traces of fortifications built during the Revolutionary War remain on the island's north end.

title: U.S. Panel Seeks 1,000 Helpers To Scan Market for Unsafe Toys
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Consumer Product Safety Commission is looking for 1,000 citizenvolunteers to help it police the market place for products banned as unsafe.

title: Syracuse 496 Loser
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 20Penn State's football machine, still looking for some sort of competition from an Eastern opponent, set two scoring records and tied two game records today. The Nittany Lions, as expected, trounced Syracuse, 496, 27,595 fans in Archbold Stadium.

title: Mrs. Klein Isn't Running but G.O.P. Makes Her Morris Issue
description: MORRISTOWN  Republicans have dominated Morris County politics for decades, but with the election two years ago of Ann Klein as State Assemblyman, county Democrats have approached the latest legislative campaigns with renewed vigor.

title: Harborfields, Amityville Stay Unbeaten
description: Chris O'Hanlon, the quarterback, threw a 10yard fourth  quarter touchdown pass to John Cameron, and Bob Radimer kicked the extra point after a 56yard drive yesterday to give Harborfields a 76 victory over Central Islip in a battle between two Suffolk unbeatens. The victory, the fourth for the Tornadoes, puts them within striking distance of the AA1 league championship.

title: Taxis Test Bumpers
description: On the toughest track in the world  the streets of New York City  General Motors is testing a new type of automobile front and rear end that gives promise of cutting repair costs and reducing fuel consumption.

title: Geri Bergman Is Married
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 20 The marriage of Miss Geri Sue Bergman, daughter of and Mrs. Mendel Bergman of Yonkers, to Steven Philip Dorman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victot Dorman of Fairlawn, N.J., took place here this evening in the Harrison Jewish Community Center. Rabbis Norton Shargel and Simeon Glustrum officiated at the ceremony.

title: Coe Mansion Is Showcase for Interior Decorating
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I.Coe Hall, the Tudor mansion built in 1919 as a New World palace for a wealthy insurance man, can be seen for the next three weeks in its third incarnationas a showcase for the talents of 25 New York area decorators.

title: U.S. Push For Job Equality
description: WASHINGTONThe day has disappeared when a young Federal agency, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, merely conducted educational and conciliation campaigns in trying (without overwhelming success) to induce companies and unions to adhere to antidiscrimination laws. Gone also is the time when a threat of court action against companies and unions hardly raised an evebrow among their lawyers.

title: The Vitamin Question
description: WASHINGTON  Vitamins are potent, mysterious, necessary and easily provided in pill form. People have died from lack of one or another essential vitamin even though their diet was above the starvation level in other respects.

title: Music in Review
description: Rigoletto, in the form of the sometimes illogically designed but always theatrically vivid production of Frank Corsaro and Lloyd Evans, reentered the repertory of the New York City Opera Friday night. The most unusual aspect of the performance was that the Rigoletto, Richard Fredricks, was obviously laboring from the effects of a cold, and had to be replaced for the final two acts by Vasile Martinoiu. Mr. Martinoiu had sung in this production before, however, and fitted smoothly into it. His conception of the part seemed basically, effectively melodramatic, and his baritone, while not distinguished in its quality, is of a roughly serviceable sort.

title: Show Woos Singles Set
description: MAKING a pass at the swinging singles set, the second Greater New York Automobile Show opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum.

title: TALKS BEING SPED
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20  Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in Mdscow today and quickly entered into talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev on the twoweekold Middle East war.

title: 6 Escape Injury When Wall Collapses
description: Three adults and three children narrowly escaped serious injury last week when the side wall of their twofamily brick residence at 1499 St. Marks Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn collapsed after being struck by the upper portion of another building that was being demolished.

title: The end of a way of life
description: The success story of the fall season a novel called Beulah Land, by a relatively unknown but respected writer named Lonnie Coleman: it has been sold for $800,000 to Dell the highest price ever paid for the paperback rights to a novel. (Avon paid over $1million for the paperback rights to Jonathan Livingston Seagull; however, some people do not consider this book a novel.)

title: WATER OF A LAKE IS SAID TO BE CURE
description: SOAP LAKE, Wash., Oct. 20 (AP)At first glance, Soap Lake looks like any other sleepy lakeside resort with its gasoline stations and motels and few visible signs of life.

title: Susan B. Cunningham Betrothed
description: WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 20Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Inskeep Cunningham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Brann Cunningham, to Hal Richard Wofford of New York. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Monroe Wofford of Reno, Nev.

title: Parsippany Unveils Projegt Latchkey
description: PARSIPPANYA problemthat confronts working mothers everywherehow to provide care for children during afterschool hoursis being attacked through a community project that was begun here earlier this month.

title: James Shelton Marries Claudia Marshall
description: Miss Claudia E. Marshall and James D. Shelton, officers of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: My Past and Thoughts
description: In his own time and in his own place, Alexander Herzen was an anachronism and an anomaly. Born in 1812, the semilegitimate son of an eccentric and reclusive Russian aristocrat his father was married to his mother, but not in the Orthodox Church, and so the union was legally invalidHerzen was steeped at an early age in the liberal thought that had been advanced opinion in 18thcentury France and still was advanced opinion in the Russia of Nicholas I.

title: AIDE BIDS TANAKA ACT ON INFLATION
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20Inflation, in Japan has become such a pressing political and economic problem that a Cabinet minister and senior leader of the ruling party has loosed a scathing attack on Premier Kalwei Tanaka for failing to slow the rocketing price increases.

title: With a Virtuoso and His Violin in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 20Do you mind if I close my eyes? asked the pilot, politely and in a voice that was barely audible. Please, replied the violinist. Then he too, closed his eyes, lifted his bow and began flooding the small hospital room with the grave air of a saraband from a Bach partita for violin alone.

title: Marcia B. MacMannis.Is Married
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 20  In St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Marcia Blake. MacMannis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Roberts MacMannis, was married to William Thomas Fallon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fallon. Both families are of Darien.

title: WALL STREET
description: Should the forecasters go out of business?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Homes
description: In the minds of many, the New York area is a land of apartment buildings. They seem to blanket Manhattan, loom over Queens and even march up the New Jersey Palisades. Yet population density within a 20mile radius of the Empire State Building is less than twothirds that of Paris. Why? Because New York is not so much a mountain range of highrises as it is a vast scrub forest of one and twofamily homes.

title: Third Week of Death
description: The ArabIsrael war of 1973 has entered its third week with the fighting and the secret diplomacy both escalating. Secretary of State Kissinger's sudden mission to Moscow after direct communication between Leonid Brezhnev and President Nixon has, stirred the first solid hope of effective peace action by the superpowers.

title: FRANK HOUSTON, 91, LED CHEMICAL BANK
description: Frank K. Houston, who retired as chairman of the board of the Chem??al Bank in 1947, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 116 East 68th Street.

title: Pop Music: Solo Yarrow
description: Peter Yarrow would appear to have shed all semblance of times past when he fronted an allelectric group at Max's Kansas City on Park Avenue South, his first New York solo appearance. And yet he occasionally harked back to the days when the folk boom was acoustically in flower with songs such as This Land Is Your Land and Bob Dylan's I Shall Be Released. On opening night his former partner Noel Stookey joined in the soft, singalong version of this song.

title: Soviet Satellite Launched To Improve Communications
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched a Molnia 2 communications satellite yesterday to help send telephone, telegraph and television signals to outlying areas of the country.

title: Offshore Oil Veto Power Urged
description: TRENTON  Oil industry experts contend that there are enough offshore oil and natural gas deposits along the Atlantic Coast to satisfy American energy needs for at least a decade.

title: Replay of the Recall: From Dealer to Driver to Dealer
description: After owning a Studebaker and a Dodge, Linda Rose of Manhattan entered the motorist's joyfully compelling redconvertible phase. She bought a Triumph Stag from a dealer in New Jerey.

title: Equity Funding Indictments Alleged
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20, (UPI)Twentytwo persons have reportedly been indicted by a county grandjury in connection with the $2billion Equity Funding Life Insurance Company case. More indictments were reported forthcoming from California.

title: Paving a Major Issue in Nutley
description: NUTLEYA streetpaving controversy between Nutley's Public Works Department and residents of The Enclosure, a former artists' colony, seems destined to end in a compromise.

title: California
description: The year is 1865, the earliest date I have yet found at which a woman refers to herself as a sex object. The lady is Mrs. Arlene Baker, an eager widow who has set her cap and aimed her bustle at young Steven Lewis, a pioneer landowner. But we are ahead of our story, which begins in 1838 when Steven's father jumps ship in Monterey to found the Lewis fortune. Dad makes it as wide  ranging entrepreneur, Steven develops a seminal agribusiness, and the two contribute to a luxuriant family tree.

title: N. Bergen's Marchetto Boots 31, 48 Yarders
description: ROCKAWAY, N.J., Oct. 20 Pete Marchetto set a Hudson County record today with a 48yard field goal that helped North Bergen to a 33.7 victory over Morris Knolls.

title: The Salamander
description: Morris West invents stories as though the world were running out of them, and The Salamander is a strong one. It can't compete for morality ribbons with such West best sellers as The Devil's Advocate or The Shoes Of the Fisherman, but it's a zippy militarypolitical thriller that drives away boredom while romancing power as if it were as sweet as a vestal virgin. Unfortunately, West lusts after big ideas, and he switches his characters into visiting lecturers on ultimate ends and means at the clink of a cocktail glass. Still, The Salamander is pretty good entertainment about man's habitually bad ambitions.

title: Hype raised to the level of entertainment
description: The great showman Phineas Taylor Barnum (181091) mastered so well the art of deviousness that he might be known today as the high priest of radical chicanery, but to friend and enemy he was known as a charlatan, trickster, bamboozler and humbug. The father of Madison Avenue, Barnum raised entrepreneurship to its zenith and made many people in advertising, show business, sales and broadcasting unwittingly and forever in his debt. Hype was artfully elevated by Barnum to the level of entertainment, and in doing this he became one of the prominent figures of Ambrica's 19th century. The energies behind his manifestation cause one to ask numerous questions about human personality and psychology, especially as they pertain to the sociology of this country.

title: 2 Top Israeli Generals Foresee Sinai Triumph
description: IN THE WESTERN SINAI, Oct. 20The two chief commanders of the Israeli offensive in Egypt spoke with exuberant confidence today of the progress of the campaign and predicted a speedy end to the war.

title: Princess Anne's Fiance Gets Wedding Uniform
description: LONDON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Capt. Mark Phillips took delivery yesterday of the fulldress uniform he will wear for his marriage Nov. 14 to Princess Anne, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: White House Called Firm in Refusing To Yield Watergate Tapes to Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Authoritative sources declared today that the White House would stand firmly behind its contention that President Nixon could not be held in contempt for his refusal to provide the Watergate tapes, themselves to Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court here.

title: VOUCHER BID DIES IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 20The New Rochelle school district revealed yesterday that it had terminated discussion with Federal officials over a plan to introduce the controversial school voucher system.

title: Barbara Secor Becomes Bride
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass., Oct. 20The First Congregational Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Barbara Wynne Secor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Secor Jr. of Middlebury, Conn., to Thomas Fisher Upson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Warren Upson of Woodbury, Conn.

title: John Howland Weds Mrs. du Pont
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 20Mrs. Gertrude Murrell du Pont was married at her home here this afternoon to John Gibbs Howland. The Rev. Julian Gunn, headmaster of St. Mary's Episcopal School in Peekskill, N.Y., and cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Cable Laid to Study Wave Energy Data
