description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.In an effort to study the effects of wave energy on coastline erosion along the South Shore of Long Island, scientists at Southampton College took to the seas this week with 2,800 pounds of armored cable.

title: V.A. Busy With Requests For Cemetery Markers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 20 (UPI) Applications for headstones and grave markers are running at 800 a day since the Veterans Administration took over responsibility for administration of the national cemetery system for veterans, the V.A. says.

title: Young Are Concerned, but...
description: Although young car owners are concerned about air pollution and the gasoline shortage, there are limits to the costs and inconveniences they would accept to minimize these problems, according to a recent survey.

title: Bonn Said to Delay Aid of $55Million to Israel
description: BERLIN, Oct. 20An influential West German newspaper reported today that Bonn was delaying capital and payments to Israel because of the war in the Middle East.

title: Auto Questions And Answers
description: I am ready to buy a new car. I have compared price, size, company reputation. Are there any considerations I may have overlooked?

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SEPARATISTS SEE A GAIN IN QUEBEC
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 20Would the people of Quebec be better off if this largely Frenchspeaking province separated from the rest of Canada and became an independent country?

title: Canterbury Festival Set for Morristown
description: MORRISTOWN  St. Peter's Church here will be the scene of a Canterbury Festival next Friday and Saturday. Highlight of the weekend will be the production of several mystery plays from the Wakefield Cycle.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford to Give Glassboro Address
description: GLASSBOROHenry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, will be the keynote speaker at a management institute to be held Tuesday and Wednesday at Glassboro State College.

title: Some Collector's Items
description: FOR a sincere hobbyist, there are no common plants. Yet there is sometimes an urge to grow the lesser known collector's items, so to speak, among indoor plants.

title: Vietcong Order Indicates Support for Battle StepUp
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20The Vietcong's Provisional Revilutionary Government today released the full text of an order to its forces that appears to sanction steppedup military activity.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: Today  Scheduled Datsun Owners Club meeting at Bob Sharp Motors, Danbury, Conn., canceled.

title: Dutch Honor Westmoreland
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 18 (AP)Gen. William C. Westmoreland, retired Army chief of staff, has received the Order of the OrangeNassau from the Netherlands. Baron R. V. van Lynden, Ambassador to the United States, presented the decoration in a brief ceremony at the State House here. The awrd recognized General Westmoreland's service in Europe in World War II and his efforts for closer bonds between the two countries. The general now lives here.

title: OR FLOW TO U.S. HALTED BY SAUDIS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 20The Saudi Arabian Government has decided to stop all oil exports to the United States, the Riyadh radio announced tonight.

title: Casey at the Series (With Translations)
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 20Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel, in his 84th year and looking better than he has in a long time, has been attending: the. World Series on both coasts and spouting his inimitable muddleEnglish at the top of his form.

title: Tanks, Planes, Men
description: TEL AVIVA murderous, intertwined armada of tanks and men collected on the brief plains bordering the Suez Canal last week to play out the end of the Middle East war. How long it would take nobody knew, but the stakes were high and clear: The existence or destructionagainof Egypt's military power, the ability of Israel to remain defiant in a hostile sea of Arabs or to be drowned in their power, and perhaps the future relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Moral And Legal Tangle
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Presideheg latest decision on the Watergate tapes is a typical Nixon performance, almost a map of his mind. It is clever, complicated and superficially generous, but it is also devious and contemptuous of the courts, the Congress and the rights of others.

title: PROSECUTORS SEEK SECRECY ON PAPERS
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP)Federal prosecutors here have field pretrial papers asking that grand jury testimony by a former administrative officer for the. Baltimore County Executive, N. Dale Anderson be kept secret until the officer testifies at Mr. Anderson's trial in January.

title: SURVIVAL PROJECT FOR EARTH URGED
description: Maurice F. Strong, the executive director of the United Natons Environment Program, called last week for the creation of an international survival plan for SpaceShip Earth.

title: Kidnapped British Executive Freed by Police in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The police today freed a British executive kidnapped, here 29 days ago and captured two of his abductors.

title: Farmingdale Takes 24th, 80
description: Life wasn't easy for the teams at the top of the three Nassau County North Shore Divisions yesterday. Farmingdale struggled to a 80 victory over Bethpage in Division I; Levittown Division had to rally to defeat Westbury, 14.6, in Division II; and Locust Valley managed only a scoreless tie with Cold Spring Harbor in Division III.

title: Shinnecocks Seek Heritage
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.When Diane Bess was a little girl growing up on the Shinnecock reservation here, she vowed that once she left she was not going to come back.

title: Mine Workers Fund Paying $245Million for Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  The United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund has reported that record benefits of nearly a quarter billion dollars are being paid to soft coal miners and their families.

title: Ruckelshaus Got Request To Oust Cox and Refused
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 20 Early this evening, William D. Ruckelshaus received a telephone call at his office from Alexander M. Haig Jr, chief of the White House staff.

title: DALEY WILL FACE PRIMARY BATTLE
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20The first early salvo in the battle to defeat Mayor Richard J. Daley was fired this week when Alderman William S. Singer announced that he would enter the 1975 Democratic primary against the Mayor.

title: The Concorde Ends Flights, Will Go to French Museum
description: PARIS, Oct. 20 (Reuters) The French prototype supersonic airliner Concorde 001, has ended its career after 396 flights810 hours in the air, 254 of them at supersonic speed  and is to become a museum piece, according to the Aerospatiale Company.

title: Book Explaining Impeachment Published by House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20, (AP) The House Judiciary Committee has prepared a book on impeachment in an effort to make members of Congress and the public familiar with the subject.

title: Rivers in The City
description: If New York had grown rationally (what city has?) its most soughtafter place to live surely would have been Riverside Drive. The manmade canyons of Park Avenue can hardly compete with the Drive's stunning views of the Hudson and the Palisades, beyond. But fashion said no, as any New Yorker knows. Riverside Drive was left to develop as a middleclass and uppermiddleclass area, while the very rich, free to live anywhere, chose the manufactured prestige of Fifth and Park Avenues in. stead.

title: Exhaust Catalyst Is It Only Creating New Woes?
description: When Congress passed the Draconian 1970 amendments to the Clean Air Act, a national goal somewhat like the Apollo lunar landing program was established, At a cost of billions of dollars, the nation again was to achieve a technological marvel by a deadline. This time the goal was terrestrial: to virtually eliminate the automobile as a source of air pollution.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Wedding in November For Constance Lawn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Lawn of New York and West End, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Ellen Lawn of Washington, to Stephen Rappaport of Arlington, Va., a certified public accountant in Washington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rappaport of Front Royal, Va.

title: Architect Here Is Accused In Slaying of Queens Clerk
description: A 52yearold engineering technician and architect for the New York City Board of Education was charged yesterday with the murder of a 33yearold unemployed Queens stock clerk in his apartment on the sixth floor at 48 West 138th Street.

title: Syria Expels 2 Reporters For Visiting the War Zone
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Oct. 20 (Reuters)Two Western journalists, Donald, Kirk of The Chicago. Tribune and Fred Bridgland of Reuters, were deported from Syria today.

title: Crime Reversal in Englewood
description: ENGLEWOOD  Although crime elsewhere in New Jersey has increased considerably in the last two years, this affluent Bergen County community has achieved what state and county lawenforcement authorities regard as a remarkable reduction in major criminal activity.

title: Auxiliary Police in Nassau Preparing for Winter
description: The Auxiliary Police of Nassau County come from a variety of professions. Some are realestate men, others lawyers, teachers, electricians or photographers. But all of them have one purposeto do what they can to help reduce the number of vandals, muggers and other wrongdoers in the county's parks, schools and beaches.

title: Homosexual Teacher Fights to Survive
description: PARAMUS  Sixteen months ago, Jolin Gish, a 36yearold Paratrius High School English teacher, in formed his school board that he had been named president of the Gay Activist Alliance of New Jersey. He also is head of the Gay Teachers Caucus of the National Education Association.

title: For Jets' Meager Offense, It's Another Tough Sunday
Curbing Drunken Drivers
description: Drunken driving, one of the largest single causes of highway deaths, may soon be impossible.

title: A Guide to Homes on Wheels
description: CHICAGO  Vacationers who choose to take their homes with them can buy or rent anything from a simple $600 foldup camping trailer to a $22,000 29foot motor home with a lounge, bathtub and kitchen, or a 31foot splitlevel trailer, attached, like an elegant tractortrailer, to their pickup truck.

title: Check Out A Fresh Frog
description: So many albums are released every month that often there are a few gems that slip by without being mentioned. Maria MuIdaur (Warner Bros. MS 2148) is her first solo though she's best known for her work with Jim Kwesldn's Jug Band when she was known as Maria d'Amato. Muldaur possesses a marvelous voice capable of warming up a ballad like Long Hard Climb or socking out a rocker like Mac (Dr. John) Rebennack's Three Dollar Bill. Her inter pretation of Don't You Feel My Leg (Don't You Get Me High) is deliciously naughty and the whole album sparkles with exceptional style.

title: Sir Rudolf Bing Is Singing Praises of Teaching in Brooklyn
description: Sir Rudolf Bing's cramped cubicle in the Institute for Studies in American Music at Brooklyn College is a far cry from the gilded corridors of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Thorpe Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)President Nixon signed a bill today for a national medal in commemoration of Jim Thorpe, the Indian athlete who died in 1951.

title: Pumpkins in Field Await Halloween
description: WATER MILL, L. I.It's really just a novelty, but we thought the kids would enjoy it. And so, last October, the Raymond Halseys opened a field behind their Green Thumb farm stand here for people to pick their own pumpkins. Success prompted a repeat of the venture this year.

title: Brown Is Subdued
description: PROVIDENCE, R.L, Oct. 20 It took Dartmouth's football team 14 minutes 57 seconds to make a first down against Brown today. But once it discovered how it was done, the Big Green had no difficulty subduing the Bruins, 2816.

title: Islanders Toppled by Sabres, 21
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 20  The New York Islanders survived 14 shots on goal by the French Connection line tonight before 11,562 fans in the Nassau Coliseum, but were beaten, 21, on goals by two other Sabres, John Gould and Rene Robert.

title: A Species That Flies/Creeps on Wheels
description: SPREAD EAGLE, Wis.Through rain and fog and wind and sleet and snow, they instinctively come by the millions.

title: Norman Chandler Dies at 74; Los Angeles Times Publisher
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (AP) Norman Chandler, former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and a builder of one of the great American publishing empires, died early today. He was 74 years old.

title: 6 Debutantes Bow At Tuxedo Dance
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 20Six young women made their debuts here tonight at the Autumn Ball Dinner Dance, the party which this year replaced the more formal Tuxedo Autumn Ball. The ball was traditionally preceded by private dinner parties. The six were the Misses. Jennifer Lovering Gregory, Lanier Mitchell Hamilton, Virginia Williams Keech, Diana Burrill Pool, Parthenia Ross and CassLedyard Shaw.

title: FIGURINES VALUED AT $250,000 STOLEN
description: The theft of 19 carved ivory figurines said to be worth $250,000 was reported to the police yesterday.

title: Jackson Makes Up for 1972 Absence
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20 Reginald Martinez Jackson is a sensitive young man with muscles, a thoughtful man with the gift of expression, a sincere young man of candor and great class. He is the cleanup hitter and center fielder for the Oakland A's but when they went into the World Series last year he was on crutches, having ripped a hamstring muscle stealing home with a run that tied the deciding game of the pennant playoffs. I felt disassociated, he said today. I cried a couple of times.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Mrs. Hite Remarried
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 20Mrs. Elizabeth G. Hite was married at home here this afternoon to Chester H. Lassell of Greenwich and Boca Grande, Fla., a widower and limited partner in the investmentbanking house of Morgan Stanley & Co. Justice of the Peace Robert Mowbray performed the ceremony. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Television
description: LITTLE Sammy is small, but ... oh, my! When 5foot3inch Sammy Davis Jr. is at work, big men bow low. His talent makes him boss. He can treat people like punching bags, because if stars were nice guys how would you know they were stars?

title: The Rock Beat Grows Louder on TV
description: THE young girl was in the middle of a crowd sprawled outdoors in Georgia. With a sweeping gesture toward the audience, she explained proudly that if it weren't for the Brothers, there wouldn't be all these freaks. The afternoon scene was part of Saturday Night in Macon, one of 26 biweekly television specials being syndicated under the umbrella title of Don Kirshner's Rock Concerts. The centerpiece of this particular one was the Allman Brothers Band, currently successful purveyors of what is sometimes called country soul.

title: Church Street Area Picks Up as Shopping Center
description: A commercial renaissance is under way on the lower West Side, generated by the surge in officebuilding activity in the last few years and the dislocation of much small business by the World Trade Center.

title: Con Ed Building 2 Power Plants. On Housing Site
description: A midtown West Side block on which a developer had planned to erect highrise housing has been almost completely razed by Consolidated Edison to make way for the construction of two substations.

title: Theophilus North
description: Of the eight eminent writers of the twenties and thirties about whom Malcolm Cowley writes in A Second Flowering, only one is still alive, Thornton Wilder. Wilder survives not merely as a man but also as a writer. In 1962, when he was 65, he retired to the Arizona, desert to meditate upon a novel, which became The Eighth Day (1967) and won a National Book Award. Now, in his 77th year, he has another book, Theophilus North, which might conceivably equal the popularity of his second book and first best seller, now half a century old, The.Bridge of San Luig Rey.

title: Cyril is sneaky, John is straight
description: Whatever became of Linda?

title: The New Play
description: A BREEZE FROM THE GULF, a play by Mart Crowley, got 10 mixed reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Watts, Post; Lewis, Bergen Record; Stewart Klein, WNEWTV; Probst, WNBCRadio; Feingold, Village Voice; Oliver, New Yorker; Simon, New York; Clurman, Nation) and 7 negative reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI; Alvin Klein, WNYCRadio; Stasio, Cue).

title: A clinic for insomniacs
description: It was 11:15 P.M. Most of the electrodes had already been pasted into place. One was behind each of the patient's ears and one above each eye; two were on her chin and three on her foreheadthese five were for measuring muscular tension. There was also a single electrode to the right of her nostrils, for measuring the rate of breathing. Now, Dr. Peter Hauri, director of the Dartmouth Sleep Laboratory at Hanover, N. H., was positioning two more electrodes on the very top of the patient's head, just over the parietal lobes of the brain; these were for picking up and recording her brain waves. You know, said the woman apprehensively, I have an awful time getting to sleep ordinarily. I don't see how I'm ever going to sleep with all these wires coming out of my head.

title: State Plans a 2d $750,000 Welfare Penalty for the City
description: The state Department of Social Services planned a second $750,000 penalty against the city yesterday as its officials attributed an August upturn in the city's welfare rolls to slownees in carrying out facetoface interviews for recertifying clients, eligibility.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 21
description: ACROSS

title: Technology of Armored War Makes for Intense Duels
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 20Although war has touched and scarred the lives of millions of people in the last four decades the awful mechanics of killing are not well understood by much of the world.

title: Calls and Telegrams Said To Support Cox's Position
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Phone calls and telegrams poured into the office of the Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, this afternoon supporting his opposition to President Nixon's proposed compromise in the Watergate tapes case.

title: Then Accepts Tapes Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. renounced today and then reaccepted President Nixon's proposal to release an authenticated summary of the Watergate tapes.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Joe Garagiola reviews the recent history of old pal Yogi Berra: When the Yankees fired him, that hurt him. So he takes another job managing. I told him he was nuts, managers get fired. But he wanted to show everybody he could manage. He has.

title: GOVERNOR PLANS STADIUM MEETING
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would meet this week with sporting and business interests to mobilize public support for the proposed $275million sports complex in Sunnyslde, Queens.

title: The Nation
description: With all the imperturbability of an unchallenged monarch, George Meany blithely returned last week to the starting point of a 360degree turn around the national political circuit.

title: DR. LEO STRAUSS, SCHOLAR, IS DEAD
description: Leo Strauss, an influential political philosopher and interpreter of classical political theory, died Thursday of pneumonia at Anne Arundel General Hospital in Annapolis, Md. He was 74 years old and lived in Annapolis.

title: Canadian Minister Signs Science Accord in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (Reuters) Canada's Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce, Alistair W. Gillespie, has signed protocol on science and technology with the Soviet Union.

title: Cutting War Powers
description: WASHINGTON  As renewed war continues to rage in the Middle East, President Nixon and Congress are facing a showdown over the powers of the President to commit United States armed forces to foreign hostilities without Congressional consent.

title: Hatfield Asks Controls' End
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, has introduced a bill to repeal the Economic Stabilization Act. It is a simple truth that wage and price controls, in all their phases, have not worked, he said Thursday in a Senate speech.

title: Pratt Unit Aids Areas In Fighting City Hall
description: We'd like to see that communities gain more control over the institutions that run their lives, said Ron Shiffrnan, director of the Pratt Institute Center for Community and EnvironMental Development.

title: Devlin's 137 Leads Golf By 2 Shots
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 20 (UPI)Bruce Devlin of Australia defied the rain and swirling winds today to notch eight birdies for a fourunderpar 68 in the second round of the Wills Masters golf tournament.

title: Black Theater Fete Set in Brooklyn
description: The Black Theater Alliance Festival, designed to serve as a showcase for black theater talent, will get under way at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Oct. 31 with a performance by the AfroAmerican Studio Theater.

title: Giants Facing New Woe: Hayes Back for Cowboys
R. A. Saunders, Physician, Weds Anne E. Leslie
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 20  Miss Anne Elizabeth Leslie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Huston Leslie of New Auburn, Wis., and Sanibel, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Dr. Richard A. Saunders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dero A. Saunders of New York and Kunkletown, Pa.

title: The Great American Baseball Card Flipping, Trading and Bubble Gum Book
description: Got it. Got it. Don't got it. Got it in doubles. Got it. Don't got it. Got it in triples. Don't got it. Got it. Got it. This is running commentary on somebody else's stack of baseball cards. If you are lucky enough to have got ita rare Ted Williams, for exampleflaunt it and enjoy. If not, well, try to trade for it. Your Ted Williams for my Granny Hamner, Sherm Lollar, Ted Kluszewski, and Lauren Pepper. Or my Richie Ashburn for your Gino Cimoli, even up, since we're each holding doubles.

title: Sally Suominen Wed to C. E. Summerall
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Oct. 20Miss Sally Suominen and Charles E. Summerall, graduates of Syracuse University, were married here this morning in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee.

title: News Summar and Index SUNDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1973
description: The Major Events of the DaySection 1

title: Rinaldo Calls It Quite a Year For a Freshman in Congress
description: UNIONGerald Ford was in the House of Representatives when he received word that Spiro Agnew had resigned as Vice President. For Matthew 3. Rinaldo, who was serving as assistant to the man who was later nominated to fill the post, the scene would not easily be forgotten.

title: WOMEN WIDENING ROLES ON POLICE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 20Two years ago, there were six women on the police force in Dallas. Now there are 65 and, said Patrolman Jan Montgomery, because she insisted that women be on the street, the Chief of Police assigned her to the Tactical Patrol Unit.

title: Sydney Launches New Opera House
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 20Queen Elizabeth II today officially opened the giant $150million Sydney Opera House, a building designed to look like a ship under full sail, in spectacular ceremonies that imitated the launching of a real ship on the blue waters of Sydney Harbor.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The Truck Trend
description: DETROITOne evening not long ago, a couple going out for dinner drove up to the exclusive Detroit Athletic Clubnot in a Cadillac or a Lincoln, but in an ordinary Chevrolet van.

title: the traveler's world
description: THESE are perilous times for the airlines and for airline presidents, perilous and puzzling, too, because while some airlines are racking up alltime profits, other, equally good carriers flying beside them in the same economic and political climate are losing their shirts and, in two recent cases, their presidents. After staggering losses this year, Eastern and American Airlines last month shuffled off their presidents. Floyd D. Hall, Eastern's board chairman, assumed the presidency as well, while American's directors returned to the president's chair the man who built that line into one of the great and profitable carriers, 74yearold C. R. Smith, Smith had retired full of honors as chairman of American to be Secretary of Commerce briefly and was relaxing in the calmer waters of Wall Street.

title: The Presidency
description: WASHINGTONA few days after Spiro T. Angew resigned as Vice President and was convicted of income tax evasion, bumper stickers began appearing with the message, One down, one to go. However, crude, they were a clear reminder that President Nixon's problems had not vanished with his Vice President; in fact, the very occurrence of the unprecedented resignation under fire by Mr. Agnew seemed to remove the political inhibitions on public discussion of the worst possibilities facing Mr. Nixon.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL GETS FIRST CHIEF
description: Dr. Alfred Gellhorn, dean of the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and director of the Medical Center there, has been named the first director of City College's Center for Biomedical Education.

title: Clarkstown North Wins; So Does Spring Valley
description: Clarkstown North retained its undefeated status in Public School Athletid League play by defeating, Tappan Zee, 216, yesterday. Tom Sullivan led the North with two touchdown passes, one to Bruce Fritz for 36 yards and the other to Chet Mellen for 28. Rick Kolka, the county's leading groundgainer, scored id the final period on an 80yard run. Tappan Zee's touchdown came when Tony Chambrovitch raced 44 yards.

title: The Quality of Life Here Is Rated High in Survey
description: Tops in mental health and racial equality, and even in lowcost transportationthat was the New York metropolitan area at the end of the nineteensixties, according to efforts to measure some important aspects of the quality of life in 18 major urban areas.

title: Israel Reports Enlarging Of Foothold on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 20  Israeli orces on the west bank of the Suez Canal pushed out in three directions today, enlarging and deepening their foothold on Egyptian territory, a military spokesman said here.

title: In Cold Print: Copyright and Wrong
description: In Sweden, every time a book is taken out of the library the Govern. ment pays a small royalty to the author and the author's union. Not only that but one day in the spring of 1969 the authors mobilized Sweden's literary community to descend on its libraries and, with wheelbarrows waiting outside to cart them away, check out all available books. The object: To protest the small size of the royalty and the Government's failure to negotiate with the author's union over what it should be. The results: Empty library shelves and the royalty was raised.

title: Prison Reform
description: WASHINGTONStop building prisons! End disparities in sentencing! Find jobs for exconvicts! It was familiar stuff, and when the National Advisory Commission on criminal Justice Standards and Goals issued its massive blueprint for corrections reform last week, repeating these and other venerable goals, the yawn of deja vu was hard to stifle.

title: Upper brackets
description: ACROSS

title: Mini Horse Show Set for Central Park
description: A mini horse show, cosponsored by the Parks and Recreation Department and the National Horse Show, has been scheduled for the Great Lawn in Central Park next Saturday at 12:30 P.M.

title: Knowles Gave Staub Fastballs, Best I Have, to Get Key Out
description: OAKLAND, Calif. Oct. 20 In every ball game, many a manager has said, there is one key out that can be identified afterward as the nub of the victory or defeat. In today's 31 Oakland victory, which evened the World Series, it was the strike out of Rusty Staub by Darold Knowles in the eighth inning.

title: Yale Beats Columbia By 29 to 0
description: Yale scored its first Ivy Leaglie football victory of the year by thwarting Columbia, 29 to. 0, at Baker Field yesterday. It was the third game of four played in which the Lions went scoreless.

title: WORKSHOPS EXPLAIN FEDERAL PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Joint Center for Political Studies has announced that it has begun a series of regional workshops to acquaint local leaders of socially and economically deprived communities with new and changing Federal programs.

title: Nose to Nose With the White Rhino
description: I MADE a dash for a tree. It was a thorny and weaklooking bramble of a treehardly a suitable bardcade against a charging 3to4ton rhinocerosbut It was the sturdiest defense in sight. I was doing precisely What the game ranger had said we should do in case of being approached by a rhino. Get behind a tree, the biggest one you can find, he had told us. But the ranger hadn't told us what to do in case we should become surrounded by a number of these fierce mammoths. And that is exactly what had happened. There were no fewer than 11 huge white, or squarelipped, rhinoceroses in front, behind, to this aide, and to that side of us. And trying to, put a tree between myself and the nearest rhino seemed scant protection from several other rhinos a little farther away which happened to be behind me. Yes, I was terrified.

title: HIJACKED PLANE FLOWN TO BOLIVIA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 20 (UPI)  An Argentine Airlines plane was hijacked on a domestic flight today and flown to a Bolivian border town, where it was reported to be stranded.

title: Gardens
description: ISAAC NEWTON was hit on the head by an apple years ago. This minor natural phenomenon inspired him to pronounce the law of gravity. This is a basic law that must be considered in solving problems of steep slopes.

title: Antiques Festival Has Something for Everyone
description: There is no other show around quite like the National Arts and Antiques Festival, which opened yesterday for a nineday run at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: LEVITT CRITICIZES TRANSIT PROJECTS
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the Transit Authority had contracted to spend only 10 per cent of a 1967 bond issue authorization of $600million for new construction and that project costs had doubled in the meantime.

title: What to Look for in Car Safety
description: You want to buy the safest car available? What would you buy?

title: Simpson Needs 1,051 Yards in 9 Games to Snap Jim Brown's Mark
description: Henry Aaron will have 162 games next season in which to equal and surpass Babe Ruth's home run record. O. J. Simpson has nine left this season, one of them today, to break pro football's great record held by Jim Brown: most yards gained rushing in a season, 1,863. Brown set it 10 years ago playing for the Cleveland Browns.

title: Letters: How Dare She Call Our Collars Blue!
description: To the Editor:

title: Morristown Offers In and Out Surgery
description: MORRISTOWN  Morristown Memorial Hospital opened a $20million, sixstory wing this weekend, thus increasing its floor space from 277,000 to 477,700 square feet and offering this northwest New Jersey area many new medical services.

title: CHELSEA FIGHTING EFFECTS OF FIRE
description: CHELSEA, Mass., Oct. 20With the aid of Federal and state disaster relief agencies, supported by bardworking civilian volunteers, this industrial satellite of Boston is striving to recover from last Sunday's ruinous fire.

title: Tennessee Bows, 4221
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 20  Unbeaten Alabama exploded for three touchdowns in the fourth quarter and beat Tennessee, 4221, today in an impressive performance that could push the Crimson Tide into the No. 1 spot in college football.

title: Ali Batters Lubbers in Easy Decision
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 20Muhammad All battered Rudi Lubbers tonight in scoring a unanimous 12round decision over the Dutch heavyweight.

title: Headliners
description: A Matter of Ethics

title: President Sent Another Message to Brezhnev as Kissinger Left for Moscow Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 President Nixon sent another message today to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, after sending Secretary of State Kissinger on a flight to Moscow early this morning to discuss ways of ending the twoweekold Middle East war.

title: Leningrad Orchestra Performance Is Canceled on L.I. Because of Mideast War
description: MINEOLA, L.I.A concert by the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra scheduled to be held at the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University at Brookville tonight has been canceled by the Island Concert Hall, because of the Soviet policy of aiding the Arab nations in their war with Isreal.

title: What's Doing in Los Angeles
description: FIRST THINGS FIRSTRent car. All the cliches are teueLos Angeles is 100 suburbs in search of a cityand there is simply no other way to get around. Don't be afraid of the freeways; they are generally safe and efficient, except perhaps at 8 A.M. or 4:30 P.M., the peak hours; some interchanges are truly works of art. The major, rental companies generally charge $15 day and 15 cents a mile, but others are cheaper. DollarADay, for instance, will rent you a compact, standard shift car atyou guessed it$1 a day, plus 14 cents mile, with a 50mile a day minimuen. And they'll pick you up at the airport. The phone number of the Hollywood office is 4613291

title: Loughlin Harriers Triumph
description: The pattern of victory in scholastic crosscountry racing was virtually unchanged yesterday, as 2,000 runners from 130 schools competed in the St. John's University run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Child to Mrs. Waldron
description: A daughter was born Oct. 8 to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Waldron of Riverside, Conn., in the Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Waldron is the former Miss Pamela Labouchere of Wilton, Conn. The child, the couple' third, is named Allison Woodbury. Her father is president of F. C. Waldron & Co., Inc., an investmentadvisory firm.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Germany Invests in Schools
description: BONN (UPI)West Germany built about 8,700 schools from 1965 to 1970, averaging 1,740 new schools per year. They were built at a cost of 18billion marks (about $7.8billion), according to Education Ministry figures.

title: Hofstra Field Goal Downs Wayne, 96
description: DETROIT, Oct. 20  Jim Hogan's 44yard field goal with 8 seconds to play gave Hofstra University a 96 victory over Wayne State today. It was Hofstra't sixth triumph against one loss.

title: Red Bank Doubles Pleasure
description: It was a good day for Red Bank teams yesterday.

title: A Roundup of 1974 Models for the Domestic Auto Market
description: DETROITStyling still sells cars, says Gene Bordinat, vice president for design at the Ford Motor Company. I think it's the single most important factor.

title: 3dPeriod Spurt Wins For Suns
The New South
description: ATLANTAThe milling crowd had waited since the polls had closed earlier in the evening for this moment.

title: 8 MURDERS LAID TO A CALIFORNIAN
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 20 This scenic oceanside county of 124,000 population, referred to as the murder capital of the world by its district attorney In February, will witness its second mass murder trial of the year starting Tuesday.

title: U. N. Body Approves a Call For World Food Conference
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 A call for a world food conference to be held next year under United Nations auspices has been approved by the Economic and Social Council.

title: All About Hardiness
description: GARDENERS are aware of differences in cold hardiness among various ptints. Tomatoes, squash and marigolds turn black after the first frost. Cabbage, carrots and snapdragon are not harmed by light frosts, but succumb to a hard freeze. Some plants uch as maple, fir and juniper olerate50, or even colder.

title: Two novels, an anthology and an alphabet
description: The traditional purposes of literary innovation have been two: to develop new descriptive tools, perhaps by developing new ways of seeing; and more important, to discover new ways of probing the human psyche and exploring the human condition.

title: Irish Rout Army, 623
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 20Army and Notre Dame brought the magic of their football rivalry back to its birthplace today, producing the largest crowd and most festive traffic jam in West Point history.

title: Bahrain Orders U.S. Navy To Leave Dock Facilities
description: BAHRAIN, Oct. 20 (Reuters) The Persian Gulf country of Bahrain today canceled an agreement giving dock facilities here to the United States Navy, saving Washington had a week's warning that this would happen if it continued its hostile stand against the Arab nations.

title: ROBERT JACKSON, 93, EXDEMOCRATIC AIDE
description: Robert Jackson, lawyer and mining company officer, who served as secretary !if the National Democratic Committee from 1932 to 1934, died Friday in New York Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in Littleton, N. H.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Suddenly conservatism seems like the ideology where the fun is. This is a switch. In the old days (the Bogart era) it was the liberals who enjoyed life. Liberalism connoted cocktails, fast driving, advanced ideas about sex, crude sport with stuffed shirts and general hellraising. All the really great people were liberals. Bogart was a liberal. There wasn't anything else worth being.

title: News of the Camera World
description: A WORKSHOP on Women in Photography will be conducted by the Ansel Adams Gallery in Yosemite National Park Nov. 1725. It will explore the subject of women both as Subjects and photographers, and applicants from both sexes are welcome. Imogen Cunningham will be special guest instructor, and the workshop will include field and laboratory work, as well as lectures and individual consultation. The tuition will be $200. For information write to Ansel Adams Gallery, Box 455, Yosemite National Park, Calif. 95389.

title: Matlack Loose and Confident For SeventhGame Assignment
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 20Tomorrow's pitcher stood behind a table of hot dogs, chili, ham and vanilla cake. Jon Matlack still had his uniform on, as if he were going to wait in the New York Mets' clubhouse until it was time for him to warm up for tomorrow's decisive Seventh game of the World Series.

title: Home Improvement
description: AMMERING, banging, squealing or whistling noises in a home's plumbing system can not only be annoying, they can also be an early indication of plumbing defects that could develop into serious problems if ignored.

title: HOW BE 2 SIDES MEET WAR'S COST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 20 The financial support for the Middle East war has pitted the oil billions of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia against the huge voluntiuy contributions of American Jews to Israel.

title: In America's First Family of Tennis, They Start Out Early, Like at Age
description: When she was 4, the rumor was that she swatted tennis balls around her father's court with a sawedoff racquet. Now she's 6 years old, 3 feet tall, 53 pounds and ready to wield a fullsize racquet against tough competitors like big sister Chris.

title: Okker Tops Nastase
description: MADRID, Oct. 20 (AP)Tom Okker of the Netherlands downed topseeded Ilie Nastase, 64, 16, 75, today and advanced to the final of the Spanish international tennis tournament.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE complexion of the restive American economy is continuing to change. And so are the pronouncements of leaders in the private economic community who keep their stethoscopes fastened on the business pulse.

title: Transit Bond Vote
description: Two years after his $2.5billion bond issue was shot down at the polls, Governor Rockefeller will go to the people again on Election Day, this time with a $3.5billion package, and there were growing reports from around the state last week that the new model was facing the same fate as its predecessor for the same basic reasons: a credibility gap and the public's concern over rising costs.

title: Shipping Cars in Boxes
description: Detroit is borrowing an idea from the maritime worldthe cargo container in hopes of reducing the millions of dollars worth of damage inflicted by vandals on new cars during transit from the factory to the showroom.

title: Barbara Snyder Becomes Bride Of Thomas Lott
description: The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Barbara Blanchard Snyder to Thomas Fair Lott. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: Photography
description: WITH the SharpFocus Realists making hay while the photographic sun shines simply by copying photographic images in oil paint, it is good to be able to turn to the work of someone who has been experimenting with the same combination of media for much longer and has taken it well beyond such simplistic exploitation.

title: Ellen Coleman Flaherty Bride Of Joseph Andrew Brothers
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 20  Miss Ellen Coleman Flaherty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Flaherty of Wilmington and Mantoloking, N. J., and Joseph Andrew Brothers, were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Charles R. MacDonald in the Green Hill Presbyterian Church.

title: Auden as Critic
description: W. H. Auden wrote his literary criticism with his left hand, and it was all the better for it. His reputation didn't hang on it; he had a distaste for critical systems; with the exception of his lengthy comments on Shakespeare, he wrote mainly about prose. As a result, he could satisfy his own curiosities, he could let a point go once he had made it, and he was not tempted to build a defense for his poetry. He was one of the most pleasurable and enlightening critics to read.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Brazil, Bolivia. Uruguayand now Chile. Latin America is becoming a heap of ruined ideas and victims' bones. At the top tribunal of uniformed pygmies legislates, excommunicates, and executes nonbelievers. In, the meantime, Mr. Nixon washes his hands, Mr. Brezhnev dedicates psychiatric hospitals for incurable dissidents, Chou Enlai greets Mr. Pompidou, and alerts Western Europeans to the Russian peril. The peace of the superpowers is built en the relics of Greece, Czechoslovakia, Uruguay, Chile. In Prague, Russian tanks, and in Santiago generals trained and armed by the Pentagon have arrived at the same antithetical theorem  democracy and socialism are incompatible.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Since the appearance of my article For a Coop Owner the Lessons are Painful [Oct. 7], so many brokers have offered me suburban houses as an alternative to my cooperative apartment that I realize the article gave the unfortunate impression that I found no redeeming virtues in my coop ownership.

title: Getting a Boot Out Of Football the SmallCollege Way
description: EVERY once in, a great while the persistent smallcollege football viewer will discover that rare commodity, a genuine pro prospect. It is a surprising and rewarding occurrence, and it happened to me at Norwich University in Vermont. I was sitting with the home side rooters and he was playing for the opposition, American International College. So good were his speed and ballhandling skills that the entire game began to revolve around him. On the long sweeps around end he was too fast for his own blockers, as well as the Norwich defense, and his kick returns were nearly perfect pieces of openfield running, I wondered if professional scouts had somehow got wind of him and been lured to this remote football field or if the find was all mine. Apparently, alas, I was surrounded by scouts because the player (Bruce Laird) later became one of the early choices of the Baltimore Colts in the annual pro draft of the best football players.

title: A California Boy Follows In His Father's Footsteps
description: SANTA YNEZ, Calif. (AP)Jim Hanly, 17 years old, followed his father's footsteps when he was selected as this year's Boy's State representative of Santa Ynez Valley high school and Santa Ynez Valley Post No. 160, American Legion.

title: Canadiens Lose, 42, To Flames
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 20 (UPI)  Two goals by Larry Romanchych at right wing, led the Atlanta Flames to a 42 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: Lab at Princeton Fashioning Harness for Hydrogen Bomb
description: PRINCETON  Physicists at Princeton University are spearheading a multimilliondollar nationwide effort to harness nuclear fusion as an answer to the country's growing need for clean, abundant sources of energy.

title: Penn Central Beefs Up Jersey Service
description: The Penn Central Railroad is increasing its afternoon rushhour service from New York to mainline points in New Jersey by adding two commuter trains to its already crowded schedule.

title: Hospital Is Enlivened by Art
description: MORRISTOWNAs every television watcher knows, most hospital lobbies are bleak pacing places in which nervous people derive what comfort they can from dogeared magazines, nondescript chairs and plastic plants.

title: Camille Cerasoli Wed
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. Oct 20Miss Camille Pia Cerasoli, daughter of Dr. Arnold J. Cerasoli, a physician and Mrs. Cerasoli of MountVernon and Circleville, was married here this afternoon to Anthony Michael D'Aquanni, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter D'Aquanni of Mount Vernon. The Rev. John Gordon performed the ceremony in St. Ursula's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday announced his opposition to the $3.5billion transportation bond issue, and called on the other mayoral candidates to make a more intensive study of the issue.

title: A City Without Cars?
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.Downtown Providence is envisioned as a pedestrian city  its congested, narrow streets transformed into landscaped malls, plazas and small parksin an imaginative proposal devised by students of the Rhode Island School of Design.

title: Arthur Daley
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20The World Series has now reached such a preposterous state that not even Tug McGraw is sacred. The A's wheeled a hit and run out of him in the eighth inning today although the major damage to the Met cause had already been done. The A's had previously behaved disrepectfully against another of the Mets' most sacred cows, Tom Seaver, as they gained a solid 31 victory to deadlock this postseason fiesta at 3all. So the seventh game on the morrow will decide the identity of the new champions.

title: Musk: Chamber Society
description: The fifth season, a soldout house, a fine program, and a significant new faceall of that in Tully Hall on Friday night, when the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center held forth. The new face belonged to Jamie Laredo, who has replaced Charles Treger as the violinist in the society's permanent ensemble.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Capital Bullets, a team with a new name, a new home and a new coach, will play the Knicks at Madison Square Garden at 7:30 P. M. on Tuesday. The club, formerly the Baltime Bullets, is playing its home game at the University of Maryland until a new arena at Largo, Md., is completed. K. C. Jones, the former Boston Celtic star, became coach when Gene Shue resigned to go to Philadelphia. Shue will also come to the Garden on Saturday night at 8 P. M. with his new team, the 76ers, who compiled

title: TV Tower for Eagle Rock
description: WEST ORANGEThe Essex County Park Commission is expected to decide Wednesday whether to allow the construction of a 400foot commercial television transmission tower on public parkland atop Eagle Rock Mountain.

title: Help Program Is Established To Try to Aid Fraud Victims
description: A couple that bought a plot of land in New Mexico from a company that didn't own it; a woman on welfare whose furniture was being repossessed because she could not meet the monthly payments, and a photography buff who lost $300 to a flybynight company that promised a lifetime supply of filmall called Help.

title: Despite Lack of Data From Pilots and Officials, Reports of UFO Sightings Are Many and Widespread
description: Rarely, if ever, since Kenneih Arnold reported in 1947 seeing what came to be known as flying saucers during flight near Mount Rainier in Washingon State have there been such widespread reports of unidentified flying objects, or UFO's, as in recent days.

title: Disfigured Get New Lives
description: Eight patients are taking part in a hospital program in Brooklyn that is helping them to overcome the psychological effects of a disfiguring disease that often leaves women no longer feeling like women, in the words of Mrs. Elaine Heyman, who is in charge of the program at the Downstate Medical Center.

title: Older Veterans Getting Aid
description: NORTHPORT, L. I.  A United States Government unit that opened here six years ago primarily to aid veterans of the war in Vietnam is now being besieged by World War II veterans.

title: Condominiums Broaden Scope
description: The condominium  an individually owned property that Is part of a complex of many unitshas come of age.

title: Llana ArrottWatt Has Nuptials
description: In the Unitarian Church of All Souls here yesterday afternoon, Miss Llana ArrotWatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert ArrottWatt of Korumburra, Australia, became the bride of Thomas Michael Wyman, son of Mrs. Charles A. Wyman of New York and Holmes, N .Y., and the late Mr. Wyman.

title: DRIVER EDUCATION CRITICIZED ANEW
description: After more than a generation of highschool driver education, highway deaths are still mounting among the nation's young drivers.

title: A Bourse for Railroad Buffs
description: KETUCHEN Collectors of railroad memorabilia will meet here next Saturday to buy, sell and trade their wares. The Railroadiana Bourse, as it is known, will be held from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Holiday. Inn, which is situated at the junction of U.S. 1 South and I287.

title: This Is the Captain Speaking, and I'm in a Turbulent Mood
description: AT cocktail parties and church suppers these days, I shudder every time someone asks me what I do for a living. The reason, of course, is that as soon as it's revealed that I'm an airline pilot I get bombarded with complaints about service. Everyone seems to have his personal horror story to recitetelling of an instance of being bumped because of overbooking, being delayed or rerouted, or being served uneatable food. I used. to just grin and bear these stories, but recently I've taken to counterattacking. We crew members have some horror stories of our own to tell about the behavior of the passengers we, sometimes have to put up with.

title: Oakland Defeats Mets, 31, to Even World Series
Texts of the Letters and Proposals by Cox, Richardson and Wright
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Following are copies of correspondence and various proposals submitted by the special prosecutor, Archil:ald Cox; Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson and White House counsel concerning the White House tapes:

title: The Truth of Time
description: Now, in October, in the fall of the year, you can look at the horizon and see all the way to January, even to April if you are so minded, for it's a wide horizon now, and a wide, deep sky. Last summer is scuffling crisply underfoot, and the winter ahead is still a gabbled warning from the southbound geese.

title: Computer Simulates Road Perils For Pupils
description: EDISONA computerized educational system that simulates actual road conditions is teaching high school students in this Middlesex County community to drive.

title: The Arab Oil Weapon Comes Into Play
description: There has been no rest and relaxation this weekend for oil company executives and Government officials caught up in the worsening energy problem. The business and politics of oil have entered what appears to be the most difficult period in a long and volatile history.

title: 15 Vessels Stranded In Suez Canal Since 67
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20 (UPI)Fifteen foreign vessels stranded in the Suez Canal since the 1967 war are still there, but it is not known whether their skeleton crews are aboard, the Suez Canal Authority said.

title: Crane Wilbur, Film Actor, Writer and Director, Dies
description: TOLUCA LAKE, Calif., Oct. 20Crane Wilbur, who appeared in many motion pictures as well as on the Broadway stage, died Thursday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home. He was 86 years old.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The Polaroid Corporation has bet 15 years' research and $250million that its new instantpicture camera will revolutionize photography. It shortly will begin to find out what the payoff is.

title: News of the Screen
description: The suspense, if not the Mystery, is ended. The 74yearold Alfred. Hitchcock, who has been involved in filmmaking for a halfcentury, has started work on his 53d movle, the first since he directed his 1972 hit, Frenzy. And he has again joined Ernest Lehman, the screen writer of his successful 1959 thriller, North by Northwest, who is writing the prospective suspense drama for Universal, Which also released Frenzy.

title: A Breeze Blows Hot And Cold
description: MART CROWLEY'S A Breeze From the Gulf, now at the Eastside, is so honestly written and so perfectly performed that you cling to it for dear life, as though the very act of clinging might finally give it a shape. I don't think it has a shapeit's a threecharacter play that seems to me in desperate need of a fourthbut its fevered adolescent memories, loose as nightmare and always eager to touch old scars to make certain they are still there, have the fitful feel of life about them, itch by itch, blow by blow.

title: Delaware Is Beaten By Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20The longest college football winning streak came to an end today when Rutgers University crushed the Blue Hens of Delaware, 247, before a crowd of 21,000 fans.

title: Red Cross States Position On the Rights of P.O.W.'s.
description: GENEVA, Oct. 20Foreign volunteers are entitled to the protection of the Geneva convention guaranteeing prisoners of war humane treatment, a spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross said today.

title: Miss Anderson a Bride
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Oct. 20  Miss Christine Elizabeth Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Anderson of Foxboro, was married here this afternoon to Richard Salmon, son of Mr. and. Mrs. Charles Salmon of Baltimore. The Rev. Kenneth Bjorklund, a Lutheran minister, and the Rev. Paul McDonald, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The bride is advertising director of the M.I.T. Press journals department. Her husband is assistant financial manager of the M.I.T. Press.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1973
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 19  The ouster of Thailand's three most powerful army officers was all that was needed to start the country down the road toward democracy and the rapid solution of its problems, according to the 22yearold leader of the powerful student movement.

title: COX OFFICE SHUT ON NIXON'S ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20On orders from the White House, the Federal Bureau of Investigation sealed off tonight the offices of the dismissed special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and his staff.

title: Trenton: An Antique First
description: TRENTON  The capital of New Jersey is having its first major antique show and sale today and tomorrow.

title: New and Recommended
description: AS IF BY MAGIC, by Angus Wilson. (Viking, $8.95.) Hamo and Alexandra, two delightfully comic English eccentrics, set out to test their ideals in the world, which finds them wanting.

title: In Flushing Meadows The Glitter Is Gone But Hope Still Flourishes
description: The building has the foundations of a fortress, but its superstructure, elevated on pylons, is covered in peeling skin of blue and green glastic. Graffiti artists have risked their all to decorate the cornice high above. At the bottom, the dry reflecting pools are a tangle of ruined plumbing. Deeper within the derelict is sign, missing most of its letters: Exhibit Hall of the Great Society.

title: Wine Fills Water Tower
description: TELINS, France, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The water tower in this Rhone Valley town has been filled with wine because the harvest has been so abundant this year, that there was no more storage space in the local cellars, local officials reported today.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MONTCLAIR  If you know Bloomfield Avenue only as a heavily trafficked earlymorning and lateafternoon horror, its transformation into a delightful shopping street between rush hours may seem unbelievable. But here, and especially for shoppers who look for atmosphere as well as objects, are antiques shops by the dozen, art and curio dealers, the last word in boutiques and a myriad of other businesses as well.

title: Paper Hit by Shortage
description: BATON ROUGE, La. Oct. 18 (AP)Because of the newsprint shortage, the Louisiana State University student newspaper, The Daily Reveille, will switch to the type of paper used in telephone directories next semester.

title: 2 Sisters Are Thrown Out Of Hotel Window to Death
description: Two sisters from the Caribbean island of Grenada, one of them an airline stewardess, were thrown to their deaths early yesterday from a sixthfloor window of the Windsor Hotel at the Avenue of the Americas and 58th Street Three hours later, the principal suspect, a boyfriend of one of the dead women, apparently committed suicide by walking in front of an IRT subway train in Brooklyn.

title: LOCAL ACTION URGED ON SUPPLIES OF FOOD
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 20 (AP)Part of the problem involved in America's food prices and shortages has been a loss of selfsufficiency and local supply, contends Paul Hawkins, former president of the Erewohn natural food distributorship.

title: A Scuffie Erupts in Capital As U.S. Nazi Group Marches
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  A group of American Nazis dragging an Israeli flag toward the Israeli Embassy was set upon by members of they Jewish Defense League today and at least two persons were injured in the scuffle.

title: Top the aushak with chaka
description: The cook who wants to try something different might turn to the cuisine of Afghanistan. Rhea Talley Stewart went to that country as a tourist and stayed to do research into its history and cuisine. One product of her work was her recently published book, Fire in Afghanistan (Doubleday); another is a collection of Afghan recipes which she adapted to American ingredients. Her version of aushak a dish somewhere between lasagne and ravioli, and a recipe for elephant ears, wafer thin cookies, are given on this page. For those who want to eat approximately ethnic, add a vegetable salad of tomatoes, celery, radishes and onions to round out the meal.

title: Ohio State Conquers Indiana, 377
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 20 (UPI)Bruce Elia a fullback, and Cornelius Greene, a quarterback, scored two touchdowns each today as Ohio State trounced Indiana, 377.??

title: DALLAS SITE SET FOR DEVELOPMENT
description: DALLAS, Oct. 20A 53acre site on the western edge of the central business district hare has been chosen to be developed jointly by the city of Dallas and a private development group over the next 15 years.

title: Butterflies for Free on Staten Island
description: When Michael Zappalorti spots a butterfly dipping and fluttering near his home in the Charleston section of Staten Island, he breaks out a net, begins pursuit and eventually adds another specimen to his bulging collection.

title: Architecture
description: AKRON, Ohio THEY got it all together in Akron. The trials and errors of a 15year performing arts center building boom in the United States have finally produced a superb structurethe Edwin J. Thomas Performing Arts Hall, which had its gala opening last week.

title: Arming of Stony Brook Campus Guards Is Opposed
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Oct. 20  Student and faculty groups at the State University here are vehemently opposing a recommendation by the Stony Brook Council to train a carefully selected group of campus security officers to carry guns if such arming should later prove to be necessary.

title: More Tieups for the Motorists
description: TRENTON  Those New Jerseyans who drive to New York for work or pleasure should resign themselves to the fact that many months of restricted travel lie ahead.

title: Nixon Refuses the Court's Order, Richardson and Cox Reject Nixon's
description: WASHINGTONFor three months, despite a damaging loss in public prestige and the adverse rulings of the Federal courts. President Nixon had proclaimed his absolute right to refuse to yield up his White House tape recordings on conversations bearing on the coverup of Watergate crimes. Then, suddenly and unexpectedly but faced with a Court of Appeals decision that he either give in or appeal to the United States Supreme, CourtMr. Nixon brought forth what he thought was a political compromise.

title: Black Executives in New Rode
description: COLUMBUS, Ind.A nearly allwhite town of 27,000 famed mostly for its modern architecture and the Ku Klux Klan tradition of its environs seems an unlikely mecca for black executives hoping to rise in the corporate, world.

title: Recruiting Police
description: If your bent is police work and you haven't the equivalent of two years in college, don't apply for a job in Nassau County. On the other hand if you're shorter than 5 feet 11 and weigh less the 150 pounds forget about being a policeman in White Plains. If you're black or of Hispanic origin you'll find a warmer reception from police recruiters in New York City, Hartford and Newark. But if you're older than 34 forget Hartford; older than 35 don't try Newark. And the age limit is 27 in Mineola, 29 in New York City and White Plains.

title: Council Will Promote Trails
description: TRENTONThe establishment of a council to promote the development of trails throughout the state has been announced by Joseph J. Truncer, director of the Division of Parks and Forestry in the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: ...and again
description: There are no more doves left in Israel. In a way the exdoves are more furious than the hardliners. Theirs is the anger of patient men, in the Churchillian phrasemen who have tried to talk reason and to believe that Egypt's basic intention was to eventually coexist with Israel. Outside of the Arab Communist party in Israel, the whole country resounds with the quiet determination and tenacity of people who have learned a lesson which will long be remembered. Leftists and liberals, including splinter groups which are running in the coming elections on a peace platform and which have strongly criticized the Israeli Government's foreign policy, are expressing hardlining views and calling for revenge and punishment. Ha'aretz, Israel's leading independent daily, which usually takes a liberal and moderate stand on foreign affairs and security matters, and often criticizes the Government's policies on such issues, has openly advocated crossing the armistice lines and taking over strategically important territoryto cut not merely the fingers but the hand which was raised against us. Professors in Israeli universities, who in the past had signed petitions and public letters urging a more flexible policy toward the Arab states, have joined in denouncing the Arab attack as manifest annihilate Israel.

title: Westfield Notches No.46 Without a Setback, 356
description: New Jersey's top team, Westfield, increased its staterecord unbeaten streak to 46 games yesterday with a 356 victory over Cranford before 4,000 fans in Cranford.

title: $5 SPEEDS DATA TO BUSY PUPILS
description: WOODBURY, L. I., Oct. 20In this increasingly complex world, even the tradition of children's school work has developed specialists  Including a library research service that will supply information to young scholars.

title: A fifthdimension of authorship
description: The First Amendment protects, after a fashion, the freedom of the press, but there is noticing in the Constitution which guarantees access to that press, nor is there official encouragement for the publication of prose and poetry in these United States. From the beginning, the inviolable public press has been invariably commercial, imbued, like the republic itself, with the spirit of gain. As a result, our first national bard, Freneau, was permitted the dubious liberty of printing his poems in the newspapers he edited, and our first genius of fiction, Charles Brock den Brown, published his own work in his own magazine, thus establishing a samizdat tradition less in the face of oppression than indifference.

title: Bank Industry Is Riding Crest
description: PRINCETON  New Jersey's banking industry, reacting to the impact of industrial growth, economic pressures and changes in state banking laws, is riding the crest of a fouryear expansion that has raised its total assets to $27.1billion.

title: Kerr Reviews The Father
description: IT'S always satisfying in the theater to find yourself a little bit outsmarted. Near the end of The Father, Strindberg's apostrophe to the female as praying mantis and the male as all too obliging victim, the generally fine company assembled at the Roundabout Theater strikes a tableau. The Male, the unlucky father who can never be really certain he has fathered anyone, is by now trapped in a straitjacket a real oneand raving on a sofa, soothed only by his ancient nurse. (Nurses are not to be trusted any more Than wives are; it is this old nanny who has slyly slipped the jacket onto the child she weaned.)

title: L.I.U. Gains Soccer Tie
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 20Gone Gourdain of Long Island University captured an errant kick and turned it into a goal today to give the Blackbirds a 11 tie with Adelphi University in a Metropolitan Conference Division

title: Good investigative reporting
description: A dictum of conventional journalism is that the profession, and certainly its practitioners, are not news, but Jack Anderson has repeatedly and effectively transcended the fraternal rules. He is deservedly described as America's best known investigative reporter; if his sometimes breathless style displeases purists among his colleagues, the substance of his work ought to please anyone concerned with the continuing validation of the First Amendment and the ability of ordinary citizens to affect the course of government.

title: A New Regulation On Eggs Adopted
description: TRENTONA new regulation concerning the labeling of eggs has been adopted by the state's Board of Agriculture.

title: The Radial Arrives
description: AKRON, OhioAfter years of proven service in Europe, the radial tire is coming of age in America.

title: Trends
description: As Congress debates the Jackson Amendment and the political meaning of dtente, the degree to which Western influencesand dissentare permitted in the Soviet Union has become a major issue. How does the Soviet manonthestreet find out about the West? Hedrick Smith reports from Moscow.

title: Illegal Wiretaps?
description: WASHINGTONEarly last spring, before James McCord and John Dean opened the Watergates, reporters in Washington were being told that the breakin at the Democratic offices and its subsequent coverup were just the tip of the iceberg,

title: Curtain Time in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRA threeyearold professional theater group, one that offers a wide spectrum of dramatic skills, techniques and methods, has open its season an Thursday. Appropriately, it has chosen Thornton Wilder's Our Town as its initial pruduction.

title: Seagull to Be Seen Here
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (UPI) A Judge cleared the way yesterday for the movie Jonathan Livingston Seagull to have its premiere as planned in New York on Tuesday. Superior Court Judge Campbell W. Lucas, delayed a ruling on suits against Hall Bartlett, producer of the movie.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Confucian Confusion
description: HANGCHOW, ChinaConfucius is by far the best known ancient Chinese sage so it comes as a surprise to foreigners that this famous philosopher should be the center of a raging political storm involving both external and internal implications vital to modern China's destiny.

title: A Wonsan, an Artist and a Rebel
description: THE career of Mary Cassatt had its elements of drama  quiet, wellmannered drama, to be sure, but drama nonetheless. Coming from the best societyshe was a Philadelphia Cassattshe grew up in the newly acquired tradition of leisure to which the American upper classes, particularly its women, had been consigned. But beneath the good manners, the Worth dresses, the extravagant Reboux hats, she was something of a rebel a woman who knew her own mind and knew what she wanted to do in life. Born in Allegheny, Pa., in 1844, the daughter of a wealthy banker, she managed to persuade her reluctant father to allow her to take professional training as an artist at a time when it was considered hardly suitable for a young woman of breeding. She found the courses at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts dull and academic, however. In 1867, she went to France for three years of study and thereafter spent most of her life abroad.

title: High Court To Decide On Housing Of Students
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.The United States Supreme Court decision last week to heft a else involving the right of Belle Terre, an incorporated village about 15 minutes away from the State University campus here, to limit residency in housing is expected to have a major efSet on students living offcempus. It is the first time in 40 years that the Court has agreed to hear a basic zoning case.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Grouse Hunt
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N. H.Walking along a logging road, I surprised three ruffled grouse scratching for grit and basking in the warm midafternoon sun.

title: Brooklyn Youth Slain Resisting Theft of His Coat
description: A 19yearold Brooklyn youth who wanted to become a policeman and had patrolled his Williamsburg neighborhood for more than a year as a police aide was stabbed to death a block from home early yesterday when he tried to resist a gang of eight thugs who stole his coat.

title: Rich Rock From Canada
description: LIGHTHOUSE is an exception to the general rule that basic, danceable rock and roll does not mix easily with symphonic instrumentation. The nineman Canadian group employs electric cello and viola in addition to a threeman horn section, guitar, piano, bass and drums.

title: Post Wins, 2423, on Pass, Kick
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Oct. 20 Ed Powers, quarterback, connected on a 9yard scoring pass to Richard Maake, a flanker, as C. W. Post College came from behind to defeat Kings Point, 2423, in a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Football Conference game. The victory was Post's fifth in six games. Kings Point has a 33, wonlost record.

title: Auto Boom Amid Signs Of Revolt
description: IT'S a believeitornot year for the automobile industry. Believe it or not, we already have:

title: KGGMTV, Albuquerque, and CBS, New York
description: It's still dark at 5:25 A.M. when Gail Noble, a heavyset, baldish man with arthritic legs, rolls his wheelchair to the locked doors of the studio. Inside, he turns on the ceiling lights and begins flipping heavy electronic switches. At about the same time, on a nearby mountaintop, an alarm clock rouses Bill. Smith, who shuffles in old moccasins through his building, turning on antenna circuits at the highest television transmitter site in the world.

title: For connoisseurs of Southern politics
description: It, would be impossible to write a dull biography of Leander Perez, that outrageous, preposterous, dictatorial thief; that pernicious, egregious, bigoted mugwump. He was a caution, ol' Leander was. From the 1920's until his death in 1969 he ran Plaquemines Parish, south of New Orleans, and Plaquemines will be lucky if it gets over the experience. Among connoisseurs of Southern politicians, the Judge (he was actually the District Attorney, but that's just a minor lunacy) is always counted as one of the Real Greats.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the. United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Nassau Library May Be TV Showcase
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I. Everybody from 8 to 88 could be a potential television star or producer, using Nassau County's 53 libraries as studio resources, according to Andrew Geddes, director of the Nassau Library System, who said that such a plan is under study.

title: Navy Routs Air Force Team, 426
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 20 (UPI)Cleveland Cooper, a running back, scored three touchdowns and Al Glenny, quarterback, threw his first three scoring passes of the season today as Navy, routed the Air Force Academy, 426.

title: WOMEN WIDENING ROLES ON POLICE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 20Two years ago, there were six women on the police force in Dallas. Now there are 65 and, said Patrolman Jan Montgomery, because she insisted that women be on the street, the Chief of Police assigned her to the Tactical Patrol Unit.

title: Courtlandt Gross Weds Shirley Brewster Davis
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 20  The Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss. Shirley Brewster Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newlin Fell Davis of Haverford, to Courtlandt Devereux Gross, who is with White, Weld & Co., investment bankers in New York.

title: Things to Consider in Shopping for a '74
description: If price is the main consideration, now is probably a better time to buy a new car than later.

title: In Morris, a Painful Schools Merger
description: MORRISTOWN  The merger of two school districts to achieve racial integration here is proceeding painfully, inexorably and, despite the fact that similar efforts elsewhere are floundering.

title: Knicks Bow, 8569; Record Low Score
Again, again ...
description: Why now? Why more blood on the sands of Sinai? The last patch is barely dry. The battered remnants of the round of 1967 are still visible to the eye, and memories of that war continue to gnaw at the souls of the relatively few not sick of the whole affair. The last thing anyone needed was a new war in the Middle East.

title: Nixon Requests $150Million For Relief on 3 Continents
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) President Nixon has asked Congress for an additional $150million to help with disaster relief in Pakistan, the subSahara region of Africa, and Nicaragua.

title: The Auto Disposal Problem
description: Roughly every 25 seconds somewhere in the United States, someone will park his automobile, take the keys out of the ignition, remove the license plates and other traces Of registration, and walk away from the car, leaving it forever.

title: The Cranberry: Ruby of the Barrens
description: CHATSWORTHThe Lenni Lenape Indians had a legend about how cranberries came to New Jersey thousands of years ago.

title: Bill on Federal Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, has introduced legislation that would end the Government's practice of awarding contracts without bids, and said he was acting in the light of former Vice President Agnew's case.

title: GREEK CHIEF DROPS POLITICAL TALKS
description: ATHENS, Oct. 20Greece's new Premier, Spvros Markezinis, decided today to drop plans for a dialogue with the country's former political leaders about the planned general elections.

title: Why Pick on Love Story?
description: JUST to be perverse about it, I rather like Love Story and Shaft. You can stop right now, unload me, put some other tapedeck into your brain, and the world will go on humming without appreciable damage. But ... I fail to see in what way these two new programs are any worse than 85 per cent of the rest of the programs on prime time. It's as though the critics, paddling across the pond of their own torpor, had paused to stick a couple of frogs. Love Story and Shaft got stuck because they were unlucky enough to be there during the pause.

title: Gas Fumes Kill 2 in Bronx Building
description: Two persons were killed and 10 others were injured late Friday night when gas fumes from a coal furnace rushed through an apartment building in the Bronx.

title: Bridal Is Held For Miss Falk
description: Miss Margaret Sue Falk, copy editor of Esquire magazine, was married here yesterday afternoon to Giovanni A. de la Rama Pirovano, an investment manager with Field Enterprises in New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Edgar performed the ceremony in the Central Presbyterian Church.

title: Suffolk Farm Plan Too Late for Some
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.  For nearly 50 years William Mackno and his two sisters have worked the 42.5acres of farmland their father, Jacob, bought here shortly after the end of World War I in the heart of the Eastern Long Island farm belt.

title: The doctrine of Zealous Nationalism
description: The agony, of the Vietnam war, whatever else it has done to the United States, has certainly had one salutary effect. No previous period in the country's history has produced so extensive and so penetrating a scrutiny of American foreign policy and of the elements in the  national thinking which have shaped it.

title: DISMISSAL POSES LEGAL QUESTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The events of this day posed series of legal questions.

title: Cultural Aspirations of 4 Parents Mushroomed Into a Music and Arts Foundation
description: CEDARHURST, L. I.  In 1948, four residents of the Five Towns area who were disturbed about the lack of local cultural opportunities for their children, organized one music appreciation class.

title: POINT OF VIEW
