description: High food prices have been the dominant domestic problem facing the Nixon administration this year. They have plagued most American families.

title: Stone Supplier Switches to Gems
description: NORTHPORT, L I.There is a man on Long Island with rocks in his head. His name is Clem Reseska, and he presides over a world of gems and geodes, crystals and fossils, in a most unlikely place.

title: Nobel Winners
description: Henry Kissinger was chairing a White House meeting of the Washington Special Action Group on the Middle East crisis when he received the note last week. He smiled and passed the note. Then, applause.

title: The Ballet: Interplay
description: Jerome Robbins's Interplay is, given a good per formance, virtually indestructible. Friday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, the Joffrey Ballet gave it a good performance. In fact, the company gave it an excellent performance.

title: Grownups Join Children in Model Sailboat Regatta
description: It was a warm and bright picnic day in Old Greenwich, Conn., last Sunday for the ninth annual model sailboat regatta at Binney Pond. Hundreds of eager kids and equally eager parents showed up to launch their miniature craft on the sparkling pond. But the sailboats that stole the children's show were owned and operated by two grownups, Ed Laviano and Andy Minder, each of whom had invested more than $500 in his toy boat. The two men came to the event to show off their radiooperated catamarans and spend the afternoon exchanging pointers with other developmentminded catamaran builders.

title: Nixon Signs Bill to Finance Radio Free Europe for Year
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  President Nixon has signed legislation authorizing $50.2million for the operations of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty for the 1974 financial year, which began last July 1.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WASHINGTONMany of the comments on the military coup in Chile have been to the effect that this proves the impossibility of achieving socialism in Latin America by peaceful means. Those who favor socialism, it is then argued, have no choice but to seek their goal through violence.

title: Bucknell, Lafayette Play Scoreless Tie
description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 20 Bucknell battled Lafayette to a 00 tie today.

title: L.I. Woman Sea Captain
description: MONTAUK, L. I.With her slender figure, her long blueblack hair painstakingly teased into bouffant style, and her eyes expertly shadowed and lined, Elizabeth Ann Mulhern defies the stereotype.

title: A prewar Duesenberg Arlington sedan
description: While some people are content to amass Rembrandts, Tiffany vases or diamonds, one of the hottest growth industries collecting is being spurred by those prefer cast aluminum to stamped tin, real leather to vinyl, and guttapercha to vakelite, and who therefore collect  and invest inclassic cars.

title: The Tape Coverup
description: President Nixon's abominable solution to the legal battle over the Watergate tapes has confronted a shaken country with a devastating new crisis. The firing of Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox, coupled with the courageous resignation in protest by Attorney General Richardson and the summary ouster of Deputy Attorney General Ruckelshaus for refusing to take his place, make it plain that the nation is in the hands of a President overcome with dictatorial misconceptions of his constitutional authority.

title: Veterans Day
description: Today is Veterans Day, a national holiday formerly, called Armistice Day and observed for many years on Nov. 11. Schools, banks, post offices, courts and mostother government offices will be closed. Garbage will not be collected in New York City and alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended.

title: Personal Finance
description: Taxpayers have lost two important deduction cases in the courts recently and won one significant concession from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: L.I. Prisoner in Turkey Called Victim Of Backlash on U.S. Narcotics Policy
description: NORTH BABYLON, L. I.His family remembers Billy Hayes when he was free, when he surfed in the waters off Long Island, when he rode motorcycles and took parachute jumps and ran with the bulls at Pamplona.

title: PAUL GODLEY DIES; PIONEER IN RADIO
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Oct. 21 Paul F. Godley, a radio pioneer who won fame for his successful transAtlantic shortwave tests five decades ago for the American Radio Relay League, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in little Falls.

title: Stevenson to Propose Renewal of Prosecutor
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP)Senator Adlai Stevenson 3d, Democrat of Illinois, said today that he was preparing legislation to reestablish the office of the special Watergate prosecutor.

title: Shirley Verrett Takes Up the Challenge
description: A group of opera buffs, was standing in the ticket line outside the Metropolitan, chatting about Shirley Ver. rett's return to the opera house after two years, to take the role of Cassandra.

title: B.P. Lawyers Study Implication Of Judgment on Libyan Actions
description: LONDON, Oct. 21Lawyers for British Petroleum are studying the implications of a judgment by an arbitrator that Libya's nationalization of the company's Sarir oilfields was illegal and confiscatory.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A new state law helping New York consumers to correct billing errors will go into effect on Nov. 1, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced. Under the law, a customer who feels a bill is in error can send written notice by registered mail to the creditor within 30 days. The creditor is obligated to respond within 15 days and to take action if there is an error within 60 days. Merchants cannot dun during the 15day period, and are liable for damages if they fail to follow the procedure.

title: Israelis Are Assured Army Is Eating Well
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 21 (AP)The Israeli state radio has assured Israelis that their soldiers are eating well on the front. The station sent one of its reporters to war zones to test the food.

title: Most in Gibraltar Oppose Spanish Claim
description: GIBRALTAR, Oct. 19  Majority opinion in this Britishheld fortress appears as adamant as ever in its opposition to Spanish claims to sovereignty despite what Spain has called generous offers.

title: 5 Die in Vancouver Fire
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 21 (AP)Five persons were killed by a fire that burned through the top floor of the Columbia Hotel in the downtown section here today. Four were dead on arrival at the hospital. A fire chief said that at least two of them died trying to escape by jumping from the fourth floor. A fifth died in the hospital.

title: Criticism of Nixon Rising Arnong Area Congressmen
description: A number of Democratic Congressmen in the tristate area called yesterday for the impeachment of President Nixon while even the President's fellow Republicans were highly critical of him, although generally stopping short of demands for impeachment.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown refleets prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: PRIMERATE CUT AIDS BOND PRICES
description: Creditmarket analysts view the reduction in the prime rate, announced Friday by several of the nation's largest banks, more as a confirmation of the recent downtrend in shortterm money rates than as a signal that rates will start dropping sharply now.

title: SOPRANO SHOWS ELAN IN CITY OPERA BOW
description: The New York City Opera added a promising soprano to its roster on Saturday afternoon when Diana CataniSoviero made her debut with the company as Nedda in Leoncavallo's Pagliacci.

title: SINGER AND PIANIST MAKE DEBUTS HERE
description: Rosemary George and Emanuel Krasovsky, two of the four winners in this year's auditions sponsored by a group called East and West Artists, made their New York debuts Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. Of the two, Mr. Krasovsky, a Russian pianist who emigrated to Israel and who is working now at the Juilliard School, made the more striking  if not necessarily the more pleasant  impression.

title: FUEL SUPPLIERS REJECT CONTRACTS
description: Manyfueloil distributors are refusing to make oil available to previous customers at the 1972 level, although that was the basis on which major oil refineries were required to make fuel available to them under Federal regulations, a New York State commission said yesterday.

title: Palestinian Raids Reported
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 21 (UPI)Palestinian guerrillas have born. barded 42 northern Israel civilian settlements, causing one death and wounding 16 people, since the war began, the Israeli state radio said today. The station, giving no source for its figures, said that in 202 armed encounters with the guerrillas since Oct. 6, Israeli security forces had killed 10 infiltrators and caught one.

title: HARLEM MAN IS SLAIN BY GUNMAN WITH DOG
description: A 44year old Harlem man was shot dead early yesterday when he tried to enter his apartment building but was blocked by a man with a dog.

title: Marcos Plan Another Vote
description: MANILA, Oct. 21 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos said in a newspaper interview today that he planned to call another referendum on martial law, probably next year.

title: About New York
description: Almost 10 years ago, the most celebrated morality play in New York was the murder trial of Mark Fein. It had everything, and most of all it had Mark Fein, a rich executive from Park Avenue, who was accused of killing Ruby Markowitz, his bookmaker frm Williamsburg.

title: Okker Defeats Fillol
description: MADRID, Oct. 21 (AP)Tom Okker of The Netherlands defeated Jaime Fillol of Chile, 46, 63, 63, 75, today and won the Spanish international tennis tournament in a grueling 2hour match.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: P.B.A. Sees No Pact With Lindsay

title: Veterans Day
description: Today is Veterans Day, a national holiday formerly called Armistice Day and observed for many years on Nov. 11. Schools, banks, post offices, courts and most other government offices will be closed. Garbage will not be collected in New York City and alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Oct. 22, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bridge: Apfel and Schoenfeld Take Metropolitan Pairs Title
description: One of New York's greatest veteran experts captured the open pair title at the Metropolitan championships at the New York Hilton here Saturday. Dr. Kalman Apfel, whose busy medical practice leaves him little time to demonstrate the expertise that brought him two national titles in the fifties, was successful teamed with Abe Schoenfeld of Hicksville, L.I.

title: Priest Among 3 Cabot Prize Whiners
description: The Maria Moors Cabot prizes for interAmerican journalism will be awarded this week to David F. Belnap, bureau chief in Buenos Aires for The Los Angeles. Times, the Rev. Donald J. Casey, M.M., editor of the Maryknoll magazine and director of World Horizon Films, and Diana Julio de Massot, editor and publisher of the newspaper La Nueva Provincia of Bahia Blanca, Argentina.

title: DERELICT, SET AFIRE BY MIAMI BOYS, DIE,
description: MIAMI, Oct. 21 (AP) A homeless derelict died today after he was doused with gasoline and set afire by four teen agers who also set fire to a second man and tried to ?? a third, the police said.

title: Rolling Stone Is Still Gathering Readers, Revenue and Prestige
description: With a mixture of rock criticism and rock gossip and serious reporting on national issues, the twicemonthly Rolling Stone magazine has reached a circulation of 325,000, and the end of the climb does not seem near.

title: LEVITT CRITICIZES STATE U. COLLEGE
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 21  State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that the State University College at Old Westbury was not using its buildings and its faculty enough.

title: Public Reacts Strongly to Cox Ouster
description: Half a block from the White House yesterday, James Goodnow stationed himself on the sidewalk in front of the Treasury Building along with two large cartons full of imitation straw hats bearing Impeach Nixon labels.

title: HONDA'S ENGINES USED IN BIG CARS
description: The unconventional autoengine technology of Japan's Honda Motor Company has registered a significant new accomplishment in the battle aginst pollution.

title: F.B.I. Guarded Jackson for Playoffs, Series
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21  A letter threatening the life of Reggie Jackson, received by the Oakland A's a few weeks ago, caused him to be guarded by the Federal Bureau of Investigation throughout the American League playoffs and the World Series, Jackson revealed after the Series ended with his team victorious and himself the winner of the Most Valuable Player award.

title: North Carolina Editor, 66, Will Retire at End of Year
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP)J. Wallace Carroll, 66yearold editor and publisher of The WinstonSalem Journal and Sentinel, will retire at the end of this year, the paper said today.

title: Gross for Series Almost $4Million
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 21 (AP)The final World Series and playoff financial figures, as released today by the office of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn:

title: Jersey Schools to Cut Heat To Help Meet Oil Shortage
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 21Thermostats in classrooms of schools here, as well as in other areas of Union County and neighboring Morris County, will be lowered tomorrow as a result of notices of cutbacks in fuel oil deliveries.

title: Europe, Relying on Arab Oil, Seeks New Energy
description: BONNA revolution during the last decade in the way that Western European countries obtain their enemy, with everincreasing dependence on imported oil, is responsible for the region's unprecedented vulnerability to any Arab oil embargo.

title: In Turin, Cardinal Speaks Out for Workers
description: TURIN, ItalyHe was born 70 years ago, the son of a stone mason, and as a young seminarian in the Piedmontese town of Cueno he helped his father build walls.

title: NATHANIEL BLOOM
description: Nathaniel Bloom, a director of M. Bloom & Sons, sample card printers, died Saturday in the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: NIXON DEFENDED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Some of President Nixon's top assistants said today they were confident that Congress would not institute impeachment proceedings in the wake of his latest shakeup at the Justice Department.

title: Step to Peace
description: In a frenzied weekend of negotiations between Secretary of State Kissinger and Communist party leader Leonid I. Brezhnev in Moscow, the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to call for an urgent ceasefire in the ArabIsraeli war. By any measure this is a significant achievement in diplomacy, at a moment when it seemed that the tempers of combat and great power rivalry had taken tragic control of a long simmering regional confrontation.

title: Soviet Industrial Performance Recovered During Nine Months
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21  The Soviet Union disclosed today that its industrial performance for the first nine months of 1973 had recovered after last year's poor showing, although the consumer sector is still lagging behind goals set.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Sports Injury Clinic Set Up by Doctor, an ExAthlete
description: NEWARK, Oct. 21A sports injury clinic to provide orthopedic diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitative services for injured athletes, especially on the high school and college levels, has opened at the Orthopedic Center of United Hospitals of Newark Park Avenue? The clinic, which is held on the first and third Wednesday of each month, is under the direction of Dr. Max M. Novich, a burly surgeon who boxed his way in North Carolina and has been a sports enthusiast ever since.

title: Parsons Takes NASCAR Title
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct. 21 (UPI)  David Pearson drove his Mercury to almost a twolap victory today over Buddy Baker's Dodge in the American 500 stock car race. But the big winner of the day was Benny Parsons in the final Grand National race of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

title: White House Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21It was not the kind of day for impeaching a President.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: David W. D. Dickson was installed yesterday as president of Montclair State College in ceremonies attended by representatives of about 250 colleges and universities. Dr. Dickson, the fifth president of the college, succeeded Dr. Thomas W. Richardson.

title: Going out Guide
description: NATIVE CUSTOMS Ernest L. Chambre works as a customs broker and freight forwarder and would be unknown by any collector other than those who held the now defunct title of the Collector of Customs. Yet for 30 years he has been a No. 1 collector in his field, which may not have a No. 2. He has amassed more than 18,000 documents dealing with United States Customs, and a vast number of them are fascinating, historically valuable keepsakes.

title: NAPHTALI TURSINAI, HEBREW SCHOLAR, 86
description: Dr. Naphtali Herz Tursinai, a leading authority on Semitic languages who had been president of the Hebrew Language Academy and the first Bialik Professor of Hebrew Philology at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, died Wednesday in Jerusalem, where he lived. His age was 86.

title: CHESTER E. REILLY
description: NEPTUNE, N.J., Oct. 21 Chester E. Reilly, who retired last May as executive vice president and a director of the United States Tobacco Company, died yesterday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Spring Lakes, and formerly in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: ACCOUNTING BOARD DRAFTS STANDARDS
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the organization set up last summer to write the rules for corporate reports, issued today an exposure draft of its first statement of accounting standards.

title: JOHN BARNHILL DIES; EXFOOTBALL COACH
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 21 (AP)John H. Barnhill, director of athletics at the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville from 1946 to 1970, died at a hospital here today. He was 70 years old.

title: Japan's Payments Deficit Nearing a Critical Point
description: TOKYO, Oct. 21 Japan is swiftly approaching a critical point in her balance of international payments, which has run in the red for seven consecutive months.

title: Sneed Wins Kaiser Golf In Playoff
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI) Ed Sneed, playing in the shadow of fellow Ohio State graduates, Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf, defeated John Schlee on the first extra hole today to win the $150,000 Kaiser International open golf tournament.

title: Nets Beat Utah Stars; Erving: 33
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 21 Joe Mullaney had a tough night on his first trip to his native New York as the new coach of the Utah Stars.

title: A College Head Cooks for His Students
Prison Rodeos Rated With Best
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Oct 21William Bailey held firmly to the sides of the wooden rodeo starting gate to steady himself as he slid into position on the bull in the No. 7 chute.The announcer facetiously encouraged him to keep practicing his redeo skills, saying, You'll be a rodeo champion before you get out.

title: Protein Found in Elderly Studied for Link to Aging
description: A mysterious natural substance, known for more than a century, has been discovered with such startling frequency in elderly people recently that scientists studying it now hope it will unlock some secrets of the aging process.

title: 3M REPORTS PROFIT ROSE 20% IN QUARTER
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday a 20 per cent increase in thirdquarter earnings on a sales gain of 20 per cent, setting a record for both the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: A's Feel They Play Best in Crisis
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21 Even though we won, I think people can't see how well we can really play, and we'd like to prove it to them, said Sal Bando, captain of the Oakland A's right after they won the World Series today in the final game for the second time in two years.

title: 1,900 Row at Cambridge, But One, 78, Is Ashore
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21The annual river jam took place on the Charles today. More than 1,900 oarsmen, competing in 460 racing shells that ranged from small singles to sleek eights, weaved along a threemile serpentine course causing considerable gawking by passing motorists.

title: Cox Office Plans to Maintain Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Watergate special prosecution force, with its leader, Archibald Cox, dismissed yesterday by Presidential edict, plans to continue its investigation, a spokesman said today.

title: SYRIANS REPORT A BIG AIR BATTLE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 21An Israeli air raid, the first in this capital for six days, sent Syrian MIG fighters scrambling into combat, today for what a Syrian military spokesman called a great battle.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: COLONIA, Oct. 21You might say that sports is the No. 1 topic in the Peragallo household.

title: Jordanians Are Voicing Battle Cries
description: WADI EL SIR, Jordan, Oct. 21Jordanian troops are using an ancient Arab psychological weapon in their clashes with Israeli forces, Jordanian authorities reported todaysaihag albarb, the battle cry.

title: ECONOMIC DEBATE ERUPTS IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 21A major Government debate, with political and ideological overtones, has erupted over India's economic policies.

title: Sneed Wins Kaiser Golf In Playoff
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI) Ed Sneed, playing in the shadow of fellow Ohio State graduates, Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf, defeated John Schlee on the first extra hole today to win the $150,000 Kaiser International open golf tournament.

title: Dolphins Top Bills, 276, Hold Simpson to 55 Yards
description: The championship pretensions of the Buffalo, Bills and the recordbreaking aspirations of their star running back, O. J. Simpson, were bath rudely jolted yesterday by the tenacious defenders of the Miami Dolphins.

title: A Mideast Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The absence of peace between Israel and her Arab neighbors carries a threat of world economic chaosparticularly if the war is allowed to spread into the oil fields of Iraq. The world has lived with this danger for years. It cannot live another month with the aggressive arms airlift Russia is running to her Arab satellites.

title: Ribera's Art in Scholarly Show
description: Jusepe de Ribera: Prints and Drawings, a new exhibition at the Art Museum of Princeton University, exemplifies one of the happiest current developments in the overall American art scene. After closing on Nov. 18 it will move on to Harvard's Fogg Museum (Dec. 8Jan. 13), which pretty well defines its character as a scholarly study on a subject devoid of razzledazzle.

title: COX OFFICE PLANS TO PRESS INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Watergate special prosecution force, with its leader, Archibald Cox, dismissed yesterday by Presidential edict, plans to continue its investigation, a spokesman said today.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: FASHION TALK
description: Nostalgia is apt to keep its icy grip on the young as long as the young keep their eyes glued to old movies onthe television screen and old musicals are revived on Broadway. So Pinky Wolman and Dianne Beaudry are kept busy designing clothes to wear while watching the late show. As it happens, they wouldn't go amiss at a rock concert either.

title: Criticism of Nixon Rising Among A rea Congressmen
description: A number of Democratic Congressmen in the tristate area called yesterday for the impeachment of President Nixon while even the President's fellow Republicans were highly critical of him, although generally stopping short of demands for impeachment.

title: Veterans Day Closings
description: Many businesses and industrial plants, the nation's major securities exchanges and some commodity exchanges remain open today, Veterans Day However, all Federal offices are closed; state offices in many states are closed, as are banks in New York and New Jersey and some other states, In New York, commodity exchanges closed include the New York Cotton Exchange, the Commodity Exchange, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

title: Risa Rosenthal Bride Of Dr. Noah S. Finkel
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 21 Miss Risa Rae Rosenthal, assistant to the articles editor of McCall's magazine, was married today at Temple Israel to Dr. Noah Scott Finkel, chief resident in orthopedic surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Mordecai Waxman and Isaac L. Swift, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel.

title: A HASTY MEETING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 21The United States and the Soviet Union today sub mitted to a hastily called meeting of the United Nations Security Council a joint resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire in the Middle East.

title: Aggressive Dallas Play, Turnovers Decisive
description: IRVING, Tex., Oct. 21The season may have ended for more than the New York Mets today.

title: Lively Illegal Border Traffic Runs From Senegal to Portuguese Guinea
description: BANGANGA, Senegal, Oct. 12  Jean Correa returned this morning to his village from boarding school to help With the harvest. He ran with eager young cousins to check the corn, sorghum and rice crops and to pause for a short time to ask the spirit of the tree for help with a good harvest, to insure that the Casamance River fish are plentiful, that cattle thieves will pass our village by and that the Portuguese do not attack us.

title: Green of A's Says He's Going to Retire
description: OAKLAND, Calif., 21 (AP) Dick Green, the Oakland second baseman who changed his mind about retiring two years ago, said after the end of the World Series today: I think it's time to quit. The 32yearold infielder added, I'm happy to be going out on top.

title: Net Final Taken By Chris Evert
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 21 (Reuters)Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won the $110,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today by defeating Mrs. Nancy Gunter of Lake Livingston, Tex., 63, 63, in the final.

title: HarvesterUnion Accord On Overtime Is Reported
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UPI)Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that negotiatcirs for striking union members and the International Harvester Company had reached agreement on the issue that triggered the strikevoluntary overtime.

title: Prankster's U.F.O.. Steals Show at L.S.U. Game in Biggest Surprise of the Day
description: The most unexpected thing to happen Saturday during a ing a game involving one of the top 10 teams in the nation was the sighting of an Unidentified Flying Object over Tiger Stadium in Baton Rouge, La., during halftime of the Louisiana StateKentucky contest. Most of the 68,000 people at the night game saw the brightly glowing thing float in a southwesterly direction with a police helicopter in pursuit.

title: Advertising: A Special Delivery
description: If major American corporations can take to advertising to cure that unloved and misunderstood feeling, why shouldn't the United States Postal Service? It certainly hires enough people and loses enough money to qualify as large.

title: L.I. Poloists Win
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 21Long Wand took an eightgoal lead in the first chukker and defeated the Fairfield County Hunt Club of Westport, Conn., 2016, last night, in the final round of the northeast circuit eightgoal polo championship. Tony Coppola, led Long Island with 10 goals.

title: Gloom Settles Early Here For the Mets' Believers
description: For believers, gloom began to settle in the city's homes and watering places around the third inning yesterday when the Mets fell one day short of a seasonful of miracles.

title: Rev. J. Vincent Watson, 57, Retreat Master on L.I., Dies
description: MANHASSET, L. L, Oct. 21The Rev. J. Vincent Watson, retreat master at St. Ignatius Retreat House here, died today in North Shore Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: MacPhail to Head American League
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Lee MacPhail, vice president and general manager of the New York Yankees, will be named American League president and Joe Cronin will be named chairman of the board at a league meeting in Chicago Tuesday.

title: Ballet: Utah Repertory Ends Visit
description: The Repertory Dance Theater of Utah ended its latest New York visit at the Hunter College Playhouse last weekend, Among the attractions was the world premiere of Glen Tetley's Stationary Flying, given its first performance last Thursday but seen by me on Saturday. The title proved somewhat indicative of the work.

title: Mets Plan Parley on Berra Pact
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21 Regarding the rehiring of Yogi Berra as the New York Mets' manager, M. Donald Grant, the club chairman, commented today, I'm sure we'll negotiate something in the near future.

title: Moscow, Backing Sihanouk, Will Leave Only Caretakers in Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENN, Cambodia, Oct. 21The Russians, whose profile in Cambodia has been se low you could hardly make them out, are now, somehow, preparing to crouch even lower.

title: Byrne and Sandman Clash Sharply on Major Issues
description: New Jersey's two major candidates for Governor clashed sharply in an informal debate at The New York Times in which each contender ridiculed the other's positions on the major issues of the campaign, one of only two races in the country this year.

title: A Stern Egyptian Disciplinarian vs. Israel's Bulldog General
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21A popular story from the sixday war of 1967 has as its hero an Egyptian commando leader who managed to bring his men out of the Sinai peninsula after the ceasefire, avoiding capture by the Israelis.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Byrne and Sandman Clash Sharply on the Major Issues
description: New Jersey's two major candidates for Governor clashed sharply in an informal debate at The New York Times in which each contender ridiculed the other's positions on the major issues of the campaign.

title: Dolphins Top Bills, 276, Hold Simpson to 55 Yards
description: The championship pretensions of the Buffalo Bills and the recordbreaking aspirations of their star running back, O. J. Simpson, were both rudely jolted yesterday by the tenacious defenders of the Miami Dolphins.

title: A's Top Mets, 52; Win Series Again
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21 Winter finally arrived for the New York Mets today when they lost the seventh and final game of the 70th World Series to the Oakland A's, 52.

title: Mizell, North Carolina Republican, Acts to Block Huge River Power Project
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Representative Wilmer D. Mizell, who had a renowned last ball when he pitched for the St. Louis Cardinals, the Pittsburgh Pirates and the New York Mets, has just thrown a curve ball at Donald C. Cook, president of the American Electric Power Company of New York and one of its principal subsidiaries, the Appalachian Power Company of Roanoke, Va.

title: NAVAJO HEARINGS WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: GALLUP, N. M., Oct. 21After some internal bickering, chiefs on the Navajo. Indian Reservation have agreed to allow the United States Commission on Civil Rights to hold three, days of public hearings on Navajo problems, focusing on educational systems.

title: Howard Hughes Memo Disclosed In Controversy Over Gift to Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 In the spring of 1968, when Howard R. Hughes was being pressed by the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice and the Atomic Energy Commission's nuclear weapons testing program, he told his chief assistant to begin working toward the election of Richard M. Nixon as President.

title: The Big Play
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21From the President's point of view, the timing was perfect:

title: Brennan Backs President In His Dismissal of Cox
description: Peter J. Brennan, the Secretary of Labor, yesterday said that he would have to support the President in his dismissal of the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, because it's the President's prerogative to fire those who defy him, the Associated Press reported.

title: 4 More Arab Governments Bar Oil Supplies for U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21Four Persian Gulf oil producers  Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain and Dubai  today announced a total embargo of oil to the United States.

title: Gerela's 4 Field Goals Lead to Jets' 2614 Loss
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21If the Jets' ability had matched their spirit and determination today, they could've escaped from the longest road trip in National Football League history with an even split in six games.

title: Blades Top Nordiques Here, 43
description: After the New York Golden Blades credited them selves with a 43 victory over the Quebec Nordiques yesterday in a World Hockey Association game at Madison Square Garden, they still needed someone to deposit a lot of money to their credit.

title: Emotional Saga of MVP Jackson
description: Emotionit has been Reggie Jackson's trademark from the time he broke into baseball, throwing a bat after he struck out, fighting with a pitcher who threw too close. It was no different yesterday, just minutes after the Oakland A's won the World Series and he was named the tournament's most valuable player.

title: Protein Found in Elderly Studied for Link to Aging
description: A mysterious natural sub stance, known for more than a century, has been discovered with such startling frequency in elderly people recently that scientists studying it now hope it will unlock some secrets of the aging process.

title: Pop Music: Jim Dandy of Black Oak Arkansas
description: Black Oak Arkansas, previously relentless and somewhat unsubtle in attack and volume it still hovers around the threshold of pain regarding the noise it makesappears to be making more of a show with its good old, Southerntinged rock'n'roll.

title: Report in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 21The Israeli Army has widened its bridgehead west of the Suez Canal and now controls about 24 milesor roughly onequarterof the western bank, an Israeli spokesman said here tonight.

title: Gold Star Mothers: Rather Than Dwell on the Loss They Help the Living
description: WASHINGTON  We are not a morbid group at all, Mrs. Elva Newman said at the house that doubles as her home and as the national headquarters of the American Gold Star Mothers, Inc., a national association of women whose sons died in the United States armed forces in the wars of the last 56 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Orr Gets 2 As. Bruins Win, 82
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Boston Bruins struck for three goals within three minutes late in the first period, including Phil Esposito's eighth of the season, and went on to an 82 National Hockey League victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Candidates' Day
description: Controller Abraham D Beame, the only one of the four major mayoral candidates who did not turn up for breakfast forum yesterday, was aeeused of lacking independence.

title: 42 ABANDON SHIP AFIRE IN ATLANTIC
description: Thirtyfive crew members of an abandoned Greek freighter burning in the Atlantic 700 miles east of New York were rescued early today by three vessels, that had sped to the scene. Seven crewmen remained missing as the search continued.

title: LABOR STILL SPLIT WITH DEMOCRATS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 21 Despite the Democrats' political disaster of 1972, in which a rift between the A.F.L.C.I.O. and the party contributed to an overwhelming defeat in the Presidential election, organized labor is still unable to end its conflict with the Democrats and has not yet closed its own ranks.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Remarks by acid Soviet Delegates
description: Following are texts of remarks at the United Nations Security Council last night by John A. Seali, the United States representative, and Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet representative:

title: Mediator to Meet Thursday With Publishers and Union
description: A state mediator will meet Thursday with representatives of the New York Publishers Association and Paper Handlers Union 1. The union, which has been working without a contract since March 30, requested the meeting. The association represents The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times.

title: Report in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 21The Israeli Army has widened its bridgehead west of the Suez Canal and now controls about 24 milesor roughly onequarterof the western bank, an Israeli spokesman said here tonight.

title: Israeli Thrust Tests Egypt's Strategy
description: The continued expansion of the Israeli bridgehead west of the Suez Canal and the containment of the powerful Egyptian farces in the Sinai peninsula could present the Egyptian command with its most difficult decision of the war, according to United States land British military sources.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: U.N.Aided School in Chile Closes Classes in Protest
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21The LatinAmerican School for Social Sciences, which the United Nations helped found here 16 years ago, has suspended its activities and sent home foreign students because it says it fears for their safety under the military authorities.

title: The End Begins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21During his few minutes as Acting Attorney General, William Ruckelshaus had a telephone call from the White House chief of staff, Gen. Alexander Haig. The General conveyed. President Nixon's order to fire Archibald Cox as special Watergate prosecutor. Mr. Ruckelshaus, like Elliot Richardson, refused. Then General Haig said:

title: Casals Rallies Briefly
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Pablo Casals regained consciousness today and moved his arms as if trying to say something, but his doctors did not expect the 96yearold cellist to overcome heart, lung, kidney, and circulatory complications that have followed the heart attack he suffered last month.

title: Confidence in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21An Egyptian military spokesman today gave a grim, if still confident, apraisal of the Israeli bridgehead on the west side of the Suez Canal.

title: Well Preserved Villa of Roman Period Is Unearthed 20 Miles South of Naples
description: TORRE ANNUNZIATA, ItalyParts an ancient city that archeologists say might be as significant to the history of civilization as Pompeii and Herculaneum have been discovered about 20 miles south of Naples. Although fulltime excavations have only recently got underway, the archeologists have unearthed an almost perfectly preserved major villa dating from the Roman periodand traces of other villas and habitations.

title: Major Bills in Congress
description: Oct. 22, 1973. ENACTED

title: Sakharov Says Arabs Menaced Him and Wife at Moscow Home
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21  Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet nuclear physicist, reported tonight that two Arabs who said they were from the Black September terrorist group threatened is life if he were ever to issue another statement sympathizing with Israel.

title: CHALLENGE POSED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Congressidnal leaders of both parties said today that Congress would have to begin looking immediately at the question of impeaching President Nixon.

title: WILLIAM H. COOK

title: Books of The Times
description: In crime, as in so many other things, this country has lost much of its style. We used to have ingenious thieves, for example, men who used their wits to evade laws drawn up by people who had an antique passion for order. Such Raffles types were often sociologists of a sort: they studied their fellow man and preyed on his vanity. They took their job seriously, prepared for them like Ph.D. candidates. There was a moral in their imorality: some worked harder to defy our work ethic than those who lived by it. In everything but their basic premise, they might be models of conventionality.

title: Exit Mays: Sitting, With No Regrets
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21 Willie Mays took off his baseball uniform for the last time as a player. It was folded neatly inside his New York Mets' equipment bag alongside his locker after today's completion of the World Series.

title: Meany Summons Council To Meet on Nixon's Acts
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 21 (UPI) George Meany, president of the AFLCIO, scheduled an emergency session of his executive council tomorrow to consider the shocking actions of President Nixon in dismantling the special Watergate prosecution and forcing the two top Justice Department officials out of office.

title: Vote Yes for Transit
description: Finding fault with the proposed transportation bond issue is easier than coming up with a realistic alternative, not only for freezing this city's 35 cent fare but for giving New York State the promise of a rational twentiethcentury transit system. In the absence of any such alternative that can be counted on for the near future, we support the bond issue, convinced that desperately needed action now must be preferred to an indeterminate wait for some possibly better plan.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 21 (UPI) Cambodian Government troops and Communist forces battled today near Sala Lekpram where Route 5 the rice toad to Cambodia's second largest city of Battambang, has, been blocked for days, according to reports from the field. There was scattered fighting elsewhere.

description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 21 (AP) Vijay Amritraj of India, the topseeded player defeated Mal Anderson of Australia, 64, 57, 79, 63, 119, today and won the Indian Grand Prix international tennis tournament before crowd of 4,500.

description: LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP)A wall of a balcony for spectators collapsed at Heathrow Airport during the arrival of the Osmond Brothers, an American pop group, today. At least 20 young girls were injured, none critically.

title: OneMan Law ...
description: The desperation of President Nixon's moves this weekend to block the Watergate investigation makes it plain that neither law nor orderly governmental process now stand as obstacles to the exercise of his will.

title: Rangers Lose to Montreal
description: Yvan Cournoyer and a supporting cast of Montreal Canadiens beat the New York Rangers, 32, last night while Wayne Thomas confounded the Cassandras by showing he may yet fill the shoes of the great Ken Dryden in goal.

title: SelectaTree Time
description: Psychology buffs should know about an interesting exercise going on in Sullivan County: people who can't wait for Christmas are being given a Yuletide teaser and then forced to delay gratification.

title: Wait Till Next Year
description: With all else tottering, the world looked to the Mets for reassurance in the inevitable ultimate triumph of the eternal veritiesfaith, guts and good pitching. Riddled with injuries that persisted right into the World Series, the miracle men of Shea Stadium had fought their way from the bottom of the league a month before the regular season ended to a perch one game away from a world championship. Alas for the Ya Gotta Believe spirit, that last victory eluded them in Oakland yesterday. But it is not too early to paint up the signs for 1974. Truth and justice cannot be denied forever, Watergate to the contrary notwithstanding. What's more, the year's rest has to bring Tom Seaver's arm back up to its incomparable best.

title: Bond Buyer Picks Directors
description: The Bond Buyer has elected Frank J. White and Albert L. Kraus as directors, it was announced over the weekend. Mr. White, is executive vice president of the concern, and Mr. Kraus is editor of The Money Manager and is in editorial charge of its other publications and services.

title: Rockefeller Calls on Congress To Rush $2Billion Aid to Israel
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday urged Congress to move quickly in appropriating the $2.2billion requested by Presidnt Nixon to finance military aid to Israel.

title: City Plans to Build Malls In 1 5 Neighborhood Areas
description: The city is planning to construct pedestrian malls or make other major street renovations in 15 neighborhood retail shopping areas.

title: Carol Halpern Bride Of Richard P. Glass
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., Oct. 21 Miss Carol Sue Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Halpern, was married here this afternoon to Richard Paul Glass, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter M. Glass of Great Neck, L. I. Rabbi Daniel Jazer performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: The Screen: Summer Wishes' Stars Joanne Woodward
description: From time to time, there's a movie that makes you feel like a moderate heel. Although you respect the talents and the themes, it's not possible to respond emotionally, even though you might wish to. And that's the hitch with "Summer Wishes, Winter Dreams," which opened last night at the Plaza Theater.Joanne Woodward "plays a restive, well-tailored woman who has been married for 24 years to a devoted oculist (Martin Balsam). She has almost nothing to do but baby-sit for her daughter, lunch with her mother (Sylvia Sidney, bristling with fierce impatience: welcome back), redecorate her West End Avenue apartment, shop and fight with all her relatives.The mother's sudden death hastens a probably inevitable crisis. All of Miss Woodward's regrets about the past and her fantasies about the future erupt: She mourns what she has missed, dreads dying, wrestles with earlier experiences that can't be altered or recaptured, agonizes over the things that she may never do before she dies.This is a portrait of someone confronted by her own mortality, while watching the possibilities ahead diminish. Surely the subject is as valid as breathing. However, in the tradition of "Rachel, Rachel" and "Gamma Rays," Miss Woodward has been directed to win the sweepstakes. Misery floods the screen. Yet, it's very hard to believe that the kind of vigorous, sinewy character she evokes could feel so perpetually defeated.Here, she plays much of her part at an unbroken level of irritation, slamming back at those around her with the gumption that's missing in our mayoral candidates, It's the same vitality that we saw in "The Three Faces of Eve," and we recall the range of feelings that has streamed through a number of her pictures. But since she acts as if she had been drinking Drano, the moments of vulnerability just aren't convincing.Mr. Balsam, as the kindly, reassuring husband, is burdened with lines like, "Do you know that you are more beautiful than the day I met you?" and "You can't do better than your best." Again, we think wistfully of his brilliance in many other roles.But the alternate folksiness and banality of the script means that "Summer Wishes" is a forlorn waste of two fine character actors.

title: Williams Announces Resignation as Manager of A's
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21 Dick Williams went through with his resignation as manager of the Oakland A's today, moments after they had won the World Series for the second straight year, insisting that personal factors prompted his decision many weeks ago.

title: MISS GIAT IS SUPERB IN PROKOFIEV PIECE
description: Jacqueline Giat, who, has been a flutist with several orchestras including the American Symphony and is now on the New York University faculty, can play a blue streak. But her program at Carnegie Recital Hall an Sunday night was a model of honest musicianship as well as a technical display.

title: 2 Bronx Youths Accused Of FireBombing Radio Car
description: Two youths were taken into custody yesterday shortly after two Molotov cocktails were thrown from a roof at an unoccupied police radio motor patrol car in front of 882 Beck Street in the southeast Bronx. No injuries or damage were reported.

title: Social Democrats Hold Meeting in West Berlin
description: BERLIN, Oct. 22 (AP) Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany led his party's parliamentary delegation into the Reichstag building here today. It was the first time in more than three years that a meeting was held by the Social Democrats in West Berlin. The political demonstration was to emphasize that such gatherings were normal and within the fourpower agreement on Berlin concluded in 1971.

title: WILLIAM G. HEEP JR.
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 22  William G. Heep Jr., vice president and managing director of Lord & Taylor's Westchester store, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here.

description: The East River between the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges was closed to shipping traffic for four and a half hours yesterday to permit the maiden voyage of the 226,200ton tanker Brooklyn.

title: BYRNE PLAN AIMS AT CURBING GRAFT
description: UNION, Oct. 22Brendan T. Byrne, who has stressed integrity in government and his own experience in law enforcement in his campaign for election as New Jersey's Governor, called today for stronger criminal penalties for public officials convicted of bribery and extortion.

title: Canals Dies in Puerto Rico at 96
description: RIO PIEDRAS, P.R., Oct. 22 Pablo Casals, the celebrated cellist and conductor, died today at Auxilio Mutuo Hospital of complications from a heart attack suffered three weeks ago. He was 96 years old and lived in nearby Santurce with his wife, Marta.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 22Democratic and Republican political activity on the campuses is at a virtual standstill.

description: The General Telephone & Electronics Corporation reported yesterday records in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales, net income and share earnings for both, the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

description: MONSON, Mass., Oct. 22 (AP)Children found a human skull at a construction site here yesterday, the police said. It was sent to the State Police Laboratory in Boston for analysis.

title: CEASEFIRE PLAN IS PRAISED HERE
description: Jewish and some Arab groups here welcomed the United Nations call for a ceasefire in the Middle East yesterday but emphasized that they had not, altered their previous positions.

title: Stock Prices Drop on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped sharply yesterday in lackadaisical trading. The drop in activity was attributed to the observance of Veterans Day.

title: Argentine Offices Bombed
description: MENDOZA, Argentina, Oct. 22 (AP)The offices of the Governor of Mendoza state were almost destroyed today by a bomb. An office boy, was wounded. The Governor, Alberto Martinez Baca, had been criticized by rightists in the Peronist party for unwillingness to get rid of leftists.

title: Philharmonic Agrees to Accept Arbitration but the Union Balks
description: The New York Philharmonic's management announced yesterday that it had agreed to accept the New York State Mediation Board's proposal of binding arbitration in the fourweek strike by the orchestra's musicians. Spokesmen for the players, however, immediately denounced the plan and said the musicians had not been consulted, and would not agree to it.

title: Industry Waning as the Focus for Aid
description: PARIS, Oct. 22The rich countries are changing the strategy of development aid, giving a higher priority to rural development and food production while deemphasizing industrial growth.

title: Mayor Says Those in the Governor Race Will Be Chasing Him
description: By the time I get through, the candidates will be chasing me. This was the comment of an ebullient Mayor Lindsay the other day to some of his closest advisers when he burst into City Hall after a wellstaged celebration of the official opening of the $58million Police Headquarters. The candidates he may have been talking about were those seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor next year.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. WANTS NIXON TO RESIGN
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 22 Standing and cheering, delegates to the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention here voted today, to ask President Nixon to resign and to demand his impeachment if he did not.

J., and Bill Logan of Lakewood, N.N.T., and Flight C, Gilbert Munz and Martin Sternberg, both of New York City.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: One man was killed and 13 others were injured, three seriously, when a jell used in making vitamins exploded yesterday at a Newark chemical plant, the police said.

description: An Uruguyan national, described as the top supplier of cocaine in the United States, was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan and held in $500,000 bail.

title: Boy Dies Getting High
description: SAUGUS, Calif., Oct. 22 (UPI)A 14yearold boy died yesterday shortly after he tried to get high by hyperventilating, sheriffs deputies said. The boy Kelly Canlalosi, was found lying unconscious on the floor of his home by friend whom he had telephoned. He was dead on arrival at Hillside Hospital. Hyperventilation is often used by skin divers and is the practice of taking deep breaths, and then exhaling slowly.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The collapse of Spiro T. Agnew's career was a negotiated decline and fall.

title: Woman Shot by Hitchhiker

The woman, Suzan C. Metzler, was discovered early today after she crawled out of the ditch. She underwent surgery late today for a gunshot wound to the abdomen.

title: How Agnew Bartered His Office To Keep From Going to Prison
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The collapse of Spiro T. Agnew's career was a negotiated decline and fall.

title: A Musician Who Looked Beyond the Printed Note
description: Pablo Casals represented a type of musicianship that is virtually extinct todaya musicianship that had its roots in the romantic traditions of the 19th century. As such he was a romantic himself, and young musicians today tended to look fondly upon him as a living anachronism. All, especially string players, had nothing but respect for Casals's powers as an instrumentalist. But as an interpreter his ideas ran counter to many of today's cherished notions. Today's musicians tend to be literalists. The printed note is the ultimate guide. Casals, however, along with other great musicians of his generation, tried to look beyond the printed note. The important thing in music, he kept telling his pupils, is, what is not in the notes. The important thing is the recreation of an emotion, mood, an experience.

title: CeaseFire Lines Reflect Some Territory Exchange
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 22An Israeli general said tonight that his nation had won a very big victory in the Middle East war but it could have been bigger.

On the network level, sports involves, big money and therefore demand and receive unusual care and attention.

description: A thin plurality of 44 per cent of Americans, questioned since Saturday night in a national poll say that they favor impeaching President Nixon, N.B.C. News said last night.

description: Lawrence Iason, who retired recently as chairman of the board of N. Erlanger, Blumgart & Co., Inc., a textile concern, died yesterday at his home, 44 East 67th Street. His age was 80.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Acting Attorney General Robert H Bork today formally placed Henry E. Petersen once again in charge of investigating the Watergate scandal.

title: Tokyo Firm Owns Rousseau Sold Secretly by the Met
description: The modern masterpiece Monkeys in the Jungle by Henri Rousseau, which the Metropolitan Museum sold secretly early last year, was purchased by Mitsui and Company, a 300yearold Tokyo trading firm, which obtained it for about $1.7million.

title: 11Car Night Derailment Damages Jersey Home
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 22 Eleven cars of a 52car eastbound ErieLackawanna freight train were derailed here at 4:25 oclock this morning. The damage was estimated in the hundreds of thousands of dollars and rail traffic was tied up for the better part of the day.

title: Israelis West of Canal Find BurnedOut Zone
description: WITH THE ISRAELI FORCES IN EGYPT, Oct. 22An Israeli soldier poked his head out of an Egyptian bunker on the western bank of the Suez Canal today and grinned. Want some ice cream? he asked, offering his visitor a paper cup and spoon.

title: EuropeanU.S. Dissension on Oil
description: PARIS, Oct. 22In the face of cutbacks in oil production by eight Arab states, controls over petroleum exports are proliferating in Western Europe in a situation that is producing new Atlantic dissension.

title: Citizen's Rights Cases Put Crushing Load on U.S. Appeals Courts
description: One defendant sits in Federal court bound and gagged. Anbarnyard epithet. A schoolboy appears in court to challenge the principal who ordered him not to wear an earring in school. A young woman goes to Court to fight for the right to compete in a high school beauty contest for virgins onlyshe is an unwed mother.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 22 (Reuters)The United States dollar slipped slightly in value here today, reflecting anxieties about the political situation in Washington. But hopes for a Middle East ceasefire limited its decline and served as a powerful counterbalance to the pessimism aroused by the latest Watergate developments.

title: School Building Destroyed; Boston Classes Canceled
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP)The Dorchester High School Annex was a total loss after a fouralarm fire yesterday, according to a School Department spokesman.

title: SWISSAIR EXECUTIVE SEIZED IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21 (AP) Kurt Schmid, LatinAmerican general manager of the Swissair airline, was kidnapped today by unidentified armed men who intercepted his car, a company official reported.

title: Auto Dealers Expect Sales to Drop for the 1974 Models
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22The 1974 model United States cars are still new to the showroom, but in Montana, where winter comes early, a Chevrolet dealer said: There are not too many [people] coming out to drink your coffee and eat your doughnuts, But the people who are looking are buying, They are taking dead aim on something.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Where Are the Volunteers?, a recent column by C. L. Sulzberger, culls an interesting conclusion from questionable reasoning. Despite the fact that the policy of voluntary enlistment in the military is too new to warrant drawing conclusions as to its effectiveness, the gap between anticipated and actual enlistments should not be surprising to anyone. Unless military service is perceived as a desirable learning experience, simply increasing the inducements to participate in what many, consider a meaningless activity is unlikely to increase voluntarisin. Furthermore, his concern that lower numbers of servicemen may be insufficient to maintain peace or the political status quo ignores the need for and efficacy of manpower under conditions of rapid technologicak developments in military weapons systems.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:
MISS KIND REOPENS VESPER BAH SERIES
description: For the last five years, the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity has presented a series of Bach cantatas as part of its regular Sunday vesper service, closely duplicating the way Bach himself performed the cantatas, week by week, at Leipzig's St. Thomas Church.

title: Insurance Group Supports Federal NoFault Rules
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 (UPI)The American Insurance Association today endorsed Federal guidelines for nationwide 11 fault auto insurance as an alternative to slow and haphazard movement by the states individually.

title: Financially Beset Hospital on S.I. Is Down to Its Last 50 Patients
description: Richmond Memorial Hospital, the only nonprofit voluntary hospital serving Staten Island's south shore, was down to 50 remaining patients yesterday as administrators awaited a court ruling today to determine whether the hospital would close completely.

title: Cuban Doctors Help Arabs
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22 (AP)Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba said tonight that his Government had sent physicians and medical technicians to the Middle East to give their collaboration to the brother Arabian peoples. Mr. Castro, in a Havana broadcast monitored here, said the medical personnel had been sent to the Middle East in recent days but did not specify how many people were sent and whether they were working in civilian hospitals or with tary units.

title: Jordan Accepts the Truce Without Disbanding Force
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 22The Government announced tonight that it had accepted the United Nations Security Council resolution calling for Middle East ceasefire. But it stipulated that the Jordanian Army contingent that has been fighting on the SyrianIsraeli front was under the orders of the Syrian authorities and that they had not yet indicated their response.

title: Navajo Leader Assails Federal Unit
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Oct. 22  Thee chairman of the largest Indian tribe in the United States charged today that the biggest barrier to economic development and selfsufficiency for Indians was Federal red tape and bureaucratic fumbling within the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: Advertising: Index to Affection
description: Women who read Cosmopolitan are more affectionate then men who read Playboy's Oui but more affectionate still are the men who read Cosmo. At least that's the way they see themselves and that's what they communicated to the interviewers from Target Group Index.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Press For Basic Mideast Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Administration officials said today that in the wake of the Middle East ceasefire resolution, they expected Washington and Moscow to take the lead in coming weeks in trying to prod the warring countries into negotiating a political settlement of the longstanding IsraeliArab problem.

title: CEASEFIRE'S LINK TO OIL UNCERTAIN
description: Government and industry officials are uncertain as to whether the Arabs also intend to sheath their oil weapon if a ceasefire is achieved in Syria and the Sinai.

title: Cambodia Troops Cross Mekong To Wrest Village From Rebels
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 22 (AP)Government marines attacking from assault boats have reoccupied a village across the Mekong River from Kompong Chain, the military command said today.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Two gifts of the sea that we had always considered trash came to our table recently as savory surprises.

title: Griffin to Propose Halting Election of Vice Presidents
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan, the assistant minority leader, proposed today a constitutional amendment to abandon permanently the election of Vice Presidents and give Congress and the President joint power to select them.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Jakarta, Indonesia  Muhammad Ali, 217 pounds, Cherry Hill, N.J., outpointed Audi Lubbers, 196, Netherlands, 12 rounds.

title: New Interest Stirred in Conditions of Blacks in South African Gold Mines
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaBlack workers newly recruited for South Africa's rich gold mines start out in a steamfilled room where the temperature hovers at around 90 degrees.

title: There can be no menace more lethal to our liberties and fatal to our influence than this flouting of laws . . .
description: CHICAGOAs the president of the American Bar Association, I urge in the strongest terns that appropriate action be taken promptly by the courts, and if necessary by Congress, to repel the attacks which are presently being made on the justice system and the rule of law as we have known it in this country.

title: Suit Asks End of Okla. Probation
description: Some football coaches and players may feel Oklahoma inflicts cruel and unusual punishment when the Sooners pile up those 50 and 60 point victories. Now the Big Eight Conference and the National Collegiate Athletic Association are being sued for maintaining a policy that inflicts cruel and unusual punishment on Oklahoma's football team. Paul (Buddy) Burriss, a former Oklahoma football player, and Jack M. Higley of Oklahoma have filed a class action suit in Oklahoma City attempting to set aside the twoyear probation penalty placed upon the Sooners' football program by the Big Eight and the N.C.A.A. Oklahoma was charged with 14 rules violations, including the accept

title: Higher Prices Seen for Apparel
description: The outlook for men's sports. wear next spring is highe?? prices, shortages of key items and more informal styling.

title: U.S. Aide Denies Impropriety In Rebozo Insurance Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 22 (AP) The Chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board denied today that there was any impropriety in the approval of federal insurance for a savings and loan association with close ties to Charles G. Rebozo, a close friend of President Nixon.

title: Fuel Price Rise Feared
description: The Alaska pipeline bill has been amended by a HouseSenate conference committee in a way that, according to Administration officials, will lead to big increases in prices of heating oil and gasoline. Details on Page 7.

title: EXAIDE DENOUNCES GREECE'S PRESIDENT
description: ATHENS, Oct. 22One of the former Greek military leaders has turned against President George Papadopoulos, accusing him of trying to consolidate his dictatorship under a parliamentary cloak.

title: City Fights Licensing of Career Center, Charging Evasive Aim
description: The operators of a vocational school that had its license revoked last month for fraudulent advertising are trying to reopen the same kind of operation under a new name, according the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Soviet and Japan Begin Fisheries Talks
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 22Highlevel Soviet and Japanese officials began negotiations here today on longterm rights for Japanese fishermen off four disputed islands occupied by the Soviet Union but claimed by Japan.

title: Streetcar Run Extended.
description: The Broadway run of A Streetcar Named Desire, which had been scheduled to close last Saturday, has been continued at the St. James Theater becaues of an increase in business.

title: People in Sports: Archibald Out
description: Nate [Tiny] Archibald, who led the National Basketball Association in scoring and assists last season, is expetted to miss at least a week of action because of an injury to his right Achilles tendon. The 6foot guard fcir the Kansas CityOmaha Kings suffered the injury on Oct. 10 against the Chicago Bulls and was unable to play on Saturday night against the Golden State Warriors.

title: Dr. Robert F. Loeb Dead at 78; Metabolic Expert, Noted Teacher,
description: Dr. Robert F. Loeb, Bard Professor of Medicine Emeritus and former chairman of the department of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, who was considered one of the nation's leading medical teachers, died Sunday at his home, 950 Park Avenue. He was 78 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON HOUSE INQUIRY INTO NIXON'S ACTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives tentatively agreed today to have the House Judiciary Committee begin an inquiry into whether President Nixon has committed any offenses that could lead to impeachment.

title: GROUP IN DETROIT TO RUN A TROLLEY
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (UPI)The clanging bells and rhythmic clicking of trolley wheels so familiar in American cities in the early part of the century will be heard once again in Detroit next summer.

title: A Transsexual and Her Family: An Attempt at Life as Usual
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J.  It was a day much like any other day in the life of Mrs. Paula Grossman: A hormone shot at the doctor's. A lunch of three hot dogs at Opdyke's Charcoal Grill, her favorite roadside restaurant. A trip to a country market to buy 15 dozen eggs wholesale.

title: The Opera: Les Troyens at the Met at Last
description: That rarest of masterpieces, the complete Les Troyens by Hector Berlioz, came to the Metropolitan Opera last night in its first staged production in this city. It was high time. One of the most unusual operas. ever composed, Les Troyens has been making the rounds of Europe and other American cities, but until two years ago the Metropolitan Opera acted as if it never existed.

title: Prices on Big Board Slip As Trading Pace Slows
description: Investors' concern over the weekend's dramatic political events sent the stock market lower yesterday in slower trading.

title: Steinbrenner: Yanks Interested in Williams
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 (UPI) George Steinbrenner, chief owner and president of the New York Yankees, said his team was interested in hiring Dick Williams, but that the former Oakland manager had not been approached about the job.

title: A.F.LC.I.O. WANTS NIXON TO RESIGN
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 22 Standing and cheering, delegates to the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention here voted today to ask President Nixon to resign and to demand his impeachment if he did not.

title: State Opposes U.S. Curtailment Of Penn Central Freight Runs
description: ALBANY, Oct. 21Official of the State Department o?? Transportation said today tha?? they would fight to preserve freight services on 436 miles o?? Penn Central branch line track in the state that the railroad said did not meet the track safety standards of the Federal Railroad Administration.

title: Banks in Japan Negotiating on a Big Part of Loan to Abu Dhabi
description: TOKYO, Oct. 22A major bank here reported today that a Japanese banking consortium was negotiating a loan of $30million to $50million to the Government of Abu Dhabi, one of the Persian Gulf sheikdoms that have cut off oil shipments to the United States.

title: Precarious Foundation for Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22Diplomats here and in scattered capitals around the world worked today to construct the road to peace in the Middle East from a precarious point of departure: a costly war and a hastily arranged and fragile ceasefire.

title: Jersey Woman, 20, Apparent Victim Of Strangulation
description: STRATFORD, N.J., Oct. 22A slight, 20yearold secretaryreceptionist was found dead today, apparently strangled, in the bedroom of her apartment in this quiet residential borough 12 miles south of Camden.

title: Wood Field and Stream: Visit to Office
description: Among a wandering columnist's delights are the infrequent visits he makes to his office, for in so doing he is available for telephone calls that might not otherwise reach him, and he can also get a head start on reading letters that, in time wasted during forwarding, might lose their tang.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Phone Is Lifeline to Homebound Aged
description: Isabel Zubinic, an 83yearold widow, waits every morning for a phone call to break the silence in her oneroom apartment. She seldom speaks to anyone in person for she lives alone in a small room up five long flights of stairs.

title: 1MILLION STUDY SET BY FORD FOUNDATION
description: The Ford Foundation yesterday announced the appropriation of $1million to finance research into the growing role of economics in international relations.

title: Italians Seize Eight on Ship In Smuggling of Cigarettes
description: ANCONA, Italy, Oct. 22 (Reuters)The Italian Coast Guard said today that it had arrested eight suspected cigarette smugglers after an 11hour battle at sea during which machine guns were fired and an officer was seriously injured by an ax blow.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Paul Dudley White, the Boston heart specialist who treated the late President Eisenhower several years ago, is this year's winner of the American Heart Association's James B. Herrick Award for unprecedented achievements in the practice and advance of clinical cardiology here and around the world.

title: Futures Trading Soared By 51% in Nine Months
description: Commodity futures trading, setting new records, jumped 51 per cent in the first nine months of 1973. From Jan. 1 through Sept. 30, 19.4 million contracts were traded, compared with 12.8 million in the same nine months of 1972, according to the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc.

title: PARTIES' CHAIRMEN SPLIT ON LEGALITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The chairmen of the Democratic and Republican National Committees disagreed today over the legality of President Nixon's compromise in the White House tapes case and the removal of Archibald Cox as Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Nearly 20 Years After Landmark Court Case, New Suit Charges Topeka Schools Still Discriminate Racially
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 20Nineteen years after the United States Supreme Court held in a historic and farreaching Topeka case that school segregation was unconstitutional, a new suit has been filed here that alleges the city is still systematically discriminating against black students.

title: Mr. Nixon Takes a Whitewash
description: WASHINGTONRichard Nixon has ordered his own whitewash. He has put an end to an investigation of his Administration's activities that he had promised would be independent, unhindered and complete, and he has reasserted his political direction of the Department of Justice.

title: HEYWOOD PLAY MS. TO BE AUCTIONED
description: LONDON, Oct. 21 The manuscript, hidden since 1634, of an unknown play by the 17thcentury dramatist Thomas Heywood will be auctioned by Sotheby's on Nov. 20.

title: MRS. EDWARD M. HEALY
description: Mrs. Helen Hicks Healy, who had helped her husband, Edward M. Healy, run Camp Androscoggin, Wayne, Me., where, many New York boys went, died Sunday at her home in Wayne. Her age was 73.

title: Marals Wondering About Giant Plight
description: While Coach Alex Webster was busy trying to find out what was wrong with the Giants, Wellington Mara said yesterday that Webster was not to blame for the team's fourgame losing streak.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHTS GAMES

title: Allende's MiddleClass Foes Winning Power Under Chile's Junta
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22Middleclais organizations representing truckers, shopkeepers, doctors and others who played a major role in the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens are emerging as a significant force in the political vacuum in Chile today.

title: The Dance: No Joke
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22So far as dance is concerned Philadelphia jokes should cease forthwith. Why only yesterday I spent a week in Philadelphlano, seriouslyand saw two excellent dance performances: The Pennsylvania Ballet at the start of its 10thanniversary season at the Academy of Music, and Paul Taylor ending up his season at the Walnut Street Theater, which has consisted entirely of the world premiere of Mr. Taylor's new fullevening piece, American Genesis.

title: Brief Stopover in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP)Secretary of State Kissinger stopped at London's Heathrow Airport tonight for a meeting of slightly less than an hour with Britain's Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL BEGIN TRUCE AT U.N. CALL; SYRIA CONSIDERS TERMS BUT KEEPS FIGHTING
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 22A ceasefire in the fourth Middle East war since the creation of Israel went into effect today on the Egyptian front, about 12 hours after the United Nations Security Council called for an end to the hostilities.

title: City Council Choices
description: As a result of the national and international crises and an unusually dull mayoral campaign in New York City, the election of members of the City Council is being almost wholly ignored this year. Such lack of interest would be unfortunate in any year since the Council has an important governmental role to play as the local legislative and investigative body. Inattention to the councilmanic races is especially unfortunate this year because the Council has been expanded from 37 to 43 members in an effort to achieve better representation for all the city's racial and ethnic groups.

title: Syria Reports Clashes on the Golan Heights After IsraeliEgyptian Truce Begins
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Tuesday, Oct. 23  Syria reported last night that her troops were fighting Israeli forces on the Golan heights well after the ceasefire agreed upon by Israel and Egypt went into effect on the Sinai front.

title: A's Future Remains Bright Under Any Manager
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 22Having become the first team to win two straight World Series in more than a decade, what now for the Oakland A's?

title: JUDGE ALLYN BROWN OF CONNECTICUT, 89
description: NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 22Judge Allyn L. Brown, former chief justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, died today in Norwich. He was 89 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 22Halloween is approaching, but George Sadovsky, the 61yearold harness horse owner and driver, isn't interested. Up to last year, however, Halloween to Sadovsky meant what harvest time means to an Iowa wheat farmer.

title: Ram Game Blacked Out By New Law
description: Pro football's only unbeaten teams, the Los Angeles Rams and Minnesota Vikings, play at Bloomington, Minn., on Sunday and don't look for the game on your local television set. You are stuck with the. Giants and Jets, and both have lost four of six games. The Jets play Denver at Shea Stadium and on Channel 4 while the Giants meet the Cardinals in St. Louis one hour later on Channel 2. The National Football League campaign, which reaches its halfway mark this weekend, is thin on both division races and key games this season, and its television scheduling has not broken in favor of the nation's largest market, New York.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Patrick A. Robinson, an 18yearold A.W.O.L. Marine, armed with a shotgun, held his teenage girlfriend and three other persons hostage in a mobile home trailer park in Dover Township, N.J., in a nightlong siege during which he wounded three policemen and demanded a plane to fly him to Egypt.

title: IRAQ, GUERRILLAS REJECT THE TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 22Both Iraq and the Palestinian resistance movement today rejected the ceasefire called for by the United Nations Security Council and accepted by Israel and Egypt.

title: CAMPORA WELCOMED IN DEBUT IN IN MANON
description: Giuseppe Campora, the Italian tenor, has been singing in and around New York now and then for nearly 20 years. But it was not until Sunday night that he made his unscheduled debut with the New York City Opera, taking over the part of Des Grieux from an indisposed Jose Carreras in the season's first Manon.

title: Mets Return With Pride; Get Many Trade Offers
