description: Neither victory parades nor crocodile tears greeted the New York Mets early yesterday when they returned home from their long journey to the National League pennant and their final setback in the seventh game of the World Series.

title: A Somewhat Fond Look Back
description: The Oakland A's got high on champagne, the traditional method World Series winners have long used touch off clubhouse celebrations. The losing New York Mets also got high but without any feelings of exhilaration. It was done for them by the chartered airliner that returned them to New York early yesterday morning. the baggage compartment were cases of the bubble water that had been brought along in the hope of a Met victory. They remained unopened. So the Mets never had even a sip of champagne and even the beer tasted flat. It had been a strange World Series, marked by Sports bizarre happenings and occasional playmaking that would have shamed a bushleaguer. of The sterling athletes were blinded by a The Times glaring sun for the first two days in Oakland and then they were tossed heartlessly into the deepfreeze locker at Shea Stadium for the abomination of night baseball for the next three games. Finally they lucked their way through morning showers for the last two days in that garden paradise of the San Francisco Bay area, Oakland, for ideal Indian Summer weather in the homestretch.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON HOUSE INQUIRY INTO NIXON'S ACTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives tentatively agreed today to have the House Judiciary Committee begin an inquiry into whether President Nixon has committed any offenses that could lead to impeachment.

title: CeaseFire Lines Reflect Some Territory Exchange
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 22An Israeli general said tonight that his nation had won a very big victory in the Middle East war but it could have been bigger.

title: Qaddafi Threatens to Cut Off Oil to Europe Because of Truce
description: PARIS, Oct. 22Col. Muammad elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, threatened today to cut off all oil deliveries to Western Europe because its representaLives in the United Nations had voted for the ceasefire posed on them by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: No Clues Found in Killing Of Man in Brooklyn Homo
description: Brooklyn homicide detectives reported yesterday they had no clues in the brutal killing of a 70yearold man, whose body was discovered last Thursday in his apartment at 132 Bradford Street in the East New York section.

title: Times Reporter Is Honored
description: Lehigh University has presented an award to H. Maidenberg, a reporter on the businessfinancial news staff of The New York Times, for his coverage of the commodities futures markets. The award, a plaque, was presented by the university's College of Business and Finance and Department of. Management and Finance during a conference on commodities trading over the weekend.

title: 5 DIE IN SHIP FIRE IN MIDATLANTIC
description: Five crewmen died in a fire aboard the sinking Greek freighter Eurygenes Sunday night and a United States Navy reserch vessel plucked 36 other crewmen from lifeboats in midAtlantic, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

title: Woman Shot by Hitchhiker
description: SEDALIA, Colo., Oct. 22 (UPI)A 26yearold woman from Niagara Falls, N.Y., was beaten and shot by a hitchhiker after an argument and then tossed out of her car into ditch along a deserted stretch of a Colorado highway, the authorities said today. The woman, Suzan C. Metzler, was discovered early today after she crawled out of the ditch. She underwent surgery late today for a gunshot wound to the abdomen.

title: U.S. INDIAN AIDES SHOT IN DAKOTA
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Oct. 22 (AP)Two Bureau of Indian Affairs policemen were shot and wounded last night on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, the authorities said.

title: Polish Chief Forecasts a Purge of Party
description: WARSAW, Oct. 22 (AP) The Communist party leader, Edward Gierek, said today that a purge of the party's 2.5 million members was near.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Jakarta, Indonesia  Muhammad Ali, 217 pounds, Cherry Hill, N.J., outpointed Rudi Lubbers, 196, Netherlands, 12 rounds.

title: Marathon  Confirms Talks With Ireland on a Gas Find
description: FINDLAY, Ohio, Oct. 22 (UPI)The Marathon Oil Company today confirmed reports that it had held preliminary discussions with the Republic of Ireland about the potential development and uses of natural gas reserves it discovered in the Celtic Sea.

title: Sirica Will Meet Today With Two Grand Juries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Federal District Judge John J. Sirica will meet tomorrow morning in his courtroom here with members of the two main grand jades that have been investigating the Watergate affair.

title: Casals, the Master Cellist, Won Wide Acclaim in Career That Spanned 75 Years
description: I think it goes like this, a cello student struggling with a Johann Sebastian Bach suite once told Pablo Casals.

title: 6 ExStudents at Wisconsin U. Testify on Behalf of Saboteur
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 22 Several locally prominent radical activists, who attended the University of Wisconsin in the late nineteensixties, testified in an occasionally tearful hearing here today on behalf of Karleton Armstrong, an admitted saboteur.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CALIFORNIA  Clyde Wright and Steve Barber, pitchers; Ken Berry, outfielder; Art Kusnyer and player to be named later were traded to Milwaukee for Ellie Rodriauez, catcher; Skip Lockwood and Gary Ryeson, pitchers; Olle Brown and Joe Lahoud, outfielder.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Arabs, in the U.N., Accuse Israel of Aiding South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 22 (Reuters)  Renewed charges that Israel is aiding the white minority Government of South Africa with arms and trade sparked a heated and bitter debate today between Israeli and Arab delegates in a General Assembly committee.

title: 3 Killed in Car Crash
description: FULTON, N. Y., Oct 22 (UPI) Three men were killed and a fourth was critically injured yesterday when their car skidded out of control and slammed into a tree, the state police said. The driver, George Killpatrick, 22 years old, of Fulton, was accused of driving while intoxicated and speeding. The dead, all from Fulton, were Greig Fletcher, 24; James S. Peluso, 22, and Robert Trepasso, 22. John Ascenzi, 21, of Fulton was treated for a fractured spine.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Press For Basic Mideast Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Administration officials said today that in the wake of the Middle East ceasefire resolution, they expected Washington and Moscow to take the lead in coming weeks in trying to prod the warring countries into negotiating a political settlement of the longstanding IsraeliArab problem.

title: CAMPORA SINGS WITH CITY OPERA
description: The extraordinary beauty of the Shingon Buddhist Monks' Sho myo ceremony Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music made one regret all the more the peculiarities attendant upon their brief New York visit. The three performances last weekend attracted such small audiences that academy officials switched them from the Opera House to the far smaller Ball Room.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: Amer. Basketball Ass'n

title: Clubhouse Fire Kills Boy
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP)A young boy died yesterday in a fire that destroyed a wooden clubhouse built by neighborhood youngsters on an unused section of railroad track, the police reported. The victim was identified tentatively as James McNeill, 8 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis McNeill.

title: The Derelict Population Is Declining, But the Whole City Is Its Flophouse
description: Wearing tattered clothing and burntout expressions, the derelicts of New York sprawl on the city's sidewalks, clutching bottle of cheap liquor wrapped in brown paper bags. They call the sidewalks home, and there seem to be more of them than ever.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: From 4,000 to 6,000 highschool students, mostly seniors from metropolitan schools, conferred at the Americana Hotel in Manhattan with campus representatives from 125 Roman Catholic colleges and universities.

title: Financially Beset Hospital on S.I. Is Down to Its Last 50 Patients
description: Richmond Memorial Hospital, the only nonprofit voluntary hospital serving Staten Island's south shore, was down to 50 remaining patients yesterday as administrators awaited a court ruling today to determine whether the hospital would close completely.

title: Lawyers Assail President; Congress Is Urged to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Shocked and angered by what they consider to be an unprecedented attack on the nation's system of justice, the leaders of America's legal profession began mobilizing today to rebuff President Nixon and, if need be, to urge his impeachment.

title: Hill Sees Jet Problems as Sum Of Team's Emotional Traumas
description: Jet fans watching their favorite team on television this seasonand that's the only way they've been able to see themhave seen the team crawl to a disappointing start for various reasons, including injuries, missed blocks, errant passes and faulty running.

title: Blacks in City Constitute Largest Group in School
description: Black students, after doubling their numbers in the city's public schools over the last dozen years, are for the first time the largest group in the multiracial system.

title: Phosphate Ban Found to Be Reviving Syracuse's Dead Lake
description: Syracuse's dead lakeOnondagamay be coming back to life as a result of the statewide ban of phosphates in detergents, according to a report in the current issue of the journal Science.

title: 4 Struck Paper Plants Resume Canadian Output
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 22 (AP)Four of five Canadian International Paper Company mills have resumed full production following contract  ratification votes by workers who have been on strike since August.

title: Blacks in City Constitute Largest Group in School
description: Black students, after doubling their numbers in the city's public schools ever the last dozen years, are for the first time the largest group in the multiracial system.

title: LastPlace Finish in First Race Gives Orphan Happy Ending
description: When Jose Rodriguez was still an infant, his parents abandoned him in a shabby Manhattan rooming house.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 22Arthur Ashe, the American tennis star, has applied to play in the South African open lawn tennis tournament here Nov. 1427 in a spirit of goodwill and cooperation.

title: Major Independents
Siren Song of the Bowery Is Muffled
description: The buildings are rundown, the streets are littered, the men and women broken. But for thousands of derelicts, the Bowery is both hell and home.

title: ITALIAN LABOR UNIT LOOSENS SOVIET TIE
description: ROME, Oct 22  Italy's strongest labor organization formally loosened its ties with the Sovietdominated World Federation of Trade Unions at a congress that ended in Varna, Bulgaria, today.

title: Legislature's Action on Healh Criticized by Community Society
description: The Community Service Society of New York accused the Legislature yesterday of an unwillingness to deal realistially with alarmingly increased rates of health disorder and disease.

title: MEANY IS HOPEFUL ON TEAMSTERS PACT
description: BAL HARBOUR; Fla., Oct. 22 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, reported to the federation's biennial convention today that he still had hopes of comsummating an agreement with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters that would give the United Farm Workers Union jurisdiction over field workers in California.

title: HIJACKERS IN BOLIVIA GIVEN SAFE CONDUCT
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 22 (UPI) Four airline hijackers freed their 11 hostages and gave themselves up to Bolivian authorities today after striking a bargain for safe conduct that ended a 48hour holdout in southern Bolivia.

title: Five Killed as Plane Hits California Building in Fog
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 22 (APFive personsa pilot, his son, grandson, soninlaw and one other person died yesterday when their light airplans crashed into a building during a fog.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1973

title: LEGION DEPLORES 'DATE FOR HOLIDAY
description: The principal speaker at the annual Veterans Day parade charged yesterday that business interests had diluted the significance of the holiday by recommending a change in the date.

title: 37 More Food Outlets Here Are Charged With Violations of the Health Code
description: The Health Department has released the names of 37 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: Knicks' Candid Camera Pans Their Performance
description: The Knicks held a prolonged practice session yesterday at Madison Square Garden that included the showing of a horror movie filmed Saturday night. It was entitled, New York 69, Chicago 85.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: From Sinai to Peace
description: Between the diplomatic ingenuities of the two superpowers and the workaday inclinations of Arabs and Israelis living sidebyside, the dream of peaceful coexistence in the Middle East is reaching toward the daylight of reality.

title: Crash Kills Elderly Couple
description: READING, Pa., Oct. 22 (UPI)  Charles Clopp, 84 years old, and his, wife, Edna, 82, of Wernersville, were killed yesterday when their car collided with a mobile home on Rt. 422 near here.

title: MitchellStans Trial May Start Today
description: An extraordinary criminal trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans is scheduled to start here today, but it may be postponed because of a disputed White House tape recording.

title: 11Car Night Derailment Damages Bloomfield Home
description: BLOOMFIELD, Oct. 22 Eleven cars of a 52car eastbound ErieLackawanna freight train were derailed here at 4:25 o'clock this morning. The damage was estimated in the hundreds of thousands of dollars and rail traffic was tied up for the better part of the day.

title: Israelis West of Canal Find BurnedOut Zone
description: WITH THE ISRAELI FORCES IN EGYPT, Oct. 22An Israeli soldier poked his head out of an Egyptian bunker on the western bank of the Suez Canal today and grinned. Want some ice cream? he asked, offering his visitor a paper cup and spoon.

title: TIMES PROFITS UP 30,4% IN QUARTER
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday thirdquarter net income of $4.19million, or 37 cents a share, up 30.4 per cent from the yearearlier level.

title: Train Rolls 80 Miles With No One. Aboard
description: ESSEX JUNCTION, Vt., Oct. 22 (AP)A driverless diesel engine rolled 80 miles yesterday from Rutland to Essex Junction at 5 to 10 miles an hour before it was detected.

title: Raiders Tied on Late Kick, 2323
description: DENVER, Oct. 22 (UPI) Jim Turner, who missed a pair of legnthy first half field goals, booted his third threepointed of the game from 35 yards out with three seconds remaining tonight to give the Denver Broncos a 2323 tie with the Oakland Raiders.

title: FUTURES PRICES LITTLE CHANGED
description: Wheat, corn and soybean futures prices showed little change at the end of trading yesterday, despite some wide swings during the session.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EXPOSURE SoHophoto started life in a SoHo walkup a year or so ago. Shortly after this plebeian beginning, the photo gallery, which is a cooperative of about 100 members, moved to 30 West 13th Street, (6529721), where you take an elevator to its roomy open quarters on the fifth floor.

title: 3 Children Killed, 2 Adults Injured In Danbury Blaze
description: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 22Three children were, burned to death and two adults injured when fire raged through a secondfloor apartment today in the Beaver Brook City Housing Project on Eden Drive here.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Text of Dean' Petition
description: WASHINGTON, Oct., 22Following is the text of the resolution to be presented to Congress by deans of United States Iaw schools throughout the nation:

title: 3 Boys Accused of Murder In Burning of Miami Man
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22 (AP)Three boys were charged with firstdegree murder today in the death of a homeless derelict who was sprinkled with lighter fluid and set afire.

title: FOES OF MRS. MEIR RESUME CRITICISM
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 22No sooner did the shooting die on the Egyptian front than Israel's opposition reopened its attack on the Government.

title: Seat Price Declines
description: A membership on the New York Stock Exhange was sold for $120,000, it was announced yesterday. This was down $20,000 from the previous sale on Oct. 12. The current market is $115,000 bid, $140,000 asked.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Three Airlines Will Reduce Chicago Trip to Save Fuel
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (UPI) Three major airlines today announced agreement to reduce service between Chicago and sven other cities in efforts to conserve fuel.

title: Catholic Colleges Recruit City Youths
description: From 4,000 to 6,000 highschool students, mostly seniors and mostly from metropolitan schoolsmore than longtime recruiters could remember from past years  conferred here yesterday with representatives of 125 Roman Catholic colleges and universities.

title: Vatican Hails Truce Move
description: ROME, Oct. 22The Vatican radio today praised the resolution of the United Nations Security Council that called for a ceaaefire in the ArabIsraeli war. International mediation, the Vatican broadcast said, is the only way of halting, at last, bloodshed and promoting and guaranteeing peaceful coexistance of peoples and nations.

title: Beyond CeaseFire. . .
description: By collaborating through the United Nations ceasefire resolution to bring the ArabIsraeli fighting to a halt, the United States and the Soviet Union have succeeded in checking a tragic slaughter that threatened to become unbeatably costly in lives and resources for both sides. They have also narrowly averted a grave threat to their own dtente, and thus to the peace of the world.

title: COMMAGER URGES NIXON IMPEACHMENT
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 22 (AP)Henry Steele Commager, the historian, called tonight for the impeachment of President Nixon and said the President had violated the law 13 times.

title: Lawyers Assail President; Congress Is Urged to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Shocked and angered by what they consider to be an unprecedented attack on the nation's system of justice, the leaders of America's legal profession began mobilizing today to rebuff President Nixon and, if need be, to urge his impeachment.

title: Capri Price Raised $245
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (UPI)The Fofd Motor Company announced a price increase of $245 today for its Capri models, which are imported from West Germany for sale in the United States. The increase would raise the cost by 6.8 per cent.

title: Seeley Wins Decision
description: Walter Seeley of New York outpointed Vilomar Fernandez of Santo Domingo in a juniorlightweight bout last night in a 10round boxing match at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Seeley, 131 pounds, raised his wonlostdraw record to 2233.

title: People and Business
description: In an uncommonly tough talk to professional securities traders, Ray D. Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has asserted that the industry is being undermined by hardcore fraud and total disregard of the interests of investors.

title: Excerpts From Rules That Established Cox's Office
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Following are excerpts from rules and regulations signed by former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson and printed in the June 4 Federal Register establishing the office of Watergate special prosecutor within the Department of Justice:

title: Sandman Aides Expect Grand Design to Work
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22Those who are working on or writing about the gubernatorial campaign of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., agree on one thingit is unusual.

title: Press Sharply Criticizes Nixon on Ouster of Cox
description: President Nixon's dismissal of Archibald Cox has elicited the strongest press criticism since his election neatly five years ago.

title: CHILDAID CHIEF GETS STATE POST
description: Mrs. Barbara. Blum, the city's Commissioner for Special Services for Children since 1971, was named yesterday to head a new 16county metropolitan region for the State Board of Social Welfare, supervising public and private agencies for children and adults.

title: Scott Paper to Lift Output
description: The Scott Paper Company said yesterday that it would increase the production capacity of its packaged products divi sion by installing a new highspeed paper machine and supporting converting facilities at its plant at Chester, Pa. The cost will be more than $25million.

title: Defiant President
description: In the face of President Nixon's defiance of the law, the courts, the House and Senate, and the American people have to ponder and act upon their responsibilities in this grave time.

title: 2 Boys Die In Sand Fall At a Dump
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 22Two youths were buried alive and six others narrowly escaped death today as a mountain of sand collapsed on them in four closely spaced avalanches at the Huntington Town dump here.

title: Paris: Youthful Creativity Is in Retreat
description: PARIS  The latest Paris Biennale, which just closed at the Musee d'Art Moderne, presented nearly 100 artists under the age of 35 from all pad a of the world. On the whole, this eighth Biennale resembled closely other recent avantgarde jamborees. There was stuff that dangled from the ceilings or was spread over the floors and stuff that leaned against the walls. There were photographs, typed statements and scrawlings, prepared areas and processed itineraries, and of course there was no sculpture and, statistically speaking, no painting. The most noticeable new trends reflected a disenchantment with politics and technology, and a growing retreat into private mythologies: revolutionary slogans and neon tubes have given way to keepsakes and Arts Abroad

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Woman Parachutist Killed
description: CASA GRANIE, Ariz., Oct. 22 (AP)Linda Wright, who was married last month after a parachute jump with her husbandtobe, plunged to her death yesterday while attempting a solo sky dive. The 18yearold Phoenix woman's, main parachute and backup parachute did not open as she fell 3,500 feet. Her husband, Rod, was watching from the ground.

title: 12,000 Relief Recipients Already Put in City Jobs
description: It's a chance to do good for others and to open doors for yourself, says Steven Russell. He's a school health aide at Public School 101 in East Harlem, giving eye tests and calling parents attention to the fact that at least five out of each class of 25 or 30 youngsters needs care.

title: Justice Department Gives No Objection to Bendix Deal
description: The Bendix Corporation announced yesterday that it had been advised by the Justice Department that it had no objection to the purchase by Bendix of the Autolite Spark Plug plant and trademark from the Ford Motor Company. Bendix said the transaction would be completed as rapidly as practicable.

title: CONFEREES FAVOR A FUEL PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22A HouseSenate conference committee has quietly amended the Alaska pipeline bill in a way that Administration officials say would lead to large increases in the price of heating oil and gasoline.

title: A.W.O.L. Marine Shoots 3 In Dover Township Siege
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, Oct. 22 An 18yearold A.W.O.L. Marine, armed with a shotgun, held his teenage girlfriend and three other persons hostage in a mobile home trailer park in nightlong siege during which he wounded three policemen and demanded a plane to fly him to Egypt.

title: Curbs on Soviet Scientists Deplored by Academy Here
description: The New York Academy of Sciences announced yesterday that it had sent a message to the Soviet Academy of Sciences expressing concern about reports of repression of freedom of speech for scientists in the Soviet Union.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Separate plans to shore up New York's sagging theater district were put forward yesterday by two of the mayoralcandidates.

title: DOCTORS' INFLUX BACKED BY A.M.A.
description: The American Medical Association, in an editorial published in Its journal yesterday, challenged the prevailing attitude that the migration of thousands of foreign physicians to the United States represented, a brain drain, seducing badly needed doctors away from developing countries.

title: Second Chicago Plan in 3 Years Fails to End Building Color Line
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 22For the second time in three years, a voluntary accord between this city's construction companies and building trades unions for hiring member's of minority groups on federally subsidized building projects has collapsed because of poor performance.

title: An Elderly Man in Belfast Killed as Bomb Wrecks Bar
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 22 (AP)An elderly man was killed tonight in a bomb explosion that wrecked an East Belfast bar.

title: Cox Investigators Had Groups Studying Five Areas in the Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 The Watergate breakin was only one of five broad areas under close examination by Archibald Cox before his dismissal Saturday as special prosecutor.

title: Chrysler's Deficit For Third Quarter Less Than Feared
Judges to Honor Sirica
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., Oct, 22 (UPI)Judge John J. Sirica of Federal District Court in Washington, who made landmark rulings in the Watergate case, will be presented a special award at a meeting this Thursday of the American Judges Association, a spokesman said today. The group, the nation's only association of judges, will also consider a resolution opposing President Nikon's dismissal of Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, according to Judge M. Michael Gordon of Municipal Court, Houston.

title: KERKORIAN PLANS 2D SALE OF STOCK
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the former flight instructor who in 1968 paid $67.5million for control of Western Airlines, Inc., said yesterday it now was his intention to sell a significant number of his shares through a public offering. Mr. Kerkorian holds about 23 per cent of the 13.9 million outstanding Western shares.

title: Effort to Get Farmer Data From Tax Returns Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) The House Government Operations Committee says Agriculture Department attempts to get financial information from three million farm income tax returns for statistical purposes could be an invasion of privacy.

title: STEEL IMPORTS OFF IN FIRST 8 MONTHS
description: The American Institute for Imported Steel noted yesterday that steelimports for the first eight months of this year fell by 332,000 tons to 10.4 million, tons. The figures were based on statistics released by the Department of Commerce.

title: CAIRO DEMANDS ISRAELI PULLOUT
description: CAIRO, Oct. 22  A ceasefire went into effect today at 6:52 P.M. local time on the Suez Canal front and in the Sinai Peninsula, the Egyptian high command announced.

title: U.A.W. Sets a Friday Deadline As Key Issues Snag Ford Talks
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22With major issues still to be resolved the United Automobile Workers today set a deadline of 10 A.M. Friday for reaching a new contract agreement with the. Ford Motor Company.

title: A DELAY IS SOUGHT ON STADIUM PACTS
description: NEWARK, Oct. 22  The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, hardpressed for funds because of successive marketing delays on a proposed $280million bond issue, is apparently in the process of trying to renegotiate contractsigning deadlines with five construction companies.

title: Chess: Taking It Easy at the Start May Keep you Alive Until End
description: Quite a number of experienced players recommend taking it easy at the start of a match or tournament because there is nothing harder than trying to recover from the kind of disaster a backfiring adventure can produce. Early losses often lead to nervous, overanxious pressing that proliferates into further defeats.

title: Storm Off Bahamas Eases
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22 (UPI)Tropical storm Gilda, with highest winds down to 35 miles an hour, was downgraded today to a tropical depression. The latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center here put the center of the disturbance just east of the island of Eleuthera in the Bahamas. The disturbance was forecast to drift slowly toward the east with a very slow weakening of circulation.

title: Pregnant Whale Takes First Food in 8 Days
description: Francis, the pregnant white whale at New York Aquarium, in Coney Island, regained her appetite yesterday and took her first food in eight days.

title: How Grownups Can Still Enjoy a Carousel
description: SANDWICH, Mass.  Shirley Temple Black's carousel horse rides a brass pole in a pavilion on her Woodside, Calif., estate. Lucille Ball parks her prancers by her pool. Ganna Walska, the much married 93yearold diva, has a merrygoround menagerie guarding the splendid flora around her Montecito, Calif., mansion. And Julia Helms uses two jumpers to form a divider between living and dining areas in her Washington home.

title: Salom Rizk, Syrian Chronicler Of His Life in America, Is Dead
description: Salom Rizk, who Wrote and lectured widely on his life story of a vagabond orphan in Syria questing for education, freedom and economic security in America, died yesterday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 63 years old.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Detroit Edison Company yesterday announced that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed public offering of 4million shares of common stock. The offering, expected on Nov. 14, would be headed by Morgan Stanley. The company's stock closed at 18, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CAIRO DEMANDS ISRAELI PULLOUT
Scots Seek Kinship and Commerce
description: Two Scottish dukes and three earlsamong them the chiefs of the clans of Campbell, Murray and Brucewalked down upper Fifth Avenue yesterday clutching the strings Mickey Mouse balloons that bobbed above their titled heads.

title: High School Sports
description: He is 6 feet tall and weighs 220 pounds. He has earned a letter in four sports and has led Syosset's football team to four straight victories this season. He is Kevin Mannix, a fullback of bigtime proportions and bigtime ambitions and perhaps the best player on Long Island.

title: A. D. Emmart Dead at 70; Retired Editor of Sunpapers
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 22A. D. Emmart, retired associate editor of the Baltimore Sunpapers and editorial page editor of The Baltimore Evening Sun, died yesterday at the age of 70.

title: Music
description: The Symphony of the New. World played a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon, though it had to cross a picket line of striking New York Philharmonic musicians to do so. The New Wotld group, whose rehearsals for this program reportedly had been disrupted by arguments over the strike, performed far below its best under the direction of James Frasier Jr., a 32yearold Detroiter making his New York debut.

title: Fuel Price Rise Feared
description: The Alaska pipeline bill has been amended by a HouseSenate conference committee in a way that, according to Administration officials, will lead to big increases in prices of heating oil and gasoline. Details on Page 7.

title: ELMORE L. KEENER JR.
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22Elmore L. Keener Jr., a principal partner and member of the board of directors of the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League, died today in West Penn Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Fox Chapel, a suburb.

title: Union Oil Profit Up 61%
description: The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday that its thirdquarter earnings rose 61 per cent to $50.7million. The ninemonth profit was up 44 per cent to $129.1million. The company said strong demand and higher prices had contributed to the gains.

title: U.S. OIL EXHIBITION OPENS IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 22  While Arab nations are cutting off oil supplies to the United States, the Soviet Union today moved a step closer toward cooperation with American companies in this field by formally opening the largest American exhibition ever held here to show oil and gas technology and equipment.

title: Brasco Has Liberal Reputation
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco, the Brooklyn Democrat who was indicted yesterday in an alleged bribery conspiracy, has a reputation as a vigorous, liberal Congressman but also as a man who has been helpful to individuals allegedly linked with organized crime.

title: Anaconda Raises Prices Of Brass Mill Products
description: The Anaconda American Brass Company, a unit of the Anaconda Company, said yesterday that it had increased prices for brass mill products, including copper water tube, to reflect a blended copper cost of 81 cents a pound up from 6.5 cents a pound.

title: TV Academy Elects Cannon
description: John Cannon, radio and television personality, has been elected chairman of the National Academy of Television Arts land Sciencies, effective June 15, 1974. He will succeed Thomas W. Sarnoff, West Coast executive vice president for the National Broadcasting Company. For the last four years, Mr. Cannon has been president of the academy's New York chapter.

title: Confident Dartmouth Set To Test Harvard Eleven
description: Undefeated Harvard can assure itself of a winning football season if it can overcome Dartmouth this Saturday in Harvard Stadium. The Crimson has not beaten the Big Green since 1968. Unfortunately for Harvard, Dartmouth seems to have found itself after scoring its first victory of the campaign over a rugged Brown squad last weekend, 2816. We have some confidence now, said the Dartmouth coach, Jake Crouthamel. He cited the confidence builders: 1) Putting together a sustained scoring drive, 70 yards, and all on the ground. 2) Putting together strings of successive first downs. 3) Scoring on defense (Tom Fleming's 74yard punt return).

title: NIXON TAPE EYE STIRS AMEX RISE
description: The announcement that President Nixon would relinquish the Watergate tapes touched off a wave of buying yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market. But profit taking near the close reduced gains.

title: MRS. MEIR SPEAKS
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Oct. 24Israeli and Egyptian forces continued fullscale war in the southern sector of the Suez Canal front yesterday despite the ceasefire that technically went into effect Monday. The northern part of the front was reported quiet.

title: Technology to Soviet
description: The Control Data Corporation and the Soviet Union signed a 10year agreement yesterday to cooperate in the development of advanced computer technology. The accord is the first with a major computer manufacturer as well as the first such longterm pact with a United States company. Page 63.

title: Lon Nol Assails U. N. for Considering Sihanouk's Entry
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 23President Lon Nol criticized the United Nations today for taking up the question of who should represent Cambodiahis Government in Phnom Penh or the Pekingbased government in exile of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, whom Lon Nol deposed in 1970.

title: Watson Is Named As Blazers' Coach
description: VANCOUVER, Oct. 23 (AP) Phil Watson, a general manager, took over as coach of the Vancouver, Blazers of the World Horkey; Association today, replacing John McKenzie who stepped down as playercoach to concentrate on his duties as right wing on the team.

title: Court Lets Stand Edict Voiding Jersey School Tax
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23  A New Jersey Supreme Court decision that struck down the state's traditional system of financing publicschool education was allowed to stand today when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal in the case.

title: Flurry in Markets
description: PARIS, Oct. 23After a period of relative calm since midsummer, fresh flurries are hitting Europe's currency maxkets.

title: Film: Summertime Killer:The Cast
description: Splashes of background colorManhattan streets, a bit of Rome, Lisbon's Estoril sector and the high-rise Madrid suburbs  erratically brighten a humdrum suspense melodrama titled "Summertime Killer," now playing around town.The young killer, Christopher Mitchum (Bob's face, blond hippie hair), out to avenge his murdered father, picks off underworld kingpins, finally kidnaps a pretty girl, Olivia Hussey, and guess what happens.Closing in, as love blooms, are the girl's father, Raf Vallone, and his hoodlums, and a dogged detective, Karl Malden, who must have taken a wrong turn from "The Streets of San Francisco," his television show. Compressed, the picture might have sufficed as a 40-minute segment (minus commercials).Here, the punctuation and padding are obivous, as in the frenetic photography of Antonio Isasi, the director, and the prolonged resolution. For all the tense hopping around on all sides, it couldn't matter less.

title: 3 Win Nobel Physics Prize And 2 the Chemistry Award
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 23Two scientists with leading American companies and a Briton won the 1973 Nobel Physics Prize today for theories that have advanced and expanded the world of miniature electronics.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Uganda Says Three Nations Plan a Commando Invasion
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 23 (UPI)President Idi Amin ordered today that all American and British nationals in, Uganda without identification cards be arrested and kept in military custody, Radio Uganda said.

title: 5 Tugs Move Largest Ship to Be Drydocked Here
description: The largest ship ever to be drydocked here, the 775foot 62,700ton Panamanian tanker Asopos, has been moved out of a floating drydock with the aid of five McAllister tugs.

title: Making It Stick
description: The peacemakers' role is never done, as the Soviet Union and the United States are finding out in the Middle East. Yesterday they gained further Security Council support for their joint diplomatic initiative of early Monday as United Nations observers were ordered to the battlefront. Without belittling the immensity of this week's superpower accord, it nevertheless is only the beginning.

title: Transit. Worker Is Burned; Her Boyfriend Is Accused
description: A young Transit Authority employe was seriously burned yesterday when she was working in a subway toll booth and a man, hurled lighter fluid at her and then threw in a lighted match, the police said.

title: BELGIUM AND ZAIRE REACH AGREEMENT
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  Belgium and Zaire, the former Belgian Congo, announced yesterday that they had reached an identity of views for new cooperation after talks between their Foreign Ministers.

title: Nixon Speaks at 9 P.M.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon, facing what he perceived as a grave national crisis of confidence, decided today in verypainful and anguished discussions with his staff to abandon his strongly held opinion against turning the Watergate tapes, over to the courts, his assistants said.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO AID MENTAL PATIENTS
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23 (AP)A suit was filed in Federal Court today charging that thousands of mental patients in New Jersey hospitals are committed under a state law that is unconstitutional.

title: Crisis on Two Fronts
description: The domestic crisis over possible impeachment of the President and the international crisis over the Middle East and oil have not, thus far, had a devastating effect on business or investor sentiment.

title: Hughes Wins U.S. Contract
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company received a $49.8  million Air Force contract for the manufacture of Maverick airtosurface missiles, it was announced yesterday.

title: Revenue Worries Cut Prime  Time TV News Specials
description: It is a form of culture shock to pass from the crisis in Washington in the 7 o'clock news to the comicstrip antics a prime time and back into the real world of a President in trouble at 11 o'clock. Unless there is some last minute rescheduling by the networks, this will be the way of it in this critical week in American history until Friday when the Columbia Broadcasting Systern gives up an hour at 8 P.M. for a program by the news division with the participation of assorted political figures and legal experts. That program has already undergone a significant change. With yesterday's unexpected development in the capital, the special, originally titled The Question of Impeachment, is now to be called, The White House Tapes: The President's Decisions.

title: Red Offices Burned in Sicily
description: MESSINA, Sicily, Oct. 23 (AP)  The Communist party headquarters in Messina was almost destroyed in a fire today by persons who left swastikas scrawled over the walls.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1973

title: No Real Choice in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 23  It was late Sunday night when Premier Golda Meir received a personal message from President Nixon urging Israel to accept the SovietAmerican ceasefire proposal that had been worked out in Moscow just a few hours earlier.

title: Henry Ford Is Speaker At Glassboro Ceremonies
description: GLASSBORO, N. J., Oct. 23 (AP)In the aftermath of Vietnam and Watergate, the American people have begun to lose faith in their institutions and their leaders, says Henry Ford 2d.

title: Births
description: SHAIFERJill and Jack (nee Harren), happily announce the arrival of their son, Seth Ian, Oct. 23, 1973.

title: Transit Worker Is Burned; Her Boyfriend Is Accused
description: A young Transit Authority employe was seriously burned yesterday when she was workling in a subway toll booth and a man hurled lighter fluid at her and then threw in a lighted match, the police said.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Ordering Declines For Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) New orders for durable goods decreased nearly $1billion in September from the August level, largely because of a slower pace of orders in the steel industry, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Bonds for Jersey Stadium Temporarily Off Market
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today it had asked its underwriters to temporarily withdraw a proposed $280million bond issue from the market with the understanding that a stronger security can be restructured in 30 days.

title: FRANCIS GORDON, A MICROBIOLOGIST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  Dr. Francis B. Gordon, a microbiologist who was active in the Naval Medical Research Institute here, and his wife, Mary, died Sunday when a freighter on which they were passengers caught fire and, capsized in the Atlantic Ocean 800 miles off the East Coast.

title: High Court Refuses to Hear Plea By Jersey Defending School Tax
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23  A New Jersey Supreme Court decision that struck down the state's traditional system of financing publicschool education was allowed to stand today when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal in the case.

title: Skylab Launching Periled
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 23 (UPI)A mishap today during the loading of fuel into the rocket that will boost the Skylab 3 astronauts into space threatened to delay their planned Nov. 10 launching.

title: Prison Hunger Strike Ends
description: WINDSOR, Vt., Oct. 23 (AP) Windsor State Prison officials said today that a hunger strike by inmates had ended.

title: 24Hour Controller Strike Closes Rome's 2 Airports
description: ROME, Oct. 23A 24hour strike of flight controllers and other technicians closed Rome's two civil airports today.

title: 10DAY BLACKOUT ENDED IN AMMAN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 23The Jordanian authorities, in a gesture of confidence, tonight lifted the blackout they had imposed on Amman 10 days ago for fear of Israeli air raids.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Authorities held an 18yearold youth without bail in Freehold yesterday in connection with the murder of a nightclub singer, Judith Anne Golub, who was found strangled in Middletown last week.

title: Rail Expansion in Northeast Opposed
description: The chief executive officer of the profitable Norfolk & Western Railway said here] yesterday that his system would oppose any move of a Western or Southern railroad to extend its lines into the Northeast by acquiring parts of the Penn Central, the ErieLackawanna or any of the other bankrupt lines. There have been recurring reports that legislation has been introduced and is now being, marked up in the House Commerce Committee would permit roads operating in contiguous states to invade the territory now being served by the bankrupt lines.

title: Tho Rejects Nobel Prize, Citing Vietnam Situation
description: PARIS, Oct. 23Le Duc Tho has rejected the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to him jointly with Secretary of State Kissinger for the Vietnam agreement they negotiated, Hanoi announced today.

title: Middle East War Is a Vast Test Range for the Most Advanced Soviet Weapons
description: The Middle East war has become a vast test range for Soviet military equipment, from highly sophisticated antiaircraft and antitank missiles to the newest battle tanks, Western Military sources believe.

title: ABRUPT REVERSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon, in a stunning reversal, abruptly agreed today to turn over the Watergate tape recordings to Federal District Judge John J. Sirica.

title: USE OF MOTOR FUELS SEEN RISING 6.3 PCT.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The nation's consumption of motor fuels is expected to increase 6.3 per cent this year, despite the gasoline shortage of late spring and summer, the Federal Highway Administration said yesterday.

title: East Side School Boycott Is Ended After Six Days
description: Parent leaders in School District 1 on the Lower East Side yesterday called off their sixdayold school boycott pending a ruling by a Federal judge on the parents' suit for new community school board elections in the district.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Antibusing Move Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  Foes of forced busing of school children said today they would attempt in January to dislodge from the House Judiciary Committee an antibusing amendment to the Constitution.

title: Police Act Against Workers Trying to Run French Plant
description: BESANCON, France, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  The police today surrounded a building here where workers fighting for the revival of the bankrupt Lip watch factory had set up their headquarters.

title: Capitulation and Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon's capitulation to the courts today strengthened the suspicions of his critics and opponents. They were convincedor prepared to be convinced  that his purpose in initially refusing to give the Watergate tapes to Federal Judge John J. Sirica was not so much to preserve the confidentiality of Presidential communications as to get rid of Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox.

title: Chinese Arrive in Tulsa
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 23 (UPI) Ten librarians from China arrived in Tulsa today during the sixth week of their tour of library and educational facilities in the United States. The tour is one of the scholarly communication exchanges arranged after President Nixon's 1972 trip to Peking.

title: PENALTY IMPOSED SOAPBOX EVENT
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 23 (UPI)A Juvenile Court judge ordered Robert Lange, Sr. today to donate $2,000 to a local boy's club and told him to apologize to the nation's youth for helping his nephew cheat to win the 1973 National Soap Box Derby at Akron, Ohio.

title: AroundWorld Flight Ends
description: HEMET, Calif., Oct. 23 (UPI) A retired Air Force colonel attempting to fly his homemade plane around the world has called it quits, his wife said from their home here yesterday. Donald P. Taylor, 53 years old, who mortgaged his home to finance the flight, called his wife, Lois, and said he was giving up the voyage because of the bad weather over the Bering Sea.

title: Physics Prize Won for Research in Electronics
description: The three winners of this year's Nobel Prize in Physics made discoveries regarding phenomena unfamiliar to the layman, yet vital to his television set or the computers that affect many aspects of his life.

title: Relief Is General In Political Camps At Nixon's Reversal
description: The loud sighs of relief have been only slightly muffled by reminders that the political battle over Watergate is not yet over. The nation's political leaders expressed almost universal relief that President Nixon had finally agreed to release Presidential tape recordings related to the Watergate case to a Federal judge.

title: Red Smith
description: If anyone around here is losing faith in the American dream, let him reflect upon Vida Blue, a poor kid from Mansfield, La., who pays 10 times as much income tax as the President of the United States. It could happen only in America.

title: Rep. Brasco and Uncle Indicted In Alleged MailContract Plot
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to receive $27,500 in illegal payoffs in 1968 from a Bronx trucking concern headed by an alleged Mafia member.

title: Nobleman Managing Nobel Funds Astutely
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 23The money behind the Nobel prizes is being so well managed these days that the prizes for chemistry and physics awarded today are each worth about $122,000. In 1953, a Nobel prize was worth $33,840.

title: CAIRO ACCUSATION
description: EL FIRDAN, Egypt, Oct. 23Heavy artillery boomed almost incessantly a few miles southwest of here today as Egyptian forces in this area along the Suez Canal wearily lived through the first day of a ceasefire that had already been broken.

title: METALS COMPANIES SCHEDULE CHANCES
description: The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday that it was curtailing production of certain aluminum items, while Martin Marietta Aluminum, Inc., said it planned to about double the capacity of a rolling mill.

title: FIRST OF REFUGEES ARE LEAVING CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct, 23The first group of 70 political refugees being assisted by a United Nationssponsored relief program flew to Sweden today.

title: Insurance Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve said it would hold hearings next month on whether banks should be permitted to underwrite Mortgage guarantee insurance. The hearing set for Nov. 28, will be on a proposal made by the board in May that would permit bank holding companies to do this.

title: CHESIMARD CASE GETS A JURY SHIFT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 23  Superior Court Judge Leon Gerofsky granted a defense motion today for jury selection outside of Middlesex County in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Square, and ordered the process moved to Morris County.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Two major performers have been signed for leading roles in Broadwaybound stage productions. Claudette Colbert will return to the theater this season in Jerome Chodorov's comedy, A Community of Two, which will be placed in rehearsal Dec. 3. George Gaynes will be costarred with Miss Colbert. The playwright will direct.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Three of the four major candidates for Mayor expounded at the same forum yesterday on why they should be elected on Nov. 6.

title: Warning by Banker
description: LONDON, Oct. 23  The prospect of another worldwide currency crisis of shattering proportions next year was raised here today by a leading American banker.

title: Ruckelshaus Terms His Defiance Of Nixon a Very Easy Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The last question asked of the former deputy attorney general, William D. Ruckelshaus, at his news conference today was, Would you take another job in this Administration?

title: CAIRO ACCUSATION
description: EL FIRDAN, Egypt, Oct. 23Heavy artillery boomed almost incessantly a few miles southwest of here today as Egyptian forces in this area along the Suez Canal wearily lived through the first day of a ceasefire that had already been broken.

title: Text of Cox's Farewell Remarks to Watergate Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Following is at transcript of the farewell, remarks of Archibald Cox to the staff of the Watergate Special Prosecution Force, as prepared by the special force's public information office, before the White. House announced that President Nixon would turn over the Watergate tapes to Judge John J. Sirica:

title: CONTRACT SAVES HOSPITAL ON S.I.
description: A twoyear contract retroactive to last April 1 has averted the threatened closing of Richmond Memorial Hospital on Staten Island, which had been struck since Oct. 9 by 250 employes belonging to Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union.

title: TIDES TO BUY PAPER IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase The Lexington Dispatch, an afternoon newspaper published six days a week in Lexington, N. C.

title: MARKET RALLIES ON NEWS OF TAPES
description: Stock prices rallied sharply yesterday in late trading, bounding ahead on the news that President Nixon had agreed to turn over the Watergate tapes to Federal District Judge John Sirica.

title: HOXIE FAIRCHILD OF HUNTER DEAD
description: Dr. Hoxie Neale Fairchild, professor emeritus of English at Hunter College and author of Religious Trends in English Poetry a sixvolume series that he began in 1939, died yesterday at St. Lukes Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 464 Riverside Drive here.

title: LOUIS GOEBEL DIES; CHURCH LEADER, 89
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (AP)The Rev. Dr. Louis W. Goebel, the first president of the former Evangelical and Reformed Church, died here last night at Deaconess Hospital. He was 89 years old.

title: Quake Felt in California
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 23 (UPI)A slight earthquake, registering less than 3.5 on the Richter scale, jiggled this Orange County community last night but no damage was reported.

title: Corporate Earnings Reports for the Third Quarter Continue to Indicate Strong Gains in Many Industries
Casals Honored by Thousands At State Rites in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 23Puerto Ricans from all walks of life and political indeologiss joined today to mourn the death of an adopted son, the cellist Pablo Casals.

title: People and Business
description: Richard A. Jitney, president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, has been named chief executive officer, effective Nov. 1. He succeeds Raymond C. Firestone a son of the founder; the late. Harvey S. Firestonewho will continue as chairman.

title: High court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Supreme Count took the following actions today:

title: To Children, At Least, Mall's Art Is a Hit
description: GREECE, N.Y.  Can a blinking, armwaving, robotlike sculpture cohabit with the peau de soiedraped mannequins of Nusbaum's Bridals and Formals? Can giant, foam rubber bread loaves that rise and fall with every trampolining child live in peace beside the pantyhose displays at Parklane Hosiery?

title: Auxiliary Policeman Is Freed, LookAlike Held in Sex Case
description: An auxiliary police officer was cleared of sexualabuse charges and a former hospital security guard has been arraigned on the same charges in a case of apparent mistaken identity, District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx announced yesterday.

title: UConns Win in Soccer
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 23The University of Connecticut upset Brown, 10, today in soccer. A junior forward, Len Tsantares, scored on a rebound shot with an assist by Franta Innocent.

title: FARMERS CAUTIONED NOT TO OVERPLANT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) While the Federal Government and most consumers, urge farmers to increase production, Representative William J. Scherle, an Iowa grain and livestock farmer, bucks the trend by telling his constituents: Don't Overplant! or Plant with Caution!

title: Advertising: TVTrainin Kids
description: The National Broadcasting Company has departed from a longstanding policy of not underwriting the production costs of publicserviee spots in order to help to create a fect, make children less vulcampaign that should, in efnerable to commercials.

title: Woman Strangled With a Stocking In East Side Flat
description: The body of a 29yearold woman, who had been stabbed several times with a kitchen knife and strangled with a stocking, was found by the police last night on the floor of her East Side studio apartment, following a telephone tip from a man who refused to identify himself.

title: Short Hair vs. Long: The Scissors Are Snipping Away These Days
description: Hairdressers have been preaching short hair for a couple of years now, and have met a good deal of resistance. After all, as Kenneth, one of the hairdressing superstars, once said, a lot of hair makes a woman feel important. But, while the tide seems to be turning, at midpoint in the long vs. short hair debate women still have widely different views. Short hair, which needs more frequent professional attention, can cost more. But is short hair more trouble to take care of at home than long locks, which can be allowed to hang or be pulled back into a pony tail or a bun?

title: ISRAELIS TIGHTEN GRIP WEST OF SUEZ
description: WITH ISRAELI FORGES IN EGYPT, Oct. 23Israel tightened her grip on a large enclave of captured Egyptian territory west of the Suez Canal today, pouring in supplies and fresh troops to make her bridgehead secure against military threat.

title: Fire Safety for Aged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 23 (AP) Demands for stricter fire safety standards in nursing homes for the aged was urged today in the House. Representative Joel Pritchard, Republican of Washington, of the House Republican Task Force on Aging, told a House subcommittee that the best way to save lives in fires was to require automatic sprinkler systems and alarms in all buildings designed for the aged.

title: Hanoi Charges U.S. Tries To Divide Communist Bloc
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse) North Vietnam today attacked maneuvers by President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger, and criticized what it called the blindness of those who tended to forget that American imperialism remains the No. 1 enemy of all the peoples.

title: Berra Gets Reward: A 3Year Contract
description: Yogi Berra finally signed for some peace of mind yesterday.

title: Scarcity Alters DrugTrade Patterns
Wells College Gets Grant
description: AURORA, N.Y., Oct. 23 (AP) Wells College, has received a $5,000 special grant under Eastman Kodak's 1973 Educational Aid Program, according to John D. Wilson, president of the college. He said the grant would be used for new darkroom facilities in the college's fine arts center.

title: Insanity Plea in Texas Case
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)Elmer Wayne Kenley, 17 years old, one of two, youths accused of murder in Houston's mass murder case, will plead insanity at his trial, scheduled for Jan. 14, his lawyer said today.

title: Peeling Led To Research ty Chemists
description: In 1951, an intuition that something was wrong led. Ernst Otto Fischer in Munich, Getmany, and Geoffrey Wilkinson in Cambridge, Mass., independently to push open the door into a new field of chemistry  organonietallic cornpounds with a sandwichlike structure.

title: City Decorates 34 Police Officers, 5 Posthumously
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday presented 34 medals, five of them posthumously, to police officers for heroic acts, and he used, the occasion to criticize the Nixon Administration on the issue of law and Order.

title: MacPhail Heads A. L. In January
description: CHICAGO Oct. 23 (UPI)Lee MacPhail. 55yearold general manager of the New York Yankees, was unamimously named the American League's new president today, succeeding Joe Cronin.

title: The Dance
description: The Fred Benjamin Dance Company, which completed a longweekend engagement at the Clark Center for the Performing Arts on Monday evening, is now five years old. It is a company that tries to combine ballet jazz with ballet classicism, and the results have a certain Alvin Ailey air to them.

title: 2 SENTENCED TO DIE TO GET A NEW TRIAL
description: ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP)The State Court of Appeals today reversed the conviction of two Bronx men sentenced to death for the 1968 slaying of a Westchester County deputy sheriff.

title: SHORTAGE OF TIMBER SEEN IN U.S. REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Pressures from environmentalists to protect United States forests could sharply reduce timber production and raise lumber prices 50 to 60 per cent by the year 2000, a Forest Service report said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Oct. 23 (UPI)Joe Woolley, the former Ball High school football coach, will go on trial next month on misdemeanor charges that he rigged the grade transcript of an Oklahoma University quarterback, Kerry Jackson. Woolley, 36 years old, admitted last spring he altered Jackson's high school record to better his academic standing and preserve his eligibility at Oklahoma last year. Woolley, also tampered with the transcript Oklahoma's center, Nike Phillips.

title: Why Philharmonic Strike Drags On
description: Why is the New York Philharmonic strike dragging on? What makes this walkout, by 106 musicians, so bitterly fought and so strangely impervious to the usual peacemaking tactics? The strike, now four weeks old, has become an increasingly tangled ball of yarn in which standard economic arguments intertwine with personality clashes, charges of conspiracy, wounded pride and a determination on both sides not to be bluffed. The key to the stalemate is the recently negotiated contract of another of the socalled Big Five orchestras, the Chicago Sympllony, which under the baton of Sir Georg Solti has come to be regarded by many knowledgeable listeners as currently the finest in the land. On Oct. 13, after a fourweek work stoppage (termed a lockout by the players), the Chicago players won a total increase of $60 a week over a threeyear contract. The Philharmonic management, which admits to having been surprised at the size of the Chicago settlement, says it cannot and does not intend to match that contract.

title: 2 NEWSMEN CALLED IN SENATE INQUIRY
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Oct. 23 (AP)  Two Manchester Union Leader reporters were served Subpoenas today to appear before the Senate Watergate committee at Washington Friday and bring with them all records pertinent to the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: A FloodTom City in Oklahoma Recovering Slowly After Rains
description: ENID, Okla., Oct. 23 (AP)I just don't know what to do. The best thing for me maybe is just to declare bunkruptcy.

title: U. S.JapaneseEuropean Body Off to a Shaky Start in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Oct. 23A new organization of prominent North American, Western European and Japanese private citizens called the Trilateral Commission got off to a shaky start here today as Japanese members objected to the commission's aims and procedures.

title: Indian Experience in Readings and Lore
description: THE INDIAN EXPERIENCE, an AmericanIndian revue, by Wayne Johnson and John Kauffman; directed by Gregory A. Falls; setting by Bill Forrester; lighting by Jody Briggs. Presented by The Zean Production Company. At Playhouse 2, West 48th Street.

title: Business Briefs
description: James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, criticized bankers making housing loans yesterday for shoddy, sloppy and worse practices.

title: Jerkens Set to Pull 2 More Out of Hat
description: Even a magician like Allen Jerkens can't pull stakes victories out of the hat every time he tries.

title: NIXON CUT QUOTAS AFTER '70 PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Fifteen days after a complaint to President Nixon about his failure to adjust import quotas on certain dairy products Was coupled with a $2million pledge from the dairy industry for his 1972 campaign, the President drastically reduced the quotas on at least two of the products.

title: Tho Rejects Nobel Prize
description: Le Duc Tho, the North Vietnamese negotiator, rejected the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday, charging that peace has not yet really been established in South. Vietnam. Details, Page 3.

title: Richardson Says White House Aides Suggested Ousting Cox Before He Balked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said today that White House aides had sug gested discharging Ardhibald Cox as the Government's special Watergate prosecutor days before Mr. Cox balked at President Nixon's order not to continue his quest for the Watergate tape recordings.

title: Film Comment Magazine Given To Lincoln Center Film Society
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center, sponsor of the annual New York Film Festival, announced yesterday the acquisition of Film Comment, a bimonthly magazine devoted to the art of cinema. At the same time, the society reported that the 11th annual festival, which concluded Oct 13, had been the most successful in history, drawing 37,750 people, nearly 15,000 More than the previous year, and achieving an overall attendance of 91 per cent of capacity.

title: Dow in Oil Drilling Program
description: The McMoran Exploration Company announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with the Dow Chemical Company for a joint exploration drilling program for oil and gas in the continental United States.

title: Surina Triumphs, In Bowling Final
description: Matt Surina of Longview, Wash., rolled a barrage of strikes at four straight foes last night to capture the $5,000 firstplace prize in the $50,000 Brunswick Eastern open bowling tournament at Bayside Lanes in Queens. He averaged 250.

title: Drama in a Crowded Courtroom
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The first arguments to be heard in Chief Judge, John J. Sirica's courtroom today began much before the White House lawyersCharles Alan Wright and Leonard Garment arrived.

title: Patton Asks Ethics Board Ruling On Job Offer From Realty Group
description: Ken Patton, head of the Economic Development Administration, said yesterday that he had, been offered the job of president of the New York Board of Real Estate and that he had asked the city's Board of Ethics to rule on whether his acceptance would create a conflict of interest.

title: Protestant Leader in Ulster Narrowly Wins Party Backing
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23The leader of Ulster's Protestant Unionist party, Brian Faulkner, survived a crucial party vote in Belfast today, but the narrow majority in favor of continuing negotiations to establish a Roman CatholicProtestant coalition government showed the deep divisions among the Protestants.

title: Bridge: Unheralded Quartet Victor In BoardAMatch Contest
description: The metropolitan championships of the greater New York Bridge Association ended Monday night with a convincing victory in the boardAmate team event for an unheralded quartet.

title: Tho Rejects Nobel Prize
description: Le Duc Tho, the North Vietnamese negotiator, rejected the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday, charging that peace has not yet really been established in South Vietnam. Details, Page 3.

title: Boy, 12, Found Strangled In Ditch in Pelham Area
description: A 12yearold boy was found strangled in the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx yesterday in what the police described as a vicious, terrible murder.

title: Forged Transcript Puts Focus on College Recruiting Abuses
description: They are known as the Spook, the Frog, the Eccentric Millionaire, Big Bob, the Garf, Uncle Harry, the Waiter and Big Walter. They are selfproclaimed college recruiters, who usually do not work for one college, but peddle their talents' and those of the outstanding players the uncover.

title: CON ED REVENUES SHOW 17.2% RISE
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday an increase of $188.9million in revenues for the first nine months.

title: Mitchell Trial Put Off to Jan. 7 To Resolve Difficulty on Tapes
description: A dispute over White House tape recordings delayed the scheduled trial yesterday of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stars on charges that they obstructed a major investigation and lied about it to a grand jury.

title: Capitulation and Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon's capitulation to the courts today strengthened the suspicions of his critics and opponents. They were convincedor prepared to be convinced  that his purpose in initially refusing to give the Watergate tapes to Federal Judge John J. Sirica was not so much to preserve the confidentiality of Presidential communications as to get rid of Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox.

title: Alignment Of Playoffs Shapes Up
Excerpts From News Conference by Richardson and Exchange of Letters Between Nixon and Richardson
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a conference held in Washington yesterday by former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson, as recorded by The New York Times, and the texts of letters exchanged last week by President Nixon and Mr. Richardson:

title: DE CARLO BURIAL HELD IN MORNING
description: EAST HANOVER, N. J., Oct. 23 (AP)The burial of a reputed Mafia leader. Angelo DeCarlo, scheduled for this afternoon, was held this morning instead because the family just didn't want any more publicity.

title: Jets' Defense Is Working Well, But Stronger Attack Is Needed
description: The New York Jets found a home yesterday  Shea Stadium. In their first appearance there this season, the team engaged in a mild workupasweat practice in preparation for Sunday's home opener against the Denver Broncos.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In 1803, in Marbury v. Madison, Chief Justice Marshall reminded the nation: The Government of the United States has been emphatically termed a government of laws, and not Of men. President Nixon's recent actions challenge that basic axiom.

title: Head of House Judiciary Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23With his wavy Silver hair and dark pinstriped suits, he looks the very model of a Congressman, pure Washington, but his voice is the voice of the streets, tough and raspy, pure Newark. These are the two worlds of Peter Wallace Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, which has jurisdiction over the two most compelling issues confronting official Washington: exploration of possible impeachment proceedings against President Nixon, and investigation of the fitness of Mr. Nixon's nominee for Vice President, Gerald R. Ford.

title: China Trip Is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, did not reach agreement in Moscow on much more than was included in the Middle East ceasefire resolution adopted by the Security Council yesterday morning.

title: TELEGRAMS POUR INTO WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23More than 150,000 telegrams, the heaviest concentrated volume on record, according to a Western Union official, have swamped the company since President Nixon's ouster of Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Treasury to Begin Study Of the Securities Markets
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Treasury Department announced plans today to develop a group of Administration positionswhich may or may not be the same as those taken by the Securities and Exchange Coinmissionon the regulation of the securities markets.

title: Brewery Workers Merger With Teamsters Is Backed
description: Karl E. Feller, president of the United Brewery Workers, and Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, signed papers yesterday in Washington to merge the two unions.

title: UNION AIDE IS GIVEN 3 YEARS FOR BRIBES
description: Kenneth Fundus, former business manager of a motion picture theatrical union local here, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to three years, in prison for receiving bribes involving the sale of union membership cards.

title: The 9 Conversations Sought by Cox
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Following are the nine tape recorded conversations which former special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, requested of J. Fred Buzhardt, Presidential counsel dealing with Watergate, on July 23, and which Mr. Cox said had been carefully selected as those which other evidence in our possession identifies as most material to the investigation, to wit:

title: Private Nixon Fund Is Linked to Rebozo, TV Network Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Archibald Cox, the former special Watergate prosecutor uncovered evidence during his last week in office of a private investment fund administered on behalf of President Nixon by his closest friend, Charles G. Rebozo, according to A.B.C. News.

title: Kidnapped Spanish Eagle To Be Flown Back Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (UPI)A rare Spanish imperial eagle, mysteriously kidnapped from a bird preserve in Spain, will be returned to its home.

title: Alignment Of Playoffs Shapes Up
description: With the halfway mark of the National Football League season due this weekend, it is not difficult to pick the eight teams that can expect to qualify for the playoffs. However, each has its problems or sensitive areas and nothing is ever certain in the N.F.L. Why do teams play ineptly one Sunday and up to their potential the next Sunday? Your guess is as good as mine. said Mike Reid, the erudite Cincinnati tackle. Here is a midstream status report.

title: Saigon Reports Bombarding Hostile Artillery to Its North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (AP)  Government planes and heavy artillery pounded positions from which North Vietnamese and Vietcong gunners were suspected of having lobbed shells into a division base camp at Lai Khe, 25 miles north of the capital, killing five civilians.

title: Books of The Times
description: THEOPHILUS NORTH. By Thornton Wilder. 374 pages. Harper & Row. $7.95.

title: Muscular Dystrophy Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will help open the nationwide fall fundraising campaign of the Muscular Dystrophy Association at a White House meeting tomorrow with this year's poster child, Michael Shane Newsome, 6 years odl, of Louisville, Ky., and Dr. Michael DeBakey of Texas, the heart surgeon.

title: HOUSE UNIT SEEKS AID FOR VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The House is working on a bill to increase G.I. Bill benefits 13.6 per cents an amount the Veteran Administration says is unnecessary despite two studies contending that current payments are inadequate.

title: CHESIMARD CASE GETS A JURY SHIFT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 23Superior Court Judge Leon Gerofsky granted a defense motion today for jury selection outside of Middlesex County in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Squire, and ordered the process moved to Morris County.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Ken Patton, head of the Economic Development Administration, says he has been offered the job of president of the New York Board of Real Estate and has asked the city's Board of Ethics to rule on whether his acceptance would create a conflict of interest.

title: Mr. Nixon Retreats
description: President Nixon has capitulated to the explosion public and Congressional outrage over his effort evade Federal court orders to turn over to United States District Judge John J. Silica the subpoenaed taped conversations touching on the Watergate affair. In announcing the dramatic reversal, Presidential lawyer Charles Alan Wright left no room for doubt that Mr. Nixon's move was in response to the refusal of the American people to allow the President to continue place himself above and beyond the rule of law.

title: Oil Shortage May Raise Electric Bills Here
description: New Yorkers may be faced with a $100million rate increase for electrical service during the next year, the, city and the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday, because of spiraling. Costs and diminishing sources for oil stemming largely from embargoes in the Middle East.

title: 11 COMPOSERS OFFER NEW CHAMBER WORKS
description: With 11 composers, 17 performers and 15 first New York performances, one might have expected a fair range of quality In a program of new chamber music on Monday night at Carhegie Recital Hall. But although the concert did avoid my dogmatic commitment to my particular style, it failed to turn up much interesting music.

title: Airline to Cut Flights
description: DENVER, Oct. 23 (UPI)Frontier Airlines said today that reduced supplies of jet fuel would force it to cut back on scheduled passenger flights to smaller communities in the 16 states that it services. The limited cutback in some flying is necessary to comply with the Federal mandatory fuel allocation program effective Nov. 1, limiting all airlines to the same fuel supply received in the corresponding months of 1972, said Frontier's president, A. L. Feldman.

title: Leafs Rally For 22 Tie With Stars
description: TORONTO, Oct. 23 (UPI)Bob Neely scored with 3 minutes 25 seconds to play tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 22 tie with the Minnesota North Stars.

title: PLUMBERS' INQUIRY URGED BY ELLSBERG
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 Dr. Daniel J. Ellsberg has called for an investigation into the possibility that the White House plumbers engineered the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: PATROLMAN KILLS THIEF IN JAMAICA
description: A Transit Authority patrolman shot and killed an unidentified man in a subway station in Jamaica, Queens last night, minutes after the man had allegedly robbed a neighborhood medical center, the police reported.

title: Dr. Abraham W. Schenker, Rehabilitation Specialist, 78
description: Dr. Abraham W. Schenker, a physician who had been active in rehabilitation therapy for the Veterans Administration died, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, at Roosevelt Hospital on Oct. 12. He was 78 years old and lived at 303 East 66th Street.

title: Music
description: The American Symphony Orchestra, which went into drydock for one season after its founder, Leopold Stokowski, moved to England, came sailing back into action with all flags flying on Monday night. The orchestra, now managed by its members, began its season at Carnegie Hall with an entirely successful concert under its new music director, Kazuyoshi Akiyama.

title: 3 Win Nobel physics Prize And 2 the Chemistry Award
