description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 23Two scientists with leading American companies and a Briton won the 1973 Nobel Physics Prize today for theories that have advanced and expanded the world of miniature electronics.

title: Indiana Group Called Sale in Brazil Plane Crash
description: RIO de JANEIRO, Oct 23 (AP)A Brazilian airliner, with passengers including the Lieutenant Governor of Indiana and 11 other members of a state trade mission, crashed into Guanabara Bay here today and sank. The cause of the accident was not immediately known.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1973

title: NIXON VETOES BILL FOR U.S.I.A. FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon vetoed today a bill authorizing funds for the United States Information Agency because it contained a provision requiring the agency to turn over any confidential information Congress demanded.

title: Political Spotlight Shines On India's Biggest State
description: LUCKNOW, India, Oct. 18 At midafternoon along Mahatma Gandhi Road, the youthful peddlers are busily selling, holiday balloons and toys. Women are surging around stalls to buy new shoes for children and bargain over the price of cloth for saris. And men are sitting in the Kwality Restaurant and a halfdozen coffee houses to whisper about Kamalapati Tripathi and Chiran Singh and C. B. Gupta and, of course, Indira Gandhi.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Psychiatrists Find Boyle Competent to Stand Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) W. A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers, was declared today mentally competent to stand trial on charges, that he had conspired to murder his union rival Joseph A. Yablonski.

title: Harvard Will Segment Managing of Portfolio
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)Harvard University announced today that it would split its $1.5billion endowment, largest of any university's into several parts managed separately.

title: 2D TRUCE OF WEEK
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Oct. 24Israel announced early to day that she and Egypt had agreed on a new ceasefire to go into effect at 7 A.M. (1 A.M. Wednesday, New York time).

title: Mr. Nixon's Deceptive Compromise
description: The one thing you have to say for Richard Nixon is that he knows when he is, licked. Almost everything he always said he would never docompremise with Moscow, recognize Peking, accept deficit financing, or be unfaithful to his promiseshe has dome. And he has done it again by releasing the Watergate tapes, which he said he would never release.

title: Gift of Land Expensive
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 23 (AP)Back in the 1960's, Emil Muller, a land developer, gave three acres to the suburban community of Penfield as the site for a recreation center. The town never built the center, so Mr. Muller recently offered $125,000 for the parcel, and town officials agreed to accept it.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Recover From Early Lows
description: Corporate bond prices were down in early trading yesterday but recovered from their lows before the close in quiet trading.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Kentucky Utilities Company said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 695,649 common shares. The company's common closed at 23 down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Suburban Bachelors Bask in New Respectability
description: RYE, N. Y.The middleaged bachelor was indulging in a bloody mary and a little fantasy in a hotel dining room here the other day.

title: Nixon Speaks at 9 P.M.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon, facing what he perceived as a grave national crisis of confidence, decided today in very painful and anguished discussions with his staff to abandon his strongly held opinion against turning the Watergate tapes over to the courts, his assistants said.

title: China Trip is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, did not reach agreement in Moscow on much more than was included in the Middle East ceasefire resolution adopted by the Security Council yesterday morning.

title: College for Prisoners Due in '74
description: The establishment of a new state college at which all of the students will be prison inmates is expected to be approved this morning by the trustees of the State University of New York.

title: Harry Karafin, ExReporter Jailed for Extortion, Dies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (AP)Harry J. Karafin, a former reporter for. The Philadelphia Inquirer who was serving a prison term for blackmail and extortion, was found dead today in the hospital section of ??raterford prison. He was 57 years old and had been treated or cancer.

title: Excerpts From a Federal Court Hearing on the Tapes and Text of a Statement by Silica to 2 Grand Juries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Following are excerpts from the official transcript of a hearing today in United States District Court, where Chief Judge John J. Sirica read porLions of a ruling in the Watergate tapes case by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and Charles Alan Wright announced that President Nixon would comply with the ruling, and the text of a statement read by Judge Sirica to the two Federal grand juries empaneled to investigate Watergate and other case:

title: Rockwell International Set to Acquire Admiral
description: The Rockwell International Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Admiral Corporation, manufacturer of television receivers and other consumer appliances.

title: About New York
description: There was nothing to distinguish Umberto's Clam House from any other place where a gunman might have killed Joey Gallo except that it was having trouble getting its liquor license, President Nixon's picture hung by the front door, and it was on Mulberry Street.

title: Security Council to Send Observers to Suez Front
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23The Security Council, trying to shore up the imperiled cease fire in the Middle East, adopted a resolution tonight confirming its previous call for a ceasefire, and Syria informed the Secretary General that it would abide by the ceasefire.

title: Oil Shortage May Raise Electric Bills Here
description: New Yorkers may be faced with a $100million rate increase for electrical service during the next year, the city and the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday, because of spiraling costs and diminishing sources for oil stemming largely from embargoes in the Middle East.

title: Ford, U.A.W. Resume Talks
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23 (Reuters) Bargainers for the Ford Motor Company and the United Auto Workers went back to the negotiating table today in an effort to beat a Friday strike deadline for 185,900 workers.

title: AluminumSuited Men Fined For Obstructing Traffic
description: JONESBORO, Ark., Oct. 23 (AP)Two men accused of impersonating visitors from outer space have been fined $25 each plus $24.80 in court costs on charges of malicious mischief.

title: Trouble Far From Over
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23President Nixon's decision today to release White House tape recordings has failed to halt House plans for an inquiry into his possible impeachment.

title: Misappropriation of Funds Laid by Penn Life to Equity
description: SANTA NIONICA, Calif., Oct. 23 (UPI)The Pennsylvania Life Corporation says the Equity Funding Corporation of America may have misappropriated a $3.7million payment in 1972.

title: BLOOMFIELD GETS P.U.C. ASSURANCES
description: BLOOMFIELD, Oct. 23Angry residents of this suburban community received written assurance today from an official of the State Public Utilities Commission that tracks would be inspected for safety before service on the ErieLackawanna Railway was resumed.

title: M.I.T. Fills Physics Post
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., OOct. 23 (AP)  Dr. Francis E. Low has been appointed head of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Center for Theoretical Physics. Dr. Low, Compton professor of physics at the institute succeeds Dr. Herman Feshbach, who has become head of the school's Department of Physics.

title: Futures of Wheat Climb Daily Limit
description: Rumors that the Australian wheat crop could have been hurt a little by too much rain spurred a rise in wheat Futures prices in Chicago yesterday.

title: GULF OIL'S PROFIT UP 90% IN QUARTER
description: Sharply higher earnings were announced yesterday by a number of major oil companies. All sectors of the industry did well but the large international companies led the parade.

title: Technology to Soviet
description: The Control Data Corporation and the Soviet Union signed a 10year agreement yesterday to cooperate in the development of advanced computer technology. The accord is the first with a major computer manufacturer as well as the first such longterm pact with a United States company. Page 63.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Engineers Start Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (UPI)  The Consulting Engineers Council of Maryland started its own investigation yesterday into kickbacks by members to elected officials as a means of obtaining Government contracts. A sevenmember conmittee was appointed to review the situation and make recommendations after reviewing court proceedings and a statement of evidence against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: U.S. Shooters Victors
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (Reuters)The United States won three team gold medals in the PanAmerican shooting championships here today. Tommy. Pool, Robert Mitchell, David Kimes and David Boyd won the English match with 2,367 points. Boyd won the individual title with 595 points.

title: Avis Officer Tells of Free Cars for Mackell Aide
description: An executive of the Avis Rent  a  Car System testified yesterday that he had provided free cars to Joseph N. Monty while he was chief rackets investigator for former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens.

title: Syria Accepts Truce Bid, Waldheim Tells Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23The Security Council, trying to shore up the imperiled ceasefire in the Middle East, adopted a resolution tonight confirming its previous call for a ceasefire, and Syria informed the Secretary General that it would abide by the ceasefire.

title: Brasco Has Liberal Reputation
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco, the Brooklyn Democrat who was indicted yesterday in an alleged bribery conspiracy, has a reputation as a vigorous liberal Congressman but also as a man who has been helpful 10 individuals allegedly linked with organized crime.

title: AUTONOMY ASKED IN SCHOOL VOTING
description: Isaiah E. Robinson, chairman of the Board of Education's decentralization committee, yesterday urged a complete separation of the administration of community school board elections and that of general political elections.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Work Begun on Queens Subway Extension
description: A giant yellow bulldozer on wheels, with Mayor Lindsay and Dr. William J. Ronan aboard, scooped up a big chunk of pavement from a Jamaica parking lot yesterday to signal the start of a major phase of the new southeastern Queens subway line.

title: The Theater: An AvantGarde Japanese Musical
Belgian Premier Shuffles Cabinet in Coalition Rifts
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 23 (UPI)Premier Edmond Leburton shuffled his ninemonthold coalition cabinet today, cutting it from 36 to 28 members.

title: Trouble Far From Over
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon's decision today to release White House tape recordings has failed to halt House plans for an inquiry into his possible impeachment.

title: Pecuniary Recompense
description: This letter was written by George Washington, before he became President, to His Excellency, Patrick Henry Esgr., Governor.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Suit Is Filed Against a Town In Connecticut on Beach Curbs
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 23  The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union announced today that it had filed suit in Superior Court here charging the town of Fairfield with illegally restricting the use of its town beaches by nonresidents.

title: Honochick Plans Retiring as Umpire
description: ALLENTOWN Pa., Oct. 28 (UPI)  Jim Honochick, an American League umpire for 25 years, said today he was considering retirement.

title: Methadone Programs Decried By Drug Addicts at Hearing
description: Many methadone treatment programs for drug addicts here have become mere dispensaries that do little or nothing to help addicts rehabilitate their lives, a special City Council committee was told yesterday by addicts and other witnesses.

title: Cays, Paced: By Wilkens, Win First
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (UPI) Lenny Wilkens tossed in 30 points and Bobby Smith added 24 tonight to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 10396 National Basketball Association victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Pablo Casals
description: In his incredibly long and productive life, Pablo Casals stood for many things. He was more than a musician.

title: ABRUPT REVERSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 President Nixon, in a stunning reversal, abruptly agreed today to turn over the Watergate tape recordings to Federal District Judge John J. Sirica.

title: Brasco Case Follows Indictment of Podell
description: Yesterday's indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco was the second time this year in which a Federal crime was charged to a Brooklyn Congressman.

title: Scarcity Alters DrugTrade Patterns
Of Men and the Foreign Policy
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The professional discussion of foreign policy is unique among the great social disciplines in that good tailoring combined with a certain assurance of manner is extensively a substitute for thought. For this reason, one can, with a sense of novelty, still make a commonplace point. It is this: While, as commonly imagined, men do have a certain influence on the foreign policy  on those dealings in and with other countries that affect national and general wellbeing  policy has an even more profound effect in selecting the people who guide it. This circumstance, I shall argue, does much to specify the kind of policy that we can pursue. There are policies which require a class, of talent which we cannot wisely risk or afford. These are matters which even a brief glance at recent history affirms.

title: U.S. WEIGHING USE OF EARTH'S HEAT
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 23The Government moved a step closer today to largescale development in the western United States of geothermal energy, the earth's heat.

title: Canada Firm on Energy In Talks With U.S. Aides
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 23John A. Love, the director of President Nixon's Energy Policy Office, came to Canada today in his continuing search for oil and natural gas to, meet shortages in the United, States.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ANIMAL TYPES There's a rhinoceros, a jabberwock, a gryphon, an ostrich, several dragons, a basilisk (they say it's also a cockatrice, if that's a help), all under glass in the main lobbythat's the one at the top of the highrise steps on Fifth Avenueof the New York Public Library at 42d Street. They're all in books on display under the title, Curious Creatures: An Alphabetical Bestiary.

title: One Land Without Inflation
description: SHANGHAIExactly halt a century ago history's most disastrous inflation wiped out the German economy. In October 1923 one U. S. penny could purchase 6,250,000 paper marks. Now most nations are again frightened by an uncontrollable leap in prices. Prof. John Vaizey writes in International Currency Review: The current inflation is steadily accelerating toward the takeoff point of hyperinflation.

title: Richardson Sidesteps Constitutional Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Elliot L. Richardson said today that when he took himself out of the game last weekend he had not really left the Nixon team.

title: COMPUTER ACCORD SIGNED BY SOVIET
description: The Control Data Corporation and the Soviet Government announced yesterday that they had signed a 10year agreement to cooperate in the joint developmen of advanced computer technology and related services.

title: NIXON AND PANEL RESUME DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The compromise between President Nixon and the Senate Watergaie committee over the White House tape recordings fell apart today.

title: Mining Agreement Reached
description: The Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company reported yesterday it has reached an agreement with The titles Service Company to develop and mine an area owned by Cities Service that is adjacent to Inspiration's Joe Bush and Pinto claims at Inspiration, Ariz. The copper ore will be treated at Inspiration's plants and paid for on a royalty basis.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Records: Gilels's Masculine Poetry
description: Emil Gilels, the distinguished Russian pianist, does not play very often in the United States. But he remains a master, and two new tworecord sets have arrived to reaffirm that mastery: The playing is full of that masculine poetry for which he has always been admired, strong yet poetic, traditional yet full of individual personality.

title: Rockefeller Center to Pay Columbia U. More in Rent
description: Rockefeller Center will pay Columbia University $9million in annual rent, with graduated increases to $13million, for about three square blocks in the heart of the center under the terms of a renegotiated lease.

title: 1973 Nobel Science Laureates
description: Ernst Otto Fischer

title: ISRAELIS TIGHTEN GRIP WEST OF SUEZ
description: WITH ISRAELI FORCES IN EGYPT, Oct. 23Israel tightened her grip on a large enclave of captured Egyptian territory west of the Suez Canal today, pouring in supplies and fresh troops to make her bridgehead secure against military threat.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION HIGHEST SINCE JUNE
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 20 rose to 2,915,000 tons, the highest level since the June 16 week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain, of 1.1 per cent over the previous week, when 2,882,000 tons were poured. The production index climbed to 119.5 from 118.1 a week earlier.

title: Supreme Court Again Divides 5 to 4 Appeals on Prohibition of Obscenity
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Supreme Court divided sharply again today over the issue of defining and prohibiting obscenity, with a narrow 5to4 majority continuing to make local community standards determine whether a crime has been committed.

title: Listless Knicks Battered By Bullets Here, 10184
description: The Knicks, who scored 69 points in their previous game, scored 84 last night.

title: Losses by Israelis A Third of Arabs', The Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Defense Department estimated today that Arab losses, both in men and equipment, ran about three times those of the Israeli forces in the 17 days of fighting up to the declaration of a ceasefire.

title: Syria Announces Acceptance of CeaseFire Plan but Calls for Israeli Withdrawal
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Wednesday, Oct. 24Radio Damascus announced at 6:15 A.M. today that Syria accepted a ceasefire with Israel on the Golan heights front on the condition that Israel withdraw from all Arab territory occupied in the 1967 Middle East war.

title: Moscow Accuses Israel
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23The Soviet Union accused Israel tonight of renewing Middle East hostilities in violation of the United Nations ceasefire resolution and warned of the gravest consequences if fighting persisted.

title: HENRIETTA MOORE
description: Mrs. James R. Larkin, who as Henrietta Moore was a wellknown television actress, died at FlowerFifth Avenue Hospital on Monday after surgery. She was 50 years old and lived at 325 Central Park West.

title: POLICY DEFENDED BY INDIAN BUREAU
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Oct. 23Officials of the Bureau of Indian Affairs told the United States Commission on Civil Rights here today that they had neither time nor manpower enough to enforce Federal nondiscrimination clauses in some $60million worth of yearly contracts the bureau signs to run the Navajo Indian reservation.

title: TV Review
description: Kojak, a new weekly series scheduled to enter the Columbia. Broadcasting System line  up tonight at 10, is a spinoff from The MarcusNelson Murders, a twohour drama presented on the netweek last season, Perhaps, judging from the first episode, the better word would be ripoff.

title: BYRNE ENDORSED BY TENANTS' BODY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23  Brendan T. Byrne proposed today la program to guarantee fairness to tenants and landlords through guidelines for local rent ordinances, model leases and other tenantlandlord arrangements. He said the legislative and executive branches should take the initiative in providing the program.

title: Accused Slayer of Mobster Enters Manslaughter Plea
description: A man accused of murder last April 6 of Bruno Carnivale, a reputed mobster, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to a lesser, charge of manslaughter in the second degree.

title: LABOR DELEGATES ARE NOT SATISFIED
description: BALHARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 23  Delegates to the A.F.L.C.I.O convention here, who voted yesterday to ask President Nixon to resign, were startled but not satisfied today when they learned that the President had decided to surrender the Watergate tape recordings to a Federal judge.

title: Brasco and Uncle Indicted in Alleged Bribe Plot
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn was indicted, yesterday on charges of conspiring to receive $27,500 in illegal payoffs in 1968 from a Bronx trucking concern headed by an alleged Mafia member.

title: People in Sports: Cubs' Jenkins in Texas Livery?
description: Ferguson Jenkins of the Chicago Cups is likely to be wearing a new uniform next seasonthat of the Texas Rangers. Dariny O'Briena, general manager of the Rangers, said yesterday his club, was trying to obtain the 6foot5inch righthanded pitcher. Jenkins was a 20game winner for six seasons in a row, startingin 1967, but last year Slipped to a 1416 wonlost record, with an earnedrun average of 3.88. The Rangers finished the recent campaign with the Worst record in the major leagues. Interleague trading doesn't officially start until Friday.

title: Moscow Accuses Israel
description: MOSCOW, Oct, 23The Soviet Union accused Israel tonight of renewing Middle East hostilities in violation of the United Nations ceasefire resolution and warned of the gravest consequences if fighting persisted.

title: COURT GUARDIANS HONORED BY CITY
description: The parents of a 15yearold truant introduced him carefully to a court worker assigned to his case, hoping he would make a favorable impression on her.

title: THEODORE SHAPIRO
description: Theodore Shapiro, a cofounder of the Dutch Masters Paint and Varnish Company of Brooklyn in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday at his home, 35 East 35th Street. He was 87 years old.

title: Sandman Says His Loss Would Be G.O.P.'s Fault
description: MILBURN, Oct. 23Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican gubernatorial candidate, has told Republican leaders that they will have only themselves to blame if they lose the election Nov. 6.

title: 2d Newark. Fire in 2 Days. Injures 2 Fighting Blaze
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23  Fire raced through a threestory frame dwelling at 49 Astor Street this morning, injuring two firemen and destroying the interior of the building. It was the second fire in the city's industrial section in two days.

title: Notes on People
description: In 1968, President Tito of Yugoslavia was one of the harshest critics in the Communist world of the Sovietbloc occupation of Czechoslovakia, and ideological and other differences between the Yugoslays and the Czechoslovaks remain. But Yugoslavia is intent on increasing trade and engaging in cooperative economic ventures with Czechoslovakia, and so yesterday President Tito genially welcomed to Belgrade Gustav Husak, who rose to leadership of the party in Czechoslovakia as a result of the invasion of 1968 and the subsequent ouster of Alexander Dubcek, a Communist reformer.

title: Ohio Court Rules Candidate Who Quit Must Be Replaced
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (AP) Judge George McMonagle ruled today in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court that candidate must be selected to succeed James Carney on the Cleveland mayoral ballot for the Nov. 6 election.

title: Byrne for New Jersey
description: For any New Jersey resident with even a casual concern about the staggering problems that beset his state, the obvious choice for Governor is Brendan T. Byrne.

title: USE OF HOME FUEL IN TRUCKS SCORED
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 (AP)The use of home, heating oil in dieselpowered vehicles as a tax dodge is costing the Federal Government and the states millions of dollars in revenue a year, the authorities here say.

title: 2 OUSTED IN PARIS ON RADIOTV ISSUE
description: PARIS, Oct., 23A major struggle over political control of France's state  owned television and radio monopoly led today to the dismissal of both antagonists.

title: Burial of De Carlo Is Held in Morning To Avoid Publicity
description: EAST HANOVER, Oct. 23 (AP)  The burial of a re puled Mafia leader, Angelo DeCarlo, scheduled for this afternoon, was held this morning instead because the family, just didn't want any more publicity.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 23If this year's woman's swimming team at Princeton improves on last year's thirdplace finish in the intercollegiate nationals, it may be largely because of the efforts of Cathy Corcione, a senior majoring in art history who has retired three times from competition.

title: GOVERNOR FAVORS MORE AID TO ARTS
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the state would have to appropriate a much larger subsidy for the arts next year because of increasing deficits being suffered by arts organizations.

title: CITY'S BEEF BUYING AUGURS PRICE RISE
description: New York City's, municipall food purchases showed beef prices rising 1.8 per cent for, delivery in the first two weeks of November, but poultry dropping 10 per cent, in bids accepted yesterday.

title: COX IS CHEERFUL IN FAREWELL TALK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Archibald Cox bade farewell to his staff today. Dismissed by the President Saturday in an action that stirred a nationwide outcry, the former special, Watergate prosecutor had no words of bitterness or revenge.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Town Supervisor Jerome A. Ambro of Huntington, L.I., ordered yesterday that a patrol be mounted weekday afternoons and all day on weekends and holidays along the twoandahalfmile border of the town dump in East Northport, where two 13yearold boys died Monday in the collapse of a mountain of sand.

title: Complex Legal Issues Involved in the Dispute Over Tapes Are Only Partly Resolved
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The past week's climactic events in the custody battle over secret White House tape recordings may have averted dangerous constitutional deadlock between President Nixon and the Supreme Court, but they resolved only some of the complex and controversial legal issues involved.

title: TV New Permissiveness in PrimeTime Fare
description: In any discussion of permissiveness on television, the favorite catchword of defenders is contemporary. Second in popularity is mature. Both words carry legitimate weight, but neither can obscure the fact that TV, as the most massive of mass mediums, is confronted with some very serious problems.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The attempt last week by the community school board in District 1 to suspend Luis Fuentes is the latest development in a chain of events that began even before the controversial 44yearold Puerto Rican educator became superintendent of the longtroubled Lower East Side district.

title: PRESIDENT TALKS TO PRESS TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24President Nixon, in another, sudden turn in the Watergate crisis, canceled his scheduled television address to the nation tonight and planned instead a news conference at 9 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Cut in U.S. Oil. Supply Is Estimated at 10%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Administration officials estimated today that the United States might lose nearly 10 per cent of its oil supplies as a result of production cutbacks and embargoes in the Middle East.

title: U. S. Rejects Egypt's Call for American Troops to Help Police Mideast Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The United States said today that the ceasefire in the Middle East was beginning to take effect and rejected Egypt's call for Soviet and American troops to help police the truce.

title: THAI PANEL IS NAMED TO DRAW UP CHARTER
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 24 (AP)Premier Sanya Dharmasakti appointed an 18man committee today to draft a new constitution that is expected to be announced within six months.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Regulating the Snowmobile
description: It has long been clear that snowmobilesat last count there were two million of them in North Americaare here to stay. The problem then is how to regulate their use so that they will do a minimum of harm to the natural environment and its denizens, including man.

title: HurryUp Card Speeds Citibank Check Cashing
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it has developed a new hurryup check cashing card that permits depositors to cash personal checks quickly up to the full amount of their balances at any branch.

title: Queens Youth Seized in Murder of Grocer's Wife
description: A 17yearold Queens youth was arrested yesterday in connection with the murder of the wife of a Bronx grocery store owner last month, the police reported. And in a coincidental development, the grocer also made a Criminal Court appearance in connection with a separate gun charge.

title: Flying Tiger Sets 74 Budget
description: The Flying Tiger Corporation announced a 1974 capital budg et of $145million for its leasing subsidiaries, the North American Car Corporation and National Equipment Rental, Ltd.

title: Faith in the Truth
description: As the nation faces further crises in law and constitutional government, it may be helpful to examine one just Past.

title: Haig's Oration
description: Haig: Friends, liberals, civilians, lend me your ears;

title: Permanent Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTOA halfcentury ago, Owen J. Roberts was appointedSpecial Prosecutor to investigate the Teapot Dome scandals, which had reached President Harding's Attorney General and other top members of his Administration. His appointment restored public confidence that those who had violated the public trust, whatever their rank, would be prosecuted. Public confidence was not misplaced.

title: Rutgers' Star Rushes To Credit Men Up Front
description: Rutgers' fine tailback, J.J. Jennings, says that he won't trade his offensive line for any other in the country about as often as his coach, Frank Burns, says, I wouldn't trade J. J. for any other running back in the country. Jennings, who leads the nation in rushing with 156.6 yards a lame, admits that he might be a few yards short of that figure without the help of the eight players who share the six important blocking spots.

title: Geothermal Survey Set
description: DENVER, Oct. 24 (UPI)The PetroLewis Corporation has agreed to spend $500,000 to explore 20,000 acres in Colorado for natural steam for the Public Service Company of Colorado The utility plans to build geothermal electric plant if natural steam is found in sufficient quantity. It said the existence of the suspected geothermal energy reservoir had not yet been established.

title: BEATRICE FOODS SETS ACQUISITION
description: The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Londontown Manufacturing Company, a producer of rainwear and outerwear.

title: PRESIDENT TALKS TO PRESS TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24President Nixon, in another sudden turn in the Watergate crisis, canceled his scheduled television address to the nation tonight and planned instead a news conference at 9 P.M. tomorrow.

title: MAJOR NATIONS OPEN TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 24The most ambitious negotiations yet undertaken for freeing the flow of, world commerce were launched here today under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: Chelsea Rag Dealers
description: CHELSEA, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP)The Board of Aldermen of Chelsea, ravaged by a $100million fire on Oct. 14, has voted to oppose relocation of junk and rag dealers, from the burned area into other parts of the city.

title: Psychiatrist Offers Police Aid
description: They might have been adulteducation students, the 60 or so men listening to a lecture here on criminal psycholdgy in an overheated hall, except for the revolvers jutting from the hips. They were homicide detectives enrolled in a twoweek course to improve their skills at solving murders.

title: Wounded Knee Plot Denied
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 24 (AP)Tonia Ackerman, under indictment in the Wounded Knee incident in South Dakota, pleaded not guilty today at her arraignment in United States District Court here.

title: She's Very Big on Chihuahuas
description: Eight years ago, Mrs. George Varga bought a Chihuahua as a pet. But she would have nothing to do with me, said the blonde housewife the other day. She idolized my husband, George. Since I still wanted a pet, we bred her. She had two male pups. Knowing little about the breed, Mrs. Varga buoght a book on the subject That's where I learned there was such a thing as a dog show, she recalled. So I attended a couple of local ones and then decided I'd show the pups.

title: Man Found Guilty In a Bank Robbery Is Free for 5 Years
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 24 (UPI)Joseph Erhart of Buffalo has had a prison sentence hanging over his head for five years.

title: TAPES REVIVING CAMPUS PROTEST
description: The dismissal of Archibald Cox and the dispute over the White House Watergate tapes has sparked a number of hastily organized protest actions on campuses across the country, just as observers and commentators had begun to declare that campus activism was dead.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Three of the four major candidates for Mayor, facing what is widely regarded as a commanding lead by the fourth, Controller Abraham D. Beame, and fighting for public attention that has been focused on Washington and the Middle East, tried to reach out yesterday with a joint news conference.

title: EDWARD A. WALSH OF FORDHAM DIES
description: Edward A. Walsh, Patterson Professor of Journalism Emeritus at Fordham University, died in Fordham Hospital yesterday after having apparently suffered a heart attack at his home, 2836 Marion Avenue, the Bronx. He was 73 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1973

title: MiniMet, 2 Seasons Old, Silenced by Lack of Funds
description: In another economy move, the Metropolitan Opera has suspended performances of its MiniMet this season. The program, originated last season, produces seldomheard chamber operas for a small hall.Then Met announced earlier that its serious financial difficulties had forced it to cancel a new production of Mozart's Don Giovanni, scheduled for the coming spring, as well as next summer's series of free concert performances of opera in the city parks.

title: Private TwoYear Colleges Get Bundy Aid From State
description: ALBANY, Oct. 24 (UPI) The first Bundy aid to private twoyear colleges was announced today by gate Education commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist.

title: Planner of Aswan City Helping Town in Westchester Prepare for Triple Growth
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Oct. 24One of the huge maps displayed last night in the Hiram Halle Library, where 60 Pound Ridge townspeople had gathered to hear a new concept in town planning, looked like an invasion chart.

title: 2 Bounty Descendants Die
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 24Two descendants of the 18thcentury mutineers of H.M.S. Bounty died within the last two reeks, according to a shortwave radio report received here from Pitcairn Island in the Pacific, where they lived. Mi Bette Christian, who was 76 years old, died Oct. 16, and Theodore Young, 85, died Oct. 2. Their deaths reduced the population of Pitcairn Island to 69 persons.

title: Chess:
description: Emanuel Lasker, world champion for a recordsetting 27 years, from 1894 to 1921, believed so strongly in the virtue of spontaneity and freshness over the board that he exempted himself from the neverending search for the latest opening innovations. He viewed these as fads, impotent to curtail his creatively rugged middlegame play, and his remarkable achievements justified his selfconfidence.

title: SANDMAN BITTER OVER LAG IN FUNDS
description: CEDAR GROVE, Oct 24An angry and bitter Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. told Republican audiences today that his gubernatorial campaign was in trouble for lack of funds and he urged a people's crusade to turn the tide by Election Day.

title: SONGS BY WOMEN AT THEATER CLUB
description: The fact that Circle of Sound, an evening of songs F'mposed and performed by omen at the Manhattan Theter Club, 321 West 73d Street, provided an opportunity for Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford to emerge from their customary backstage roles as writer and composer is ample justification for what otherwise is a production that might give Bobby Riggs considerable pleasure.

title: 9 KILLED, 40 HURT IN CRASHES IN FOG ON PIKE IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24At least nine persons were killed and more than 40 injured in a series of collisions that sent 65 vehicles crashing and careening into each other in a heavy fog that swathed a large stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike late last night and early this morning.

title: Hugh B. Cox, Lawyer, 68, Dies; ExAssistant Solicitor General
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Hugh B. Cox, former Assistant Solicitor General, died of cancer at his home in Alexandria, Va., on Saturday. He was 68 years old.

title: East of the Jordan, Yawns and Work

title: Faith Baldwin's 80 BookFilled Years

Faith Baldwin, the doyenne of American light fiction writers, celebrated her 80th birthday Oct. 1, her literary and personal pace only slightly slowed from what it was some 30 years ago. Not only has she just published at least her 80th romantic novel (it may actually be the 85th or 90th, she's lost count), but also she is preparing for a holiday in Cape Cod and renewed writing.

Firestone said that this could result in some of the tires becoming overheated, which could result in premature failure and in extreme cases rapid loss of air.

title: The Future of Elliot Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Aside from everything else, a man said at, lnch.here today, Elliot Richardson looks like Clark Kent. You expect him to pop into a telephone booth any minute, and come out in his Superman suit.

title: P. & G.'s Profits Declined 6% in Quarter

It was the big soap and detergent producer's first quarterly profit slide in 17 years resulting from Lifo accounting system, rising costs and freeze on prices, as outlined at the annual shareholders meeting Oct. 9.

title: Indian Moslems, Bitter, Hold Balance in a Key Election

title: The Theater: Children of the Wind, a Dated Period Piece
description: Jerry Devine's play Children of the Wind, which opened at the Belasco Theater last night, is set in the nineteen  thirties. For that matter it could very well have been written in the thirties. This does not mean that it is not a wellmeaning at times even worthy play, decently constructed and crafted. But it does mean that it suffers from a dangerous lack of energy. It seems a secondhand play that tries to live the past rather than recreit.

description: The Police Department enlisted the aid of 200 clergymen from black and Hispanic areas yesterday to help recruit members of minority groups for the department.

description: Two former plainclothes police officers who had pleaded guilty to assaulting a Bronx man while on duty were sentenced yesterday to a minimum of one year in prison. The sentence, imposed on William F. Itelly and Brendan Conway by State Supreme Court Justice Donald. Sullivan in the Bronx, is not to exceed seven years.

title: Brooklyn Man Dies in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 24 (AP)The United States military command has today announced the names of four crewmen who died Monday in the crash of an Air Force helicopter near Osan Air Base, 30 miles south of Seoul. One of the four was S. Sgt. Gerardo Sorrentino Jr., 31 years old, of Brooklyn.

Longenecker of Tulane University and will serve for one year. The association is composed of 46 universities across the country with major graduate and professional schools.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Operators of a Brooklyn methadonemaintenance clinic that had come under fire from Flatbusharea residents who charged that they had been terrorized by drug addicts said yesterday they would move from the area. The announcement was made several hours before the operators were to show cause in State Supreme Court why they should not be forced to move. The clinic, FlatbushBrooklyn Medical Associates, 125 East 18th Street, will move to Pacific Street and Flatbush Avenue. The clinic treats an estimated total of 500 addicts.

title: Design Competition Opens For Coins to Appear in '76

description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 24 (AP)  Mrs. I. Wayne Rutter of Williamsville, N.Y., the firstround leader, posted an eightoverpar 80 today, but remained in front by a stroke after the second round of tlie NorthSouth women's senior golf championship.

title: John D. Ratcliff, Writer, Dies; Did 200 Reader's Digest Pieces
description: John D. Ratcliff, a prolific writer on science and medicine who contributed more than 200 articles to Reader's Digest (more than any other writer), died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Drake Hotel. He was 70 years old.

title: L.S.U. Student Is Suicide
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 24 (UPI)While deputies tried to restrain him, Frank Mistretta, a 24yearold Louisiana State University student, killed himself yesterday by beating his head against the steel wall of a jail isolation cell, the East Baton Rouge Parish authorities said. He hadbeen put in the cell in an attempt to restrain him after he ran from the office of Dr. Hypolite Landry, the parish coroner, The youth's parents had taken him to talk to Dr. Landry because they said he had seemed disturbed.

title: HIRING PRACTICES OF G. S. A. SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Civil Service Commission charged yesterday that officials of the General Services Administration had been hiring personnel improperly because of political connections rather than job qualifications.

title: 9 KILLED, 40 HURT IN CRASHES IN FOG ON PIKE IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24At least nine persons were killed and more than 40 injured in a series of collisions that sent 65 vehicles crashing and careening into each other in a heavy fog that swathed a large stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike late last night and early this morning.

title: UpjohnPlans Asian Plant
description: The Upjohnn Company announced plans here yesterday to build a plant in Japan to make isocyanate chemicals. Isocyanates are raw materials in the production of urethanes. Cost of the project, which will be carried out by KaseiUpjohn, a joint venture, was not disclosed.

title: Screen: Voight in 'All-American Boy':The Cast
description: Since old-style alienation is having a comeback, perhaps we'll soon get crinolines and quiz-show scandals as well. But the brand of mossy disaffection evoked in "The All-American Boy," which opened last night at the Baronet, has nothing to do with politics or generations or rebellion. Instead, it belongs to the old I-can't-connect school. We've seen that so often on the screen that the theme needs a fresh twistwhich it doesn't get in this movie.Jon Voight is cast as a weary, resentful mid-American who hates his small hometown and doesn't want to commit himself to anything or anyone. However, in spite of himself, he succeeds as a fledgling boxer and is promised a great careeruntil he suddenly refuses to participate in the next big fight.He throws everything awayhis fiance as well as his future in boxing. But we never learn why. This picture flaunts such a stubborn disregard for characterization and motive that it could almost be billed as a mystery. For example, Voight is immediately established as a depressive. But there's no clue to whatever it is that keeps him staring broodily into space, rejecting intimacy or even contact with those around him. Charles Eastman, who wrote and directed the movie, absolutely refuses to explain what's biting his hero.The film is especially frustrating because Voight is such an intelligent actor. Remembering the variety that he brought to his previous roles, we can sympathize with the dilemmas he must have had in working with dialogue like this: "What you thinkin'?" "I ain't thinkin' nothin'." "People are always thinkin' somethin'." And when one of his girlfriends says that he smells like a cantaloupe, it's merciful that we don't have to see his face in close-up.But even in this picture, there are moments when Mr. Voight's quality comes through. He's very good at watching and listening, a skill that eludes many actors. He's also strong in showing his disgust at being treated like a slab of sirloin, when his boxer's body is displayed and examined by others.Mr. Eastman also did Mr. Voight a particular disservice by having someone say in an early scene that he looks like Marlon Brando. Throughout, you suspect that the actor was resisting the director's efforts to make him imitate Brando. True, Mr. Voight's gloomy, downward gaze sometimes suggests a slight similarity, and this is certainly an inarticulate part. But Mr. Voight, who hasn't yet played the same role twice, doesn't deserve to be shoved toward someone else's style of performing.

description: MIDLAND, Tex., Oct. 24 (UPI)The Dowdle Oil Corpothreewell drilling program on a 160acre lease in Okmmulgee County, Okla. A second well will be drilled in Ofkuskie County and the third in Osage County All will seek to tap oil at depths of 3,000 to 4,000 feet in the Dutcher, Cromwell and Wilcox sands.

title: Books of The Times
description: BURR. By Gore Vidat 430 rapes. Random House. $8.95.How diabolically welltimed is the appearance of Gore Vidal's latest novel, Burr: just at this most disillusioning moment in American history, when all the old verities are beginning to seem hollow, Mr. Vidal gives us an interpretation of our early history that says in effect that all the old verities were never much to begin with. And Mitt a tour de force is the result!. How close Mr. Vidal has managed to stick to the actual historical record only two of his characters are invented (one is Charles Schuyler, a Jaw clerk and aspiring journalist who is the primary narrator of Burr, and whom Mr. Vidal identifies in his. Afterword as based roughly, or the obscure novelist Charles Burdett; the other is one William de la Touche Clancey, a Tory sodomite with a tongue that darts in and out of his mouth like a lizard's catching flies, who, Mr. Vidal assures us, could, obviously, be based on no one at all); as for the actual historical figures who appear in the novelonly in three minor cases are they not in the right places, on the right dates, doing what they actually did; and their conversations, though partly made up, always reflect the recorded views of the speakers. Yet for all this documentary authenticity, how alive and immediate everything seems!

title: Hockey Tonight
Suspension for Turcotte? Stewards to Rule Today

Speak Action, with Ron Turcotte aboard, was placed second by the stewards after she finished first in the first section of the $23,450 Rare Treat Stakes. Ordinarily, such a development opment would be only of passing interest for most fans by the day's end. But Turcotte is scheduled to ride Secretariat on Sunday in that Triple Crown champion's final career appearance and the Canadianborn jockey may be prevented from so doing.

title: The Screen:' Massacre in Rome' Is World War II Story
description: Stars are generally an asset to a film. But in the case of "Massacre in Rome," which opened yesterday at the National, Murray Hill and 86th Street East Theaters, they constitute its chief flaw.That is not to say that Marcello Mastroianni, as a principal priest and art restorer, and Richard Burton, as a German colonel in Rome as the Allies close in during World War II, give inept performances.It is simply that their presence at the moral summit of this film unbalances its recounting of a controversial and bloody fragment of history that began with the destruction by partisans of a German SS detachment on the Via Rasella and ended with a reprisal that took more than 300 Italian lives.The conflicts at the film's heart, the questions of where duty lies, of when the rules of war insult the souls of men beyond endurance, of when self-sacrifice becomes the ineluctable argument, become subsumed rather than illuminated by the interplay between two of the screen's more commanding presences.And when they are not at the center of events, Leo McKern, as General Maelzer, Burton's superior, is so busy chewing scenery in a performance that seems to call for a leash if not a muzzle, that it becomes impossible to take matters seriously.Directed by George Pan Cosmatos, "Massacre in Rome" is an opulent Carlo Ponti production with a warm eye for the spaciousness and beauty of the city's interiors and the panoply of its priesthood. The music, by Ennio Morricone, possesses all the subtlety of an elbow in the ribs.In the end, for all its apparent concern for life and death, "Massacre in Rome" turns out to be a curiously bloodless film, a monument not to its victims but to its stars.

title: SHOP TALK

title: The Aluminum Industry Is Said To Suffer From Price Controls
description: The head of the aluminum industry's trade association said here yesterday that price controls were blocking a proper return on the enormous invested capital of our industry.

title: Increase Tops '72 Level by $1Million
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24  The Ford Motor Company announced today a thirdquarter profit of $95million, only $1million above the $94million in the same period a year ago.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)  A spokesman for one of the Nation's biggest grain concerns urged Congress today to create a new, wellfinanced independent regulatory agency to stiffen Government supervision over trading commodity futures.

title: Saints Bow To Blades Here, 5 to 2
description: The New York Golden Blades, playing their best hockey of the young season, easily defeated the Minnesoto Fighting Saints, 52, at Madison Square Garden last night in the World Hockey Association, having allowed only 11 goals in five previous contests.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLOSE UP They are putting up bleachers on the stage at Hunter College Playhouse, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues (535.5350), and you will not be allowed to sit in any of the Playhouse's regular seats. Not only will the 200 bleacher seats cut off the usual audience area, but also they are expected to multiply the intime ambiance of a new series of early evening 6 P.M. Thursday concerts given by the Performers Committee for 20th Century Music.

title: Industry Regrets Timing As Oil Earnings Climb
description: While cannons roar in the Middle East and energy shortages loom in consuming nations around the world, the oil industry is announcing some of the biggest profit increases in its history.

title: She's Very Big on Chihuahuas
description: Eight years ago, Mrs. George Varga bought a Chihuahua as a pet. But she would have nothing to do with me, said the blonde housewife the other day. She idolized my husband, George. Since I still wanted a pet, we bred her. She had two male pups, Knowing little about the breed, Mrs. Varga buoght a book on the subject That's where I learned there was such a thing as a dog show, she recalled. So I attended a couple of local oars and then decided I'd show the pups.

title: Air Pollution Curbs Industries In Birmingham and Pittsburgh
description: Air pollution, at its worst in at least two years, forced factories to shut down some operations in the industrial cities of Birmingham, Ala., and Pittsburgh yesterday.

title: Celebrities Showed Up With Pens In Hand
description: Celebrities are recognized by their famous faces and not, as a rule, by their feet.

title: SMITH QUITS POST IN WESTGATE DEAL
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 24C. Arnholt Smith agreed late today to surrender active control of the Westgate  California Corporation, the keystone of the financier's business empire, in order to escape trial on multimilliondollar fraud charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 24 (AP)The Government has again authorized meat exports to the United States, effective Oct. 29.

title: PRICES ARE HIGHER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday in what some analysts said they believed was relief over the apparent settlement of the Watergatetapes controversy. However, trading declined.

title: ENROLLMENT UP AT U.S. COLLEGES
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 24College enrollment is up about 2.5 per cent from last year, it was reported today by Dr. Garland G. Parker, a national authority on college enrollments.

title: Concert Honors Casals
description: Tonight's Music from Marlboro concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be dedicated to the memory of Pablo Casals. The cellist and conductor, who died Monday at the age of 96, had been active in the Marlboro Music Festival for 13 summers.

title: MRS. ETHEL PRITCHARD
description: GALESBURG, Ill., Oct. 24 (UPI)  Mrs. Ethel Custer Pritchard, publisher of The Galesburg RegisterMail and president of the Galesburg Woadcasting Company, died today in a hospital here. She was 77 years old.

title: Beyond the Tapes
description: With his lastminute decision to obey a Federal court order to surrender the White House tapes, President Nixon has escaped the contempt citation that continued. defiance would have rendered all but inevitable. A nation appalled by the prospect of a President in contempt of court is understandably relieved. But the fundamental nature of the governmental crisis has not been changed, much less resolved, by the President's action.

title: The Quiet Revolution
description: After relatively easy passage by the Senate, a bill that would encourage states to plan sensibly the uses of their still empty lands has fallen on difficulties in the House of Representatives. Members of that chamber, particularly those on the committee that is now trying to frame a companion measure to the Senate bill, are being subjected to a flood of mail denouncing the legislation in highly emotional terms.

title: Bar Group Here Favors New Special Prosecutor.
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York said yesterday that the dismissal of the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, was the latest step in a disgraceful and cynical game plan and called upon Congress to pass legislation allowing the courts to appoint a new special prosecutor.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the Rutgers University president, announced yesterday that the university had received $27,751,646, a record, in gifts, bequests, grants and contracts during the 1972.73 fiscal year. This compared with $19,120,945 in 197172, he said.

title: COAST TRIAL SEEKS PRESIDENTIAL TAPES
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) Prosecution and defense attorneys says that it should be possible now to obtain any Presidential tapes relevant to the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: North Vietnam Said to Add 70,000 Men to Its Forces in the South
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 American intelligence officials report that North Vietnam has moved more than 70,000 fighting men, 400 tanks and more than 200 artillery pieces into South Vietnam since the ceasefire nine months ago.

title: Rescuers Free 2 Trapped In Gold Mine by Landslide
description: DOWNIEVILLE, Calif., Oct. 24 (UPI)Rescue workers dug tons of dirt and mud away from the entrance to an old gold mine late last night to free two men who had been trapped 33 hours by a landslide.

title: In Sea of Contradictions, The Old and New Egypts
description: ZAGAZIG, Egypt, Oct. 23Driving through the Egyptian countryside today, a correspondent could glimpse some of the contradictions that make the Egyptian scene so hard for a foreigner to understand.

title: Test of Faith
description: Shortly after the United Nations Security Council issued its second call in less than 48 hours for a ceasefire in the Middle East, the Egyptian Foreign Minister declared that observance of the new order would serve as a test of faith. Within hours, heavy fighting had broken out anew on the Suez front.

title: StormSewer Bill Backed At a City Council Hearing

The measure is aimed at reducing street flooding, mainly in stilltobedeveloped areas in Queens and on Staten Island.

title: Honduras Devaluation Set

The new par value of the lempira is 0.368331 grams of fine gold, or 84.4444 lempiras per troy ounce of fine gold. The previous par value was 0.409256 gram.

title: Screen:' Jonathan,' Rare Gull, Makes Unusual Film The Program
description: This "Jonathan Livingston Seagull," reportedly quite a book, is quite a bird in a beautiful and touching movie that falls short only toward the end when it perches instead of soaring.How does one film a slim, cult-adored bestseller about an altruistic, rebel gull who sails and philosophizes through the seasons in search of self-fulfillment? Well, one starts with some perfectly magnificent photography by Jack Couffer.This camera work is so stunning that it immediately establishes a sensitive texture for a simply story of a roaming nonconformist with wings and a human voice. Intelligently and tastefully, the director-producer, Hall Bartlett, and the author, Richard Baoh, have integrated the bird's musings with arresting passages of silence and a surprisingly effective score sung by Neil Diamond, who composed it with Lee Holdridge.To one viewer, who loved the first half, the only catch is the final footage, when our feathered hero comes home to convert his old flock with some gummy platitudes. This portion is a bit pat and even synthetic, for all the clever photographic simulations of massed bird chatter and anger. This aspect of the movie, its technical manipulation, is at times remarkable.The picture also runs far too long. But the over-all flavor and impact remain striking, purposeful, sweet and at times heart-clutching. Jonathan, at least his human spokesman, generally says a mouthful. The comments are hardly new and too often humorless; nevertheless they fitted perfectly into this pictorial transformation from the printed page. Word and image made a combination that held this viewer.Maureen, another gull, tells Jonathan, "you really are an exceptional flier." Amen, J. L.

title: Herman Is Reclaiming Starting Role on Jets
