description: The New York Public Library has received the largest individual bequest in a decade, and one of the largest of the century, from the estate of a spinster who lived plainly in a basement apartment at 28 East 10th Street.

title: Queens Hospital to Be Nursing Home
description: The Veterans Administration is preparing plans to take over the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens and use the main building as a nursinghome daycare facilityspokesman for veterans groups said yesterday.

title: TV to Focus on Giants and Jets Sunday
description: The local fan has a right to feel frustrated about the fare in front of him for profootball Sunday. The Jets open their home season at Shea Stadium as underdogs to the Denver Broncos while the Giants are slight favorites in St. Louis. None of the four teams has a winning record. Channel 4 will televise the first game at 1 P.M., and Channel 2 the second at 2 P.M. The national network game, CincinnatiPittsburgh, will not he televised here. A preview of all games follows with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: Earnings Climb Sharply At Texaco and Atlantic
description: Texaco, Inc., and the Atlantic Richfield. Company announced yesterday that earnings for the third quarter and first nine months of 1973 continued the trend of sharp gains for the nation's major oil companies.

title: Dick Was Scrubbing the Porch
description: When Charles O. Finley welshed on Dick Williams, raised a couple of questions for Joe Cronin, probably the last Joe will be asked to resolve before he is catapulted from the exalted rank of president of the American League to the celestial realm of chairman of the board. The questions: How hard does the manager of a baseball team have to resign before he can make it stick? If the manager and his employer speak their parting injunctions on a national television network, does that make it official, or must there he a formal burning of the contract in the public square?

title: 65 in Opposition Drop Out of Portuguese Election Charging Farce
description: LISBON, Oct. 25In defiance of Government warnings, 65 Opposition candidates have withdrawn from the election scheduled next Sunday for a new National Assembly.

title: Lisbon Is Trying 3 Feminist Authors
description: LISBON, Oct. 25  In a small bare courtroom here today, three young Portuguese women went on trial for offending public morals with a book espousing the feminist cause, which is largely unknown in this maledominated society.

title: DON FRANISCO, 82, AD MAN, IS DEAD
description: Don Francisco, who had major careers as a leader in advertising and as a State Department official, died yester day at his home in Amagansett, L. I. He was 82 years old.

title: Waith Views Crime In the Schools Here As Possibly Worse
description: Crime and violence are possibly worse than last year in the city's junior high and elementary schools, but is down in the high schools, Eldridge Waith, chief administrator of the Board of Education's office of school safety told a City Council committee yesterday.

title: From Cuba to Suez . . .
description: By an ironic coincidence, yesterday's SovietAmerican confrontation came eleven years to the week after its classic predecessor, the Cuban missile crisis. The two confrontations differed enormously, but in one essential they were the same: Richard M. Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev yesterday had to contemplate the same kind of nuclear holocaust that John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev recoiled from in 1962.

title: Officials Say Soviet Note and Alerting of Airborne Troops Brought U.S. Response
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 An alert of airborne troops within the Soviet Union combined with a Soviet threat to send forces into the Middle East was cited by military officials today as the reason the United States placed its forces on a worldwide alert.

title: ACTION BY COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25The Security Council voted today to establish a United Nations emergency force to insure a ceasefire in the Middle East, using troops from smaller countries.

title: The 5 Conditions of Defense Readiness
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The precautionary alert that United States military forces found themselves under today is one of five defense readyness conditions.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Mayoral candidates paid, homage to Brooklyn yesterday at when thre of them appeared all the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce where the emphasis was on programs for decentralizing the government away from Manhattan. The fourth candidate sent a representative.

title: About New York
description: Although he may not choose to, Elliot L. Richardson can now attend all the dinner parties he wants to on the East Side of Manhattan. When a man becomes celebrated in Washington the way Mr. Richardson has, he becomes celebrated on the East Side, too, and the former Attorney General is now only a length or two behind Henry Kissinger in the matter of being considered desirable by prominent hostesses.

title: ACTION BY COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25The Security Council voted today to establish a United Nations emergency force to insure a ceasefire in the Middle East, using troops from smaller countries.

title: U.A.W. IS HOPEFUL ON FORD ACCORD
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25Leaders of the United Automobile Workers cautioned their members today to remain on the job as indications arose that negotiators with the Ford Company were close to reaching a new contract agreement before the strike deadline of 10 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Pro TV Blackout Lifted at 6 Sites
description: Six of Sunday's 12 National Football League games, including the clash between two unbeaten teams, the Los Angeles Rams and the Vikings at Minnesota were sold out yesterday, 72 hours before kickoff, and will be televised locally, the league said.

title: Maryland Gets Energy Office
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 25 (UPI)  Gov. Marvin Mandel created today a new state Office of Energy Policy and said he might ask for emergency powers to cope with a desperate fuel shortage this winter. He said the new Cabinetlevel office would implement for Maryland the Federal program for mandatory fuel allocation that goes into effect Nov. 1.

title: Military Installations in Area Are Unusually Active in Alert
description: Military installations in the state and nearby were on precautionary alert yesterday, according, to Defense Department spokesmen, and although officers at the installations would not confirm the alert there were reports of unusual activity at many of them.

title: Spot Finally Found for Van Pelt: He Becomes a Backup Tight End
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 25Brad Van Pelt, the New York Giants No. 2 draft choice who has yet to play in a regularseason game because of a nagging groin injury, came out of today's skull session grinningand with a fistful of new plays.

title: DR. MAURICE DIONNE
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 25Dr. Maurice J. Dionne, chief of staff of the Regional Memorial Hospital, which he helped found here, died last night of a heart attack while playing chess in the community's recreation center. He was 69 years old.

title: Judge Backs Completing T.V.A. Dam
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 A Federal judge ruled today that the Tennessee Valley Authority may resume building the long controversial $69million Tellico Dam project near Knoxville. The ruling is expected to be appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati.

title: Finsterwald Shares Lead On 65 Round
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 25 (AP) Dow Finsterwald, the 1958 Professional Golfers' Association champion but now a parttime tourist, scrambled for a sixunderpar 65 and a share of the fristround lead today in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

title: DECREASE FORECAST FOR PRICE OF BUTTER
description: Some significant reductions in butter prices were forecast for next week for city consumers by the State Department of Agriculture. The prices had reached the highest retail peaks in seven years.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States ordered its military forces on a worldwide precautionary alert because of overnight concern that the Soviet Union was planning to send troops to the Middle East. Before the crisis seemed to ease after Moscow joined in a Security Council resolution barring major powers from a Middle East peacekeeping force, Secretary of State Kissinger said at a news conference that the United States was not seeking a confrontation with he Russians. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, P. 18.]

title: Linus Pauling to Challenge F.D.A.'s Curb on Vitamins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) Dr. Linus Pauling, twice winner of the Nobel Prize, said today he would go to court to try to stop the Food and Drug Administration from imposing its new controls on vitamins.

title: Police Kill Man They Say Tried to Board Subway Free
description: A man allegedly tried to enter an IND subway station at Eighth Avenue, and 116th Street without paying his fare was shot to death by a Transis Authority patrolman last night. The police said the suspect had pulled a gun while being questioned in a washroom in the station.

title: KISSINGER CUT OFF; VIEWERS CHIDE N.B.C.
description: Television viewers complained to the National Broadcasting Company network here yesterday after it ended its coverage of Secretary of State Kissinger's news conference in Washington before its completion.

title: Bronx Subway Crash
description: More than 100 subway riders suffered smoke inhalation and hundreds more were trapped in a smoky tunnel in the South Bronx when an IRT express train struck a train stalled by a fire. Details, Page 14.

title: The Changing Times
description: President Nixon and his chief defense counsel, Charles Alan Wright, have not always displayed a similarity of views on the larger legal questions of the day. For example, each reviewed the book Witness by Whittaker Chambers in The Saturday Review of May 24, 1952. Their opinions were at opposite poles.

title: Stocks Seesaw on News of Mideast
description: The stock market moved yesterday  first down and then up  with the changing situation in the Middle East.

title: ExPoliceman and 18 Indicted on DrugSale Counts
description: Nineteen men in the Bronx and Westchester County, including a former policeman and a sanitationman here, have been indicted on charges of having sold five pounds of cocaine and heroin to undercover policemen, two District Attorneys announced yesterday.

title: Nigeria Breaks Israeli Ties
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 25 (Reuters)Nigeria today became the 17th African country to break off diplomatic relations with Israel in 19 months. A Government statement charged that Israel's crossing to the west bank of the Suez Canal and her actions since the ceasefire order constituted ample evidence of bad faith.

title: San Antonio Papers Sold
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 25 (UPI)  HarteHanks Newspapers, Inc., has completed the sale of its morning and evening newspapers, The San Antonio Express and The Sain Antonio News, to the AustralianBritish group, News America Inc., for $18million, the two companies announced today.

title: On Key
description: The most practical way to end the monthlong silence of the New York Philharmonic is for its striking musicians to join the orchestra management in submitting all unresolved issues to impartial arbitration.

title: African Aides Act To Retrieve Statue
description: Elated that a longsought sacred tribal carving has been found here after it mysteriously vanished six years ago, officials of the Cameroon Embassy in Washington set in motion yesterday diplomatic moves that they hope will result in the statue's return to the western African kingdom of Kom.

title: Where the Food Is Also a Feast for the Eyes
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective Judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly; one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Two Papers Curbing Ads
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (UPI)The Chicago SunTimes and the Chicago Daily News canceled their large classified advertising sections today because of newsprint problems. Despite the settling of Canadian newsprint strikes, our allocations of paper are not expected to return to normal for seveal weeks, The Daily News said in a notice to readers.

title: Rainfall Dims Hopes For Big Wheat Crop
description: CAIRO, Kan., Oct. 22The new winter wheat was poking out of the drying ground in Pratt County this week, as thin and scraggly as whiskers on the cheek of a teenaged boy.

title: Bruins Top Sabres, 94; Esposito: 2
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)Phil Esposito scored two goals tonight, one on a power play and the other on a shorthanded situation, as the Boston Bruins outscored the Buffalo Sabres, 94. Chris Oddleifson, a rookie, also scored two goals.

title: Business Briefs
description: With net income in the third quarter and nine months rising to records for both periods on increases of 9.2 per cent and 12.9 per cent respectively, directors of the Southern Railway yesterday voted to increase the regular quarterly dividend to 48 cents a share on the common stock from the 43 cents paid previously.

title: JeanPhilippe Carson Dead; Cinematographer Was 49
description: JeanPhilippe Carson, a cinematographer and executive of the Camera Company, was killed on Sunday, when a truck toppled on to his parked car at Culican in the Mexican state of Sinaloa. He was 49 years old.

title: U.P.I. Names 2 to Posts As Metropolitan Editors
description: The appointment of Eugene S. Haggerty as metropolitan region news editor and Allan R. Bruce as New York City editor for United Press International was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Cunningham, regional manager.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: EGYPT SAYS ISRAEL CONTINUES FIRING
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25Egypt accused Israel today of continuing to violate the ceasefire agreement and said Israeli troops had fired on Egyptian forces wherever they were found.

title: Water Pipeline Is Started To Fight Fire in Meadows
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Oct. 25 National Guard troops, forest rangers and prison inmates began laying a water pipeline today in an effort to inundate a massive subterranean fire in the Hackensack Meadowlands giving off heavy, acrid smoke. The smoke contributed to the zero visibility that caused the macabre traffic accidents along the New Jersey Turnpike early yesterday.

title: Broncos' Revived Offense Hurt by Defensive Lapses
description: Charley Johnson, the Denver Broncos' quarterback who will be facing the Jets Sunday, has a Ph.D. in chemical engineering. It's a wonder he and his offensive mates haven't needed an M.D. to treat their severe case of frustration.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Persistency Is Rewarded
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.Persistence, although it lacks glamour, often wins the prize, whether it be a fair lady's hand, or, in Freeman Willoughby's case, a big fish.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has blocked the construction of a 1,000unit residential and retail complex just south of the United Nations, which had been approved by the state. The utility has decided to build a substation on a vacant block that it had leased to Sylvan Lawrence, a major builder, who had planned a multiuse tower that would have incorporated the substation in its base with bridges across Tudor City Place and First Aventie and a halfacre park. City Officials expressed frus tration with the utility's decision for the site, which they consider one, of the most important and valuable in the city.

title: 5 Indicted in Smuggling Of TaxFree Cigarettes
description: A cigarette smuggling ring that allegedly cheated the city and New York State out of $3million in tax revenues last year was reported smashed yesterday with the indictment of five reputed organizedcrime figures.

title: PRIMERATE CUT EXPECTED TODAY
description: The demand to borrow money lessened more noticeably during the week ended Wednesday, making it all but certain that the First National City Bank today would lower its base interest rate on corporate loans to 9 per centthe second reduction in a week.

title: SUBWAY MISHAPS STILL A PROBLEM
description: Subway safety has become matter of increasing concern recently, but the Transit Authority maintains that incidents such as last night's subway accident in the Bronx represent a statistical rarity in a 237mile subway network that carries 3.8 million passengers on an average workday.

title: Across U.S., People Tell Why They Back Nixon or Oppose Him
description: From the 5:02 commuter train to Stamford, Noroton Heights and Darien, Conn., to the Admiral Kidd Club in San Diego, President Nixon still has his supporters.

title: Bridge: North American Playoffs Begin in Milwaukee Toinght
description: Playoff matches to determine the 1974 North American world championship team begin tonight in Milwaukee and will end Tuesday night. In one of the semifinals, the Spingold champions are likely to have the best of matters against the Florida sextet that won the Grand National title. In the other match, the Aces, who won the Vanderbilt title and are strengthened by a famous Canadian pair, are strongly favored against a young group that won the Reisinger championship.

title: Smoke Fells 150 on IRT In Crash in South Bronx
description: More than 150 subway riders suffered smoke inhalation and other minor injuries and hundreds more were trapped in a dark smoky tunnel in the South Bronx for an hour or more last night after an IRT express train struck the rear of anOther that had been stalled by a fire.

title: Barclays Seeking to Buy First Westchester Bank
description: Barclays Bank, the big British bank that was turned down in May in its bid to take over the Long Island Trust Company, now aims to acquire the First Westchester National Bank, $206million bank with headquarters in New Rochelle,

title: Candidates' Day
description: Mayoral candidates paid homage to Brooklyn yesterday with a joint appearance at the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce where the emphasis was on programs for decentralizing the government away from Manhattan.

title: U.S. Oil Company Executive Kidnapped in Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 251 (Reuters)The president of the Argentine subsidiary of Standard Oil of Indiana has been kidnapped in Buenos Aires, police sources said here tonight.

title: Booklet Discloses How Jews Fought Against the Nazis
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25The American Jewish Committee released today a detailed document delineating the actions of Jewish men, women and children against the Nazi war machine.

title: Chicken Cooked With Orange
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Priest From Saranac Lake Knifed in Monticello Alley
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Oct. 25 (UPI)A Catholic priest from Saranac Lake was stabbed in an alley off the business district here early today and was placed in the intensive care unit at Community General Hospital.

title: Moscow Exhibits Tension, But No Intent to Intervene
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25The Soviet Union showed new signs of tension with the United States today, but gave no public indication that it was preparing to intervene in the Middle East. The Soviet

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two men were charged with arson yesterday morning while town firemen put out several fires set in the rear of the First Memorial Presbyterian Church in Dover.

title: Dance
description: As Time Goes By is the name of the song Sam plays again for Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman is Casablanca, and nowjust coincidentally  it is the title of a truly avantgarde and witty new ballet by Twyla Tharp.

title: Trapped Egyptian Force Held Key Factor in Crisis
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 25  The Egyptian III Corps, estimated to number 15,000 to 30,000 men, remained trapped by the Israelis today, unable to acquire fresh supplies of water and food.

title: FRANK A. STROM
description: PROVIDENCE, Rd., Oct. 25Frank A. Strom, board chairman of the Old Stone Bank in this city until March 30, died today at the Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital.

title: BILL BANNING LEAD IN PAINT IS PASSED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) A bill prohibiting the use of leadbased paint in federally financed homes, on toys and on other items won final Congressional approval yesterday and went to President Nixon.

title: F.B.I. Gives $1,000 and Apology to Student Over Release of File
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 25The Federal Bureau of Investigation agreed out of court today to apologize and pay $1,000 to a former. University of Oregon student president whose F.B.I. file was given to a radio station news director.

title: Record Auction Price Paid for U.S. Painting
description: What was called the highest auction price ever paid for an American painting was paid last night by an unidentified collector from Long Island who bid $260,000 for Eastman Johnson's Washington Crossing the Delaware.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHINA HANDS The trip to China has become something of a graduate degree for New Yorkers and others in any specialty field, and there has been a reasonably heavy traffic in visitors bound from Kennedy for Canton. It is only reasonable that many of them have been women and that some of the women are going to share their experiences under the auspices of the PanPacific and SouthEast Asia Women's Association, a halfcenturyold group whose New York area chapter has headquarters in the Barbizon, 140 East 63d Street (7510889). It's a nongovernmental organization with consultative status at the United Nations.

title: 3 Share Golf Lead With 65's
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 25 (AP)  Dow Finsterwald, the 1958 Professional Golfers' Association champion but now a parttime tourist, scrambled for a sixunderpar 65 and a share of the firstround lead today in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

title: TRAMUNTI GUILTY OF PERJURY HERE
description: Carmine Tramunti, the reputed head of a Mafia crime family here, was convicted yesterday of perjury for his testimony as a defendant in a 1971 stockfraud trial.

title: 2 Boys Held in Police Death
description: HORNELL, N.Y., Oct. 25 (UPI)Two 15yearold boys were picked up by authorities on charges they struck and killed Daniel Swift, a 25yearold Hornell policeman, last night with a car they were trying to steal.

title: AirConditioner Maker Agrees to Tone Down Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The first settlement of a case arising from the Federal Trade Commission's advertising substantiation program was announced today by the commission.

title: MRS. TOBIN T. CARLIN
description: WINNETKA, Ill., Oct. 25 Mrs. Mary Elaine Mertz Carlin, wife of Tobin T. Carlin, president of American Breeding Herds, Inc., died Sunday at the age of 58.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL FOR MEDICAL CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  A $185million emergency medicalcare bill, stripped of a Public Health Service hospital provision that had helped prompt a Presidential veto, was passed by the House today.

title: Advise and Reject
description: History is open to interpretation, but Elliot Richardson appears to be the first Cabinet officer since Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan in the first Wilson Administration to have resigned on a matter of principle. Ironically enough, Mr. Richardson might well have been, instead, the first Cabinet nominee since Lewis Strauss in 1958 to have been refused confirmation by the Senate.

title: U.S. Says Mafia Informer Gave Evidence Against Rep. Brasco
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco on Tuesday came as a result of information given to the Justice Department by John A. Masiello, a Mafia captain wild was involved in the cage, according to Federal sources.

title: This Potential Voter Is a FourLegged Type
description: NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 (AP)The Republican committee of North Haven, in an attempt to flush out more potential voters, recently mailed reminders of failure to register to many residents, including Jason Brock of Ridge Road.

title: Toward a New Beginning
description: WASHINGTONIf Lord Macaulay had been in Washington during the last week he would never have written that Your Constitution is all sail and no anchor. The Constitution not only demonstrated its holding power, but also its capacity to inspire men and women in high places and humble places to rush forward and tend the anchor chains.

title: Pop Music: Yoko Ono's Contradictions
description: Let us start with the premise that Yoko Ono, who opened a stay Tuesday night at Kenny's Castaways, 84th Street off Third Avenue, and will continue there through Sunday, is a simply terrible pop music performer. She can't sing, her tunes are tuneless, and her lyrics are clumsy. (Her Plastic Ono Super Band does have its virtues, especially when it is on its own.)

title: Public Service Plans to Change Some Generators Back to Coal
description: NEWARK, Oct. 25 (AP)The Public Service Electric & Gas Company, the largest utility in New Jersey, today announced that it was preparing to convert some of its generating units to coal to enable it to cope with a potential fueloil shortage this winter.

title: People and Business
description: Cyrus S. Eaton, the 89yearold financier, is not going to conduct a proxy contest so he can personally name a chairman of Chessie System, Inc., after all.

title: POWERS ADDRESSES PRINTERS AT NEWS
description: Bertram A. Powers, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, called a halt to work in the composing room of The Daily News for 20 minutes yesterday afternoon to report on contract bargaining difficulties.

title: Music: Thomas Conductsand Chats
description: Michael Tilson Thomas, the talking conductor, gave a Spectrum Concert on Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall. With the willing members of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra at his disposal, Mr. Thomas animadverted on the theme of sound stretching. He spoke. He had the orchestra illustrate passages from the music. He sang a bit and he danced a bit. All this in the cozy, confidential, mantoman sincerity  la the young Leonard Bernstein. And jokes. And Yiddishisms. And cuteseyness. After a while one could scream.

title: BANGOR PUNTA SIGNS STOCKSALE ACCORD
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed a purchase agreement with BP Associates, a partnership sponsored by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., under which the partnership had agreed to buy 1.2million shares of a new class of 50cent Bangor Punta convertible preference stock for $12million in cash.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: CLERICS QUESTION FITNESS OF NIXON
description: Five American religious leaders haveissued statements criticizing President Nixon's actions in the Watergate case in the lase week.

title: AMEX SHARES OFF AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange opened lower, then rallied on news that the Soviet Union would accept a ceasefire peacekeeping team in the Middle East that would exclude the United States, the Russians and other bigpower nations, but dropped again at the close. Prices in the counter market, however, closed higher.

title: A MIXED PATTERN SHOW IN PROFITS
KISSINGER SPEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct 26The United States orderd its military forces on a world wide precautionary alert early yesterday morning, citing concern that the Soviet Uniot was planning to introduce military forces into the Middle East But the crisis seemed to abat?? when the Soviet Union joined later in a United Nations Security Council resolution bar ring big powers from partici pating in a Middle East peace keeping force.

title: CIVIL SERVICE UNION BACKS TRANSIT BOND
description: ALBANY, Oct. 25Leaders of a labor union and an industrial trade group, undecided earlier about a stand on Governor Rockefeller's proposed $3.5billion transportation bond issue, today decided to support the plan.

title: Text of U. N. Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25Following is the resolution adopted by the Security Council today:

title: State Examining Its Role in Wake of Obscenity Rule
description: The New York State Legislature, which is considering amendments to the state's obscenity laws in the wake of last June's United States Supreme Court ruling changing the criteria for obscenity determinations, opened the first of a series of joint hearings on the subject yesterday. It heard testimony from more than a dozen witnesses representing authors, publishers, booksellers, libraries, religious groups and civilliberties organizations.

title: Burglar Alarm Bill Signed
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday signed into law a bill that requires that any motor vehicle equipped with a burglar alarm prominently display the number of the owner's local police precinct station house when the vehicle is parked on a highway or public parking lot, The station house will maintain uptodate information that will percommunication with the owner of the vehicle if the alarm is activated.

title: 4 Living on Houseboat Accused in Looting of Yachts
description: Four persons who lived on a makeshift 35foot houseboat at City Island were arrested yesterday and charged with looting pleasure boats of equipment and furnishings.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 2.7 From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 191.1 from 193.8 last week.

title: Padres Get McCovey
description: Willie McCovey, the National League's Most Valuable Player in 1969, and Ferguson Jenkins, the league's Cy Young Award winner in 1971, were the key figures in two threeman trades yesterday.

title: Whalers Trounce Blades, 83
description: The New England Whalers outplayed the New York Golden Blades last night and posted an 83 victory before 3,721 fans in a World Hockey association game.

title: LUNG CANCER TEST TO BE EVALUATED
description: The National Cancer Institute is sponsoring a multimilliondollar study to see if the current dismal survival rate among victims of lung cancer can be improved through screening techniques that may detect the disease in its early stages.

title: Tigers Release Howard
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25 (UPI)Frank Howard, one of the highest priced designated hitters in baseball, was given his unconditional release today by the Detroit Tigers. The 37  year  old Howard, whose 382 home runs make him 17th on the career list, had declined a job as a minor league manager in the Tigers' farm system.

title: European Colt Sold In $2.5Million Deal
description: LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP)Rheingold, Europe's record moneywinning horse, has been sold for $2.5million. Rheingold will go to stud in Ireland.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Oct. 25 were:

title: Callas Returns at Concert in Hamburg
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Oct. 25 (Reuters)A nervous Maria Callas was given an enthusiastic welcome when she returned to the stage here tonight in her first major concert in eight years.

title: KISSINGER SPEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The United States ordered its military forces on a worldwide precautionary alert early this morning, citing overnight concern that the Soviet Union was planning to introduce military forces into the Middle East. But the crisis seemed to abate when the Soviet Union joined later in a United Nations Security Council resolution barring big powers from participating in a Middle East peacekepeing force.

title: Major Political Controversy Set Off in Israel Over Government's War
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 25A major political controversy has erupted here over Israel's state of readiness just before the Middie East war began and the Government's decision to accept a ceasefire last Monday.

title: Charles Hay, Oilman, 71, Headed Hockey Canada
description: TORONTO, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press)Charles C. Hay, the first president of Hockey. Canada and retired president of Gulf Oil Canada, Ltd., died yesterday after a short illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Industrial Nations Put Off Crisis Action
description: PARIS, Oct. 25  Officials from the leading industrial nations exchanged oil supply and price information today and agreed there was as yet no need for joint action to deal with the threats of a world energy crisis caused by the Middle East conflict.

title: Appeal Is Made to Forestall Layoffs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Commerce Secretary Frederick B. Dent issued an urgent appeal to business today to conserve energy so that oil shortages do not cause factory shutdowns and layoffs of workers.

title: Notes on People
description: Women's liberationists, who have been campaigning for the removal of the submissive obey from the marriage vow in the Church of England prayer book, were given a royal backofthehand yesterday by Princess Anne.

title: EGYPT SAYS ISRAEL CONTINUES FIRING
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25Egypt accused Israel today of continuing to violate the ceasefire agreement and said Israeli troops had fired on Egyptian forces wherever they were found.

title: ABEBE BIKILA, 46, TRACK STAR, DIES
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 25, (AP)  Abebe Bikila, the Ethiopian who was the only man ever to win two Olympic marathons, died today, apparently of a brain hemorrhage, in an army hospital here. He was 46 years old.

title: 5 MEN ARE INDICTED IN $1.5MILLION FRAUD
description: NEWARK, Oct. 25A Federal grand jury today indicted five men, including two alleged organizedcrime figures, on charges of bilking thousands of small investors in a $1.5million stockfraud conspiracy.

title: JOHN R. THOMPSON
description: John R. Thompson, assistant to the president of Philip Morrit International and its director of public relations, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in HastingsonHudson, N. Y.

title: U.S. Board Will Hold an Inquiry on Turnpike Collisions
description: The National Transportation Safety Board announced yesterday that it would investigate the macabre series of chain collisions on the fogshrouded New Jersey Turnpike Wednesday that left nine persons dead and more than 40 injured.

title: CONFIDENT BEAME FORMS A JOB PANEL

description: For Frank Navarro, Columbia's football coach, this season has been more agony than ecstasy. The Lions began matters by playing Bucknell to a scoreless tie, then beat Princeton.

title: Rites for Krupa on Monday

title: NixonKissinger Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The NixonKissinger policy of negotiation instead of confrontation seemed to be still working to day  against considerable odds.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 200,000 common shares of the Missouri Public Service Company at $14.625 per share was made yesterday by Merrill Lynch. The company's common closed unchanged Itt 14 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bonn Bids U. S. Halt Arms to Israel Via Germany
description: BONN, Oct. 25 (Reuters)West Germany has told the United States to halt all arms shipments to Israel from West German territory, a Foreign Ministry statement said today.

title: Corporate Role on Energy Urged
description: The head of the Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation called on the aluminum industry yesterday to support al Manhattantype Project to solve the nation's energy crisis.

title: Opal V. Boynton, 72, Dead; A Social Work Educator
description: Opal V. Boynton, social work educator, who retired in 1967 as a consultant in group work administration and supervision for the Young Women's Christian Association and settlement houses in the United States and Canada, died Wednesday in Toronto, where she lived; Her age was 72.

title: City Cancels $2Million JobAid Contract
description: The city's Human Resources Administration yesterday canceled a $2million contract with a Queens company to run an antipoverty program to train truck drivers after a report found that the program was poorly managed, had no accountability, used shoddy equipment, cost the city extra money and did not lead to good jobs.

title: Watchdog Weighed As Westgate's Chief
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 25  Speculation centered today on a San Diego civic leader, Herbert Kunzel, as the probable new chairman of the WestgateCalifornia Corporation, succeeding C. Arnholt Smith, deposed head of the $190million conglomerate he created 13 years ago.

title: Film: 'Black Hand Side':Stage's Brooks Family Arrives on Screen The Cast
description: "Five on the Black Hand Side," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and 86th Street Twin theaters, is amiable but realistic in attempting only to solve a few problems for a middle-class black family. But by tickling the funny bone, Charlie L. Russell's adaptation of his Off Broadway play is a good deal more effective than most of the militant and violent so-called black films that are getting redundant.In effect, the comedy is essentially the same as that staged by the American Place Theater in January of 1970, which delved into the harried home life of a barber who rules his wife, two sons and daughter as autocratically as Nero. His wife, of course, is more obedient servant than mate, and the communication between father and his grown, rebellious children is virtually nonexistent.Naturally, this domestic despotism is disrupted when the barber's meek but loving spouse, now at the end of her patience and faced with anxieties about her daughter's imminent marriage, revolts in comic women's lib style by demanding and getting her long-deferred rights.Mr. Russell's script may be a basically lightweight affair, but he writes with an affection and keen perception that make his people and the issues, couched either in jive talk or straight dialogue, three dimensional and pertinent. Credit for the giggles and truths is also due Oscar Williams, who directed with professional feeling for pace and comedy.But "Five on the Black Hand Side" also rests on its varied principals and the rich incidents that make its slight theme real and enjoyable.Leonard Jackson is properly outraged, pompous and funny as the barber who makes life with father a trial. Clarice Taylor, who is repeating her stage role as his wife, gives the once-timorous and now defiant Mrs. Brooks the finely underplayed indecision and dignity the part demands. She is entirely, convincing when she wryly observes that the family loves her husband "but can't live with him."Glynn Turman, D'Urville Martin and Bonnie Banfield are comically persuasive, as the embattled offspring. And a large cast, including Virginia Capers and Ja'Net Dubois, as helpful neighbors; as well as Sonny Jim and Carl Mikal Franklin and even Godfrey Cambridge, in a minute role, adds small delights to a modest but meaningful entertainment.

title: $3MILLION LAWSUIT ON G.O.P. DISMISSED
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct, 25A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a $3million suit brought by former Assemblyman Stanley, Harwood against the 1972 Republican campaign committee and others.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES DEBT CEILING RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The House Ways and Means Committee approved today legislation to extend the statutory ceiling on the national debt and permit payment of up to 6 per cent interest on savings bonds. The bonds now pay 5 per cent annually if held to maturity.

title: The Fed's Independence
description: The Federal Reserve Board and its allies in the nation's private banking system see a threat to the muchprized independence of the nation's central bank in a bill that has emerged from the House Banking and Currency Committee. The bill would provide for periodic audits of the Federal Reserve Board and the regional reserve banks and branches by the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress.

title: Rockefeller Hits the PartyFund Trail
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 25Governor Rockefeller began a busy Republican fundraising visit today with his full political entourage and a message that Watergate is a tragedy of individualsnot the Republican party.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE WATERGATE STEPS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. Oct. 25 (AP)Democratic state chairmen called on Congress today to provide a new, independent Watergate prosecutor and to press its inquiry into, a possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: A Crisis A Day
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The main thing is that a direct confrontation between the policies and military forces of the United States and the Soviet Union in the Middle East has been avoided for the time being, but you have to wonder how long the American people are going to be dragged along the brink by a jumpy Government they no longer trust.

title: Police Believe a Thwarted Extortionist Bombed Bank
description: Detectives who have sought for a week a motive for the pipebomb explosion at a Union Square bank now strongly believe that the bomber electronically set off the two highly sophisticated devices after failing in a scheme to extort $100,000 from the bank.

title: BadCheck Spree Costing $200,000 Laid to TeenAger
description: ORLANDO, Ha., Oct. 25 (AP) The police are holding a New York City teenager who, they say, used a friend's credit card and an estimated $200,000 in worthless checks to finance a roundtheworld trip that may have cost a total of $500,000.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Oct. 26, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A.M.C. Bars New Dealers
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25 (Reuters) The American Motors, Corporation said today it would not accept new dealer franchise applications until after Jan. 1. A.M.C. added that the decision was made after careful examination of newcar inventories and production schedules in light of unprecedented retail demand.

title: CON ED THWARTS APARTMENTS PLAN
description: The Consolidated Edison Company will build an electric substation just south of the United Nations, thwarting plans of a developer and the city for erecting a 40story apartment building there.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25New Jersey's candidates for Governor pledged today in a joint appearance before the State School Boards Association to overhaul the state's public school system.

title: Pipe Laid to Fight Fire Linked to Pike Crashes
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Oct. 25 National Guard troops, forest rangers and prison inmates began laying a water pipeline today in an effort to inundate a massive subterranean fire in the Hackensack Meadowlands giving off heavy, acrid smoke. The smoke contributed to the zero visibility that caused the macabre traffic accidents along the New Jersey Turnpike early yesterday.

description: At the Race Tracks

title: Lady Carolyn Townshend to Wed
description: The engagement of Lady Carolyn Elizabeth Townshend of London to Edgar Miles Bronfman, president of Distillers Corporation  Seagrams, Ltd., has been announced here. The marriage will take place here in December.

While the members of the orchestra watched, the leader of the group tried to make a s$eech but was hooted down by the small audience.

title: African Aides Act To Retrieve Statue

description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)For three months, Leopold Chouinard has been waging a private, silent fight against pain and sometimes agony.

description: WINNIPEG, Oct. 25 (AP)Mack Herron, a fullback with the New England Patriots but formerly of the Winnipeg Blue Hens, pleaded guilty today to charges of possession of marijuana and cocaine and was fined $1,000. Herron previously had pleaded not guilty to the charges after a raid on his apartment on May 26.

title: No Strings
description: In hopes of counteracting the ruinous political effect of President Nixon's miscalculation in firing Archibald Cox, Senate Republican leaders are now urging the President to name a new special prosecutor to take over the Watergate cases. Whatever relief from public outcry such a move might bring to harried G.O.P. legislators, it would not meet the nation's need for assurance of total independence for Mr. Cox's successor.

title: Messiaen and Wife Present His Music
description: A great deal has been made of Olivier Messiaen's genius for transfiguring and raising to mystical planes the ordinary sounds of naturethe birdcalls that serve as basic materials for so much of his work, for example. But quite as remarkable in its less exalted way is the French composer's seeming ability to reproduce with uncanny fidelity whatever sound takes his fancy.

title: Referendums to Block Zoning Shifts Ruled Out
description: TRENTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The state's secondhighest court ruled today that municipal residents did not have the power to block local zoning amendments through a referendum.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week were an estimated $1billion, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $929million.

description: Seven weeks after charging that nearly all superfecta races at New York harness tracks were fixed, Federal investigators are still digging for evidence to prove it.

He joined the agency in July as deputy assistant director for Congressional affairs.

title: For Today's Designers, Fashion Isn't Enough
description: Dress designers once concentrated on designing dresses. If they were feeling adventurous, they perhaps tried a coat. Today, that's pretty simplistic. Everybody's designing everything, and on a global scale.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An emergency allocation of gasoline by Texaco, Inc., temporarily averted a crisis for fleet taxis, some 600 which were forced off the streets here yesterday morning because of empty fuel tanks. After meeting with Texaco officials, fleet operators and state officials, Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, announced a temporary restoration of supplies.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct, 25Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from the statement by the Soviet delegate, Yahov A. Malik, to the Security Council on the resolution adopted today:

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Oct. 26  Kim Dae Jung, South Korean opposition politician kidnapped in Tokyo in early August and brought here mysteriously, was freed from 71 days of house arrest today.

Mauch, who gained the honor in 1962 and 1964 when he piloted the Philadelphia Phillies, guided the Montreal Expos last season to a fourthplace finish in the Eastern Division, 3 games behind the New York Mets.

Pons, 68, has retired and now resides in Tallahassee, Fla. He was director of racing and a steward at Rockingham Park for more than 20 years.

title: T. NORMAN PALMER
description: T. Norman Palmer, a former newspaperman who headed a marketing consulting firm bearing his name, died of leukemia yesterday at Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn. His age was 58 and he lived at 150 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills, Queens.

description: TVCHANNEL 9, 8 P.M.

title: L.I.U. Student Found Dead In His Dormitory Room
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 25 A 21yearold student at C. W. Post Center of Long Island University was found dead in his dormitory room here this atfernoon, the police said.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)A South Vietnamese Government base in the Central Highlands 12 miles west of Pleiku fell to the North Vietnamese two days ago, military sources said today. It was the second large Government camp near Pleiku captured in a month.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25Following is the resolution adopted by the Security Council today:

description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 25 (AP)Billy Cunningham lead a balanced attack tonight as the Cougars downed the Utah Stars, 115104, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: The Ultimate in Recycling
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 25 (UPI)University of Wisconsin researchers reported today that they were studying the possibility of making food out of sewage. Two bacteriologists, R. S. Hanson and J. G, Zeikus, said they had a process for producing bacteria from waste material. The plan mimics nature's recycling process, using bacteria to convert decaying matter to methane. A second type of bacteria uses the methane to form bacterial protein.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Metroliner service will be expanded by one round trip daily and one New YorktoWashington Sunday Metroliner run beginning this Sunday, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation announced today.

title: Now It's All Right to Call an Umpire a Bum
description: It's official. If you think the umpire is a bum, Justice George M. Carney of the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday, you can tell him so. Even if you're Joseph M. Cronin, president of the American Leagueas long as there is no malice intended.

title: Shipping/Mails
LowCaste Indians Still Know Terror
description: KALLIPASHIM, India, Oct. 19Laxmi Rani is terrified to leave her mud hut in the morning and climb on her bicycle to pedal to school four miles away.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Government exempted the fertilizer industry from price and wage controls today in an effort to increase farm production and food supplies.

title: Safety a Target as Deer Season Opens

He shot five times and hit the target area five times.

description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 25  The Egyptian III Corps, estimated to number 15,000 to 30,000 men, remained trapped by the Israelis today, unable to acquire fresh supplies of water and food.

description: A new principal, Mrs. Juana Dainis, took over it Public School 206 in East Harlem yesterday, despite a boycott by parents who kept virtually all children home from two schools for the fourth straight school lay.

title: THAI PREMIER VOWS DOMESTIC REFORMS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 25 (AP)Thailand's new head of Government said today that he would concentrate on domestic problems and uphold the foreign policy of the previous Government.

title: G.M. POSTS PEAK SALES AND PROFIT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25The General Motors Corporation today reported record thirdquarter and ninemonth sales and earnings.

description: Trading was quiet and prices fell slightly in the corporate bond market yesterday.

description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 25 The Governor cut a ribbon; the highschool band played and the city installed sidewalk flower pots.

title: At SAC's Nerve Center, The Surface Seems Calm

title: Cambodian Port's Dreams of Glory Are Just Dreams
description: KOMPONG SOM, Cambodia, Oct. 16Luxury villas along the coast lie deserted, their wealthy owners in Phnom Penh rarely using them any more for weekend revelries. Threestory brick apartment buildings have been halted in midconstruction and military families have become Talk squatters in their exposed interiors. The big railroad depot sits empty, its tower clock stopped; each of the four faces shows different time.

title: New Police Building
description: Designing a building for the city of New York is the sort of nightware that makes architects wonder why they didn't go into some easier profession, like neurosurgery.

title: A. ALLEN THOMSON
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 26 A. Allen Thomson, director of government affairs for Pepsico, Inc., and a former vice president in charge of the sugar department of the PepsiCola Company, died yesterday in the White Plains Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 48 Fenimore Road.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The body of a 23yearold Trenton mother of three was found in a park there early yesterday, an apparent murder. victim, the police said. According to the Mercer County Pathologist, Dr. David A. Fluck, the woman, Mrs. Norma Rosado, had also been sexually assaulted.

title: The Beautiful People Have the Secret to Losing Weight: Eat Less
description: Luciana Avedon  who used to be the Princess Pignatellistopped briefly in New York this week on the last lap of her 20citiesinamonth our of this, country It was like having the Mona Lisa on tour. Luciana, as even the people who don't know her call her, is somewhat of an Italian national treasure.

title: BYRNE INSISTS FOE DOES RAIN DANCE
description: RIDGEWOOD, Oct. 26Brendan T. Byrne said today that his Republican gubernatorial opponent, Charles W. Sandman Jr., had failed to offer acceptable solutions to the state's problems and instead looks for areas where the people are troubled and then does what call a rain dance.

title: NIXON IS BACKED BY BUSINESSMEN
description: A sampling of tip business executives indicates they do not think President Nixon should resign, nor do they believe that Congress should begin impeachment proceedings.

title: Buffalo Physician Is Sentenced In Death of Woman in Abortion
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 26 (AP)A Buffalo physician was sentenced to up to three yars in prison today for the death of a woman after an abortion.

title: U.S. Court Orders the Administration to Release Impounded Medical Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The United States District Court here ordered the Nixon Administration today to release for spending more than $140million in previously impounded medical research and training funds.

title: Lachaise Nude Sculptures Displayed
description: The Parisianborn American sculptor, Gaston Lachaise, who died in 1935 at the age of 53, was an artist of restless and elemental force. In the relatively short span of his careerhe began exhibiting at the age of 17he managed to produce a rather prolific oeuvre, much of it devoted to the theme of woman, which, more often than not, was treated with open sexuality and frank lustiness. At his most exuberant, Lachaise had a flair for exaggeration, for handling the physical and sexual aspects of his subjectmatter with a robustness and humor that, even today, many viewersespecially womenseem to find offensive and outrageous.

title: SeltzerSachs In Pianism With Words
description: Cheryl Seltzer and Joel Sachs like to talk about modern music, and they do so so sincerely that the listener is persuaded in advance to respect the work. Their Modern Revelations program at Hunter College Playhouse on Thursday went down easily, even for one who in principle hesitates to encourage mixing lectures and music making.

title: Campus Notes
description: An interest in the Japanese Language and in Asian studies prompted Marion Smith to apply for a Reserve Officers Training Corps scholarship, and this fall the 18yearold freshman became the first woman in the history of Cornell University to receive one $20,000 for tuition, room board, books and incidentals for four years.

title: Middlemen Kept, Food Prices High Despite 1.5% Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Consumers last month paid $1.40 a week more for a typical food basket than they would have if food processors and retailers had passed on the full amount of a drop in raw farm product prices, an Agriculture Department report showed yesterday.

title: Rexnord Confirms Talks On Sale of a Subsidiary
description: Rexnord, Inc., Milwaukee, has informed its employes that it is conducting negotiations that might lead to the sale, of part or all of its construction machinery group. The group contributed sales of $32.6million, or 9 per cent of the company's total sales of $363.5 milion. It accounted for $2.1million, or 8.3 per cent of the company's income before taxes.

title: Transcript of President Nixon's News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Affairs
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After more than twenty years of protecting and building up Taiwan, the United States is now withdrawing from that island. This is a followup of the NixonChou joint communiqu issued in February 1972, in which the President affirmed the ultimate objective of the withdrawal of all U.S. forces and military installations from Taiwan and said the U.S. will progressively reduce its forces and military installations on Taiwan as the tension in the area diminishes. Now that a ceasefire has been reached in Vietnam, the U.S. is fulfilling its commitments.

title: Environment Is a Key Issue First Time In SandmanByrne Race for Governor
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26New Jersey's ailing environment, which is suffering from inefficient sewage treatment, brimming landfills and eyesearing motor vehicle exhaust, has emerged for the first time as a major issue in a gubernatorial campaign.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MANE BOUT Horses have always shown off in Central Park, but usually only on the bridle paths. Today at 12:30, however, there's going to be a real horse show, free to anyone who cares to watch horses in action with no odds on them. It takes place on the park's Green Lawn, which is near the West Drive and the West 81st Street entrance, north of the Delacorte Theater.

title: A Bus Passenger Is Killed In Altercation With Driver
description: A Transit Authority bus driver fatally stabbed a 24yearold Bronx man yesterday after having been allegedly threatened with robbery at knife point, according to the police.

title: Two Share Golf Lead With 134's
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 26 (UPI)John Mahaffey, a Ben Hogan protege from Houston, Tex., and Lou Graham, an experienced 10year tour golfer from Nashville, Term., tied for the lead in the $135,000 Sahara Invitation golf tourney. They had 36hole scores of 134, eight under par and one stroke ahead of the field.

title: $900,000 for Car Accident
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UPI)  A 31yearold native of India, Manhar Kajjaria, was awarded $900,000 from Volkswagen by a jury yesterday because of an auto accident that left him permanently paralyzed from the waist down. His attorneys charged that the Volkswagen's poor doorlocking system caused the door to fly open during the accident, throwing him outside.

title: SURPLUS IN TRADE FOR SEPTEMBER AT 8YEAR HIGH

title: Rebels Stall Truck Convoy With Rice for Phnom Penh

description: Joan Mir turned 80 this year, which is getting along, but his new show at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, is enough to make you want to hurry up and reach that age yourself. title: The Theater: The Beard Restyled
description: When Michael McClure's The Beard was presented Off Broadway in 1967, the surrounding controversy about its frank language and sexual explicitness obscured the merit of the play and the production. Incisively directed (by Rip Torn) and performed (by Billie Dixon as Jean Harlow and Richard Bright as Billy the Kid), this was a mordant cartoon fantasy about selflove, roleplaying and sexual duplicity.

title: Con Ed Seeks Suspension Of HighSulphurOil Bans

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 President Nixon said tonight that the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed to use our influence more than we have in the past to put pressure on the Israelis and Arabs to reach a permanent settlement in the Middle East.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 26South Korea proposed to Japan today that a diplomatic compromise be sought to settle the case of the abduction of a former South Korean opposition leader from Tokyo to Seoul, according to Japanese Ambassador Torao Ushiroku.

title: DoItYourself Revolution
description: SHANGHAI  Ever since Moscow broke with Maoist China, ending all aid and even closing its consulate genera here, this country has stressed its selfsufficiency. While it may pay by slowing the speed of potential progress, the amount of ground covered by this goitalone policy is impressive. Steel output has risen from 5.35 to 23 million tons a year between 1957 and 1972, petroleum from .46 to 29 million tons and chemical fertilizer from .63 to 20million tons, despite the fact that emphasis has probably been on defensive armament. The G.N.P. has increased about 5.5 per cent per annum.

title: Music: From Leningrad
description: Just before Gennadi Rozhdestvensky came on stage to start Thursday night's conceit of the Leningrad Philharmonic, a group of militants briefly took over Carnegie Hall. Banners were unfurled that said Free Alexander Feldman, Free Panov, Free Soviet Jews, Free Sylvia. As the startled members of the orchestra watched, a man near the stage started to make a speech. He was hooted down by the audience. Security police rushed down the aisles, but the demonstrators were already leaving. They continued to picket across the street.

title: Screen: 'The New Land':The Cast
description: With "The New Land," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie theater, Jan Troell, the Swedish director, brings to an end the arduous saga of 19th-century migration from his homeland to America, which he began in "The Emigrants."What he has achieved seems no less than a masterly exercise in film-making, a rare union of carefully nuanced performances from a cast led by Max von Sydow and Liv Ullmann, a use of sight and sound that beggars, at least by its aspirations, the work of more easily satisfied men and a long but selective narrative as alert to the sins that taint national history as it is sensitive to the small dramas that ultimately seal the course and quality of lives.The uniform excellence of "The New Land" (and "The Emigrants," which opened here little more than a year ago) is no accident.Mr. Troell is credited with the direction, the editing and part of the screenplay and also with the photography, which could be mistaken as gratuitously lavish, were it not so sensitive to telling detail and were nature not so powerful a force in the rural lives these films depict.Mr. Troell is a busy and flexible workman, as willing to use silence to make a point as he is to turn his soundtrack over to the song of unseen birds in the spring, to bees in the summer and to flies in the presence of death.These are small touches, to be sure, but indicative of an intention to exploit the medium to its fullest, to construct impact cumulatively and to strike no false notes. Fingernails are dirty; tough hands pass an idle moment stroking a kitten's fur; age announces itself in broken capillaries.The cast appears thoroughly responsive to Mr. Troell's commitments. Most deserving of praise are Mr. von Sydow and Miss Ullman as Karl Oskar, the farmer, and his wife Kristina; Monika Zetterlund as Ulrika, and Eddie Axberg as Karl Oskar's ill-fated brother, Robert.Although for anyone who has seen "The Emigrants," this film will be enhanced by a pleasure akin to a reunion with old friends, "The New Land" is complete in itself. And it is a lovely and moving film.
