title: Three Rivals for Chief Judge Speak Outon Campaign Issues
description: This is like having house seats for The Sunshine Boys, protested Supreme Court Justice James J. Leffnot entirely in jestas he watched his two opponents in the race for Chief Judge of New York State bicker and belabor each other for more than two hours.

title: Lundy Restaurant Ordered to Close. After 3d Inspection
description: Lundy Brothers Restaurant, the 60yearold seafood emporium overlooking Sheepshead Bay, was closed by the city's Health Department yesterday for allegedly failing to remove violations that included mouse excreta and roach infestation.

title: Nixon Gives Newsman Memento of Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)President Nixon took off his tie clasp at the end of his news conference tonight and gave it to a photographer who told him he was covering his first Presidential news conference.

title: FORD AND U. A. W. REACH AN ACCORD
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative agreement early this morning on a new contract for the next three years covering 185,000 production workers.

title: Networks Dispute Nixon's Criticism Of TV Reporting
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company disputed President Nixon's sharp criticism last night of television news coverage.

title: Heart of Meadows Fire Extinguished
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Oct. 26The heart of a subterranean fire snaking beneath 40 acres of the Hackensack Meadowlands was extinguished today by massive amounts of water pumped in from a nearby creek.

title: SURPLUS IN TRADE FOR SEPTEMBER AT 8YEAR HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The United States ran a trade surplus of $873.3million in September, the largest surplus for a single month since March, 1965.

title: Bridge:
description: Suppose you are playing a smallslam contract and can see a safe road to 12 tricks. Can it ever be right to try for an overtrick and imperil the slam?

title: Curb on Insurer Sought
description: State Supreme Court Justice Albert S. McGrover yesterday ordered the Eveready Insurance Company to show cause why It should not be placed under control of the Superintendent of insurance as an insolvent insurer.

title: Many Smiles, but Little Warmth
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26President Nixon smiled a lot at his news conference tonight, but they were not happy smiles.

title: Wildcat Bus Strike Ends
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  Normal bus services were resumed in the Watts district today after 400 bus drivers voted to end their wildcat strike in protest against violent acts by youths riding the area's buses. The drivers voted to return to work following an assurance by Mayor Tom Bradley that more police protection would be provided for drivers and passengers.

title: Antiques: China Trade
description: The saga of China trade porcelain is as piquant and digestible as a Peking banquet. Or so Clare Le Corbeiller has made it seem in the literate catalogue she wrote and the dazzling exhibition she arranged for the China House Gallery, 125 East 65th Street. And to this diminutive gallery's credit, the handsomely installed show, which remains through Jan. 27, represents another of the memorable events held there over the years under aegis of the China Institute in America.

title: JEWISH OFFICIAL FEARS A BACKLASH
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 The executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee warned the American Jewish community today to be alert to an antiSemitic backlash in the wake of the war between Israel and the Arab states.

title: U.S. Is Easing the Alert But Links Step to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The United States began removing its forces from a readiness alert today but conditioned its actions on moves by Moscow to take Soviet airborne forces off alert.

title: Big Board Role Reported In Shift of Weis Accounts
description: Before the failure of Weis Securities, Inc., the New York Stock Exchange helped to facilitate the transfer of the accounts of an undisclosed number of wealthy investors to another brokerage firm, according to an informed source.

title: Knack for Rummaging Turns Up Big Winner
description: ST. CLAIR SHORES, Mich., Oct, 26., (UPI)A woman's knack for saving old keepsakes, even if it meant rummaging through garbage cans, turned up a lottery ticket worth at least $10,000.

title: N.B.C. Acts After Complaints By Homosexual Organizations
description: Officials of the National Broadcasting Company yesterday acknowledged that the network had at times dealt unfairly with homosexuals in its programs, and they agreed to maintain a continuing liaison with homosexual organizations for advice in future treatment of homosexual topics.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1973

title: TruckBus Crash Kills 4
description: CROSSETT, Ark., Oct. 26 (UPI)  A pickup truck and school bus collided at an intersection today, killing four persons and injuring 24 schoolchildren. All of the dead were adults riding in the pickup.

title: MOSCOW CRITICAL
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26Leonid I. Brezhnev accused the United States today of artificially fanning tensions over the Middle East with fantastic rumors of Soviet plans for unilateral military intervention. But he stopped short of an outright denial.

title: Williams in Racilig Post
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26 (AP)The State Racing Commission announced today that Commissioner W. Daniels had been appointed acting chairman of the panel. Hugh L. Mehorter, the chairman, has been ill for several weeks.

title: Notes on People
description: In Boston, the American Judges Association presented its Award of Merit to its hero of the moment, Judge John J. Sirica, of the United States District Court, praising him for his judicial courage in his handling of the Watergate case. Afterward, he displayed fine judicial impartiality in assessing some of the major figures in the Watergate case. What did he think of Elliot Richardson? He's a great American and a great lawyer. Archibald Cox? He's a great American. President Nixon? A great man. Okay, okay. Then what did it feel like to be in the center of the controversy? Am I in the center? Judge Sirica asked. What did I do?

title: Soviet Sees European Arms Cut by 1975
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, asserted today that the Soviet Union was prepared to begin cutting back its armed forces in Central Europe as early as 1975 if the forthcoming negotiations in Vienna on EastWest troop reductions proved successful.

title: Provocative President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Not since Richard Nixon's last press conference almost 11 years ago in California, after he was defeated by Edmund G. Brown for the governorship and thought his political career was over, was there such interest in his personal reaction to adversity as there was tonight in his meeting with the reporters in the White House. Few Presidents in the history of the Republic faced a more difficult assignment, under more trying circumstances. And almost all the way through, he was in complete command of himself and of the wide range of complicated and even dangerous political problems home and abroad.

title: Police Still Investigating 19 Missing Figurines Here
description: Detectives of the 19th Precinct said yesterday that an investigation was continuing into the alleged theft of 19 carved ivory figurines said to be worth $250,000, as reported to the police last Saturday.

title: P.B.A. CHIEFS SPLIT ON ENDORSEMENT
description: KEARNY, Oct. 26  A dispute over the endorsement of Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, by the Executive Committee of the State Patrolmen's Benevolent Association surfaced today when leaders of several important local P.B.A.'s endorsed Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate.

title: Cast of Raisin Works as Close as a Bunch of Grapes
description: There are ovations every night at the 46th Street Theater for Raisin. But they are for the cast, not individual performers. There are no stars in the rerun of Lorraine Hansberry's Raisin in the Sun, now a drama with music. There are no actors with stature similar to that of a Sidney Poitier, Claudia McNeil or Ruby Dee, who were in the original production in 1959.

title: Jewish School Is Stoned, 2 Are Held in Brooklyn
description: Yeshiva Mirrer, a Jewish school at 1891 Ocean Parkway, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, was stoned last night, the police reported.

title: Alaska's Kenai Peninsula Is Expected to Ease U.S. Gas Shortage
description: KENAI, AlaskaAn impoverished elderly woman testified at a recent California Public Utilities Commission hearing in Los Angeles that the cost of gas heating was forcing her, in cold weather, to retreat to bed with her clothes on.

title: Democrats in Congress Unsatisfied, Demand a Totally Independent Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Democrats in Congress, not satisfied With President Nixon's decision to have a special Watergate prosecutor appointed under his jurisdiction, demanded tonight a prosecutor completely independent of White House control.

title: Children to Take Part In UNICEF Day March
description: Several hundred children will march up the Avenue of Americas from 42d Street to morrow beginning at 12:30 P.M. in the UNICEF Day Parade that serves as a kind of forewarning of the assorted goblins that will be flapping about Wednesday night, which is Halloween.

title: Dow Stock Index Up 12.57 On Good Economic News
description: Favorable economic news enabled the stock market to turn in a bullish performance yesterday with the DowJones industrial average ending the session at its best level in more than eight months.

title: Con Ed Seeks Suspension Of HighSulphurOil Bans
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that the cutoff of fuel supplies from Arab countries had forced it to begin purchasing highsulphur fuel, which is banned by city and state laws, and it called for temporary suspension of those laws.

title: Beth Stone's 68 Leads by Stroke
T. A. SAYS TRAIN MOVED WITH CARE
description: A Bronx IRT train that struck a stalled train afire just ahead of it on Thursday night was moving past a red stop signal with extreme caution in the smoky tunnel, the Transit, Authority said yesterday.

title: Children of Wind Closing
description: Children of the Wind, the, new play by Jerry Devine that opened at the Belasco Theater on Wednesday, will close its Broadway run after tonight's performance, the fifth. Shepard Traube and Buff Cobb produced the play.

title: Witness in Agnew Inquiry Gets 6Month Term and Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Joel Kline, a bankrupt stock and land speculator who was a Government witness in the investigation of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail and fined $10,000 on a charge of obstructing justice.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, Oct. 26 Gene Hermanski, a former Dodger outfielder who started a triple play early in the 1949 season with a shoestring catch, thought he had a pretty fair understanding of baseball fans.

title: Riva Ridge Favored in Farewell Today
description: Meadow Stable's great Riva Ridge is expected to depart from the thoroughbred racing wars today as a champion should. The 4yearold colt has been listed as the overnight oddson favorite in the $100,000 added Jockey Club Gold Cup at Aqueduct.

title: Now, Even Mickey Mouse Is Computerized
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Mickey Mouse has been computerized. In California and Florida, Walt Disney Productions now uses data processing to animate lifesized, threedimensional figures in the performance of complete shows, with voice and music. Stage performances are given at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., and at Walt Disney World near Orlando, Fla. The apparatus and method of operation, developed at the Burbank, Calif., plant, are protected by Patent 3,767,901, granted this week to Millard G. Black, Robert A. Nater and five other inventors.

title: ROCKEFELLER GIVES PRAISE TO BEAME
description: TUCSON Ariz, Oct. 26 Governor Rockefeller today praised New York City Controller Abraham D. Beame the other party's mayoral candidateas an experienced pub lic official who, if elected, would give the city pretty good efficient administration.

title: Drug Holdup Is Failure
description: LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 26 (AP) Two men wearing stocking caps and carrying sawedoff shotguns demanded the drug known as speed from a veterinarian here this morning. The veterinarian, Jonathan Hall, concinved the men that he had no amphetamine or any other drugs at his office and they left him unharmed.

title: ASHI IN A CONFLICT OVER RESIDENCY
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26  A dispute in Superior Court here today showed that Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, had made conflicting statements under oath as to his place of residence.

title: Business Briefs
description: DALLAS, Oct. 26 (AP)Judge William M. Taylor Jr. of The United States. District Court assessed a total of $80,000 in fines today against fivesteel companies accused of fixing the price of reinforcing Steel bars used in buildidg construction.

title: AN AUDITED CLERK RETURNS $21,500
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 26 (AP)A clerk in the Tenth Circuit Court at New London resigned after the state began a routine court audit and the next day sent the chief prosecutor a sealed envelope containing $21,500 in cash, checks and money orders, the state auditors report.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: Boy, 15, Shot at School
description: A 15yearold boy was shot apparently without motive, by an unidentified youth in the hallway of Tilden High School in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn at 4 P.M. yesterday police reported. The police said the victim, Darrell Jackson o 177 Cobert Street, Brooklyn was in fair condition at Kings County hospital.

title: Notre Dame Seeks First Victory Over U.S.C. Since Rout of '66
description: There are reliable people who still insist that following Notre Dame's 510. victory over Southern California in 1966, John McKay said, I'll never lose to that Parseghian again.

title: Bus Vandals Make 3,700 Pupils Late In Rockaway Twp.
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP, Oct. 26Schools in this sprawling Morris County township were dismissed two hours early this afternoon after 12 of 40 school buses were vandalized and knocked out of operation.

title: 76ers Bow. To Bucks By 9892
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (UPI)Kareem AbdulJabbar and Bob Dandridge combined for 59 points tonight to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 9892 vnctory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.

title: People and Business
description: In the 40 yeats since its founding, the National Security Traders Association, a group in the overthecounter market, has operated without a fulltime paid president. Now it has oneMorton N. Wiess.

title: SHOP TALK
description: One of the nice things about the exhibition and sale of rare jade from Hob Cie Ltd. at Bonwit Teller through next Saturday is that Don Hob comes with the show. The seventh generation in his family to head the firm, Mr. Hob holds court daily in the store's second floor gift department, and customers love it.

title: Watergate Unit Postpones Hearings Until Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Senate Watergate committee today postponed, from Tuesday until Wednesday, the scheduled resumption of public hearings into campaignfinancing irregularities and other subjects. No witness list was announced.

title: Wheels on Their Feet Fashion on Their Minds
description: Funky clothes, roller skates and soul music are the ingredients for the house specialty at the Empire Rollerdrome, 200 Empire Bouleyard, Brooklyn. Every Tuesday, and Thursday from, 8 o'clock to midnight, young black New Yorkers converge on the indoor roller rink to kick up their heels and show of their clother.

title: Hayden Stone Reports Loss for Third Quarter
description: Hayden Stone, Inc., reported yesterday a loss of $668,073 for the September quarter, in contrast to a profit of $24,968 for the same period a year earlier.

title: Crisis to Confidence
description: Emerging from three weeks of military tragedies in the Middle East, and two days of apparent superpower confrontation, President Nixon could state last night that the outlook for an ArabIsraeli peace settlement is the best that it has been in twenty years. If so, and there indeed appear to be objective reasons for such belief, this period could well stand as a major turning point for an endemic trouble spot of the world.

title: JEAN W. BARBEY
description: Jean William Barbey, who retired in 1964 as president of Bally, Inc., in the United States, the Swiss shoe manufacturers, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here and in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: Bonn Is Singled Out
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26President Nixon chastised this country's Western European allies tonight for withholding the support the United States would have liked for its Middie East policies and actions, suggesting that Europe would have frozen to death this winter unless there had been a settlement.

title: Quebec Premier Presses Election Drive
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 26In the filial days of what could be crucial ejection campaign for Quebec, Premier Robert Bourassa is focusing increasingly sharp attacks on the separatists who are seeking political independence for this largely Frenchspeaking province.

title: HOUSE UNIT FACES PROCEDURE SPLIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The House Judiciary Committee, which will meet Tuesday to work out ground rules for an inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon, appeared today to be headed toward a partyline split on a central issue.

title: Huge Waves Cause Damage Of $170Million at Palermo
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Oct. 26 (AP)Some $170million in damage was caused by a storm that struck the port of Palermo yesterday, port officials estimated today.

title: A Visiting Policeman, Learns the Hard Way
description: A vacationing West German police sergeant, who came to New York because of his interest in American police problems, received a textbook demonstration early yesterday, according to the police: He was robbed at knifepoint by two men who took his wallet, $150, his watch, his return ticket home, his passport and his German police shield.

title: BigPower Entry Pleases Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 26The Egyptian Government expressed satisfaction today over the intention of the United States, as well as of the Soviet Union, to send unarmed truce observers to the Middle East.

title: Zambia Breaks With Israel
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 26 (UPI)Zambia tonight became the 20th African country to sever diplomatic relations with Israel because of the Middle East war. The government also severed relations with Chile, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that if elected he planned to remove the city's Department of Social Services from the Human Resources Administration, one of Mayor Lindsay's superagencies, and make it an independent agency.

title: Israelis Say Foe Must Quit to Get Water
description: AYUN MUSSA, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, Oct. 26They started the war, and they must have thought about all the risks, said Maj. Gen. Yeshayahu Gavish, commander of the southern Sinai Peninsula, whose troops provide the blocking force south of the trapped Egyptian III Corps.

title: Excerpts From the Address by Soviet Party Leader Brezhnev to a Session of the World Peace Congress
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26  Following in unofficial translation are excerpts from the speech of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to a session of the World Peace Congress:

title: SKYLAB 3 MISSION MAY LAST 85 DAYS
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. Oct. 26 (AP)The space agency said today that the Skylab 3 astronauts would be launched on schedule on Nov. 10 on a mission that could last as long as 85 days.

title: MOSCOW CRITICAL
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26Leonid I. Brezhnev accused the United States today of artificially fanning tensions over the Middle East with fantastic rumors of Soviet plans for unilateral military intervention. But he stopped short of an outright denial.

title: Alcatraz, Now Empty, Silent and Desolate, Is Opened to the Public
description: ALCATRAZ, Calif., Oct, 26 Once the prison walls reverberated with the sounds of metal and men. But today, as the cold morning winds ruffled the eucalyptus trees and columbine flowers, the silence of the placenow empty and desolatewas broken only by the hushed voices of visitors.

title: A Fatigued Nixon Asserts He Will Not Quit His Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct., 26 President Nixon, his face showing fatigue and his voice displaying occasional hurt and anger, asserted tonight that he would not be deterred by demands for his impeachment and that he had no intention of resigning.

title: Sihanouk Quoted as Saying He May Resign Cabinet Post
description: PARIS, Oct. 26 (UPI)Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian rebel leader, was quoted today as having said he might resign from his Pekingbased Cabinet because of bad relations with his leftwing Khmer Rouge allies.

title: A Fatigued Nixon Asserts He Will Not Quit His Post
description: WASHINGTON Oct, 26 President Nixon, his face showing fatigue and his voice displaying occasional hurt and anger, asserted tonight that he would not be deterred by demands for his impeachment and that he had no intention of resigning.

title: PRIMERATE CUT TRIGGERS AMEX
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday with analysts crediting the rise to the lowering lily the First National City Bank of its prime rate from 9 to 9 per cent.

title: Senate Confirms Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nominations of Harry J. Hogan of Maryland to be an associate director of the ACTION agency, and of J. Raymond Bell of New York to be a member of the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission.

title: Atlantis,GreekLanguage Daily Paper, Shuts Down Operations After 79 Years
description: Atlantis, the Greeklanguage daily newspaper that has been published here since 1894, folded quietly yesterday as its property was sold off at public auction by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Some Other News
description: ESSEX JUNCTION, Vt., Oct. 22 (AP) A driverless diesel engine rolled eighty miles yesterday from Rutland to Essex Junction at five to ten miles an hour before it was detected.

title: Unsafe Subways
description: The city's subways have long ceased to qualify for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's perennial, selfserving description as the world's safest. The system may just possibly be the world's luckiest. Luck once again seems the only mason why the latest accident in the South Bronx took no lives, though over 100 persons suffered relatively minor injuries.

title: Alert Puzzles Europeans
description: LONDON, Oct 26  The failure of the United States to provide advance word to its allies of yesterday's worldwide troop alert contributed today to a sense of bewilderment in European capitals about the United States. There were no official complaints about what some called a snub, but there was substantial private grumbling.

title: DR. RAYMOND E. BANTA
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 26Dr. Raymond E. Banta, a physician here, died today at his home, 288 Orchard Place. He was 63 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: FIRE BOMB TOSSED INTO A SYNAGOGUE
description: A 75yearold synagogue on the Lower East Side was extensively damaged by fire early yesterday morning, after a firebomb was hurled into the building.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Oct. 26  A young pair from Streatham, England, earned the applause of about 1,200 spectators last night as they combined to capture the compulsory figures section of the dance competition of Skate Canada '73.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 Slashed Fighting Female Mugger

title: Ontario Paper Company. Resumes Output at Plant
description: THOROLD, Ont., Oct. 26 (AP) Production resumed today at, the Ontario Paper Company plant here, which had been closed by strikes since Sept. 29, following ratification of a new contract by 200 tradesmen in five unions.

title: John H. F. Anderson Marries Miss Tucker Lee Etherington
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., Oct. 27 In St. James Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Tucker Lee Etherington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sandford G. Etherington Jr., was married to John Huxley Fordyce Anderson, son of Mrs. A. R. F. Anderson of London and the late Mr. Anderson. The Rev. William Peabody performed the ceremony.

title: Rental Effort Is On At Luxury Coop
description: The sponsor of the cooperative apartment building at 733 Park Avenue, at the southeast corner of 71st Street, has started to rent apartments in the 30story tower after selling fewer than half of the units during an expensive advertising campaign.

title: WALL STREET Politically Safe Oil Stocks Win Investors' Esteem
description: Earlier this year, gold stocks were glittering on Wall Street while the general market kept going down, down, down.

title: Drug Clinics In Brooklyn Get Funds
description: The privately run Addiction Research and Treatment Corporation, which caused a furor in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn more than a year ago by enrolling 1,200 drug addicts in one facility, has decentralized its operations into five smaller Brooklyn programs and last week received financing from the city for two of them.

title: Nixon's Continuing Vetoes
description: WASHINGTON In addition to the daily crisis over Watergate tapes, impeachment and the Middle East, another power struggle between President Nixon and Congress intensified last week: fundamental differences on the balance of powers between the executive and the legislative branches of government and programmatic differences on the Administration's pollcies were translated into the hard currency of votes and vetoes.

title: Ford Says Nixon Probably Regrets His Attack on the Television Networks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 Representative Gerald R. Ford, the Vice Presidentdesignate, said shortly after President Nixon's televised news conference last night he believed that the President on second thought, probably wished he hadn't attacked the news media so vigorously.

title: Photography
Grocer Kills a Customer In an Altercation Over Bill
description: A 29yearold Bronx grocer was arrested yesterday in the fatal shooting of a customer during an argument over a bill and in the unintentional wounding of a passenger in a bus passing by.

title: 1st Lloyd Cottage
description: LLOYD NECK, L.I.Caught up in the quandry over the future use of Caumsett State Park is the fate of Henry Lloyd's original cottage standing on the grounds. The saltbox cottage was built in 1711.

title: L. I. School Racial Study
EDWARD S. MAGOWAN
description: Edward S. Magowan, a realestate broker and private investor, died Friday in the New York Hospital on his 68th birthday. He lived in Southampton, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Jungle Habitat Is Now a Good Neighbor
description: WEST MILFORDWinter driving in this northwest Passaic County municipality can be treacherous. When snow and ice cover its twisting roads, cars move slowly, if at all.

title: The Birth Of Daylight Saving Time
description: Robert Garland of Pennsylvania is credited with being the father of Daylight Saving Time in the United States; he was instrumental in persuading Congress to adopt it during World War I. However, it is known that in 1784 Benjamin Franklin awoke at 4 A.M. in Paris to find bright sunlight streaming into his room, Which started him thinking that most people in the summertime slept through four or five hours of daylight, making up for it by using candles at night. To Poor Richard this was downright extravagant.

title: Brick Goes 27th Game Without Losing
description: Brick Township extended New Jersey's longest schoolboy winning streak to 23 games yesterday with a 286 victory sver Toms River South in Brick.

title: Catholics and Jews Set Talks
description: PRINCETON  In observance of the eighth anniversary of Vatican Council II's promulgation of the Roman Catholic Church's statement on the Jews, Catholic and Jewish theologians will take part in a consultation at the Aquinas Institute here Tuesday.

title: Planned Towers in Dispute in Queens
description: For many suburban comrnunities, the steady influx of city dwellers has been a boon bringing with it only a hint of future problems. But along the North Shore of Queens, many residents are convinced a crisis has already arrived.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TODAY

title: Mary Ruddy Plans Wedding in March
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 27The engagement of Miss Mary Lucile Ruddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ruddy of Tarrytown, to John W. Diercksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Diercksen of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in March is planned.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Saying cheese
description: ACROSS

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Nets and the Kentucky Colonels, two of the strongest teams in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division, will meet Friday in Nassau Coliseum, 7:30. P.M. Dan Issel and Artis Gilmore, the Colleading scorers and rebounders, are the men the Nets must stop.

title: Ford Foundation Vows $100Million For Ford Hospital
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27The Ford Foundation has, pledged $100million to Detroit's Henry Ford Hospital, which is beginning a 10year expansion program in research, education and medical treatment.

title: People and Business
description: New developments keep coming from computer makers, and now a New Jersey company has devised one to monitor the onsite operation of vending machines. Earl C. Ramsey, president of Rowe International, Inc., of Whippany, said that the Rowe system utilized televisiontype equipment and a teleprinter, thus enabling one person to keep tabs on up to a thousand machines.

title: India
description: NEW DELHIThis is the festive Diwali season, when the Goddess Lakshmi is supposed to slip into homes in northern and western India and magically bestow prosperity for the new year. It is traditional to gambletrusting in Lakshmi's good luckand to close one's accounts and books in order to start anew after the holiday.

title: Tennessee 397 Victor Over T.C.U.
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 27 (AP)Stanley Morgan, a freshman caught eight passes for 201 yards and two touchdowns and Condredge Holloway threw three scoring tosses today as Tennessee, after a listless first half, crushed Texas Christian University, 397.

title: The Two Most Striking Shows in Town
description: MIRO, MIRO on the wall, who's the richest of them all?, read the picket placard outside the Museum of Modern Art where striking staff members had walked out, as they did two years ago, giving the institution the dubious honor of being the only museum in the United States to have been struck by its professional personnel, not once, but twice.

title: Post Beats Drexel On Late Kick, 1615
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27Nick DiConstanzo kicked an 18yard field goal today with 28 seconds remaining in the game to give visiting C. W. Post a 1615 victory over Drexel. It was post's sixth victory against one loss. Drexel is 32.

title: Quincy J. Carter Is Bride in Suburb
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Oct. 27Miss Quincy Jane Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Andrew Carter, was married here this afternoon to Willoughby Ingalls Stuart Jr., son of Mr. Stuart of Boston and Marblehead Neck, Mass., and the late Mrs. Stuart. The Rev. Richard S. Monkman, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Community Church.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Through Football Success or Adversity, Syracuse's Ben Remains Controversial
description: Ben Schwartzwalder reached manhood in his native West Virginia during the Depression. A football scholarship that the 150pounder earned at center enabled him to gain a bachelor degree from West Virginia University.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: TodayThe Hill Jumper Classic, Route 124, North Salem, N.Y. Open, preliminary and suitable jumpers. 9 A.M.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: COMMUTER TRAINS PLANNED IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27The state of Michigan wants to revive rail commuter service, with a 16trainsaday operation between Detroit and Ann Arbor, 37 miles away.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: TrashDisposal Problem: CountyRun Dumps May Be Answer
description: TRENTONThe problem of waste disposal in New Jersey is increasingly preoc= cupying officials at all levels of government. It is a problem aggravated by diminishink available land, skyrocketing disposal costs and growing threats to the ecology.

title: Israel Reports Complete Quiet on Both Fronts for First Time Since War Began
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 27The Middie East ceasefire appeared to be taking hold today as Israel reported complete quiet on both fronts for the first time since fighting began on Oct. 6.

title: WOMAN IS JAILED AS A GUNRUNNER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27when 17yearold Marilyn Buck left Texas in September, 1965, to attend the Universtiy of California at Berkeley, it was her first journey away from home. She was an honor student and a member of one of Austin's most respectable families.

title: Numismatics
description: COLLECTORS in central and western Pennsylvania  as well as others more distant for whom getting there is half the fun  will have a onceinabluemoon opportunity to visit an important coin show in their own backyard next weekend. The 21st annual convention (coin show) of the Middle Atlantic Numismatic Association will be held on Friday, Saturday and Sunday in the new Host Inn in Harrisburg, at Routes 283 and 441 (near exit 19 of the Pennsylvania Turnpike).

title: Symphony In Queens Is Adding New Series
description: The big push is on for the Queens Symphony Orchestra. This means:

title: Reactions in Crisis:
description: WASHINGTON  Dramatic events, to be fully realized, need characters in dramatic crisis, but normally this city fails to produce more than an occasional actor who can play the role. In the last ten days it has had them in abundance.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Recordings
description: TRANSCRIPTIOM, particularly for the piano, have been considered disreputable for several decades, largely because so many people accepted them as the equivalent of the orig anal, and this was wrong. The translation of a musical work from one medium to another, e. g. from Orchestra to piano, can no more result in the same thing than a translation of a poem from Russian into English. Yet think of how useful both kinds of translations are. More disturbing than straight transcriptions those that attempt to, follow the original ss faithfully as possiblehave been transcriptions that are really variations on the original and have been considered distortions beneath the contempt of purists. Yet listen to what Leopold Godowsky, pianist and avid transcriber, has to sty: Why should musicians be denied the privileges of comment, criticism, dissertation, discussion, and display of imaginative faculties when transcribing, arranging, or paraphrasing a standard work!

title: The iron law of history: No longing is completely fulfilled Secretary Henry
description: WASHINGTON. A diplomat from a small European country was posted as minister to Washington a couple of years ago largely because he had known Henry Kissinger at Harvard. For months the new minister sought to see the Special Assistant to the President. In vain. At length he ran into Kissinger at a large reception at the Soviet Embassy. Henry, he said, you don't seem to have much time for your old friends That, Kissinger shot back, is the secret of my success.

title: 3Day Hilton Head Racing Workshop a Wetting Experience
description: HILTON HEAD, S.C. It was like a circus school for highwire acrobats. Most everyone fell off.

title: U.S. Explanation of Alert Called Absurd by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 27  The Soviet Union today dismissed President Nixon's explanation of why American forces were put on alert Thursday as absurd and called the American tactics, an attempt to intimidate the Soviet Union.

title: News of the Screen
description: Martin Scorsese, the 30yearold local director who scored a resounding hit with Mean Streets, apparently subscribes to the idea that you can't go home again. His next film will be Alice Doesn't Live Here Any More, an original script by Robert Getchell. It will take him far from the sidewalks of Little Italy, where he was raised and where Mean Streets was shot. The movie will be produced by David Susskind for Warner Bros., starting in January, with filming in Oklahoma City, Phoenix, Denver and California's Monterey.

title: Woman Is Affirmed In Cleveland Race For Mayor Nov. 6
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 27Campaigning in Cleveland's mayoral election. Nov. 6 can now begin in earnest.

title: Houston Upset, 70, By Auburn
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 27 (UPI)  Chris Vacarella, a freshman quarterback, scored on a 7yard dash in the first period today and Auburn's defense made it stand up as the Tigers handed previously unbeaten and 10th ranked Houston its first shutout in 89 games, 70.

title: Safety Agency to Provide TollFree Help on Toys
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Parents concerned about the safety of toys they are buying for Christmas will soon have a tollfree number to call for answers to their worries from Federal officials.

title: School Overcomes Adversity
description: ENGLEWOOD  Dwight Morrow High School has had more than its share of violence and racial tensions in the last five years. Yet, an extraordinary 72 per cent of the black seniors who graduated last June were accepted by colleges, a rate 28 per cent higher than the, national norm.

title: Easing Frictions Along Trail
description: TRENTONIn recent years, New Jersey has been confronted with the problem of how to satisfy the growing demand for an opportunity to enjoy nature in the face of continuing development of remaining open space.

title: Color TV TubesExpanding Again
description: A vigorous round of expansion by the producers of picture tubes for color television sets is raising the question whether the industry is heading for the same fall it suffered in the late nineteensixties.

title: Child to Mrs. Gryl Jr.
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Gryl Jr. of East Windsor, N. J., on Oct. 14 in the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center. Mrs. Gryl is the former Miss Virginia C. Scherer of Woodhaven, Queens. The child, the couple's second daughter, is named Kristine Nicole. Her father is a mechanical engineer with Western Electric Research Center in Princeton.

title: Fire Engines Proved Big Hit at First National Show
description: The National Horse Show is 90 years old this year a lifetime that has spanned four Madison Square Gardens.

title: SOME U.S. JEWS CRITICIZE NIXON
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27The juxtaposition of the Middle East war and the domestic controversy over the Watergate disclosures has evoked mixed emotions among one group of Jewish leaders.

description: POWER

title: Catholic. Forums Attract Candidates
description: A yearold Roman Catholic politicaleducation group attracted the four New York mayoral candidates to forums in Brooklyn and Queens last week that sought to deal with matters of particular concern to the outer boroughs.

title: SANDMAN OPPOSES OFFSHORE PLANTS
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, told an environmental conference today that he was flatly opposed to off shore nuclear generating plants

title: Orangutan Born at Zoo
description: STONEHAM, Mass., Oct. 27 (AP)An orangutan was born today at the Metropolitan District Commission's Walter D. Stone Zoo here.

title: 14 Working Dogs Get Degrees
description: Something new has been added to the dog show picture.

title: DR. ARTHUR BENDICK, RADIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Arthur J. Bendick, specialist in radiology, died Friday at his home, 136 East 55th Street His age was 85.

title: Education
description: CHICAGORebecca Clouse was recalling that big day last spring for the 13 highschool seniors in the village of Alexander, N. D. First off, her friend, Max Melby, got his finger smashed under the school's new safe. Then, the seniors' mothers began running toward the school waving torn envelopes in the air: The college acceptance letters had arrived.

title: Janet Henry Hylan Wed in Connecticut
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Oct. 27Miss Janet Henry Hylan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Hylan of Fairfield, was married here this afternoon to Philip Ramsay Merriss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Merriss of Greens Farms. The Rev. William A. Dimmick performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Duryea Says Governor Will Seek a Fifth Term!
description: HERKIMER, N.Y., Oct. 27 (AP)  Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea said today that Governor Rockefeller had told him he would seek a fifth term as Governor.

title: Danbury Wins 7th in Row, 4018
description: Danbury rolled to a 4018 victory over Norwalk yesterday to gain first place in the Fairfield County West Division. Both clubs had been tied for the division lead with 40 wonlost records.

title: Steadiness Under Fire
description: The intemperance of President Nixon's news conference assault on the media in general and on television in particular did much to undermine the impression he was seeking to create of a President in full command of himself.

title: Cuba Honors Allende
description: HAVANA, Oct. 27 (Reuters)  One of Havana's main. thoroughfares, Carlos III Avenue, has been renamed for President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile, who died in a military takeover.

title: Egg Business Fights to Live
description: UPPER FREEHOLD TOWNSHIPIn 1956, New Jersey reached its peak as a major eggproducing state. Since then, poultry farming has declined steadily at the rate of about 7 per cent a year.

title: Sharon Born Is Fiancee
description: LINCOLN PARK, N. J., Oct. 27  Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Born have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Marie Born, to Lee Michael Zerman, son of Mrs. Abner Zerman of Pinebrook, N. J., and the late Mr. Zerman. Miss Born, a graduate of Glassboro State College, is a fifthgrade teacher in the Wanaclue County school system. Her father practices medicine here. Mr. Zerman, who attended the Stevens Institute of Technology, is an installation technician with Fritz Heating and Cooling Company of Whippany.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Colts Neck Survives As a Fount Of Applejack
description: COLTS NECKUnlike Milwaukee, this historic Monmouth County area may not have a beer to make it famous, but it does have what is said to be the oldest operating distillery in the country.

title: Basketball Transact'ns
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: Yale Halts Cornell, 203, on Doyle's Touchdowns
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27 Tommy Doyle, the Yale quarterback who has known great days and frustating ones on the gridiron, silenced his critics in the fourth quarter of the Eli's game against Cornell here today. Doyle scored two touchdowns on rollout runs of 18 and 15 yards to assure a 203 victory, which kept Yale in contention for the Ivy League championship.

title: LAWRENCE KUBIE, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: TOWSON, Md., Oct. 27Dr. Lawrence S. Kubie, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died yesterday in the Greater Baltimore Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: DialaRide Bus Fare Cut Doubles Use of Service
description: TRENTON  In a move designed to acquire additional riders, the state has reduced the fares on an experiniental bus service that it provides in South Jersey.

title: We're All Still Captives of the White House
description: THE most astonishing television program of the new season was presented a couple of Fridays ago. It featured the President of the United States and was carried live on the three commercial networks. The occasion was Richard M. Nixon's announcement of his choice for new Vice President.

title: Colorado InflictsFirst Loss on Missouri
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 27 (AP)A sophomore fullback, Jim Kelleher, scored from 4 yards out with 1 minute 21 seconds to play to give Colorado a 1713 victory over previously unbeaten Missouri in a Big. Eight football game today.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Prospective customers are following the new 1974model cars into dealer showrooms across the country, and the first reaction is one of complaints  complaints about seat belts, higher prices and poorer performance.

title: Future Social Events
description: Oct. 30The East Side Settlement in the South Bronx and Bennett College in Millbrook, N. Y., have taken blocks of seats at Madison Square Garden for the 90th anniversary opening night of the National Horse Show. East Side House for the seventh year will present the Challenge Trophy to the winner of the fivegaited saddlehorse class. Tickets are $50, $35 and $25 from the settlement's Manhattan office. Bennett College, whose trophy is for the fine harness class, will swell its funds for faculty salaries from proceeds of its $75 and $40 tickets, which may be obtained from Ruth A. Nicholson, 130 East 63d Street. Meycr Davis will be leading his orchestra at the show for the 12th year.

title: FRANK H. REITMAN
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27Frank H. Reitman, an industrialist and racetrack owner, died today in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 86 years old and lived at 175 Prospect Street.

title: Winter Bridal For Miss West, Donald Ross
description: Miss Susan Stillman West and Donald Ogden Ross plan to be married Jan. 12 in St. James Episcopal Church. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James W. West, parents of the future bride, whose fianc is the son of Mrs. Earl Beckwith Smith of Jamestown, R. I., and W. Ogden Ross of New Haven.

title: CHINA BOLSTERING MILITIA IN CITIES
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 27  A major drive is under way in China to build up urban militia units that can function as an armed auxiliary to the Communist party.

title: Oil Our Supply Is Sure to Be Short...
description: WASHINGTON  Shall the President of the United States be empowered by Congress to limit the number of hours that shopping centers, department stores and other commercial establishments may remain open? That such a farreaching exercise of Federal power was even under consideration in Washington last week was indicative of the potential gravity of this winter's fuel shortage.

title: Outside Issues Plaguing Kean
description: LIVINGSTON  The Assembly race in the 25th Legislative District is particularly sensitive to all the cross  currents at work in this politically unpredictable year.

title: Indian Festival Low on Joy for Want of Cooking Oil
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 27For two weeks Indians have listened to the radio news about the Middle East and read newspaper articles about President Nixon. But what housewives, peddlers, farmers, politicians and businessmen have been talking about is vanaspati.

title: Campus Rallies Urge Nixon's Impeachment, but Tone of Moderation Prevails
description: Petitions, letterwriting campaigns and a few moderately attended but quiet rallies marked campus protests last week and calls for President Nixon's impeachment or resignation.

title: In Elath, Neither War Nor Peace
description: ELATH, Israel, Oct. 27The lights went on again in Elath last Wednesday night, but, like all of Israel, this town on the Red Sea remains on a war footing.

title: Ridge Is On Top
description: Glenn Gerding scored two touchdowns while Joe Finn passed for one score and ran for another as Cedar Ridge moved to the top in Middlesex County yesterday with a 286 victory over Colonic in a battle of unbeaten teams in Madison Township.

title: Music: Leningraders
description: Music by Prokofiev was the subject of the Leningrad Philharmonic's concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, and Gennady Rozhdestvensky, the conductor, lost no time in demonstrating that he has a personal and persuasive approach to the interpretation of Prokofiev's works.

title: 3d Suspect Surrenders in Kidnapping
description: A third suspect in the kidnapping early Friday of a McDonald's restaurant manager surrendered to the police early yesterday. The restaurant manager, Frank Marion, 44 years old, was abducted as he walked along Second Avenue on his way to work. He later escaped unharmed.

title: JUDGE CANDIDATE SHUNS BAR FUNDS
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., Oct. 27 Judge Richard J. Shay is beginning to realize the cost of his decision to run for State Supreme Court without the support of lawyerssomething almost unheard of in judicial campaigning.

title: Rules on Pesticides Taking Final Form
description: VINELAND  After two years of preparation, New Jersey's regulations to control the use of pesticides are being put into final form.

title: Women Office Workers Oppose Discrimination
description: Beyond her other duties as a legal secretary, Margie Albert, the middleaged mother of two children, says she has been an allround nursemaid, mother, waitress, personal shopper, and social secretary to more men than I can remember.

title: HealthCare Facility In Flatbush Disputed
description: The Board of Estimate will decide on Nov. 15 whether to permit construction of a controversial 12  story health  related facility on Ocean Parkway in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: No plaque on Hitler's house
description: BRAUNAU AM INN, Austria. The house where Adolf Hitler was born here on April 20, 1889, bears no plaque. That is the way Braunau Burgermeister Hermann Fuchs and most of the city fathers want it. Not all of the businessmen agree. So the best color postcard in Braunau's shops showsin prominent right foregroundthe handsomely restored, thickwalled old building that used to be the Gasthof zum Pommer. The town's tourist brochure has another version of the same scene.

title: The Cloud Over Nixon
description: Between his blasts at the networks and his boasts about his own coolness and toughness, Richard Nixon at his news conference Friday rather expertly fudged the question whether new special prosecutor would be any better able than was Archibald Cox to get vital documents and tapes from the White House.

title: Notes: Nude Skiing, Seminars, in the Sand
description: AMONG the latest prescriptions heing offered by resort operators to help ward off winter's ills are an antistress vacation noted earlier in this column, a series of medical seminars in the sand on a Caribbean isle and, believe it or not, a weekend of skiing in the nude high in the Laurentians of Canada.

title: Region
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Turnpike is the vehicular spine of the Eastern megalopolitan corridor and the most densely traveled toll road in the country. Last year alone, this road handled nearly 108 million trucks, buses and automobiles that logged more than one billion miles.

title: Cromwell
description: Cromwell Our Chief of State was the title of the English edition of this new biography by the author of the bestselling life of Mary Queen of Scots. The phrase, from Milton, was well chosen. In life and death Cromwell has been the object of admiration and abuse, respect and hatred, praise and slander. But neither friend nor enemy can dispute the fact that he was the only effective leaderour chief of men in a critical decade of English history.

title: Two Black Shows Get Stuck, Another Really Rolls Television
description: TELEVISION is the nation's cracked living room mirror, distorting the simplest reflections. In this new time for virtually all other image conveyorsmusic, the novel, cinema for examplesTV remains the least adventurous and, often, the most reactionary of our communicative systems.

title: Randolph Stays Unbeaten, 70
description: For the second time in two seasons, Randolph halted Roxbury's bid for an unbeaten season yesterday with a 70 upset in Randolph township.

title: STRIKES DISRUPT ITALY'S AIRPORTS
description: ROME, Oct. 27A chain of strikes caused chaos at Italy's troubleprone airports this week, and the press here is now seriously warning that civil aviation in this country may collapse.

title: South Shore Upsets Jefferson 166, and Will Play Lafayetter for Brooklyn Title
description: An aroused South Shore team defeated previously unbeaten Jefferson, 166, yesterday in a game that decided the title in the Public Schools Athletic Brooklyn Division II. South Shore, in its second season of varsity football, stifled Jefferson's powerful attack, which had rolled up 254 points in five straight victories.

title: Long Beach In Court Over Law On Rents
description: The City of Long Beach and a major group of apartment house owners and builders squared off last week In the opening round of a court battle over the validity of Long Beach's new rentstabilization law, which restricts rent rises on renewal leases in some 5,000 apartments.

title: Press Club Admits Women
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 (UPI)The San Francisco Press Club voted yesterday to permit women to become full members, ending years of bitter criticism from many women journalists. Prior to the 233to62 vote, the club had only allowed women to be associate members.

title: Nixon Plan on Prosecutor Is Opposed by Mansfield
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 President Nixon's position that the new special Watergate prosecutor will be named by the Administration rather than the courts drew continued opposition today from Democrats in Congress.

title: Syria Is Reported Beset By Frictions in Her Forces
description: Diplomatic reports reaching Western Europe and Washington indicate that the Syrian Government has had grave trouble recently both internally and in its relations with Iran.

title: Freedom of Expression Taking Hold in Liberia
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 24 Does the purchase of shares in a major foreign business concern here by Liberia's only political party mean that a foreignconcern is directly financing local political activity?

title: Mount Sings French Works
description: William Mount's recital of French vocal music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night was that of a knowledgeable musician of taste whose voice is serviceable and whose performing personality is rather bland.

title: President at Camp Sees Approving Telegraths
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Oct. 27 (AP)President Nixon and his family went over a stack, of approving telegrams today as the President relaxed at his mountain retreat after a week of domestic and international crisis, the White House said.

title: Pop: Roy Wood Is One Move Ahead
description: ABOUT the first thing America ever heard about Roy Wood was a report in 1966 that a British pop group called Move had taken to smashing up automobiles and TV sets as part of their stage act. It was not wildly exciting news, particularly since the Who had, already set a precedent by bashing a guitar now and then, while an automobile, being a larger target, took even less talent to demolish.

title: Display on the City's Mayors Is Shown in Queens
description: When the Queens County Art and Culture Center decided to stage an election period exhibition about the Mayors of New York in the 75 years since the center became ?? they did not realize that art and politics can become a curious mixture.

title: Sunday Observer
description: During the two winters we lived in London there was no heat at all to speak of anywhere in that whole vast gray conurbation. Or so it seemed to Americans already conditioned by their new imperial wealth to excesses of everything, including room heat. This was 1954, of course. Nowadays London is as much at ease with central heating as White Plains or Chevy Chase, Nit at that timetwilight of empire and all thatit could le a cold place when winter

title: Economic Policies Of U.S. Are Linked To Chilean Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27Representative Michael J. Harrington said today that American economic policies of deprivation set into motion, the string of events that led to the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile.

title: Municipalities Await $18Million State Tax Windfall
description: TRENTONA surprisingly large $18million tax windfall it is four times bigger than last year's will be distributed Thursday by the State Division of Taxation. The money is going to all but two of New Jersey's 567 municipalities.

title: City Mall Plans Called Surprise By Communities
description: Civic leaders and community residents in Brooklyn and Queens expressed surprise and concern last week that the city had not consulted them in drawing up proposals for pedestrian malls.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Concert
description: Sixten Ehrling, the Swedish conductor who recently resigned after 10 years as music director of the Detroit Symphony, made his debut Friday night in Tully Hall as conductor of the Juilliard Orchestra. Obviously that post entails a good deal more than public appearances, and one will have to wait awhile to see how Mr. Ehrling fares at Juilliard, But by and large Friday's concert was an attractive success.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST homeowners pay little or no attention to the roof on their house until wet spots somewhere on the inside give warning that a leak has developed. Yet an afternoon spent at least once a year inspecting the roof for potential trouble spots and making minor repairs where necessary can often prevent oaks before they start and can serve to postpone the day when expensive professional repairs (or even complate replacement) will be required.

title: Holy Cross Rally Sends Army to 6th Defeat, 1710
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 27Army continued to suffer through some of the worst days in its 84year football history today as the Cadets, within minutes of their first victory of the season, were beaten by Holy Cross, 1710, at Michie Stadium.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: ARTHUR DAILEY, 87, JERSEY CIVIC LEADER
description: Arthur T. Dailey, a founder and chief executive until his retirement in 1952 of the Summit (N. J.) Federal Savings and Loan Association, died Friday pan Delray Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old and also lived in Summit.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed her are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated. as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Mahaffey, L. Graham Lead Golf
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 27 (AP)Lou Graham and John Mahaffey each carded twounderpar 69's today and remained in a tie for the lead after three rounds of the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

title: Gail Lederman Married
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 27  Miss Gail Lederman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lederman of Mount Vernon, was married tonight to Dr. Jerome M. Felsenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Felsenstein of Bellerose, Queens. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison.

title: Unbeaten Notre Dame Sends U.S.C. to First Defeat, 2314
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 27It seemed like old times here today as Notre Dame snapped Southern California's 23game unbeaten streak with a 2314 football victory.

title: Regan Alford Plans December Nuptials
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Dr. and Mrs. T. Crandall Alford of Washington and Emittsburg, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Regan Ann Alford, to William Ray Forrester Jr. of New Orleans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Forrester of Ithaca, N. Y.

title: Arlene Rubin Engaged To Richard P. Shaw
description: Miss Arlene Rubin, a research scientist with the Department of Institutional Research at New York University, and Richard P. Shaw, assistant national product manager with Four Roses Distillers Company, will be married in December.

title: New Lincoln School Names New Director
description: The New Lincoln School, a private coeducational school with a reputation as an experimental laboratory in modern education, has named as its director Collin Reed, who is at present assistant headmaster of the Collegiate school.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: THE Cosmopolitan Chapter of the Photographic Society of America will hold their annual allday photographic show and symposium, PHOTOIN 5 next Sunday, Nov. 4, at the Hotel Commodore, 42d Street and Lexington Avenue, starting at 10 A.M. The opening event will be a print symposium at which each person attending is invited to submit one print (blackand white or color) for comments and critical appraisal by a panel of photographic artists.

title: Julia W. Howe Plans Nuptials
description: GLENCOE, Ill., Oct. 27Mrs. Treadwell Rumi has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Webb Howe, to Benjamin Moore Rowland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Rowland of New Britain, Conn.

title: Hackensack Drops Ridgewood From Ranks of Unbeaten, 1514
description: Hackensack stunned previously undefeated Ridgewood, 1514, at Hackensack, thwarting a twopoint conversion attempt by Ridgewood with three seconds remaining in the game.

title: Nuclear Energy
description: Arab moves this month to slow or cut off the flow of oil to the United States, Western Europe and Japan have sharply focused attention on development of alternative energy sources that could liberate this country from dependence on a demonstrably unreliable source.

title: Priscilla Townsend Wed at Home
description: CROSS RIVER, N. Y., Oct. 27Miss Priscilla Townsend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend, was married here at home this morning to M.C. Van de Workeen. He is the son of Mrs. Ivan Van de Workeen of Northboro, Mass., and the late Mr. Van de Workeen.

title: VOTESIPHON CASE TAKES NEW TURN
description: The cooperation of a key witness and the development of new evidence have brought about a dramatic turn in the Manhattan grand jury investigation of an alleged Republican party votesiphoning scheme, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Texas Tech Tops S.M.U.
description: LUBBOCK, Tex. Oct. 21 27  Joe Barnes baffled Southern Methodist with option runs and accurate passing today to lead Texas Tech to a 3114 Southwest Conference victory.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Say Boy, 9, Killed Man, 45A 9yearold boy id the Bronx stabbed his mother's 45yearold friend to death with a butcher knife early yesterday after the Alan had beaten the boy's older brother, the police reported.

title: Theatrical Tryout Resembles an Encounter
description: GREAT NECK, L. I. You feel as if there's a thick mud seeping into the room, the young man with the soothing voice tells the group around him in the gymnasium of the North Shore Community Arts Center.

title: The Big Powers
description: WASHINGTON  The shock, the drama, the fears and hopes of last week's Middle East developments revealed vividly both the strengths and the limits of the new SovietAmerican detente.

title: Scientist Is Testily New Rural Society Based on Electronics
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 27 The man, who invented the longplaying record, the first, practical color television system, the video tape casette and other revolutionary communications devices is now at work trying to engineer a society of the future.

title: School Financing New Jersey Now Must Find a Different Way
description: TRENTONPublic schools in New Jersey's suburban communities rank among the best in the country. Tenafly, for example, has nearly $80,000 in taxable wealth behind each of its 3,000 students and can spend more than $1,500 annually per student. The facilities are comparatively sumptuous.

title: New & Novel
description: The Mannings By Fred Mustard Stewart. 648 pp. New York: Arbor House. $895.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL AGREETOMEBTING ONTNECEAS&FIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Egypt and Israel agreed early today to negotiate face to face on carrying out the ceasefire along the Suez Canal, the State Department announced.

title: Hobart Triumphs Over Union, 3714
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 27Rick Kowalski, a halfback, ran for 275 yards today and scored three touchdowns as unbeaten Hobart trounced Union, 3714. Jerry Hanley, a halfback, scored twice and ran up 193 yards for the victors.

title: Syracuse Loses, 3423, To Miami
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 27 (UPI)Ed Carney, a quarterback making his first varsity start of the season, sob red one touchdown and passed for another today in leading Miami of Florida to a 3423 victory over Syracuse.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Hamilton
description: A son was born Oct. 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hamilton of New York at the New York Hospital. Mrs. Hamilton, whose husband is a dealer in autographs and owner of the Charles Hamilton Galleries, is the former Miss Diane Brooks. The child has been named for his father.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Certainly the ingredients in ROTTEN WITH HONOR by Derek Robinson (Viking, $6.95) are familiar enough, and have been, ever since that spy who came in from the cold. An inexperienced British agent is assigned to cover a top Russian spy in London. There is a plant in the spy's organization, and soon the plant is dead. Up turns a formula for using water as a means to extract atomic energy. Ordinary tap water nothing esoteric like heavy water.

title: The Excruciating Art of TimetableMaking
description: THE necessity of turning back clocks and watches by one hour today may be a nuisance for the average citizen, but for companies engaged in the transportation business, the expiration of Daylight Saving Time at 2 o'clock this morning is a headache of monumental proportion. That's because the drawing up of timetables, which is ordinarily one of the world's most complex tasks, is made even more difficult at a time like this. The making of timetables was simplified at least to some degree a few years ago when most of the states in this country got together and accepted the last Sunday in April and the last Sunday in October as the days on which to move clocks an hour forward in the spring and an hour backward in the fall (Hawaii, Arizona and parts of Indiana are still holdouts), yet the job has been made immensely more complicated by the speed and range of jet airplanes which flit across time zones as readily as stagecoaches used to cross bridges.

title: Lynn Details HousingSubsidy Plans
description: James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, detailed last week the Nixon Administration's plans for phasing out the major subsidizedhousing programs that the President contends might best be replaced by housing allowancesdirect cash payments to the poor to help them compete in the private housing market.

title: Susan Kamms Fiancee of Eric Seligman
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Oct. 27Mr. and Mrs. S. Peter Kamins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Beth Kamins, to Eric B. Seligman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Seligman of New York and West Palm Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for the spring.

title: Poems in Persons
description: Psychoanalysis and literature have been closely linked ever since Freud borrowed from Sophocles a name for the most famous of his discoveries: the Oedipus complex. Still, Freud himself was a cautious literary critic who once even conceded that unfortunately analysis has to lay down its arms before the problem of the crek tive writer. But the early psychoanalytic critics, less hesitant than their master, systematically combed through the writings of famous authors for evidence of neuroses; such inquiries developed naturally from the romantic conception of the artistic character as being oversensitive or even diseased. Today such diagnoses would be offered much more tentatively, for critics have come to appreciate that literary works provide a peculiarly tenuous and unreliable kind of clinical evidence.

title: Transit Improvement Job
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27, (AP)The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority has been awarded $4,456,872 for major structural improvements, the office of Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican, of Massachusetts, has announced, The improvement will be on the Orange Line elevated structure between Washington Street and Forest Hills.

title: POINT OF VIEW The Trouble With U.S. Exporters
Mayor Says Bipartisan Choices For Bench Are Cynical Deals
description: Mayor Lindsay charged yesterday that deals made by party bosses for bipartisan nomination of judicial candidates represented the most cynical defiance of the integrity of the courts.

title: Passaic Psychologist Aids Rape Unit
description: PASSAICA young New Jersey psychologist is working with the New York City Police Department on a special project that is designed to protect women against tape and to help the victims of actual attacks.

title: Most Units Off Alert, Which May End Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)The Pentagon relieved most of the 1.6 million servicemen in the United States and in the Pacific from emergency alert today, but left key units at the ready in this country and in Europe.

title: Islanders Turn Back Rangers, 32
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 27  How are the mighty fallen ... !

title: Crimson Upset, 2418
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27Dartmouth, always a thorn in the side of Harvard, stunned the favored Crimson with a 2418 triumph on a sunny, windy afternoon today. It was Harvard's first defeat of the season.

title: Less than history and less than fiction
description: Aaron Burr had a career of great variety, excitement and interest. He commanded a regiment in the Revolutionary War; he was a successful New York lawyer; he went high enough in New York politics, then as now distinctly arcane, to become Jefferson's first Vice President. He was still Vice President when he killed his greatest political enemy, Alexander Hamilton, in a duel at Weehawken. This. feat was not well regarded, and Burr was indicted for murder in New Jersey and New York. He continued, however, to preside over the Senate in Washington. Later, after a peculiarly futile expedition down the Mississippi, he was tried for treason on the grounds (probably correct) that he had attempted to detach the West from the Union. It was also possible that he hoped to revolutionize Mexico. He was acquitted on both counts but found it convenient to go abroad for a while. In France, being very hard up, he tried to sell the French Government a scheme for advancing its interests at the expense of the United States. He returned to America, resumed the practice of law, made lot of money, spent more, and died in 1836.

title: Nixon Backers Waver On Their Native Son
description: COSTA. MESA, Calif., Oct. 27Last year, Dale Elmore voted for President Nixon and contributed to his campaign. But last night, following the President's news conference, Mr. Elmore's confidence was badly shaken.

title: Even the Rich Sometimes Forget to Remember
description: The myth, long perpetuated by the fashion magazines, is that the rich and famous move effortlessly among their various houses, forever serene and perfectly equipped, forgetting nothing, their only problem the hauling of small jewel cases with perhaps a favorite sable slung over an arm. Well that, as they say, is a lot of balderdash.

title: Surrealism and fantasy
description: This new book of nine stories by Doris Betts, author of four novels and The Astronomer and Other Stories, is deceptively simple and entertaining on the surface. They resist interpretation the way Wallace Stevens said poems shouldalmost completely. Although liberally laced with elements of the Southern gothic, the grotesque, black humor, surrealism and fantasy, the writing escapes categorization and remains very much an index of one woman's intriguing mind, and the finest fruit of her imagination falls to the reader in a shower of startling images, metaphors, and similes. She is barely forty and her heart does not want to stop; it beats against the cancer like a fist on a landslide. He feels responsible for everything he sees, and started living through a long lens at an early age. She ... slipped between the sheets like an otter going under the surface without a ripple. Even Papa still thinks it was carrying hay bales and feed that gave him his cancer. First he got hernia and then the hernia got mean.

title: Agnew and Sinatra At Same Chicago Hotel
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and Frank Sinatra, the entertainer, are occupying penthouses at a hotel here.

title: National Show Starts Here Tuesday With 4 Equestrian Teams Competing
description: With a strong international field, perhaps the most impressive ever, lined up, the 90th staging of the National Horse Show gets under way for eight days and nights in Madison Square Garden Tuesday.

title: The Ballet: Petruchka
description: When the Joffrey Ballet first revived Petruchka three years ago it was pretty much of a mess. The Alexandre Benois scenery and costumes had been meticulously revived from sketches in the possession of Nikita Lobanov, but the Fokine choreography, revived by Leonide Massine, did not fare so happily.

title: Pamela Taylor Becomes Bride Of H. J. Wilson
description: Miss Pamela Gage Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Gage Taylor of Denver, formerly of Mendham, N. J., was married here yesterday morning to Harold Joseph Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Wilson of Albany.

title: Pitt Rallies To Subdue Navy, 2217
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) Bill Daniels ran 3 yards for a touchdown with 33 seconds to play today as the University of Pittsburgh, which had lost a 160 halftime lead, stormed back to defeat Navy, 2217.

title: Follow the Bouncing Mall
description: Avenue U, Dyckman Street and Steinway Street do not haye quite the chic aura of Madison Avenue. But these neighborhood shopping streets, and 13 others around the five boroughs of New York, were given a chance last week to get something that Madison could never manage: a pedestrian mall.

title: DISPUTE REPORTED ON RELIGIOUS ADS
description: Religion in American Life, the nonprofit organization that promotes interest in religion through advertisements in the national news media, has announced that this year's campaign will be directed to the problem of violence in American society.

title: Arthur Daley Into Proper Perspective
description: Dave Johnson of the Atlanta Braves batted .270 last season and crashed out 43 home runs, a record for second basemen. The previous record of 42 had been set by Rogers Hornsby of the St. Louis Cardinals in 1922 and it lasted slightly more than half a century. But do you know what the Rajah's batting average was the year he set so enduring a mark? Brace yourself for this one. It was .401. That's what it was. Those comparative statistics have stuck in my craw with a nagging persistence ever since the season ended. And this is probably the best outlet for getting rid of assorted pentup feelings. Is there really that much home run magic in an Atlanta ball park that's known as The Launching Pad? When he was with Baltimore, Johnson's homer high was 18, but with Atlanta he actually outhomered Henry Aaron, 43 to 40. They even could kid each other spectral objectives that were ahead of them.

title: Foster Care Rates Up
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27 (AP)State Welfare Commissioner Steven A. Minter has said that weekly board rates for children in the department's foster care program will be increased $3, effective Nov. 17, The payment will go from $18 to $21 for children under 10 and from $22 to $25 for children 10 and older.

title: Wildcats Crushed by Ohio State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 27 (AP)Unbeaten Ohio State, the nation's top  ranked team, scored nine touchdowns in 25 minutes today, crushing Northwestern, 600, to retain a share of the Big Ten lead.

title: Bill Moyers Now Enjoying Pace of Suburban Living
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.In a minor way, it was startling concession, coming as it did from a boyishlooking dynamo who was a White House power at 27 years of age, a bestselling author at 37 and a nationally known television personality at 38. Bill Moyers, a man born to run, has finally learned to walk.

title: Art
description: WALT DISNEY and I parted company one day in 1938, terminating a onesided relationship that had endured for close onto 10 years. It was a quiet separation, heartbreaking for me but hardly noticed by anyone else, least of all by Disney, who was busy at the time following the sensational success of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.

title: Barrancabermeja Or Bust: Looking for Daddy's Oil. Well
description: Pauline Applebaum, heavy with child, kissed her husband goodby and climbed onto the hard boards of the railroad handcar that would take her out of the Colombian jungle to the hospital. Three months later, I was born and lived my early years at the El Centro oil camp,Luisa Applebaum Kriss

title: Somerset Schools to Get Police Advisers
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPA controversial program that will place a municipal police officer on fulltime duty in each of two local schools will be initiated soon in this Somerset County community.

title: A Campaign Warms Up In a SmokeFilled Room
description: In the smokefilled room of Charlie's Dragon Seed, a notsoChinese restaurant with an allAmerican bar in Jackson Heights, Queens, four men campaign for votes among 40 constituents, most of whom have already cast their ballots.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Point of View
description: The ascendancy of the community voice in local decisionmaking is a welcome factor in planning. But an unwelcbme side effect is the failure of some communities to take into consideration the need for industrial development.

title: James Darling, Solo Trumpeter
description: The trumpet, being an aggressive beast by nature, often sounds best when played with restraint  particularly in the context of an exposed solo recital, James Darling, a trumpeter with the Cleveland Orchestra, is just such a tastefully circumspect musician, and he made an excellent case for himself and his in strument Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Anuszkiewicz Has Summit Showcase
