description: SUMMIT  In the early nineteen sixties, when Op art first became fashionable, Richard Anuszkiewicz was hailed as a founder of the genre. Possibly, he would wish to dispense with the title today, for the fad has faded while his art goes on.

title: Increase in Highway Deaths Tied to Lower Drinking Age
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27 (AP)Traffic safety has been hit hard by the Massachusetts action in lowering the legal drinking age to 18 years, the state public safety secretary has charged.

title: Southern Illinois Rises to Top on Nine Shutouts
description: Bob Guelker calls it luck, but everybody else in collegiate soccer agrees it is ability that Guelker's team in Southern Illinois at Edwardsville possesses. Just 19 lucky kids from St. Louis and one from Chicago have done it, Guelker said on Friday.

title: MRS. HENRY K. HEWITT
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27Mrs. Florida Hunt Hewitt, widow of Vice Admiral Henry Kent Hewitt, who commanded United States naval forces in North Africa and at the invasion of Sicily in World War II, died here yesterday at her home. She was 85 years old.

title: Sara Cole Fiancee Of Raul Alvaro Jr.
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Oct. 27Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Ashley Cole of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Elizabeth Cole, to Raul Ferdinand Alvaro Jr., son of Mr. Alvaro of Elizabeth, formerly of Bayano, Cuba, and the late Mrs. Alvaro.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Music
description: WASHINGTON, D. C. FOR too many years, under the unremitting glare of national scrutiny, there existed in Washington an orchestra of such embarrassing mediocrity as to mare one's patriotic blood run cold. Today, that same orchestra has been jolted out of the doldrums and transformed into a respectable group. Only now, in its 43d year, is it perhaps worthy of the title National Symphony. Responsible in the main for the ensemble's much altered course is a 67yearold American of Hungarian birth who, while no firecracker himself, is sort of a miracle worker when it comes to salvaging sinking symphonic ships.

title: Douglas Sandburg Weds Karen Kuhlman
description: PINEVILLE, Pa., Oct. 27The marriage of Miss Karen Louise Kuhlman to Douglas Kent Sandburg, son of Mrs. Raymond T. Sandburg of Rushford Lake, N. Y., and Seminole, Fla., and the late Mr. Sandburg, took place here this afternoon.

title: Miss Joan Sullivan Is Married To Lawrence Richard Lynch
description: RUMSON, N. J., Oct. 27Miss Joan Elaine Sullivan and Lawrence Richard Lynch were married here this afternoon in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church by the bride's uncle, Msgr. Herman L. Heide Jr.

title: TASK FORCE ASKS HEALTIT CARE PLAN
description: Farreaching revision of city health programs has been urged by a 60member task force of the Community Council of Greater New York, which said hundreds of millions of dollars were spent annually without commensurate public accountability.

title: Merchants Go Electronic
description: A new generation of cash register, built to answer a host of important questions that merchants previously could not even ask, is swiftly moving to the center of the retailing scene.

title: The question was, is and will be: Who owns Palestine?
description: After the latest events in the Middle East There Could Have Been Peace scarcely seems the most promising title for a historical study of the ArabIsrael dispute. Could there really?the prospective reader might well murmur skeptically; and turn on to more realistic, or more apposite, fare.

title: E. MERRILL ROOT, POET, 78, IS DEAD
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Oct. 27E. Merrill Root, who once was described by Robert Frost as the second best poet in America, died yesterday in the Maine Medical Center, Portland. He was 78 years old.

title: $10Million Clinic in Manhasset Emphasizes Preventive Medicine
description: MANHASSET, L.I.North Shore University Hospital's $10million Levitt Clinic, which will serve some fivemillion residents and 4,500 physicians from areas in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, will officially be dedicated here today.

title: Long Beach Race Pits Two Old Allies
description: LONG. BEACH, L. I.Two old allies in the battle to rid this city of its onetime Democratic machine are competing against each other to represent the city in county governmentnow that the machine has been toppled.

title: Paradise Lost The Decline of the AutoIndustrial Age. By Emma Rothschild. 253 pp. New York: Random House. $6.95.
description: 1. General Motors reported $2.16billion total profit in its last annual report, but the roof of its Lordstown plant still leaks.

title: Being a great power is no longer fun
description: Defeat, which is the major part of Stuart Loory's title, is also the moral import of the Southeast Asian war, whatever our leaders may tell us to the contrary. Though relatively unfamiliar to Americans, defeat is known to countries in other parts of the world, some of whom are demonstrably better off for the experience. Even by pragmatic test, defeat has its merits, i.e., it proves that somebody did something wrong, which in turn means that we can do something better.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: KUWAIT, QATAR, BAHRAIN AND DUBAI announced a total embargo of oil to the United States, joining the embargo of Saudi Arabia, Libya, Abu Dhabi and Algeria. The moves made the cutoff of Arab oil to the US. theoretically complete. . . . The world's flow of oil from the Mideast has been reduced by four million barrels a day. . . Commerce Secretary Frederick B. Dent urged businesses to conserve energy. . . . A HouseSenate conference committee amended the Alaskan pipeline bill in a way that Administration officials say will lead to large increases in the prices of heating oil and gasoline. . . . John A. Love, director of the Energy Policy Office, met with Canadian officials the search for oil and natural gas resources.

title: HawkViewing: Useful Fun
description: UPPER NYACK, N. Y. From the convenience of a folding beach chair perched atop windswept, 700foothigh Hook Mountain, Eric W. Single, a resident of this Rockland County community, sits and count hawks.

title: Both Clubs in Slump
Dempsey Rallies Rye to 1413 Verdict
description: Taking advantage of a costly turnover late in the game, Rye kept its 14game unbeaten streak intact yesterday with a 1413 triumph over previously undefeated Westlake.

title: The way of the activist is hard
description: Widespread guru worshipping, thriving food and body cults, and a fashionable and aggressive devotion to passivity are once again bearing out the truth that periods of intense political activity are usually followed by periods of cultural backlash, often on the part of some of the people who have waged the activity most intensely. The phenomenon is disturbing, because it seems to indicate that political commitment for the middle classes is bound up more closely to matters of happinessthroughselfdeprivation followed by plenty of happinessthroughselffulfillment than it is bound up with ideology. These days, in fact, it wouldn't surprise me if The Roots of Ideology turned out to be a beautifully illustrated book about organic gardening. It's not necessarily unfortunate, however, that this novel, set on the New Left of the late 1960'sby the editor of this Book Review and the author of three previous novels appears in this atmosphere, for the problems it raises are not actually political ones.

title: Rutgers Aide Traces Black Cabinet
description: NEW BRUNSWICKIt was during the Presidential campaign of 1932 that Robert C. Weaver, who three decades later became the first black to serve in a President's Cabinet, received a telephone call at his home in Washington.

title: Papillon Is Best at Queensboro
description: Is was Tom Glassford Day at the Queensboro Kennel Club's 47th show here yesterday. Three of the six dogs in the final had been gaited to their group victories by the redhaired handler from Chester Springs, Pa.

title: 14 Seized in Gambling Raids
description: DARTMOUTH, Mass., Oct. 27 (AP)  State police officers equipped with crowbars and axes arrested 14 persons in 26 gambling raids in seven Massachusetts communities today, the attorney general's oflice said.

title: Azzolina Is in Trouble in Reelection Bid
description: MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP State Senator Joseph Azzolina, the Legislature's foremost proponent of capital punishment and a Republican political power in Monmouth County, is in trouble in his battle for reelection.

title: AROUND THE
description: Continue planting.... Keep the hose out... Rake leaves; compost.... Gather nuts.

title: Gala Is Scheduled By Opera Theater
description: NEWARK  The Opera Theater of New Jersey will launch its eighth season next Sunday with a fundraising gala at Symphony Hall. The opening presentation will be Cilea's Adriana Lecouvreur, starring Magda Olivero, cido Domingo and Maria Louisa Nave.

title: From Walter Matthau to Izzy Stone
description: A FILM criticisn't supposed to like too many films. It gives him a bad reputation with his peers, with taxicab drivers (who don't go to movies but know they're all lousy anyway), even with movie producers, a lot of whom are compulsive gamblers: they need to fail. They figure there must be something wrong with the critic who likes their films. You give a producer a compliment and it's likely to worry him all night.

title: TOP BLACK WOMAN IS OUSTED BY NASA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has dismissed its highest ranking black female official in a dispute over equal employment.

title: LAWYERS QUERY GRAND JURY ROLE
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Oct. 27Though only one person has been called to testify in the last 10 minths, Robert K. Meisel Jr. remains in prison for refusing to talk to a Federal grand jury about a purported conspiracy among law enforcement officials and other individuals in Butte, Mont., to aid in the illegal shipment of arms to the Irish Republican Army.

title: Island Trees Leaves For Want of a Doctor
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., Oct. 27 Levittown Division, sitting on top of Nassau North Shore Division II, had to feel a little sick after the goingson that took place against Island Trees today.

title: Mongol Conversion
description: HUHEHOT, Inner MongoliaIn 1570 a shrewd Chinese statesman named Wan Chunhu sent a memorandum to Emperor Lung Ching suggesting that the way to handle the menace of the warlike Mongolians to the north was by converting them to Buddhism.

title: Brooklyn Woman, 18, Is Slain; Husband, 20, Is Hurt Seriously
description: An 18yearold woman was found beaten to death and her 20yearold husband lying unconscious with a fractured skull yesterday in the East New York district of Brooklyn.

title: David R. Ross Fiance of Helen T. Frank
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Oct. 27Miss Helen Tiffany Frank and David Richard Ross plan to be married Jan. 12. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Norman Lindsley Davidson, stepfather and mother of the future bride whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ross of Pearl River, N. Y.

title: Bundy, Lodge Help Groton Rout Gov. Dumtner, 566
description: GROTON, Mass., Oct. 27Bill Bundy's running and Cabot Lodge's passing paced Groton to a 566 rout of Gov. bummer today. It was the fourth straight victory for Groton, which dropped its season to St. Paul's

title: Teamsters to Pay $220,000 To End Sniping Death Case
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 27 (AP)The teamsters union has agreed to pay $220,000 to the widow and the estate of John Galt, who was killed in a truck sniping incident during a labor dispute three years ago. Attorneys in the case announced the settlement Wednesday.

title: A.B.A. CRITICIZES WATERGATE PLAN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 27  The American Bar Association, saying that it could not accept the appointment of another special Watergate prosecutor by the Nixon Administration, called upon Congress today to create an independent Office of Special Proscutor to carry forward the Watergate inquiry.

title: The Mayoral Wars
description: The showpiece in Abraham B. Beame's array of mayoral campaign literature is a handout which features bn its Over a photograph reminiscent of a family album  a child of almost 60 years ago with his hair slicked down to a patent leather sheen.

title: WARREN CLARK
description: MYSTIC, Conn., Oct. 27Warren Clark, who retired in 1968 as a Partner in Brundage, Story & Rose, New York investment counsel, died here Wednesday. He was 73 years old and formerly lived in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: TALKS WILL BEGIN ON POLAR BEARS
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct 27 (Reuters)A fivenation conference is due to get under way here next month in an attempt to draw up an international agreement that will preserve the dwindling numbers of one of the earth's largest land creatures, the polar bear.

title: No tricks, just treats
description: Halloween is here again with toothy pumpkin faces, witches on broomsticks and small fry knocking at the door to deliver shy trickortreat ultimata. And there is still time to make these homemade treats. The glistening cinnamon candies and soft coconut balls will please the young, and the chocolateliqueur balls will be a treat for their grownup escorts.

title: Bit by Bit He Builds a Mansion
description: With a little of this and a little of that, a new old home rose in Dutchess County

title: Nation's Doctors Move To Police Medical Care
description: STOCKTON, Calif.  American doctors are quietly but quickly developing a new nationwide system to police the quality and cost of the medical care they dispense.

title: Otilio Ulate Blanco Is Dead; Former Costa Rican President
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 27 (UPI)  Former President Otilio Ulate Blanco died today in San Juan de Dios Hospital. His age was 82. He suffered a stroke two weeks ago.

title: After the Confrontation
description: President Nixon last week defined the SovietAmerican crisis over the Middle East as the most difficult... since the Cuban confrontation of 1962. It does not seem an unjust appraisaldespite Secretary Kissinger's diplomatic denialthat at the height of the American military alert the United States and the Soviet Union were indeed in a most serious confrontation. The evidence to date suggests that Moscow was moving toward dispatch thousands of its troops unilaterally into the Middle East. It was deterred apparently by the most serious warnings from Washington and also by the availability of the United Nations as an international meeting place where generally satisfactory arrangement for enforcing the Middle East ceasefire was successfully negotiated.

title: N. Babylon Wins Title, 1312
description: North Babylon became the first Suffolk team to win league championship, the first for the Bulldogs in 14 years, in a 1312 AA1, victory over defending champion Lindenhurst yesterday.

title: Terrariums Are Terrific With Miniatures
description: A GROW  EVERYTHING gardener, Mrs. Andrew Messick has a special knack with miniature plants. Perhaps her love of rock gardening inspired her talent for fitting little plants into terrariums. With deft hands she transforms bottles, pitchers, plastic cubes, aquariums and jugs into delightful tiny gardens.

title: Planned Towers in Dispute in Queens
description: For many suburban comrnunities, the steady influx of city dwellers has been a boon bringing with it only a hint of future problems. But along the North Shore of Queens, many residents are convinced a crisis has already arrived.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Wily Pickerel
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.H.Two black ducks burst from a small cove on the north shore of McDaniel's marsh and were soon lost sight of against the dark, ragged, rainbearing clouds that hung overhead all day.

title: Martin Foster In Violin Recital
description: In what looked like a bit of sleightofhand, the first performer to be presented this fall by Carnegie HallJeunesses Musicales in its International Artists Series was Martin Foster, who graduated from Juilliard this year. The 22yearold violinist is, however, Englishborn and Canadianreared. He studied in Montreal before coming to New York to work with Dorothy Delay.

title: thee traveler's world
description: IF you enjoy watching a new movie on a long plane trip, you can thank Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca, Uncle Miltie Berle, Ed Sullivanand David Flexer. Berle and the other television stars of the fifties emptied the country's movie houses of paying customers and then the television networks bought up all the old movies and people sat up late raving about films they wouldn't pay to see when they were at firstrun downtown houses.

title: The now look
2 GROUPS SEEKING A FIREHOUSE HERE
description: A Board of Estimate decision on the fate of a former firehouse at 243 West 20th Street, now used by the Women's Liberation Center but wanted by people in Chelsea for a community counseling program has been postponed indefinitely.

title: Publisher to Leave Post At Cincinnati Enquirer
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 27 (AP)Francis L, Dale, 52 years old, president and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer since 1965, will step down Wednesday.

title: Democrats Vote to Abolish '72 Quotas for Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) The Democratic party's reform commission unanimously approved today new delegate selection guidelines eliminating the socalled quotas that caused a deep party division last year.

title: WOMAN, 79, SHOT VISITING A GRAVE
description: A 79yearold woman visiting a family gravesite in Brooklyn was shot and robbed yesterday by one of three youths she yelled at for pushing her 80yearold husband down and robbing him, the police said.

title: $11 Prove Out Wins; Riva Ridge Is Last
description: Meadow Stable's $11.2million weekend farewell party got off to a disastrous start at Aqueduct yesterday when favored Riva Ridge came up empty in the $110,100 Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: Lynn Franklin Bride
description: Miss Lynn Franklin, daughter of Mrs. Robert J. Franklin of East Brunswick, N. J., and the late Mr. Franklin, was married here yesterday evening to Samuel S. Seward 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seward 3d of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. H. Leslie Christie of the Marble Collegiate Church performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS SAY SANDMAN IS FACING A MAJOR DEFEAT
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27Many of New Jersey's top Republican leaders conceded today that Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s campaign for Governor had floundered badly and that he and the G.O.P. appeared headed for a major defeat in the elections a week from Tuesday.

title: Democrats Hopeful In Bay Ridge Vote
description: True to their ancestral urgings, the Irish and Italians of Bay Ridge register themselves politically as Democrats. Oftenunhappily for the Democratic organization that is the last support the party gets from them.

title: Nina Congdon to Be Married To Nicholas Thayer, an Artist
description: CROSS RIVER, N. Y., Oct. 27Mr. and Mrs. James Buffum Congdon of Cross River have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Hurd Congdon to Nicholas Thayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Otis Thayer of Katonah and Ipswich, Mass.

title: Late Spree by Maryland Overwhelms Duke, 3010
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 27 (UPI)Louis Carter, a tailback, passed for two touchdowns and ran for another today as Maryland whipped Duke, 3010.

title: Court Bars TeenAger From Donating Kidney
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27. (UPI)A state appeals court ruling that Louisiana law prevents a minor from donating private property has stopped a retarded teenager from given one of his kidneys to an ailing sister dispite parental consent.

title: British Pianist Plays MacDowell
description: Edward MacDowell (1861 1908) may seem like something of a lost cause to most American musicians. Not, however, to Clive Lythgoe, a young British pianist who made his New York recital debut Wednesday night in Town Hall with a concert entirely devoted to MacDowell's music.

title: Repair Guide for Worn Out Bottle Gardens
description: WITH some repairs last season's terrarium can look like new again. How long a terrarium lasts depends on how well, and with what it was planted, and where it was placed.

title: Committees of Council Plan Public Hearings
description: The following open hearings of City Council committees will be held this week:

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN rather uncharacteristic fashion, the financial markets in the United States have shrugged offalmost casuallythe dramatic and historic developments in the political and international realm the last few weeks, maintaining an almost serene composure.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market turned in a very strong performance last week. The DowJones industrial average finished its highest level in more than eight months.

title: Sunnyside Complex May Be Sidetracked
description: A highpowered proposal to create a massive sports complex over the Sunnyside rail yards in Queens may find itself switched to a side track if opponents can get their hands on the controls.

title: Formal Admission Of Women Studied By a Male College
description: Haverford College, a small male liberal arts college near Philadelphia, may expand and become fully coeducational in the coming year.

title: Fischer Is Challenging Spassky to a Rematch
description: MANILA, Oct. 29 (AP) Bobby Fischer said today that even though he was the world chess champion, he wanted to challenge Boris Spassky to a rematch to end reports that he was resigning.

title: BUETENS, LUTENIST, PLAYS ENGLISH AIRS
description: Stanley Buetens, lutenist in residence at the University of California, Los Angeles, and author of the widely used Method for the Renaissance Lute, gave a recital of old English airs at Town Hall Friday night. Undoubtedly aware of the difficulty in maintaining interest within so limited a repertory, Mr. Buetens chose likable pieces, kept the program unusually short (scarcely more than an hour overall, including intermission and encores), and devoted most of the second half to luteaccompanied vocal performances.

title: HEAD OF HOSPITAL QUITS IN DISPUTE
description: Stanley Salmen, who has been the target of some bitter criticism as president of the French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center as a result of the institution's bankruptcy and failure to convert the former New Yorker Hotel into a health center, has resigned because of personal reasons.

title: School Rolls Are Declining
description: TRENTONState agencies that deal with education say that enrollment in the public schools has reached its peak and will decline by at least 30,000 pupils by the end of this decade, a view that is in line with national predictions.

title: Col. Oleg Pantuhoff, Served In Russian Imperial Guard
description: Col. Oleg I. Pantuhoff, a member of the former Russian Imperial Guard and, in 1909, a founder of the Russian Boy Scouts, died Thursday in Nice, France, at the age of 91. He lived in France, but was a United States citizen half his life.

title: Death on the Turnpike: What Is the Answer?
description: NEWARK  One again, authorities are investigating the causes of a gruesome series of accidents on the New Jersey Turnpike  a night of carnage last week raised the highway's 1973 death toll to record 70  but perhaps any regular driver has. the answer.

title: McCarthy Tries Minnesota Comeback
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 27 Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy has made a fourday tour of Minnesota's sixth Congressional District to assess his chances of making a political comeback next year in the House of Representatives.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Who needs prepaid legal insurance for assistance to tenants in tenantlandlord disputes [Prepaid Legal Services Pressed, Sept. 9]? In our city the tenants' rights are protected by law.

title: Honest as an Oak
description: This is the time to appreciate the oaks, those sturdy trees of solid fiber and enduring virtues. We see them standing out in the woodlands now, as the lesser trees drop their more vivid colors and can be seen in their true dimensions. There is a tough, leathery texture to the oak's leaves, as there is a tough and gnarly texture to the tree's bark and fiber. It holds its leaves as some men hold their virtues.

title: Belgrade, Worried by Mideast, Calls Units, Holds War Games
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 27  Worried about possible repercussions from the Middle East conflict, Yugoslavia sent thousands of troops and armed civilians into action today against an enemy on fogcovered slopes southwest of Belgrade.

title: COUNCIL APPROVES WALDHEIM REPORT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27The United Nations Security Council tonight approved, by a vote of 14 to 1, arrangements for a 7,000man emergency peace force from small countries to serve as a buffer between Egyptian and Israeli forces to prevent a resumption of fighting.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Once they were the New York football Giants' most flamboyant playersFran Tarkenton, the inventive quarterback, and Fred Dryer, half beach boy and half defensive end. But shortly after the 1971 season, they were banished by Wellington Mara, primarily because the Giants' owner considered each too individualistic for the Giants' corporate image. Tarkenton was traded to the Minnesota Vikings, Dryer to the New England Patriots, who then dispatched him to the Los Angeles Rams. Each was virtually forgotten last season as the Giants produced a respectable 86 wonlost record. Out of sight, out of mind. Especially with both the Vikings and the Rams out of the National Football League playoffs.

title: Herricks Stuns Syosset in Last Minute
description: The biggest upset of the Nassau County season took place yesterday when Herricks scored with 23 seconds remaining to beat previously undefeated Syosset, 1816, in a North Shore Division I game at Syosset.

title: Elizabeth Wrightson Ramsing Fiancee of Donald C. Byrne
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 27Miss Elizabeth Wrightson Ramsing, a greatgreatgranddaughter of George Huntington Hartford, founder of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, will be married to Donald Coleman Byrne next May.

title: What's Doing in San Francisco
description: SUNDOWN  There is one surpassing distinction that this city enjoys: its stupendously beautiful setting. Except for a soggy period of intermittent rain that usually comes between midNovember and midFebruary, the air here is swept clean by winds off the Pacific and the sun twinkles down on San Francisco Bay, which is glimpsed in aching beauty at almost every turn in any street. Ever since my first days here I have found it restoring to sit in the Fairmont Hotel's Crown Room or the Top of the Mark at the Mark Hopkins Hotel, both on Nob Hill, and watch night come to the city. Somewhat the same effect can be had at ground level at the Buena Vista, a swinging bar at 2765 Hyde Street, where you can buy oldfashioned steam beer. If weather permits you to see the Golden Gate Bridge, you will watch the fog drift through its towers, finally cloaking them perhaps, and then creep across the city to envelop Coit Tower on Telegraph Hill, hide Alcatraz Island and cover the tops of the financial district's towers. If you look to the south, you can see rows of traffic lights winding down the peninsula on which the city stands to Palo Alto and San Jose, while to the east traffic between Oakland and Sah Francisco fills the Bay Bridge. There, below you, the city waits, beginning to pulsate with night noises.

title: McCarthy of All Hallows Wins in CrossCountry
description: Gene McCarthy extended his unbeaten streak and upstate schools dominated the team scoring yesterday in the Fordham University Eastern. interscholastic crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: The General Motors Maverick
description: DETROIT  To hear John Z. DeLorean tell it, there's no problem in quitting a $650,000ayear job because you can live easily on just 10 per cent of that.

title: Deerfield Ground Game Upsets Andover, 2421
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 27 Richie Zink scored three touchdowns today in Deerfield's 2421 upset victory over previously undefeated Andover. Zink rushed for 155 yards in 22 carries while a teammate, Reggie Nalley, carried 18 times for 120 yards. Deerfield's record is 32.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The public is buying lessand stealing more  these days, confounding strenuous efforts of many retailers to reduce losses from shrinkages in inventory.

title: UConn Sets Back UMass by 286
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 27 (AP)Eric Torkelson ran for two touchdowns in the second quarter as Connecticut tightened its grip on the Yankee Conference lead with a 28.6 victory over Massachusetts today.

title: Woman, 71 Back in the Fight
description: NEW BRUNSWICK When the Middlesex County Planned Parenthood Association lost its president recently, it called on a 71yearold former president to take over.

title: CholeraCausing Organism Eradicated in Texas Area
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 47 (UPI) The National Center for Disease Control said today that it was satisfied that a choleracausing organism in southern Texas had been eradicated and that there was no danger of the disease's spreading.

title: Mark O. Winkelman Marries Miss Dorinda Cruickshank
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 27Miss Dorinda Townsend Pell Cruickshank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Cruickshank of Wellesley Hills, was married here this afternoon to Mark Otto Winkelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marius Otto Winkelman of Utrecht, the Netherlands. The Rev. Lauren F. Flewelling performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Rumanian Official Reported Executed for BribeTaking
description: VIENNA, Oct. 27 (Reuters)A Rumanian Government official has been executed after being found guilty of taking bribes from foreign businessmen, according to the Rumanian press.

title: Farmwife Sells Wool, Loomsand Lessons in Weaving
description: MARTINSVILLEA farmer's daughter in this rural Somerset County town has added a new twist to her father's farm food salesthe weaving of her own sheep's wool. She not only sells the yarn, the looms and the finished wool apparel, but the weaving knowhow as well.

title: Creative Diplomacy
description: A lasting peace agreement in the Middle East is possible. It must be based on the Security Council resolution of Nov. 22, 1967, but with a whole new set of guarantees for the security of Israel.

title: In St. Louis, They May Be Setting a Precedent
description: HELPED a $50,000 grant from thee Ford Foundation, the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra has organized its own chamber  music series and thereby may be setting a precedent. Many symphony orchestras have their small complements of players who go out on their own to perform chamber music. Some orchestras, during periods in residence at a college, will break up into small units to teach and perform. But for a major ensemble to produce concerts of chamber music, except as a special offering to elite subscribers, is believed to be new.

title: Headliners
description: Tho Says No The 1973 Nobel Peace Prize situation, controversial from the start, was thrown into further confusion last week when Le Due Tho of North Vietnam rejected his share of the award won jointly with Secretary of State Henry Kissinger for their negotiation of the Vietnam ceasefire agreement. Mr. Tho said, Peace has not yet really been established. His action reflected Hanoi's view that the United States is responsible for the continued fighting in South Vietnam. Two of the five members of the prize selection committee have resigned in protest against the joint award, and it was not immediately clear whether the committee now would leave Mr. Kissinger as the sole recipient. Meanwhile, the Physics. Prize was awarded to Ivar Giaever and Leo Esaki, both working for American companies, and Brian D. Josephson of Britain; and the Chemistry Prize went to Ernest Otto Fischer of Germany and Geoffrey Wilkinson of Britain.

title: A Comment on the Week
description: Confrontation. Withdrawal. Confrontation again.That was the pattern set by Richard M. Nixonin the week of his greatest crisis to datesurelyone of the most anxious weeks in the history ofthe American Presidency.

title: The Small Powers
description: TEL AVIV  It may not be very tidy, an Israeli general observed as he traced on a map the meandering forward lines now held by Israeli forces on both sides of the Suez Canal, but it gives us the political and military leverage we need.

title: Ramsey Clark Scores U.S. Supreme Court's Rulings on Sex and Pornography
description: What, after all, is wrong with hot sense, asked Ramsay Clark, the former Attorney General, quoting a Thomas Mann phrase at a symposium on sex, the law and the citizen sponsored by the Sex Informad tion and Educational Council the U.S.

title: Chronicle of an Arctic Whale Hunt
description: SATURDAY, Aug. 25There is only one customs officer on duty in Winnipeg and he is not amused. Before him, the customs officer in Vancouver took one look at our gear and passed it, presuming that the Winnipeg man would have more time to cope with such craziness. But now the Winnipeg man is perturbed by our two portable swimming pools. I would think, he announces icily, that as long as there are only six of you, one pool would be enough. We explain that the pools will hold the whales we plan to capture in Hudson Baytwo whales to a pool. It turns out, however, that our whalecatching permits from the Canadian Government don't carry any weight with customs. We may proceed, the man says, but our scientific equipment for testing and treating whales must stay behind until the appropriate ministries can scrutinize it. Bill Flynn, a veteran aquarium curator and leader of our expedition, tells us not to panic. He has been on two previous white whale hunts and nothing went right on those expeditions either.

title: Luxury Housing Expands on West Side
description: The march of luxury residential construction and rehabilitation northward from Lincoln Center has reached a point north of 72d Street, more than halfway to the West Side Urban Renewal Area.

title: Playing can be painful North Dallas Forty By Peter Gent. 314 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $7.95.
description: What are you so scared of? Seth Maxwell, the quarterback of North Dallas Forty, asks Phil Elliott, who doubles as wide receiver and narrator.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 27 (AP)Heavier than expected cuts in Arab oil production already have reduced output more than 4 million barrels a day, or by about 20 per cent, the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: Bridge
description: Eight deals of bridge in an evening might not seem enough for most enthusiasts. But it was a highly satisfying achievement for a few residents of the Hanoi Hilton in recent years. If you are in a twoman cell with one opponent, and your partner and your other opponent are in an adjoining cell, and communication is largely by means of a tap code, it is clear that the dealing alone must be a slow business and misdeals occur frequently.

title: School Integration
description: TOPEKA, Kan.Ahnost 20 years since the Supreme Court ruled that school segregation was unconstitutional there still is no clear legal consensus on what constitutes genuine desegregation, and thousands of classrooms throughout the country are still not integrated.

title: Kasia Baker Has Nuptials
description: Miss Kasia Baker and Andrzej Bartkowiak, both of New York, were married here yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Halberstam. The Rev. Boris Erwitt, a Buddhist monk, performed the ceremony.

title: Westfield Blunts Nutley Drive in 00 Tie Cedar
description: A goalline stand in the closing minutes yesterday saved New Jersey's longest unbeaten streak before a crowd of 10,000 in Nutley.

title: CANDIDATES SCORE CON EDISON. PLANS
description: Two mayoral candidates sharply criticized the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday for buying highsulphur fuel oil that would add to the city air pollution.

title: 2 Scientists Honored By Planned Parenthood
description: The Planned Parenthood Federation of America presented its highest award yesterday to Dr. Christopher Tietze and Sarah Lewit, husbandandwife team of social scientists, for their research in birth control.

title: Braille Being Tested as Tool for Sighted
description: SOUTH BRUNSWICK TOWNSHIPA blind instrucfor is preparing to teach 15 sighted South Brunswick youngsters to read Braille as part of a federally funded experiment in reading instruction.

title: Newark State Gets a New Name: Kean
description: TRENTON  The state's Board of Higher Education has approved a name change whereby Newark State College at Union is now Kean College of New Jersey. The college occupies part of what was once the Hamilton Fish Kean estate on Morris Avenue in Union.

title: Chess: Soviet Championship Offers A Stellar Talent Aggregation
description: The prestige of several national championships has declined in recent years, principally because the leading players, who ought to be participating, prefer the greater glory of winning international tournaments abroad.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Lunia
description: A daughter was born Oct. 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Pakhraj C. Lunia in the New York University Hospital. Mrs. Lunia is the former Miss Ratna Anchlia of Bikaner, India. The child is named Anupma.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ill.  He earns $200,000 a year, raises quarter horses on a working farm, heads the world's largest auto insurer and serves as president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.But anyone who talks to Edward B. Rust, president of the $2.8billion State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, very quickly discovers that he is anything but an ordinary company president.

title: Silhouettes and souvenirs
description: In the years since 1965, when In Cold Blood was published to much excitement and latenight fingernail bitingan odd, not to say nasty, cloud seems to have settled on Truman Capote's reputation as a writer.

title: Women Get Instruction On Politics
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.Colleges have long had writers, poets, dramatists and artists in residence. But Douglass College here has politicians in residence women politicians at thatwho live in a dormitory and teach a popular course designed to get women away from the stamplicking and coffeemaking side of politics and into the roughand tumble world of male egos and backroom bargaining.

title: Kidnapped Baby Is Returned Unharmed
description: A 24yearold former nurse's aide was charged yesterday with kidnapping an infant boy from Unity Hospital in Brooklyn 11 days ago after she brought the child unharmed into a police station late Friday night.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Denver Foe at Shea
description: For the first pro football weekend since Dec. 17, 1972, the Jets did not fly to another city yesterday, did not work out in someone else's stadium and did not sleep at a hotel.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from mono than 250 book stores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the right Rand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Indiana Paper Purchased
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 27 (UPI)Freedom Newspapers Inc. announced today the purchase of The Seymour (Ind.) Tribune, an afternoon daily with 10,000 circulation. Freeddom Newspapers in nine states now has combined daily circulation in excess of 600,000.

title: . . . While the Philharmonic pickets sound their own note of protest
description: IS it too much to hope that our musical institutions will actually learn something from the musicians' strikes that have blighted the present concert and opera season and threaten to mar the ballet, as well? A lot of the public would like to tell management, as well as union: You are not associated with Exxon or G.M. or some similar monster of Free Enterprise that can recover from a series of crippling strikes, as naturally as a bear from hibernation to continue producing for a market so massive it absorbs every increased costyou are part of a fragile, deficitriddled cultural necessity that is sustained by esprit de corps, luck and the taxfavored generosity of a comparative few. Sinewy labor machismo or lofty managerial indifference will only destruction.

title: VidalAnother Opinion
description: It's time once again to take exception to a review  in this instance, George Dangerfield's review of the new Gore Vidal novel (Page 2). Really, Burr is wicked entertainment of a very high order. But first a few words on history and fiction.

title: Vietcong Charge 20,000 G.I.'s Remain
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27The Vietcong charged today that the United States had violated the Paris peace agreement by leaving nearly 20,000 military personnel in civilian guise to oversee combat operations by South Vietnamese forces.

title: Is it useful? Is it just? Or is it only cruel?
description: Last year the United States Supreme Court, by a vote of 5 to 4, held that the death penalty as then imposed was a cruel and unusual punishment and thus a violation of the Eighth Amendment to the Copstitution. Not everyone could agree on what the Court meant to sayeach of the nine Justices wrote a separate opinionbut many concluded that the Court's chief objection was to the arbitrary and capricious imposition of the death penalty. Thus many inferred that the Court might accept a law that made the death penalty automatic for specified crimes. President Nixon in March of this year submitted to Congress a proposal that would authorize the imposition of the death penalty under fairly clear standards for certain Federal offenses (for example, warrelated treason, sabotage and espionage, and particular crimes from which victims die). Hearings were held before the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Criminal Laws in April and May on both the Nixon bill and a similar one submitted by Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, and others.

title: Knicks, Led By Jackson, Down 76ers
description: Phil Jackson, playing in place of the injured Dave DeBusschere, came up with what were probably his finest 12 minutes of professional basketball last night to lift the Knicks to an unexpectedly difficult 9690 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Jean Marie Sinnott Bride of Francis James Sheerin
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 27  St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jean Marie Sinnott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Martin Sinnott of Larchmont, to Francis James Sheerin, an assistant United States attorney, son of Francis A. Sheerin of Garden City, L. I., and the late Mrs. Sheerin.

title: Brownstoners Fair Attended by 2,000.
description: A week ago yesterday, more than 2,000 people flocked to the Bossert Hotel in Brooklyn Heights, to view the Brownstone Fair sponsored by the Brooklyn Brownstone Conference.

title: Fordham Wins From Jaspers
description: Fordham's varsity football team scored two touchdowns in the second half to defeat Manhattan's club eleven, 28 to 20, yesterday in their annual Bronx battle at Jack Coffey Field.

title: Tulsa Press Saves Paper
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 27 (UPI) This city will be without newspapers this year on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day because of newsprint shortages. The Tulsa Daily World and The Tulsa Tribune said that the action was a move to conserve dwindling supplies of Newsprint.

title: Stamps
description: COLLECTORS of American stamps had better start saving their pennies, for it seems certain there will be many new stamps acoming and they will be costing more.

title: Other N. J. Scores
Former Aides to Cox Striving To Retain Their Independence
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 James S. Doyle, chief information officer for the Watergate Special Prosecution Force, was snarling at the man from the. Justice Department.

title: Stanford Is 4514 Victor; Boryla Star
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 27 (AP)Mike Boryla broke a Stanford record today by throwing five touchdown passes, including two in the opening minutes, and the Cardinals trounced Washington State 45 to 14 in a Pacific8 football game.

title: Helping Count Big Macs Better
description: The hungry customer orders two Big Macs, French fries and a chocolate shake. The MacDonald's cashier makes three quick circles with an electronic stylus on the tablet of a small computer terminal.

title: Christine Waterbury Sets Nuptials
description: WALLINGFORD, Pa., Oct. 27  Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Myers Waterbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Orr. Waterbury, to Peter James Dearnaley of London.

title: AGED JEWS CALL CONEY A JUNGLE
description: A cityfinanced study asserts that fear and terror paralyze the perilous existence of thousands of Jewish senior citizens in Coney Island.

title: DISCIPLES OF CHRIST ELECT PRESIDENT
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 27 (AP)With one dissenting vote, more than 5,000 members of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) today elected Dr. Kenneth L. Teegarden of Fort Worth as the denomination's new general minister and president.

title: Letters
Taylor Named to Post By State Racing Board
description: Robert H. Taylor, who protected Presidents Truman, Eisenhower, Johnson and Nixon during 23 years as a member of the United States Secret Service, was named director of operations yesterday. by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A commercial site at the northeast corner of 125th Street and Eighth Avenue in Harlem has been acquired by the Harlem Commonwealth Council in conjunction with the Freedom National Bank for eventual development as an office building and store complex.

title: B. C. Wins 117, From Villanova
description: NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 27 (AP)Mike Esposito ran for 161 yards and scored the decisive touchdown late in the third period today as Boston College defeated Villanova, 117.

title: Bellmore Kennedy Wins Battle of Unbeatens, 1412
description: Bellmore Kennedy, which couldn't win anything last season, is taking everything in Nassau South Shore Division I this year. Yesterday the boys from J.F.K. knocked off unbeaten Massapequa, 1412. The victory gave Bellmore Kennedy a 50 wonlost record and first place.

title: The Dialectical Imagination
description: In the past few months several American publishers have issued translations of major works by members of the legendary Institute of Social Research in Frankfurt, Germany. Although the Institute's classic study The Authoritarian Personality by Theodor Adorno and others has been in print for years, few if any of their other books have been available in English. Now Herder & Herder have brought out Max Horkheimer's Critical Theory and Horkheimer and Adorno's Dialectic of Enlightenment; the Seabury Press has published Adorno's Negative Dialectics; and Beacon Press, which has for years been loyally publishing the work of the only well  known member of the Frankfurt school, Herbert Marcuse, has issued his Studies in Critical Philosophy.

title: Faithful in their fashion
description: Some of us can't approach this book without prejudice: an instinctive recoil from what Harold Nicolson and Vita SackvilleWest represented, both politically and socially. He, the diplomat and statesman, was anti Semitic, contemptuous of middleclass and working people (I do not like the masses in the flesh), also disdainful of the eternal superficiality of the American race; he agreed with a friend who pronounced him too fastidious and too critical to have the essential faculty of belief in democracy and confessed that he loathed the dark races. She, the novelist and poet who felt that the monarchy is our most valuable institution and wrote in protest against a rural bus service, I hate democracy. I hate la populace. I wish education had never been introduced, once began her gardening column in The Observer, If you have a moat around your garden....

title: Pablo Casals, 18761973
description: AT the end, of course, Pablo Casals was a symbol. Anybody who lived to his great age961 would automatically be a symbol. But in his case, the Casals legend was based on a good deal more than mere seniority. Nobody would seriously argue against the fact that for many years he was the world's greatest cellist. Nobody ever disputed his monomaniacal dedication to music. And then there was his strong stand against dictatorships, which alone would have made him a public figure. And then there was Casals the teacher, Casals the conductor, Casals the player of chamber music, Casals the inspiration. The tiny Catalan musician carried enormous weight.

title: Contemporary Russian Literature
description: Dtente or no dtente, the cultural exchange with the U.S.S.R. is always in a certain amount of trouble, so it is good to have this evidence of how worthwhile it has all been. Untendentious, lighthearted and serious by turn, sometimes encumbered by all the paraphernalia of the Graduate School and sometimes innocent of method itself, this huge double volume of Russian Literature Triquarterly is one of the best results of the intellectual traffic between MoscowLeningrad and our own campuses. It is written and translated for the most part by young Americans who have been to Russia for extended periods of study. They have met their contemporaries  poets, artists, cinasts and other intellectuals who are slightly older than they  and, skipping the intervening generations of moral and mental waste, they have met the old and infinitely alive intellectuals who are now in their seventies and eighties. This is what they have brought@back.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available sin time to appear in Section 2:

title: HENRY B. LENT
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., Oct. 27Henry B. Lent, author of 60 nonfiction career books for young readers, who retired in 1957 as a copy supervisor for Young & Rubicam, Inc., was drowned yesterday while fishing at the Lakota Club lake. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Miss Reifers Plans Bridal
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 27Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Reifers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Meriane Reifers to William L. Palmason, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lorne V. Palmason of Summit, N. J., and Wolfboro, N. H.

title: 60 SCHOLARS ASSAIL NOBEL TO KISSINGER
description: A letter denouncing the selection of Secretary of State Kissinger for the Nobel Peace Prize has been sent to the Norwegian Parliament by a group of 60 professors and graduate students at Harvard and the Massachussets Institute of Technology.

title: Letters: Not Quite TransCanada
description: To the Editor: Undoubtedly Wade Greene's A LandBound VoyageAcross Canada (Travel Section, Sept. 23) was a great trip and a real bargain, but he didn't go across Canada and he didn't go from the Pacific to the Atlantic. He stopped 800 miles short of Halifax, Nova Scotia, which is across Canada and on the Atlantic. What he said would be akin to a United States citizen's saying, I drove coasttocoast, San Francisco to Cleveland.

title: For Egypt, At Least A Change
description: CAIRO  From the Egyptian point of view, the balance sheet as the guns fall silent is still provisional.

title: What Others Call Junk, He Transforms Into Art
description: FOR sheer rampant originality, probably no period in art since the days of Cubism and Dada can rival the years around 1960 that saw the climax of Abstract Expressionism and the birth of Pop. For many who came to consciousness in that moment of es. thetic anarchy, it was a heyday, a time whose talisman was the word New. Energies that would later take forms of general cultural and political ferment then seemed to be exploding within gal

title: U.N. AIDING MANILA IN HUNGER BATTLE
description: MANILA, Oct. 27  As new typhoons damaged 125,000 acres of rice fields here, caus ing the loss of 2 per cent of this year's crop, United Na lions experts joined Filipino technocrats in a race to create a measure of security against hunger.

title: Penn Drubs Princeton And Leads Ivy League
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 27  Pennsylvania's football team turned adversity into diversity today as it manhandled Princeton, 240, and gained undisputed possession of first place in the Ivy League, with Harvard losing to Dartmouth. The Quakers have three victories and no defeats in league play.

title: Follmer Takes the Lead In Auto Champion Series
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 27 George Follmer of nearby Arcadia, Calif., whose day began with a ridiculously severe penalty for. mislaying a uniform, emerged as the hero and the point leader from the first two races of a new type of auto racing compe tition, the International Race of Champions.

title: Fully Independent
description: Everything President Nixon said at his news conference about assuring independence for the new special prosecutor he plans to name as successor to Archibald Cox made it plain that his appointee would run up against the same limitations that frustrated Mr. Cox's endeavor to uncover the truth of Watergate.

title: Kennedy Defeats Reagan In Gallup Presidency Poll;
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27A Presidential race held today between Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the top choices of voters in their respective parties, would result in a victory for Senator Kennedy, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Papa, who was Hitler?
description: BONN. It is 1973, and Willy Brandt, Socialist and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, is Chancellor of Germany. The nation enjoys prosperity and relative serenity, so that the social and economic factors that shaped Germany in the nineteenthirties seem part of the distant past.

title: A Chinese Minority Grows Bigger
description: KWEILIN, China, Oct. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The Government is trying to increase the population of China's biggest national minority, living in the wooded hills of the Kwangsi Chuang Autonomous Region, on the edge of southern China.

title: Bleaker Job Picture Confronts Teachers
description: CALDWELL  Competition for teaching jobs in the public school system here has been keen for some years, but this year the district's administrators have been startled by what one of them called an avalanche of applications.

title: Michigan Wins No. 7 In 347 Rout
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 27 (AP)The unbeaten Michigan Wolverines, getting two touchdowns each from Ed Shuttlesworth and Gordon Bell, scored 24 points the first five times they held the ball and beat the Minnesota Gophers, 347, today in a Big Ten conference game. The victory was Michigan's seventh this season.

title: Miss Anne Shen Is Married Here
description: Miss Anne Shen, who is studying for a Ph.D. in Chinese history at Columbia University, was married here yesterday afternoon to Albert Y. T. Chao, a financial analyst with the Mobil Oil Corporation in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: James L. Long to Wed Karen Rose Greer
description: PLANTATION, Fla., Oct. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Greer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Rose Greer, to James L. Long, son of Mrs. John E. Long of Purchase, N. Y., Fort Lauderdale and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mr. Long, a New. York stockbroker.

title: Where Are We Going?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27In all the long catanddog relationship between Presidents and reporters, there has seldom been a more savage attack on the integrity of American journalism than the one delivered in the White House the other night by President Nixon.

title: Trial Set for Indian Leaders
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D. Oct. 27 (AP)The trial of two American Indian Movement leaders charged in connection with the occupation of Wounded Knee is to begin Jan. 8 in United States District Court at St. Paul, Minn.

title: POLICE IN ITALY PROTEST ON PAY
description: ROME, Oct. 27When Rome police headquarters broadcasts Calling all cars! these days, some of them are likely to reply Fewer orders and more money!

title: Confessions of a middleclass drifter
description: Times change.My first car was a political decision. In 1969, a tiny Austin America sedan seemed to conform to the radical line. It was a rational vehicle, one designed to meet the needs of The People.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
The French are in
description: PARIS. Toward the end of the summer doldrums, an opinion poll asked Frenchmen how they felt about is rentre (backtoschool, backtowork, backtobusiness, backtopolitics) and the result made headlines: 56 per cent pessimistic. But summer headlines in France are like summer lightning: scary and startling, yet not really downtoearth. It takes the damp of fall to ground the excitement and measure its effect.

title: Marshal Semyon Budenny, 90, Bolshevik Cavalry Hero, Dies
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (Reuters) Marshal Semyon M. Budenny, the last surviving military, commander of the Bolshevik Revolution, died today at the age of 90, the Soviet press agency Tess, reported.

title: Linda Rodman Fiancee
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Oct. 27Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rodman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Rachel Rodman, to Richard Edward Honigman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Honigman of Brooklyn.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Reggie Jackson of the A's eats some words: I said before the World Series the Mets didn't have any name players, but I was wrong. They're all name, players.

title: Coffee table books for high coffee tables
description: Here we have a new genre: the coffeetable book that should be kept out of the reach of the children. Higher coffee tables would seem to be the answer; but the Japanese are using all our tall lumber to make bowling alleys with. So the alternative is to raise a generation for whom there is no pudendum, and that can call a vulva a . That generation is here, leaning on my coffee table, and when it takes over I fear G. P. Putnam's Sons will go begging for buyers as avid as I to wallow in the formerly forbidden delights (1,001 pages, more or less) of their socalled World History of Erotic Art.

title: A Test of Power
description: THE PRESIDENT: He had gone too far, maneuvered too often. Hundreds of thousands of citizens demanded he be stopped; the House began formal consideration of impeachment. Republicans joined the demand that he recreate the independent Watergate investigation he had summarily abolished; at a tense press conference, he said he would. Mr. Nixon also decided not to defy the courts: He would surrender his tape recordings. The week put the President and a handful of Government officials to a severe test; their reactions are described on page 2. In the middle of it all, the nation underwent a brief but tense war scare; page 3.

title: First Observer Unit In New U.N. Force Reaches City of Suez
description: CAIRO, Oct. 27A contingent of the United Nations emergency peacekeeping force reached the city of Suez today after being held up for more than five hours by an Israeli roadblock, a spokesman for the United Nations said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BUILDS OWN SATELLITE
description: IOWA CITYOther craft may weigh more, more and require the services of thousands of skilled neers to build and fly. Others may carry more elaborate entific instruments and farther out into the system.

title: Two Churches Marking 250 Years of Service
description: Two venerable New Jersey churchesone in Bergen County and the other in Mercer Countyare celebrating 250 years of service to God and community.

title: WOMAN, 79, SHOT VISITING A GRAVE
description: A 79yearold woman visiting a family gravesite in Brooklyn was shot and robbed yesterday by one of three youths she yelled at for pushing her 80yearold husband down and robbing him, the police said.

title: BEAME LEADS IN POLL WITH 52% OF TALLIES
description: The first results of the 1973 straw poll conducted by The Daily News show Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, leading his three opponents with 52 per cent of the vote.

title: U. S. and Russian Scientists Join in Ocean Fishing Study
description: MONTAUK, L.I.  Three scientists from the New York Ocean Science Laboratory here recently joined efforts with their Soviet counterparts in a research and management study of offshore fishery.

title: Architecture
description: THERE is a delightful little sleeper of a show at the New York Cultural Center called 1930's Expositions and we commend it to you, whether you deal in firsthand memories or trendy revivalism, as an enchanted bit of nostalgia and a brief respite from the arduous presence or New York. It memorializes an innocent and romantic world that idealized past and future on the pleasure principle in an art form of equal innocence and romanticism that reached its apogee in a single decade.

title: Smutty Jokes By Sophisticated Yokels
description: FIRST there was the Museum of Modern Art's New Images of Man exhibition. That took place in 1959. Then there was the Whitney Museum's Human Concern/Personal Torment exhibition. That took place in 1969. I had rather hoped we would be spared another such foray into the banalities of crackpot existentialism for at least another decade, but no such luck. Here is Robert Doty, the curator at the Whitney who brought us the Human Concern/Personal Torment debacle only four years ago, with another serving of dimestore horrors. This one is called Extraordinary Realities, and may currently be seen in the secondfloor galleries at the Whitney. Appropriate, I suppose, for the Halloween seasonbut what is a show like this doing in an art museum that expects

title: REGENTS STUDYING INTEGRATION HERE
description: The State Board of Regents has asked city school officials for a full report on what the city system is doing to promote school integration.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1973

title: Retail Chic in London
description: LONDON  At 9:36 A.M., security guards open the black and gold doors and the waiting customers step out of Kensington High Street into Biba's, a boutique that has grown into London's newest. and oddest department store.

title: Whale Turn Back Sharks, 31
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27 (UPI)Tom Webster scored three goals today to lead the New England Whalers to a 31 victory over the Los Angeles Sharks in a World. Hockey Association game.

title: Somerset Property Designated as a Park
description: MORRISTOWN  The North Jersey Conservation Foundation has agreed to purchase 165 prime acres of a Somerset County estate for use as a future park.

title: Late Rally Keeps L.S.U. Unbeaten
description: COLUMBIA, S. C. Oct. 27 (UPI)Mike Miley ran 2 yards for a touchdown with 1 minute 3 seconds left in the game to rally unbeaten Louisiana State to a 33 to 29 victory tonight over South Carolina.

title: Weeklies Facing Crisis In Newsprint Shortage
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I. Scores of weekly newspapers across Long Island, in many instances a major source of local news and advertising in dozens of small commnunities and the most powerful independent voices in their areas for decades, are facing major financial difficulties and even, in some cases, being forced to consider going out of business entirely because of a shortage of their lifeblood newsprint.

title: Dartmouth Names Woman
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 27 (AP)Prof. Carolyn Shaw Bell of Wellesley College has been appointed an overseer of the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, the first woman appointed to any governing board at the school, Dartmouth said this week.

title: Suez Strategy: An Israeli View of Egyptian Mistakes
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 27On the fourth day of the 1973 Middle East war, an Israeli general warned his nation not to expect an elegant victory, but the military operation that concluded the war may be remembered as one.

title: Constance Stafford to Be a Bride
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 27Miss Constance Holloway Stafford plans to be married Dec. 29 to Walter Edwin Constantine Jr., who is with the law firm of Whitcher, Kelleran & Dubek here. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the future bride. Dr. Walter F. Stafford Jr., a neurologist, and Mrs. Stafford of Buffalo and Point.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ABERAVON, Wales, Oct. 27 (UPI)Mark Cox of Britain powered his way to a 67, 62 victory over Owen Davidson of Australia today to win the first event of the Dewar Cup indoor tennis series. Cox was in command after winning the first set tiebreaker, 7 points to 0. Virginia Wade of Britain hammered out an easy 63, 61 victory over Julie Heldman of the United State. It was the fifth time in six finals that Miss Wade had beaten Miss Heldman.

title: Kerr on The Contractor
description: THE most effective and affecting moment in the Chelsea Theater Center's Manhattan production of David Storey's The Contractor comes with a single line of Neil Fitzgerald's. Mr. Fitzgerald is playing the oldest of the old, the trembling remnant of a generation that once made rope by hand and worked 18 hours a day, and he is watching his son erect a marquee for his granddaughter's wedding.

title: Clothes for the apples of their eyes
description: When grandmother goes shopping, her chbices may leapfrog right over the inbetween generation and zero in on what the grandchildren want or she may buy the kind of clothes she wants to see them wear, but either way parents are seldom consulted. And maybe that's the way it should be. It makes grandmother's presents something special. Three sets of grandchildren are shown here wearing their latest grannybought outfits.

title: Glimpse of Merchant Prince's L.I. Life
description: LLOYD NECK, L. I.  The gates of Caumsett State Park, the former Marshall Field estate, were opened to the public for a day yesterday, providing visitors with a glimpse of an era when merchant princes lived in expansive opulence.

title: PIERSON C. IRWIN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 27 Pierson C. Irwin, a retired tea importer, died today at his home, 101 Park Avenue. He was 84 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Mountain Pond and it was 10 below zero and our wine froze in the bottle?

title: NATO ADVANCING ON ENVIRONMENT
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 27The North Atlantic Treaty Organization moved this week to expand its efforts to protect the environment by agreeing to study the practical applications of solar and geothermal energy.

title: Avid Fan Records Beiderbecke Jazz
description: BARTLEY  The Fastest Washboard in the East was almost slowed down last weekend.

title: FEWER STUDENTS GET POSTAL JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The United States Postal Service, under the terms of a union contract negotiated last July, has reduced the scope of a program designed to provide parttime employment for needy students.

title: Louise Gerrity Will Be Bride
description: MALVERN, Pa., Oct. 27Mr. and Mrs. Charles Matthew Gerrity have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Gerrity, to Edward Peter Vollertsen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vollertsen of Atlanta.

title: Yitzhak Gefen Weds Harriet Orentlicher
description: GREENFIELD PARK, N.Y., Oct. 27Miss Harriet Orentlicher and Yitzhak Gefen, who served three years with the Israeli Air Force, were married here this evening. Rabbi William A. Orentlicher, father of the bride and rabbi of the Bayside (Queens) Jewish Center, performed the ceremony at the Pioneer Country Club.

title: Study Panel Urges Curb on Groups That Control Admission to Professions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Federal study group on ed?? cation urged today that th?? Government adopt a more vig?? slant antitrust posture towar?? professional and occupation?? groups that exert control ove?? who works in their fields ?? activity.

title: Cabbages Fit for Kings Are Bargains at Roadside Stands
description: Cauliflower, broccoli, cabbagethree for $1. Not a loss leader, but another autumn roadside bargain in eastern Suffolk County. Some of the crop will reach markets further to the west, but most of it is sold from stands or off flatbed trucks at the roadside, often at the edge of the very field where it grows, cutting expenses to the bone.

title: Head of Striker's Takes Communion From His Adversary
description: NEWARK, Oct. 27The president of a gravediggers union on strike at a cemetery operated by the Roman Catholic archdiocese here went through a second day of his own hunger strike inside the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart today and received holy communion from the church official with whom he has been negotiating.

title: Ellen Riese Is Married
description: Miss Ellen Riese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Riese of Kings Point, L. I., was manled here last evening to Robert S. Grimes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Grimes of Jackson Heights, Queens. Rabbi Nathan Barnberger performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Monday Night's Lights Finally Shine in Buffalo
description: Monday night's nationally televised football game will match the Kansas City Chiefs and the Buffalo Bills in the latter's new stadium at Orchard Park, N.Y. The significance for the Bills is that this will be the first exposure of their team in pro football's showcase, the Monday night scene. The Bills no longer need to feel like orphans. They belong. So do the Denver Broncos, who made their initial Monday night appearance last week. Since the series began in 1970, there was reason to believe that these two clubs, hardly powerhouses with glamorous histories, were being stighted.

title: Future of Uris Clouded in Wake Of Sale to Kinney
description: It was over the Fourth of July weekend this year that National Kinney Corporation, the twoyearold building services company that got its start in car rentals and cleaning contracts, successfully negotiated a lastminute deal to buy a majority of the stock of Uris Buildings Corporation, one of New York's largest commercial landlords and one of the biggest investment builders in the country.

title: Dance
description: CHOREOGRAPHY is the kind of job choreographers try to keep at. It is a job where the actual craft of the business is dearly bought. Studios and bodies are hard to find, and usually choreographers are intensely anxious to keep in practice. Robert Joffrey is an exception. Moreover he obviously need not be. Here is a presumably aspiring choreographer, who happens to run his own company, who also happens not to have made a ballet for six years.

title: Chile
description: SANTIAGOThe military coup here six weeks ago was directed first against the late President Salvador Allende Gossens and his experiment in Marxism by democratic consent. But it was also directed against party politics in general. Marxist parties have been outlawed by the junta, other parties sent into indefinite recess, Congress closed down, the Communistdominated National Labor Confederation dissolved and all political meetings banned.

title: Music in Review
description: Veda Zuponcic's debut program in Tully Hall on Monday night was an intelligent variation on the regulation lineup of piano recital pieces classical, romantic, 20thcentury and the showy virtuosic. It included a Haydn Sonata in G (Hob. XVI), Schubert's posthumous Sonata in C minor, the Elliott Carter Sonata and Liszt's Venezia e Napoli.

title: Dickinson Leads Early But Result Is Familiar
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Oct. 27 Union Hill spotted Dickinson a 60 lead, but rallied for 23 points in the second period to hand Dickinson its 38th successive setback, 306, today.

title: Braves, Led By Heard, Down Cays
College Hall a Historic Site
description: NEWARK  The raveling fringes of downtown Newark, flattened several years ago by rioting, arson and urban renewal, have been graced by the selection of the administration building of Newark College of Engineering as a National Historic Site.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The Nixon Administration finds itself staring full in the face the proposition that wageprice controls are addictive.

title: Mahovlichs Score Pair In Canadiens' 42 Victory
description: MONTREAL. Oct 27 (UPI) The Mahovlich brothers Frank and Peter  each scored a goal tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 42 triumph over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: BribeTaking Policemen Help Catch Other Officers
description: More than 20 New York policemen caught taking bribes here during the last two years have been persuaded to gather evidence against fellow officers in the hope of receiving lenient treatment, according to First Deputy Police Commissioner William P. McCarthy.

title: Tufts Gets Ford Grant
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 27 (AP)Tufts University said this week it had received a $120,000 grant from the Ford Foundation to administer its LatinAmerican teaching fellowship program.

title: Handicapped to Get Aid at Bergen Polls
description: HACKENSACKAt least five of the seven communities in the fastgrowing Pascack Valley area of Bergen County will provide ramps and other aids at polling places on Nov. 6, thus enabling handicapped voters to cast their ballots with a minimum of effort.

title: My Films Come Out of My Nightmares
description: Brian De Palma, former under ground filmmaker, scores with Sisters, a horror story about a murderous Siamese twin

title: News of the Stage
description: The Ford Foundation has made a grant of $62,000 to the Theater Development Fund, a nonprofit corporation that assists Broadway and Off Broadway, theater.

title: Tito, Mihailovic And the Allies, 19411945 By Walter R. Roberts 406 pp. New Brunswick, N. J.: Rutgers University Press. $15. The Kapetanios Partisans and Civil War in Greece, 19431949. By Dominique Eudes. Translated from the French by John Howe. 400 pp. New York: Monthly Review Press. $11.50.
description: Partisan, for all its power to convey a sense of dedication, somehow fails to express fully the wild daring of those men of the mountains who fought overwhelming odds in the Balkans during World War II. They were desperadoes in the strongest sense of men who had nothing or, at most, very little to lose.

title: Raisin Is Sweet, Could Be Sweeter
description: THE strength of Raisin lies in the keen intelligence and restless invention of musical underscoring that has simply invaded Lorraine Hansberry's once tightlyknit, fourwalled, closequartered play, A Raisin in the Sun, plucking the walls away, spilling the action onto tie streets with a jittery downflight of strings, mocking and matching realistic speech with frogthroated sass from the heavybreathing bass viols. The weakness of Raisin lies in the ultimate monotony of its melodic line, sometimes making you wish that a song were over so that the family infighting could get going again.

title: Forecast: Partly Sunny
description: Those who make America's private business and investment decisions can usually count on the Government's quarterly gross national product data to at least point them in the right direction.

title: 25 RAINLESS DAYS SET RECORD HERE
description: The city's skies were sunny, the autumn air was mild and reasonably clean and the day was generally so delightful that the weather record set yesterday was not one to be detected with mere senses.

title: Jordanians Indicating Tougher Stand
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 27Signs of hardening in Jordan's position on the future of Jerusalem have appeared here in the capital, although King Hussein's Government has not publicly setout its views on the issue in detail in recent weeks.

title: Carroll Curry In Debut Here
description: Another Canadian made a New York debut on Wednesday night at Tully HallCarrol Anne Curry, a soprano who has sung extensively with opera companies in Canada. Miss Curry is the kind of artist who can do great service to contemporary music. She has a clear voice, if somewhat tremulous at the top; her enunciation is superb, so that the words in any language are immediately understandable, and her phrasing is impeccable.

title: FatherSon Beame Team Setting Standards for Campaign Organization Unmatched by Other Hopefuls
description: With the prospects of victory serving to oil the machinery, Controller Abraham D. Beame is running a professional, adequately financed campaign organization while his rivals in the mayoral race have been plagued in varying degrees by lack of money, dissension and pure amateurism in their campaign organizations.

title: Dancealot Pays $31.40 In Selima
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 Dancealot, from the Mill House Stable of Jarries Cox Brady Jr., made a strong bid for the 2yearold filly division championship today when she defeated eight rivals in the $127,060 Selima Stakes at Laurel Race Course.

title: Canceled Debate
description: Roy Innis, executive director of the Congress of Racial Equality, is an advocate of black nationalism and militant opponent of racial integration. Dr. William Shockley, a physicist who won the Nobel Prize for his role in invention of the transistor, is a vigorous exponent of the theory that genetic rather than environmental factors are primarily responsible for the disadvantaged position of blacks in a predominantly white society.

title: Will These New Era Movies Bring Out the Snob in You?
description: SOMETIMES in the critic's lordly eagerness to pontificate on es thetics and currents in art, the fact that movies remain, first and foremost, an industry can be momen wily obscured. Money is still the rul ing seed and harvest of cinemaa fact not totally lacking in artistic significance itself, for it explains why Orsor Welles has not directed a film in eight years, while Ross Hunter can pump millions into a Hindenburglike Lost Horizon, smiling with confidence as he assures the public that this kind of papiermch extravagance is just what American movies need. Watching someone like Hunter on a television talk show insist that people are hungry for clean fun and family entertainment is like hearing a doctor prescribe warm milk and applesauce for a patient with ulcersthe bite in the belly may be preferable to the cure.

title: Catherine Morell Wed in Suburb
description: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 27Miss Catherine Eugenia Morell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gaspar John Morell of Rye, was married here this afternoon to Donald Alan Raddatz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Raddatz of Evergreen Park, Ill.

title: EnergySaving Time
description: The return to Standard Time early this morning should give impetus to legislative efforts to extend the benefits of Daylight Saving Time throughout the year.

title: Seminole Club Advances In GolfCourse Ratings
description: For the golf player who wishes to maximize or minimize, his frustration with the game, Golf Digest magazine has made a selection of America's 100 Greatest Tests of Golf.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: The Best of Life

title: Richard Dennis Fianc of Mary Jo Lee
