description: CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Oct. 27  Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lee Jr. of Yonkers and New Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jo Lee, to 1st Classman Richard W. Dennis of the United States Air Force Academy, of West Hempstead, L. I. and New Fairfield.

title: All too often an ornamental facade, behind which all sorts of nonsense and meanness are carried
description: One of our more pervasive Myths is the justice of our legal system. Society, to be comfortable with itself, feels it must trust in the courts and the men who run them. As Whitney North Seymour Jr., writes, The fair settlement of private disputes, the evenhanded enforcement of the law, and the sensible and sensitive handling of antisocial conduct are all essential to people's living together in peace.

title: Holy Family Earns Tie for Lead
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., Oct, 27 Holy Family upset previously unbeaten Holy Trinity, 126, yesterday to tie for the lead in Catholic High School Football League Division 11 competition, Both teams now have a 5.1 wonlost record.

title: AGES FIGHT BACK IN TITLE BRIDGE
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 27 America's most famous bridge team began fighting its way out of trouble in international playoff competition here today. The Aces, who have been the United States representatives in the world championship for the last four years, pulled back 53 international match points to lead by 13 after trailing by 40 points against a young sextet captained by Dan Morse of Houston.

title: American Heroine
description: The most importantfact about Allen Davis's new study of Jane Addams is that it is the first book that systematically and persuasively separates the real woman from the myth. It will be indispensable to anyone interested in the subject or the period 18901915. The value of this becomes even more evident when one recalls that Jane Addams (18601935), native of northern Illinois, founder of Hull Housethe best known American settlementsocial reformer, suffragist, pacifist and writer, was regarded as the most famous American woman in the decides before World War I, an era in which many of the patterns and conflicts of our own day are rooted.

title: State Has Started Campaign to Draw Additional Tourists
description: ALBANY, Oct. 27With the ending of the summervacation season, the state has begun a campaign to attract more tourists.

title: How Shipper Foils Hijackers
description: SECAUCUS  Truck hijacking, which is estimated to have cost its victims $950  million in company profits last year, has ceased to be a problem for the Nelson Distribution Corporation here. The company installed its own specially designed hijack security system about a year and a half ago.

title: GRADUATE SCHOOLS RANKED BY DEANS
description: Harvard, Chicago, Michigan, Columbia and the University of California, Berkeley, have more graduatelevel professional schools that are leaders in their fields than any other universities in the country, according to a survey of deans that is to be published tomorrow.

title: Lions 282 Victims
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. Oct 27  Jim (J.J.) Jennings Rutgers candidate for allAmerican honors, ran for 100 yards today and scored his 15th touchdown of the season but ended up sidelined with a sprained left ankle as his team beat Columbia, 28 to 2.

title: Clarkstown North Posts Sixth Straight Triumph
description: Clarkstown North, the only unbeaten and untied team in the county, stretched its streak to six yesterday by routing Spring Valley, 277. Jim Bandel scored from the 5 and 1, and Rich Kolka registered twice from the 1 as Clarkstown North handed the Valley its third loss in six games.

title: Kings Point Rally Tops Wagner, 136
description: KINGS POINT, LI., Oct. 27Kevin Beaugez, a junior quarterback, rallied the Mariner eleven in the final quarter today for a 13.6 victory over Wagner College at Tomb Field,

title: Bayside Triumphs, Gains Title
description: Unbeaten Bayside gained its sixth victory by beating Springfield Gardens, 180, at Bayside. The triumph clinched the Queens Public Schools Athletic League division title for the Commodores.

title: Concert Planned For Romantics
description: If one happens to bump into any 20th century Romantics, he might let them know that an array of kindred spirits will be assembling next Saturday evening at the Saw Mill Junior High School, in Commack.

title: Debra Pandell Has Nuptials
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Oct. 27Miss Debra Ann Pendell and Eldredge Langstaff Bermingham Jr., students at Bowdoin College, were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Edward B. Anderson on the grounds of the Unitarian Church.

title: G. M. CONTESTING FINDING OF DEFECT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The General Motors Corporation, in a new confrontation with Federal safety regulators, is vigorously contesting the finding of a safety defect in the steering gear of more than 50,000 1959 and 1960 Cadillacs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A city regulation that becomes effective next Thursday will require merchants here to post prominent notices of their policies on refunds and exchanges. The rule applies to nondefective merchandise and is intended to remedy situations in which customers make quick purchases, find them not to their liking and then learn that the store does not give cash refunds or exchanges.

title: Spotlight Still on Politics At the Nassau Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 28  Elvis Presiey wiggled here. Spiro T. Agnew made a speech here, and Julius (Doctor J.) Erving has dissected his basketball opponents here all since the Nassau Coliseum opened 21 months ago.

title: Bridge: Aces Are Favored in Final of North American Playoffs
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 28The final playoffs, began here tonight to determine the 1974 North American team for the world championships. Favored by most observers are the Aces, whose nonplaying captain, Ira Corn Jr., has strengthened his nucleus of Dallas expertsBob Wolff, Bob Hamman, Bob Goldman and Mark Blumenthalby adding two Canadian stars, Eric Murray and Sam Kehela.

title: Many lsraelis Feel It's Far From Over
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28Just north of Tel Aviv this morning schoolchildren in blue uniforms were digging in the dunes on the side of the highway, filling sandbags for use in, the city's shelters.

title: MRS. EDWARD M'WITHEY
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 28Mrs. Mary Linen MacWithey, widow of Edward L. MacWithey, a stockbroker, died yesterday in the Memorial Center for Women here. She was 96 years old and a resident of East Orange.

title: LEONARD S. WEBER, PUBLICITY MAN, DIES
description: Leonard S. Weber, president of the Weber Organisation, producers of public events, died Saturday of complications from a brain tumor at his home, 360 East 72d Street. He was 45 years old.

title: WIND IN JET WAKE CAUSING CRASHES
description: Violent air currents found in the, wake of jumbo jetliners have caused more than 20 smaller planes to crash, according to Government officials.

title: A.M.A. Urges Discipline Of Incompetent Physicians
description: The American Medical Association has lashed at doctors for making excuses for not policing their profession and has demanded that medical societies and state officials meet their responsibilities in disciplining physicians who abuse their licenses to practice medicine.

title: 2 Stanek Sextuplets Home
description: LAKEWOOD, Colo., Oct. 28 (AP)Edna and Eugene Stanek had the first two of their five surviving sextuplets at home today for the babies' sixweek birthday. The others are to go home within 10 days.

title: Sabres Win, 52, Lose Perreault
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 28 (UPI)Gil Perreault, who broke his left leg in the second period, scored a goal in the opening period tonight to spark the Buffalo Sabres to a 52 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game.

title: Chou Attacks Russians For Delaying Border Pact
description: PEKING, Oct. 27Relationships between the United States and China have in no way been affected by the Watergate affair, Premier Chou Enlai said in an interview last night.

title: Poor School Practices in State Said to Cost Taxpayers Millions
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 28Governor Rockefeller's unofficial inspector general for education charged today that poor school management was costing taxpayers millions of dollars a year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Wilton Vaugh, Politics Editor For Old Boston Post, Dies
description: SCITUATE, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP)Wilton Vaugh, political editor of The Boston Post when it closed in 1955, died yesterday at the South Shore Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Chou Attacks Russians For Delaying Border Pact
description: PEKING, Oct. 27Relationsinps between the United States and China have in no way been affected by the Watergate affair, Premier Chou Enlai said in an interview last night.

title: On Syrian Campus, Medical Treatment and Politics
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 28 When Dr. Mohammed Sartawi, a Palestinian neurosurgeon at Houston's Memorial Hospital, heard that Damascus was being bombed by Israeli warplanes, he took an emergency leave and flew here.

title: Soviet Diverting Rivers to Grain Land
description: The Soviet Union, in an evident move to reduce dependence on American wheat, has quietly begun construction of a major irrigation canal that is ultimately intended to divert water from big Siberian rivers to dry graingrowing lands to the south.

title: MIDDLETON ROSE
description: Middleton Rose, who retired in 1970 as vice president of Laird, Bissel & Meeds, Inc., stockbrokers, died Saturday here. He was 78 years old and lived at 55 East 86th Street.

title: Personal Finance
description: Everybody loves to buy a new car, but almost nobody enjoys trying to match wits with a car salesman.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The unofficial inspector general for education in New York State charged that poor school management was costing taxpayers millions of dollars a year. Daniel Klepak, who was named director of the State Office of Education Performance Review by the Governor, said in Syracuse at the annual convention of the State School Roards Association that his office was looking into a umber of matters that were adding substantially to school costs, including excessive teacher absences, school lunch practices and school investment policies.

title: Dr. Taha Hussein Dead at 85; Egyptian Writer and Educator
description: CAIRO, Oct. 28 (AP)Dr. Taha Hussein, the Egyptian writer whose books have become classics of modern Arabic literature, died today, a day after receiving the United Nations human rights prize. He was 84 years old.

title: Traffic Snarls End Drivein's Sex Films
description: SAYREVILLE, N. J., Oct. 28 The Amboys DriveIn Theater tonight dropped its sex films and began showing the violencefilled Dillinger, and the police, town fathers and Garden State Parkway officials were hoping that traffic near the theater would once again flow at normal rates.

title: Mrs. Miller Bride of Adm. McNitt
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 28 Mrs. Patricia Hicks Miller, an interior designer, was married here this afternoon to Rear Adm, Robert Waring McNitt. U. S. N., retired, who is dean of admissions at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md.

title: BARNETT ZELENKO
description: Barnett Zelenko, a retired dress manufacturer, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 98 years old and lived at 611 West 148th Street.

title: Cavaliers Edge Celtics
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (AP) Austin Carr scored on a 3point play with five seconds remaining to give the Cleveland Cavaliers a 10299 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.

title: Her Goal is to Send the Customers Away Liking Themselves
description: Five days a week, Pearl Weiss emerges from the subterranean world of the Lexington Avenue subway to fairyland world of green eyelids, blood red lips and plastic fingernails.

title: The Stage: Darkroom
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28In Darkroom, a new play by David Epstein, which opened this weekend at the Yale Repertory Theater, seven young people meet in a remote farmhouse in New Hampshire to make a film, ostensibly about themselves.

title: Stony Brook Coed Raped and Beaten In Dormitory Room
description: STONY BROOK, L. L, Oct. 28 A 20yearold college senior was raped and beaten at the State University Center here last night after two men entered her room on a pretext and ordered her at gunpoint to undress, campus security officials reported.

title: A.M.A. Urges Discipline Of Incompetent Physicians
description: The American Medical Association has lashed at doctors for making excuses for not policing their profession and has demanded that medical societies and state officials meet their responsibilities in disciplining physicians who abuse their licenses to practice medicine.

title: Cleo Moore, Actress, Dies; Ran for Louisiana Governor
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 (UPI)Cleo Moore, an actress who was once married to the youngest son of Gov. Huey Long of Louisiana, died Thursday at the age of 44.

title: Advertising: Exurban Magazine
description: When he was still working here, William S. Blair, then president of Harper's Magazine, Inc., had luncheons on occasion at the, Coffee House, a small club frequented by people in his business. He never met a fellowmember, Richard M. Ketchum, managing director of the book division of American Heritage, there.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the Nation. al Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Vandals Ruin Building At Army Reserve Site
description: Vandals broke into an Army Reserve center in the Wakefield section of the Bronx over the weekend and heavily damaged a wooden building there by repeatedly raming it with a tow truck.

title: Pakistan Denies She Lags In Repatriation of Biharis
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 28 A Foreign Office spokesman today described as factually incorrect reports that Pakistan had lagged on repatriation and deliberately made it difficult for Biharis to come here from Bangladesh.

title: Survey Finds Wall St. Moving Through Period of Massive Change
PHILIP L. KELSER
description: Philip L. Keiser, a retired financial counselor who had served in the LendLease Administration in Washington in World War II, died Saturday at his home, 133 East 64th Street. He was 72 years old.

title: PORTUGUESE VOTE SHOWS NO CHANGE
description: LISBON, Oct. 28The Government retained its monopoly in the National Assembly today in an election boycotted by the Opposition.

title: Soviet Intervention Called Peril to U.S. By Eugene Rostow
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28Eugene V. Rostow today sharply denounced Soviet intervention in the ArabIsraeli conflict as a carefully planned move threatening the fundamental security of the United States and its allies.

title: HEART OPERATION KEY ISSUE IN TRIAL
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 28A man pleaded not guilty to murder last week in a case that may contribute to medicallegal history on the definition of death.

title: Civil Rights Panel Likens Navajo Nation to Third World Countries
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Oct. 28  On June 1, 1868, after merciless campaign by Kit Carson's troops, the leaders of starving and diseased refugee nation of native Americans called Navajos signed a treaty committing their future to the United States. Government.

title: W. N. Wishard Jr., Urologist Who Taught at Indiana, 75
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP) Dr. William Niles Wishard Jr. a urologist, died here yesterday at a hospital. He was 75 years old. Dr. Wishard had practiced medicine here since 1928 and was clinical professor of urology at the Indiana University School of Medicine.

title: Impeachment Book Issued
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (UPI)The American Civil Liberties Union said today it had put out A Handbook for Impeachment to encourage such proceedings against President Nixon.

title: Rough Riders Gain First
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 28 (AP)The Ottawa Rough Riders clinched first place in the Eastern Conference of the Canadian Football League today, beating the secondplace Montreal Alouettes, 160, before a crowd of 26,734, Ottawa's largest of the season.

title: DAVID B. M'CREADY
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 28Lieut. Col. David Beattie MacCready, an Army veteran of both World Wars, who had taught at Peekskill and Manlius Military Academies, died yesterday in Princeton Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived here and in Willsboro, N.Y.

title: Norman Hall Marries Miss Kathleen Boyle
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Oct. 28In St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Kathleen Jeanette Boyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Boyle of Passaic, became the bride of Norman Christopher Hall. He is the son of Mrs. Lynn Donohue of Westbury, L.I.

title: Cook Wins at Martinsville
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., Oct. 28 (AP)  Jerry Cook of Rome, N.Y., won the 250lap National Championship Modified race today at Martinsville Speedway.

title: Paul E. Prosswimmer, 71, Led Franklin National Bank
description: Paul E. Prosswimmer, retired president of the Franklin National Bank, died Saturday in Nassau Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 4 Road on the Hill, Great Neck, L.I.

title: CleanUporClose Order Is Driving Undesirables Out of Bryant Park
description: Gamblers, junkies, brown baggers sucking at wine and liquor bottles, derelicts, panhandlers and menacing ripoff specialists.Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman's description of the undesirables who have been spoiling Bryant Park for everybody else.

title: Ballet: Feld and Arpino
description: This week the Joffrey Ballet enters the fourth and last of its curtailed fall season at the City Center 55th Street Theater. For the last few years the Joffrey Ballet has played six weeks at the City Center, but now with the loss of certain City Center support it has been forced to cut back.

title: LINDSAY CAUTIONS SUCCESSORTOBE
description: Mayor Lindsay took the occasion of the dedication of a new familyhealthcare center in the Bronx yesterday to offer some advice to his successor, whoever he may be.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Taxpayers Association has announced its opposition to a $25million bond issue for education facilities for severely handicapped children because of what it calls inadequate advance planning and a lack of adequate information for the public.

title: Miss Peters Is Wed To Eric M. Spector
description: PEMBROKE, Mass., Oct. 28  Miss Loraine Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Peters of Covina, Calif., was married here this afternoon to Eric Mason Spector of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius J. Spector of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: About New York
description: Autumn is the special time in New York, and the golden days came one on top of the other for a month. In a wady, it was a cheat because autumn in New York is supposed to have a poignancy about it, and those days were not poignant. They were full of sunshine and glory, and they made the miseries in Washington and along the Suez easier to take.

title: Pakistan Said to Resist Taking Biharis
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 28Two months ago India and Pakistan signed an agreement that sought to resolve the major disputes leftover from the 1971 Bangladesh war. Today the tangled problems of repatriation remain a source of friction and deepening anger.

title: McAdoo Pours In 44
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 28 (UPI)Bob McAdoo led the Buffalo Braves to a 122100 victory over the Kansas City Omaha Kings tonight by racking up 44 points.

title: Poll Held on Cox Dismissal
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 (UPI) About 174,000 households in the 18th Congressional District arebeing polled by Representative H. John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, to determine public reaction to the dismissal Archibald Cox. Mr. Heinz expressed concern that the Nixoncourt crisis had plunged the nation into an extremely serious confrontation.

title: GOING OUT
description: DECADE The American Place Theater opens its 10th season at 7,30 tonight,only a few crosstown blocks from its birthplace. The company, dedicated to producing only new plays by living Americans, gave its first performances over at St. Clement's Church on 46th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues. Only a season or so ago, it moved into its own home, comfortable premises downstairs in the high office tower at 111 West 46th Street (2470393). The opener of this season is House Party, a new work by Ed Bullins.

title: Cambodia's War: Road Opened, Another Cut as Capital Relaxes
description: PHUM KRUOS, Cambodia, Oct. 28It was an average day in the current monsoon phase of the Cambodian war.

title: WIND IN JET WAKE CAUSING CRASHES
description: Violent air currents found in the wake of jumbo jetliners have caused more than 20 smaller planes to crash, according to Government officials.

title: Hambletonian Awarded to Liberty Bell for 3 Years
description: The Hambletonian, perhaps, the last great sports event that belonged to rural America, was awarded yesterday to a bigcity track for the first timeLiberty Bell Park in Philadelphia.

title: PHILHARMONIA PLAYS MODERNS PROGRAM
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia's new Meet the Moderns series got under way Saturday night at the Academy of Music with a program devoted to contemporary British composers. Vaughan Williams's Thomas Tallis Fantasia and Britten's Serenade, hardly modern either stylistically or chronologically, went down easily enough from the Philharmonia strings under Lukas Foss's baton. Joseph Porrello, tenor, and Paul Ingraham, horn, were the commendable soloists in the Britten.

title: Coast Financier's Straw Man Named
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 28A California land baron who served as a campaign adviser to President Nixon has been identified by Government prosecutors as a straw man who helped C. Arnholt Smith conceal corporate and incometax frauds amounting to millions of dollars.

title: Difference Over Access to Documents Could Delay Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28An apparent conflict between President Nixon and his Acting Attorney General, Robert H. Bork, over the independence of a new special Watergate prosecutor could delay the naming of a repplacement for Archibald Cox unless it is resolved in the next day or two.

title: Altman and Gould Make a Brilliant Long Goodbye
description: In The Long Goodbye, Robert Altman, a brilliant director whose films sometimes seem like death wishes (Brewster McCloud), attempts the impossible and pulls it off.

title: Police Say Mugged German Policeman Was Not Mugged, German or a Policeman
description: The account of a man who said he was a West German policeman and was mugged in Queens last week was labeled a fairy tale by the police yesterday.

title: Benny Tate, Caught Game When Ruth Hit 60th Homer
description: WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., Oct. 28 (UPI)Henry (Benny) Tate, the catcher for the Washington Senators in 1927, when Babe Ruth hit his 60th home run, died last night at a hospital here. He was 71 years old.

title: Candidates for Governor Taking The Same Road on Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Oct. 28When it comes to income taxes, the most controversial issue in the state's gubernatorial campaign, the candidates are jostling each other in an effort to occupy the same strategic ground.

title: RED CROSS INQUIRY ASKED BY SYRIANS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 28Syria has called on the International Committee of the Red Cross to investigate a report that Syrian prisoners of war were forced to march ahead of Israeli troops who were advancing through a mine field that was protecting a Syrian position in the Golan heights.

title: SEX FILMS ENDED BY TRAFFIC JAMS
description: SAYREVILLE, N. J., Oct. 28 The Amboys DriveIn Theater tonight dropped its sex films and began showing the violencefilled Dillinger, and the police, town fathers and Garden State Parkway officials were hoping that traffic near the theater would once again flow at normal rates.

title: HIGH AIDE IS SENT TO U.S. BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, Oct. 28  President Anwar elSidat tonight sent a senior career diplothat on a trip to Washington.

title: Rights Head Is Honored
description: Jack M. Sable, the State Commissioner of Human Rights, received the Man of the Year award yesterday from the Police Department's Shomrim ciety for his outstanding dicisions concerning discrimination: In making the presentation to Mr. Sable, the State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, told the 1,500 people at the society's 49th annual Scholarship Spiritual Breakfast in the New York Hilton Hotel that Mr. Sable had established his credentials by performance and service.

title: Rockefeller Provides the Springboard For Democrat Who Aspires to His Job
description: Extensive, free statewide exposure  the dream of many politicians who sit in wintry anonymity in the Legislature  has begun for Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, a rich, young Manhattan legislator who would like to become Governor some day.

title: Scheduling Appearances for a Candidate Is Hectic Task
description: The letter from W. Kenneth Williams, D.D.S., arrived al BeameforMayor headquarters on July 12 and was entered as No. 988 in the composition book kept by Beverly Schechter, a volunteer in the scheduling office.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Why, wrote an East Side resident, are only McIntosh and Delicious apples available in the city?

title: Why We Are Shaken
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28In answering the first question at his press conference Friday, President Nixon brought up the case of Aaron Burr as a precedent to support his continued withholding of Presidential papers. He said:

title: Bicentennial Designs Of Coins to Win $5,000
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) The Treasury says it will pay $5,000, each to the persons submitting the winning new bicentennial designs for the quarter, halfdollar and dollar coins.

title: Not for Sale
description: In urging corporations to put a stop to the practice of making unrestricted gifts to colleges and universities, David Packard is attempting to turn the clock of education and social progress back by twenty years. It was in 1953 that Frank W. Abrams, then chairman of the board of Standard Oil of New Jersey, established the legitimacy of unrestricted corporate gifts to higher education. A test case instigated by Mr. Abrams culminated in a landmark decision in the New Jersey Superior Court holding that corporations are not only entitled but actually have, an obligation to support higher educationwithout strings attachedas the engine of economic and social progress.

title: Protester's Body Removed From Cemetery in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 28 (Reuters)The body of Jan Palach, the Czech student who burned himself to death in early 1969 in protest against the Sovietled invasion of Czechoslovakia, has been removed from a cemetery here, informed sources said today.

title: Blitzes Help Blunt Hadl's Passing Defeat Is First
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 28It was one of those fieldgoal games. The Minnesota Vikings continued their all  winning march through the, National Football League today by defeating the Los Angeles Rams, 109, in a contest which saw one touchdown scored, nine field goals attempted and four made.

title: California Fights Brush Fire Attributed to an Arsonist
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 28 (UPI)A mountain brush fire set by an arsonist with an incendiary device raced faster than you could run through 8,000 acres, destroyed 15 structures and forced evacuation of a retirement village 50 miles east of San Diego, state and Federal officials said today.

title: CHILDREN'S JUSTICE CALLED A FAILURE BY JUDICIAL PANEL
description: In a scathing report, seven present and past judges of the Family Court and the state jucial administrator charged yesterday that city, state and private agencies had all failed the cause of troubled children here.

title: Paris's Latest ReadytoWear Gives Real Women Their Due
description: PARIS, Oct. 28  Why starve on meat and water when the clothes are going to be designed for the woman who can suddenly blissfully shrug off such problems as keeping a shape?

title: W. Robert Reardon Weds Miss Warner
description: MILLBROOK, Conn., Oct. 28  Miss Nancy Evelyn Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oswin V. Warner of Monroe, was married here this afternoon to W. Robert Reardon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Reardon of Kingston, N. Y. The bride and her husband are programing writers with the International Business Machines Corporation in Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

title: Donohue Scores ThreeRace Sweep on Coast, Then Retires From Driving
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 28 Mark Donohue won three today, including the races today, including the third heat of the new International Race of Champions, then announced his retirement from active racing except for the final of the I.R.Q.C. event, which will take place in February Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Cemetery Union Head Continues Fast in Cathedral
description: NEWARK, Oct. 28Sam Cimaglia, president of a cemetery workers' union that struck the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark last month, moved into the third day of a selfimposed hunger strike inside Newark's vast Sacred Heart Cathedral today and vowed to stick it out for as long as God gives me strength.

title: Crises of Authority
description: One cannot have crises of authority in a society for a period of months without paying a price somewhere along the line.

title: Secretariat Wins Finale
description: Secretariat ended his racing career yesterday with a 6length victory in the Canadian International Championship at Woodbine race track, Toronto. Page 49.

title: U.S. Reports First Drop In Population of Nassau
description: For the first time since Nassau County was founded in 1899, the Long Island suburban neighbor to New York City has declined in population, according to a new estimate by the Federal Bureau of Census.

title: Cox's Dismissal Brings Watergate Into the City's Politics as Republicans Join Democrats in Criticism of Nixon
description: The furor over the Watergate coverup and President Nixon's dismissal of Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, has spilled over into the New York political arena where, until last week, there had been no noticeable impact as Republicans took the position that the scandals were the responsibility of the Nixon Administration, not the Republican party. However, that line of defense was shaken with the public uproar over the Cox dismissal. State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican mayoral candidate, and several Republican Congressmen in marginal districts vied with Democrats in criticizing the President's action and raising the possibility of impeachment.

title: MISS LUDWIG'S DIDO IS KEENLY REALIZED
description: Christa Ludwig, the distinguished mezzosoprano, has been plagued by illness for the last year, and at the last moment it kept her from singing in the opening performance of Les Troyens at the Metropolitan Opera last Monday night. She was to have sung Dido in the second part of Berlioz's remarkable work.

title: New Delhi: Cool Air Ignites Culture
description: NEW DELHI  Darkness falls on the capital by 6:30 now. Along Janpath and Connaught Circus, shoppers and hawkers and moviegoers push through the crowded bazaars. On rooftops the dark migratory birds from north Siberia, who flock to New Delhi each autumn in search of food and warmth, chirp loudly as the lights flicker downtown. The six months of heat from the plains have finally been tempered by the monsoon showers. Almost fragilely, cool air clings to the city, especially in the morning and evening, and sets the mood and tone of the social and artistic and even business life of the capital. After the torpor of summer, New Delhi welcomes the autumn with a hasty embrace.

title: NEW HEART STUDY ABSOLVES COFFEE
description: Those who have given up the traditional American breakfast of eggs, bacon and coffee for fear of heart disease may at least get back their coffee, according to a new study, made in California, that found no relationship between heart attacks and the nation's most popular beverage.

title: GOVERNOR'S RACE IN VIRGINIA CLOSE
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 28Growing voter indecision, and perhaps apathy, have thrown the 1973, Virginia governorship race into doubt.

title: Secretariat Wins Finale
description: Secretariat ended his racing career yesterday with a 6length victory in the Canadian International Championship at Woodbine race track, Toronto. Page 49.

title: Notre Dame Joins the Elite In Dreaming of No. 1 Rank
description: Thoughts of the national college football championship, about as elusive and real as a leprechaun, flitted through the dreams of Notre Dame players and coaches last night in the aftermath of the impressive 2314 victory over Southern California on Saturday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Striking Musicians Prepare For 6Concert Iberian Tour
description: Some 95 members of the New York Philharmonic, on strike since Sept. 25, will leave for Spain next week for a nineday, sixconcert tour that will take the orchestra to Madrid, Barcelona and then to Limn in Portugal.

title: MONTCLAIR STARTS A HOUSING PROJECT
description: MONTCLAIR, Oct. 28The churchsponsored Union Development Corporation broke ground today for the construction of 87 apartments, the first. nonprivate housing development in this town.

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: hangers pouted By Penguins, 72; 4th Straight Loss
description: The New York Rangers, their heads bloody and bowed, suffered their fourth straight defeat last night as they let the Pittsburgh Penguins shell them, 72, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Difference Over Access to Documents. Could Delay Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28An apparentconflict between President Nixon and his Acting Attorney General, Robert H. Bork, over the independence of a new special Watergate prosecutor could delay the naming of a replacement for Archibald Cox unless it is resolved in the next day or two.

title: Red Smith
description: TORONTO, Oct. 28The horse came down through thickening gloom, outrunning the thin, mean rain that an east wind drove in slanting gusts. Some spectators couldn't contain themselves. They vaulted the grandstand rail and rushed across the dirt track to the fence that borders the grass course at Woodbine. They just had to be close when perfection went rushing past. Cops raced across to herd the stragglers back, and by the time that job was done Eddie Maple had ridden Secretariat back to the winner's circle. On the colt's red withers was a stole of white carnations with a big maple leaf of red flowers worked into it.

title: Public TV Attempts a LightHearted Look at Old Age
description: Tonight's do good project on public television is called Wrinkles, Birthdays and Other Fables. Produced by Station KCET in Los Angeles, it presumably is supposed to do for the problems of old age what last season's VD Blues did for venereal diseases. It doesn't. For one thing, old age, which can't be cured with an injection, doesn't lend Itself readily to giddy irreverence.

title: Secretariat Bids Farewell With 6Length Victory
description: TORONTO, Oct. 28Secretariat closed out a glorious career in spectacular style today, winning the Canadian International Championship by 6 lengths at Woodbine race track.

title: Watergate: Week Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28This week will see a number of actions in the manyfaceted Watergate case. In addition to the expected naming of a new Watergate special prosecutor by Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork, the following activities are also Scheduled:

title: Defeat 5th in Row as Hart Throws for 4 Scores
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28Despite a gallant 348yard passing performance by Randy Johnson, the New York Giants dropped their fifth straight game, 3527, today to the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: 3D TERM SOUGHT IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 27Can Albert J. Hofstede, a young liberal Democrat who has the backing of the labor unions and a rejuvenated local party, turn back the clock and unseat the incumbent Mayor, a former burglary detective who swept into office four years ago as a champion of law and order and conservatism?

title: NORTH BRUNSWICK DEDICATES SCHOOL
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK TOWNSHIP, Oct. 28  A $10million high school that has a leading role in a protracted controversy over the racial balance of the secondary school system in neighboring New Brunswick was formally dedicated today.

title: LEO STASHIN DEAD; PHOTOGRAPHER, 54
description: Leo Stashin, a photographer, who in recent years turned to collecting and identifying daguerreotypes of 19thcentury American statesmen, actors, inventors and businessmen, died Saturday of cancer in St. Luke's. Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 75 Bank Street.

title: U.S. Reports First Drop in Population of Nassau
description: For the first time since Nassau County was founded in 1899, the Long Island suburban neighbor to New York City has declined in population, according to a new estimate by the Federal Bureau of Census.

title: 24 From Argentine Navy Ship Missing in Collision
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 (UPI)Two Argentine ships, one a navy transport, collided early today in a narrow channel of the Ro de la Plata estuary off the coast of Argentina. Twentyfour persons were missing and believed drowned.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Numerous Records Set in September For Machine Tools
description: The machinetool industry set numerous records in September, and, based on a trademagazine survey, the outlook is bullish for a continuation of this activity.

title: The Ford Nomination
description: Congressional consideration of Representative Gerald Ford's nomination to the VicePresidency should be moved along as swiftly as a genuine probing of his qualifications will allow. The case for speed rests on a twofold need:

title: Apollo Countdown Begins For Nov. 10 Trip to Skylab
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP)  A launching team started tonight the countdown on the Saturn 1B rocket and Apollo spaceship that will boost the third set of astronauts to the Skylab space station on Nov. 10.

title: Ghana and Senegal Break Diplomatic Ties With Israel
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Ghana today broke diplomatic relations with Israel until such time as Israel withdraws from Arab lands.

title: Cambodian Intervention
description: The effort by China and a group of nonaligned nations to seat the exiled regime of Prince Norodom Sihanouk at the United Nations in place of the Cambodian Government of President Lon Nol represents flagrant intervention in the internal affairs of a member state. This is a clear violation of the U.N. Charbei.

title: New England Teachers' Seminar on Watergate Ends in Call for the Impeachment of Nixon
description: SCARBOROUGH, Me., Oct. 28  A teachers' conference here that began as a discussion of how to teach about Watergate ended as a lesson in activism yesterday with leaders from throughout New England calling for the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Texas Woman, 115, Dies
description: LAREDO, Tex., Oct, 28, (AP) Mrs. Julia M. ristan, who was 115 years old, died near here Friday. She was born March 12, 1858, in Saltillo, Coahuila, Mexico, and had lived in Mirando City for a long time. Mrs. Cristan is survived by 2 sons, 6 daughters, 72 grandchildren, 192 greatgrandchildren and 37 greatgreatgrandchildren.

title: Poisoned Walnuts Stolen in Bushwick;Police Alert Issued
description: The theft from an exterminator's truck of a pound of walnuts coated with squirrel poison spread alarm and concerted police action in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Trio in Young Swiss Troupe Delights With New Look at an Ancient Art
description: One of the most original and delightful theatrical events seen here in a long time took place at Tully Hall Saturday night when Mummenschanz, the Swiss MimeMasque Theater, made its local debut.

title: Jordan's Big War Loss Is Her Tourist Business
description: MADABA, Jordan, Oct. 26 The Prophet Moses climbed Mount Nebo in Old Testament times, according to the Book of Deuteronomy, and the Lord showed him all the land of Gilead, along with the rest of the Promised Land.

title: Clark Clifford
description: WASHINGTONAs each new chapter in the Watergate tragedy unfolds, I have an increasing sense of grim foreboding as I look at the future. The extent of the damage already sustained, and the worsening of the Administration's posture as further revelations occur, emphasize the fact that this is no time for partisanship. This is the time for Americans to work together to save this country.

title: Touch Dancing (Remember That?) Draws 100 to a World Contest Here
description: Fifty couples, who almost never step on each other's toes, waltzed, tangoed, foxtrotted and Bostonjived around the floor of the Felt Forum yesterday and Saturday night, evaluated by 13 adjudicators and, two final scrutineers in the world championships of professional ballroom dancing.

title: City Plans Fulton St. Mall in Brooklyn
description: A $4million program to convert an eightblock stretch of Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn into a mall is to be announced Thursday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Miss Bergen Leads Free Brahms Event With a Sturdy Beat
description: At an age when most people have long since decided to take life as easy as possible, Charlotte Bergen is doing just the opposite. This extraordinary, welltodo woman from New Jersey who began giving an annual free performance of Monteverdi's music at Town Hall a few years ago has begun her busiest musical season so far.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28This week will see a number of actions in the manyfaceted Watergate case. In addition to the expected naming of a new Watergate special prosecutor by Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork, the following activities are also scheduled:

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST PATERSON, Oct. 28Princeton will be a strong favorite to continue its monopoly in the seventh annual New Jersey intercollegiate crosscountry championships Tuesday at Garret Mountain reservation.

title: EGYPTIANS IN TRAP GETTING SUPPLIES; ISRAELIS ASSENT
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28  Israel agreed today to allow the encircled Egyptian III Corps to be resupplied by truck convoy.

description: Ina scathing report, seven present and past judges of the Family Court and the state jucial administrator charged yesterday that city, state and private agencies had all failed the cause of troubled children here.

title: Quebec's Election Today Holds Future of Separatists
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 28Candidates for the provincial legislature wound up four weeks of campaigning today with all sides agreeing, at least, that the election here tomorrow is likely to be crucial to the future of Quebec.

title: Goodrich Scores 49
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 (UPI)Gail Goodrich had a careerhigh 49 points and Elmore Smith blocked 17 shots tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 11198.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Broadening his attack upon the man thought to have the best chance of being elected Mayor next week, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal charged yesterday that Abraham D. Beame's candidacy represents a danger to the Democratic party.

title: DR. CHARLES J. STRAHAN
description: OCEAN GROVE, N.J. Oct. 28 Dr. Charles J. Strahan, former New Jersey State Commissioner of Education, died yesterday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. He was 96 years old.

title: Douglas, Dissenter and Rights Champion, Sets Record for Tenure on Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The judicial career of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, the evergreen dissenter, champion of the rights of the individual and laureate of the wilderness, passed a milestone today  an event for which the 75yearold jurist professes a mild distaste.

title: Poisoned Walnuts Stolen in Bushwick; Police Alert Issued
description: The theft from an exterminator's truck of a pound of walnuts coated with squirrel poison spread alarm and concerted police action in the Bush Wick section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Sally Munves Is Remarried
description: Mrs. Sally Frowenfeld Munves was married here yesterday to Theodore K. Broido, national regional director for the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. The ceremony was performed at the House of Living Judaism by Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, president elect of Union of American Hebrew Congregations, and Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein of Westport, Conn.

title: Aluminum Producers Predict Growing Shortages
description: Just try buying aluminum storm windows these days. The dealers will laugh at you.

title: Student Body Doubles
description: LOCHIEL, Ariz., Oct. 28 (AP) Enrollment is up 100 per cent in the Lochiel Elementary School. School officials reported six students attending the oneroom schoolhouse, up from three a year ago.

title: $3.90 a Pound, a State Record, Is Paid For the Top 4H Club Aberdeen Angus
description: TRENTON, Oct. 28 Housewives with surplus freezer space, buyers from New Jersey cooperatives, industries with employe cafeterias and supermarket representatives gathered here last week to support 4H Clubs and, they hoped, garner bargains in beef. This year's 4H Club Show's winner and grand champion, a purebred Aberdeen Angus named Warren, represented 1,138 pounds of good eating on the hoof. After spirited bidding during the sale that followed the show, Warren went to ShopRite of Elizabeth for $3.90 a pound, the highest price in the history of the annual auction. Last year's winner brought $3.10 a pound.

title: The Dance
description: Pat Catterson looks at dancers, and dances begin to form in her mind where others might see only physical skills. The emerging works develop meaningfully more often than not, though occasionally formal design is replaced by repetitive display.

title: Emergency Alert Continues For 400,000 U.S. Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 28 (AP)  Some 400,000 men of the United States military forces remained on emergency alert today. Pentagon officials said that the number was unchanged since yesterday.

title: Sabres Win, 52, Lose Perreault
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 28 (UPI)Gil Perreault broke his left leg in the second period, after he scored a goal in the opening period tonight to spark the Buffalo Sabres to a 52 victory over the. New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game.

title: Rachela Subel Wed to Joseph Solomon
description: WYNNEWOOD, Pa., Oct. 28Miss Rachela Lea Subel, daughter of Mrs. Allen Bernard Subel of Elkins Park and the, late Mr. Subel, was married here this afternoon to Joseph Saul Solomon, son of Mrs. Herman J. Solomon of Miami Beach and Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Solomon.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Mrs. John J. McCloy always drops in at Les Boutiques de Noel to buy cheese for nephews in Arizona and to select gifts for others on her Christmas list. Mrs. W. Vincent Astor shops at the annual Christmas sale, too, and so does Mrs. Charles S. Payson, owner of the New York Mets.

title: EGYPTIANS INTRO GETTING SUPPLIES; ISRAELIS ASSENT
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28  Israel agreed today to allow the encircled Egyptian III Corps to be resupplied by truck convoy.

title: Three Touchdowns Scored by Denver In 96 Seconds
description: After wandering for what seemed like 40 years in the National Football League wilderness, the Jets finally reached the promised land yesterday. But no one ever promised the Jets they would win in the promised land.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A BROOKLYN MALL PLANNED BY CITY
description: A $4million program to convert an eightblock stretch of Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn into a mall is to be announced Thursday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Double Concertos Given in Program By Musica Aeterna
description: From time to time, Frederic Waldman and his Musica Aeterna Orchestra give wonderfully informative concerts for the cultivated musical public that has formed around the Musica Aeterna events at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Saturday's program was a good example of these.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI)Gary Davidson, president of the World Hockey Association, is expected to be voted out of office tomorrow at a regular meeting of the league's board of trustees.

title: McClard, Saints' PickUpKicker, BootsTeam to Upset of Redskins
description: Early last week, Bill McClard was out of work. The secondyear placekicker from the University of Arkansas was cut by the San Diego Chargers, a strange move for a team that had just lost to Atlanta, 410.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Brezhnev Note Is Reported To Have Threatened Israel
description: Time magazine says in its current issue that the note on the Middle East crisis sent by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, to President Nixon threatened the destruction of the State of Israel by Soviet forces if Israel did not stop violating, the ceasefire.

title: Rangers Routed By Penguins, 72; 4th Straight Loss
description: The New York Rangers, their heads bloody and bowed, suffered their fourth straight defeat last night as they let the Pittsburgh Penguins shell them, 72, at Madison Square Garden.

title: On Motives
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28They hate me, said Franklin Roosevelt of his most savage critics, adding with a vengeance and I welcome their hatred.

title: CHICAGO 7 START NEW TRIAL TODAY
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28A new contempt of court trial for the seven defendants in the Chicago riot and conspiracy case and for two of their lawyers will begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court. Judge Edward T. Gignoux of Maine was appointed to handle the trial by United States Chief Justice Warren Burger.

title: Many Israelis Feel It's Far From Over
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28Just north of Tel Aviv this morning schoolchildren in blue uniforms were digging in the dunes on the side of the highway, filling sandbags for use in the city's shelters.

title: Four Abortion Clinics Approved By State Health Planning Unit
description: TRENTON, Oct. 28The State Health Planning Council has approved applications for the establishment of the first four abortion clinics in New Jersey.

title: Finley is Fined $7,000 by Kuhn
description: Charles O. Finley, the controversial owner of the Oakland A's, has been fined by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for three instances of misconduct during the World Series. The most publicized of the offenses was Finley's attempt to place Mike Andrews on the disabled list.

title: Sunnyside Surprise
description: Anyone who likes surprises will just love the Sports Center proposal for the Sunnyside yards in Queens made by the newly created State Racing and Wagering Board. New York City doesn't like it very much, and for good reason.

title: Both Sides Oppress Vietnamese Villagers
description: HOAI MY, South Vietnam, Oct. 20A deceptive serenity cloaks this humble village near the central coast of South Vietnam. The Lai Giang River, broad and clear, moves lazily through the lush rice paddies to the sea. On its southern bank, mingling among banana trees and coconut palms, thatched houses stand interwined by meandering paths.

title: Daughter Reports Nixon Sometimes Discouraged
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP)Mrs. David Eisenhower spoke of her father, President Nixon, today as a man who sometimes gets very discouraged.

title: Mahaffey, on 271, Gains First Pro Tour Victory
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 28 (UPI)John Mahaffey, a pupil of Ben Hogan, won his first Professional Golfers' Association tournament when he shot a threeunderpar 68 today to win the $135,000 Sahara invitation by three strokes with a 72hole total of 271.

title: OFFERINGS CLIMB IN BOND MARKETS
description: A rising volume of new issues, especially taxexempts may well be the key nearterm factor in determining the direction the bond markets will take, many creditmarket observers believe.

title: REP. JOHN SAYLOR OF PENNSYLVANIA
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)Bepresentative John P. Saylor, senior Republican member of the Pennsylvania Congressional delegation, died early today in St. Luke's Hospital, where he had undergone heart surgery. He was 65 years old and lived in Johnstown, Pa.

title: 2 MAIL BOMBS PUT DENVER ON ALERT
description: DENVER, Oct. 28 (UPI) Cautious pcistal workers inspected every piece of mail in Denver today for bomb packages similar to one already intercepted and another delivered but noticed by its intended victim in the nick of time.

title: Peace Delegate Challenges Moscow on the Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28A Belgian peace activist today took the floor at a commission session of the World Peace Congress meeting here to ask that the Soviet Union show its attachment to the cause of liberty by granting amnesty to all its political prisoners.

title: Charge That Ford Defaulted on Loan Described as Lie
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) A spokesman for the Vice Presidentdesignate, Gerald R.I Ford, says a report that Mr. Ford failed to repay a $15,000 loan from a former lobbyist is a lie.

title: Spotlight Still on Politics At the Nassau Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 28  Elvis Presley wiggled here. Spiro T. Agnew made a speech here, and Julius (Doctor J.) Erving has dissected his basketball opponents here all since the Nassau Coliseum opened 21 months ago.

title: ROBERT M'LAUGHLIN, A WRITER AND EDITOR
description: MIAMI, Oct. 28 (AP)Robert McLaughlin, a former managing editor of McCall's magazine and a longtime writer for Time magazine, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 65 years old.

title: AGNEW AND SINATRA AT CHICAGO MEETING
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI)Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and Frank Sinatra, the singer, met with an insurance magnate and philanthropist, W. Clement Stone, at the Ambassador East Hotel yesterday, then eluded newsmen and left town.

title: Switch to Standard Time May Not Happen Again
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The country went back to standard time today. It may never happen again.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ART OF WALT DISNEY. From Mickey Mouse to the Magic Kingdoms, By Christopher Finch, With a Special Essay by Peter Blake. 458 pages, Illustrated. Abrams. $35 through 12/31/73; $45 thereafter.

title: BROOKLYN MAN HELD IN MURDER OF WIFE
description: A 20yearold Brooklyn man who had told the police on Saturday that intruders had murdered his wife was charged with the murder yesterday.

title: Elevator Crushes Bronx Boy
description: A 14yearold boy was crushed to death yesterday by an elevator in the Rosedale houses at 1020 Soundview Ayenue, the Bronx, where he lived, the police said. The police said Curtis Logan put his head through the rectangular space in the thirdfloor elevator door where a window was missing and was crushed by the descending elevator.

title: U.S. Agency Orders Departure Of Ruckelshaus Family Worker
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 KaijaLeena Rikkonen, the young Finnish woman brought into this country by the former Deputy Attorney General, William D. Ruckelshaus, and his wife, Jill, to work as a household helper in violation of immigration, laws, has been ordered to leave the United States by Nov. 7.

title: 76ers Lose By 11999 To Bullets
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 28, (AP)Phil Chenier scored 32 points and his backcourt partner, Kevin Porter, had 23 as the Capital Bullets defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 119 to 99, tonight

title: COUNTESS OF DUDLEY ROBBED OF JEWELS
description: Burglars broke into the apartment of the Countess of Dudley in a fashionable East Side residential hotel over the weekend and stole $55,000 in jewels, the police reported last night.

title: Sue Lyon in Hospital
description: CANON CITY, Colo., Oct. 28. (UPI)Sue Lyon, the film actress, who is engaged to marry a convicted murderer in the Colorado State Prison next month, was hospitalized here today for fatigue and a throat infection.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Barbara Mesh Is Bride
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 28Miss Barbara Kay Mesh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Mesh of Rockville Centre, was married here this evening to Edwin Ray Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamar E. Stanley of Miami. Judge Stanley Rosenthal of the Nassau County District Court performed the ceremony at the Salisbury Country Club.

title: Boy, 12, Found Hanged In BedfordStuyvesant
description: A 12yearold boy was found hanged to death on a rope from a door in his family's apartment in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night, the police reported.

title: Ulster Policeman Slain While Visiting Republic
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, 10ct. 28 (Reuters)A policeman was shot to death in a guerrilla ambush tonight while visiting relatives across the border in the Irish Republic.

title: Pop Music: FormFitting Is Moody's Longest Suit
description: Moody Blues, frontrunners of the socalled classical rock style, made its annual pilgrimage to New York and visited Madison Square Garden on Friday. And pilgrimage it was, for the faithful gathereda soldout house, deeply appreciative and committed from the moment the fivemember British group stepped out of a swirl of dryice fumes to begin playing. (Dry ice is very big with rock groups right now.)

title: HIGH AIDE IS SENT TO U.S. BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, Oct. 28  President Anwar elSadat tonight sent a senior career diplomat on a trip to Washington.

title: Newsweek Says Inquiries Focus on Nixon Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.1Federal and Congressional investigators are looking into possible corruption at the highest levels of the Nixon Administration, and have been focusing on the personal finances of the President himself, Newsweek magazine says in its edition to be published tomorrow.

title: Pomeranian Is Selected Best Among 327 Toy Dogs Here
description: It was toy time on 34th Street yesterday, with 327 toys on exhibition at the McAlpin Hotel. But they were all of the canine variety competing in the Progressive DOg Club's 41st annual fixture.

title: JOSEPHINE SHIRER
description: WESTWOOD, N.J. Oct. 28Josephine Shirer, an English teacher in Westwood High School from 1932 to her retirement in 1960, died yesterday in Pascack Valley Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived at 100 Mill Street.

title: Hanratty Replaces Injured Bradshaw, Sparks Victory
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28In a violent game, the Pittsburgh Steelers held off the Cincinnati Bengals for a 2013 victory today but lost their starting quarterback, Terry Bradshaw, possibly for the season, with a partial shoulder separation.

title: Behind Public Satisfaction at U.N. Over Mideast Truce, There Is Anger at Big Powers' Arbitrariness
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 28The way the superpowers acted alone in handling the Middle East crisis has provoked an angry, if muted, chorus of resentment at the United Nations.

title: Guard Shot as Bandit Gets $3,200 at Downtown Bank
description: A gunman entered a bank near City Hall yesterday, shot a guard twice, scaled a counter and seized a handful of money then dropped $800 of it as he scaled the counter again on his way out.

title: MORGAN GUARANTY SETS 9% PRIME
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company yesterday lowered its prime rate to 9 per cent, following the lead on Friday of the First National City Bank in making the quarterpoint cut.

title: ThreeInch Rain and Winds. Batter City
description: Driving, winds and pounding rains beat a daylong tattoo on the city yesterday, ending a 26day October drought with a record rainfall that flooded streets and lowlying sections, snarled traffic and drenched pedestrians.

title: Hospital Freed Killer, 16, But He Commits Himself
description: A youth just turned 16 last month walked into Bellevue Hospital's psychiatric ward last week, and voluntarily committed himself saying, I think I am going to hurt somebody.

title: Sheikdoms Said to Promise Jordan Millions in Aid for Her Role in War
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 29Arab sheikdoms on the Persian Gulf have promised millions of dollars in new aid to Jordan, largely in appreciation of her part in the war with Israel, highly placed informants said here yesterday.

title: Sandman Says Byrne Plans New Tax
description: EAST ORANGE, Oct, 29Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. charged today that Brendan T. Byrne, The Democratic candidate for Governor, intended to impose a new tax on business and industry to avoid a state income tax during the first year of his administration, if he is elected.

title: Modern Museum Union Asks Fact Finding in Bid to Return
description: The union striking against the Museum of Modern Art said yesterday that it would go back to work this week if the museum agreed to submit all strike issues to a factfinding panel.

title: NIXON REPORTED TO HAVE ORDERED I.T.T. SETTLEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has told the Watergate prosecution that President Nixon personally ordered him not to press a series of antitrust actions against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to sources close to the case.

title: Rockland Town's New Obscenity Panel Stirs Dispute and Leads to a Suit
description: CLARKSTOWN, N. Y., Oct 29An antiobscenity committee formed several weeks ago to investigate motion pictures and other public displays of materials has stirred a controversy in this quiet Rockland County town.

title: Candidates' Day Marchi Promises a Bill to Overturn Vacancy Rent Decontrol Law
For a Special Presidential Election
description: BOSTONThe nation is now facing the most significant political crisis in its history. The crisis encompasses not simply the issue of whether and how the President should be removed but perhaps more importantly the question of how, through the manner of Presidential succession, confidence in the Presidency and the political process is to be restored.

title: Douglas Defends Right of Critics To Attack Government Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Justice William O. Douglas said today that some national government leaders get the idea that they sort of run the country, that they own the country when in reality they are only minor characters compared to the people.

title: 400 Are Believed Held
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29Israeli officials said today, that the continuation of the Middle East, ceasefire was contingent on the early identification and release of more than 400 Israeli soldiers believed captured by Egypt and Syria.

title: As Giants Improve on Offense, Defensive Units Start Faltering
description: The New York Giants plugged up leaks in their passing game, punting and kickoff returns last Sunday only to find their defense sandbagged by what one of their coaches called a lack of rhythm and coordination.

title: Welfare Hotel Crime High With Many Rooms Empty
description: Some of the city's most notorious hotels catering to single welfare recipients are operating now with dozens of empty rooms, and others of the hotels have been converted to new uses, but city officials say crime is still rampant in and around the welfare hotels.

title: HEAVY BATTLE LOSS REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (UPI)Communist troops inflicted heavy losses on a Government militia platoon in a night attack 64 miles northeast of Saigon and Government troops killed more than 80 Communists in a battle in the Mekong delta, the Saigon command reported today.

title: Government Looking for Eligibles for New Welfare Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Government has begun searching for aged, blind and disabled persons who may be eligible for newly federalized welfare payments beginning Jan. 1.

title: Policeman Shot in Church
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP)  A policeman is in guarded condition today after being shot while foiling an attempt to steal collection money from a church where the offduty officer was attending services, the authorities said. A police spokesnian said Detec, tive Gerald Ross was helping with the collection and this guy tried to make off with it. The spokesman said the pdlice believe the thief Was injured in the resulting p.m battle about noon at Mount Carmel Baptist Church. The thief Iled without getting any money.

title: Cox Calls Independence Crucial for Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Archibald Cox, the former special Watergate prosecutor, said today that the case was nowhere near done and described a long pattern of frustration in attempts to get documents from the White House.

title: Arthur Daley
description: In recent years the experts have pointed accusing fingers at the increased use of zone defenses and blame this for the virtual disappearance of the game's most exciting play, the bomb. For the benefit of any backward students it should be interposed that the bomb is a longrange forward pass of the heavenhelpus variety. The passer says a prayer for guidance when he lets go and the receiver prays he will be at the proper spot downfield when the ball drops from the skies. It's enough to bring back religion.

title: Chess: Too Wild, Too Tame, Spassky Is the Goat for All Reasons
description: Boris Spassky has been getting it from all sides. The former world champion, having yielded his room at the top to Bobby Fischer in Iceland, has been criticized by Mikhail Botvinnik, the retired dean of Russian chess, for indulging in hazardous, speculative adventures in attacking play.

title: C.U.N.Y. Adopts Policy to Limit Tenure to 50% of the Teachers
description: The City University last nigh adopted a new policy that will discourage C.U.N.Y. colleges and departments from granting tenure to more than half of their faculty members.

title: N.F.L. Upsets Strike a Similar Chord
description: Underneath the padding, the face masks and the helmets are real people who have emotions. Some days pro football players are up and some days they are down. That's about the best possible explanation for the outcome of two incredible games on Sunday, Washington's defeat at the About hands of the New Orleans Saints and the Dallas loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. The Redskins and Cowboys were down. The Saints and the Eagles Were up.

title: Merrick's Return to Spark Heptagonals
description: Dave Merrick has returned to the University of Pennsylvania after a year's absence and he is right, back where he was two years ago, setting crosscountry running records. Now a sophomore, Merrick is favored to win the Heptagonal crosscountry individual title at. Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, Friday. He took that individual championship two years ago as a Penn freshman when he set a course record of 24 Minutes 31.8 seconds for the five miles of hill and dale.

title: JAMES EDGERTON, AIRMAIL PIONEER
description: BOCK RATON, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP)  Col. James C. Edgerton who in 1918 participated in the country's first airmail flight delivery, died at his home here Friday. His age was 77.

title: Peace Groups to Switch To Lobbying in Congriss
description: GERMANTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 29 (AP)  About a dozen national peace groups have agreed to discard protest marches in favor of lobbying in Congress for an end to United States aid to South Vietnam and Carnbodia.

title: 8 Executives Get Immunity at Inquiry On Election Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Senate Watergate committee obtained court orders today protecting eight corporate executives from prosecution in exchange for testimony, presumably about an alledged $25,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign last year.

title: Cairo Aide Sees Kissinger; U.S. Voices Hope on Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A special representative of Egypt's President arrived in Washington today, and the State Department said his visit represented an opportunity to begin discussing a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Food Ferried to Egyptians
description: ALONG THE SUEZ CANAL, North of Suez, Egypt, Oct. 29The first 30 of 100 truckloads of medicine and food were ferried across the Suez Canal today to the Egyptian III Corps trapped on the eastern bank.

title: Opera: The Magic Flute
description: The season's first, performance of The Magic Flute by the New York City Opera on Sunday night contained so many new parts that one might have expected the production to run with a few squeaks and rattles, like a rebuilt car. But, all went, if not famously, at least well enough to send one away marveling once more at the incomparable way Mozart mixes vaudeville humor and mysticism in this endlessly charming work.

title: Writers Visit Prairie to Extol Its Soul, Willa Cather
description: LINCOLN, Nebr., Oct. 29From, three continents, scholars and admirers gathered in Nebraska to cite and define the literary contributions of that brighteyed daughter of the prairies, Willa Cather, the centenary of whose birth is being celebrated this year.

title: Electric Bills to Rise
description: The Middle East crisis and rising oil prices will drive up electric bills by 5.4 per cent in the city and by more than 26 per cent in Orange and Rockland Counties, according to estimates released by Governor Rockefeller's office yesterday. Details, Page 13.

title: Abducted Korean Plans to Come To U.S. for Study at Harvard
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 29 Kim Dae Jung, the former opposition political leader who was released from house arrest here last Friday, said today that he intended to go to the United States with his family soon to study at Harvard.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: GRAIN CONTRACTS DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Wheat, soybeans and corn plunged by the daily permissible price limits yesterday on the. Chicago Board of Trade and even at the lower levels there was a dearth of buying interest.

title: GUILD SAYS STRIKE MAY COME MONDAY
description: The New York Newspaper Guild warned yesterday that it Would strike either The Daily News or The New York Times next Monday morning if it was not able to work out acceptable agreements by then.

title: Increased U.S. Reliance on Coal Is Urged
description: Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said yesterday that an investment of some $15billion would be required if coal is to meet 50 per cent of the nation's energy needs by 1975.

title: Yonkers Power Failure Cancels Final 2 Races
description: The eighth and ninth races at Yonkers Raceway were canceled last night after a power failure at the track and the surrounding area because of the heavy rain. Track officials canceled the the rest of card at 10:30, 31 minutes after post time for the seventh race. The lights went out on the track, the paddock and throughout the parking lot following the seventh race.

title: Particle Tests Seem to Confirm Goal of Unified Physics Theory
description: As a result of experiment conducted in Switzerland and apparently confirmed in Illinois, a number of physicists believe that two of the basic forces of natureelectromagnetism and the lesswellknown weak force responsible for radioactivity may be expressions of the same phenomenon.

title: BEAME OUTSPENDS HIS RIVALS BY FAR
description: Big labor contributions and too big fundraising events have helped Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic nominee for Mayor, outspend his three major rivals overwhelmingly in the New York City mayoral campaign.

title: Shows Open With Nostalgia, Not Revolution
description: If it's revolution you're looking for, look elsewhere, New York fashion designers are saying as they draw the curtain on their spring collections.

title: Vorster's Press Threat
description: During the quartercentury in which South Africa's Nationalist Government has hacked away at basic freedoms, thereby increasingly isolating the country in the community of free nations, there has been one constant source of light and hope: the free press, especially the courageous, hardhitting Englishlanguage newspapers. Now, if his oratory at two party congresses is to be taken seriously, Prime Minister Vorster intends to change all that.

title: People and Business
description: Harry J. Gray, president and chief executive officer of the United Aircraft Corporation, will add another cap on Jan. 1 when he becomes chairman. He is to succeed Arthur E. Smith, who said he was retiring for personal reasons. Mr. Smith is 62 years old. Mr. Gray is 53.

title: Senator Beall to Disclose All Data on His Secret $200,000 Campaign Fund
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 29The investigation into a secret $200,000 contribution to the 1970 campaign of Senator J. Glenn Beall Jr., one of three inquiries here into allegations of political corruption, has been resolved with an agreement for full disclosure of the receipt and disbursement of the money.

title: Cairo Aide Sees Kissinger; U.S. Voices Hope on Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A special representative of Egypt's President arrived in Washington today, and the State Department said his visit represented an opportunity to begin discussing a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Patrick A. Burns Dead at 65; Times Photographer 47 Years
description: Patrick A. Burns, a photographer for The New York Times for 47 years, died yesterday at his home, 1505 Archer Road, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sales of these shortterm securities. The average rate for threeMonth bills in this week's sale is 7.196 per cent up from 6.959 last week, while the average rate for sixmonth bills in this week's sale is 7.263, up from 6.951 last week.

title: Pan American Chamber Group Performs With 3 Gifted Singers
description: Hoping to broaden the base of LatinAmerican music performances and appreciation in New York, Joseph Lliso, music director of Fordham University at Lincoln Center, introduced three gifted Puerto Rican singers and his newly formed Pan American Chamber Orchestra at Town Hall on Sunday night.

title: 2 RADIO NETWORKS TURN TO THE PAST
description: Twenty years after television laid claim to a mass nationan audience, two of the ?? radio networks are about to test the feasibility of attracting listeners to the broadcasting styles of a generaton ago.

title: N.A.S.D. DISCIPLINES 7 BROKERAGE FIRMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Reuters) The National Association of Securities Dealers, regulatory agency for the overthecounter market, today announced that it had taken disciplinary action for rule violations against seven brokerage firms.

title: CNA MERGER TALKS WITH GULF HALTED
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, the world's third largest producer of crude oil, and the CNA Financial Corporation announced yesterday they had been unable to reach a definitive agreement on the agreement in principle to merge announced on Oct. 1 and that they had suspended negotiations indefinitely.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Peronists, at Leader's Behest, Are, Purging Leftists From Party
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29With the blessings of President Juan Domingo Pern, conservatives among his followers have begun a campaign to purge leftists from the Peronist movement.

title: Theater: Aleichem's Hard to Be a Jew
description: If you're one of those who think of Yiddish theater in terms of bygone art, by all means get down to the Eden Theater, on. Second Avenue, the original Broadway of the art, and see one of the more lively shows in town, It's Hard to Be a Jew.

title: DR. JESSE ZIZMOR, 65, PSYCHOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Jesse Zizmor, a psychoanalyst here since 1939, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 210 East 68th Street.

title: Food Ferried to Egyptians
description: ALONG THE SUEZ CANAL, North of Suez; Egypt, Oct. 29The first 30 of 100 truckloads of medicine and food were ferried across the Stiez Canal today to the Egyptian III Corps trapped on the eastern bank.

title: Wood, Field, Stream: Good Cooking
description: The pleasures of wood stove cookery were mine a short while ago in a remote cabin in northern New Hampshire.

title: SHAKER TO SEEK A.F.T. PRESIDENCY
description: Albert Shanker, the head of the United Federation of Teachers in New York City and the executive vicepresident of the state union, said yesterday that he would be a candidate for the presidency of the American Federation of Teachers next summer.

title: Catholic Villger Is Killed At Home South of Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Gunmen shot and killed a 34yearold Roman Catholic on the doorstep of his home in a village south of Belfast: today and terrorists blew pub in a town near the Irish Republic batten.

title: Concert
description: The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington opened its annual New York series on Sunday afternoon in the unaccustomed setting of Carnegie Hall. The concert had been given a sudden change of venue because of the New York Philharmonie picket lines at Avery Fisher Hall. Antal Dorati made capital of the acoustical advantage thereby gained, most obviously in percussive climaxes of Strauss's Till Eulenspiegel and Donald. Erb's Symphony of Overtures. For occasional visitors to Carnegie, the temptation to create a brilliant, sonorous ruckus must be great.

title: Too Cool for Comfort
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Nixon worries too much about coolness. He seems to believe that coolness is a good quality. He talks about having it himself in large quantity.

title: BUCHANAN ASKS CURB ON NEWS NETWORKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) Patrick J. Buchanan, speechwriter for President Nixon, said today that the broadcast networks have too much power in United States news reporting.

title: Russians Given First Word Of Nixon's Political Peril
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Soviet people were told for the first time, yesterday that the Watergate scandal had raised questions of President Nixon's continuing in office.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROARING 40'S Well, maybe not, roaring, but declaiming, anyway. That's the situation of the Academy of American Poets, born just 34 years, ago and dedicated to the muse of verse. The society is not exactly composed of poets, although on its board of chancellors are such as Robert Lowell and Elizabeth Bishop, but it is rather more of a service organization performing the essential job of extracting funds to carry on the work of this frequently povertypocked art.
