description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 29A jury of seven men and seven women was selected in Superior Court here today for the trial of a 23yearold Perrineville man accused of the shotgun murder last June of his hopelessly crippled brother in a hospital bid.

description: Secretariat came home in the rain yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  President Nixon has signed a $19billion approproations bill for activities of the Veterans Admitration, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the national space agency and other Government agencies in the current fiscal year.

description: Catholic Teachers Reject Pay Offer

title: Advertising: Telling It All as It Is
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 29The day when advertising tells it all, not just the good points about a product or service, is not far off, judging from remarks made here today by Lewis A. Engman, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Whips, Hidden Persuaders, Help Move Wheels of Government in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 As hidden persuaders, the House of Representatives metropolitan area whips are the pillars of party orthodoxy. They take the pulse of their state delegations to help determine Which bills to bring to the floor, which bills to shelve, and when to corral House members say, who are campaigning for Mayor on the streets of New York but who are needed in Washington on a crucial vote.

description: PUEBLO WEST, Colo.; Oct. 27Chili, the sinusclearing bowl of murkily mudlike gob and goo, has rarely been so damned and praised.

title: Iceman' Film DoesJustice to the Play
description: Just at the moment when many have been stripped of their national illusionsconcerning the purity of governmentEugene O'Neill's conviction that people cannot live without personal illusions comes through with a fresh tang of irony.As a drama for any and every decade, "The Iceman Cometh," which opened yesterday at selected theaters, stresses that human dignity depends on dreams, even deceptions. Perhaps this is an especially American trait; many Europeans seem able to survive with fewer fantasies than we do.Reeking with failure, the unbudgeable barflies in O'Neill's 1912 saloon still manage to shore up shards of self-respect with their own private myths. The former radical pretends to despise the Movement that disappointed him, and claims that he's merely a detached observer of lifewhich isn't true. The bar's proprietor, who hasn't been outdoors for the 20 years since his wife died, vows that one day he'll walk through his old neighborhood. We know he won't. The bartender who insists that he's not a pimp, just because he bosses prostitutes, and the women themselves, who say that they're only tarts, not whores, the musty anarchist who knows that life will be lovely after the Revolution, the boozehounds who are going to give up drinking, the unemployables who will surely recapture their lost jobsall keep their rusty armor intact until they're manipulated by Hickey, the glib salesman who's determined to make them swallow the truth about themselves.Nearly crazed by Hickey's challenge, they all fall apart. Some also turn against one another, suddenly pulling a gun or a knife or a broken bottle on the former companions of nickel whisky. Hickey's machinations even start the Boer War going again, between two furious wrecks who fought on opposite sides. Moreover, Hickey has the gift of making others suicidal. But finally, when the group learns that he purged himself of pipe dreams only by killing his wife, most return gratefully to the illusions that kept them going.As Hickey, Lee Marvin has the salesman's slick authority, the talent for hustling his way across people's spiritual doorsills and invading their privacy. And we can believe in his ability to force their moods to change. As he lectures them about reality, Marvin achieves a maddening moral presenceboth jovial and righteous at once. Later, he's powerful in the rage of self-hatred, also when he relives the decision to commit murder.As one character says, Hickey has "the fixed idea of the insane," and Marvin does convey that. However, his Hickey seems deliberately charmlessalthough the play demands a maniac spell-caster. Marvin's performance is just too rationally earthbound for a part that needs the touch of a magician.Fredric March as the saloonkeeper has a fine, befuddled childlike air, Moses Gunn is superb as a ravaged black rebel, and George Voskovec and Martyn Green fight splendidly together as the old warriors who share the rotgut. There's a moving glimpse of the late Robert Ryan as the exhausted ironist who waits for death; the stern pity he levels at others is tempered with an occasional youthful smile. And Tom Pedi, the pimping bartender, is deft at miming exaggerated patience.Jeff Bridges, the child of the Movement who delivered his revolutionary mother to the cops, begins well but eventually overplays. So do Evans Evans (the key streetwalker), Bradford Dillman as the shattered law school graduate, and several of the others. Those who overact may have been directed to do so because the play has one lumpy problem: how do you convey drunkenness and fatigue without losing vitality? It can be done, as we've seen on other occasions, but the question, tempts some performers to gnaw the scenery.Infinite care and thought and respect have been poured into this production. But the play doesn't flourish in film form for one reason: even the simplest camerawork breaks the continuity. We're supposed to see these people as one huddled mass, imprisoned together in the room they rarely leave, perpetually affected by one another's words or presence. Inevitably, closeups destroy that.We especially lose the impact of the ensemble during Hickey's last monologue. So we're denied the crowd's full recoil when he confesses to the killing, their collective efforts not to hear him, their agitation, their final relief in deciding that it's he who's crazy, not themselves. Admittedly, drunks don't make the world's best listeners. But here, the camera isolates them from the flow that O'Neill designed.So this isn't the "Iceman" of your lifetime. And there will be many who can't help recalling Jason Robards as Hickey; Robards is often regarded as the exclusive owner of that role. But the play is an inescapably great experience, and that fact isn't muffled by this film.

title: Paterson General Is Told to Maintain Emergency Room
description: NEWARK, Oct. 29 (AP)A Federal bankruptcy judge or dered Paterson General Hospital today to keep its innercity emergency facilities open despite claims that the facility is losing $3,200 a day.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The chief White House international economies adviser said that Congress should temporarily shelve legislation on trade concessions to the Soviet Union while Middle East negotiations were under way. Peter M. Flanigan told the Sente Banking Subcommittee that it would be inappropriate for Congress to deal one way or the other with the issue of mostfavored nation status or extension of credits to the Soviet Union when Soviet cooperation was needed to settle the ArabIsraeli dispute. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Electric Bills to Rise
description: The Middle East crisis and rising oil prices will drive up electric bills by 5.4 per cent in the city and by more than 26 per cent in Orange and Rockland Counties, according to estimates released by Governor Rockefeller's office yesterday. Details, Page 13.

title: Moscow Says It Will Help Pay for Peace Force but Insists Operations Be Lawful
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29The Soviet Union said today that it would share the costs for the new United Nations peace force in the Middie East so long as Moscow considered it was acting in a lawful and legitimate way.

title: Stage: Carmines's No Amen Religion
description: After writing musicals about Gertrude Stein, growing up in the nineteenfifties, St. Joan as a bombthrowing radical and homosexuality, the Rev. Al Carmines, the showspinning composer and minister of Judson Memorial Church, has now turned to Religion, in a musical wearing that name.

title: AMEX GAIN IS CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday although profit taking near the close eroded some of the earlier gains. However, declines outnumbered advances 443 to 400 while 321 issues were unchanged.

title: SOLZHENITSYN LINKS OFFICIALS TO THREAT
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the novelist, charged today that Soviet authorities were behind a threat made against the life of the dissident physicist Andrei O. Sakharov by men representing themselves as Arab guerrillas.

title: Key indicators Off 2d Time in 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29An index that often, gives clues to future trends in the economy declined last month for only the second time in the last three years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MARRIOTT PLANNING PEAK EXPENDITURES
description: The Marriott Corporation, an operator of restaurants, hotels and inflight services, plans record capital expenditures of $120million in its fiscal year ending July 26, 1974, up from $105million in fiscal 1973, the company disclosed yesterday in its annual report:

title: '68 Rival of Senator Hughes To Seek His Seat in 1974
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 29  State Representative David M. Stanley, who almost upset United States Senator Harold E. Hughes in 1968, announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination for Mr. Hughes's seat in 1974.

title: CARGO DIVERSION ALLOWED BY U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Federal Maritime Commission ruled today that ships can discharge cargo destined for several ports at one selected port.

title: CITIES SERVICE LIFTS THE PRICE OF COPPER
description: The Cities Service Company said that, effective Oct. 19, it had raised the price of electrolytic copper by three cents to 63 cents a pound. It added that the new price would be effective on all shipments against contracts calling for November and subsequent shipments. The major producers have generally been held at 60 cents a pound on primary copper under Phase 4 controls.

title: CHAMBER ENSEMBLE OF L.I. IN CONCERT
description: The Long Island Chamber Ensemble of New York is in many respects worthiness incarnate. The violapianoclarinetpercussion quartet, founded in 1988, offers concerts of mostly modern repertory, some of it commissioned, with firstrate musicians, both in the quartet itself and in the form of various guest artists. But the concert the group gave Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall wasn't very interesting, and it's a little hard to say why.

title: New Supermarket Squad Seeks East Side Thieves
description: Five minutes after an A. & P. supermarket on the East Side opened for business 12 days ago, four men walked into the store, drew guns and before the eyes of a dozen frightened custom ers and employes demanded the cash in the safe. The robbers took $2,650 and made their escape by car.

title: Hearing Due Today For Coast Man Held On L.I. Rape Charge
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 29A hearing will be held in District Court here tomorrow for a 34yearold man from San Francisco who is charged with the rape of a Long Island woman last Friday night, the court clerk's office said today.

title: The Brendan Byrnes: A Great Marriage Based on 20Year, TwoParty Coalition
description: WEST ORANGE, Oct. 29She is a Republican; he is a Democrat. She is Protestant; lie is a Roman Catholic. She is of ScottishEnglish descent; his forbears came from Ireland.

description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 29A jury of seven men and seven women was selected in Superior Court here today for the trial of a 23yearold Perrineville man accused of the shotgun murder last June of his hopelessly crippled brother in a hospital bed.

title: Johnny Coulon, Tiny Boxer Few Men Could Lift, Is Dead
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)Johnny Coulon, bantamweight champion of the world from 1910 to 1914, died today in a nursing home here. He was 84 years old.

Aurelio, the former Deputy Mayor who later became Presidential campaign chairman for Mayor Lindsay, raised the subject of the Mayor's Presidential campaign debt during interviews with them about their prospective appointments.

description: DETROITAmericans will buy nearly 12 million new cars this year. In an instantthe instant that the new owners drive them from the dealers' showroomsthey become used cars, of which there are now more than 100 million.

title: Opposition by Communities Is Called a Block to the Growth of Methadone Programs in City
description: Dr. Vincent Dole, a pioneer in methadone treatment for heroin addicts, said yesterday that community opposition was preventing any growth or decentralization of methadone programs in the city.

title: Kentucky Man Killed by Rattler In Rite of SnakeHandling Cult
description: LONDON, Ky., Oct. 29 A rattlesnake bit a man at a snakehandling religious service in a church in the mountains of southeast Kentucky yesterday and the man died nearly eight hours later at his home here.

title: GLOVER JOHNSON, LAWYER, 72, DUD
description: Glover Johnson, a senior partner in the law firm of White & Case, 14 Wall Street, who specialized in corporate and financial law, died Sunday at his home at Wilmot Road, New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: Study of 16 Largest Drug Companies Reports Wide Performance Variations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29An independent study of 16 of the largest prescription drug comparties operating in the United States reports wide variation in performance among them in producing safe and effective products.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Reuters)The departing president of the United States ExportImport Bank, Henry Kearns, projected today a 15 per cent annual increase United States exports in the five years from 1974 and 1978.

title: Profits Rise at Boeing, United Aircraft and Pan Am
description: Two major aircraft producers the Boeing Company and the United Aircraft Corporationreported yesterday substantial gains in profits in the third quarter. One of their principal! commercial customers Pant American World Airways, Inc. also reported an earnings improvement.

title: Thais Said to Seek Close Tie With China
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 29  The new Government, installed 15 days ago as a result of a student uprising, intends to accelerate efforts to improve relations with China and North Vietnam sources close to it said today.

title: New Home for Beverly Sills Is Destroyed by a Fire
description: TISBURY, Mass., Oct. 29 (AP)Fire destroyed the summer home being built here for Beverly Sills, the opera star, in what fire officials said may have been the seventh case of arson on Martha's Vineyard in the last two weeks.

description: Stock prices turned down yesterday as profit taking in the final 90 minutes of trading clipped earlier gains.

description: Dario Hidalgo, 149 pounds, of Santiago, Dominican Republic, gained a split decision over Jose Rodriguez, 154, of New York in a 10round junior middleweight fight at the Felt Forum last night.

title: FREDERIC G. COBURN
description: MARSHFIELD, Mass., Oct. 29 Frederic G. Coburn, a retired engineer who had headed several companies, died Saturday in Norwell, Mass. He was 90 years old and lived here.

title: Cairo Airport to Reopen
description: CAIRO, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Cairo airport, closed at the start of the 17day ArabIsraeli war on Oct. 6, will reopen tomorrow morning, the semiofficial Middle East News Agency reported today.

description: If you're really a fashionconscious trickortreater this Halloween, you'll snub the pretaporter number from Woolworth's or F.A.O. Schwarz. You'll go to the coutureMother or Teacher and get something exclusive.

title: 5 ExPolice Officers Plead Guilty in Shakedown Case
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)Five former police officersthree lieutenants and two sergeants pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of conspiracy and extortion by shaking down tavern operators in a nightclub district.

title: Illegal Advising of Cambodians Charged
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 29The question of whether United States Embassy personnel here are acting as military advisers to the Cambodian armed fordes, in violation of a Congressional ban, has been brought into the open again by a critical report from the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress.

title: Israeli Shop Offering Cards Thanking Nixon
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  A Jerusalem stationery shop owner is offering free greeting cards to be sent to President Nixon thanking him for his efforts on behalf of Israel.

title: Finley Uncertain On Appeal
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UPI)Charles O. Finley had second thoughts today whether he would appeal a $7,000 fine levied on him by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: Coast TV Strike Threatens Networks' Shows
description: A strike of studio technicians at the Los Angeles and Burbank facilities of the three television networks and their stations there could affect the production of a number of nationally televised shows. But for now, the shows are, proceeding as usual, according to network sources.

title: In Place of Euphoria
description: SAN FRANCISCO A useful byproduct of the recent sharp deterioration in Soviet  American relations would be another hard look at the developing pattern of MoscowWashington economic relations. The high costs of last year's massive grain sale to the Soviet Union are felt daily by every housewife who goes shopping. There could be even higher costs in the long run from today's lemminglike anxiety of some American businessmen to make massive transfers of United States technology and capital to the Soviet Union.

title: Simpson Gets 1,025th Yard as Bills Wiry
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 29 (AP)O.J. Simpson scored two touchdowns, became the first player in National Football League history to gain over 1,000 yards in seven games and broke a 39yearold record for most rushes in a game as the Buffalo Bills upset the Kansas City Chiefs, 2314, tonight.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The chief White House adviser on international economic policy said today that Congress should temporarily shelve legislation on trade benefits for the Soviet Union while Middle East negotiations were under way.

title: WARCRIMES SUSPECT RELEASED BY BOLIVIA
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct, 29 (Reuters)  Klaus Altmann, a naturalized Bolivian business man wanted in France for war crimes under the name of Klaus Barbie, was released today ofter nearly eight months in a Bolivian jail.

title: GITY CENTER FETES ITS 30TH SEASON
description: A Stravinsky Fanfare, Tom Vesley wandering on the stage as Fiorello La Guardiaand the City Center of Music and Drama's 30th Anniversary Program was on the road. Little flower's dream had blossomed into a big flower, and the work of men such as Newbold Morris and Morton Baum had borne fruit.

title: N.B.A. Stronz Point May Be Less Scoring
description: Scoring is down and there appears to be a greater emphasis on team defense as the National Basketball Association heads into the first full month of the season. There have been 74 games and of the 148 team scores, 53 have been under 100 points.

title: Paine, Webber to Report a Yearly Loss
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., will report a loss for its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1973, but it expects very good results for the current quarter.

title: Jamaica Library Reopens
description: The public library branch at 9411 217th Street in Jamaica. Queens, reopened yesterday after having been closd since January because of a fire.

title: N.A.S.D. Sets Price Charges
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., announced yesterday a temporary exception to the national newspaper listing criteria for quotations of overthecounter securities. The qualifying price requirement for issues included in the national and supplementary lists has been reduced temporarily from $5 to $3. The reduction in the price requirement does not change the basic national newspaper listing standard, which is the dollar value of volume of shares traded.

title: OILCURB SPREAD WORRIES EUROPE
description: PARIS, Oct. 29The Arab boycott of oil shipments to the Netherlands, which would curb supplies sharply in the continent's northern area, has intensified Europe's anxiety over the availability of petroleum products this winter.

title: MORENTE, SANLUCAR IN PURE FLAMENCO
description: Pure Andalusian flamenco for voice and guitar alone is seldom heard outside its native habitat, uncorrupted by stamping dancers and distracting nightclub trappings. Enrique Morente and Manolo Sanlucar brought the real thing to Tully Hall on Sunday night, allowing flamenco aficionados an unusual opportunity to savor the essence of this very subtle art.

title: Volkswagen Settles Suit Against National Lampoon
description: A $30million defamation and copyrightinfringement suit by Volkswagen against National Lampoon, a satirical magazine, was settled yesterday by an agreement that included a recall of 135,000 copies of a special issue that attempted to spoof Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 1969 Chappaquiddick accident.

Aurelio, the former Deputy Mayor who later became Presidential campaign chairman for Mayor Lindsay, raised the subject of the Mayor's Presidential campaign debt during interviews with them about their prospective appointments.

title: Peace Delegates Hear Attack by U.S. Activists on Soviet Policies
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29A blunt statement that was signed by seven Americans prominent in the activist left, including David T. Dellinger of the Chicago Seven, the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan and the Rev. Paul Mayer, was presented today to the World Peace Congress here. It condemned the Soyiet Government for a campaign to silence not only your Intellectuals, but any Soviet citizens who seek to express their rights.

title: SYRIA CAUTIONS ISRAEL OVER PACT
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 29 President Hafez alAssad of Syria said today that he had accepted a ceasefire with. Israel on the Golan heights front because of Soviet guarantees that Israel would surrender all occupied Arab territories and recognize the rights of the Palestinian people.

title: Rodino Vows Fair Impeachment Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The chairman of the Congressional committee inquiring into the possible impeachment of President Nixon pledged today to conduct a cautious, thorough and bipartisan investigation.

title: ELECTRICITY BILLS DUE TO RISE HERE
description: Consumers can expect electricbill increases ranging from 5.4 per cent in the city to 26.1 per cent in Rockland County by January, because of the Middle East crisis and rising oil prices, according to estimates released yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Fort Worth Profits From Recycling
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 29A municipal experiment in recycling old newspapers and magazines may give the city treasury a $250,000 annual profit.

title: 2 Japanese Are First Atop Everest in Autumn
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 29 (AP)A 48man Japanese expedition put two climbers atop Mount Everest in the first conquest of the world's highest peak in the dangerous autumn season, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Chile Takes Over Church School Run By Americans
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 29A school run for 30 years by the Congregation of the Holy Cross of Indiana has been taken over by the Chilean military authorities.

title: Three Killed in L. I. Crash
description: EAST NORWICH, L.I., Oct. 29 (UPI)Three persons were killed and two others injured in a threecar crash at the intersection of Routes 106 and 25A here today, the Nassau County police reported.

title: CITY DUNNING PLAN FACES AN INQUIRY
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau asked the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, yesterday to check into three private collection agencies that the Board of Estimate had approved for a new crackdown on parking ticket scofflaws.

title: U. S. Carrier Force Is Sent Toward the Indian Ocean

title: 7 Sentenced in Drug Case
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP)Six of the seven defendants in what the authorities at the time called the largest marijuana seizure case in United States history received maximum 20year sentences in Federal court here today. The seventh man got a 10year sentence.

title: 33 IN PHNOM PENH INJURED BY BLASTS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Three terrorist grenades exploded today among crowds of civilians in Phnom Penh, wounding at least 33 people, including two children, police officials said. One grenade exploded on a route later taken by President Lon Nol on his way to ceremonies at a refugee camp.

title: Hoff Elected in Vermont
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 29 (AP)  Philip Hoff a former threeterm Vermont Governor, was elected yesterday as the state Democratic Committee's new chairman, ousting the inAumbent, Leonard U. Wilson, on the first ballot, 25 to 15.

title: High School Sports
description: One Public Schools Athletic League football semifinal will be played at Memorial Field in Flushing, seating capacity 3,500, on Saturday, Nov. 10. The other is set for Midwood Field in Brooklyn, capacity 3,000, the following day.

title: Weary Foes Toe a Line Along a Street in Suez
description: SUEZ, Egypt, Oct. 29Shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon, a white dove flew over the forward Israeli line in this town and into Egyptian territory across the street. A little later a mangy mule shambled across the line, permitted by an Israeli lieutenant to rejoin his master.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE NO URGES DELAY ON RUSSIAN TRADE

title: Small Merchants Hail Brooklyn Mall
description: The discussion of an eightblock mall on Fulton Street in Brooklyn, a proposal that is already backed by major stores, and institutionsthere, wonpraise yesterday from smallbusiness managers and shopkeepers interviewed in the area. The proposal is scheduled to be announced by Mayor Lindsay on Thursday.

title: Woman Killed in Bus Crash
description: HAMBURG, Pa., Oct., 29 (AP)  The crash of a Sunday school bus and a van left one dead and 31 injured here yesterday. Bertha Barr, 73 years old, a passenger in the van, was killed.

title: JOSEPH E. SHEFFIELD
description: BEVERLY, Mass., Oct. 29Joseph Earl Sheffield, a stockbroker and former Republican fund raiser in New York, died today at his home here after a brief illness. He was 68 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Oct. 29Pete LaBarbiera, the football coach at Hasbrouck Heights High School, believes in giving his players as much responsibility as they can handle. I feel that the boys need part of the decisionmaking process to be happy and enjoy the game, he said.

description: The Warsaw Philharmonic Chamber Orchestra gave its New York concert debut in Town Hall on Sunday afternoon, the third program in this year's Peoples' Symphony Concerts series. Like so many other chamber groups that seem to proliferate and flourish these days (Town Hall was virtually full), the Warsaw musicians20 in allplay with superbly polished precision, relying on modest cues from their concertmaster and artistic director, Karol Teutsch.

description: Driving winds and pounding rains beat a daylong tattoo on the city yesterday, ending a 26day October drought with a record rainfall that flooded streets and lowlying sections, snarled traffic and drenched pedestrians.
