description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29  In the matter of David T. Dellinger, et al, case on trial, the clerk in Federal District Court announced at 10 A.M. today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Some of the city's most notorious hotels catering to single welfare recipients are operating now with dozens of empty rooms, and others have converted to new uses, but city officials say crime is still rampant in and around the welfare hotels.

title: Flounder Fishing Curbed
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 29 (AP)  The National Marine Fisheries Service said the Georges Bank fishing area would be closed for the catching of yellowtail flounder beginning Wednesday. The Federal agency said the annual catch limit of 15,000 metric tons for the area off the New England coast had bee reached.

title: Bridge: Aces Enter Final Playoffs Holding a Commanding Lead
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29America's most famous team was strongly placed here this afternoon in the final of the international playoff matches.

title: Agnew Aides Said to Seek Activists' Lawyers' Advice By JOHN KIFNER
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 Defense lawyers in the court cases of Dr. Daniel J. Ellsberg and the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan say that attorneys for former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew have sought advice from them in hopes of blocking the grand jury investigation of his financial dealings.

title: 400 Are Believed Held
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29Israeli officials said today that the continuation of the Middle East ceasefire was contingent on the early identification and release of more than 400 Israeli soldiers believed captured by Egypt and Syria.

title: SHOP TALK Designs for Whimsical Minds
description: Neal Small, the lighting and furniture designer, switched to doing sculpture a few years ago just when sculptors here and abroad were venturing into furniture design. Now Mr. Small is involved in an area that almost defies categorization.

title: Tennis Captain Named
description: Fern Lee (Peachy) Kellmeyer of Pompano Beach, Fla., a former highranking player, will captain the United States women's tennis team against Australia in the second Bonne Bell Cup matches in Sydney, Australia, Dec. 21 to 23, Walter E. Elcock, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, said yesterday. Australia, led by Mrs. Margaret Court, won the first meeting, 52.

title: Ah Cancels Rest Of Tour
description: Claiming that his fractured jaw had been hurt again in an exhibition bout on Friday in East Malaysia, Muhammad Ali canceled the remainder of his exhibition tour of the Far East and is en route to the United States for a checkup by doctors. Angelo Dundee, his trainer, said in Honolulu yesterday that All had been hit by Orlando Johnson, his sparring partner, in the same place that Ken Norton caused a fracture last March. The reinjury occurred during a bout in Kota Kinabalu.

title: Notes on People
description: Vincent L. Tofany, former commissioner of the state Department of Motor Vehicles, was elected president of the National Safety Council yesterday, replacing Howard Pyle, who retired after having servedfor 15 years in the post. Mr. Tofanys electionwas announced at the 61st annual National Safety Congress in Chicago. He said that as president of the privately supported public service organization, he would try to broaden the local and international programs of the council and aim at getting women and young people more interested in safety on the highways and in the home.

title: F.A.O. FORESEES FOOD TRADE WAR
description: ROME, Oct. 29  The Food and Agriculture Organization warned today that trade wars over farm products were looming, and that developing cowtries would come off worst.

title: Start Talking
description: For the first time in seventeen years, responsible representatives from Israel and Egypt have met face to face in formal negotiation. The meetings Sunday Egypt's eastern desert concerned only technical arrangements for humanitarian relief to the encircled Egyptian III Corps, and thus were immeasurably far from the direct political negotiations which Israel has long sought. But nearly two decades of artificial silence have in fact been broken; and Arabs and Israelis are at least making a start toward the kind of negotiations ordered by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Nixon Leaves for Retreat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  President Nixon left Washington tonight for Camp David, his retreat in the Maryland mountains. No member of his family or the White House staff accompanied him. A White House spokesman said he did not know when the President planned to return to Washington.

title: An Independent Mayor
description: A mood of deepening political frustration settles over New York City, an uneasy feeling among many citizens that their municipal government inadequately delivers essential services and that there is little, if anything, that anyone can do about it. This mood is evident in the sparse crowds that attend this year's debates among the mayoral contenders.

title: UGANDA ORDERS OUT U.S. EMBASSY GUARDS.
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 29 (AP)Uganda's military government tonight ordered United States marine guards at the American Embassy in Kampala to leave the country within 48 hours on the ground they were engaged in subversive activities.

title: Borowiak Gains in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct. 29 (AP)Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., beat Eric Deblicker of France, 06, 64, 62, in a firstround match today at the Coubertin open tennis tournament.

title: $75Million Lawsuit Filed Against Smith and Others
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 (AP)A new $75million classaction suit was filed in Federal District Court today against C. Arnholdt Smith and others involved in his troubled financial empire.

title: Cox Calls Independence Crucial for Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Archibald Cox, the former special Watergate prosecutor, said today that the case was nowhere near done and described a long pattern of frustration in attempts to get documents from the White House.

title: NIXON REPORTED TO HAVE ORDERED I.T.T. SETTLEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has told the Watergate prosecution that President Nixon personally ordered him not to press a series of antitrust actions against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to sources close to the case.

title: Program Reducing Hospital Stay of Surgical Patients Stirs Furor: It Cuts Hospital Income
description: A special program that has reduced the number of days that elective surgical patients Must stay in Bronx Municipal Hospital Center  saving time for patients and money for insurance companies  has beCome the center of a controversy because it is reducing the hospital's income.

title: Leapfrog Into Fusion
description: An offhand remark by President Nixon to a group prominent scientists the other day suggests that the White House is having belated, but quite significant, second thoughts about the highly touted breeder reactor, until recently the flagship in the Administration's drive to put nuclear energy in the nation's future.

title: Mr. Nixon's Common Fame
description: Ought Richard Nixon to be impeached? If so, for what?

title: MARINER 10 TO GET LOOK AT MERCURY
description: Mercury, the smallest and innermost planet in the solar system and the least known except for Pluto, will be the destination of the next interplanetary spacecraft scheduled for launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Liberals ReElected in Quebec, But Separatist Party Palls 29%
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 29Premier Robert Bourassa's Liberal party won a landslide victory in the Quebec parliamentary elections today, capturing more than 90 of the 110 seats in the provincial legislature.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS HEARINGS ON FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Senate Rules Committee decided today to begin public hearings Thursday on the nomination of Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan to be Vice President.

title: Saylor, Conservationist
description: For two decadesand often despite disappointment and frustrationRepresentative John Saylor, who at his death was ranking minority member of the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee, battled with good humor and tenacious spirit on behalf of the public interest.

title: The Theater: LowerVintage Bullins
description: Ed Bullins is one of the most prolific and respected cot young American playwrights. He describes himself as a playwright of black existence, and, certainly his own theater, the New Lafayette Theater, where he was associate director and where most of his plays have been performed, is specifically intended to be responsive to the needs of the black community. But once in a while Mr. Bullins comes downtown on what might be a tourist trip or a missionary foray. Here it seems his intention is to demonstrate the facts of black life to theater audiences that are predominantly white.

title: EUROPEANS IRKED BY U.S. COMPLAINT
description: LONDON, Oct. 29European officials are expressing surprise and irritation over Washington's criticism of their lack of support in the Middle East war, but they remain uncertain about just how to respond.

title: Umbrella Repairman Sees Silver Lining
description: Spinning the gaudily striped umbrella into a spiral blur, Donato Piccaninni flexed it open and closed with satisfaction. Like others freshly repaired in his little stand at Ninth Avenue and 45th Street, the umbrella had been there since before the city's 26day drought. The young woman who brought it in for treatment of a broken rib had never reclaimed it.

title: Horse Show Begins at Garden Today
description: The eightday equine extravaganza, known as the National Horse Show, will get under way officially at 10:30 this morning, when the first of the open green conformation hunters trots into the sing.

title: World Output and Trade Seen Rising Vigorously
description: GENEVA, Oct. 29  World production and trade are in period of exceptionally vigorous expansion despite the monetary upheavals, according to a study by the international agency that writes the trade rules for 99 nations.

title: 6 Are Held After Seizure Of 2 Tons of Marijuana
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UPI)Six persons were arrested and more than two tons of Mexican marijuana were confiscated today.

title: U. A. W. Begins Ratifying of Ford Contract
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30  The United Atitomobile Workers began today the ratification of a new contract with the Ford Motor Company that contains some gains over the settlement with Chrysler.

title: Kissinger Said to Express Disgust at Allies' Position
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Secretary of State Kissinger was quoted by a Congressional source today as having said he was disgusted with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the ground that its European members did not support United States policies in the Middle East crisis.

title: CONNALLY DECRIES ATTACKS ON NIXON
description: John B. Connally said last nighty that attacks on President Nixon had the smell of a vendetta and called on politicians demanding the President's impeachment to Cool it.

title: Smith and Ashe Victors In Paris Indoor Tennis
description: PARIS, Oct. 30 (AP)Stan Smith opened the defense of his French indoor tennis championship today with an easy 63, 61 secondround victory over a fellow American, Jeff Borowiak. Ilie Nastase of Rumania survived a struggle with Haroom Rahim of Pakistan, 46, 62, 97.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Starlark Hanover Trots to Her 21st Triumph
description: YONKERS, Oct. 30Starlark Hanover, a filly who wanted to be a pacer, left no doubt at Yonkers Raceway tonight about why she's the nation's best 2yearold trotter.

title: Knopf Sues Over C.I.A. Censoring of Book
description: ?? what their lawyers called the second Pentagon papers case, the authors and publisher of a forthcoming book about the Central Intelligence Agency filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to enjoin the Government from deleting roughly 10 per cent of the book's material and to halt all interference with its publication.

title: Botany and Subsidiaries Ruled Bankrupt by Court
description: PHILADELPHHIA, Oct. 30 (AP)  After 81 years as one of the most widely known producers of men's wear, Botany industries has gone bankrupt.

title: Unitarians for Impeachment
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)The Unitarian Universalist Association has urged the House of Representatives to initiate impeachment procedures against President Nixon. The loss of confidence in the Nixon Administration and the proliferating charges of high crimes and misdemeanors leveled against the President have caused a grave and threatening national crisis, the association's trustees said in a statement yesterday.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Thailand to Confiscate Wealth Of Military Leaders Who Who Fled
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 30 (AP)Thailand's new civilian Government ordered the seizure today of the fortunes of the three leaders who fled. the country after the military regime was overthrown.

title: FIREMEN SET DATE FOR ACTION ON PAY
description: The city's firefighters warned yesterday of a possible strike or other action next Monday if a new contract has not been worked out by then.

title: U.S. STEEL PROFIT SOARS BY 182.5%
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday gains in sales and net income for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. Shipments and sales set new highs for the first nine months.

title: Boston School Board to Ask for High Court Ruling on State Order to Seek Racial Balance
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30  The Boston School Committee prepared today to appeal to the Supreme Court a state court ruling ordering compliance with a Massachusetts law requiring racial balance in the city's schools.

title: Candidates Give Views
description: The four majorparty candidates for Mayor of New York City met informally at The New York Times yesterday and engaged in some pointed exchanges. Excerpts from the discpssion appear on the first page of the second section.

title: A Critic Reviews His Reviews
description: DURHAM, N. Y.  Brooks Atkinson spent a good part of his life reviewing plays on deadline, and now he is spending another good part of his life away from all that.

title: Dollar Strengthens in Europe Following Gains of U.S Trade
description: LONDON, Oct, 30 (UPI)United States dollars were in considerable demand on the European money markets today, pushing the price up everywhere. Only toward the close of dealings did demand sag and the price of the dollar come down somewhat.

title: AIR ACADEMY LOSES AS WAR FOES APPEAL
description: DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit has over turned the trespassing conviction of five antiwar activists, ruling that military officers could not bar civilians from public areas of the Air Force Academy.

title: PROSHANSKY GETS HIGH CITY U. POST
description: The City University of New York has picked Harold M. Proshansky, a professor of environmental psychology with professional ties to the university dating to 1951, as president of the Graduate School and University Center.

title: Sandman Calls Campaign Ball Game Yet to Be Won
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 30  With a verbal swipe at the wise guys and pollsters who have predicted his defeat in next week's gubernatorial election, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. told Monmouth County Republican leaders today that the ball game is still out there and will be won in the next few days.

title: Bridge: Aces, for 5th Year in a Row, Win the U.S. Championship
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 30The American representatives in 1974 world championship for the fifth straight year will be the Aces, captained by Ira Corn Jr. They scored a comfortable victory in the final playoffs here this afternoon by 90 international match points.

title: NIXON IS REBUTTED BY TV NEWS EDITOR
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 30 (AP) Bos Johnson, president of the 1,000member RadioTelevision News Director's Association, said tonight that President Nixon was wrong to blame the mood of the nation on the TV networks.

title: Ford Plans '75 Entry To MotorHome Field
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30 The Ford Motor Company said today it would go into the motorhome business, with production starting early in 1975.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS I.T.T. DISCLOSURE SHOWS COX'S BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The White House charged today that the disclosure of President Nixon's intervention in an antitrust case supported the Administration's contention that Archibald Cox had been running a partisan investigation for months before he was dismissed as special Watergate prosecutor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Marbury v. Madison (1803) is a case of unique interest to us today. In it the Supreme Court declared a law unconstitutional for the first time, thus establishing that Court's generally accepted function to rule on constitutionality.

title: Sirica to Consider Issue of Privilege Before Tape Audit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The first official steps toward moving the Watergate tape recordings out of the White House vaults toward the grand jury were taken in Federal District Court today, and it looked like a long, slow journey.

title: Nadjari Inquiry Set On Lost $130,000
description: The office of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, disclosed yesterday that it would, investigate a new twist in the tangled French Connection casean allegation that $130,000 was skimmed from a suitcase full of money taken by narcotics agents from two reputed major drug dealers.

title: What Year of Europe?
description: What the United States had envisioned as the Year of Europe, a period of imaginative updating and refurbishing of the NATO Alliance, capped with a new Atlantic Charter, has become instead the year in which Washington's relationship with its European partners has struck an alltime low.

title: WATERGATE ROLE OF C.I.A. SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30In the first formal report of a Congressional panel investigating the Watergate scandal, a House subcommittee said unanimously today that the Central Intelligence Agency had operated in a way that had no support in reason or law.

title: F.B.I. and Police Seize Fugitive In 1972 Killing in St. Louis
description: A black militant, who is appealing a conviction in St. Louis for a fatal assault on a policeman in a 1972 shootout was arrested in Brooklyn last night by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and New York City police.

title: U.S. Peace Delegates in. Soviet Oust Leader Over Statement
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30  An American antiwar activist has been forced out of his post as cochairman of the American delegation at the World Peace Congress for having criticized the Soviet Union for its attempts to silence dissidents.

title: Cox Sees Cases Periled if Nixon Retains Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Continued White House efforts to Withhold Presidential papers and tape recordings would leave a substantial number of future prosecutions in the Watergate scandal in jeopardy, the dismissed special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, contended today.

title: Flooded Roads Dry Off and Tides Recede Before Rain Begins Again
description: Flooded highways dried off, traffic slowly unsnarled itself and the high tides that had threatened shore communities returned to near normal yesterday as the metropolitan area shook off the effects of Monday's record 3.67inch rainfall.

title: Books of The Times
description: BLACK CONCEIT. By John Leonard. 254 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The White House announced that President Nixon would confer today with the Acting Foreign Minister of Egypt, Ismail Fahmy, and tomorrow with Premier Golda Meir of Israel as part of an intensified effort to overcome ceasefire problems and clear the way for ArabIsraeli negotiations. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Federal Allotments For Food Stamps To Rise in January
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) Federal food stamp allotments for most fourperson families will increase by $26 a month in January to help lowincome families cope with higher food prices, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: DUTCH ASK HELP AS ARABS CUT Off
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 30  The Dutch Government, under pressure trim an Arab ban on oil exports to the Netherlands, appealed today to other member countries of the European Common Market to share their oil supplies if necessary.

title: COPPER FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Copper and silver futures prices, weak in recent sessions, advanced quite sharply yesterday. One broker commented, It's a war market again.

title: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second end third, the third end fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50..

title: School Open After Brawl
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 30 (UPI)Classes resumed without incident today at Olympic High School, scene of a racial brawl yesterday that left about a dozen students injured.

title: The Prosecutor Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30there's little question any more that Congress will at least try to create a special prosecution office to take over the Watergate investigation. The question instead is whether Congress can do it legally  or, more precisely, whether Congress can create an effective prosecution office that is also legal. Lawyers and Congressmen are offering their guesses now, and more seem to be guessing yes than no. But even those who say yes do so reluctantly and less, than confidently, saying, as one constitutional expert put it, No one likes this.

title: Impeachment
description: The word which, so recently, could scarcely be uttered without incredulity or shudder has blossomed into an active threat to the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon. The House Judiciary Committee has started a formal impeachment inquiry, voting its chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., of New Jersey, full subpoena powers to gather evidence.

title: Kissinger Said to Express Disgust at Allies' Position
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Secretary of State Kissinger was quoted by a Congressional source today as having said he was disgusted with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the ground that its European members did not support United States policies in the Middle East crisis.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1973
description: The White House announced that President Nixon would confer today with the Acting Foreign Minister of Egypt, Ismail Fahmy, and tomorrow with Premier Golda Meir of Israel as part of an intensified effort to overcome ceasefire problems and clear the way for, ArabIsraeli negotiations. [Page 1, Column 8.].

title: Mayoral Candidates Confront the Issues  and One Another  at The Times
description: The edgiest exchanges during an informal mayoral debate at The New York Times yesterday occurred between Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democrat who is thought to be far in the lead, and Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, who ran fourth in the Democratic primary and is now the Liberal party candidate.

title: House Panel Starts Inquiry On Impeachment Question
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The House Judiciary Committee began consideration of possible impeachment of President Nixon today with a partisan dispute over the grant of broad subpoena power to its chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodin Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: NIXON WILL MEET EGYPTIAN OFFICIAL AND PREMIER MEIR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The White House announced today that President Nixon would confer tomorrow with the Acting Foreign Minister of Egypt and on Thursday with Premier Golda Meir of Israel as part of an intensified effort to overcome ceasefire problems and clear the way for ArabIsraeli negotiations.

title: Records: Roiling Work
description: Steve Reich's music has a way of getting under people's skin. Last winter in Carnegie Hall his Four Organs drove an otherwise respectable audience into a paroxysm of boos and catcalls. At the end (the music is so loud that one couldn't really hear the boos while it was going on) the hall erupted into screaming, both positive and negative.

title: 4 Seized in Mass Theft of Relief Checks
description: A ring that reportedly conspired to steal and sell hundreds of thousands of dollars in stolen welfare checks was said to have been broken yesterday with the arrest of four men, including an employe in the checkrelease section of the city's Social Services Department.

title: Woodall to Start and He'll Face Starifill
description: Al Woodall returns as the Jets' starting quarterback Sunday and when he looks over the Miami defense, staring him in the face will be No. 84Bill Stanfill.

title: Prices Off on Amex and OTC in Moderate Volume
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange tumbled yesterday in moderate trading. Some analysts attributed the drop to disappointment among investors over the failure of other banks to immediately follow the lead of the nation's two largest in reducing their prime rates. The two are the First National City Bank and the Morgan, Guaranty Trust Company.

title: Chile's Junta Tells, in 264 Pages, Why It Staged Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30Chile's military junta issued 264page report today in which it seeks to explain both here and abroad why it overthrew the Marxist coalition Government.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Superchic is out. So is supershock. Pretty is in.

title: U.S. ACCUSES HANOI OF BUILDUP IN SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The United States today accused North Vietnam of shipping vast quantities of matriel and of sending large numbers of troops into South Vietnam in violation of the Jan 28 Paris peace agreements.

title: The Stage: Medea by the Greek Art Theater
description: Something calling itself the Greek Art Theater surfaced from the wine dark sea of Off Broadway last night at the Players Theater. It opened with Euripides's Medea in the Rex Warner translation.

title: War Signals Misjudged, U.S. Officials Concede
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30United States officials said today that despite several suspicious signals, neither the United States nor Israel seriously believed at the start of October that the Arab countries were about to attack. This view began to change, they went on, when Soviet commercial airliners were diverted, some in midflight, to evacuate Soviet dependents from Egypt and Syria three days before the outbreak of the war.

title: LONG SENATE RIFT ON NOMINEE ENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Senate Finance Committee today confirmed the nomination of Helmut Sonnenfeldt as Under Secretary of the Treasury 168 days after it began hearings on the controversial White House appointment.

title: 52,000 TV Sets Recalled
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UPI) Montgomery Ward & Co. today asked owners of 52,000 color television consoles or televisionstereo combinations sold in late 1969 to request inspection for a possible defect that could create an electrical shock hazard. The affected sets include console model numbers 17321, 17341, 17351, 17420, 17430, 17440; 17450, 17620, 17640, 17650, 17920, 17940, 17950 and televisionstereo combinations with 23inch screens and model numbers 15540, 15820, 15840, and 18550.

title: Tower Urges Full Pursuit Of Trail of Watergate
description: Senator John G. Towers, Republican of Texas, a supporter of President Nixon's policies, said last night that the Watergate trail should be followed wherever it leads even into the Oval Office, The Associated Press reported.

title: DAIRY INDUSTRY AID DEFENDED BY BUTZ
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (UPI)  Nixon Administration help to the dairy industry may appear suspicious because of dairymen's campaign contributions, but the decisions were taken on valid economic grounds, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said yesterday.

title: Weinberger Vows That Government Will Not Exploit Indians' Resources
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 30Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told a convention, of American Indians here today that his department would not use Federal programs for Indians as a tool for exploiting natural resources on their reservations.

title: Bork Talks With Judge on I.T.T. Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Before he became Acting Attorney General, Robert H. Bork, who now is responsible for directing the Government's investigation of a controversial antitrust settlement in 1971 by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, met twice with a Federal judge in Hartford last year to discuss the case.

title: Rockefellers Divided On the Mayoral Place
description: While Governor Nelson Rockefeller and a brother, David, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, have contributed $5,000 each respectively to the mayoral campaigns of State Senator John J. Marchi the Republican candidate, and Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate. The Gayernor's former wife, Mary C. Rockefeller, has made a gift of $500 to Albert H. Blumenthal, the Democratic Assemblyman running on the Liberal line.

title: Lessee Will Put Exhibits In Times Square Tower
description: The Allied Chemical Tower has been taken over under a longterm lease by a private developer who plans to convert the Times Square landmark into exhibition halls on various aspects of American life.

title: Newark StarLedger Ends Election Endorsements
description: There was a time when no newspaper would have thought itself worthy of the name if it did not thunder at election time for or against a political candidate.

title: HERMAN L. FROSCH, INTERNIST, 78, DIES
description: Dr. Herman L. Frosch, a specialist in internal medicine, died at New York University Hospital on Monday. He was 78 years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.

title: LEADINGAS RULES DUE WITHIN 30 DAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would comply with a Federal Court order to reach a final decision within 30 days on regulations to limit the lead content of gasoline.

title: Church Assembly Urges an Amnesty For Draft Evaders
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (AP)The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) today endorsed amnesty for draft evaders and elected the church's first woman moderator.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Declaring that New York City's childwelfare system produces racial and religious discrimination and inadequate care for a substantial number of children, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agenci's announced its support of a suit against the system's policy of placing children in institutions of their own religious background.

title: GIRL FOUND SLAIN AT MADEIRA SCHOOL
description: McLEAN, Va., Oct. 30 (AP)A young girl was found slain on the grounds of the fashionable Madeira School near here today in what Fairfax County authorities called one of the more brutal cases we've ever seen.

title: DISMISSAL ASKED BY CHICAGO SEVEN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30Lawyers for nine persons involved in the Chicago conspiracy case asked Federal District Court Judge Edward T. Gignoux today Ito, dismiss a contemptofcourt case against them involving 152 charges of misbehavior.

title: Nixon Names an Alaskan To Head the Indian Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) President Nixon has nominated Morris Thompson of Juneau, Alaska, as Commissioner of Indian Affairs, Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, announced today.

title: Cahill Expected to Name Chief Justice by Nov. 12
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30Governor Cahill will name a successor to Chief Justice Pierre P. Garven in time for consideration by the State Senate when it returns Nov. 12, aides to the Governor said today.

title: Nadjari Inquiry Set on Stolen $130,000
description: The office of the special prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, disclosed yesterday that it would investigate a new twist in the tangled French Connection casean allegation that $130,000 was skimmed from a suitcase full of money taken by narcotics agents from two reputed major drug dealers.

title: TV: Moyers's Essay on Watergate
description: Last Friday, President Nixon, in still another of his analyses of the electronic media, complained that I have never heard or seen such outrageous, vicious, distorted reporting in 27 years of public life. . . . When people are pounded night after night with that kind of frantic, hysterical reporting, it naturally shakes their confidence.

title: Music: All Benefited
description: When the first chords of Berlioz's Benvenuto Cellini Overture sounded at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, older members of the audience turned and smiled at one another. For the first time since the move to Lincoln Center 11 years ago, the musicians of the New York Philharmonic were back in their ancestral home on West 57th Street and the people on stage seemed to relish the experience as much as their friends in the audience.

title: CAIRO EASES STAND ON P.O.W. RELEASE
description: CAIRO, Oct. 30Egypt today offered the release of Israeli prisoners of war on condition that Israeli troops withdraw to the ceasefire lines of Oct. 22.

title: P.O.W.'s Again
description: Egypt and Israel seem to be moving sensibly toward at least a limited prisoner exchange before the tempers of both sides are stretched any further on this emotional issue. Some Cairo spokesmen persist in attaching unrealistic conditions to any overall exchange but the differences on what is obviously a humanitarian concern are being discussed jointly by Israeli and Egyptian representatives. The constructive beginnings toward Middle East negotiations are still too fragile to permit any prolongation of senseless and cynical psychological ploys.

title: Stennis Says Haste Doomed Tapes Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 30 AP) Senator John C. Stennis said today that the proposed White House compromise of the Watergate tapes controversy had collapsed in part because of the hake with which this was put together at the last moment.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS I.T.T. DISCLOSURE SHOWS COX'S BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 30The White House charged today that the disclosure of President Nixon's intervention in an antitrust case supported the Administration's contention that Archibald Cox had been running a partisan investigation for months before he was dismissed as special Watergate prosecutor.

title: $20,000 Theft Foiled, Hostages Freed by the Police in Brooklyn
description: Two men who allegedly tried to force a Brooklyn usedcar dealer to withdraw $20,000 from his bank in Queens were seized by the police yesterday afternoon after the businessman told a bank officer that one of them was waiting outside in his parked Cadillac holding an automatic pistol.

title: CAIRO EASES STAND ON ROM RELEASE
description: CAlRO, Oct: 30Egypt today Offered the release of Israeli prisoners of war on Condition that israeli troops withdraw to the ceasefire lines of Oct. 22.

title: Hired Killers
description: On Oct. 21, two Arabs who said they were members of the Black September terrorist organization talked their way into the Moscow apartment of the dissident Soviet nuclear physicist, Andrei D. Sakharov. They threatened his life if he ever again made a statementas he had on Oct. 12sympathetic to Israel. As a result of Dr. Sakharov's report of the incident, friend, the Soviet writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, wrote him this letter.

title: Seaver Gets His 2d Cy Young Award
description: Baseball, which ended its playing season a week ago, opened its paying season yesterday with the first of the winter's trophies: the Cy Young Award for the outstanding pitcher in the National League to Tom Seaver of the New York gets.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: the huge New Jersey sports complex, proposed by Sonny Werblin, was to be only a 10minute drive from his warehouse. He was hoping the plans did not eventually include a golf course.

title: But Mansfield Proposes It Should Broaden Inquiry on Watergate Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Senate Watergate committee agreed this morning to try to wind up its public hearings by Thanksgiving.

title: Braves Win, Take First in Division
description: Look who's atop the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association: the Buffalo Braves. With a 105103 victory over the Seattle Sonics at Buffalo last night, the Braves took a halfgame lead over the idle Boston Celtics.

title: The Money Machinery
description: The ancient issue of where the power should reside to control the nation's money and credit lies at the heart of a bill introduced by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee. The issue of the independence of the Fed will not die although the Patman bill seems to have expired at least for this session of Congress. The Patman bill would have given the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, the obligation to tities of Federal Reserve System. These would include the Federal Reserve Board, the 12 Federal Reserve Banks and their 24 branches, the Federal Advisory Council, the Federal Open Market Committee and all clearing facilities of the system.

title: In Washington, Old Doubts Revive And There Is New Disappointment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The spirit of dtente remains alive in Washington, but the Middle East crisis has fractured some of the easy assumptions here about the value of the new relationship with the Soviet Union.

title: Candidates Give Views
description: The four majorparty candidates for Mayor of New York City met informally at The New York Times yesterday and engaged in some pointed exchanges. Excerpts from the discussion appear on the first page of the second section.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)Boston College, working upgrade its football program, announced today it would play host to the University of Texas Longhorns in a season opening game next Sept. 14.

title: Soviet Leaders Weep as Budenny Is Buried Near the Kremlin Wall
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Soviet leaders wept today over the grave of Marshal Semyon M. Budenny, Red Army hero of the Bolshevik Revolution and Civil War, who died Saturday at the age of 90.

title: NIXON'S 8TH VETO OF YEAR UPHELD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 President Nixon won his eighth consecutive veto battle of the year with Congress today as they Senate failed to override his veto of a bill authorizing funds for the United States Information Agency.

title: Owner Returning Statue to Kom
description: Aaron Furman, the New York art dealer and present owner of the sacred African statue, the AfoAKom, yesterday cabled the king of the tiny nation of Kom in Cameroon that he has decided to return the statue to its home.

title: Washington's Waiver of Privilege in Randolph Case Is Called in Conflict With Nixon Position
description: President Nixon's contention last week that every President since George Washington has tried to protect the confidentiality of Presidential conversations is rebutted, at least in part, by a longforgotten incident involving one of Washington's Cabinet officers. The official resigned in disgrace and obtained the President's permission to make public letters and conversations between the two as a means of clearing his name.

title: Hartwick Beats AdeIphi
description: ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 30, (AP)Hartwick's soccer team Allied today to beat Adelphi, 21.

title: CHILE INVESTIGATION ASKED IN DEATH OF 2
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30The United States Embassy has asked the Chilean Government to investigate the violent deaths of two Americans in the wake of last month's military takeover here.

title: Mrs. Meir Expected to Ask President to Ease Pressure for Israeli Compromises
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 30Premier Goida Meir's plan to visit the United States this week was described in official quarters today as an attempt to relieve what Israel regards as increasingly distressing American pressures to compromise Israeli interests.

title: BIG OIL COMPANIES URGE ALLOCATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The major oil companies gave the Government a gloomy assessment today of the oilsupply situation for this winter and recommended activation of an emergency industry committee to allocate foreign supplies of crude oil to United States refineries.

title: Leafs Down Wings, 70, Move Into Tie for 2d
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs aren't kidding around this season. Last year's National Hockey League's patsies whipped the Detroit Red Wings, 70, last night to move into a tie for second place in the East, a point behind the Boston Bruins.

title: Notes on People
description: Today is the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kaishek, and despite the strain in relations between his Nationalist Government and the United States in recent times, the Generalissimo had in hand a letter of congratulations from President Nixon.

title: GOVERNOR DENIES MOVING TO RIGHT
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 30 Governor Rockefeller tonight denied that he was moving to the right to court favor with Republicans nationally.

title: Clark Outpoints Hamada
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP)Johnny Clark, the European bantamweight boxing champion from Britain, outpointed Hiro Hamada of Japan in a 10round, nontitle bout tonight. Hamada weighed 119 pounds, Clark 115.

title: Woodall to Start and He'll Face Stanfill
description: Al Woodall returns as the Jets' starting quarterback Sunday and when he looks over the Miami defense, staring him in the face will be No. 84Bill Stanfill.

title: Quebec's Premier Hails His Landslide
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 30  Premier Robert Bourassa and his Liberal party today interpreted the landslide victory that they won in the provincial parliamentary elections yesterday as a repudiation of Quebec separatism. But others, noting that the separatists had gained too, took a different view.

title: State School Boards Say Critics Have a Point but Confuse Public
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 30  The annual convention of the New York State School Boards Association ended today, and the general feeling of many particpants was that while schools may not be as good as they should be, they are far better than their critics say they are.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES NEW DRUG JUDGES
description: The Legal Aid Society, on behalf of three clients facing felony drug charges in State Supreme Court, brought suit yesterday to prevent recently appointed Court of Claims judges from presiding over drug trials in Supreme Court.

title: MASS KILLER'S AIDE GIVEN EASED TERM
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30The life sentence of Caril Ann Fugate, companion of Charles Starkweather, the 1958 Nebraska mass murderer, was commuted to a 30to50years sentence today by the State Pardon Board.

title: CNA Financial Reports Its First Loss After Merger Talks End
CHILDCARE SCORED: BY PROTESTANTS
description: The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies has declared that the city's childwelfare system in its structure and in its operation does result in religious and racial discrimination and inadequate care and service for a substantial number of children.

title: Film Theater Offers Subscribers Refunds For Missing Tickets
description: Refunds are being offered to paidup subscribers who failed, to receive tickets to the series, of film versions of famous Broadway and London plays being presented by the American Film Theater during the next eight months under the coauspices of American Express Films, Inc., and the Ely Landau Organization, Inc.

title: GOVERNOR DENIES MOVING TO RIGHT
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 30 Governor Rockefeller tonight denied that he was moving to the right to court favor with Republicans nationally.

title: Indian Ocean Ships: Soviet 20, U.S. 3
description: A Soviet squadron of 20 ships, 10 of them modern and the rest auxiliaries, is operating in the Indian Ocean, according to the United States Navy.

title: The Dance: Yugoslav Folk Ensemble
description: For those who careand some of us dofor Balkan chain dances and ancient fertility rites, No Lola Ribar, the Yugoslav National Folk Ensemble, has something special to offer.

title: About New York
description: This is a story that tells something about (a) the difficulty of keeping a really good secretary, and (b) how labor and management can, if they must, work things out.

title: REJUVENATION SET ON JOBAID PROGRAM
description: The local National Alliance of Businessmen announced yesterday a rejuvenation of its program for hiring the disadvantaged with new emphasis on veterans and excriminals.

title: For the Prosecution Independence
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  On May 25, 1973, the Federal Code of Regulations which sets out the rules issued by the executive branch of Government was amended by an order giving Archibald Cox, the new special prosecutor, full authority for investigating and prosecuting offenses relating to the Watergate breakin, offenses arising out of the 1972 Presidential election and allegations involving the President, members of the White House staff or Presidential appointees.

title: Queen Elizabeth Outlines Government's Policy as Parliament Opens
description: LONDON, Oct. 30Queen Elizabeth II, with traditional pomp, opened a new session of Parliament today and told the assembled peers and commoners what my Gornment intends to do in the next 12 months.

title: Senator Hurt in Crash
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 30 (UPI)Senator J. Edward Caldwell, 46yearold minority leader of the Connecticut Senate, was in critical but stable condition today with injuries received when his auto hit an abutment on the Merritt parkway yesterday.

title: Mayoral Candidates Confront the Issuesand One Another at The Times
description: The edgiest exchanges during an informal mayoral debate at The New York Times yesterday occurred between Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democrat who is thought to be far in the lead, and Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, who ran fourth in the Democratic primary and is now the Liberal party candidate.

title: People and Business
description: In an unexpected move, William R. Roesch has resigned as chairman and president of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation to become president and chief executive officer of the Kaiser Industries Corporation. When Mr. Roesch leaves J. & L. on Jan. 1, 1974, Roscoe G. Haynie will become chairman and chief executive and Thomas C. Graham will become president and chief operating officer.

title: DOCTORS SCORED ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Doctors in some cities are cavalierly subjecting women, most of them poor and black, to surgical sterilization without explaining either potential hazards or algernate methods of birth control, the Health Research Group charged in a study released today.

title: Texans to Hear Goldwater
description: DALLAS, Oct. 30 (UPI)Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican or Arizona, will be the guest speaker Dec. 13 at a $100 a plate Welcome John Connally dinner, Republican officials said today.

title: Paper Says Gurney Had $300,000 Booster Fund
description: MIAMI, Oct. 30 (UPI)Tomorrow's Miami Herald reports that Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, used an, unreported $300,000 booster fund to defray office, travel and other expenses in 1971 and 1972.

title: Irritated House Leaders Cool to White House Move to Delay Soviet Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Top House leaders, protesting that they had not been officially notified, reacted coolly today to White House efforts to delay Congressional action on the issue of trade benefits for the Soviet Union.

title: GEORGE MITCHELL, EXPOLICE OFFICIAL
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Oct. 30  George P. Mitchell, former Deputy. Police Commissioner of New York City, died at his home here yesterday, He wits 81 years old.

title: British Riders Are 1, 2
description: Brilliant performances by Harvey Smith and Graham Fletcher paced the British Equestrian Team into a lead for the International Trophy at Madison Square Garden last night, where the National Horse Show opened an eightday run.

title: Middle East Miracle
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  In his private briefing of Congressional leaders on why he put the armed forces of the United Stafes on worldwide alert the other day, President Nixon took a decidedly pessimistic view of the Soviet Union's objectives in the Middle East.

title: MODERN MUSEUM REJECTS UNION BID
description: The Museum of Modern Art yesterday rejected an offer by its striking union of professional and administrative workers to go back to work tomorrow and to submit all disputed issues to a factfinding panel.

title: Sticky Jobless Rate
description: Despite two years of inflationary boom, there are still over four million people out of work. The jobless rate lingers at 4.8 per centwell above the 4 per cent mark that was long considered a norm for reasonably full employment. It is remarkable that unemployment remains so high when overall industrial capacity is under heavy strain.

title: Owner Returning Statue to Kom
description: Aaron Furman, the New York art dealer and present owner of the sacred African statue, the AfoAKom, yesterday cabled the king of the tiny nation of Kom in Cameroon that he has decided to return the statue to its home.

title: NIXON WILL MEET EGYPTIAN OFFICIAL AND PREMIER MEIR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The White House announced today that President Nixon would confer tomorrow with the Acting Foreign Minister of Egypt and on Thursday with Premier Golda Meir of Israel as part of an intensified effort to overcome ceasefire problems and clear the way for ArabIsraeli negotiations.

title: Jersey Rests Case In Mercy Killing
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 30  After offering two hours of testimony by nine witnesses, the prosecution rested its case today against Lester Zygmaniak, a 23yearold Monmouth County man who is charged with killing his brother with a shotgun in a local hospital last June.

title: CATHEDRAL YIELDS TO OHIO ON STOCK
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (AP)Attorneys for the state accepted yesterday a plan by the Cathedral of Tomorror to repay allegedly defrauded security holders.

title: Sirica to Consider Issue of Privilege Before Tape Audit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The first official steps toward moving they Watergate tape recordings out of the White House vaults toward the grand jury were taken in Federal District Court today, and it looked like a long, slow journey.

title: EMPLOYMENT BIAS LAID TO TRUCKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Department of Justice accused the nation's trucking industry today of practicing discrimination against blacks and SpanishAmericans.

title: Market Place:
description: What brings corporations together in merger discussions?

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Controversial Kissinger Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Testifying before the Senate Finance Committee recently on his nomination as Under Secretary of the Treasury, Helmut Sonnenfeldt remarked with a tinge of sarcasm, I may be one of the more investigated persons in this town.

title: Federalist Victory
description: Everyone expected Robert Bourassa's Liberals to win the Quebec election, but the dimensions of the 40yearold Premier's triumph are almost incredible. It appears that the Liberals will hold more than 100 of the 110 seats in the provincial legislature that Quebec calls the National Assembly. The separatist Parti Quebecois won only six, the rightwing Creditistes two and the oncepowerful National Union was shut out altogether.

title: Formal Talks on Troop Reductions in Europe Open in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Oct. 30Members of the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization formally opened their conference on troop reductions in Central Europe today, With both sides taking widely differing positions on how to reduce the forces to mutually acceptable levels.

title: ExHighway Aide Admits He Evaded U.S. Income Taxes
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30 (AP)The chief engineer of the New Jersey Highway Authority, Philip May, 53 years old, of Hamilton, pleaded guilty today to two counts of Federal income tax evasion.

title: WATERGATE ROLE OP C.I.A. SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30In the first formal report of a Congressional panel investigating the Watergate scandal, a House subcommittee said unanimously today that the Cehtral Intelligence Agency had operated in a way that had no support in reason or law.

title: The Vienna Talks in Brief
description: TITLENegotiations on the Mutual Reduction of Forces and Armaments and Associated Measures in Central Europe, still referred to informally by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as M.B.F.R. or mutual, balanced force reductions, as originally proposed by the alliance in June, 1968.

title: Nixon's Charge of Vicious Reporting On TV to Be Studied by News Council
description: For its first major case since it was established last April, the National News Council will look into and appraise President Nixon's charges that certain news reporting by television networks had been outrageous, vicious and distorted.

title: F15's 1,000th Flight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  The Air. Force's new F15 Eagle jet fighter has completed its 1,000th test flight, the Air Force announced today.

title: Japan and Australia Plan Broad Pact
description: TOKYO, Oct. 30Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia agreed today that their Governments would negotiate a wideranging new treaty to formalize, stabilize and broaden their relations.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: PARENTS BARRED AT QUEENS SCHOOL
description: The police yesterday barred parents from entering Public School 37 in Jamaica, Queens, where they have conducted improvised instruction for kinder. garten and firstgrade pupils. since classes started last month.

title: Plan to Amend Debt Ceiling Bill Spurs House Tax Reform Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 A fight in the House of Representatives over tax reform began to take shape today when the Rules Committee voted to permit reformers to attach an amendment to the pending bill on the debt ceiling but the acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee announced steps aimed at thwarting the reformers' plans.

title: Seaver Gets His 2d Cy Young Award
description: Baseball, which ended its playing season a week ago, opened its paying season yesterday with the first of the winter's trophies: the Cy Young Award for the outstanding pitcher in the National League to Tom Seaver of the New York Mets.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: SWEET VIOLIN TONE BY MISS MUHLBAUER
description: The predominant quality of Gilda Muhlbauer's violin recital Monday night in Tully Hall was lyricismwarm, singing lines backed by a sweet tone that bathed everything she played In a delicious glow.

title: House Panel Starts Inquiry On Impeachment Question
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The House Judiciary Committee began consideration of possible impeachment of President Nixon today with a partisan dispute over the grant of broad subpoena power to its chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: JAMES, C. QUINN DIES; LABOR COUNCIL AIDE
description: James C. Quinn, for more than three decades secretarytreasurer of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, died Saturday in the Irvington Nursing Home in Newark. He was 85 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N. Y.

title: Treasury Refunding Begins$2Billion of Notes Sold
description: The United States Treasury borrowed $2billion yesterday at higher interest rates than expected in a financing that wasn't snapped up with quite the verve that Wall Street had anticipated.

title: Barber Disarms Bandit, Then Slays Him in Shop
description: As two small boys and their mother watched in terror, a Brooklyn barber struggling with a holdup man, managed to wrest away a revolver and fired two shots that killed the intruder last night.

title: Relics of Columbus, Expected to Bring $20,000, Get No Bid
description: Great expectations fizzled yesterday at an auction sale as no bidders appeared for relics of Christopher Columbus contained in two crystal lockets.

title: Steel Price Rise Set
description: The Youngstown Sheet & Tube Company announced yesterday that it would follow other steel producers and raise prices of certain sheet steel products and redefine certain classes of coldrolled sheet steel to eliminate an intermediate grade. The new prices will become effective on Jan. 1.

title: Drug Education Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The House passed today and sent to the Senate a bill that would provide for continued education in the schools on the dangers of drugs and alcohol. The legislation would authorize $90million in Federal aid for school and community programs over three years. It passed on a 372to13 vote, after it was amended to include an alcoholic education program.

title: In Moscow, Mideast War Shakes Things Up Severely, but Not Fatally
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30When the SovietAmerican struggle over the Middle East reached its climax last week, a Texas oil executive here on business winced at the thought that his son, at a United States base in West Germany, might be pointing missile at him. Strange feeling, mused Charles White of Pampa, Tex., being here in Moscow during a crisis while my son was one of the men who leaped to his feet when the alarm bell rang. But after a brief reflective pause, Mr. White like hundreds of American executives at an oilandgas exhibition herewent back to negotiating with the Russians.

title: Music Talent Manager Is Jailed Ten Years for Drug Smuggling
description: NEWARK, Oct. 30  A 41yearold talent manager in the rock music industry who was convicted as a ringleader in a heroin smuggling conspiracy was sentenced today to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000 in Federal District court here.

title: Woman Dies in Harlem Fire
description: Mrs. Jennie Carroll, 75 years old, of 201 West 147th Street, in Harlem, died of smoke inhalation and burns yesterday, morning after an offduty fireman, John Gilstrap, pulled her from her secondfloor apartment to the fire escape and, applied mouthtomouth resuscitation without success. The fire was confined to the woman's apartment and there were no other injuries reported.

title: White House Officials and David Eisenhower Continue President's Attack on the News Media
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Last April, after a nationwide television address on the Watergate affair, President Nixon we, rd to the White House press briefing room and told a handful of surprised reporters and photographers still lingering there that he hoped they would give me hell every time you think I'm wrong.

title: Canucks Tie Rangers, 33, On 2 ThirdPeriod Goals
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 30The Vancouver Canucksscored twice within a 38second span in the third period tonight to overcome a twogoal deficit and gain a 33 tie with the Rangers.

title: BAR UNIT ALLEGES JUDGESHIP DEALS
description: The judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York charged yesterday that 10 candidates for State Supreme Court judgeships had violated the proprieties in resigning from their Civil Court seats after receiving party nominations for the Supreme Court.

title: 37 VIETCONG DEATHS REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (Reuters)  Government troops have reported killing 37 Vietcong soldiers in two clashes in the Mekong delta, where both sides are involved in a battle for the area's rice harvest.

title: Director of National Health Institutes Cites Political Background of Funding
description: Dr. Robert S. Stone, the director ofthe National Institutes of Health, said yesterday that allocations for scientific research and training could not and should not take place outside of a political process.

title: Lawrenceville's Coach Sticks to Single Wing
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J.Maybe it isn't significant, but the Choate School, which has replaced its singlewing system with a wingedT, is enjoying a winning football season. Lawrenceville, which sticks to the single wing, is having a .500 campaign. We aren't worried in the least, said Ken Keuffel, the Larries' seasoned coach who once starred at Princeton. Remember, we were unbeaten last year using our system. We've lost some key players. By next year, we may be booming again.

title: BAR UNIT ALLEGES JUDGESHIP DEALS
description: The judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York charged yesterday that 10 candidates for State Supreme Court judgeships had violated the proprieties In resigning from their Civil Court seats after receiving party nominations for the Supreme Court.

title: Aims Diverge at Canton Trade Fair
description: CANTON, Oct. 31An American businessman complained after a frustrating day at the trade fair here: The Chinese aren't going to make a significant impact on the American market until they change their policies on the question of labeling, make a bigger effort to meet American quality standards and agree to let major outlets have some degree of exclusivity.

title: Princeton Scores In Cross Country
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 30 (AP)Ron Vander Kraats of Princeton led his team to vic tory today in the New Jersey State College and University crosscountry championship.

title: Wholesale Raw Milk Prices Move Up to a Record High
description: The price of a quart of milk may go up by as much as 2 cents tomorrow in the New York and New Jersey area as the result of a record high wholesale price set yesterday by the regional office of the Federal Milk Market Administration.

title: Byrne Picks Up Some Votes In Noontime Walk in Newark
description: NEWARK, Oct. 30  Brendan T. Byrne collected a crowd and picked up some votes during a lunchhour walk through downtown Newark today.

title: An Electric Garage Door Produces a Gasoline Blast
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (UPI) A suburban Pittsburgh man, on his 43d birthday, suffered first and second degree burns yesterday in an explosion in his garage. Damage was estimated at $50,000 to his home, furnishings and two automobiles.

title: PRINTERS IN TRUCE WITH TWO PAPERS
description: Typographical Union 6 and The Daily News and The New York Times agreed yesterday on a truce in their contract dispute while Theodore W. Kheel, lawyer and mediator, assists in resolving differences, par ticularly over automation.

title: War Signals Misjudged, U.S. Officials Concede
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30United States officials said today that despite several suspicious signals, neither the United States nor Israel seriously believed at the start of October that the Arab countries were about to attack. This view began to change, they went on, when Soviet commercial airliners were diverted, some in midflight, to evacuate Soviet dependents from Egypt and Syria three days before the outbreak of the war.

title: Soames Bids U.S. Accept Wider E. E. C. World Role
description: Sir Christopher Soames, a top official of the European Economic Community, called here yesterday for a new relationship between the United States and the enlarged Common Market to take account of the increasing role which a unified Western Europe can and must and will play in the world.

title: NAN T. COMING
description: Nan T. Cuming, a retired nurse who was a former field representative of the Registered Nurses Guild, died yesterday in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 74 years old and lived at 208 East 88th Street.

title: Braves Win, Take First In Division
description: Look who's atop the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association the Buffalo Braves. With a 105103 victory over the Seattle Sonics at Buffalo last night, the Braves took a halfgame lead over the idle Boston Celtics.

title: Red Smith
description: The sporting world's Great LoverElect, Secretariat, makes his final New York appearance next Tuesday when he parades before an Election Day crowd after the third race at Aqueduct with Ron Turcotte in the saddle wearing the blue and white blocks of Meadow Stable. The New York Racing Association, whose leaders have the respect for money that you would expect of people named Vanderbilt, Whitney, Phipps and Mellon, are laying plans for farewell ceremonies benefitting a 3yearold who has amassed $7,396,808 in approximately 15 months. (Only $1,316,808 was earned by the sweat of of his face; you might call the other $6,080,000 ancillary income.) Soon after The Times the valedictory, probably within a week, the colt will be flown to Kentucky assume his role as the most celebrated sex symbol since Errol Flynn, or anyway Joe Namath.

title: Weekend Entertainment Suggested for Children
description: Films

title: NETWORKS ROTATING COVERAGE ON FORD
description: The three television networks have agreed to rotate live coverage of testimony before the Senate Rules Committee by Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan on his nomination to be Vice President.

title: Harvard Meets Upstarts From Penn on Saturday
description: J. Bennington Peers 3d, a regular contributor to the Harvard football program, characterized Dartmouth as one of the most offensive herds of dullards ever to invade any stadium.

title: $100 FOR WALLACE IS CALLED REGAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Federal campaign finance monitors today referred to the Justice department for possible prosecution an allegedly illegal corporate contribution to the 1972 Presidential drive of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Advertising: Aiding Consumers
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 30 Nobodynot the marketing geniuses, not the Government bureaucrats and not the strident consumeristsreally knows consumers well enough to say that they are speaking for them, according to Harold M. Williams, dean of the Graduate School of Management of the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Contract for Generators Received by Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday the receipt of a coptract valued at about $75million for two 1.2millionkilowatt nuclear turbinegenerators.

title: S.E.C. SUIT NAMES ACCOUNTING FIRM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an unusual action, filed suit today against a major accounting firm, Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., as well as against the company whose allegedly false statements the accountants certified.

title: Badillo Backs Bond Issue: Forms Group With Kheel
description: Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, yesterday endorsed the $3.5billion transportation bond issue.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)Boston College, working to upgrade its football program, announced today it would play host to the University of Texas Longhorns in a season opening game next Sept. 14.

title: Raves for Tarkenton's Play Selection
description: Fred Dryer, the Los Angeles Rams' defensive end playing good football this season, was musing about the performance of his former teammate on the Giants, Francis Tarkenton, following the RamsMinnesota game last Sunday. Dryer said: Tarkenton's play selection for the Vikings was unbelievable. He mixed things up consistently, making it impossible to guess with him. His play  action fakes were super. We took John Gilliam [the wide receiver] away from him. So he used his other receivers.

title: Stockholders Approve Merger Of Fruehauf and KelseyHayes
description: Shareholders of the Fruehauf Corporation and the KelseyHayes Company approved yesterday in separate meetings a merger under which Kelsey would become a subsidiary of Fruehauf.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STATE OCCASION Oklahoma! burst on the world in 1943, a new Rodgers and Hammerstein musical that was immediately recognized as a musical theater breakthrough and captured whatever attention that was not being diverted to World War II, which had been running even longer at the time.

title: P.O.W. PLEA BY U.N. BARRED BY SOVIET
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30  The Soviet Union blocked a move yesterday to ask Egypt, Syria and Israel to cooperate with the International Committee of the Red Cross on the matter of prisoners captured during the Middle East righting.

title: WELFARE CLIENTS CUT OVER NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  The nation's welfare rolls edged downward in the 1973 fiscal year for the first time in seven years, while the rise in expenditures slowed markedly, according to a new government report released today.

title: Vorster Preparing New Laws to Curb South Africa Press
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster is pushing ahead with the formulation of new laws to curb the South African press and has rejected a request to discuss the issue with the country's publishers' association, it was disclosed here today.

title: HENRY SCUDDER, 78; EXI.T.T. EXECUTIVE
description: Henry H. Scudder, who retired in 1969 as chairman of the International Standard Electric Company, overseas manufacturing, research, licensing and sales subsidary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died Monday at his home, 121 Bedford Road, Greenwich, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: Police Avert Leap From a Chimney
description: A 30yearold man who had been threatening to jump from a chimney atop a fivestory building was subdued by a' police officer yesterday after the two men struggled for six minutes on a ladder propped against the chimney at the edge of the building's air shaft.

title: The Hawk Takes Off, Traded to Lakers
description: Connie Hawkins, the King of the Schoolyards who fought his way out of a Brooklyn ghetto to become a basketball millionaire, moved yesterday from Phoenix to Los Angeles in the National Basketball Association.

title: F.D.I.C. Votes Delay On Rebozo's Status As Bank Executive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation voted unanimously today to defer action on Charles G. Rebozo's status as chief executive officer of the Key Biscayne Bank and Trust Company until completing an investigation in about three weeks.

title: STUDY FINDS MOST FAVOR FAST DEATH
description: An analysis of how 84 Swedish men and women want die shows that twothirds of the men and onethird of the women wanted to die suddenly or unexpectedly, according to an unusual report by the chief internist at Sweden's oldest hospital.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Wholesale Milk Price Up Again

title: China's Application In I.M.F. Is Deferred
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (Reuter)China has applied for membership of the International Monetary Fund, but the Fund's executive board has defered a decision on the application, monetary sources said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Hotise Commerce Committee overrode today Administration objections and added a $250million laborprotection package to legislation designed to salvage the bankrupt Northeast railroads.

title: $1,000,000 Penalty Levied on Teachers For Detroit Strike
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30A Wayne county court ordered the Detroit F. deration of Teachers today to pay fines and damages that could far exceed $1million for striking the school system here for six weeks.

title: BUILDING CONTRACTS EXPECTED TO RISE
description: Contracts for new construction work throughout the nation will total $101billion in 1974, or 2 per cent above this year's expected level, the McGrawHill Information Systems Company announced yesterday.

title: Sandman Strategy Held Faulty
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30Last June, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. made a decision to lie low during the first stages of the New Jersey campaign for Governor and save his political and financial resources for a final, threeweek campaign blitz.

title: 3 RIVALS FOR JUDGE DEFEND DONATIONS
description: The three candidates for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals said yesterday that they had received campaign contributions from lawyers who might some day appear before them, despite contentions that such financial support is improper.

title: People in Sports: Weaver Gibes at Award
description: Irony, rather than humility, was Earl Weaver's reaction yesterday when he discovered he had been named the American League manager of the year by The Associated Press. The Baltimore Orioles have won a division title four times in five years, but previously he never was honored and used to complain about that.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court ruled that municipal zoning authority did not include the power to limit the age of the persons who might live on land controlled by local zoning practice.

title: The Biggest Question In China
description: PEKINGThe Peking gossip mart, mainly tenanted by foreign diplomats and journalists, has recently been buzzing about a struggle in the shadow of Mao Tsetung between socalled right and leftwing factions of the Chinese Communist party.

title: Nets Bow To Spurs By 10492
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 30 (AP)Rich Jones sparked a secondhalf rally and led the San Antonio Spurs to a 10492 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Furniture: Ordering Is One Thing, Delivery Is Another
description: Last February, Theodore Draper, a historian and writer, ordered a sofa and love seat from W & J Sloane's flagship store on Fifth Avenue for his new home in Princeton, N. J. Projected delivery: last June.

title: Dayan Says U.S. Threat Forced Relief Convoys
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 30  Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that only under threat of losing vital United States arms supplies had Israel permitted relief convoys to reach 20,000 beleaguered Egyptian apldiers in Sinai.

title: Decline Is Largest Since Rally Began in September
description: The stock market, saddled by a variety of uncertainties, buckled sharply yesterday to produce the biggest single decline since the start of the strong rally in midSeptember.
